

Tabula.
HEre begins a short and abreue table on the Chronicles / and ye must
understand that in every leef of the book above is the title wherein is Pars
prima. ii.iii.iiii.v.vi. and.vii^ tylle ye come at the books end and thereby
shall ye know what matters conteyne in the table between part and part / And
so shall ye find above between pars and pars in the margyne written.

The Prologue
IN so much that it is necessary to all creatures of cry^^en relygyon / or of
false relygyon / or gentyles / and machomytes to know their prince / or
princes / that regne upon the^ and them to obey. So it is comodydus to know
their noble acts and deeds / and the cyrcu^stau^ce of their lives. Therefore in
the year of our lord. M.CCCC.lxxxiii. ye year of ye regne of king Edward ye
fourth at saint Aldons / so that all men may know ye acts namely of our noble
kings of England / is co^pyled together i^ this book / and moreover is
translated out of latin in to english / fro the beginning of the world ye
lygnage of Christ / from Adam till it be comen to Dauyd / and from Dauyd ye
kings of Israel and of Jews ye high bishops i^ their days with the Iuges
and prophets. The four pryncypall reames of ye world / that is to say of
Babylon. of Percees. of Greeks. and of Romans. And all the Emperors of Rome /
or Popes / by order / and their names. And many a notable fader with certain of
their acts As more plainly is declared in the chapter next after. And here
ben rehearsed the names of the Auctours / of whom these Chronicles ben translated
most namely. Galfridus Nunmoth monk in his book of Brute Saint Bid in ye
acts of England. I^ Bid in his book of times. Gyldas in ye acts of
Brytayne. wyllya^ Malmesbury monk in ye acts of kings of England and
bishops. Cassiderus of ye acts of Emperors and bishops. Saint Austyn de
cidei. Titus Liuius de gestis Romanorum. Martyn Penytencyary to ye pope in his
chronicles of Emperors and bishops. And namely Theobaldus Cartusien^ and
containing in his book ye progress of all notable faders from ye beginning
of the world unto our time with ye notable acts of the same. In this new
tra^slacyon are contained many notable and maruaylous things. And those ben
alleged by auctoryte of many famous clerks. And that every man may know how
these Chronicles ben ordered* ye shall understand / that this book is divided
in.vii. parts. Of the which ye first part contained from Adam till Bru^e
came in to Brytayne. The second part co^tayneth from Brute came first in to
England. unto the cite of Rome was builded by Romolus. The third part
conteyneth sith rome was b^ylded / unto C^yste was borne of over lady Mary. The
fourth from thens unto ye coming of Sa^dus in to England. The fy^^^ part
from thens unto the coming of the Danys. The syxte part from thene / unto ye
coming of ye Normans. The seventh part fro the Norma^s / unto our time.
which is under ye regne of Edward the fourth.xxiii. year / whoos noble
chronicles by custom may not (...) seen. And so in every part of these.vii.
parts ben showed ye most and necessary acts of all ye kings of England and
their names written above in ye margene / that every man may find them sone.
And before the king of Englondes acts ben written / there is written ye lygnage
of christ from Adam till that Christ was borne of our lady / with the hye
bishop and the Iu^e that were in that time / and certain of their acts
necessary / till it be common till christ was borne. And after that Christ was
borne / and Peter was Pope of rome / is showed by order the names of all the
popes and emperors of Rome / before / and after / with certeynt of their acts
breuyatly / and many other diverse things and merueyles in those men's days
falling. And it is showed every thing in his place / how many year it fell
after the beginning of ye world and how long before that Christ was borne. And
when that I come to Christ was borne then it is written / how long any thing
fell after the Natyuyte of Christ / And this is ye order of this book and the
things that been spoken of.

ANd as to men's desiring to have a very knowledge / of these chronicles or of
any other / it is necessary: to know.vi. things. The first is the states of
things / and those ben two One is fro the beginning of ye world unto Christ /
the which is called the state of Diuiacion. The secunde is from Christ to the
end of ye world / ye which is called ye state of Reconsiliacion. The second
thing is the diuisyon of times and those ben three. One is before the law of
moses / and an other is under ye law of Moses / an other is under ye law of
grace after christ dyed. The third is ye gouernynge of kingdoms. And as for
that ye must know: that al though there were four pryncypall kingdoms / that
is to say. Of Babylon / of Persces / of Grekis / and Romans. nevertheless: as
to the course of the world: and the order of holy scripture: ye first gouernyng
was under faders: from Adam unto moses. The second under Iuges from Moses
unto Saul. The third under kings: from Saul unto zorobabel. The fourth under
bishops from zorobabel unto Christ. The fourth is the dyuersyte of laws and
those were five. The first was the law of nature: and that was comen of all
men. The second is the law or the custom of gentyles: when that under king
Nyon ye people began to worship falls gods. The third is under the law
written: rose the law of Jews: wha^ ye Circu^cisyon divided ye Jews from
other people The fourth is under Christ / rose the law of christian men / when
faith and grace of the sacraments / informed ye life of men. The fyfth under
Machomete / rose the law of Sarrasyns and Turks. The fyfthe is / the
nobleness or vnnoblenesse in deeds And as to these / it is to know that.vii.
persons ben read of / whom the deeds many times are had in mind in
hystoryes. That is to wit / of a prince in his reame / of a knight in battle.
of a Judge in his place / of a bishop in the clergy / of a polytyk man in the
people of an husbonde man in the house / and of an abbot i^ his church. And of
these are written many times the lauds of good men / and the punyssheme^tes of
the cursyd men. The sixthe is ye true cou^tynge of the years and as to that it
is to be know / that there were.viii. manner of nombryng or cou^tynge of the
years. Three after the Hebrews. Three after the Grekis. One after ye Ramayns^
And one now after the christian men. The Hebrews three manner of wise begyn^eth
their year. After the Hebrews there is the year usual / beginning at January
/ the which they use i^ couenau^tes and barge^s making. And the year leyfull
beginning at March / ye which they use in their cerymonyes. And the year
Emergens from May beginning when they went from Egypt. they use in their
chronicles and calculacions. The Grekis nombreth their year three manner of wise.
First to ye glory and Joy of their victory / cou^teth their years from the
destruccyon of Troy The first / the second / the third / the fourth etc.
Then after the chyualry began at the hylle of Olympus / they notefyed ye
years after the same Olympyadu^. And what Olympyades is / ye shall know after
in ye book. The third / wha^ they began to have lordshyp of all ye world they
notefyed their years these manner of wise In ye year of the regne of Grekys
the.iiii. the.x. the: xv. etc. As it is open in ye book of Machabeorum Then^e
after the Romans gouernynge ye world / counted and nombred their years (ab vr
be condita) The last of all Christian men cou^teth their years from ye
Incarnacyon of christ And because we ben Christian men we use most to nombre /
from ye beginning of the world / unto christ was borne. And fro Christ was
borne unto our time. And this order is observed and kept in all the book / of
every thing in his place as it is said before.

Explicit Prologus.
Hic incipit Fructus temporum.
Because of this books made / to tell what time of any thing notable was.
Therefore the begynnyge of all times shortly shall be touched. For the which
after doctors it is to be known / that.iiii. things were made first / and
in one time: and of one aege. That is to wit / the heaven Imperyall / angels
nature: ye matere of ye four eleme^tes: and time. And that doctors call: the
work of the creacyon: the which was made before any day or night of the
mighty power of god. And was made of nothing. Then after follows the work
of the dyuysyon: the which was made in three of the first days in which is
showed the high wisdom of the maker. Then after follows the arayenge of
this work in the which is showed the goodness of the creature the which was
made.iii. of the next days following (Vt patz clare in te^^u gen^. primo) The
first day god made / and divided ye light from the darkness. The second day
god made: and ordained the fyrmament: and divided the water from the water. The
third day god made in the^ which he gadered ye waters in to one place: (...)
earth then appeared. The fourth day god made: in the which he ordained the
son: ye moan and the sterres and put them in the fyrmament. The fyfth day
god made: in the which he ordained fysshes and fowls: and great whales in ye
water. The sixte day god ordained: in the which he made be and man. The
seventh day god made: and in that day he rested of al works that he had
ordained / not as in werkynge being weary. But he ^eased to make mo new
creatures (Vide plura gen^.i.)

BE it known / that Adam ye first man / of whom it is written i^ this first age
next lowynge / lived.ix.C. year and.xxx. And he gate.xxxii. son^es / and as
many daughters.

Anno mundi.i. Et ante xp^i natiuitatem v.M.C.lxxxxix^ Here begins the
first aege during unto the floode of Noy Adam Eua

depiction of Adam and Eve, the Tree, and the Serpent IN the first year of the
world the syxte day / god made Adam in the field. Damasc^n^ and eua of one of
his rybbes / puttyng the^ in paradyse. And bad them to keep his commandment
yt they should not ete of ye fruit of life under ye pain of death. And ye same
day that they had sinned: anon he cast them out of paradyse in to ye land of
cursydnes that they should live there with swetynge and sorrow till they dyed
(Vide plura gen^.i.) This Adam was an holy man all the days of his life / and
great penance daily he did. And he commanded his children to live ryghtwysly.
And namely that they should avoid in all wise from the company of Cayn and his
children. Nor that they should not marye with none of the^. This man Ada^ was
our first fader. And for one syn^e he put us out of paradys. But through his
holy co^uersacyon and penance / he gave us ensample to come to the kingdom of
heaven. And he that will not follow his holy co^uersacyo^ and example / for one
syn^e ryghtwysly / he can not compain on him / as we do many. Seth sone to
Adam was borne after the beginning of ye world.C. and.xxx. years / and
lived.ix.C. and.xii. But Moses ouerskypped an hundredth of those / in the
which Abell wept in ye vale of Ploracyon nyghe Ebro^ This Seth for the oil of
mercy to be go^en / went to paradys. Delbora was sister to Abell Abell was
slain of cayn his brod. This Abell the first martyr began ye church of god.
This man after Austyn made the cytee of god / and he was ye first cytezyn of
that cite. And because that he was ryghtwyse our lord received his offering.
Calmana was sister and wife to Cayn. This Cayn was a cursed man / and he made ye
first erthely cite that ever i^ this world was in the which he put his people
for dread in so much as he vsyd caryn and vyole^ce. For he trusts such
thing to be done to him as he did to other / therefore he put him and his i^ to
a syker place. This man slew his brother Abell for envy / and he was
punysshed of god / and wandered about in a dyspayre. And after was slain of
Lamath a blind man.

MAtusale^ of Crystys line: lived.ix.C. lxix. years. This matusale was the
oldest man that ever any scrypturs has mind of For wha^ he had lived nyghe

yet thou shall live.v. hundred year. And he answered and said. For so little a
time as.v. hundred year. I will build no house But rested under trees and
hegges: and there slept / as he was wont to do for a time.

Anno mundi.M.iiii.C.liiii. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.iii.M.vii.C.xlv.
LAmeth was of aege vii. ho^dred.lxxvii. This Lameth the first against nature
and good maneres ordained that a man might have two wives / in doing his
auowtry. And he was sore punysshed of them / for they gave him many a grype For
it is so that by what thing a man sen^eth / by the same he is punysshed. This
Lameth slew Cayn wylfully not. But when he was old and blind / he was ladde
of a child ye which trowed that he had see^ a wild best and said to his
master that he should shote and so he slew Cayn. wherefore he beat the child
so sore that the child also was deed And it is to be known that al crafts /
or scye^ces lyberal or hand crafts / or of physyke seruyng to the curyosyte
of man are read that they were fostden of ye childern of Lameth and for they
dradde the peril to come of the flood and of the fire therefore Tuball graued
ye same crafts i^ two pylers. The one was of Marbyll / the other of ^yle or
brycke. Tuball found first the craft to work gold and silver / and yren.
And was ye first grauer that ever was Iabe found first Te^^oria for
shepherdes / and pauelyons for other men. Iuball found first the craft to
play upon an harp and organs and other musycall Instruments he vsid. Nocma
found first ye craft for to weue lynnen and woollen clothe / and to
drawathredes of wulle and flexe. And before that time / the people used the
skynnes of bestes for there clothes.

THe ship of Noe had in length.iii. hundred cubytes / in bread.l. in

depiction of Noah's ark THis Noe was a ryghtwys man and found grace against
god wha^ Noe was five ho^dred year of aege he had gote^ Cha^. Sem. and Iapheth
that time by ye commandment of god he began to make a ship. and he made it
parfyte in an.C. year. And the.C. year complete / our lord god appeared again
to him / and commanded him that he with his wife and his childern and ye wives
of them should enter the ship with all manner of bestes / and all manner of
fowls also. etc^. And anon the flood came / and stood above all hills xv.
cubyte (Vide plura gen^.viio) After the flood a great dronkenesse betyde unto
Noe. and through occasyo^ of that dro^kesse he blessed his two sons. Sem and
Iaphet / for the faders honor that they had to him and for ye honest shame
that they covered mekely there fader members when he was slepynge. and his sone
Cham / for his scornynge and his irreverence / he cursyd. And here after saint
Austyn is made / ye first mencyon of bou^dage / and of noblynesse contrary to
it^ For Noe said that Cha^ should be servant in bondage to Sem and Iaphet / for
his vnreuere^ce. Nevertheless ye shall not trow / that all that descended of
Cham were unnoble me^ and of no power. For they began first to be mighty men of
ye earth. As it is open of Nemroth and the king of Canaan and Ascorum. Nor all
of Sem and Iaphet were virtuous and noble and mighty me^ when almost euerche
one fell in to the crime of ydolatry / and were often times oppressed of other
men. But this blessing and this cursyng has a respect to virtue and vice /
for ye which a man is called truly a noble man or an unnoble man. For he that
is virtuous is a noble man and he that is vnuertuous is not noble. the same
manner of wise tho that follows ye faith of abraham rathar were called his
childern than ye Jews the which carnally descended from him. Nevertheless they
had a spyrytuall preuelege of god / for the faders merytes and his blessyng.
and these.iii sons oe Noe he being alive after thy story of Phil^i^s were
born.xxiiii.M. and.vii.C. me^ without wym^en and childern. And they had on the^
three princes Nemroth. Iactan. and Suphen.

SEm sone to Noe / the second year after the flood gate Arpharat / and other

Anno mu^di.ii.M.vi^C.xliii Et ante xp^i natiuitatem.ii.M.v.C.lvi.
Turris Babylonis.
PHaleg lived two.C. and.xxxix. years this phaleg was the younger sone of Heber
/ and i^ his days was made the confusyon of langages For in his hows abode the
old tongue al oule / and yt was Hebrewe. wherefore after Saint Austyn / in him
apered a great steadfastness of right wysnes For this house was free of that
pain / As not co^se^tynge to the building of the toure. (^t secundu^ Aug)
there was.lxxii. generaco^ns / and so there were.lxxii. langage. Iacta^ oder to
Phaleg Sem Nemroth prince of Cham Sulphen of Iaphet / these three princes with
there people gadred the^ to gyder in ye field of Sennaar / dredynge ye ^^ood to
come again said. Let us build a toure / of the which: ye hight shall reche to
heaven etc. Gen^. xii. Our lord saw the folysshnes of the people. Maruayllously
for ye pain of there sin / he confounded the tongue of the^. i^ so much that
none understood what an other said. And so they were disperpled and asondred by
all ye world. Of the malice of this Nemroth books ben written full And after
the co^fusyon of ye langage he went to the land of Pertees / and there he
enstrocte and taught them to doure and worship ye fire as god. And he left his
sone Belus in Babylon / the which Belus su^ceded him. And so from thens his
progenye opteyned ye kingdom / unto the time of many a year after. In this time
began many kyngdoms. and the most of those kyngdoms was the kingdom of
Scitarum. But there were so many rude and boystous people in it / that cite
was never had in worship. And it was a strong and a mighty regyon of
dystau^ce. And about this time began the kingdom of Egept / the which with
diverse and many alteracyons often times was chaunged^ also it is spoken of many
times in scripture Noblynesse or gentylmen about this said time began. And
this noblynesse or gentylmen was ordained for many causes. The first cause was
necessyte. For when makend drew sore and men were prompte and ready to do
evil. it was very necessary / to withstand the great malice of the cursyd
people / against good men There of a man is called a gentylma^ or a nobleman /
as before other in virtues notable. where of Ierom says. I see no thing else
in noblesse or i^ gentylmen bute that they are bounden in a creteyn necessyte /
that they shall not recede fro the virtue / and the gentylnesse of there noble
auncetours. The second was the diverse worshyppynge of the people. For no man
worshypt then / but as his natural reason gaaf. And they knew not
ryghtwysly what they should worship / all though they lived peasyble among
themself For they were so dull of wit / that they could pondre no great
thing / but ye was publysshed by the common people. wherefore it was expedyent
for there peace be kept that they should have princes of noble birth. The third
cause proceeds of some synguler strength. Many times the comynalte were grieved
through enmyes coming upon them. And then they said ye who someuer would
deffende and keep them from these peryles / he should have the right of
nobleness for him and his heyers for ever more and in this manner of wise many
are radde to be noble me^ The fourth cause of noblynesse / was great
haboundaunce of goods. Sometime the people we holde^ with great penury of mete
and drink. And then they took them and theyrs to some rich man / that through
that couenaunte / they s^old tempre the great straytnesse of there hungre / and
after that they should know him as their lord and a noble man. Also there be
found certain noble men by the prouysyon of god / though they were but few of
the which some abode in virtue / as Dauyd: and some failed anon: as Saull and
Jeroboam. Also it is radde: that many were noble men by tyranny and vyolence.
Of the which some were destroyed anon. And some abode in stablenesse / as
Paynymes might.

Anno mundi.ii.M.ix.C. and.v. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.ii.M.ii.C.lxxxiiii.
SAruk lynelly descended from our forn fader Adam to Abraham And Nachor was
sone / and he lived an houndred and.xlviii. year. And about this time ydolatry
began to encreace myghtely. And if ye reuolue and look the hystoryes / ye shall
find that three things pryncypally brought men to the sin of ydoly. That is
to understand. the affection which theg had to deed men. Dredde and
flaterynge against there princes. And the dylygence of artyfycers and crafty men
about scultures or grauynges. wicked fendes then entered in to ye ydollis /
and gave answers to the people And these wicked spyrytes confermed the error
of the people myghtely. In so much / that what some ever manner of person /
would not conform him to the reason / he should grievously suffer the pain of
death. Also there was added and put to these things the dysceyuynge laud and
praysynge of Poets / the which wretches and also dampened men in to heaven with
all their gaye aourned wrytynges exalted / And that same time / when
deuylles began for to speak / so fayrly and so mekely to man The good lord
of his great and abundaunt merry / sent his aungelles / That they should speak
to his elected men in vysybly / leest that all man kind should perysshe with
this myscheuous error.

BElus sone to Nemroth this time was king of Babylon. And he was ye first king
of this world / and this man was he whom the error of the people first trowed
/ should be a god / wherefore diverse people named him dyuersly. And some called
him Bell / some Baal some Baalim / some Beelphagor / and some Belsabub And this
unhappy error stood in man kind more than two.M. years. Ninus sone to Belus
the second king of Babylon of assurioru^ / reigned.liiii. years. And this
Ninus desired for to have lordshyp and worshype and to that intent that he
might be lord of all ye country about him / he gave battle to all that
dwelled nyghe about him. And by cause that time the people were rude and had
not the coming of yght ynge nor armor / anon he subdued unto him all Asiam.
And there was made the first Monarche in the eest party. And when his heart
was sorry for the death of his fader Belus / he made to be made to him for his
comfort an image of his fader. to whom he gaf so mighty reverence that what
someuer gylty man had fled to that image there should no man do unto him no
hurt / and he pardonned him of all his trespasse^ And through his ensample many
a man began to worship the deed image / of their dear friends. Then these
malycyous spyrites seeing the curyosyte of the people / hid them within them /
and gaaf answers unto the people / and said they were gods. And commanded
them to do reverence unto them as gods Thus that unhappy sin of ydolatry
was brought in / the which repugned myghtely to gods mageste. And in so
much this madness grew. that he should suffer the pain of death that said /
they were men but gods.

most notable writer of stories / and of his loving heaven and earth spekethe.
For he saw almighty god clearly face to face which in this frayl life was
never fou^den in scripture but of him and Poul thapostle Aron ye first bishop
lived a.C.xxiii. year / this Aron was called of god in to ye dignyte of the hye
priest or of a bishop and was ordened ye eternal testament to himself and to
all that come after him for the great power of presthode. wha^ he was a.C.xxiii.
year of aege / he decessed and was buried in the hylle of Hor. And his sone
Heleazarus succeeded him in ye bysshopryche. Pharao Boccaris this time was king
of Egypt / and this Pharao would not here the commandment of god / ne deliver
the childern of Israel / wherefore he was punysshed with ten plages (Vt patz
exo) And after he with all his host were drowned i^ ye red see. Nason sone to
Amynadab was prince of the trybe of Judas in the deserte / and about this time
the law of god was given in the hylle of Synay / and the book of Leuicici was
write / and another book was called Numeru^ / and the tabernacle was ordained.
The book of Deuteromanu^ was made. Balaam was prophet and was slain.

SAlmen of the line of christ was about these time / and had a wife that hight

decessed.

BOos sone to Salmon of ye line of christ was this time: but of him is little

Anno mundi.iii.M.viii.C.lxxv. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^. M.iii.xliiii.
GEdeon ye.vii. Judge of Israel was this time / this Gedeon subdued.iiii.

BOcci was bishop in Israel then. Abimalech the.viii. Judge in Israel was
natural son^e to gedeon. and he was not called of god / but malycyously took
on him the pryncehode of Israel. And he slew lxx of his brethern / wherefore he
ended his life myscheuously (Vt pz iudicu^) Tola was ye.ix. Judge in Israel. And

whom he made princes of.xxx. Cytees. And by cause they were good men and ruled
to the pleasure of god. Therefore in the days of these two men. Israel drew to
our lord. And therefore al thing came and was in prosperyte and welthe.

FAnus was the.iiii. king in ytaly and he was king of larentin both. Latinus
was king in ytaly after Fanus / and of this Latinus was called ye kingdom of
Latinorum. And Carmentes daughter of Euandri found first latin letters.
Tauranus about this time was king of Babylon or of Assiriorum / and under this
man Troy was dystroyed first. The occasyo^ of the batayl of Troy began for a
little thing In so much as Lamydon king of Troy received not Hercules and
Jason with due honor / as they should have received / and of so little a
trespaas / how many harms and hurtes grew. Sibilla delphica before the battle
of Troy prophe^yed / how a child should be borne of a vyrgyn without man's
seed. Lamydo^ king of Troy was slain / and his daughter Roxoma was taken in
to Grekys land. For ye which follows mighty battle and most ferdfull
myscheues (vide hystoria troianam) Hercules with Jason destroyed Iliu^ or Troy
ye which anon after was builded of Pryamus son^e to Lamydon. This Hercules
did many merueylous things and many mighty bataylles. And infynyte lesynges
ben feigned on him. At ye last when he had overcome much people / he was sore
hurt in war. And when he might not suffer the pain of his sore with the
which he was grieved. Himself he ran in to the fire / and when he was deed /
he was worshypped among the goods of ye Gentyles myghtely.

Circa annu^ mu^di.iii.M.ix.C.lxxv. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.M.ii.C.xxiiii.
AFter the death of Iayr Judge of Israel the people of Israel added new sins
to their old. And our lord took them in to the power of Philistiens and to
the children of Amo^ xviii. year. And they were gretely oppressed / and then
they cried to our lord. Then^e Repte was espied with almighty god / and
faught against Amon and sedycyous people of the hylle of Effraym. And for an
vnprudent voys he s^ewe his own daughter folysshly / and did sacrefyse to god

Israel was Judge.x. year. And under these times ye children of Israel were
quyete. And therefore none notable things were done in these days. Abdon

strong. And began batayl with the Greeks unto his own hurt. And he had a
son^e was called Hector a leyffull gentyl son^e by his wife Eccuba. This man
was faithful and wise and Incomparable of strength and noblenes. This Priamus
had an other son^e that was called paris ye which took away fro ye lord of
greeks helena wife to me nelaius ye king. Agamenon ye king brother to Menelaius
the leder of all the Greeks host faught against Troy / and at the last he
wanne the Cite falsely / and to the Greeks most shame and sclaunder that might
be. For certainly that might be called an unhappy battle where no man gives
loving to ye Greeks / but every man reports shame.

Eneas was king of ytaly three year. And this Eneas after Troy was destroyed
of the Greeks / that came i^to ytaly with.xx. ships and did mighty batayles
there. And this man had wedded Priamus daughter Elinsaram. And he was made a
god thrughe the error of the common people / and of this man came Julius cezar
and Octauianus augustus. Vlixes an eloquent man among all ye Greeks / after
many perils on the sea went home to his Penelopem. the most faithful and
the most chaste woman that is radde of. And the Greeks perysshed wretchedly
after that they had destroyed Troy / both on the water and on the land as
they went home ward again. And that was ye pryncypal date of their writing
after that victory. For they wrote their hystoryes and other wrytynges (sic
a^no primo. vel secu^do. etc^. post Troiam captam) And that was the third year
of abdon Judge of Israel.

Anno mundi ^iiii.M.lx^v. Et ante xp^i natiuitatem.M.C.xiiii.
IEsse sone to Obeth of the line of christ otherwise called ysay fad to dauyd
this time lived a notable man i^ honest. No king ^egrete governor. But of him
many times is made me^cyon i^ holy scripture. For of him descended christ our
savior. This time Ely was Judge and bishop of Israel the which had two sons
Ophni and Phinees. and for he corrected the^ not suffycyently / he and they
were punysshed both of our lord. For they were slain of the Philistiens. And
Ely fell of his sete and brake his neck. This Ely was Judge next after

but of ythamar / ye lygnage dured an hundred and.xx. year. In the which
lygnage Ely was first bishop / and Abiathar the last (Vide plura primo regum)

This time Saul was king in Israel after ye master in his hystoryes / and
Josephus in his ^viii. book. This Saul was first king in Israel / and
reigned.xx. year / the which or he was king was a good man and elect of god
but after ward wretchedly he failed: and he was slain and his three sons in
the hills of Gylboy In the time of Saull Samuel was Judge and prophet in
Israel / an holy man / and borne of a barayne mother many a day. And he
mynystred before our lord from a child to his aege. And was not high bishop
/ but he Iuged Israel all the days of his life. And was the very prophet of
god. Two kings he anointed. Saul first / and after Dauyd. This samuel alone /
and Moses are radde. that they prayed for their enemies in all ye old
testament. Of this samuel and Saul be diverse oppynyons. Isyder says / that
Samuel and Saul ruled Israel.xl. year. And Iosepus in his.viii book / and ye
master in his stories says. Samuel to be Judge.xii. year alone. And after him
Saul to regne.xx. year (Plura vide primo regu^)

AScanius the.vii. king of ytaly was son to Eneas / and builded the cite of
Alby^n. And he was called ye king of Albano ru^. This ascanius gate Siluius
the.viii. king of ytaly / the which Siluius was fader unto Brute king of
brytayne / now called England. And I leave of ye kings of ytaly: for they did
but little noble things / till it be comen to Romulus and Remus yt builded
Rome. And then shall those kings come again / and now to proceed to ye
chronicles of England / for the which namely this book is made. And Venes and
Padua were builded about this time / of the resydue of the Troyans. Homere the
great poet about this time was / the which wrote and feigned gloryously many
a lesynge.

Incipit regnu^ Britanie. nu^c dicitur Anglia. Here may ye se how London first
began at Albion Albion

Before that I will speak of Brute / it shall be showed how the land of
England was first named Albion / and by what encheson it was so named.

OF the noble land of Sirrie / there was a ryal king and mighty and a man of
great renown / that was called Dyoclesya^ that well and worthily him governed
and ruled through his noble cheualry. So that he conquered all the lands
about him / so that almoost all the kings of ye world to him were attendau^t.
It befell thus that this Dyoclesya^ spowsed a gentyl damoysell that was wonder
fair / that was his uncles daughter Labana. and she loved him as reason would
/ so that he gate upon her.xxxiii daughters / of the which ye eldest was
called. A bine. And these damoyselles wha^ they came unto aege became so fair
that it was wonder whereof Dyoclesyan anon let make a somonynge / and
commanded by his letters that all ye kings that held of him should come at a
certain day / as in his letters were contained to make a feast ryall. At
which day thither they came / and brought with them Admyralles princes and
dukes / and noble chyualry. The feast was ryally arrayed / and there they lived
in Joy and mirth enough / that it was wonder to wit. And it befell thus /
that Dyoclesyan thought to mary his daughters among al tho kings that were at
that solempnyte. And so they spoke and did / that Albine his eldest daughter
and al her systers rychely were married unto xxxiii. kings / that were lords
of great honor and of power at this solempnyte. And wha^ the solempnyte was
done / every king took his wife and ladde them in to their own country and
there made them queen's. And it befell thus afterward that this dame Albine
became so stout and so stern / that she told little price of her lord / and
of him had scorn and dyspyte and would not do his will / but she would have
her own will in diverse matters. And al her other systers every chone bare them
so evil against their lords that it was wonder to wit. And for as much that
the^ thought that their husbondes were not of so high parentage come as their
fad But those kings that were their lords / would have chastysen them with
fair manner upon al love and frendshyp that they should amend their
selfwylled condycyons. But all was for naught / for they did their own will in all thing that the^ lyked. and had of power. wherefore those.xxxiii. kings upon
a time and often times beat their wives. For they we^de that they would amend
their tatches. And their wickedness. But of such condycyons they were / that
for fair speech and warning / they did all ye wors / and for betynges often
times much the wors. Wherefore the king that had wedded Albine wrote the
tatches and condycyons of his wife Albine / and sent the lettre to Dyoclesyan
his fader. And when the other kings herd that Albines lord had sent a
lettre to Dyoclesyan. anon they sent letters sealed with their seals the
condycyons and tatches of their wives. when the king Dyoclesyan saw and herd
so many playntes of his daughters. He was sore ashamed ^ and became wonder
angry and wroth toward his daughters and thought. how he then^e might amend
it that they so mysdyde. And anon sent his letters unto the.xxxiii. kings
that they should come to him: and bring with them their wives euerychone at a
certain day. For he would there chastyse them of their wickedness / if he
might in any manner wise. So the kings came all at that time and day that then
was set between him and the kings. Dyoclesyan received them with much
honor / and made a solemn feast to all that were underneath his lordshyp.
And the third day after that solempnyte / the king Dyoclesyan sent after
his.xxxiii. daughters that they should come and speak with him in his chamber.
And when they were come / he spoke to them of their wyckednes and of their
cruelte and spytefully them repreued and blamed / and to them he said. That if
they would not be chastysed / they should his love lose for evermore. And when
the ladies herd all this / they became abashed and greatly ashamed. And to
their fader they said / that they would make al amends and so they departed
out of their faders chamber. And dame Albine that was the eldest sister ladde
them alto her chamber / and then made to void all that were therein so that no
person was among them but she and her systers together. Then said Albine. My
fair systers well we know that ye king our fader us has reproved shame and
despised / for because to make us obedyen^ unto our husbondes. But certes that
shall I never whiles that I live / sithe that I am come of a more higher kings
blood than mine husbonde. And when she had thus said / all her systers said
the same. And the^ said Albine well I wot fair systers that our husbondes
have co^playned unto our fader upon us wherefore he has us thus foul reproved
and despised wherefore sister my counsel is / that this night when our
husbondes ben a bid / all we with one assente for to kytte their throtes and
then we may be in peace of them And beter we now do this thing under our
faders power than other where else. And anon all the ladies consented and
granted to this counsel. And when night was comen / the lords and ladies
went to bed / And anon as their lords were a sleep / they kette all their
husbo^des throtes / and so they slew them all. when that Dyoclesyan their
fader herd of this thing / he became furyously wroth against his daughters /
And anon would them all have burnt. But all the barons and lords of Sirrie
cou^seyled not so for to do such streytnesse to his own daughters / but only
should void the land of them for ever more so that they never should come
again / and so he did. And Dyoclesyan that was their fader anon commanded
them to go in to a ship / and delivered to the^ vytaylles for half a yere^
And when this was done / all the systers went in to the ship and saylled
forth in the sea / and betoke all their friends to Apolin that was their god.
And so long they saylled in the sea / till at the last they came and arrived in
an isle / that was all wilderness. And when dame Albion was come to that land
and all her systers. This Albyne went first forth out of the ship / and said
to her other systers. For as much said she as I am the eldest sister of all
this company / and first this land has taken / and for as much as mine name
is Albine. I will that this land be called Albion / after mine own name. And
anon al her systers granted to her with a good will Tho went out all the
systers of the ship and took the land Albion as there sister called it. And
there they went up and down / and found neither manne woman / ne child /
but wild beestes of diverse kinds. And when the vytaylle were dyspended and
they failed / they fed them with herbs and fruits in the season of the year
/ and so they lived as they best might. And after that they took flesh of
diverse beestes and became wonder fat. And so they desired man's company /
and man's kind that the^ failed. And for hete they waxed wonder courageous of
kind / so that they desired more man's company than any other solace and
myrthe wha^ the devil that perceived went by diverse countrees and took a
body of ye air and liking natures shed of men / and came in to the land of
Albion / and lay by tho wym^en and shadde tho natures upon them and they
conceived / and after brought forth gyau^tes. Of ye which one was called
Gogmagog / and an other Longherigam And so they were named by diverse names /
and in this manner they came forth and were borne horrible gyau^tes in Albion
And they dwelled in caves and in hills at there will And had the land of
Albion as them lykyd / unto ye time that Brute arrived and came to Tornes that
was in the isle of Albion. And there this Brute conquered and dyscomfyted the
gyauntes abouesayde.

Explicit prima pars.
Here begins now how Brute was gotten / and how he slew first his mother /
and after his fader. And how he conquered Albion / that after he named Brytayne
after his own name that now is called England after ye name of Engyst of
Saxony. This Brute came in to Brytayne about the.xviii. year of Hely.
BE it known that in the noble cytee of great Troy / there was a noble knight
and a man of great power that was called Eneas. And when the cite of Troy was
lost and destroyed through them of Greece. This Eneas with all his meyne fled
the^s and came to Lombardy. That the^ was lord and gouernoure of ye land a
king that was called Latyne. And an other king there was that was called
Turocelyne / that strongely warred upon this king Latyne / that oftentimes
did him much harm And wha^ this king Latyne herd that Eneas was come / he
received him with much honor / and him with held for as much as he had
herd of him / and wist well that he was a noble knight and a worthy of his body
and of his deeds. This Eneas helped king Latyne i^ his war / And shortly for
to tell / so well and so worthily he did that he slew Turocelyne / and
discomfyted him and all his people. And when all this was done / king Latyne
gaaf all that land that was Turocelynes / to this noble man Eneas in marriage
with Lauyne his daughter ye most fairest creatue that any man wist. And so
they lived together in yoy^ and myrthe all the days of there lyftyme And after
Ascanius sone to Eneas wedded a wife / and upon her he gate a sone that was
called Silueyne. And this Silueyne when he could some reason of man / vnwetynge
his fader and aenst his will aqueyted him with a damoysell that was cosyn to
Lauyne that was king Latynes daughter ye queen that was Eneas wife / and
brought the damaysell with child. And when Ascanius his fader it wist / anon
let enqueyre of ye wysest masters and of ye grettest clerks / what child
the domoysell should bring forth / and they answerde and said / that she
should bring forth a sone that shalde kylle both his fader and also his
mother. And so he did. For his mother deyed in berynge of him. And when this
child was borne / his fader let call hi^ Brute And the masters said that he
should do much harm and sorrow in many diverse places / and after he should
come to great honor and worship. This king Ascanius deyed when god would / and
Silueyne his sone received the land / and made him wonderly well beloved
among his people. And so wha^ Brute that was Silueynes sone was.xv. year old
/ he went upon a day with his fader for to play and solace. And as Brute
should have shot unto an heart / his arowe myshappe and gla^ced / and so there
Brute slew his fader.

How Brute was dreuen out of the land / and how he held him in Greece.
ANd when this myschau^ce was befall all ye people of the land made sorrow
enough and were sore an angered. And for enche son there of they drove brute out
of the lord / and would not suffer him among them. And wha^ he saw that he
might not there abide / he we^ from thens in to Greece / and there he
found.vii. thousand men that were of the lygnage and kynred of Troy that were
come of great blood as the story tells / as of men and wymmen and chyldern /
the which were all hollde in thraldom and bondage of the king Pandras of
Greece / for the death of Achilles that was betrayed and slain at troy. This
brute was a wonder fair man and a strong and a huge of his age and of glad
there and semblaunt / and also worthy of body / and was well beloved among his
people. This king Pandras herd speak of his goodness and his conditions / and
anon made him dwell with him so that brute became wonder preuy and much
beloved with the king / so that long time brute dwelled with the king So at
the last they of Troy and brute spoke togyders of kynred and of lygnage and of
acquayntaunce / and there playned them unto Brute of there sorrow and of there
bondage / and of many other shames that the king Pandras had them done. And
unto brute they said upon a time. ye be a lord of our lygnage and a strong
man and a mighty ^ ye be our capytayne and lord / and gouernoure / and we will
become your men / and your commandments do in all manner of things / and
bring us out of this wretchedness and bondage / and we will fight with the
king for truth with ye grace of the great god / we shall him overcome and we
shall make you king of the land and to you do homage / and of you we shall
hold ever more. Brute had tho great pity of their bondage that they were
brought i^. And preu^ly went then from the kings court and tho them that
were of Troy / went and put them in to woods and in to mountains and them
there held. And sent unto king Pandras / that he should give them leave
sauely for to we^de out of the land / for they would no l^nger dwell in his
bondage. The king Pandras wexed tho sore anoyed and tho swore that he should
slay them euerychone / and ordained a great power and went to ward them all
for to fight. But Brute and his men ma^ly them defended and fyerfly fought and
slew all the kings men that none of them escaped / and took the king and
held him in prison / and ordained counsel bytwen them what they might done
And some said that he should be put to death / and some said that he should
be exiled out of ye land And some said / that he should be bre^te. And tho
spoke a wise kynght that was called Mempris / and said to Brute and to all tho
of Troy. if king Pandras would yield him and have his life. I counsel that he
give unto Brute that is our duke and our sovereign / his daughter Gennogen to a
wife / and in marriage with her an ho^dred ships well arrayed / and all his
tresoure of gold and silver of corn and of wine / and as much as we need to
have of ^o thing and other. and then^e go we out of this land / and ordained
us a land else where. For we neno^e of our kynred that come after us shall
never have peace in this land among them of Greece. For we have slain so many
of there knights and of other fre^des that ever more war and contake should
be among us Brute tho and all his folk consented well to that counseyll. And
this thing they told to king Pa^dras. And he for to have his life granted as
much as they axed / and anon gaf unto Brute Gennogen his daughter to wife /
and an hundred ships with asmoche / as them neded of all vytaylles / as before
was ordained Brute tho took his wife and all his men / that forsook the land
of Greece and went them unto the sea and had wind and weder at their will and
came ye third day in to an I Will that was called Lorgers. This Brute anon
sent of his men a land for to espy the manner of the country. And they
found an old cite all wasted and forlet that was there in another man ne woman
/ ne no thing dwelling / and in the mydeell of this cite they found an old
temple of a fair lady that was called Dyana the goddess. And they came again
unto Brute and told him what they had seen and found. And they counseled him
to goo and do sacrefyce unto dame Dyana / for she was wo^te to give answer of
what ever men prayed her and namely unto them that her honored with sacrefyce.
Brute went unto that yamge and said Dyana noble goddess that all thing haste
in thy might and power / wyndes / waters. woods / field / and all thing of
the world / and all manner of beestes that theryn ben. To you I make my prayer
/ that ye me counseyll and tell / where / and in what place: I shall have a
couenable dwelling for me and for my people and there I shall make in honor of
you a well fair temple and a noble / wherein ye shall always be honored / wha^
he had done his prayer. Dyana answered in this manner Brute said she go even
forth thy way over the sea in io France to ward the west / and there ye shall
find an isle that is called Albion / and that isle is be compassed all with the sea / and no man may come there in but it be by ships and in that land were
wont to dwell gyauntes / but now it is not so / but all wyldernes. And that
land is destenyed and ordained for you and for your people.

How Corin became Brutes man / and how king Goffar was dyscomfyted.
Then when Brute had this answer of Dyana the gods. Anon he let ye
ancres wind up and sailed in to the high see. And when he and his men had
saylled.xx. days and moo / they found fast besyed a cost of ye see a
thousand men of the lygnage and kynred of Troy. And there sovereign and there
master of all was called Corin^ And when Brute wyste whens they were / he tho
took them with much Joy in to his ships / and ladde them forth wiht him
These Corin there be came brutes man and to him did homage. And so long they
saylled forth in the sea till they came unto Gascoyne. And anon they arrived in
the haven of Lyegers and there they dwlled.viii. days them for to rest. and
there saylles to amend there that it was need. Tidings soon came to king
Goffar that was lord of that lord how that much people of strange land
were arrived in to his lord in ye haven of Lyegres wherefore he was sore
angreged and anoyed / that they came and arrived in his land without his
license and his leave. And anon ordened him a great power for to drive out brute
and to destroy him and all his people. But it was so that king Goffar was
dyscomfyted and all his people. And him self fled in to France / there for
help and socour. And in that time reigned in France ^xii. kings / and an.xi.
of them assembled a great power for to help Goffar and for to fight ayest
Brute. This Goffar dwelled with the^ of france half a year and more. And in
the mean time when Goffar was in France. Brute and his company destroyed all
the land of Gascoyne and let take all the tresour that king Goffar had / and
there let bring it all in to his ships And this Brute found in that land
a fayry place and couenable / and there brute made a fair castle and a
strong. when that this was done / king Goffar came from France and.xi. kings
with him and brought with him.xx.M. men for to fight with Brute and his
company and Brute had but.vii.M. and.CCC men. And nevertheless when the two
hosts met together. Brute folk thorugh help of himself: and of Turin his
cosen: and of Corin ye well and manly him defended: and fought so till that in
little time they had slain of the Frensshemen two thousand and mo. Anon
all that were alive fled away. And in this bataylle Turin Brutes cosyn was
slain. And Brute let entere him worthily when he had space and leyser in the
castle that he had made: and tho let call that same castle Toures: For by
cause of the name of Turin that there was entered. And yet unto this day there
is a noble cite that is called Toures. And king Goffar wyste that Turin was
deed he came again with his men: and after yaue a strong bataylle unto Brute.
But brute and his men were so weary for fighting: that they might no longer
endure: but to megre him and all his. And then Brute yede in to his castle
with his men: and made the gates fast for to save them: and for to take
counsel amoage them what were best for to do. Brute and Corin gaaf counsel
and ordained pryuely: that Corin should go out and busshe him i^ a wood till
on the morn so that in the morning when that Brute should fight with his
enemies: then Corin should come with his folk in the one side: and slay and
do all the harm that he might. And in a morning in the dawning of the day
Brute went out of the castle: and fyersely faughte with his enmyes: and they
manly deffended them. But within a little time Brute and his folk slew.viii.
hundred of king Goffars men. Then came Corin with ye busshement and smote to
ground he and his company all those that would stand or abide. So that the
king Goffar and his company were dysco^fyted: and fast they began to flee And
brute and Corin with there company fyersely them pursewed and slew mo of them
in ye fleing than they did in ye battle. And i^ this manner Brute had the
victory. and nevertheless brute made much sorrow for his cosyn Turi^ that there
was slain and other also that he haded lost of his men. That is to say. vii^
hundred and.xv. The which nobly he entered in the same castle of Toures /
there where he had entered Turin his cosyn.

How Brute arrived at Totnesse in the isle then called Albion / and of the
bataylle that was betwixt Corin and Gogmagog.
SO when all this was done Brute would no longer there dwell / for to fight /
nor for to lose no moo of his people. For king Goffars people might every
day encreace / mo and moo. And Brutes lossened. And therefore he took all his
men and went unto the sea and had wend and weder at their will. And the fyfth
day after they arrived in an haven at Totnesse / and came in to the isle of
Albion And there neither man nor woman as the story tells they found but
Gyau^tes. And they dwelled in hills and in caves. And Brute saw the land was
fair and at his liking. And was good also for him and for his people / as
Dyan a the goddess had him behyght. And therefore was Brute wonder glad and
let assembled upon a day all his ^ol^e to make a solemn sacrefyce and a
great feast in honor and reverence of Dyana the goddess of the which he
had counseyll first for to come in to this land. And then when that they
had there solempnyte done / as they upon a day sat at there meet / there
came in upon them.xxx gyauntes and slew of Brutes men.xxx. Brute and his men
anon street up and faught with the gyauntes and slew them euerychone except
one that was called Gogmagog. and he was master of all the Gyauntes. And he
was stronger and higher than any of other. And Brute kept him for by cause
that he should wrestyll with Corin that was Brutes man. Fo he was greter and
higher than any of bruces men from the gyrdelstede up ward. Gogmagog and Corin
undertook there for to wrestell. And so togyders they went / and wrestlyd a
long time / but at the last Gogmagog Held Corin so fast that he brake two
rybbes of h^ side wherefore Corin was sore angry. And there he took Gogmagog
betwixt his arms and cast him down upon aroche / so that Gogmagog brake all
to pieces / and so he deyed an evil death. And therefore the place is called
unto this daythe saute of Gogmagog. And then after Brute yaue all that
contree unto Corin. And there Corin called it after his name Cornewayl^. And
his men he called Cornewaylles / and so should men of tha country be called
for evermore / And in that contree dwelled Corin and his men. And they made
towns and howses / and enhabyted the land by their own will

How Brute builded London and called this land Brytayne / and Scotlonde Albyne
/ and walys Camber.
London.
depiction of London BRute and his men went forth / and saw about in diverse
places / where that they might find a good place and couenable that they might
make a Cite for him and his folk. And so at the last they came by a fair
River that is called Tamys and / there Brute began to build a fair cite / and
let call it new Troy / in mind and remembrance of the great Troy / from
the which place all there lygnage was comen. And this Brute let fell down
woods / and let eere and sow lands And also let mawe down meadows for
sustenaunce of him and of his people. And then he departed the land to them
/ so that euery^he of them had a part / and a certain place for to dwell
in. And then Brute let call this land Brytayne after his own name and
his folk he let call Brytons. And this Brute had gotten on his wife Gennogen
three sons / that were worthy of deeds. The first was called Lotrin / the
second Albanak and the third Cambar. And brute bare crown in the cytee of
Troy.xx. year after the time that the cytee was made. And there he made ye
laws that the Brytons hold / and this brute was wonderly well beloved among
all men. And Brutes sons also loved wonderly well togyder^ And when Brute had
sought all the land in length and also in bread he found a land that Joined
to Brytayne / that was in the north and that land Brute yaue to Albanak his
sone. And let call it Albanie after his name / that now is called Scotlonde.
And Brute found an other country toward the weste / and yaue that to Cambar
his other sone / and let call it Cambar after his name / and now is called
walys. And when Brute hadne reigned.xx. year as before is said / then^e he deyed
in the Cite of new Troy.

How Lotrin that was Brutes sone entered with much honor / and governed the
land well and worthily.
AFter Brute reigned Lotri^ hes sone / that was the second king in Brytayne.
The which began to regne the second year of Samuel. And this Lotrin was
crowned king with much solempnyte and glory of all the land of Brytayne.
And after when he was crowned king. Albanak and Cambar his two brethern went
again into their own country and there they lived with much honor / and
worship. And Lotri^ their brother reigned / and was king and governed it well
and wisely for he was a good man and wonderly well beloved of all his land.
And it befell so that Albanak dwelled in his own land with much honor and
worship. And then came king Humbar of Hunlonde with a grate power and aryued
in Albyne / and would have conquered the land / and began to war upon king
Albanak was slain / the people of that land fled unto Lotrin and told him
for he was king of brytayne / how that his brother was slain / and prayed him
of his help and of his socour for to avenge his brothers death. Lotrin there
anon let assemble all the Brytons of Kente / of Dover in to Dear went of
Norfolk and Southfolke / of Keftefen / and Lyndessey. And when they were
assembled they spedde them fast toward there enemies for to give them battle
And Lotrin had sent to Cambar his brother that he should come unto him with
all the power that he might make him for to help / and to he did with a good
will. And so they came togyders / and took there way pryuely for to go and seek
Humbar where they might him find. And so it befell that this Humbar was beside
a water that was a great River with his folk / him for to dysporte. And there
came Lotrin and Cambar his brother with all there people suddenly or that any of
that other wyste. And when Humber saw them come he was sore adradde / for as
much as his men wist it not before / and also they were unarmed. And anon
Humbar for dredde lepte in too the water / and drowned him self / and so he
deyed / and hes men were all slain so that none of the^ escaped. And therefore
is that water called Hu^bar / and ever more shall be for by cause that these king
Humbar therein was drowned. And after that Lotrin went to his ships and took
there gold and silver as much as he found unto him self. And all that other
pylfre he gaf unto other foke of the host. And they found in one of the
ships a fair damoysell / that was king Humbars daughter / and she was
called Estrylde^ And when Lotrin saw her / he took her with him for her
fayrnesse / And for her he was overtaken in love, and would have wedded her.
This tidings came to Corin / and anne thought to avenge him upon Lotrin. For
as much as Lotrin had made couenau^^ for to spowse Corins daughter / that was
called Guentolin. And Corin in haste went unto him unto new Troy / and thus
he said to Lotrin. Now certes said he / ye reward me full evil / for the
pains that I have suffered and had many times for Brute your fader. And
therefore sith it is so I will aue^ge me now upon you. And he drew his fawcon on
high and would have slain this Lotrin the king. But the damoysell went
between tho and made them to be accorded in this manner. That Lotrin should
wedde or spowse Guentolin that was Corins daughter / and so Lotrin did. And
netheles when that he had spowsed Guentolin Corins daughter / pryuely he came
to Estrylde / and brought her with child / and gate upon her a daughter / the
which was called Abram. And it be fell so that anon after Corin deyed / and
after when he was deed. Lotrin forsook Guentolin that was his wife / and made
Estrelde queen. And there Guentolin that was his wife went from thens all in
great ire and wrath unto Cornwayle / and there seized all the land in to her
own hand / for as much as she was her faders heir she vndetoke feautes and
homages of all the men of the land. And after ward assembled a great host
and a great power of men / for to be avenged upon Lotrin that was her lord /
and to him came and give him a strong battle and there was Lotrin her
husbonde slain and his men dyscomfyted in the v. year of his regne. Guentolin
let take Estrylde and Abram her daughter / and bound the^ bo^he hand and foot
/ and cast them both in to a water / and so they were drowned wherefore that
water was evermore after called. Abram / after the name of the da^moyseyll that
was Estryldes doughter^ And English men call that water Seuerne / And
walsshtmen call it Abram unto this day to. And when this was done Guentolin
let crown her queen of all the land / and governed the land full well and
wisely unto the time that Madan her sone that Lotrin had gotten upon her was
of.xx. year of aege that he might be king and so the queen regnd.xv. year.
And then let she crown her sone king / and he reigned and governed the
land well and worthily. And she went in to Cornewaylle / and there she
dwelled all her lives time.

How Madan reigned in peace all his life.
MAdan sone to Lotrin reigned on ye Brytons.xl. year / the which began to regne
the.xv. year of Saull. And this Madan lived in peace all his day / and got two
sons. Mempris and Maulyn. Then^e he deyed and lies at new Troy.

depicion of King David DAuyd the second king in. Israel reigned this time a

in all mankind In whom ever was found so much power and so much humylyte /

/ and so pure and devout a contemplacyon of spyrytual things / so many men to

How Mempris slew his brother Maulyn.
THis Mempris and his brother Maulyn strove fast for the land And Memprin
began to regne the.xxxv. year of Dauyd. And for by cause that he was the eldest
sone / he would have had all the land / and Maulyn would not suffer him so
that they took a day of love and accorde^ And at this day Mempris let kylle
his brother thorugh treason and him self after ward held the land. And anon
let crown him king and reigned. And after be came so lyther a man that he
destroyed within a while all the men of his land. And at the last he be came
so wicked and so leche^nus / that he forsook his own wife and used the sin
of Sodomy. wherefore almighty god was gretely dysplesed and sore wroth with
him. And upon him took vengaunce for by cause of his weckednesse. For on a day
as he went forth on hunting in a forest / there he lost all his men that
were with him and wyste not what he should do / and so he went up and down
him self allone / and cried after his men but they were gone. And there camen
wulues anon and all to drew him in pieces when he had reigned.xxiiii^
year. when his people herd that he was so deed / they made Joy and myrthe
enough and anon made Ebrac his sone king and he reigned with much honor.

Of king Leyr sone to Bladud and of the answer of his youngest daughter / that
gracyously was married to the king of France.
AFter king Bladud reigned Leyr his sone. And this Leyr made the town of
Leycetre / and let call the town after his name / and governed the town
well and nobly. This king Leyr had three daughters. The first was called
Gonorill. The second Rigan. And the third Cordeill / and the youngest daughter
was fairest and best of condycyons. The king their fader became an old man /
and would that his daughters were married or that he dyed. But first he thought
to assaye which of them loved him most and best. For she that loved him best
should best be married And he axed of ye first daughter how well she loved him.
And she answerde and said / better than her own life. Now certes said her
fader / that is great love: Then he axed the second daughter: how much she
loved him. And she said more and passing all the creatures of the world. Per
ma foy said her fader I may no more axe. And tho axed he of the third daughter
how much she loved him Certes fader said she: my systers have told you
glosynge words: but I shall tell you the crouth for I love you as I ought to
love my fader. And for to bring you more in certain how I love you. I shall
tell you. As much as ye be wroth: so shall ye be loved The king her fader
we^de that she had scorned him and be came wonder wroth: and swore by heaven and
earth she should never have good of him but hes doughts that loved him so much
should be well auau^ced and married. And the first daughter he married to Mangles
king of Scotlonde. And the second he married to hanemos earl of Cornewayle and
they ordened and spoke between the^ that ye should depart the reame between
them two after the death of king Leyr their fader. So that Cordeill his
youngest daughter should nothing have of his land. But this Cordeill was
wonder fair and of good condicyons and manners That the king of France Agampe
herd of her fame / and sent to the king Leyr her fader for to have her unto
his wife / and prayed him thereof. And king Leyr her fader sent him word that
he had departed his land and given hit al unto his two daughters before said:
and he said he had no more lord wherewith her to marye. And when Agampe the
king of france herd this a^swere / he sent anon again to Leyr and said.
That he axed nothing with her but oonly her clothing and her body. And anon
king Leyr sent her over see to the king of france. And he received her with
much worship / and with solempnyte he spowsed her / and made her queen of
France.

How king Leyr was driven out of his lord through his folk. And how Cordeill
his youngest daughter help him in his need.
THus it befell afterward / that tho two eldest daughters would not abide till
Leyr their fader was deed. But warred upon him whiles that he was on live and
did him much sorrow and shame / wherefore they took from him holy ye realm /
and between them had ordained / that one of the^ should have king Leyr to
soiourne all his life time with.lx. knights and squyres / that he might
worshypfully ride and go whether that he would and in to what country that him
lyked to play and to solace. So that Maugles king of Scotlonde had king
Leyr with him in the manner as is above said And or the other half year were
passed. Gonoril that was his eldest dought and queen of Scotlonde / was so
anoyed of him and of his people that anon she and her lord spoke together
wherefore his knights half and his squyres fro him were gone / and no moo
left with him but oonly.xxx. And when this was done / Leyr began to make much
sorrow for because that his state was empeyred. And men had of him more scorn
and dyspyte than ever they had before. wherefore he wist not what to done. And
at the last he thought he would go in to Cornewayll to Rigan his other
daughter. And when he was come / the earl and his wife that was Leyrs daughter
him welcomed / and with him made much Joy. And there he dwelled with xxx.
knights and squyres. And he had not dwelled scarsly.xii. months there / that
his daughter was weary of him and his company. And her lord and she of him had
great scorn and despyte / so that from.xxx. knights they brought unto.x.
And afterward he had but five / and so they left him no moo. Then made he
sorrow enough. and said sore weeping. Alas that ever I came in to this land
and said. yet had ye be better to have dwelled with my first daughter. And
anon he went thens to his first daughter again / but anon as she saw him
come / she swore by god and by his holy name / and by as much as she might:
that he should have no moo with him but one knight \ if he would there abide.
Then began Leyr to weep. and made much sorrow: and said then. Alas now have
I to long lived / that this sorrow and myscheyf is to me now fallen. For now
I am poor: that sometime was rich. But now have I no friend ne kynne that to
me will do any good. But when I was rich all men me honored and worshyped and
now every man ^athe of me scorn and dyspyte. And now I well wot that Cordeill
my youngest daughter said me troth / when she said. As much as I had so
much should I be loved. And all ye while that I had good: so long was I loved
and honored for my riches. But my two daughters glosed me then: and now of me
they set little price. and soth told me Cordeil: but I would not believe it ne
understand. and therefore I let her goo from as a thing that I set little
price of: and now wot I never what for to do sith my two daughters have me
thus dysceyued: that I so much loved: and now must I needs seek her that is in
an other land: that lightly I let her go from me without any reward of
gifts. And she said / that she loved me as much as she ought to love her
fader by all manner of reason And then I should have a^ed her no more. And those
that me otherwise behoteth through their falls speech: now have me desceyued. In
this manner Leyr long time began to make his moon: and at ye last he shypped
him to ye see and passed over in to France: and axed and aspyed where ye queen
might be found. And men told him where she was* and when he came to ye cite
that she was in pryuely he sent his squyre unto the queen / for to tell her
that her fader was come to her for great need. And when the squyre came to the
queen / he told her every deal of her systers from the beginning unto the
end. Cordeil ye queen anon took gold and silver plenty / and took it to the
squyre in counsel that he should go and bear it to her fader / and that he
should go in to a certain cite / and him array and wasshe / and then come
again to her. And bring with him an honest company of knights.xl. at ye
leest with their meny. And then he should send to her lord ye king / and
feyne that he were come for to speak with his daughter / and him for to se and
so he did. And when the king and the queen herd that they came: with much
honor they him received. And ye king of france then let lend through al ye
realm / and commanded that al men should be as entendau^t to king Leyr the
queen's fader in all manner of things as it were unto himself. wha^ king leyr
had dwelled there a month and more / he told to the king and to the queen
his daughter / how his two eldest daughters had him served. Agampe anon let
ordeyne a great hooste of Frensshme^ and sent in to Brytayne with Leyr ye
queen's fader for to co^quere his lord again and his kingdom. And Cordeill
also came with her fader in to Brytayne / for to have ye realm after her
faders death. And anon they went to ship and passed the sea and came in to
Brytayne and fought with ye felons / and the^ dyscomfyted and slew / and then
had he his lord again / and after lived.iii. year and held his realm i^
peace and after ward dyed. and so Cordeill his daughter then let enter him
with much honor at Leycestre

Anno mu^di.iiii.M.iii.C.xlix. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.viii.C liii.
AMasius son to Ioam reigned on the Jews.xxix. year / after the which the
kingdom of Jews was without king.xiii. year. This man worshypped ye gods of
Seyr (vt pz.ii. para.xv. Jeroboam sone to Ioam reigned on Israel.xli. year the
which was manly and vyctoryous. For he overcame the king of Sirie / and
restored Israel and Damask after the word of Iono the prophet. But he was
not good. Therefore says austyn. if good men regne / they profit many a man.
And if ylle men regne / they hurt many men^

Anno mu^di.iiii.M.iii.C.lxxxviii. Et ant xp^i natiuitate^.viii.C.xi.
Ozias or Azarias sone to Amasie reigned on the Jury.lii. year / the which
lived well before our lord / of him is none evil thing written but that he
usurped the dygnyte of preesthode under Azari / ye which he forbode him. For
yt which cause our lord stroke him with a leper (vt pz.ii. para) Ozee bishop
and prophet was this time the first of ye.xii. that is send astaynst ye.xii.
tribus. Joel ye second of ye.xii. prophesied of Judah. Ananias ye third
prophesied against many people. Abdias ye fourth of the.xii. prophesied against
Edom zacharius son^e to Jeroboam reigned in Israel.vi. months / the which
began to regne the.xxxviii. year of Ozias and was naught i^ his living as his
predycessours were. And Sellum slew him / and reigned a month. And Manahen
slew him and took his kingdom (vt pz.iiii. regu^) This Manahen reigned.x. year
/ the which began to regne the.xxxix. year of Ozias \ and he ruled him
myscheuously. And our lord took him in the power of the king of Assuriorum.
And he paid to him a thousand talentes of silver. (vt pz.iiii. regu^) Phaseia
son^e to Manahen reigned in Israel.ii. year / and he began to regne the.l. year
of Ozias: and he was naught in his living. Phase slew phaseia: and reigned.xx.
