men did (Plura vide.iiii. regu^) And after this. Israel was without any
king.viii. year

How Morgan and Conedag that were neuewes to Cordeill warred upon her. And put
her in prison.
NOw as king Leyr was deed Cordeil his youngest daughter reigned the.x. year of
Ozias king of Jury. And after her reigned Conedag the.xv. year of Ozias: and
Cordeil that was Leyrs youngest daughter after ye death of her fader had all the
land.v. year. And in ye mean time deyed her lord Agampe / hat was king of
France: and after his death she was wydowe. And there came Morgan and Conedag
that were Cordeils systers sons and to her had enuyte: for as much as their
aunte should have the land. So that between them they ordained a great power:
and upon her warred gretely. And never they rested till they had her taken and
put her unto death. And tho Morgan and Conedag seized all the land / and
departed it between them. And they held it.xii. years. And when that
those.xii. years were gone there began^e between them a great beatel / so that
they warred stro^gely togyders. And eueryche of them did other much disease.
For Morgan would have all the land from beyond Humbre that Conedag held /
But he came against him with a great power / so that Morgan durst not abide
but fled a way in to walys. And Conedag pursued him / and took him and slew
him. And tho came Conedag again and seized all the land in to his hand and
held it And reigned after.xxxiii^ year. And then he deyed and lyth at new
Troy.

And by cause the matere conteyneth most comodyously together of ye kings of
Brytayne / now called England / for ye time of them is not certainly known /
what time of ye wrolde the kings folowen reigned. Therefore they shall be
together / till it be comen unto Guentolen king of Brytayne now called England

How Reynolde that was Conedags sone reigned after his fader: and in his time it
rayned blood three days in to kenynge of great death.
ANd after this Conedag reigned Reynolde hes sone that was a wise knight and a
hardy and curteyes that well and nobly governed the land / and wonder well
made him beloved of all manner of folk. And in his time reigned blood that
lasted three days. As god would / and soon after there came a great death of
people / For hosts without nombre of people fought till that almighty god there
of took mercy and pity and tho ga^ it cesse. And this Reynolde reigned.xxii.
year and deyed and lies at york.

How Gorbodian regne in peace that was Reynoldes sone.
AFter this Reynolde that was Conedags sone / reigned Gorbodian that was this
Reynoldes sone ^xv. year / and then he deyed and lies at york.

How Gorbodian had.ii. sons and how that one slew the other for to have the
heritage / and how ydoyne there mother slew that other wherefore the land was
destroyed.
SO when this Gorbodian was deed / his two sons that he had be came stout and
proud and ever warred together for the land. And that one was called Ferres /
and that other Porres. And this Ferres would have all the land / but that
other would not suffer him. This Ferres had a felonous heart and thought through
treason to slay his brother. But pryuely he went in to France / and there
abode with the king Sywarde till upon a time when he came again / and fought
wych his brother Ferres / But full evil it happed tho / he was slain first.
when ydoyne there mother wist that Ports was deed / she made great sorrow / for
by cause that she loved him more than that other. And thought him for to slay
pryuely. And pryuely she came to her sone upon a night with two knyues and there
with kytte his throat / and ye body in to small pieces who herd ever such a
cursed mother / that slew with her own hondes her own sone And long time
after lasted the repreef and shame to the mother / that for by cause of ye one
sone she murdered the other / and so lost them both.

How four kings curtously held all Brytayne / and what were there names ye
shall here after.
AS the two brethern were deed they left not behind them another son ne
dougter / ne none other of the kynred that might have the heritage. And for as
much as the stro^gest me^ drove and descomfyted the febleit and took all there
lo^des so that i^ every country they had great ware and strife under them but
among all other thing / there were among them in the counther / that
overcame all the other / and though there might and strength they took all the
lands / and every of them took a certain country / and in his contree let
call him king / and one of the^ was called Scater / and he was king of
Soctlonde / and that other was called Dawalier / and he was king of Loegers /
and of al ye lord that was Lotris / that was Brutes sone / the third was
called Ruda^ / and he was ki^ge of walys / and the fourth was called Cloten /
and was called king of Cornewayle. But this Cloten should have had all the
land by reason for by cause that there was no man that wyste none so right an
heir as he was. But they that we strongest set little by them that were of
less estate / and therefore this Cloten had no more land among them but
Cornewaylle

Of king Donebant that was Clotens sone wanne the land.
THis Cloten had a sone that was called Donebant: that after the death of his
fader became an hardy man and a fair and a curteis so that he passed al ye
other kings of fayrenesse and of worthynesse and ano^e a he was knight he
wyste well that wha^ his fader lived he was most ryghtfull heir of all ye
land: and should have had by reason. But ye other kings that were of a much
more strength than he was: took from him his land. And after ward this
Donebant ordened him a great power and conquered first all the land of
Loegers and after he would have conquered all the land of Scotlo^de and walys.
And Scater came with his men and yaue him battle. And Rudac came again with his
walysshmen for to help him* but so it befell that Rudac was slain and also
scater in plain battle. And so Donebant had the victory: and conquered all
the land: and well mayntened it in peace and in quyete / that never before it
was so well mayntened.

How Donebant was the first king that ever bare crown of gold in Brytayne.
THis Donebant let make him a crown of gold / and wered the crown upon his
heed as never king did before / and he ordened a statute that and a man had
done never so much harm and mye come i^ to ye Temple / there should no man
him mysdo / but go there in sauete and in peace / and after go in to what land
or country that him pleased without any harm / and if any man set any ho^de
upon him He then^e should lose his life And this Doneba^t made the town of
Malmesbury / and ye town also of the Vyse. And when he had reigned well and
worthily.xl. year / then^e he deyed and lies at new Troy.

How Brenne and Belin departed between them the land after the death of
Donebant there fader. And of the war bewixt them.
ANd after that this Donebant was deed / his sons that he had departed the
land between them / as there fader had ordained so that Belin his eldest sone
had the all the land of brytayne / from Humber South ward. And his brother
Brenne had all the land from Humber unto Scotlond. But for as much that Belin
had the better part. Brenne therefore wexed wroth / and would have had more of
ye land / and belin his brother would grant him no more / wherefore co^take and
war arose among them two But Brenne the younger brother had no might ne
strength against Belin / and therefore Brenne rhrugh counsel of his folk went
from thens in to Norwaeye to ye king Olsynges / and prayed him of help and
socour for to conquer all the land upon Belin his brother upon that covenant
that he would have his daughter to wife and the king Olsynges him granted /
And Belin anon as his brod was gone to Norweye he seized in to his hand all
the land of Northoumberlonde / and took all the castelles and let them be
arrayed and kept the costs of the sea / that Brenne should not arryue in no
side / but that he were taken^ The king Olsynges let assembel a great host
/ and delivered his daughter to Brenne and all the people that he had
assembled. And this damoysell Samie had long time loved a king that was
called Gutlagh and to him she told all her counsel / how that Bren^e should
her have / and her led with him for ever more and so he should lose her but
that she might for sake Brenne. And when Gutlagh had herd this tidings / he
lay for to aspye Bren^e with as many ships as he might have. So the two
fletes met together and long time they faught / so that Brennes men turned
again were dyscomfyted. And king Gutlagh took Samie and put her in to his
ship. And Bre^ne shamefully fled thens as a man dyscomfyted. And this king
Gutlagh would have gone in to his owene country / but there came upon him such
a great tempest that five days lasted / so that thorugh that tempest he was
driven in to Brytayne with three ships and no moo / and tho that kept the
costs of the sea took Gutlagh and Samie and all his folk and them presented
to Belin And Belin put them in prison.

How Belin drove out of his land king Gutlagh of Denmerk and Samie.
IT was not long after that Brenne came again with a great navy / and sent to
his brother Belin / that he should yield again his land to his wife and his folk
/ and his castelles also. Or else he would destroy his land. Belin dradde
no thing his malice / and would no thing do after that he had said.
wherefore Brenne came with his folk and fought with Beline. And then Brenne
was discomfyted and his folk slain / and him self fled wi^h.xii. men in to
France. And this Belin that was Brenne brother went thenue to. york / and
took counsel what he should do with king Gutlagh. For king Gutlagh proferde
to become his man / and for to hold his land fo him yeldynge yearly.M.li. of
silver for evermore / and for surenesse of this couenaut to be kept Gutlagh
sho^de bring him good hostage / and to him should do homage and his folk /
and yet he should swear upon a book yt it should never be broke ne failed.
Belin tho by counseyll of his folk granted him his axenge / and so Gutlagh be
came his man and Belin undertook of him his homage by an oath and by writing
the same couenau^tes. And upon these couenau^tes king Gutlagh took Samie and
his folk and went thens / and turned again to Denmak. Ever more after were the
couenau^tes holden and the treuage paid till the time that Honelus was king of
Denmark and also of his land thorugh his wife Gildebu^h that he had spoused for
she was ryghe heir of his land. This Belin dwelled tho in peace / and worship
fully him held among his barons / and he made four ryall ways / one from
the eest in to the weest and that was called watlynge street / and an other
from the north unto the south / and that is callen Ikelme street. And two
other ways he made in bossynge through out ye lord that one is called fosse
and that other Fosse dyke. And he mayntened well the good laws that Donebant
his fader had made. and ordained in his time / as before is said.

How acordeme^t was made between Bre^ne and Belin thorugh Cornewen there mother.
BRenne that was Belins brother had long time dwelled in France / and there
had conquered a great lordshyp through marriage. For he was duke of Bourgoyne
through the dought of the duke fewyn that he had spoused that was right heir of
the land. And this Brenne ordened a great power of his folk / and also of
France / and came in to this land for to fight with Belin his brother. And
belin came ayenste him with a great power of Brytons / and would tho have yeuen
him battle. But there mother Cornewen that tho lived had that one brother would
have destroyed that other and went between her sons and them made acorde with
much pain So that at the last tho two brethern with much bliss went
together in to new Troy / that now is called London / and there they dwelled a
year. And after they took their counseyll for to goo and conquer all France.
And so they did / and burnt town and destroyed the land both in length and
in bread. And the king of France yaue them batayl with his power / but he was
overcome / and yaue trauge unto Belin and to his brother. And after that they
went forth unto Rome ^ conquered Rome and all Lombardy and Garmany / and took
humage and feaute of earls bacons and of all other. And after they came in to
this land of brytayne / and dwelled there with brytons in Joy and rest. And
tho made brenne the twone of brystowe / and after he went over to his own
lordshyp / and their dwelled he all his life And belin dwelled at new Troy and
there he made a fair gate that is called belynges gate after his own name.
And when this belin had reigned nobly.xi. year he deyed and lies at new Troy.

How king Cormbratus slew the king Cenmark / for by cause that he would not
pay his truage as he should
ANd after this belin reigned his sone Cormbratus a good man and a worthy. And
the king of Denmark would not pay to him his truage that is to say a thousand
pound as he had sworn by oath for to pay it / and also by writing record
to belin his fader. wherefore he was evil appayed and wroth / and assembled a
great host of bry^ons and went in to Denmark and slew the king Gutlagh /
and brought the land in subgec^ion all new. And took of the folk feautes and
homage / and after went ayene in to his own land. And as he came fothe by
Orkeney / he found.xxx. ships full of men and wymmen beside the cost of the sea. and the king ared what they were. And an Earl that was master of them
all curteysly answered unto the king and said. That they were exieled out of
Spane / and so that they had traueyled half an year and more in the sea / to
wit if they might find any king in any land that of them would have pity or
mercy to give them any lord in any country where in they might dwuell and
hauerest / and become his lyege men / and to him would do homage and feuate
while that he lived / and to his heyers after him / and of him and of his
heirs hold that land. And when ye king this herd / he had pity of him /
and yaue them an yel all wilderness / there that no man was dwelling sauf
oonly wild bestes. And the Earl thanked much the king and became his man and
did him homage and feaute and took all his folk and went in to the same isle.
And the Earl was called Irlamall / and therefore he let call the land Irlonde
after his own name. This king Cormbratus came again in to his land and
reigned.xxv. year / and after he deyed and lies at new Troy.

Anno mu^di.iiii^M.iiii.C.xl. Et ante xp^i natiuitatem.vii.C.lvi.
IOathan sone to Osias reigned in ye Jury.xvi. year / of this Ioathan no thing
is written of / but that he took not away excelsa as other did) vt pz.ii.
para) Amarias was bishop. And ysayas the noble prophet was in his days.
Olympias with the Greeks began the first year of Ioathan after Josephus. And
after Beda Troy was destroyed four hundred year before the first Olympias
began under Esalo a Judge of Athens. In which Coribus gate ye chyualry among
all men Olympus is the name of an hylle in Grecia / the which for his
precyousnesse is called the hylle of god^ And after Ierom one Olympias
conteyneth fully four year / in the which four year / four yearly princes
are made. And these Olympiades are places ordained tothe worship of Iupater
under the hylle of Olympo. And the law of this. That who someuer is best in
any chyualry / what someuer he desires he shall have.

Anno mu^di.iiii.M.iiii.C.lvi. Et ante xp^i natiuitetem.vii.C.xliii.
ACham the sone of Ioathan reigned on the Jews.xvi. year of this Acham no
thing that is good is wryte^ for he forsook our lord. And our lord stroke
him with his own people strongly / and with the kings of Tirri (vt pz.ii.
para. xx viii.) Achicob this time was bishop. Ozee king of Israel reigned
^ix. year the which began to regne the.xii. year of Acham king of Jews.
This Ozee dradde not god / for he lived naught. And he was the last king of
Israell^ And in the.ix. year of his regne he was taken of Salmanasar. And
Israel was translated in to Assirias (vt habetur.iiii. regum.xvii.)

Anno mundi.iiii.M.iiii.C.lxii. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.vii.C.xl.
Rome.
depiction of Rome AFter Euseby Rome was made in the hyl of Palatin the fourth
year of Acha^ king of Jews of two brethern Romulus and Remus.xi. Kal. Man.
the.vii. Olympiades beginning. Josephus and Beda sayen the.vi. Olympiades /
and so they defferre a year. Nevertheless it is read other men to have reigned
about that place myghtly in ytaly. That is to wit Ianus. Picus Famus. Latinus
/ the which unto Eneas reigned about two hundred year. And then after ward
from this Eneas to Romulus / it was reigned under.xv. governors.iiii.C.xxxii.
year. After that fro the Cytee was made unto the last year of Tarquyne yt
proud / it was reigned vnd.vii. kings about two hundred and.xliii. yere^
Then^e after ward under Senators and Counsullers / unto Julius Cezar Emperor
/ by four hundred.lxiiii. year. Romulus the first of Romans / of whom they
ben called in latin Romans / made the cite to be named Rome after his name. The
which gadred together the people on every side an.C. of the sage men and wyseste
he chose / the counsel of whom all thing he dysposed / the which he named
Senators for ye time of their aege. And he made their names to be written in
golden letters / wherefore we write noble faders and things so yet. Also he
called.M. men of arms the which he named Milites (a numero mi^i^to) But these
were noble blod. Therefore as saint Austyn says (de ciuit^. dei) And also there
was long war betwixt the Sabyns and them. For Romulis took many wymmen of
the noble blood of Sabyns / and married them to that unnoble blood. Of this
Romulus Orosyus writes much evil (Vt patet in libro suo) About this time
Merodach the king of Babylon send great gyftis to Ezechie the kyge of Jews
(vt pz.iiii. regu^.xx.) And then^e the kingdom of Babylon begone.

Anno mundi.iiii.M.lxxii. Et ante xp^i natiuitatem.vii.C^xxvii.
Ezechias the.xiiii. king of Jews a good child of a cursyd fader reigned with
a partyte heart to our lord. And he restored the house of god / and there was
none like him before nor after among the kings of Jews / therefore our lord
god gloriyed him. For when Senancheryb the king of Assuriorum came ayenste
Ezechias with a mighty host / our lord stroke his people and slew an
^C.lxxxv. of fighting men / and Sennacheryb fled shamfully (vt pz.iiii.
regum.ix. et.ii. para.xxxii.) Sadoch this time was high bishop there.

Anno mundi.iiii.M.v.C.i. Et ante xpi natiuitotem.vi.C^lxxxxviii.
MAnasses king of Jews reigned.lv. year / and he was an evil child of a good
fader / for he did more cursedly than any that was before him. For he slew the
prophets of god / that the streets in Jerusalem were al blody. And he made
ysai the prophet to be sawen the pieces with a saw of tree. wherefore ye king
of Assuriorum wasted the Jury / and took Manasses ^ put him in prison. And
after Manasses repented his trespaas and cried for mercy to our lord / and was
herd. Then he was restored to his kingdom / and he amended his life) vt

Incipit monarchia Persarum.
Darius uncle to Ciro. fellow in ye kingdom with Ciro translated the kingdoms
of Babylon Caldees in to the kingdom of Persarum and Medorum Cirus was
emperor.xxx. year This Cyrus held the monarche hole at Perses. Of this man
prophesied ysayas / and he destroyed Babylon: and slew Balthazar king of
Babylon / and he worshyped greatly danyel ye Jews he send home again that they
should build the Temple of god (Vt pz Esdre prio) Babylon that strong castle
was destroyed and hes power was take from him as it was prophesied. This was
the first cite and the gretest of all the world / of ye which Incredyble
things are written / and this that was so strong i^ one night was destroyed /
that it might be showed to ye power of god / to the which power all other ben
but a sperke and duste. For it is said forsooth: that it was Incredyble to be
made with man's ho^de or to be destroyed with man's strength whereof all the
world might take an ensample and it would or might be enfourmed. Tarquinus
Superbus was the.vii. king of Rome / and he reigned.xxxv. year. This man
concyued first all the torments which are ordryned for malefactors. As exile
/ prison / wells / and galowes feters and manacles / chains and colous and
such other* And for his great pride and cruelnes god suffered him to myschyef
and in what manner of wise it shall be showed. He had a sone of the same name /
ye which defoyled a worthy man's wife / they called him Collatin and his wife
was called Lucres. This Tarquinus that was this.vii. kings sone aforesaid
came unto the ladies house absente her husbonde to supper and to lodgyng And
when all were a sleep he a rose with a sword in his hand and with strength
and fere he rauysshed the woman. And when he was gone ye nere day after / she
send unto her fader and to her husbonde / for she was of great kynne / and
thus she said to them. The kings sone came hither and as friend / of whom* I
had no mystrust and thus he has defoylled my chastyce and lost my name for
evermore. Then her friends saw her weep and pytously complained and they
comforted her as well as they could and said it was no vylany unto her for it
was against her will. She answered and said yet shall there never woman excuse
her by Lucres / For though she consented not to this did yet shall she not dye
without pain for that deed. And with that word she had a knyf ready under her
mantell / with the which she smote herself to the here and for this cruelnes
and this pyteous death the people of rome arose and exiled ye king for ever more
and all his progenye. And thus seized these kings of Rome and never was none
after.

Of the governance of Rome till the Emperors began.
AFter this tyraunte was deed the Romans ordened that their sho^de never be
king more in Rome. But they would be governed fro that forth by Co^sules. So
wha^ tho kings had reigned.ii. hundred year and.xl. they made this statute that
two Consules should be chosen: and they should govern the cite and the people.
and for this cause these two were chosen that any of the^ would make any if
excess: the other should govern him. For their was no thing obeyed: but if
they consented both. Also they should not stand in there dygnyte passing one
year: for this cause. That for domynacyon of long time: they should not usurp
upon them more than was right In all this time the Empire of Rome was not
dylated possynge.xii. mile. The first Consules that were made: they called
Lucium and the other Brutu^ / and these two men did great things in their
time But yet ye people bare heavy of their domynacyon / wherefore they chose an
other man / the which should have more auctoryte than they / and they called
him Dictator In this same time their was a great dyscencyon betwixt the people
and the Senate werfore they chose Trybunas with their Iuges over the people /
and defended them fro wrong as says ysyder. For the Dictator when he was
chose he lasted.v. year / and the Trybunas were remeued every year. But ye
must understood that ye shall not have here after all ye Consules named that
governed Rome between ye sessynge of kings / and the beginning of
themperours. For it were to long to write / specially when every year were new
syn / that one man might be chosen so oftentimes as we read / and also for the
endurynge of there governance. For they were governors of Rome.v.C.
year.lxvii. So the most famous men of these shall be reherced / after the
form of Chronicles / and as they stand in the book was echeone after other.

Circa annu^ mundi.iiii.M vii.C.lix. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.iiii.C.xl.
ELyac is reherced in the line of Christ in Mathee. prio and more of him is not

went from Babylon in to Jerusalem. where of he had.xii. year the ledynge of
the people / And the.v. year he began to repeyre the yates and the walls of
Jerusalem / the which work he ended in two year and four months / and that
whit grieve Impedymentes. For the half of the people stood armed without the
cytee to withstod the people of other nacyonne. intending dystroy them / and
ye other part labored in arms holdinge in the one hand stones for walls /

Platoes master. Democritus ypocras / and other / of whom the noble works
abode were also.

How king Mor with dyed thorugh myschaund^e / thorugh a be.
AFter this Howan reigned Morwith / and he became so wicked and so stern: till
at the last a great vengeance came upon him. For when as he went upon a time
by the sea side hemette with a great be: that was black and horrible and
hydeous. and he we^de that it had be a whale of the sea: and bent an arblast
and would have slain that be with his quarrel but he might not smite him.
and when he had shot al hes quarlles that be ano^e came to him in a great
have: and him devoured a live: and so he deyed for his wickedness: thorugh

Of Artogaill that was Grandobodia^s sone / how he was made king / and sithe

AFter Grandobodiam reigned his sone Artogaill.v. year / and he became so wicked

How Hesyder was made king after the death of his brother.

How Lud was made king after the death of Ely his fader.
AFter the death of Ely reigned Lud his sone and governed well the land and

they should keep their own laws at ye.vii. year should be without tribute (

foot me^ and.iiii. M. horsemen: and ships C.lxxx. And it is uncertain whether
it is more meruaylle: that he should conquer all the world with so little a
power or how that ever he durst go upon them with so little a power. And there
was of Alexand and his host slain ye ^yng of Persarum (Et vt orosius dicit
qui^quies decies ce^tena milia) Eneas ye sone of Iady was bishop after his
fader. Manilius Papirius and Fabius we^^ co^sulers at rome. This papirius wha^
he was a child he was very wise and he feyned many fair lesi^ge that he might
keep hes masters counsel and the Senators. And when he came unto man's
state: he was so noble a war^you^^ That when ye Romans dradde Alexander he was
chosen for to goo ayenste hym^ And of the gods charged not but he scorned and
reproved the gods: saying before that unhappy thing should fallen And that
to his great loving holy douctours say

Incipit monarchia Grecorum. et cessat monarchia Persaram.
King Alexander this time began to be lord of all the world: and he was
called great Alisand for his great victory ye which he had in so little time It
was an euyde^c Judge me^t of ye wrath of god against syn^ers of that time
certainly some miracle our lord did in helping of his power for him / for ye
see of Pamphilicon was divided to him as in old time the reed see to the Jews
when he persecuted Darius. Also at his prayer the hills of Caspii were shytte
that certain of the cursed Jews mygh never come out. But at last in babylon
with venym he was poyso^ed and dyed the ^xxxiii year his of age / and ye fyfth
year of his monarche the.xii. year of the kingdom of Macedon. Know ye that
when Alexander was deed those.xii. to whom he divided his kingdom accord they
might not / and then began Infenyte batylles / and at the last four opteyned
all the kingdom (Vide plura in Orosio)

Anno mundi.iiii^M.ix.C.ix. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.ii.C.ix
AChym of the line of Christ sone to Sadoch is nombred i^ Mathe prio. and of him
is no more had in scriptur. Symo^ was bishop this time an holy man / and also
ryghtwys he was named of the people. Eleazarus was bishop after syomon / this
man send to Pretholomeo king of Egypt.lxxii. learned me^ of every trybe sex /
to Interpret the law of the Jews / the which translated from Hebrewe i^ to
Greek thorugh a great miracle that so manimen should in.lxxii. days translate
all holy scripture with one accord (Vide aug. de ciui. dei) Dolobela Emilius.
Marcus Curious. Genutus time were Co^sules at Rome This Dolobela conquered
Samnites / and after many bataylles had / and Marcus subdued Epitoras and
slew.xxiii.M. of his men / and then fled king Pirro / the which send to
him for peace and offrynge to him greere yeftes. And then this Consul answered
and said / there shall no batayl cause me to flee / nor no money corrupt me.
For I had lever command rich me^ to do this and this than be rich myself.
Tonucius subdued the cite of Argiuorum / and a legyon of knights of Rome he
send to Rome / and caused them to be beat openly in the mids of the market /
for they had them not lefully to the court of Rome For the law was then
kept so streytly at Rome / that and they had failed to do ye due obseruaunce
in virtue they should be punysshed. These Romans and many before and after were
the most noble men of the worlds honest that might be: and in all manner of
virtue circumspect: As holy doctors say that they put there examples to
Christian men but not the Intencyon: for they lacken the keye of faith

Incipiunt reges Egyti or alr non pt^ seri^ co^tinuaco^. et intexent^ reges
Sirie.
PTholomeus Philodolphus this time was king i^ Egypt: this Philodolphus was the
very worshyper of one god: and full gracyous to the Jews: of whom.xx.M.
and.C. he delyuerd out of captyuyte: and that he did that he might please the
god of Israel: of whom he herd the meruayles. And his law he desired to have:
nor it might not be translated in to none other longage but of devout me^: and
that with a due reverence and a solempnite. Certain men atempted to have
written it amon the Gentyle stories: whom the plage of god stroke tylle they
repented. This king send unto Eleazar the bishop: to send to him learned
men: The which he did gladly (Vide plura in mgro^ histo)

Anno mundi.iiii.M.ix.C.lix. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.ii.C.xl.
ELyud of the line of christ: gate Eleazar as it is open i^ Mathe. io. and more

except a few Romans were left a live: and subdued the country. Appius

the^. Atilus Regulus a noble senator over came three Kings and.lxxiii. cytees
he subdued: and a dragon of a.C.xv. foot he killed. After ward when he was
over cruel against his enmyes: and denyenge to give them peace: but if they
would pay a might trybute: they almoost being in dyspayr and fought against
him: and overcame him and his host and took him: and nevertheless yet they
would feign have had peace: but this most faithful man had lever dye in pains
great / than to give rest and peace to cursyd people. His loving greatly saint
Austyn exalts. Emelius Fabius and Gaius would have delyuerde Regulus but they
opteyned not. Ptholomias Ever gites this time was king of Egypt a victoryous
prince and a mighty. This man subdued Siriam and Cirilia^ / and the most part
of Asie / and took there goods and brought them in to his country. Ptholomeus
Philopater / sone to Euergites reigned in Egypt.xvii. year. This man fought
against two brethern. Seneleu^ and great Antiochu^ / and he prostrated many a
thousa^de / but nevertheless he prevailed not (Vide plura in Iohe^ super
Danielis) Hanyball the most cursed king of Penorum and of Affricanorum
myghtely hoted ye Romans / for he destroyed them almoost to ye vttermest end
/ and nyghe the cytee of Rome he destroyed. And so many noble men of Rome he
slew at one time / that three bussheles full of gold rings he drew offyngers.
Also i^ a certain water / of the slain bodies of these Romans / he made as
it were a bridge / that his host might pass. And at the last Cipio ye noble
senatur direckid his host to him and sco^fyted him and almoost Cipioes host of
Romans was slain. Lucacius consul. Simpronius Valerius. Fulnius Lutinus
staius and Cipio / ruled at Rome / this time the Romans had peace one year
alone / and it was take for a miracle tha^ they had rest so long. For before

when the year was done gadred all the strength of ytaly / and they had in
their host.viii.M. armed men for dread of the Frensshmen / whom they dradde
strongly / and after ward ye Romans subdued them. Epiphanes the sone
Philopater reigned in Egypt.xxiiii. year. Cleopatra daughter to great Antiochus
was his wyf^ Antrochus magnus this time reigned in Syr^y / the which did much
myschyef to the Jews (vt pz Mathe) Onias this time was bishop in Jerusalem.
This Onias for the tyranny of Antiochus fled with many Jews in to Egypt /
feynynge him to fulfill the prophecye ysaie.xix. that is to wit To build the
Temple. But i^ that he sin^ed for he said otherwise than he thought. The king
of Egypt gracyously received him / and gaf him ye land of Helipolees / and
there he builded his Temple. Somon his sone was bishop at Jerusalem / after
that his fader was fled.

Circa annu^ mundi.v.M.xxxiiii. Et ante xp^i natiuitatem.C.lxv.
ELeazar of the line of christ was about this time. Of him no thing written in
scripture: but that Mathe nombreth hi^ (vt pz prio) Onias Pius was to the
bishop this time an holy man: and well beloved with god and man And not
alonely with good men but evil men also. At the last unright wysly was slain
of Adronito (vt pz.ii. machabeorum) Paulus Tereneius Scipio Affricanus: these
were Senators at rome. These two erected an host against Hanyba^l: and there
almost the Romans hope dyed^ For there was slain. xl^iii.M. Romans. And this
noble Scipio affricanus brought again ye state of the Romans people the which
stood in a distpayre ever to have recovered. For he fought with Hanybal manly
and dysco^fyted him. All Spain ^e over came All Africa he subdued: gre^
Antiochus he brought to be his servant. All Asie he made trybutary to the
Romans: this man so noble and so victoryus by his own unkind country was
outlawde: and there he deyed. Philometor the sone Epiphanes of Cleopatra reigned
in Egypt.xxxv. year. This king ye^ a child / noble Antiochus greatly oppressyd
with many dysceytes but the Romans sent Legates the which commanded
Antiochus that he should cesse of his tyranny against him. And Marcus Publius
made a cercle to Antiochus thus saying. The Senators of rome and the people
command yt that thou go not out of this cercle ^yl thou have answered to this
matter This Antiochus seeing that he might not contynue^h^ tyranny said if it be
thus commanded me of the Senators and Romans people I must needs turn aye^
and so wood a^gry he was that he lost the sege of Alexandre / and turned to ye
poor releues of ye Jews / vengynge him upon them by cause he might not venge
him on a more myghtyer people (vt pz iii lio Machabeorum.ii.

MAthachias an holy man / and of all loving most worthy hated in his heart
the conuersecyon of all sinners / alonly trusting in our lord god of Israel
(vt pz primo macha. ii.) And this man had.v. sons of the same love unto god.
This man was not bishop in Israel / but his three sons were. Judas Machabeus
was bishop.iii. year / and he was sone to Mathathias. This Machabeus was the
most named man that ever was i^ Israel / the which had never none like him
before ne after. He was in battle a mighty man and offered him to deye a martyr
for the laws of god. Ionatas his brother succeeded him.xix year. The which
grew in virtue and governed and stood steadfast in the laws of god / and
after falsely was slain of Cryphone and two of his sons (Plura vide Judah et
fre^m eius li. macha. Antiochus Epiphanes sone to Antiochus the mighty this
time was king of Syrry, This man from the heed unto the feet within and
without all was cursed / And therefore he was fygured to Antecryst. Many martyrs
cruelly he made and falsely he dyspose him to enter in to Egypt as his fader
did / but he opteyned not for the Romans let him. His most unhappy work
/ and how he was in hastage at Rome / and how the prophecy of Danyell was
completed in him / ye may see in the book of Machabeorum. Quintus Flaminius.
Marchus Cato. Thiberius Gracius were Senators of Rome. This time was so
contynuall and so much bataylle / that learned men of Gentyles and of the true
faith both were weary for to write the acts or to have the^ in mind. In the
which bataylles men meruaylled greatly on the steadfastness of the Romans /
that no trybulacyon / no dread no hardenesse might not fere them / but ever
continued in battle. And certainly these Romans after the worlds honest /
they were the most wysest men that were. And therefore the Machabees desired
there company.

Circa annu^ mundi.v.M.lix. Et ante xp^i natiuitatem.C.xl.
MAthon sone to Sadoch of the line of Christ gate Jacob (vt patet Mathei.i.)
Simon sone to mathias was bishop.viii year. This Simon was a very wise man /
and from youth until his aege was ever of good conuersacyon / ever more
virtuous. And at ye last he was slain of his brother Elay. (vt pz.i. macha)
Johannes Hircanus sone to Simon / was after his fader.xxix. year / a noble man
as all the kynrede was before him. This man after his decesse left his wife a
very wise woman and his five sons to govern the Jury of the eldest was called
Aristobolus an impatient man and an unhappy. His own mother with three of his
younger brethern he prysoned and slew them through hungre and so alone he lived
king and bishop one year (Vide plaura li. Machabeorum) Publius Lucimius.
Lucius Emilius. Lucius Lucinius. Lucius Consorinus were Consules at Rome. In
whoos time the Cartagynes and the Romans warred strongely^ But the Romans
subdued them / entendynge to have destroyed ye Cartagynes utterly. But among
the Romans there was a notable wise man called Scipio Nauta. And among many
notable cou^seylers two he ga^ specially to be had i^ mind. The first that
Cartago should not be destroyed that through the occasyon of for and bataylles /
a In ward co^corde should abide among the Romans / and a perpetuell strength
for contynuell excercyse of battle. The second. That in no wise the other
should be builded in Rome. For he said that was the most enmye that might be
to ye people that used war For that place nourysshed sloth and provoked
lechery And how wisely this notable man gaaf counseyll / the times following
declares (vide plca in Aug. dei ciuite dei libro.iiii.) yet for all this
counseyll that noble cite of Carcago was destroyed of Cipio and the Senators.
And it burnt.xvii. days contynuelly Many men there were sold / and many men
ran in to the fire wylfully. Corinthus this same year was destroyde of the
Romans / the which was the rychest country of the world. Ptholomeus this
time reigned in Egypt / and was famylyer with the Romans. And so long he and
his predecessors reigned as they kept fydylyte to the Romans. And know every
man that there was none other cause that the power of ye Romans increased so
strongly abue other people / but virtue / the which habundanly rygned in them
/ and namely reght wysnesse which above all thing they used. And as long as
they kept mesures and loved right wysnesse / so long they were never overcome
And as soon as they were corrupted / it is radde / they were ouercome^. It is
had in a certain reuelacyon of god showed to saint Brygyte that our lord god
bears wetnesse to these old Romans. That none in this naturell life lived
more right wisely. And what lyghtes of faith they showed in the time of
Christian relygyon shall be showed after ward.

Regum Jude orum restituitur.
ARistobolus was the first king and priest in ye Jury this man reigned one
year alone / and took to him the Dyademe of the kingdom. And he held him not
content with that his fader gaaf him in his testamente. But he put his mother
in prison and his brethern. And therefore he perysshed wretchidly with his
brother Antigonus the which was of his counsel and helped him.) Vide
magystrum in historiis (Antigonus brother unto the king was slain through the
enuytee of the queen. lexander was bishop after Arstobolus / and he
stood.xxvii^ year. And he was al atyraunte / all though he appeared sobre in the
beginning. But he made it known what he was in his stomach / for he slew his
own brother. And in.xii. year he slew.l. thousand of the old sage faders of
great virtue / by cause they told him his mysgydyng. Then^e when he should
deye / he left two sons behind him Hircanu^ and Aristobolum. But certainly he
said his wife should regne / for she stood in the grace of the people. Seruius
Flaccus. Lucious. Fabius. Plubius this time were Senators at Rome This time
bataylles amonste them sif began^e. Of the which the first cause and the
beginning / was Graceus a myghhy man / well known with noble Romans / began
to seek a cause against them. And by cause that he might do no thing alone to
them / he meued the common people to them saying / That all the lands and
possessions should be divided equaly / and also the money. etc^. And for that
cause there was an Insurrreccyon / in the which Graccus was slain / and many
myscheues fell after (Vide Orosium) In ye time of these men / there was a
child borne at Rome / having four feet / four arms / two faces and four
eyes. The hylle of Ethna spetted out flammynge fire horrible / and destroyed
the places nyghe about it. And these men berynge rule. Cartago was commanded
to be restored. And it was fulfilled of the Romans people. And there was
mighty battle in the cite of Rome. Fabius with a little host overcame the
king of Armenye And there were drowned an honyred and four score thousa^de men
in the water of Rome. Ptholomeus Alexander was king in Egypt. In his time was
borne Lucerius a Poet / ye which afterward was mad for love of wym^en and
slew himself. Pthoiomeus sone to Cleopatre reigned after him / under whom
Salustius ye noble writer of hystoryes was borne. Ptholomeus Dionisius was
after this man And in his time virgyll and Oracius were borne.

Anno mu^di.v.M.C.xxxiiii. Et ante xp^i natiuitate^.ix.C.v.
Jacob naturell fader to Joseph of the line of crest is reherted in Luke and
Mathe and little of him is had in scripture. Alexandra wife to Alexander was
bishop in the Jury.ix. year / and showed much tyranny al if she was made
bishop by her feyned holy relygyon. And Hircanu^ her sone she provoked to the
bysshopryche / and she ordained that he should regne after. This woman in ye
line of the bishops is put fro the cou^tynge of ye years. Not as she used the
office of a bishop for it was not leyfull to her. Hircanus sone to Alexandra
reigned.xxxiii year. This Hircanus after the decesse of his mother succeeded in
the kingdom / in ye which he had little prosperyte for percyalte of the people.
For anon he was over comen / and after ward he was restored through the help
of the Arabees. And then he was made trybutary to the Romans. And so (...)
was in peace a little time. But not in ye name of king. At the last he did
wretchedly for he was begyled through the fraud Parthorum the which Antigonus
hired against him (vide plene magistru^ history) The heresye of ye Pharysees
about this time began. And among them were three sects in the Jury. Pharacey.
Saducey. and Essey. All these were divided from the common use of the Jews /
and were enfe^^e with mani errors for they said that they were holyer than
other men. For they lived streytlyer than other men did (Vide plus alias)
Virgyll the most excellent of Potes was magnefyed this time / and meruaylous
things he did. And among other when that Neopolis was vexed with deedly pain
of mighty worms. Virgyll cast a worm of gold in to a pound or a water /
and it lay a certain season there. And when it was take up in to the town /
all the cite was made full of worms. And till the worm of gold was put in to
the water again / they had In fyte worms. And when it was in the water all
the worms went a way. Also it is wreten in the chronicles of Rome / that
Virgyll by conning condesce^ded or thycked the air / so that he walled his
gardyne with the air. And he made a bridge of the air / by the which he
might pass every time that he list Also he asked Morcellu^ Neopolitanu^ /
neuewe unto the Emperor / if he would have a bird taught to kylle all birds
or a fly taught to drive all flies out of the cite. And this Marcellu^ told
this to the Emperor. And he desired to teache a fly to kylle all flies. For
the common people were sore anoyed with ^^yes. And many other maruales he did
(vide magistru^ Rodulfu^ Cesteru^) Oracius Flaccus / and Salustius Crispus
historicus were at this time. Quintus Cipio. Gaius Lucis this time were
Consules at Rome. Pompeius. Marcus Crassus and Julius Cezar this time were
Dictatours at Rome. For as it is said / before there were many dygnytees at Rome
/ of the which some dured one year / some two year. And among all the
dygnytees the Dictatours exceded / for it dured five year. But when the common
people and the lord shypes of Rome encreasynge were made three Dictatours. And
this time was pompeius. Julius and Marcus Crassus Dictatours. And by cause
Pompeius was of great honor and aeged / he bode at Rome to keep the common
people of Rome. Marcus Crassus was send to subdue and fight with the regyon of
Perthus. And through treason he was taken and slain Julius Cezar was send to
the weste part of the world to subdue them. And he has with him seven
legyons of people. And when that he had subdued Lomberdye and France his
five year were spended / the which were assygned to him and no longer. There
by his own auctoryte he took other five year upon him / in the which he
subdued Cassybolon king of Brytayne / and the Frenshme^ that rebelled against
him This same Julius after he had conquered the countrees / unto Rome he roode
again / for to be receued with certain worship as conquerours were before him
but it was denied him / and also the entree of the Cytee / by the Instygacyon
of a lord called Pompei. wherefore this Julius Cezar was annoyed / and with
force of might entered the Cite / and robbed the common treasoure and ladde it
with him / and departed it among the seven legyons that were his servants.
Then went he in to Spain to fight against this Pompei. For Pompei had
the governance of Cartago. But after that Iourneye in ytale Pompei and he
encountered together. In the which bataylle Pompei fled unto the king of
Egypt / and that same king for special love that he had unto this Julius
Cezar smote or Pompeus heed and sent it to Julius Cezar. yet for all the
enuyte that was betwixt them two Julius wept when that he saw this Pompeius
heed^ This Julius was exceeding in wit before other men / and he faught in
bataylle.lii. times. This man alone exceded Marcus Crassus: the which is said
to have foughten.xxxix. times. This man took first the Empire of Rome upon
him: when Pompei and other noble men of the Romans were slain. And at the
last the fyfthe year of his Empire: This Julius Cezar the ruler of all this
world was slain in the counsel house thrughe treason of his lords. Cathon
the most named philosopher: Seeing Julius Cezar have the victory: whom he
favored not: at a town called Vticam did slay him self (iuxta illud Mauult
cota mari: quam deroget vrbis honorari) But for that after Austyn he was not
excused of senne.

This time the Jury was trybutarye to the Romans for percyalyte of two
brethern Aristobolus and Ercanus both of them for envy of other cast them to
the Romans that they might regne. This time three sons appeared in heaven to
ward the eest part of the world: the which by little and lytelle were
broghte in to one body. A great sign it was that Africa. Asia: and Europa
should be brought i^ to one monarche and that ye lordshyp of Anthony the
Senatoure and Lucius Anthonii should turn in to one lordshyp. Marcus Cicerio
Tullius the most noble Rethorycen was Counsel of Rume this time.

How that the Brytons granted unto Cassybolon which then to fore that was
Luddes brother the land. In whoos time Julius Cezar came twyes for to conquer
the land of Brytayne.
AFter the death of king Lud reigned his brother Cassybolon and became a good
man and much beloved of his bryto^s so that for his goods and corteysy they
granted him the reame for ever more to him and to his heirs. and the king of
his goodness let nourysshe worthily both the sons that were Lud his brother.
And after made the eldest sone earl of Cornewayle / and the yngest sone he made
earl of London. And while this king Cassybolon reigned / came Julius Cezar that
was Emperor of Rome in to the land with a power of Romans / and would have
had this land thrughe strength / but Cassybolon over came him in battle
through help of the Brytons / and drove him out of this land. And he went
again to Rome and assembled a great power an other time / and came again in to
this land for to give battle to Cassybolon / but he was dyscomfyted through
strength of ye Brytons / and through help of the Earl of Cornewayle and the
Earl of London his brother / and through help of Gudian king of Scotlonde / and
Corbonde the king of Northwalys / and of Brytayl king of Southwalys. And in
this bataylle was slain Nennon that was Cassybolons brother / wherefore he made
much sorrow / And so went Julius Cezar out of this land with a few of
Romans that were left a live. And then Cassybolon went again to London and
made a feast to all folk that tho him had helped. And wha^ that this feast was
done / Then every man yede in to his own country.

Of the debate that was betwixt Cassybolon and the Earl of London / and of the
truage that was paid to Rome.
ANd after it befelle thus upon a day / that the gentylmen of the kings
household and the gentylmen of the Earls household of London after meet went
togyd for to play And thorugh debate that arose among them Enelin that was
the Earls cosyn of London slew Ire^glas that was ye kings cosyn. wherefore
swore that Enelyn should be hanged. But the Earl of London that was Enelins
lord would not suffer him / wherefore the king was gretely wroth and vexed
toward the Earl / and thought him destroy. And preuely the Earl sent letters
to Julius Cezar that he should come in to this land for to help him and him
avenge upon the king / and he would help him with all his might. And when
the emperor herd this tidings he was full glade / and ordained a strong power
/ and came again the third time in to this land / and the Earl of London
helped him with.viii. thousand men / and at the third time was Cassibolon
overcome and dyscomfyted and made peace to the Emperor for three thousand
pound of silver yeldi^ge by year for trauge for this land for evermore. And
then half a year after passed the Emperor Julius Cezar went again unto Rome
/ and the Earl of London which him. For he durst not abide in this land. And
after Cassybolon reigned.vii. year in peace / and tho he deyed the.xvii. year of
his regne and lies at york.

How that the lords of the land after the death of Cassybolon and for by cause
he had none heyer made Adragen king.
AFter the death of Cassybolon for as much as he had none heir of his (...)
body begote^ / the lords of land by ye comyns assente crowned Andragen earl
of Cornewayle and made him king. And he reigned well and worthily / and he was a
good man and will governed the land. And when he had reigned. v^ii. year then
he deyed / and lies at London

Circa annu^ mundi.v.M.C.lix. Et ante xp^i natiuitatem.i^.
Joseph of the line of Christ was about this time borne / and after was
husbonde unto our lady. Anthigonus was bishop this time in the Jury. This
Anthigonus was sone unto Aristoboly / and on every side he was false. For he
obeyed not to the Romans / and a great plage he brought unto the lord for to
destroy Hircanus his uncle that he might regne king / and so Hircanus was
expulsed / and Flaccus was slain / and Herod was exiled. But when Herod came
unto Rome and told the Senators all these thyngys / the Emperor cerated him
king sendynge with him an host / the which took Jerusalem. And Anthigonum
the bishop taken / led to Anthony the Senatoure / the which made him seker
/ and so was Herod confermed in to his kingdom. And he a stranger reigned on
the Jews / and so the kingdom of the Jews cessed as Jacob had said. Titus
Liuius historicus and Quidius were this time.

Incipiu^t imperatores augusti. et dictus est augustus quia augebat populum
OCtauian was Emperor of Rome.lvii. year.vi. mouths and.^. days. This
Octauyan neuewe to July wha^ he was a young man took the Empire upon him. His
flourysshynge youth he spended in war. Five thousand bataylles he did. And
shortly after many bataylles / he brought all the world in to one Monarche /
that man had no fellow And in his days peace was in all the world thrught the
prouysyon of the very god. That the temporal peace might glorifye the natyuyte
of our savior Christ Ihesu. This Octauyan was the fairest man that might be /
and high in wit / the most fortunate in all things. And he lacked not the
vice of his flesshely lust. This man made all the world to be mesured. And
in the.lii. year of his regne was our lord Ihesu Christ borne / the Sauyoure
of this world / the which grants eternal peace to his lovers. Hic nota
secundum Ieronimum) that Anna and Emeria were systers. And of Emeria was borne
Elyzabeth mother to Johan the Baptyste. And she was first wedded to Ioachim of
whom she took Mary mother of Christ. The second husbonde was Cleophe / and he
gate oon her Maria Cleophe / the which was wedded to Alphe of whom proceeded
James the less Simon Cananeus. Judas Tadeus / and Joseph the which is called
Barsabas / The third time Anna was wedded to Salome / of whom she took Mary
Salome the which was wedded to zebede and of them came James ye more / and
Johan the euangelyst The first Mary wedded Joseph brother to Cleophe before
said. This time Sibilla Tiburrina prophesied of Christ / and said to
themperoure August / that he should not trow that he was not god after the
folysshenes of the paynyms And there she showed him a fair virgyne in heaven
holdinde a child in her arms / and said to him / this child is greter than
thou / and therefore do him worship. The monarche of Rome about this time
myghtly encresed. And when it was so that by all the world in diverse prouynces
bataylles were raised suddenly all men merualynge / they were sessed and put
them holy to the prince of Rome that openly it might be showed that such an
universal peace came never by labor of bataylle / but of ye powere of the
very god / that in his natyuyte peace should regne in all the world. Herod
Ascolonira was king in the Jury.xxxv. year This Herod ydumeus was ye first
strange king that reigned on the Jews. The master in historiis says / he
was a noble man and faithful in the beginning / and in all thing he had him
nobly. He wys very ge^tyll unto the Romans and to the people that loved peas^
And in his old aege / when he would much please the Romans herd of the
birth of Christ: dredynge to be expulsed of his kingdom as a stranger:
wretchedly he fell and slew the Innocents and dyuer of his own children.
And at ye last was hateful to all people: and fell syke and deyed wretchedly.
Mary the mother of Christ was borne before the Natyuyte of christ.xv. year or
there about.

Of Kymbulyn that was Andragens sone reigned after his fader
AFter the death of Andrage^ reigned Kymbalyn his sone a good man and well
governed the land in much prosperyte and peace all his life time. And in his
time Ihesu Criste was borne of that sweet virgyne Mary. This king Kymbalyn had
two sons. Gynder and Armager good knights and worthy. And when this Kymbalyn
had reigned.xxii. year: he deyed and lies at London.

Cristus natus est ex virgin maria. anno mundi.v.M.C.lxxxxiii.
IN the begynnyge of the.xlii. year of Octauyan themperoure. which began to
regne in March: and in.xxx. year of Herod.vii.C. and.l. year after that Rome
was builded / the.vi. monthe from the conceyuynge of Johan Baptyst: the.viii.
Kal. of Apryl: the.vi. fery at Nazareth of Galylee: of the virgyne Mary was
conceived Christ our savior and the same year was borne^

Here at Crystys Natyuyte begins the sixte aege during to the fynall
Judgment: having years as god knows Here begins the sixte aege during to
the end of the world.


THat day our lord Ihesu Christ was borne / a well of oil beyond Tybre by
Rome spra^ge and ran all day. The goldy^ yamge fell yt which Romulus had
made: and put it in his palace saying. This image shall not fail vnre a maid
bear a child. when Herod disposid him to slay the chyldern of Israel: he was
commanded by the letter of the emperor to come to Rome to Answer to the
accusacyon of his chyldern Alexium. and Aristoboli: And there were three Herodes
grely spoken of for there ill deeds The first was called Ascolonita / and under
this man was borne christ / and the children of Israel were slain. The
second was called Antipas sone to ye first Herod / under whom John^ Baptyst
heeded / and christ suffered death. And the third was called Agrippa sone to
Aristoboli / sone to the first Herod / the which slew James and prysoned
Peter. The first Herod when he saw his sons Alexiu^ and Aristoboli through
the pretens of his letter by the Emperor send / strive for the succession of
his kingdom / he disposid and made Antipater that was his first begoten sone
to be before them: and when they were talking of the death of their fader he
cast them away: and they went to the emperor to complain of ye wrong of
therfader. And in the mean time the three kings of Coleyne came by Herod unto
Jerusalem: and when they came not again by him he thought that they were ashamed
for to come again by him for because that they were disceyued: and that they
found not the child as he denied: therefore in the mean season he cessed to
slay the chyldern of Israel and so wene unto Rome for the cytacion of
themperoure. And he took his way by the cite of Tarsum where he burnt the
ships in the which the three kings of Coleyne should have saylled in to there
own country. Then after a year and certain days: this Herod came from
Rome again: accorded with his sons And for the co^fyrmaco^n of his kingdom he
was made much holder: and then he slew all the chyldern of Bethleem that were
of two year of aege and under that had space of one night of aege: and among
these was there one of his own chylrden. And Aristoboli and Aleriu^ werre had
in suspeccion: in so much as they promised a harbor a great reward that he
should take and kitte there faders throat wha^ that he did him shave. and when
this Herod herd this he was grieved and there he slew both his sons. And
Herod Agrippa his sone he ordained to be kige. wherefore Antipater his oldest
sone was about to poison his foder: the which Herod Agrippa understood: and
prysoned there his brother that which the Emperor herd and said that he had
leuee be an hog of Herodes: than for to be one of his sons: for his hogs
he spares and his sons he sleeth. And when that Herod was.lxx. year of age
he was stryken with a great sykenesse in his hondes and in his feet and in his
members: that no lethe might come to him for stenche: and so he deyed. So
Antipater his sone in prison herd tell of this and Ioyed gretely: and
therefore that cause he was slain. Then strove Archelaus and Herodes for the
succession of the first Herod. The Emperor there through counsel of the
Senators: the half of the Jury and Idumea gaaf to Archelaus under name of
Tetrarche. And the other part he divided in two. Galylee he gaaf to Herod
Antippa. And Ituriam and Traconidem he gaafe to Philype Herodes brother. And
that same year Christ came from Egypt / And Archelaus was accused many times
of the Jews / and was exiled in to Vyennam in to france. And in that place
were set four Tetrarchees / to the repreuynge of the vnstablynesse of the
Jews. And that same year Octauyan ye Emperor deyed.

IHesus Christ at.xii. year of aege herd the doctors in the Temple. Our
lord. Ihesu Christ at.xxx. year of Aege was baptysed^ Ihesu Christ the lord of
all. things at.xxx. year of aege and.iii. months deyed far his servants
Anninus Rufus was bishop in the Jury about this time. Valerius Geaceus was
after him.xi. year. This man openly sold the bysshopryche / and he that most
yaaf had it. And there was money in alytell while. Poncius Pylatus was Judge
and Proctour in the Jury under ye Emperor. And under this man John^ Baptyst
began for to preche. And our lode surffred death / the which was dampened to
death unright wysly for dread of the emperor. Tyrus a certain king gate a child
on Pyla a poor man's daughter / the which man hight Arus / and this child
of his moders name and his be^syre put togyds was called Pylatus / This Pylatus
ye fourth year of his aege was sent to his fader. The which king of his
lefull wife had gotten a child even of the aege with Pylate / and by cause this
lefull gote^ child as they proceeded in aege exceded this bastard Pylatus he
was full of envy and slew his brother the lefull gotten child. wherefore forth
with his fader se^te him to Rome for pledge for his trybute that he paid to
Rome / entendynge he would never redeem him. In the which time the kings sone
of France was pledge for his trybute / ye which exceded him in strength and
chyualry also he slew him. Therefore the Romans sent Pylate as a profitable
man for ye common well to the isle of Ponto to tame the cursyd people / the
which slew eueri Judge that came to them And he that cursid man governed that
vnhapy people what with thretynge and with promise / and with law and with
ieftes that no^e of them durst contrai do to his pleasure / wherefore he was
called Pylate of Ponto. Herodes Antipa young in his conuersacyons / with
yeftes^ and messages drew him to him and made him prince of the Jury under
him. And this time Pylate gadred much money / and Herod not knowing he
went to Rome that he might receive of the Emperor that Herod had given him.
Wherefore Hyrode and Pylate were enmyes together / unto ye passion of our lord /
when that pylate send Ihesus unto Herod clothed in a white clothe / then^e
they were made friends. Ouidius Naso in ponto above this time deyed the fourth
year of his exile. Tyburius this time was Emperor at Rome / and he reigned
xxiii. year / and he lived i^ the year that our lord Ihesu Christ deyed and
somewhat after. This man was in all his works greteli auysed that there should
be nothing suddenly done wise i^ wars studyous i^ books fair of speech fresshe
in wit / save he would of times feyne himself to do things that he would never
do of other. This Emperor understood and trusted in christ / and worshyped him
for god Some men say at the last he was cruel ayenste people but it was a
great reason of pity that he was ever gracious to his subgettes and poor men.
And he had peace all his days / and all the people that said against cryste^
folk with out oni mercy he destroyed: and he exyled pylate for ever Then he
decessed and a worse succeeded him. After Euseby it is written: our lord at.xxx.
year of his aege chose his.xii. apostles: the which made our Creed: that is
believe. and they made it after the Resurreccyon of christ: and after ye holy
ghost was send unto the^. when they had chose Mathia the apostle and each of
the^ made a part as it is showed hereafter. And this mathia was chose between
ye doye of the Ascencyon and wytsondaye in the place of Judas Scaryot the
traytoust / of ye which Judas in a history is read thus. There was a certain
man in Ieruslem that high Ruben / and after saint Ierom he was of ye trybe of
isacar. And his wife hight Cyborea the which one a certain night when he would
lustely know his wife / she dremed that she should bear a child of myschef and
ye child should be a traitor to his king and to al ye people of that regio^ and
wha^ that child was borne and called Judas his fader and his mod abhorred as
well to slay there child / as to nourysshe a traitor to the king and all his
people / there fore they put him in to a panyer / or a lepe in to the sea / and
he flowed to the isle of Scaryoth / where the ladi of that place had no child
by her husbonde and she feyned her to be with child / but she failed And after
i^ a little season ye same laid and queen conceived a chil of her husbonde and
when that he was of aege. Judas many times angerd him and caused him to weep /
the which the queen saw / and beat Judas many times / and after she knowleged
that judas was not ye kings snoe hers / wherefore Judas slew the kenges sone /
and he dradde the pain of ye law / and fled with certain exiles to
Jerusalem. And wha^ he came there: he gate hi^ in to Pylates court that was
Judge and by cause that o cursed man draws to a^ other: therefore he drew to
pylate and stood greatly in his favor. And upon a certain day wha^ Pylate looked
out of his palace in to an orcharde of a that man's was called rube^ that was
very fader to Judas. Pylate desired to have apples: and Judas went to gadre
apples: and Ruben ran to Judas for to let him because he took hes apples
whithaut any leave and wha^ they had chyd this Judas smote his fad on ye heed
with a stone and slew him: and Judas fled a way secretly aft that deed but it
was said that rube^ died suddenly. Then pylate gaf to Judas all ye goods that
Rube^ had and ciborea Rube^s wife that was mother to Judas. and he dealed not
curcesly with her as a ma^shold with hes wif and for that she wept and wailed
for she had put her so^e to ye see and that she was married against her well It
was perceived that Judas had slai^ hes owe fad and wedde hes own mod. Then^e
ciborea his mod and wife meuyd him to leave his sin / and then he followed
Christ: and he forgave him his syn^e and made him his procoure and apostle. And
howfals he was to Christ / it needs not to reherce. And ye same year Mathewe
was chose^ / and ye holy ghost was send in to them as it is said before. The
appostles or they were sparpied in to all ye world they gadred them cogyd in
to Jerusalem and made the Creed here folowinge that is our bileue.

IHesu Christ our savior rose fro death to life and said to his discyples All the
power in heaven and in earth is given unto me. And goo ye thus in to all the
wrold and preche and teache unto every creature / and Ish all be with you unto
the end of the world. Here he chyse him.lxxii. discyples. and he had.xii.
apostles ye which he send in to all the world to preche. Ne it is not read
that there were more ordres among the discyples of Christ / of whom the
prestes and bishops in the church of god yet keep the form. For to the
appostles the bishops succeed / and to the dyscyple priests. To the which
two ordres / all the church is given as a goodly Ierarche (Vt patet in Decreto
Damasie pape)

Johannes. wrote in Asia in Greek langage In principio erat verbum. and cetera.
