Here begins the order of Popes of Rome / and contynneth as the line of
Christ did before. For in them god left his power. Anno domini.xxxiiii.
PEter a Jew the first pope was a blessed man and a glorious apostle of
Christ. He was heed of ye church.xxxvii. year. And he held his bysshopryche in
the eest.v. year and said mass he made our lord / and alone said the Pater
noster. Then after he came to Antiochiam and there he abode.vii. year
techynge the way of troth. And Simon Magus he confounded away. That season he
preched to the people that were circu^cysed / the which were in Ponto of
Galati. Capadocia. Asia. Bichinia. Then herd he that Simon Magus deluded the
Romans / through the love of the faith / he came to Rome in the fourth year of
Claudius ye Emperor. And there he preched the word of god / and showed the
falshede of Simon Magus and turned many a man to the faith / Then he send
his precher by diverse prouynces / by whom christian relygyon was myghtely
increased. He ordained the feast of Lenton before Eester / and Aduent and the
Emerynge days to be fasted of all cryste^ people / in to the myrrour of the
first and second coming of our lord Ihesu. Then^e when he had be pope at
Rome.xxv. year.vii. months and ^viii. days / He was slain of Nero (Eius pla
opera vide actibus aplorum) Baius this time was Emperor at Rome and
reigned.iii. year and.x. months. This Gaius was first vicyous in living / for
two of his own sesters he mysused / and on one of them he ga^e a daughter /
which child he set betwext the knees of Iupyter in the Temple / and feyned
after ward that Iupyter had gotten her. wherefore he did cry through the
country that all men should worship her as a goddess / This man also made
an image like himself and sent it to one Patronie Presydent at Jerusalem under
the Romans commaundynge him that he should compel the Jews to do worship
thereto. And fore these enormities and many other / our lord suffered him to be
slain at Rome in his own Palace.

Of king Gynder that was Kymbalyns sone / that would not pay the truage to
Rome for the land that Cassybolon had granted / and how he was slain of a
Romyne.
ANd after the death of this Kymbalyn reigned Gynder his sone a good man and a
worthy / and was of so high heart that he would not pay to Rome that trybute
that king Cassybolon had granted unto Julius Cezar wherefore the emperor that
was tho that was called Claudius Cezar was sore anoyed And ordained a great
power of Romans / and came in to this land for to conquer the tribute through
strength / and for to have it on the kynge^ But this king Gynder and Armager
his brother assembled and gadred a great host togyd of Brytons and yaue battle
to the Emperor Claudius / and slew of the Romans gerte plente. The Emperor
had after ward one that was called Hamon that saw the people there fast
slain / and pryuely cast a way his owe arms and took the arms of a deed
Bryton and armed him with his armor / and came in to the bataylle to the king
and said in this manner. Sir be of a good heart for gods love for the Romans
that been your enmyes anon shall be slain and dyscomfyted euerychone. And the
king gaf no keep to his words / ne to his speech forbi cause of the arms
that he hae upon him / and demyd that he had been a Bryton. But the traitor
ever held him next the king And pryuely under ye sholder of his arms he
smote the king / wherefore the king deyed and fell down to the earth when
Armager saw his brother so deed herast away his arasmes and took to him his
brothers arms / and come in to the batayl among the brytons and badde them
hertly for to fight / and fast lay a down the Romans. And for the arms they
wend it had be king Gynder that before was slain / yt they wist not. Then
began ye Brytons fyersly for to fygth / and slew ye Romans So at the last the
Emperor forsook the field and fled as fast as they might with his folkein to
wynchestre. And the false traitor Hamon that had slain the king / fast anon
began for to flee with all ye have that he might And Amager ye kings brother
pursued him full fyersly with a fyers heart / and drove him unto a water and
there he took him. And ano^e smote of both hand and feet and heed / and hewed
ye body all to peers / and then let cast him in to the water wherefore that
wat was called Hamons haven. And after there was made a fair town that yet
stondeth that is called Southampten. And after Armager went to wynchestre for
to seek Claudius Cezar the Emperor of Rome. And there Armager him took. And
Claudius the emperor thorugh counseyl of the Romans that were with him left a
live / made peace with Armager i^ this manner as ye shall here. That is to say.
How that Claudius the Emperor should give unto Armager Gennen his fair
daughter for to have unto his wife. So that this land from that time for ward
should he in the Emperors power of Rome upon such covenant / that never
after ward no Emperor of Rome should take none other trybute of this land /
but only feaute And they were accorded. And upon this covenant Claudius Cezar
sent to Rome for his daughter Gennen. And as she was come Claudius Cezar yaf
her unto Armager to wife. and Armager spowsed her at London with much
solempnyte and mirth. And then was Armager crowned and made king of Brytayne.

Of king Armager in whose time. saint Peter preched i^ Anthyoche with other
apostles in diverse countries.
THis Armager reigned well and worthily / and gourned the land right
worshypfully. And Claudius Cezar in remembrance of this accord / and for
reverence and honor of his daughter made in this land fair town and a
castle / and let call the town after his name Clauestren / ye which now is
called Gloucestre* and then^e wha^ all this was done the Emperor took his leave
and then^e went to Rome again. And Armager then was king / and governed the
land well and worthily all his lives time. And this Armager gate a seen on his
wife which was called westmer. And while that this Armager reigned saint Peter
preched in Anthioche And there he made a noble church. In the which he satte
first in his chair And there he dewelled.vii. year. and after he went to
Rome: and was made pope: tylle that Nero ye Emperor let martyr him And then
preched openly all the apostles in diverse lands the right faith. And when
Armager had reigned.xxxiiii. year: he dyed and lies at the auncyente cite of
London.

How king westmer gaaf to Berynger an ylonde forlet. And there this Berynger
made the town of Berwyke.
ANd after this Armager reigned his sone westmer: that was a good man and a
worthy of body: and well governed the land. It befell so that tidings came to
him upon a day: that the king Roderyk of Gascoyne was come in to this land
with an hughe host of people: and was dwelling in Scanys more. and wha^ king
westmer herd those tidings he let assemble an huge host of Brytons / and
came to the king Roderyk and yaue him battle. And king westmer slew king
Rodoryke with his own hondes in plain baytaylle. And when king Roderyks men
saw that there lord was slain / they yielded them all to king westmer / and
became his men for ever more. And he gaf them a country that was forlete^
wherein they might dwelled. And thither they went And dwell there all their
lives time / and.ix. hundred men there were of them and nomoo left at that
batayll^ Their governor and prince was called Berynger. And anon he began a
town that they might there in dwell and have resort and let call the town
Berwyk upon Twede. And there they enhabyte and becam rich. But they had no
wymmen among them / and the Brytons would not give there daughters to the
strangers. wherefore they went over see in to Irlonde / and brought with them
wymmen and there they them spo^wsed. But the men could not understood their
langage ne the speech of these wymmen / and therefore they spoke together as
Scotts. And after ward through chaunginge there langage in all France they were
called then^e Scotts and so should the folk of that country be called for
ever more.

How king westmer let arere a stone in the entering of westmerlo^de / there
that he slew Roderyk / and there he began first housynge.
ANd after this batayl that is above said when Roderyke was deed / king
westmer in remembrance of his victory let arere there beside the way a great
stone on high / and yet it stondeth and ever more shall stand. And he let
grave i^ ye stone let that thus said The king westmer of Brytayne slew in
this place Roderyk his enymye. And this westmer was the first that builded house
and town i^ westmerlo^de and at that stone begins westmerlo^de that westmer
let call after his own name. And when westmer had so done he dwelled all
his life time in that country of westmerlonde / for he loved that country more
than any other country / and when he had reigned.xxv. year / he deyed and lies
at Karleyll.

Of king Coill that was westmers sone that held his land in peace al his
lives time.
AFter this: his sone king Coill reigned a good man and a worthy: and of good
condycyons: and well governed his land. And of all men he had love and peace.
And in his time was never contake debate: nor war in Brytayne. And he reigned
and was king in peace all his lives tyme^ And wha^ he had reigned.xi. year he
deyed and lies at york.

Claudius was Emperor at Rome next after Gaius. And he reigned.xiiii. year /
and.viiii. days. This man came in to great Brytayne now called England / for
to challenge the trybute which they did deny unto the Romans. And after
great bataylles there was between the Emperor Claudius and Armager king of
Brytayne. And after accordement made / that this armager should wedde Claudius
daughter / and after they two should ever live in peace. In token werof / this
Claudius named the cite where they were wedded after him / and called it
Claudicestre / where we now it call Gloucestre. This Claudius had three wives.
And on Petiua the first wife he gate a daughter that hight Antonia / the first
wife decessed / and he wedded Messalinam / and gate a sone that hight Brytanicus
and Octauia a daughter. The third he wedded Agrippina having a sone that hight
Nero. Claudius wedded his daughter Octauia to Nero his wives sone. This
Claudius for love that he had to Agrippina his last wife / he slew Messalina
his first wife / leest she should have help Britanicus her sone and his to
Empire. yet Agrippina the last wife of Claudius dradde / leest her husbonde
would have proferred Brytanicus and h^^e deposed Nero her sone / therefore she
poisoned her husbonde Claudius / and Nero was promoted to the Empire. And this
same Nero ayue his mother such a reward again. For he poisoned Brytanicus and
slew his own mother and his wife Octauia. James ye more the apostle this time
was slain of Herod Agrippa / and Peter was prysoned (Vt pz act.xii. The body
of saint James was brought by miracle in Galeciam of Spyne.

Nero after Claudius was Emperor / and he reigned.xiii. year and.vii. months.
This Nero was a cursyd man / and made grethe waste in the Empire. He would not
fysshe but with nets of gold and ropes of sylke. A great part of ye lords
of Rome he slew He was enemy to no men but to good men. He slew his brother
and his wife his mother and his master. He slew also Peter and Poule / he would
never were one cloth two times. All his horse and his mules were shood with
silver / and at the last he did set a great part of Rome on fire / some
say the Romans complained the streets were to narowe. And as he had burnt a
great part of Rome. Nero said there is space to build the streets wyder.
Then the Senators with the common people came upon him to sleehim and he
fled by night in to the subarbes of ye cytee and hyde him / and he herd
karles and beggars saying. And they wist where the Empe^rour were he should
never escape them. Nero thought it should be great derogacyon to his name and
he were slain of karles. And on a great stake he ran him self to the heart
and deyed and there was buried. And deuylles kept his body many a day after /
and did great hurt to the people / till by a miracle of our lord the body was
found and taken away / and then ye deuylles voyded. Seneca was this time
master to Nero. Iuuenales pota. Lucanus poeta. James the less the appostle
bishop of Jerusalem was slain of the Jews ye.vi. year of Nero. Marcus the
euaungelyste was martred the first year of him.

Circa annu^ xp^i.lxxiiii.
LInus ytalicus was pope of Rome.x. year and.iii^ months and.xiii. days This
Linus and his successor Cletus / through their holy conuersacyon were made to
mynystre the tresoure of the church to the people Peter being a live. And
Peter attended to prayenge and prechynge. It is read of this Cletus / that he
wrote first in his letters (Salutem et apostolica^ benedictionem) Before this
time was many a dyscyple of Peter slain under Nero. Galba this time was
Emperor / and he reigned.vii. months. This man was made Emperor by the power
of Spain in the same land Nero living. And after the death of Nero brught to
Rome / and there was slain of a man that came with whete to Rome. He smote of
his heed and bare it to him that was Emperor next / seeing all his men and
none of them helping him. In this man's days came ye great Rethoricyen to
Rome fro Spain / and was the first that ever taught the science openly / his
nyme was Quintilian. Otho reigned after him / and he reigned but.iii. months.
For one Vitellus that was President of France challenged ye Empire. And in
ytalye betwixt these two were three great bataylles And in the fourth battle
Otho saw he should be overcome and in great dispeyre he slew himself.
Vitellus reigned after Otho and he reigned.viii. months / for he was follower of
Nero most special in glotony / and in singing of foul songs: and at festes
etynges out of mesure that he might not keep it. Vespasianus reigned next
after him.ix. year and.x. months and.xii. days. The well governed men of
Rome seeing the cursyd succession of Nero sent after this Vespasian unto
palestyn For there he was and his sone Titus which had besyeged Iherusalem.
And wha^ be herd that Nero was deed: by whom he was sent to Jerusalem: and
herd of these cursyd men regnynge. At the Instaunce of these men: not
wyllyngly: took upon him the Empire. And anon as he was come to Rome: he
overcame the tyraunte Vitellus and let him be draw thorugh Rome: and after in
to tybre till he was deed: and then^e let him sail without sepulture for this
ye people desired. This man was cured of waspis in his nose anon as he byleued
in our lord Ihesu: And yt was the cause which went to Jerusalem / to venge
Crystis death He fought.x^xii. times with his enemies and deyed the year of
grace.lxiix.

Anno diu^ lxxxiiii.
CLetus a martyr was pope.xi. year this Cletus was a Romayn and gretely beloved
pylgrymages to saints saying it was more profit to the health of man's
soul to visyte the place yt saint peter was in than ^or to fast two year. He
cursyd all tho men lettynge such pylgrymages / or counselors contrary
thereto. At the last he was martryd by Dami^^an the Emperor. Titus sone to
Vespasianus was Emperor this time and reigned three year. And he abode stylle at
Jerusalem after the eleccyon of his fader and destroyed the cytee. And slew
there as the storye says with battle and hungre.xi. hodred thousand Jews
And a hundred thousa^de he took and sold.xxx. for a penny. By cause they sold
Christ for.xxx. pens / and brought thens all thing that was precious / and put
them in his house at Rome which was called Te^plu^ pacis / But now is that
place fall down for ye most party / and all these great Iewelles ben
dystrybuted to certain chirches in Rome. This Titus was so full of virtue that
all men loved him / so set forth / that they called him the most delectable of
men. He was full lyberall to all me^ in so much that he said often times / ye
there should no man goo from an Emperor with an heavy heart / but he should some
what have of his petycyon. He would be sorry that day in the which he had
granted no man no benefyte. when that he was deed every man yt was in Rome
wept for him / as that they had lost their fader. Domician brother to Titus
reigned after him.xxiiii. year and.v. months. First he was ^asy / and after
ward full unreasonable For much of ye Senate was destroyed by his malice / and
also much of his kynred. He began the second persecuco^n after Nero against
christian men / in the which persecucion John^ the euangelyst was exiled in to
Pathius after the Emperor had put him in to a tonne of oil bre^nynge and
hurt him not. So this man was not the follower of his fader Vespasian / ne his
brother Titus / but rathur like Nero and his kyn read. And for these wicked
condicyo^s he was slain in his own palace at Rome in the.xxvii. year of his
aege^ Clemens a martyr was pope.ix. year and he succeeded Cletus. This Clemens
first of saint Peter was ordained to be successor to him. And for peril he
would Linus and Cletus should be popes and fore him / lest that through that
ensample prelates should ordeyne under the^ who some ever they would. This man
made ye life of martyrs to be written by regyons. And he made many books He
ordained that a child should be confermed as soon as it might / namely after
it was crystened. And at ye last he was martred under Traian. Nerua was
Emperor after Domician oo year and two months. And when he was chosen he
meued the Senate to make a law / that thing which Domician commanded to be
kept should be broken / By the which mean saint Johan the eua^gelyst was
losed out of his exyl: and suffrey to come again to Ephase. This man did an
other thing right comendable that he assigned so wise a man as Traian was to
govern the people after him. Nota. Traianus Hispanicus was Emperor.xxi. year.
This Traianus many man said. He was the best among all the Emperors: But in
one thing alone he was vicious In so much as he for the love of the false
gods was about to destroy ye christian faith. Iugyng in himself so most to
please god. Some men say not by himself but by other he pursewed the christian
faith: and in ye end of his life he did but few to death. And all his loving
Isette at naught. But at saint Gregory meued with pity weeping: and prayed unto
our lord for him: that he would have mercy upon him and by his prayer have him
out of hell: in to which place he was dampened. And now if that he be saud or
not: a great alteracyon is among doctors. And to us yt write Crony eles: it
is no part of our charge to determyn. But all the eest part of ye world.
Babylon. Selencia: the utter parts of the ynde. Germayne the second after
Alexander held under. In all these things so pyteous and so mekely he guyded
him to every man as a king. He was gentle: and to no man vnge^tyll: the
which is read of few: All his days he lived that men said he was the most
worthy man in all his Empire. And thought and said ever more: that no man was
more unworthy to be Emperor than he.

Anno dm^.C.iiii.
ANacletus a martyr was pope ^ix year And he. was a Greek. He monysshed an
cryste^ men: that priests should be worshypped above all other men. Saying:
that priests doing sacrifyce to god should be borne out and not vexed: but be
worshypped. And priests when they said mass the should have wyenesse with them
and namely bishops Also he decreed that clerks should were no berdes nor long
here. Also that a bishop should be consecrated of three: and diverse other
thing. At the last the.xii. year of Traianus he was martred and buried by the
body of saint Peter. Plinius the second Orator and phelosopher wrote much
things. This man meued Traianus that he should wythdrawe the sentence yeuen
ayeste christian folk: written to him that they should do no ylle but take heed
to the virtue: But that they should rise before day and worshoppe there god
secretly in the nyght^ Euaristus a Greek and a martyr was pope.x. year and.vii.
months after Anacletus. This man ordained that man and woman should be wedded
openly: and that they should be blessed openly of the priest and fader and
mother. And he was martred ye third year of Adrian and buried by saint Peter.
Alexander a Romayn was pope.viii. year and.v. months. This Alexander the
most part of the Senators he conuerterd unto our lord And he constytuted
and ordained / that holy water should be spynkled in to christian me^nes houses.
And he ordained that the bread that prestes use to sing with should be made of
pure and clean bread and that in a little quantyte. At the last he was martred
under Adryan that was the Emperor. And many of them he converted to the faith.
Sixtus a Romayn was pope.x. year and.iii. months. This man ordained (Sanctus
Sanctus Sanctus. etc^) Should be said in the mass. And that the holy things
of the church should not be touched but of mynysters of ye church. Also that
the corporax should not be made of sylke / but of pure lynnen clothe wouen /
and not dyed and that a woman should not touch the holy / vessel of the a
wter / ne the palle. Also he ordained / that yfony bishop were vacant / that
no bishop should be received in to his benefyce but with the popes letters.
Also that no mass should be said but upon an a wter / and at the last he was
martred. Adrianus was emperor.xxi. year This Adriani many things is co^me^
deed to christian men / other will he was gracious / and certain of them that
would not do sacryfyce to the false gods he slew. He was an universal man
all most in all science. Peace he had all his days / but with the Jews and
many a law he made. And then he commanded that christian men should not be
dampened to death but with due process. Jerusalem he subduded again / and
forbadde that no Jew should dwell therein by no wise. Criste^ me^ he suffered
there to dwell. Against his will he came to the Empire / But he governed him
very well. wha^ ye senators prayed him to call his sone Emperor after him /
He said / it is not ynoughte to me that against my will I have reigned which I
have not deserved. For ye emperourus of Rome should go by succession of blood /
but to such men as have deserved it through their merytes. Many times he reigned
vnuertuously that is a king borne / and virtue should come before his kingdom.
Eustachius other wise called Placidus and Therospita his wife / and two of there
sons / of whom merueyllous things ben read / were martred by the
commandment of Adrian. This Placidus was master of the Emperors knights
Jerusalem was restored by Adrian and made larger / so that the place where
Christ deyed was within the walls / the which was without before. And this is
the third buyl dynge again of that cite / for yt was thryes destroyed. Of the
Caldees in the time of zedethee / of Anthyocus in the time of Machabeorum / and
of Tytus in the time of Vespacian.

Anno dm^.C.xliiii.
THelesporus a Romayne was pope.xi. year this man ordained this angels ympne
to be song in the mass (Glorya in excelsis deo etc^) and the gospel to be
read before the sacrynge / and o^ Crystemasse day three masses to be song. And
he ordained there should no mass be song be fore three of the clock. And at
the last he was martred and buried at saint Peters^ Ignyus a Greek was pope
four year. This man ordained that a child should have a god fader and a god
mother at the time of baptysynge: and also one at confyrmaco^n. Also that no
Archebysshop / except the pope shalde condemn his Suffrygan but if the cause
were showed in the prouyncyal counsel of bishops. Then^e he was martred and
buried at saint Peter's. Anthonius Pius was Emperor.xxii. year with his sons
Aurolio and Lucio This man was myghtly wise and naturelly fair of speech / the
which lightly in oo man is not found Noto. Exceeding men in wysdom comynly
are not fair speched / nor peasfull namely of nature / ne contrayous.
Exceeding men in fair speech come^ly are less than wise. This man was meued
with both these proprytees. Therefore many kingdoms the which receded from
other Emperors wylfully to this man turned again. And to christian men was no ne
so gentle. He said thrught the ensample of Cipio. I had lever keep one
hereof a man / than slay an hundred of mine enmyes. And some martyrs were made
under him / but they were made under the co^moundemente of the Emperors before.
And the crygen people were so hateful unto the bishops and to the priests
of ye Temple of the false gods: that they provoked the princes always ayenste
them. For they supposed that the christian faith should destroy them Therefore
it was no merualle: all though the price was vnpleased: for they said All there
gods were deuyllesy^ lower Iuges pursued christian folk and mar^ed: them. This
time.x. thousand martyrs. were crucyfyed in Arminea / in an high hylle called
Arath. Pompeius trogus isto tempore historias a nino vsque ad octauianu^
deduxit.

Anno dm^.C.liiii.
PIus ytalicus was pope.xi. year. and.iiii. months and.xv. days / This man
ordained the feast of Eester ever more should be hallowed on the sunday. And
also an heretyke coming fro the sect of the Jews should be received and
baptized. Then he was martred and buried in saint Peter. Anicetus was pope
after Pius almoost.x. year / this man made many decrees of the Canon and for
bishops (vt in cause violatores. etc^. Galienus a leche gotten in Pergamo was in
great fame at Rome. The which not alonly expowned the books of ypocras but he
put many of them to his books. And of this man is said / for his discrete
abstynence the which he used / he lived an hundred and.xl. years. He never ete
nor drank his fylle. Nota abstinenciam. He never took raw fruytes. Always he
had a sweet brethe. He deyed all only through aege and no sykenesse. Marcus
Anthonius the true / and Lucius Comodus were Empyrours.xix. year. These took
the Empire after Anthony the meke / and then began two Emperors to regne /
but Lucius Comodus decessed. And Anthom was Emperous a lone / the which was a
victorious man and a noble / but that he made the fourth persecucion to kylle
cryste^ men. This Marcus was of so great sadness and steadfastness / ye for no
chance he lough never / ne changed no chere / another for gladness ne for
sorrow. And when he was a child / he was of such manhood / that on a certain
time wha^ he looked his tresour / and had not that which he might give his
knights and his men when he went to fight ayenste the Germayns / the Sclauous
/ and Sarmatus / he would hurt ne grieve no body / but had lever to selle his
wives golden vessel and her arayment / her beddynge / and all her ryall stuff
/ than take tax of the Sena^ours / or of his prouynce under him But he gate
the victory of his enmyes / and recovered all again / and released the
prouences or there trybutes. And those that would selle him his wives tresour
again he restored them there money / and those that would not / he never grieved
them. But the tables of there dettes betwixt him and them he brent openly in the
market place and thanked them / that they helped him in his necessyte.

How king Luie reigned after his fader / that was a good man / and after he
became christian.
AFter this king Coill reigned Lucie his sone: that was a good man to god and
to all the people. He sent to Rome to Eulentre yt then was pope: and said. He
would become a christian man and receive bap^ym in the name of god and torn to
the right faith and believe. Eulentre se^te two Legates / yt were called Pagan:
an other Elybam in to this land and baptized the king and all his meyne And
after went from town to town and baptized the people till all the land was
baptized. And this was in the year an hundred.lvi. after the Incarncyon of our
lord Ihesu christ. And this king Lucie made tho in this land two
Archibysshops: one at Caunterbury an other at york and other many bisshops
that yet be^ in this land And when these two Legates had baptized all this
land: they ordained prestes for to baptyse chyldern: and for to make the
sacrament: and after they went again to Rome. And the king dwelled in his
land: and reigned with much honor.xii. year: and after deyed and lies at
Gloucestre.

How this land was long without a king: and how Brytons chose a king.
THis king Lucie had none heir of his body begote^: that was after ward great
harm and sorrow to the land. For after this king Lucies death: none of the
great lords of the land would suffer an other to be king: but lived in war
and debate among them self.l. year without king. But it befell after ward
that a great prince came from Rome i^ to these land that was called Seuerie:
not for war but for to save the right of Rome. But never theles he had not
dwelled half a year in this land but that the Brytons slew him. And when
they of Rome wist that Seueri was so slain: they sent an other great lord in
to this land that was called Allec that was a strong man and a mighty of body
and dwelled in this land long time and did much sorrow to the Brytons. So
that after for pure malice: they chose a king among them that was called
Astelepades. And assembled a gr^aee host of Brytons: and went to London to
seek Allec: and there they found him and slew him and all his fellows. And
one that was called walon deffended him fyersly: and fought long with the
Brytons but at the last he was dyscomfyted and the Brytons took him and bond
his hondes and feet and cast him in to a water. wherefore that water was called
ever more walbroke. Tho reigned Astelepades in peace: till one of his Earls that
was called Coill made a fair town ayenste the kings will: and let call the
town Colchestre after his own name. wherefore the king was full wroth and
thought to destroy him And began to war upon him and brought great power of
men and yaf the Earl battle. And the Earl defended him fyersly with his power
and slew the king himself in that battle. And tho was Coill crowned and made
king of this land. This Coill reigned and gouerened the land well and nobly /
for he was a noble man and well be loved amonged the Brytons. when tho of Rome
herd that Astelepades was slain: they were wonder glad: and sent an other
great prince of the Romans yt was called Co^stance. And he came to ye king
Coill for to challenge the trybute that was wo^te to be paid to Rome. And ye
king answered well and wisely and said: that he would pay to Rome all that
right and reason would with good will. And so they accorded tho with good will
and without any co^take. And so both they dwelled togyd in love. King Coill
yaaf to him his daughter Eleyne for to have her to his spowse / that was both
fair and wise and good and well lettred. and this Co^stance spowsed her there
with much honor. And it befell soon after that this king Coill deyed in
the.xiii. year of his regne / and lies at Colchestre entyred

Of king Constance that was a Romayne that was chosen king after ye deeh of
Coill for as much that he had spwsed Eleyne that was king Coils daughter.
AFter this king Coill Constance was made king and crowned / for asmoche as
he had spowsed king Coils daughter that was heir of that land. The which
Co^stance reigned well and worthily governed ye land And he begat on his wife
Eleyne a son that was called Consta^tyne. And this king bare true faith. And
truly did unto them of Rome all his life. And when he had reigned.xv. year / he
deyed and lies at york.

How Co^sta^tine that was ki^ge Consta^ce sone / and the sone of Saint Eleyne
governed and ruled the land / and was Emperor of Rome.
AFter king Constance death reigned Constantyne his sone and the sone of saint
Eleyne that found the holy cross in the holy land. And how Constantyne be
came Emperor of Rome. It befell so in ye time there was an Emperor at Rome
that was a Sarrasy and a tyrant / yt was called Maxence / that put to death
all that byleued i^ god and destroyed holy church by all his power and
sleweall Christian mi^ that he might find And among all other he let martyr
Saint Katheryne. And many other christian people that had dread of death fled
and came in to this land to king Constantyne. And told him of the sorrow
that Maxence did to the Crystyanytee wherefore Constantyne had pity / and made
great sorrow / and assembled a great host and a great power and went over unto
Rome / and there took the cite and slew all that there was i^ that were of
mysbyleue that he might there ^ynde / And tho was he made Emperor and was a
good man and governed him so well that all ^ondes to him were attendaunt for to
be under his gouernaunce^ And this devil and ty^aun Maxence that time was in
the land of Gre^e / and herd these tydyngs / and suddenly became wood / and
suddenly he deyed and so he ended his life. when Constantyne went from this
land unto Rome: he took with him his mother Eleyne / for the much wisdom
that she could / and th^e other great lords that he much loved / ye one was
called Hoell an another was called Taberne / and the third Morhyn And took
alhys land to keep unto the Earl of Corn wayle that was called Octauyan. And
so anon as this Octauyan wyste that his lord dwelled at Rome. Inco^tynent he
seized all the land in to his hand / and therwyth did all his will among
high and low and they hellde him for king. when these tidings came to
Constantyne the Emperor: he was wonder worthee toward the Earl Octauyan And
sent Taberne with ^xii.M. men for to destroy the earl for his falsenesse. And
they arrayued at Por tesmouth. And when Octauyan wist that he assembled a great
power of Brytons and dyscomfyted Taberne and Taberne fled thens in to
Scotlonde. and ordained there a great power / and came ayne in to this land
another time to give battle to Octauian. when Octauian herd that / he
assembled a grate power and came to ward Taberne as much as he might / so
that those two hosts met togyders upon Stanesmore / and strongely smote
together / and tho was Octauian dysco^fyted / and fled thens unto Norwaye. And
Taberne seassed all the land in his hand / towns and castelles / and as
much as they there had. And syn Octauian came again from Norwaye with a great
power and seized all the land in his hand and drove out all the Romans ^ and
was tho made king and reigned.

How Marimian yt was the Emperors cosyn of rome spowsed Octauians daughter and
was made king of this land.
THis Octauian governed ye land well and nobly / but he had none heir save a
daughter that was a young child that he loved as much as his life And for as
much as he wered syke and was in point of det / and might no longer regne /
he would have made one of his neuewes to have be king / the which was a noble
knight and a strong man that was called Conan Mer^edok^ and he should have
kypte the kings daughter and have married her when time had been. But the lords
of the land would not suffer it / but yaaf her counsel to be married to some
high man of great honor and then might she have all her lust / and the
counsel of the Emperor Constantyne her lord. And at this counsel they
accorded / and chose tho Cador of Cornewaylle for to go to the emperor for to
do this message. And he took the way and went to Rome / and told the
Emperor this tidings well and wisely. And the Emperor sent in this land
with him his own cosyn that was his uncles sone a noble knight and a strong /
yt was called Maximian. And he spowsed Octauians daughter / and was crowned
king of this land.

How Maximian that was themperours cosyn / conquered the land of Armorycam /
and yaaf it to Conan Meriedok.
THis king Maximian became so ryall that he thougt to conquer the land of
armory came for the great richesse that he herd tell yt was in that land / so
that he ne life man that was of worthynes / knight / squere ne none other man /
that he ne took with him to the great damage to all the land. For he left at
home behind him no man to keep the land / but took them with him fro this
land.xxx. thousand knights that were doughty men's bodies / and went over
to the land of. Armorycam and there slew the king yt was called Imball / and
conquered all the land. and when he had so done / he called Conan and said.
For as much as king Octauian made you king of Brytayne / and through me ye
were let and dystroubled that ye were not king. I give you this land of
Armorycam / and you there of make king. And for as much as ye be a. Bryton. I
well that this land have the same name / and no more be called Armoricam / but
be called Brytayne. And the land from whens we be comen shall be called much
Brytayne And so shall men know that one Brytayne fro thae other. Conan
Meriedok thanked him greatly / and so was he made king of little Brytayne. And
when all this was done. Maximian went from thens unto Rome / and tho was made
Emperor after Constantyne. And Conan dwelled still in little Brytayne with
much honor / and there let ordeyne.ii. thousand ploughmen of the land for
to culture the land to harow it and for to sow it and feffed the^ rychely
after yt they were. and for asmoche as king Conan and none of his knights ne
no^e of his othere people would not take wives of ye nacio^ of france / he tho
sent in to great. Brytayne to the earl of Cornewayle that me^ called dionothe
that he should these thorugh out all this land.xi.M. of maidens. That is to
say.viii.M. for the mean people / and.iii^M. for the grettest lords that
should them spowse. And when Dyonoth understood this / he made a commandment
thorughout all the land of Brntayne. And as many as the nombre came to be
assembldy together of maidens / for there was no man that durst wythstande his
commandments / for as much that all the land was take him to ward and
keep / to do all thing that him good lyked. And when these maidens were
assembled / he let them come a fore him at London. And let ordeyne for them
ships hastily / and as much as them neded to that vyage. And took his own
daughter that was called Vrsula that was the fairest creature that any man
wist. And he would have sent her to konge Conan / that should have spowsed her
and made her queen of the land But she had made pryuely to god a vow of
chastyte / that her fader not wist / ne no^e other man else that was living
upon earth

How Vrsula and.xi. thousand maidens that were in her company went to ward
little Brytayne / and all they were martrde at Colayne.
This Vrsula chose unto her company.xi. thousand maidens / that of all other
she was lady and meystresse And all they went to ship at one time in the
water that is called Tamyse / and commanded her kynne and her friends to
almighty god / and saylled to ward little Brytayne. But when they were come in
to the high see / a strong tempest arose as it was gods will / and vrsula
with her ships and her compny were drive to Hundlonde through temstpe / and
arrived in the haven of the cite of Coleyne And the king of the land that was
called Gowan / was tho in the cytee^ And when he wist the tidings / that so
many fair maidens were there arrived: He took Elga his broher and other of his
household with him and went to the ships to see that fair company. And when
he saw them so fair: he and his company would have ouerlayne them and take
fro them there mayndehode. But Vrsula that good maid coumseylled: prayed:
warned: and taught them that were her fellows that they should defend them
with all their might: and rather suffer death tha^ suffer there body to be
defoyled. So that all tho maidens became so steadfast in god: that they
defended them thrughe his grace: so that none of them had power to do them
shame. wherefore the king Gowan was sore anon that he for wrath slew them
euerychone anon right: and so were all tho maidens martred for the love of
god: and lies at Coleyne.

How king Gowan came for to destroy this land and how a man of great power
that was called Gracian deifended the land.
AS all this was done king Gowan that was a Sarrasyn called his brother. Elga
and said to him: that he should go conquer the land that all those fair
maidens were borne in. And he ordened tho a great power of Pehites of denmark
of or^e^ay and of Norway^ And they came in to this land: and burnt towns and
slew folk: and cast a down chirches and houses / and ^obbed all the land in
length and bread and put to death all tho that would not forsake the right
believe and crystendome / for as much as there was no sovereign that might them
help. For the king Maximian had take with him all the worthy men when he went
to conquer little. Brytayne And in the same time ye ye here now tell was
saint Albon martryd through the wo^d tyr^^^ Dyoclesyan / in the same place where
is now^ an abbaye made of saint Albon whiles that he was a paynym. But he
converted him to god through the predicacyon of clerk and a wise man that was
called. An^^ble that was ^^rbourghed a night in his house. And this was after
thyn carnacyon of Ihesu Christ ^ii. hundred.xxvi. year. And men shall
understand that saint. Albon suffered his martyrdom before that saint Edmonde
was martryd and therefore is saint. Albon called the first martyr of England.
This Gowans brother and his folk that were sarrasyns went through the lord and
destroyed al thing that they found and no thing they spared^ when these
tidings came to rome how ye king Gowan had begone for to destroy this land /
ye Emperor of come sent a strong man and of great power that was called
Gracian with ^xxiiii.M. well fighting men for to cast out those sarrasyns of
this land. And all they arrived at Portsmouth. Maximian might not come himself
/ for as much. as he was chosen Emperor after the death of Constantyne that
was Saint Eleyns sone. when this Gracian was arrived with his host / he let
sapye preuely where king Gowan might be found. And he set upon them suddenly
as they lay in their beds / and disco^fyted him and slew them in there
beds euerychone / that none of them escaped / sauff Gowan that fled in to
his own country with much sorrow and great pain. Soon after it befelle
that Maximian was slain at Rome thrughe treason. And when Gracian wyste that
tydynge he let crown him king of this land.

How Gracian made him king when Maximian was slain / and after ward the
Brytons slew him for his wickedness.
THis Gracian when he began to regne he became so wicked and so stern / and
so much sorrow did to the Brytons yt they slew him among them. Tho when
king Gowan understood yt Gracian was slain and done to death he assembled a
great power and came again in to this land. And if he had first done harm tho
did he much more. For tho destroyed he all this land / and the christian people
that were in much Brytayne so that no man was so hardy for to name god / and
he that so did anon he was put to strange death. But ye bishop of London that
was that was called Gosselim escaped / and went thens to them of Rome to seek
socour / to help to dystroy the sarrasyns that had destryed this land. And
the Romans said / that they had been so often enoyed for there sendinge people
in to Brytayne all for to help the Bryto^s / and they would no more so do /
and so the Bishop Gosselin went thens without any socoure or help. And tho
went he to the king of little Brytane that was called Aldroye / and this was
ye third king after Gowan Meryedok / as before is said. The bishop prayed
this Aldroye of help and socoure / and the king had pity in his heart when he
herd how the bishop fled / and how that the christian men were so slain in
great. Brytayne through ye paynyms and sarrasyns / he granted him co^stantyne
his brother him for to help with power of folk. And then did arraye horse
armor and ships and al things that neded to that vyage. And wha^ al thing
was ready / he called ye bishop / and to him said I take you here Co^stantyne
my brother upon this couenau^^. That if god give him grace the paynems and that
sarrasins to destroy yt ye then make him king. And the bishop granted with
good will. Constantyne and the bishop took leave of ye king Aldroye and betoke
him to god and took men.xii. thousand and went to there ships and saylled to
ward great Brytayne and arrived at Totnesse. when the Brytons herd these
tidings that to the^ came socoure / they were strongely helped / and ordained
the^ an huge no^bre of people and came to them and received them with much
honor. Gowan anon as he wist of these tidings / he assembled all ye
Sarrasyns and came against them and yaue the^ battle. An^ Co^stantyne slew him
with his own ho^des. And all those other Sarrasyns were dyscomfyted and slain
that no^e of them escaped but those that were converted unto almighty god.

How Constantyne that was the kings brother of little Brytayne was crowned
king of great Brytayne / for his great virtue and his great worthynesse.
Anon after ye battle they went to London and crowned there Co^stantyne and
made him king of this lord. And ye bishop Gosselyn set the crown on his
heed and anointed him / as it befalls for a king to be. And tho began
crystendome again in this land / And anon this king Constantyne as he was
crowned. Anon after he spowsyd his wife through counsel of ye Bryto^s And he
begat three sons on her. The first was called Co^stance and that other
Aurilambros / and ye third Vter. This Co^stance the elder brother* when he came
to aege he made him a monk at wynchestre. This Constantyne their fader
through treason was slain For it befell on a time that a Pehite came to him upon
a day in message as yt were. And said that he would speak with ye king preuely
in counsel. The king let void his chamber of the men yt were there with in
/ and there abode no moo but yt king and the Pehite. and he made a cou^tenau^ce
as though he would have spoken with the king in his eere. And there he slew
him with a long knyf. And after that he went meruaylously out of the chamber
in to a another chamber so at ye last no man wist where he was become. when the
kings me^ wist that their lord was so deed they made then so much sorrow
that they wist not what to do. For as much as his two sons Aurilambros and
Vter were so young / that they might not be king / and the third was a monk
as is said before. But Vortiger that was Earl of westsex thought preuely in
his heart thrugt queyntaunce for to be king himself. And went to wynchestre /
where that Constance was monk / and said unto him. Constance said he / your
fader is deed and your two brethern that been with Gosselyn ye bishop of London
to nourysshe be so young / ye none of the^ may be king. wherefore I counsel you
/ yt ye forsake your habyte and come with me. And I shall make such a mean
unto ye Brytons / yt ye shall be made king.

Of Constance that was king Consta^tynes sone / that was a monk at wynchestre
and how he was made king after his faders death thorugh counseyll of Vortyger
that was Earl of westsex / for as much a Aurylmabros and Vter his two brethern
were but young of aege. And Vortyger let slay him for to be king himself.
This Vortyger cou^selled this Constance so much / till he forsook his abbot
and went with him. And anon after he was crowned king by thassent of the
Brytons. This king Constance when he was crowned and made king / he wist ne
knew but little of the world ne cude nothing what knyghthode axed^ And he
made vortiger his chyef master and cou^seyller / and gaf him all his power /
for to-ordeyne and do as much as to ye reame aperteyned. So that himself no
thing entermedled but only bare the name of king. when Vortiger saw that he
had all the land in his ward and gouernall / he thought a preuy treason to
slay Constance the king / that he might him self be crowned and made king and
regne. And let send after an ho^dred kynghtes of Pehites the worthyest of all
ye land / and them held with him for to dwell \ as to be kepers of his body
as he would goo thorugh the land to ordeyne things that apperteyned to a
king. And this Vortiger honored so much the hundred kynghtes and so much
yaue them of gold and silver and so rich Iewelles / robes horses and other
things plente / wherefore they held him more lord than they did the king.
And Vortyger told them / if he might be king / ye as it were through treason /
he would make them rychest of the land. So at the last through great gifts
that he had given largely they cried through the court that Vortyger were beter
worthy to be king than Constance. wherefore Vortiger made semblaunt as he had been wroth. And he departed thens from the court: and said he must goo else
were for things that he had to do. And so the traitor said for by cause
that they should slay him: that is to say Constance. when this Vortyger was
gone: yt befell soon after: yt tho hundred kynghtes of Pehyces brake the
doors of the kings chamber and there they him slew: and smote of his heed
and bare it to Vortiger there that he dwelled. And so when vortiger saw that
heed he wept full tenderly with his eyes: and never theles he was some deal
glad in his berte of his deth^ And anon this vortiger took those hundred
kenghtes of Pehytes: and badde his servants bind their hondes behind them:
and ladde them to London: and there they were dampened unto death as falls
traitors. And anon after all the Brytons of the land by the common assente
crowned vortiger and made him king of the land

Anno dm^.C.lxxiiii.
SOther a martyr was pope after Anycetum.ix. year the which decreed that a
Nonne should not touch the pale of the awter: nor put in sense thereto. And
that she should were a wymple about her heed. And many perils he saw about
matrymony. Therefore he ordained that no woman should be callen a lefull wife:
but if she were blessed of the priest. Elentherus a martyr was pope after
Sother.xv. year: the which ordained that christian men should refuse no meet
reasonable that was man's mete (Nota) Also that no man vnaccused in crime:
should be put from his dygnytee or degree till he were conuycted: thorugh
ensample of christ the which kept still Judas Scaryoth not accused: and Crist
knew him gylty. And what someuer he did among the apostles for the dygnyte
of his service abode ferme and stable^ And he sent also Legates unto Lucie the
king of Brytayne: the which baptized him and his people. And Fagus and Domianus
legate: the which the pope sent first: preched in England and this
crystendome dured in Brytayne two ho^dred year: unto the time of Dyoclesyan the
Emperor when saint Albon was martred. Marcus Anthonius: and Lucius Comodus
were Emperors / but Marcus deyed anon / and Lucius Comodus reigned. Comodus
was called prouffytable of scorn / for he was to every man vnprouffytable. He
was yeuen utterly to lechery. Many Senators and Christian men he made to be
slain. He dampened his own wife to death for aege. He deyed a sodeyne death with
struglynge among maidens. Helius Pertinax after this man was Emperor.vi.
months / and was a man of great discrecyon / whom Julian the great lawer
slew. And he entered the Empire / and was slain the.vii. month of Seuerus.
Victora martyr was pope after Elentheriu^.x. year. and for ye discord of the
paschall time he called a counsel i^ Alexand where he was present yt time /
and many other / where he decreed that Eesters day should be kept on the
Sunday but he must kept the change of the moon of Apryll and that was to
dyfferre fro Jews for many bishops of the eest abode that time / the same
day that the yewes did halowe that feast. Also he ordained yt in the time of
need / childern mystht be cristened in every place / and in every water.
zepherinus a martyr and a Romayne was pope after victor.ix. year. This man
ordained that Christian people of.xii. year of aege and above / should receive his
god on Eeester day ones oo year. also he ordained that all the vessels of the
awter should be glass or tynne / and not tree / as in old time the
consecracyon of ye glorious blood was made in tree vessell^ And this time past
/ and the worship of the church grew / and glasen vessel were forbode (Vt
patet de conse. de pri. ca.) Origenes the noble clerk was this time / and he
wrote so much / that saint Jerome said I have read of Origenes works.iiii.
thousa^de volimes without pystles. He translated the Bible from Hebrwe in to
Greek / and did many other great things. And of this Origenes Sampson.
Solomon / and Traian / is a great question among doctors if yt they ben
dampened or saved. Therefore those things yt with out perell we ben not bound
to know nor the church is not certifyed of them. And therefore let them
alonly committed unto god. Calistus a martyr and a Romayne was pope after
zepherinus ^o. year / and he ordained the Cimiteri (in via apia) where many a
thousand martyr is buried. Also he ordained the feast of the Eemerynge days
to be kept. Anthonius Aurelius was Emperor.iii. year. And this man lacked no
kind of lechery / and at the last he was slain among a great multitude of
people / for his myscheuous living. Anthonius Marcus reigned after him.vii.
year. This man lived abstynatly / and therefore he was slain as was his
predecessor. Alisander was Emperor after Anthonius and reigned.xiii. year This
man at the Instau^ce of his mother a christian woman and ye techyng of Origenes /
ye which came to Rome to convert her / was made so good unto christian men yt
he suffered them to have there cou^seylles and their prayers by themself / but
nevertheless in this time the cursed officers of him made many martyrs.

Anno dm^.CC.xliiii.
VRbanus was pope after Calistus.viii. year / and old and young he was very
virtuous. And all the hallowed vessels of the church he made of gold or
silver. This man left his popehede and went to Agryppa and.xi. thousand
virgyns with him. And ye clergy said he left not his dygnytee for holiness
but for appetyte of tho virgyns / and wrote him not in the book of popes. And
there he a virgyn was martred with those virgins. Poncianus a martyr succeeded
Vrbanus. And he ordained that psalms should be soyde day and night in the
church of god. And that a priest should say Confite or before the mass.
Anteros a martyr was pope after this man / this man ordained that a bishop
might be remeued from one unto an other. And he made the life of martyrs to be
written. And he was slain and buried in the Cimitery of saint Calixt Maximianus
was chosen Emperor act Magu^cia of the host / and not by ye Senators and
reigned three year / and destroyed the church myghtely / and was slain for
Origene. Gordian reigned after him.vi. year / and of him is little written / but
he was slain (Hiis diebus Celus dux Colchestrie in asclepio regnat in
britannia annis quasi.xxx. vsque ad aduentum Constancii. Lati.M. vacat) Phylyp
was Emperor after him / and this Phylyp chose to him Phylyp his sone / and
they reigned.xvii. year: and were the first Emperors yt were crystend: and
after slain of the host: They be queued all there tresour in there death: yt it
should be dysposed to poor men. And saint Laurence at the assygnacyon of his
master the pope departed this tresour about Rome / the which was great cause
of his martyrdom (Vt quide^ dicunt) Decius was Emperor three year / and in all
things a tyrau^t. For he entered thempyre when he and the host had slain the
two Philyppes his lords and after that he was slain with his sone. Fabianus a
martyr and a Romayne was pope after Anteros.xii. year / this was a very holy
man. For when Christian men stood to abide the eleccyon of the pope / suddenly a
white douue or a culuour descended on his heed / saying unto him / thou shall
be pope of Rome. This man ordained every year ye Creme should be hallowed upon
Sherethursdaye. Also he divided regyons to deakens the which should write the
life of maetrys. And at the last Dicitus slew him. Cornelius a martyr and
Romayne was pope after Fabianus.iii. year. This man took up the bodies of Peter
and Poul / and with great honor put them in worshypfull places with beata
Lucina^ Lucius was pope after Cornelius three year / and of him little is
written. Gallus with his sone Volucianus were Emperors two year / and they
fought with Emilianus / and were slain And Emilianus the third month was
slain Valerian was Emperor with his sone Galyene.xv. year. This man was
virtuous and manly in the beginning / but after was given to vice / and much
wrytchednesse. And so was his sone Galiene. This valerian went unto the land
of Perse. And therefore ye great blod of martyrs which he had shed was taken
of the king of Perse. And when he had take him he put out both his eyes and
kept him in great bondage. And to this entente he kept him / that when so ever
he should ride / this Veferian shall be lie down / and he should set his leet
upon his back when he would take his horse. This herd Galiene his sone yt was
left at Rome. And that caused him that he was not so cruel against Christian
men. And here was the.viii. persecucyon of the church made by the Emperor.
And made ye Romans to lose there kingdoms / the which were never recouerd
again to the emperor / And general pestelence was through out all ye world for
there trespass. Stephanus a martyr after Lucius was pope.iii. year / this man
ordained that no man should use none hallowed clothes but to ye worship of god.
Sixtus a martyr and a Romayne was pope after Stephanus two year. This man
ordained that the mass should besayd upon an awter the which before was not /
and then he deyed. Dyonisius a Romayne was pope after him two year. This man
divided parysshes and chyrcheyardes / and assygned to chyrches certain priests.
Felix a martyr was pope after Dyonisius two year. He ordained that for the
memory of martyrs masses should be said. Also he ordained the Dedycacyon of
the church every year should be said. Claudius was Emperor after Valerian /
this emperor subdued Gothas nobly / and then he dessessed.

Anno dm^.CC.lxxiiii.
EVticianus a martyr was pope after Felix.viii. year. This man ordained that
corn and beenes should be blessed on the awter. And he buried.CCC and ^xliiii.
ma^tyrs with his own hondes. Aurelius was Emperor after Claudius.v. year this
Au^elius (...) christian men was gentle wherefore he had the victory in every
place gloryously. And when he was desceyued by cursyd men and pur^e^^d christian
men myghtly / and namely in France for there he abode / and after that he had
never good fortune. But was slain. And this was the nynth persecucyon of the
church and c^^sten faith. Tacitus was Emperor after this man / And he reigned
but three months and was slain in Ponto. Probus was Emperor after him.v

occupied with Barbaryk men. And he yaue them and Pannonias lyce^ce to have vineyards. And when he had almoost a^l things well in peace he said. Knights
with in a little time shall not be necessary: and anon after he was slain at
Sir^^iu^^ Carus and his two sons Carunus and Numerian were emperors after
Probus but some were they deed: and their fader was drowned: and the two sons
were slain: all these three reigned but.ii. year. Dyoclesian and Marimian came
after these three Emperors the one reigned in the Est: and the other in the
weste. The first thing that Dyoclesyan did: he burnt all ye christian men's
books that might be found. The two tyrauntes did more harm to Christian men
than ever did any other^ For.x. year lasted the persecucyon. And as we read.
with in ^xxx. days.xx. thousand men were slain for Crystis sake. And in
England all faith was almost destroyed in ye time of maximian Gaius was pope
after Euticianus / this man ordained that no man should accause a bishop or an
other clerk to any seculer Judge. And yt a pagon or an heretyke should not
accuse a Christian man. Also he ordained that he yt was worthy should ascend gree
by gree to his order / fyrsten Benet / than Colet / subdeacon / deacon / and
than priest. And at ye last he was martred under Dyoclesyan. Arcellinus a
martyr was pope after Gaius.xi. year and.iiii. months This man was persecuted
sore / for dread of death he of freed three corns of incense to the sacrefyce of
the ydolles. And after ward he openly repented / and suffered the pain of death
for the faith of the church of god. His body lay unburied three days for dred
of the curse of god. And after thorugh auysyon of saint peter and Marcell he
was buried at saint Peter's foot. Marcellus was pope after Marcellinus.v. year.
This man ordained that a general counseyl might not be ordained without the
auctorite of the pope (vt pz.xvii. di.c. sinodu^) Also he chose.xv. Cardynalles
in the cite to burye christian men. At the last when he had kept beestes long
time in a house closed in with them / by the commandment of Maximian / he
deyed for fault. Eusebius a martyr was after this man two months and certain
days. This man of a lay man was made pope / and he ordained that no lay
ma^sholde accuse his bishop but if he went fro his faith (vt pz.ii.ix.vii.c.
laicos) Nato. This time saint Albon was martred in Brytayne. This Albon when he
was a pagan / he lodged a certain man / the which converted him to the faith
and after was Iuged unto death. And much people he turned unto our lord /
that were nygh the water / the which he made dry through his prayer. And he
suffered death nygh ye cite of verelom (Vide plura in vita sancti Albani)
Melchiades a martyr succeeded Eusebius.iiii. year. This man forbode ye men
should fast on Sunday or on Thursdaye in so much as paganes fast on those
days. At the last he was martred as al his predecessors were. And
understand ye that there were.xxxiii. popes of Rome martred each one after
other. Peter was the first / and this melchiades was the last. And then^e it
was laudable after Gregory / a man to desire a bysshopryche. Galerius was
Emperor after Dyoclesyan two year / and an other with him called Consta^cius
So was the Empire in those days divided. This Consta^cius after he had
conquered all spain / he came in to great Brytayne / and there he wedded a
kings daughter an whom he gate great Constantyne. And this same Constancius
deyed in Brytayne / and lies at york / as Martyne says in his Chronicles /
and left on live Constantyne that was gotten on Eleyne and was king of Brytayne
and of France

Circa annu^ dm^.CCC.viii.
SIluester was pope after Melchiades. This was a glorious Confessor / and many
ways he worshipped ye church of god what in writing / what in miracles. He
recyued ye pratrymony of saint Peter. That is for to say the kingdom of ytalye
with the cite of Rome of Constantynople the Emperor / and to the worship of
the hole universal church of god he turned it. He baptized Eeleyne and the
Jews / and then he decessyd an holy Confessor Constantyne the mighty was
Emperor this time. This Constantyne was a glorious man and a victoryous in
bataylle. In gouernynge of the common people he was very wise And in the
necessyte of the believe he was with out compayre. Devout. His pity and his
holiness ben so written in the books of holy doctors / that without doubt / he
is to be nombred among Saints. And the Greeks say that in the end of his
life he was made a amo^ke. And more ey may here of him in the Chronicles of
England. For he was king in England. Helena the queen mother to Constantyne
repaired again the holy Cross this time. And she made.lxx. Colleges / and she
glorified the state of all holy church. Nicholas bishop of Myrree seete an
holy man was this time. Athanasius was this time bishop in Alexandre a
glorious doctoure / made the (symbalum Quicunque vult saluus esse. etc^. Marcus
was pope after Siluester two year and.viii. months / this man ordained the
Creed should be openly song in the church. And that the bishop of Hostience
should consecrate the pope / and that he should were a palle. Julius was pope
after Marcus.xi. year / under Constantyne the second. Constanus this man was
exiled.x. year and after suffered death under Constantyne the second.
Constantinus with his two brethern redned.xxiiii. year. And in his last end
he was perverted by the heresyet of the Arience by a bishop called Eusebe. And
he pursued ye church of god stro^gely. The end of this man was this. as he
should go to co^sta^tynople unto agret counseyll in ye which cou^cyl he thought
to have co^de^pned ye bishop and ye clerks of true believe / he went before
unto a chamber to avoid such things as nature required / and anon suddenly
his bowels fell from him / and thereby was deed as ye now here. Liberius was
pope after Julius.xix. year and.vii. months. Then was the second dyscorde
of the church between Liberyus and Felix / for the heresye of the Ariens ye
which favored Lyberyus. Then Constancyus the emperor called again Liberius
from his exyle / by cause he favored this heresye And the church deycede
Liberyus and took Felix for pope / and the other was expulsed as an heretyke of
the church. But Felyx obtained not / for the Emperor put in Lyberyus and
expulsed Felyx. Feilix was pope after the death of this Lyberyus. And he
declareed Constancyus the Emperor an heretyke and anon after he was martred.
And here was the first that ever ye church of Rome had an Infamed pope. For
all ye predecessors of this Liberyus were saints and yaue holy ensamples.
Iulymus Apostata was after Constancyus Empero ur two year and.viii. months /
He was called Apostata for he fleede this Constancius / which slew his
brother. And for fere of death was made a christian man and a monk. But after
ward by the counsel of Nygromancers / he asked ye devil whether he should
be Emperor or not. The devil said that he should be Emperor upon a
condycyon that he should forsake his christian faith and be utter enmye to
christian men And so he dode. For he yaue leave to the Jews that they should
build again the Temple in spyte of the christian men. And he took all the goods
that christian men had and destroyed many of them. Iomynyanus was Emperor after
him.viii. months. For when Iulyanus was deed the host chose him Emperor.
And he was a christian man. And he said it was not lestull to a christian man to be
lord over so many hethen people. They answered and said. Rather than he should
forsake ye Empire they would be crystened. And thus took he the dygnytee. But
soon he was deed / and in a meruayllous manner. For he was laid in a cholse
house after his Iourneye made all of stone newely whyted with lyme / in ye
which they made to his comfort as they thought a fire of charcoole^ And of
the air of these two in the morrow he was found deed. Valentinian with his
brother Valent was Emperor after Iominianus.xi. year For he departed the
Empire and gave his brother the eest / and keep himself the west part / This
Valentinian was a lord with Iulyanus Apostata. And it happed him on a time for
to goo in a Temple of false gods for to do satcrefyce. And mynystres stood
there with water hallowed after the gyse with the which they strynkled the
lords. This valentinian smote the mynyster that cast the water upon him and
said. He was rather defoyled by it than cleansed. For this Iulianus did exile
him. But our lord god for his open confession of his name rewarded him with
the Empire. His brother Valent fell in to the opinion of the Ariens and deyed
in that heresye. This same Valent lived four year after Vale^tinian with
Gracian the emperor. ^Thys time lived saint Ambrose.

Anno dm^.CCC.xliiii.
DAmacias was pope after. (...) lix.xviii. year and two mon^thes this was an
eloquent man in meter. And he wrote many stories of popes and martyrs^ He
ordained that. G^oria patri should be said in ye ends of the psalms. And that
was at the prayer of saint. Ierom. And through the mocyon of this pope. Jerome
translated the. Bible from Hebrewe in to Latin / and then he decessed a
confessor. Valence with Gracian and Valentinian were Emperors four year / In
