service of god that was defended before with Emperors enfected with heresye as
was Valens and other / wherefore the church had no lyberte when valens was on
live. A Synodus of a ho^dred and.l. bishops were gadred under Damasius pope at
Consta^tynople ayenste Macedoniu^ an heretyke / the which denied the holy
ghost to be very god. And then^e was the Creed made / that is song on holy
days in the church. Augustynus a Cartaginen^ of Africa was this time He was
as noble a Rethoricien as might ebe. And in. all phylosophye and poetrye in
comparable And all thing that any philosopher found in his yougth he
understood with little labor And about this time he was sent to Mediolanum
where he was turned anon of saint Ambrose and baptized. This man grew unto
anoble doctor of the church. And not long after that he was bishop of
yponen^. And there he lived.iiii. year / and much dyuynyte he wrote (vt patet
in librissu is) Siritus was pope ofter Damasius.xv. year / he dampened heretykes
and little else is written of him. Thodosyus sone to Gracian with vale^tyne his
uncle were Emperors.^xvii. year / This man was a christian man and gracyous /
and in governance like to Trayanus / soon wroth and anon reconsyled. This
man on a day when he would have gone to have herd mass / saint Ambrose
forbadde him the entree of ye church / till he had penance and made
satysfaccion for the sleenge of.xxx. knights the which he slew in anger at
Constantynople. wherefore they made a law that the sentence of a prince should
be deferred.xxx. days of those yt should do execusoon if they might fall in
the grace of the prince within the.xxx. days. About this time was a child
borne in the castle of Emons / from the nauyll and above divided in two bodies
/ having two heedes and two wits / so ye the one slepynge or etynge / the
other slept not neete not. And when they were two year of a ege / the one
decessyd and the other lived three days after. Claudius poeta was this time.
Arcadius and Honorius reigned.xxx. year. And in their time Rome was nere
destroyed by a king called Alaticus. Of the which destruccyon rose a great
blasphemye of the Romans. For they said they farde never well sythen Christ
came to Rome / and bereeued them there goods by the prechyng of Peter and Poul
And yet this Arcadyus subdued all his enmyes by the power of god / and shed
no blood. Ayenste this blasphemye saint Austyn made that solemn work / the
which they call (de cyuytate dei) Honorius was Emperor with Theodosius his
brothers sone.xv. year and he was a man of holy life. For two wives he had / and
yet with both he deyed mayden^ He loved specially the church and hated
heretykes. Ierom deyed this time at Bethleem the year of his aege.lxxxi.
Sanctus Heracides the which wrote Vitas patru^ to lapsn^ episcopu^ was this
time. Ioho^nes Crysostomus was exiled of Endochia the wife of Arcadius / and
through heete of the son he was deed. Anastasius was pope after Siritius three
year. This man or deyned that eueryman should stand at the redynge of ye holy
gospel. and that he that was a maimed man should not be priest. Innocencius
was pope after Anastasius / this man ordained ye syke men should be anointed
with holy oil. And at mass ye kiss of peace to be yeuen And he dampened
Pelagyen an heretyke and many other things did (vt patet.xxvi. q. i.)

Anno dm^.CCCC.xiiii.
zOzimus was pope after Innoce^cius two year and.viii. months / This man
ordained that clerks should be no tauerners ne selle no wine / and that a
bound man should be made no priest (...) the license of his lord. Bo^ (...)
Romayne was pope after zozimus four year. This man ordained that a woman
should not touch ye palle of the water ne should not wasse the awter.
Celestimus a Romayne was pope after Bonifacius.viii. year and.ix. days / the
which ordained the psalm before mass. (Iudica medeus. etc^.) And at the
beginning of the mass should be said a verse of a psalm / and at the Grayle
/ and that the Offertorye should be said before the sacrynge. This same man
sent saint Patryke to Irlonde to convert ye land and Palladius deaken of.
Rome to the. Scotts to be converted. And in the fourth year of this man there
was a general. Synody at Ephysima of three hundred bishops ayenste Nestorium
an heretyke. Theodosius the younger with valentinian his neue we reigned.xxvii.
year. In his time was the feast ordained / which is called Aduincula sancti
petri. And in his time deyed saint Austyn / in the year of his aege.lxxvi. And
this time was raised the.vii. slepers / ye which sleped two hundred years.
This man deyed at Constantynople and there was buried. This time the. Saxons
entered England / and anon by little and little they grew up myghtely. And
at the last they opteyned all the land. Sixtus a Romanyne was pope after
Celestinus.viii. year. This was a holy man and a meke And little of him is
written but ye he builded Sa^cta ma^ria mayor. Leo Tuscus a Confessor was pope
after Sixtus. This man was as holy as any man. Five times in a day or more he
would say mass. And on a time. After yt befell when a cretayne woman kyssed
his hand / he was tempted with her / And for the trespaas that he had done /
unto his penance he made his hode to be stryken of. And when the noise rose
upon him that he might not say mass as he was wont to do / then he was
right sorry. And all only betoke him in prayre to our lady to help him. And our
lady restored him his hand again and then he said mass as he was wont for
to do. And so that miracle was openly show to all people. And in the time of
this pope. Marcian the Emperor being there / was congregate at. Calcedony the
fourth universal. Synody of.vi. hundred and.xxx. bishops against. Eugicem the
abbot of. Constantynopolyton. and (Alexandrum episcopum. qui negauerunt in
chrysto veram carnem fuisse. et etiam negabant carnis nostre resurrectionem.)
And after he had made many notable sermons and epystles he decessed.
Marcianus and valentianus were Emperors this time.vii. year. In whose time was
the great. Synody before reherced / when Eusticem and Dyoscorus were condemned.

IN the time that Macianus was Emperor vortyger was king in Brytayne now
called. England. In whose time ye. Saxons came in to Brytoyne and made many
kings. That is to wit as is plain by the Cronyeles.vii And by cause it is
tedyous to man's reason to reherce many diverse names to gyder as.vii. kings
of England and in one time / the Emperors and Popes. Therefore the Chronicles
of England shall be set together tylle yt we shall treat of Alured. In whose
time the Danes came in to England. And ye Popes and ye. Emperors and other
kings deed the same time shall be se^^^ together.

Circa annu^ dm^.CCCC.xlix.
This time came ye. Saxons that were pagans first in to Brytane now called.
England under vortiger the which was crowned king of this land. This time
those yt had these two childern in kepinge ye which were Co^stantynes sons.
That is to say Aurilambros and vter / through ordynance of Gosselin that was
bishop of. London after the faders death that is to say. Constantyne durst not
dwell in this land with those childern / but conveyed them unto the king of
little Brytayne. For as much as he tho wist the treason of vortiger that tho
was made king. Thorugh who me. Constance the elder brother was slain /
wherefore the hundred knights of Pehites were put to death and bore all the
blame as that vortiger had not wist there of ne consented. And so the kepers
of those two chyldern dradde lest vortiger should put them to death through his
treason and falsenesse / As he had done the brother before. And therefore they
were ladde over in to little. Brytayn / and the king them received with much
honor and let them to nourysshe. And there they dwelled till they became
fair knights and strong and fyers. And thourght to be avenged upon
Constaunce their brother when they saw their time and so they did as ye
shall here tell after ward. It was not long after ward that ye tidings
came ouersee to ye kynred of the hundred knights of Pehites that were dampened
and put to death through Vortiger in this land / therefore they were wonderly
wroth and swore that they would be avenged of their kynnes men's death. And came
in to this land with a great power / and robbed in many places / and slew
and did all ye sorrow that they might. when Vortiger it wist / he made much
sorrow and was sore anoyed / And in an other place also tidings came to him
that Aurilambros and Vter his brother assembled a great host to came in to
much Brytayne / that is to say in to this land / for to be avenged upon
Constance their brothers death. So in that one half and in that other / he was
brougho in to so much sorrow that he ne wist whether to go.

How Engist and an.xi. thousand me^ came in to this land / to whom vortiger
yaue a place that is callde Thongcastell.
ANd soon after this sorrow / tydinges came to vortyger that a great navy of
strangers were arrived in ye country of Cent / he wist not whe^s they were ne
wherefore they were come in to this land. The king sent anon a messager
thither / that some of should come and speak with him / for to wit what folk
they were and what they axed / and in to what country they would. There were
two brethern masters and princes of that strong company / that one was called
Engist and that other Horn. Engist went to the king and told him the cause
wherefore / they were come in to this land and said. Syrewe ben of a country
that is called Saxonne / that is ye land of Germayne / wheryn is so much
sorrow / That of the people ben so many that the land may not them
susteynes. And the masters and princes that have ye land to govern and rule.
They made to come before them men and wymmen that boldest ben among them for
to fight / and that best may trauayll in to diverse lands. And so they
should them give horse and harnes / armor / and all thing that they needs.
And after they shall say to them / that they go in to an other country where
that they mowelyue / as their And cetrees did them before. And therefore sir
king / if ye have ought to do with our company: we ben comen in to your
land: And with good will you would serve your land keep help and defend
from your enmyes if that ye need. when vortyger herd these tidings: he said
gladly he would them with hold: upon such couenanuce: if they might
deliver his land of his enmyes: he would give them reasonable lo^des where
they should dwell for ever more. Engyst thanked him goodly: and in this manner
he and his company a.xi. thousand should dwell with the king vortiger. And
much they did through their boldness: they delivered his land of his enmyes
clean. Tho prayed Engyst the king of so much land that he might make to him
a Cite and for his meyne. The king answered / it was not to do without the
coancell of Brytons. Engist prayed him eftsoon of as much plyce as he might
compace with a thonge of a skyn^e whereupon he might make a. Mancer for him to
dwell in. And the king him granted freely.

Tho took Engist a bulls skin / and kytte it as sma^e as he might all in to
oo thonge all a round. And there with compaced he as much land as he might
then^e make upon a fair castle. And so when this castle was made / he let
call it Thongcastell for as much as ye place was marked with a thonge.

Of Ronowen that was Engistes douhter / and how the king Voreiger spowsed her
for her beauty.
SO when this castle was made / and full well arrayed. Engist pryuely did send
by letter i^ to ye country where he came fro / after an.C. ships filled with
men ye were strong and also well fighting in all bataylles / and ye they
should also bring with them. Ronowen his daughter that the fairest creture
that a man might see. And when those people were. come that he had sent
after / he took them in to the castle with much. Joy. And himself upon a
day went unto the king / and prayed him there worthily that he would come and
see his new maneer that he had made in the place yt he had compassed with the
thonge of the skin. The king anon granted him freely. And with him went
thither / and was well apayed with the castle and with the fair work and
together they ete and drank with much Joy. And when night came that the king-
Vortiger should go in to his chamber to take there his nyghtes rest. Ronowen
yt was Engistes daughter came with cup of gold in her hand / and kneled
before the king and said to him (wassaylle) And the king knew not what it
was for to mean ne what he should answer there upon / for as much as himself
/ ne none of all his Brytons could no English spese ne understand it / but
he spoke in the same langage that. Brytons done yet. Nevertheless a latiner
told it to the king the full understanding thereof (wassayll) and that other
should drink (hayll) And that was the first time that (wasshayll) and
(drynkhall) came up in this land. And from ye time unto this time / it is
well used in this land. The king Vortiger saw the fayrnesse of Ronowen / and
his arms laid about her neck / and thryes swetely kyssed her / and anon
right he was enamoured upon her yt he desired to have her to wife and asked of
Engist her fader. And Engist granted him upon this covenant / yt the king
should give him all the country of kent / that he there might dwell in and
his people. The king him granted pryuely with a good will. And anon he
spowsed ye damoysell / and that was much confusyon to himself. And therefore
all the. Brytons became so wroth / for by cause he spowsed a woman of
mysbyleue. wherefore they went all from him / and no thing to him took / ne
halpe him in thing that he had to done.

How Vortimer that was Vortigers sone was made king / and Engist driven out.
And how Vortimer was slain.
THis Engist went in to Kente and seized all ye land in to his hand for him
and for his men / and bycame with a little while of so great power and so
much people had / that men wyste not little time which were the kings men
and which were Engistes men. wherefore all the Brytons had of him dredde /
and said among them. But if that they ne took other counseyll between them
all the land should be bytrayed through Engist and his people. Vortiger the
king had begoten on his first wife three sons. The first was called vortimer.
The second Catagien / and the third Passent. The Brytons euerychont by one
assent chose vortimer to be their lod and sovereign / and counseyler in every
battle / and crowned him and made him king / and would not suffer vortiger no
longer to regne / for cause of the alyaunce betwixt Engist and him. The Brytons
ordained a great host to drive out Engist and his company of the land / and
yaue him three bataylles. The first was in Kente there he was lord / the
second was at. Tetforde / and the third in a shyre a this half Colchestre in
a more. And in this battle them met. Catagien and. Horn. Engistes brother
/ so that each of thym slew other^ but for as much as the country was yeuen
long before to horn through vortiger tho ^e spowsed his cosyn / there he made a
fair castle that is called Horn castle after his own name. And vortiger was
so anoyed for his brothers death / that anon he let fell down the castle to
the ground. And after he ne left night ne day till he had driven out. Engist
and his people of the land. And then^e Ronowen his daughter made sorrow ynogh.
And quen^ely spoke to them that were next the king vortimer and pryuyest with
him. And so much she gave him of gifts / that he was enpoysoned and deyed at
London the fourth year of his regne and there he lies

How the. Brytons chose an other time Vortiger to be their king / and. Engist
came in to this land / and how they fought togyders.
AFter vortimers death: the Brytons by their common asse^t eft sons made
vortiger their king upon this covenant: that he should never after suffer.
Engist ne none of his eft sons to come i^ to this land And wha^ all this was
done. Ronowen the queen pryuely sent by letter to. Engist that she had en.
poisoned vortimer: and that vortiger her lord bare again ye crown and reigned.
And that he should come again in to this land well arrayed with much people for
to avenge him upon the Brytons and for to win this land again. And when
Engist herd these tidings / he made great Joy. And appareylled him hastily
with.xv. thousand men / yt were deughty in every battle / and came in to this
land And when vortyger herd tell that. Engyst was come again with a great
power in to this land / he assembled his. Brytons / and tho went against Engyst
for to give him Battle and his folk. But Engist dradde him sore of the
Brytons for they had driven him before and discomfyted him with strength.
wherefore this Engist prayed him for a love day / and said he was not comen in
to this land for to fight / but for to have his land again if he might accord
with the. Brytons / and of them to have love and grace The king Vortiger
through counseyll of his Brytons granted him a love day. And thus it was
ordained through the Brytons / yt the same day should be holden fast beside
Salysbury upon a hylle. And Engyst should come thither with four hordred
kdnghtes without moo And the king with as many of the wysest men of his londe^
And at that day the king came with his counsel as it was ordained / but
Engist had warned his knights pryuely / and then conmaunded that every one of
them should put a long knyf in his hose. And when he said Fair syres now is
time to speak of love and peace every man Anon should draw out his kynue and
slay a Bryton. And so they slew. a M.lxi. knights / and with much sorrow
many of them escaped. And the king vortyger there himself tho was taken / and
ladde to Thongcastell and put in prison. And some of Engystes men would that
the king had be burnt all quycke And vortiger tho for to have his life /
granted them as much as they would are / and yaue up all the land towns /
castelles / cytees / and borughs to Engist and to his folk. And all the
Brytons fled these in to waiys / and there they held them still. And Engyst
went thorugh the land and seized all the land / with fraunchyles And in
every place let cast a down chyrches and houses of Relygyon / And wasted and
destroyed crystendome thrughout all this land And let ^aunge ye nam of this
land called brytayne: that no man of his were so hardy after that time to
call this lord Brytayne: but call Engist land. And then ne he departed all
the land to his men: and there made.vii. kings for to strength the land that
the Brytons should never after come therem. The first kingdom was Kent: there
that Engist himself reigned: and was lord and master over al ye other. The
other king had Southsex yt now is called chychestre The thyrdet king had
westsex. The fourth had Eestsex. The fyfth had Estangill: yt now is called
Northfolke Southfolke. Merchemeryk: that is to say therldome of Nycholl. The
sixth had Leycheter shyre. Northampton shyre. Herforde: and Huntyngdon. The
seventh had Ox enforde. Glouchestre. wynchestre. were wykeand Derbyshyre.

How that Vortyger went in to walys and began there castle yt would not
stand with out mortar tempred with blood.
AS Engist had departed all the land in this manner between his men: and in
lyuerde vortyger out of prison and suffered him freely to go whyther that he
would. And he took his way and went in to walys there that his Brytons
dwelled: for as much as ye land was strong and wicked to win. And Engyst
^neuer came therene never knew it before that land. Vortiger held him there
with his Bratons / and axed counseyll what him was best to do. And they yaue
him counseyll to make a strong castle that him might himself there in keep
and defend if need were. Ma^e sons in haste tho were fette / and began to
work upon ye hylle of Breigh / but certes thus it befell that all the work
that the masons made a day down it fell the night / and they wyste not what
it might be. There of the king was sore anoyed of that chance and wyste not
what to do. werfore he let send after the wysest clerks and also learned men
than were thorugh out walys that might be foude / for they should tell wherefore
ye fou^dament so failed under the work / and they should him tell what was
best for to do. And when these wise men long time had studied they said to
the king / that he should do seek a child borne of a woman that never had
with man to do And that child should be slain / and tempred with his blood
the mortar of the work. And so should the work ever endure withouten end.

How the king let seek. Merlyn thorugh out all walys / for to speak with him.
AS the king herd this he commanded his messagers anon to go through out
walys to seek that child if they might him find / and that they should him
bring forth with them unto him. And in record and in witness of this king
he had take them his letters that they ne were distroubled of no* man ne
let. And tho the messengers went thens / and spedde so fast that they came
in to a town that was called Carmardyne / and as they passed for the their
way they found two chyldern of.xxiiii^ year of aege thydynge together with
hasty words. And one of them said to that other Donebat said he ye do all
wrong to chyde or strive with me for ye have no wit ne no reason as I have.
Certes merlyn said he / of your wit ne your reason. I make no force. For men
tell comynly that ye have no thing of god all mighty sith ye had never fader
/ But every man knows who was your mother. The messengers of the king
vortiger when they herd the strive betwixt the two gromes they axed of them
that stood beside them whens that^ Marlyn was borne / and also whom him
nourysshed. And the folk them told / that a great gentle woman him bare in.
Carmadyne that was called Adhanr But never might noth man wit who was his
fader. when the kings messengers herd these tidings they went anon to him
that was wardeyne of the town and told him the kings will and showed him his
leter wherefore they were come thither.

Merlyn and his mother were fetched before the wardeyne of the town. And he
commanded them that they should go to the king as it was ordained by his
messagers. Merlyn and his mother went thens and came unto ye king and there
they were received with much honor. And the king axed of that lady if ye
child were her sone and whom him be gate. The lady answered full tenderly
weeping and said. She never had company of worldly man. But sir said she As
I was a young maiden in my faders chamber / and other of great lygnage were in
my company / that oftentimes went to place and solace. I belefte alone in my
chamber / would not goo ^orthe for bernnynge of the son. And on^ time there
came a fair bacheler and entered in my chamber there that I was alone. But how
he came in to me / and where. I wist it never \ ne yet know I not. For the
doors were fast barred and with me he did game of love For I ne had might ne
power / him to defen- from me. And often he came unto me in ye foresaid manner /
so that he begat this child. But never might I wit what he was.

Of the answer of Merlyn wherefore the king axed why his castle might not
stand that he had begone ne prove.
SO when Merlyn had herd all that his mother had said. He spoke to the
king in this manner. Sire how I was begoten axe ye no more For it be falls
not to you ne to none other to wit. But tell me the cause wherefore I am to
you brought and wherefore ye have sent after me. Truly said the king / my wise
couseyllers have done me to understood / yt ye mortar of a work that I have
begone / behouety to be thempred with your blood / or the foundament shall
fail for ever more. Sir said Merlyn. will ye slay me for my blood to tempre
with your mortar. ye said the king / or else my castle shall never stand as
my cou^seyllers do me to understand Tho- answered Merlyn to the king. Sir he
said he said / let them come before me those wise cou^seylles and I woll preu
they say not well ne truly. And when ye wise men were comen. Merlyn axed if
his blod were ye cause to make this work to sto^de and endure. All tho wise
men were abashed and could not answer. Merlyn tho said to the king. Sir I
shall tell you ye cause wherefore your work thus fails and may no^ stand.
There is under the mountain there yt ye have builded your toure a great ponde
of water and i^ ye botome of ye ponde under ye water there ben two dragons /
and ye one is white and ye other reed / ye fight togyd against your work do ye
mine deep eyll your men come to ye pond / and cause your men to take a way ye
water all out / and then ye shall see ye dragans as I have you told ye
together fight against your work and this is the cause wherefore your fou^dament
fails The king anon let dygge under that men came to the ponde / And let
do a way the water / and there they found two dragons as Merlyn had told
that egerly fought together The white dragon egerly assailed the reed and
lyadde on him so strongely that he might not endure / but withdrewe him and
rested in the same cave. And wha^ he had a while rested him / he went before
and assailed the reed dragon angerly / and held him so sore yt he might not
ayenste him endure / but withdrewe him and rested And after came again ye white
dragon and strongly fought with the reed dragon. and bote him evil and
overcame. that he fled from thens and no more came again.

Of the sygnycacyon of those two dragons that were in the botome of the ponde
that fought together
THis king vortyger and his men that saw this battle had great meruaysle and
prayed Merlyn to tell him what it might betoken. Sir quod Merlyn I shall tell
you. The reed dragon betokens yourselfe / and the white betokens the folk
of Saxon that first ye took and held in your land that fight against you /
and you have driven and enchaced. But Brytons of ynure lygnage overcame them
and drove them a way And sythen at ye coming again of the Saxons they
recovered this land and held it for ever more. And drove out the Brytons and
did with this land all they will / and destroyed cryste^dom through out this
land. ye had first great Joy with their coming / But now yt is turned to
you great damage and sorrow. For tho brethern of Constance that was king the
which ye let slay shall come before a qui^zeme passed with a great power from
little Brytayne / and shall avenge the death of their brother. And they shall
brenne you first with sorrow / and after they shall slay a great part of
Saxons / and shall drive out all the remenau^t of the land. And therefore abide
ye here no longer to make castle nor other work. But anon goo else where
your lives all for to save. To god I you betake / truth I have said to you
of things that shall befalle. And understand ye well that Aurilambros
shall be king But he shall be enpoysoned / and little time shall he regne

Of king Aurilambros how that he pursued vortiger and Engist and how they
deyed.
MErlyn and his mother departed from the king / and turned again to
Carmardyn. And soon after tidings came to ye Brytons that Aurilambros and
vter his brother were arrived at Totnesse with a great host / And anon the
Brytons assembled the^ and went to receive Aurylambros and Vter with great
noblesse. And had them unto London / and crowned Aurylambros and made him king
/ and did unto him homage. And anon he axed where. Vortyger that was king
might be found / for he would be avenged on his brothers death / and after he
would war upon paynems. And they told him that Vortyger was in walys / and
so they ladde him thither ward. Vortiger wyste well that tho brethern came
him to conquer / And fled thens in to a castle that was called. Gerneth
that stood upon an hight mountain / and there him held. Aurilambros and Vter
his brother and their folk had besyeged the castle full long time / for the
cagell was strong and well arrayed. So at the last they casted wild fire and
burnt howses and men and all their array: and as much as was within the
castle. So that Vortiger was burnt among all other: and so he deyde with
much sorrow. Tho was Engist in Kente and reigned there: ane herd this
tidings: and anon fled and would have gone in to Scotlonde for to have had
socoure. But Aurilambros and his men met with him in the north country and
yane him batayl. And Engist and his men defended whiles that they might. But
he and his folk were discomfyted and slain And Octa his sone fled unto
york. And Aurilambros him followed egerly. And. Octa a little while withstode
him: But after ward he put him to his mercy. And aurilambros received him: and
to him and to his men gaafthe country of Galewaye in. Scotlonde: and there
they dwelled. The king aurilambros went thorugh out the land: and put away
the name of. England: that. Engist after his name had called it befoere. Tho
let he it call again great. Brytayne: and let make again cherches: houses of
religyon: castelles: cytees and broughs. And towones that the. Saxons had
destroyed. And came to London: and let make the walls of the cite: which
Engist and his folk had castedowne. The Brytons ladde him unto the mount of.
Ambrian that sometime was an house of relygyon: that tho was destroyed thrughe
the paynems:

whereof a knight that was called Ambri sometime was founder of that house. And
therefore the same hylle was called the mount of. Ambrian. And after it was
called. Ambresbury. And shall be so for euermore^.

How Aurilambros did redress the land of great Brytayne / that which was
destroyed thorugh the Saxons before said.
HOw the king Aurilambros let amend and redress the house of Ambresbury /
and there in put monks. But now there ben Nonnes a little fro the place that
was called Salysbury / are that the Saxons slew the Brytons / where Engist and
they should have made a laue day. In the which time were slain a thousand
knights.lxi. through treason of Engist^ The king thereof had great pity and
thought to make in mind of them a monument of stone that might endure to the
worlds end. And of this thing they took there counseyll what thereof was best
for to do. Tho spoke to the king the bishop of London that was called
Ternekyn that he should require after. Merlyn. For he could best tell how this
thing might best be made. And merlyn after was sought and found and came to
the king. And the king told him his will of the monumente that he would have
made. Merlyn answered to the king and said. There ben great stones in Irlonde
and long upon the hylle of Kyan that men called. Gyauntes karoll. And if they
were in this place as they ben there / they would endure for eurer more in
remembrance of those knights that here be entyred. Per may foy said the king
as hard stone ben in my land as in Irlonde.

Soth said Merlyn. But in all your land ben none such. For gau^tes set
them for great good of themself. For at every time that they were wound or
in any manner hurt / they wysshe the stones with hot water / And then they
wysshe them there with and anon they were hoole.

How the Brytons went for to seek the great stones in Irlonde.
AS soon as the. Brytons had herd of this thing / they yede and swore among
them they would go seek those stones. And took with them. Vter the kings
brother to be thyef capytayne and.v. thousand men / and Merlyn counseled them
for to go unto Irlonde and so thye did / And when the king of Irlonde that
was culled Guillomer herd tell strangers were arrived in his land / he
assembled a great power and fought against them But he and his folk were
dyscomfyted. The Brytons went before till they came to the mount of Kyan / and
clymmed up unto the mount. But when they saw the stones and the manner how
they stood / they had great meruaylle and said between themself / that no man
should them remeue for no strength ne engyne so great they were and so
long. But. Merlyn through his craft he remeued them and brought them in to
their ships and came again in to this land. And Merlyn set the stones there
that the king would have them. And set them in the same manner that they
stood in Irlonde / and when ye king saw that it was made he thanked Merlyn /
And rychely him rewarded at his own will. And that place let call Stonhenge
for ever more.

How Passent that was Vortigers sone and the king Guillomer came in to this
land / and how a traitor that was called Cappa enpoysoned ye king
Aurilambros.
ANd men shall understand that Passent that was Vortigers sone lived ye same
time / and came in to this land with a great power / and arrived in the north
country and would be aue^ged of his faders death Vortiger and strongely trusted
upon the company that he had brought with him out of the land of Germayne /
and had conquered all the North country unto york. And when king Aurilambros
herd this he assemled a great power of Brytons and went for to fight with
passe^t and he dyscomfyted Passent and all his people. but Passent escaped thens
with some of his men / and fled thens in to Irlonde and come to king
Guillomer and prayed him of help and socour. The king granted him with good
will and said / that he would help him / upon that covenant that I my self
must go with you with all my power in to brytayne. And I would me aduenge upon
the Broytons the rather for they came in to my land and took the stones with
strength that is called Gyauntes karoll The king Guillomer let ordeyne his
ships and went to the sea with.xv. thousa^de men and arrived in walys and
began to rob / and much sorrow he did. It befell so that king Aurilambros
lay syke at wynchestre / and might not help him self. So that he sent in
his name Vter his brother with a power to help walys. And thither ward he
went as much as he might. The king of Irlonde and Passente herd tell that
Aurilambros was syke / and to him there came a Sarrasyn that was called Cappa
and said. Sire dwell ye here all in peace with your host and I behyght you
thorugh my quayntesye ye I shall slay the king Aurilambros that is syke.
Then said Passent / if ye do so I shall you rychely auaunce. The traitor
Cappa put upon him an habyte of relygyon / and let shave him a broad crown
and came unto the kings court / and said that he would help^ the king of
his malady. Tho said the traitor Cappa unto the king. Sir be of good comfort.
For I shall give you such a medicyne that ye shall sweet ano^e right and
list to sleep and have good rest. And the traitor yaaf him such poison to
sleep anon right / and deyed in his slepynge. And ye traitor said yt he
would go out to the field till he were awaked / and so escaped he away. For no
man had to him suspeccyon / for by cause of his habyte that he was clothed i^ /
and also for his broad shaven crown. But when the kings men wyste that he was
deed / they became wonder sorry / and fast sought the traytoure / but they
might not find hym^ For ye Cappa turned again unto the host frem whes yt he
came.

when Aurilambbros deyed a sterre in the morn was seen with a clear light /
and at the bought of the beeme was seen the heed of an horrible dragon
SO when the king Aurilambros was deed and enpoysoned at winchestre. On the
morn after he was deed about the time of Pryme there was seen a sterre great
and clear and the beeme of that sterre was brygheter tha^ ye son. And at the
bought of ye beeme apperyd a dragons heed / and out of his mouth came two huge
lyghtes / that were as bright as any fire brennynge. and that one beeme to
ward France and straight over the sea thither ward. And out of that beeme
came.vii. beemes full clear and long as it were the light fire. This ^^erre
was seen of many a man / But none of them wyste what it be tokened. Vter that
was the kings brother / that was in walys with his host of Brytons / saw
that sterre and the great light that it yaue / they wondered there of greatly what
it might betoken. And let call Merlyn and prayed him for to tell what yt it
myhght betoken.

Of the betokenynge of the sterre.
MErlyn saw ye sterre / and beheld yt a long time. And sythen he quoke and
wept tenderly. And sayde^ Alas alas that so noble a king and worthy is deed
And I do iou to vndersta^nde that Aurilambros your brotherds poisoned / and
that I see well in this sterre. And yourselfe is betokened the heed of the
dragon that is seen at the bought of the beeme that is your self that shall be
king and regne. And by the beeme that stondeth to ward the Eest is
understand that ye shall get a sone that shall conquer all France / and all
the lands that belongs to the crown of France / that shall be a wrothyer
king and of more honor than ever were any of his auncetours. And by the
beeme that stretched toward Irlonde is betokened that ye shall get a
daughter that shall be queen of Irlonde. And the seven beemes betoken that ye
shall have.vii. sons. And every one of them shall be king / and regne with
much honor. And abide ye no longer here / but goo and give battle to your
enmyes / and fight with them booldely for ye shall overcome them and have the
victory. Vter thanked hertely Merlyn and took his men and went to ward his
enmyes / and they fought together mortally / and so he dyscomfyted his enmyes
and them destroyed. And him self slew Passe^t that was vortigers sone And his
Brytons slew Guillomer that was king of Irlonde and all his men. And Vter
anon after that battle took his way to ward wynchestre / for to do entyere
Aurilambros king that was his brother. But tho was the body borne unto.
Stonhenge with much honor / that he had done make in remembrance of the
Brytons that there were slain through treason of Engist / that same day that
they should have been accorded. And in the same place they entyered. Aurelambros
the second year of his regne with all ye worship ye might belong to such a
king. On whoos soul god have mercy. Amen.

Of Vter Pendragon / and therefore he was called so ye shall here. And how he
was overtake with the love of Igreyne that was the Earl of Cornewaylles wife.
AFter the death of. Aurilambros. Vter his brother was crowned and reigned well
and worthily. And in remembrance of the dragon that he was lykened to / He
let make two dragons through counsel of his. Brytons And made that one for to
be borne before him wha^ he went in to battle / and ye other for to abide at
wynchestre in the bishop church. And for that cause he was called ever after
vter Pendragon. And Octa that was Engistes sone commended vter but little yt
was made new king. And ayenste him began to meue war. And ordained a great

against them / and would not suffer them to come in to the cytee / neither to
yield the cytee to them. And he besyeged the town anon right and yaue thereto
a strong assawte. But they of the cite them kept well and strongely. And when
vter herd thereof / he came thither with a great strong power for to help and
rescowe ye town and put a way the syege / and yaue a strong battle. And Octa
and his company them defended as well as they might. But at ye last they were
dysco^fyted and the most party of the^ slain. And. Octa and. Ossa were taken
and put in prison at London. And vter hymfelf dwelled a while at york / and
after he went to London. And at the Eester after he would vere crown and hold
a solemn feast. And let somone all his Earl and Barons / that they should
come to that feast. And all those that had wives should bring them also to
that feast. And all the seygnoury came at the kings commandment as they
were commanded. The feast was rychely arrayed and holden. And all worthily
set to meet after that they were of astate. So that the^ Earl Gorloys of
Cornewaylle and. Igreyne his wife sat next unto the king. And when the king
saw the fayrnesse of that lady and the beauty that she had. He was anon
rauysshed for her beauty and often he made to her nyce countenance in lokynge
and laughing. So at the last the Earl perceived the preuy lokynge and
laughing and the love between them. And roso up from the table in wrath / and
took his wife and called to him his knights and went thens wrath / without
taking leave of ye king. The king anon sent after him that he should come
again and goo not thens in dyspyte of him. And the earl would not come again
in no manner of wise. wherefore the king was wroth / and in wrath him defied
as his deedly enmye. And the earl went thens in to Cornewaylle with his wife
in the castle of Tyntagyll. And the king let ordeyne a great host and came
in to Cornewaylle / for to destroy the earl if that he might. But he had
put him in such a castle that was strong and well arrayed called. Tyntagyll
/ and wollde not yield him to the king. And the king anon besyeged the
called / and there dwelled.xv. days that never might speed / and ever he
thought upon Igreyne / and upon her laid so much love / That he wyste not
what to do. So at the last he called to him a knight that was called vlfin
that was preuy with him and told him all his counseyll / and axed him wha^ was
best for to done Sir said he / send after Merlyn anon / for he came tell
you the best counseyll of any man living Merlyn anon was sent after and
came to the king. And the king told him all his counseyll and his will. Sir
said Merlyn. I shall do so much through craft that I can / that I shall make
you come to night (...) the castle of. Tyntagyll / and shall have all yo^ will
of that lady.

the land with much reverence after his faders death: the.xvii. year of his

How king Arthur that was the sone of Vter was crowned after his faders death:
and how he drove Colegryn and the Saxons and Cheldri^ of A^mayne out of this
land
As Arthur was made king of the land / he was but young of aege of.xv. year /
but he was fair and bold and doughty of body. And to meke folk he was good
and curteys / and large of spendinge / and made him well beloved among them
there that yt was need / and when he began to regne heswore truly that ye.
Saxons never should have rest ne peace till that he had driven them out of ^he
land. And assembled a great host and fought with Colegryn the which after
ye time that Octa was deed the Saxons mayntened. And this Colegryn was
dyscomfyted and fled unto york and took the town / and there him held.
And the king besyeged him there but he might no thing speed for the cite was
so strong. And they within the town kept the cite well and orpedly. And in the
mean time Colegryn let the town to Bladulf and f^ledde himself to Cheldryk
yt was king of almayne / for to have of him socour. And the king assembled a
grette power and came and arrived in Scotlonde with.xv. hundred ships. And
wha^ Arthur wist of these tidings that he had not power and strength enough to
fight against. Cheldrik / he let be the syege and went to London / and sent
anon his letters to ye king of little Brytayne that wys called Howell his
neuewe his systers sone / that he should come to him with all the power that he
might. And he assembled a great host and arrived at Southampton. And when
king Arthur it wist he was glad enough and went ayenste them / and them
received with much honor. So that those two hosts met and assembled them
/ and took their way even unto. Nycholl that Cheldryk had besyeged / But it
was not taken. And they came upon cheldrik and his people or they wist where
that they were / and them egerly assaylled. The king Cheldrik and his men
defended him manly by their power. But king Arthur and his men slew so many
Saxons / hat never was seen such slaughter / and Cheldrik and his men that
were left alive fled a way. And king Arthur them pursewed and drove them
out in to a wood tha they might no ferder pass. Cheldrik and his me^ saw
well that they were brought in to much disease / and them yielded to king
Arthur in this manner wys. That he should take their horses their armor / and
all that they had / and they must only go on foot in to their ships. And so
they would goo home in to their own land / and never come again in to this
land. And upon assurance of this thing they yaue him good hostages. And
Arthur by counseyll of his men granted this thing: and received ye hostages:
and thereupon yt other went to their ships. And when they were in ye high
see the wynnde changed as the devil it would: and they turned their navy and
came again in to this land and arrived at Totnesse: and went out of the ships
and took the land: and clean robbed it: and much people slew: and took all
the armor that they might find. And so they went forth till they came
unto Bathe. But the men of the town shytte fast their yates / and would not
suffer them to come wy thinthe towne^ And they deffended the^ well and orpedly
against them

How Arthur yaue bataylle unto the Saxons when they came again in to this
land: and had besyeged the town of Bathe and them overcame.
Anon as. Artur herd this tidings he let hang ye hostages / and le^t
Howell of Brytayne his neuewe / for to keep the march to ward Scotlonde with
half his people and himself went to help and rescowe the town of. Bathe.
when he ^^me thither he yaue a strong battle to Cheldrik and slew almoost all
the people that he had^ For no man might him wythstonde ne endure under ye
stroke of his sword. And there both were slain Colegryn and Bladulf his
brother / and Cheldryk fled thens and would have gone to his ships But when
Arthur it wist / he took.x. thousand knights to Cador yt was earl of Corn
waylle for to let and stop his coming. And Arthur himself went toward
the march of Scotlonde. For messengers told him that ye Scotts had besyeged
Howell of. Brytoyne there that lay syke / and therefore he hasted him thither
ward. And Cador purse wed after Cheldryk / and took him er he might come to
his ships and slew Cheldrik and his people. And when Cador had done this
vyage / he hasted him again to ward. Arthur as fast as he might / and found
him in Scotlonde there that he had rescowed Howel of Brytayn but ye Scotts
were far wythyn Nounref / and there they held them a while. But Arthur them
pursewed. And they fled thens in to Limoigne / yt were in that country.xl.
Isles and great plente of birds / and great plente of Egles that were wont to
cry and fight togyders / and make great noise when folk came to rob that
land / and warn as much as they might / and so they did. For the Scotts
were to great rauenours / that they took all that they might find in the
land of Lymoygne without any sparynge / and there with charged again the folk
in to Scotlonde for to wend.

How king Arthur axed of Merlyn ye adventures of.vi. of the last kings that
were to regne in England / and how ye land should end
Sir said Merlyn. In the year of the Incarnacyon Ihesu Christ.M^CC.xv. shall
come a lamb out of wynchestre / shall have a white tongue and true lyppes / and
he shall have written in his heart holiness. This lamb shall make many gods
houses / and he shall have peace the most part of his life. And he shall make
one of the fairest places of ye wor^de / that in his time shall not fully ^e
made an end of. And in the end of his life wulf of a strange land shall do
him much harm and sorrow through war. But at the end the lamb shall be
master through help of a reed fox / that shall come out of the North west /
and him shall overcome / and the wulf shall dey^ in water. And after that time
the lamb shall live no while / but he shall deye. His heed shall be in a
strange land. And the land shall be without a governor a little time

ANd after this shall come a dragon meddled with mercy and also with woodnesse
And that shall have aberde as a got that shall give in England a shade we /
and shall kept the land fro cold and hete / and his own foo^ shall be set
in wyke and that other in London. And he shall enbrace Inhabitaunces. And he
shall open his mouth to ward walys. And the trembling of the hydour of his
mouth / his ^eres shall stretche to ward many habytacyons and countrees. And
his breath shall be full sweet in strange land. And in his time shall the
ryuers run blood and with brain. And he shall make i^ places of his land
walls that shall do much harm unto his seed after his time. And then shall
there come a people out of the North west during his regne that shall be ladde
thrughout a wicked hare / that the dragon shall do crown king / that
afterward shall flee over the sea with out coming again for dread of the
dragon. And in that time the son shall be as reed as an blood that see
thorughout all the world / that shall betoken great pestylence and death of
folk / thorugh dynt of sword. And that people shall be faderles / till the
time that the dragon deye through an hare: that shall meue against him war unto
the end of his life: that shall not fully be ended in his time This dragon
shall be hold in his time the best body of the world. and he shall deye
beside the marches of a strange land: and the land shall dwell faderles
without a good governor: and men shall weep for his death: from the isle of.
Shepey to the haven of Marcyll. wherefore Alas alas shall be their song of
faderles folk: that shall over live in his land destroyed.

ANd after this dragon shall come a got out of. Kar that shall have horns and
a berde of silver / and there shall come out of his nosethryll a dompe that
shall betoken hungre and sorrow and great death of the people. And much of his
land in the beginning of his regne shall be wasted. This got shall go over
unto France: and shall open the flower of his life and death. In his time there
shall arise an E^^e in Corn way^e that shall have feathers of go^e / that of
pride ^ha^ be without pere of the land. And he shall despy^e lords of blood.
And a^^er he shall flee shamefully by a beer at G^uer^e^h / and after shall be
made brydges of men upon the costs of the ^ee and stones shall fall from
castelles / and many other towns shall be made plain. In his time shall seem
that the beer shall brenne / and a battle shall be done upon the arms of the sea in a field ordained as a sheld And at that batayl shall deye many white
heedes / wherefore this battle shall be called the white battle. And the
foresaid beer shall do this got much harm / and it shall come out of the
South west and of his blood. Then shall the go^e lose much / and of his
land / till that the time that frenshyp shall him overcome. And then shall
he close him in a lions skin / and then shall he win that he had before
lost and more thereto. For a people shall come out of the North west yt shall
make the got so sore aferde thet he shall be in great perplexite. And he shall
aduenge him on his enmyes through counsel of two owls that first shall be in
peril for to be undone. But the old owl shall wend away a certain time /
and after he shall come again in to this land. These two owls shall do great
harm to many one / and so they shall counseyll the got to arere war against
the foresaid beer. And at ye last the go^e and the owls shall come at Burton
upon Trent / and shall go over / and for dread the beer shall ^^ee and a
swanne with him fro his company to Burton ward the north and there they shall
be with an hard shoure. And then shall the swanne be take and slain wi^h
sorrow and the beer taken heeded al there next his ^est / that shall stand upon
broken bridge / on whom the son shall cast his beemes. And many shall him
seek for virtue that from him shall come. In ye same shall deye for sorrow ^
^are ap^ple of his land / so that lands shall be upon him ye more bo^der
after ward. And those two owls shall do much sorrow to the foresaid flower
of life / and her shall led in to dystrestre / so that shall pass over the sea
into France / for to make peace between the got and ye flouredelyse / and
there she shall dwell till a time that her sede shall come and set^e her: ^
they shall be still till a time: that they shall them clothe with grache. And
they shall fethe the owls and shall put them to dyspytous death. And after
shall this got be brought to disease and great Anguysshe: and in sorrow he
shall live all his life

AFter this got shall come out of wyndesore a boore: that shall have an heed
o^ a white lynons heart: and pyteous lokynge His vysage shall be rest to like
men. His breeste shall be staunchynge of thyrste to tho that be thrysty: His
word shall be gospel. his herynge shall be meke as a lambe^ In the first
year of his regne he shall have great pain to Iustefye the^ that been untrue.
And in his time shall his land be multeplyed with alyauntes. And this boore
thorugh fyresnesse of his heart that he shall have: shall make wulues to become
lambs. and he shall be called thorugh out of ye world Boore of holiness /
fyers^esse of noblynesse and of meekness. And he shall mesurably all that he
shall do unto the brough of Jerusalem. And he shall whette his teeth upon the
yates of Pards: and upon four lands. Spain shall tremble for dread. Gascoyne
shall sweet. In France he shall put his wynge. His great tail shall rest in
England softly. Almayne shall quake for dread of him. This boore shall give
bantelles to two towns of England: and shall make the River run with blood
and brain. And he shall make many meadows reed: and he shall get as much
as his auncetours did. And er that he dyed / he shall bear three crowns / and
he shall put a land in great subiecyon / And after it shall be releued / but
not in his time. This boore after he is deed for his doughtynesse / shall be
entyred at Coleyne. And his lord shall be fulfilled of all good.

AFter this boore shall come a lamb: yt shall have f^et of leed: and an heed
of brass: and heart of loppe a swynes skin. And an hard. And in his time
his land shall be in peace: the first year of his regne he shall do make a
cytee that all the world shall speak there of. This lamb shall lose in his
time a great part of his land through an hydeous wulfe: but he shall recover
it: and give a lordshyp to an Egle of his land and this egle shall well
govern it till the time that pride shall him overcome. Alas the sorwe: For he
shall deye of his brothers sword. And after shall the land fall to the
foresaid lamb: that shall govern the land in peace all his lives time. And
after he shall deye / and the land be fulfilled of all manner of good.

AFter this lamb shall come a mold warpe / cursyd of gods mouth / a caytyf /
a cowarde / an haare / He shall have an elderly skin as a got / and
vengeance shall fall upon him for syn^e. In the first year of his regne he
shall have of all good great plente in his land and to ward him also / And in
his land he shall have great praysyge / till the time that he shall surffre his
people live in to much pride without chastysynge / wherefore god will be wrothe^
Then shall arise up a dragon of the North / that shall be full fyerse / and
shall meue war against the foresaid mold warpe / and shall give him battle upon
a stone. This dragon shall gadre again in to his company a wulfe / that shall
rome out of the west to meue war against the foresaid mold warpe in his side /
so shall the dragon / and bind their tails to gyders Then^e shall come a lion
out of Irlonde / that shall fall in company with them. And then shall
tremble the land that shall becalled England as an aspen leyf / And in that
time shall castelles be felled down upon Tamyse. And ye shall seem that Seuerne
shall be dry / for the bodies that shall fall deed there in / The four chyef
floodes in England shall run in blood. And great dread shall he / and
anguysshe that shall arise. After the mold warpe shall flee and ye dragon. The
lion and the wulf shall them drive a way / and the lon shall be without them.
And the mold warpe shall have no manner of power sauf only a ship whereto he
may wynder And after that he shall goo to land where the sea is wythdrawe.
And after that he shall give the third part of his land / for to have the
fourth part in peace and in rest. And after he shall live in sorrow all his
lyftyme^ And in his time the h^^r bathes shall become cold. And after that
shall the mold warpe deye auenturously and suddenly. Alas for sorrow / for he
shall be drowned in a flood of the sea His seed shall be come faderles in
strange loud for ever more. And then shall the land be departed in to three
parts / that is to say / to the wulf / to the dragan / and to the lion. And
so shall it be for euermore^ And then shall this land be called the ^de of
Conquest. And so shall the ryghe heirs of England end

How Arthur overcame Guillomer that was king of Irlonde. And how the Scotts
became his men
THen^e when Guillomer that was king of Irlonde herd tydyges ye king Arthur
was entered at Glastenbury: he ordained agrete pewer of Irysshmen and came to
the sea with his Irysshe people; and so came in to Scotlonde over the sea and
arrived fast there by that king. Arthur was with his host: and a none as he
wist thereof: he went to ward him and yaue him bataylle and overcame him anon
right. And Guillomer fled with his me^ again in to Irlond. And when this was
done and dyscomfyted him Arthur turned him again there that he was: in to the
place there that he had left the Scotts and would have them all slain. But
the bysshopes: abbottes and other folk of ye country and ladies open heeded
came before king. Arthur and cried him mercy and said. Sire gentle king and
mighty: have mercy and pity upon us. And as yourself be of the right law to
hold and mayntene Crystendome. For full great dyshoudur yt should be to slay
him that byleueth in almighty god as ye do. And for gods love have mercy and
pity on us and suffer us. For we have had much sorrow and pain. For the
Saxons have many times passed through our land. But that is not enough to you:
for often times they have done us sorrow and disease For our castelles they
have taken and our beestes slain and eten: and much harm they have us done
And if ye would us now slay: it were none honor to a king to slay them that
cry him mercy. For enough ye have done to us and have us overcome. And for ye
love of god yt ye will suffer us for to live: and have mercy on christian people
yt believe in Christ as ye do. wha^ king. Arthur herd this sorrow: he had pity
of them and yaue them life and lymme without any more harm. And they fell down
to his feet and thanked him and became his lyege men: and he took of them
homage. And after ye king Arthur turned again with his host the came unto
york: and made there his bydynge during that vyage. And tho gave he al Logrys
to Aloth that had spowsed his sister and other gifts great plente^ And tho was
Gawen his cosyn but of youge ^ege. And to all his other men that him had served
in his war / he gave rich gifts / and thanked them much of all their good
service

How king Arthur spowsed Gu^nor that was Gu^nors cosyn Earl of Corn wayle /
and after he conquered of Guillomer all Irlonde.


ANd when Arthur had broughth is land in peace and rest and in good state /
and all was well in every country. Tho took and wedded a wife that was called
Gu^nor and made her queen / a fair lady and a gentle that Cador the Earl of
Corn wayle had nourysshed i^ his chamber that was his cosyn. But never they
had childern together. And nevertheless king Arthur loved her wonder well and
deyrly And anon as winter was passed / he let assemble a great host / and all
his Barons and said that he would goo in to. Irlonde for to conquer the land.
And he trayed not long that he passed over in to Irlone. And Guillomer the
king let assemble a great host and yaue bataylle to king Arthur / but
Guyllomer was dyscomfyted and yielded him ot ye king and became his man / and
to him did fewte and homage and of him held all that land fro that time for
ward. And after peaskynge. Arthur ferthermore and conquered But land and
Islonde / and took homage of the folk and of the land / and there
dwelled.xii. year in peace and reigned with Joy and myrthe. And there warred no
man ne woman upon him. And he became so curtys and large and honorable / that
the Emperors court of Rome / ne none other through out all the world was not
accounted to king Arthurs / that any man wist of / ne none so well praysed^
And therefore the best knights of all manner a lands came unto him there for
to dwell. And he them received with good will and reverence. And all the
knygehtes were so good that no man knew the werste. And therefore king Arthur
made a round table that when they should sytte at there meet / all should be
ylyke high and euenly served at the table that no^e of them should make auau^t
that one of them were higher thanne an other. And king Arthur had at that
table Brytons and Frenshmen. Normans and Flemynges. Burgoyns Mausers and
Lotherins / and of all the lands a this half the mount Goryt: and of his
land of Brytayne and of the great Corn wayle: of walys and of Irlonde: and of
Scotlonde And shortly to tell of all the lands that woldes worship chyualry:
such came to king Arthurs court.

How king Arthur yede into France and conquered that land of. Froll yt was a
Romayne: and how he slew him.


Sith it befell that through counsel of his barons and lords: king Arthur
would conquer all France that tho was called Galle through Romans that tho
held ye land in their power and in their gouernnu^ce. And the Romans had
taken that land to a noble knyt and a worthy of body: that was called Froll.
And when he wist that Arthur came: he ordeoned an host of a great power and
fought with the king. And he and his folk were dyscomfyted and fled unto
Paris and entered the cite: and closed the yates and there held them. when
Arthur wist that Froll was gone to Paris he pursued after and came thither: and
him besyeged. But the cite was so strong and well arrayed / and tho that were
therein deffended them well and manly. King Arthur dwelled there more than
amonethe. And there was so much people in the cite that they dyspended all
their vytayle that they had within. and so great hungre became among them /
that they deyed wenderly thycke within the cite for ho^gre. And came unto Froll
and prayed him to be accorded with king. Arthur for to have peace and they
would yield them unto him and the cite also. Froll saw yt he might no longer
hold the town against their will \ and trusted gretely upon his owe strenth /
and sent to ye king Arthur that he should come fight with him body for body /
and so should they depart France between them two. King Arthur ano^e
granted yt. And would not that none of his people undertook the battle for
him. And upon the morn both came well arrayed without Paris there that they
should fight. and anon they smote togyders so fyersly and so well they fough on
both sides that no man demed the better of them / and so it befell ye Froll
yaue Arthur such a stroke yt he kneled to the ground would he nolde he / And
as Froll wounded king Arthur in the forhede yt the blood fell down by his
eyes and his face. Arthur anon sterre up hertely when he felt him hurt as a
man yt seemed almoost wood. And he took taburne his good sword / and drew it
upon high and yaaf Froll such astroke that thyr with he claue his head down
to the sholders so that his helm might not be his warraunt / and so he fell
down deed in the place. And then tho of the city made great sorrow for
Froll. And euerychone yielded them to king. Arthur and the town also and
became his men / and did to him homage and feaute. And he received them and
took of them goodly hostages. And king Arthur after that went forth with
his host and conquered Augien and Angyers. Gascoyne. Pehito. Nauerne and
Burgoyne. Berry. Lotherne Turyn and Peythers / and all the other lands of
France he conquered all holy. when he had conquered and taken by homages and
feautes / he turned again to Paris and there he dwelled long time / and
ordained peace long time over all ye country / and through al France. And wha^
peace was made over all through his noble knyghthode that he had / and also for
his own worthynes. And no man were he never so great a lord durst not meue
war against him another to arise for to make the land of France inquyete. And
in peace he dwelled there.ix. year / and did many great wonders / and repreued
many proud men and evil tyrau^tes them chastysed after their demerytes

How king Arthur auaunced all his men that had trauaylled in his service.
ANd after ward yt befell thus at Ester there that he held a feast at. Paras /
and rychely he began auau^ce his knights for ye service that they had him helped
in his conquest. He yaue to his steward that was called. Kay Augien and
Angoers. And he yaue to Bed were his. Butler. Normandye / that tho was called
Neustrye And to Holde^ in his chambrelayn he yaue Flaunders and Mance And to
Dorell his cosyn he yaue Bolayne. And to Richard his enewe he yaue Pountyf /
and to all other he yaue large lands and fees after they were of estate / And
when Arthur had thus his knights feoffed / at Aperyll next after suynge he
came again in to Brytayne his own land. And after at wytsontyde sewynge by
counseyll of his Barons / he would be crowned king of Glomergon / and held a
solemn feast. And let somone barons erls and knights / yt they should come
thither every chone. and there was Scater king of Scotland. Cad were king of
South waylys. Guiliomer king of North walys. Maded king of Irlonde. Malgamus
king of Gutlonde. Achelles king of Islonde. Aloth king of Denmark. Gone was
king of Norwaye / and Hell his cosyn king of Dorkeney. Cador king of little
Brytayne. Mor with Earl of Cornewaylle. Mauran earl of Gloucetre. Guerdon earl
of wynchestre. Boell earl of Hartforde. Vrtegi earl of Oxforde. Cuisall earl of
Bathe. Jonas Earl of Chestre. Enerall earl of Dorchestre. Kymare Earl of
Salysbury. waloth earl of Caunterbury. Iugerne earl of Chechestre. Arall earl
of Leyceter / and the earl of were wyke / and many other moo rich lords.
Brytons there came moo / that is to say. Dippon Donande. Gennes / and many
other that be not named here were at the feast. And many a fair feast king
arthur had hold before / but never none such / ne so solemn / and that
lasted.xv. days with much honor and myrthe. Of the letter yt was sent fro
Rome to pride to king Arthur

THe third day as king Arthur satte at his meet among his knights and
among them that satte at the feste / before the^ came in ^xii. men of age
rychely arrayed / and curteusly they salewed the king / and said they came fro
Rome sent as massengers fro the Emperor. And took him a letter that thus
much was to vndersta^d^ Gretely us maruaylleth arthur / that thou art ones so
hardy with thyn eyes in thy heed to make open war or contake against us of
rome / that own all the world to redeem / For thou haste never yet before
this time proved ne assayed the strength of the Romans / and therefore though
it shall in a little time. For Iulyus Cezar conquered all the land of Brytayne
/ aid took thereof truage / and our folk have it long I had / and now
through thy pride thou with hold it. wherefore we of Rome command the that
thou yt yield again / and yet haste thou more folly done that thou haste slain
Froll that was our baron of France with wrong. And therefore all the comens of
Rome warns the and command the upon life and lymme that thou in haste be at
Rome amends for to make of thy misdeeds that thou haste done. And it so be
that thou come not we shall pass the hill of Joy with stre^gthe / and we
shall the seek where ever thowe may be found / and thou shall not have a foot
of land of thyn own / yt we ne shall dystroye it / and afterward with thy
body we shall do al our will. when this letter was read and all men it herd
they were anoyed all yt were at ye solemn feste. And the Brytons would have
slain ye messengers / but the king would not suffer them and said / that ye
messengers should have no harm / and may by reason none deserve But commanded
them to be worshypfully served And after meet he took counsel of kings /
earls and barons / what answer he might give again to the messengers and they
cou^seylled him atones / that he should assemble a great power of al ye lo^des
of which he had lordeshyp and ma^ly avenge him upon the Emperor of the
despyte that he had se^de him such a letter and they swore by god and by all
his holy name that they should him pursewe and bren^e as much as they might
And said that they would never fail king Arthur / and rather to be deed. And
they let write a letter to send to the Emperor by the same messengers in
this manner of wyse^ Of the bold answer that king Arthur se^te to the
Emperor of Rome and to the Romans

Understands among you of Rome that I am king Arthur of Brytayne and freely
it hold and shall hold. And at Rome hastily I will be / not to give you
truage / but for to axe truage. For Constantyne that was Eleyns sone that was
Emperor of Rome and of all the honor that there to belongs. And Maximian
king conquered all France and Almayne / and mount Joy passed and conquered
all Lombardy. And these two were mine auncetours / and that they held and had.
I shall have thorught gods will.

Of the reverence that king Arthur did to the Emperors messengers.
ANd when this letter was made and ensealed / king Arthur to these messe^gers
and gave grette yeftes / and after that the messengers took their leave and
went thens / and came to the court of Rome again. And told the Emperor how
worthily they were received And also of such a ryall company that he had him
for to serve / and how he was more ryally served than the Emperor of Rome or
any other king living in all the world. And when the Emperor had ouersene
the letter / and had hard what was therein and saw yt Arthur would not be
ruled after him. He let assemble and ordeyne a great host for to destroy
king Arthur if that he might. And king Arthur as touching his power and
party / ordained his power or knights of the table round.

How king arthur faught with a gyau^t i^ spain yt was called Dinabus yt slew
Eleyne that was king Howels cosyn of little Brytayne.
King Arthur had not dwelled in that country but a little time / yt men him
told that there was come a great gyaunt in to Spain / and had rauysshed
fair. Eleyne that was cosyn unto. Howell of little Brytayne. And had brought
her upon an hylle that is called the mount of saint Bernarde. And there was no
man in that country so bold ne so hardy that durst fight with him / ne come
nigh the place there yt the gyaunt dwelled tha^ was called Dinabus. And much
sorrow he did in the country. when king Arthur heed this tidings / he
called to him Kay and Bedwere and commanded them to go pryuely and espy where
the gyaunt might be found. And they came to the ryuage there that men should
go to the mount / that was all enclosed a boute with water and yet is / and
ever shall be. And they saw a brennyge fire upon the hylle. And there was also
an other hylle nigh that / and there was upon that an other fire brynnyge. Kay
and Bed were came to the next hylle / and found a wydowe open heeded sitting
besides a tomb sore weeping / and great sorrow made. and often she said Eleyne
eleyne. And Kay and Bed were axed what she was / and wherefore she made so much
sorrow and who lay in that tomb. O syyde she what sorrow and mysauenture
fair lorseke ye here. For if the. Gyaunt may you here find he will you slay
anon. Bestylle good wife said they thereof dysmaye you not but tell us the south
why that thou make so much sorrow and weeping. Syrs said she For a damosel
that I nourysshed with my breest yt was called Eleyne / yt was nece to. Howell
of Brytayne. And here lies the body in this tomb that to me was taken to
nourysshe. And so there came a devil a Gyaunt and rauysshed her and me also /
and ladde us both with him a way he would have for layne that maid that was
young and tender of aege but she might it not suffer so great and so huge as
the. Gyaunt was. And for certain if he come now as he is wo^te to do / he
will you both now slay and therefore go ye hens. Then bespake these two
messengers and said to her / wherefore goo ye not from hens. Certes said she
when that Eleyne deed the. Gyaunt made me to abide and hau^t his will / and I
must needs it suffer. And god it wot I do it not with my will / for I had
lever to be deed than with him to deal / so much pain and sorrow I have
when he me ^oclyeth. when Kay and. Bed were had all that this woman the^ told
/ they turned again and came to king Arthur and told him all that they had
seen and herd. Arthur anon took them both wit him and went pryuely by night
that none of his host wyste and came on the morrow erly to the. Gyaunt and
faught with him strongely / and at the last him slew And Arthur badde. Bed
were smite of his heed / and bring it to the host to show it for a wonder /
for it was so great and huge. when they came again to the host / they told
wherefore they had been out / and showed to them the heed / and every man was
glad and. Ioyefull of the worthy deed that king. Arthur had done that was
their lord. And Howell was full sorrowful for his nece yt was so lost. And
after ward when he had space / he let make a fair chapel of our lady over
Eleyns tomebe.

How king. Arthur yaue bataylle to the Emperperour / in the which bataylle
the Emperor himself was slain


ARthur and his people herd tidings that the. Emperor had assembled a great
power / as well of sarasyns as of paynyms and christian men. whereof the nombre
was.lxxx. thousand horse men with foot me^. Arthur and his people ordained
fast forth their way toward the. Emperor and passed. Normandy and. France
unto. Burgoyne / and would have gone unto the host. For men told him that
the. Emperors host would come to Lucie. The Emperor and his host in the
beginning of. August remeued from Rome / and came forth right the way ^o
ward the host Tho came king Arthur spies and said / if that. Arthur would he
should find the Emperor there fast by put they said. yt the Emperor had so
great power with him of kings of ye lord of Paynems and also christian people yt
it were but folyt to king Arthur to mete with the^ For ye spies told / yt the
emperor had five or six men against one of his. King Arthur was blody and hardy
/ and for no thing him nysmayed and sayede. Goo we boldly in gods name
ayenste the. Romans / that with them led. Sarrasyns and. Paynems / that no
manner trust they have in god / But only upon their strengh. Go we now and seek
them sharply in the name of almighty god and slay we the* Paynems and christian
men that been against us with the^ for to destroy. Cryste^ men. And god shall us
help the^ to overcome For we have the right ^penyon / and therefore have we
trust in god. And we so that the enmyes that be to crystendome and to god may
be destroyed and overcome / and that men may record ye worthynesse of knight
hode. when king Arthur had thus said / they cried all with an high voys.
God that is fader almighty worshypped be thy name without end. Amen. And
grant us grace well for to do and to destroy our enmyes that been against
crystendome. In the name of the fader / the sone / and holy ghost. Amen. And
god give him never grace ne worship in the world / ne mercy of him to have /
that this day shall faynte well for to smite and egerly. And so they rode
softly / and ordained his wings well and wisely. The Emperor herd tell that
king. Arthur and his folk were ready appaerylled for to fight with him and how
they were coming He let ordeyne hes wings i^ the best wise that he cowde And
more trusted upon his strenght than in god almighty / and that was seen
afterwarde^ For when the two hosts met / the. Emperor lost four of his
folk against one of Arthur. And so many were slain \ what on ye one party and
on that other / that it was great pity to wit and to be behold. In this
battle were slain through king. Arthurs five kings of the Paynems and of
other wonder much people / and king. Arthurs men fought so well / that the
Romans and paynems had no more strength to wythstonde them / than.xx. sheep
against five wulues. And so it befelle that in this battle in the shoure / that
was wonder hard and long during in that one side and in that other / the.
Emperor among them there was slain / but there was no man that wyste for very
so the who him slew.

How king Arthur let entyere his knights that he had lost there in battle /
and how he sent the. Emperors body to. Rome that there was slain in battle
SO when the. Romans wist that the Emperor was deed / they forsook the field
and the paynens also. And king. Arthur after them chaced till it was night /
and so many of them slew yt it was wonder to tell. And the turned king
Arthur again when it was night and thanked god of his victory. And on the
morrow he let look and search all the field for his knights that he there
lost. That is to say. Borell Earl of Maunt. Bed were / and Kay / and. Lyegiers
Earl of. Boleyne. Vortiger Earl of Baac. Aloth Earl of wynchestre. Cuisall Earl
of Chestre / and after Holden Earl of. Flaandres. These were the great lords
that king. Arthur lost in that battle / with other worthy knights them
among. And some he let entere in abbayes by the country / some he let to be
borne in to their own country. And the Emperors body he let take and put
upon a beyr and sent it to Rome. And said to ye Romans / that for Brytayne
and France which he held: other truage would hen one pay. And if they axe^
him any other truages: right such truage he would them pain. The king let
bear Kay to Kenen his own castle and there him entered. And Leygier was borne
to. Boleyne there he was lord. And Holden was borne to Flaunders: there he was
entered: And all the other he let entere with much honor in abbayes and in
houses of relyon in the country that they were slain. And Arthur himself
soiourned that same year in. Bourgoyne with his host and thought the same
year following to pass the mount. Joy: and have gone to. Rome also to have
taken the Cite and have put the Romoyns in subiecyon: but the wicked tyrant.
Mordred him let: as afterye shall here

How the traitor. Mordred: to whom king. Arthur took his land to keep and
his castelles: held them against him*
AS Arthur had taken to. Mordred his reame to keep: and gone against ye Emperor
of rome: and was passed ye see. Mordred ano^e took homages and feats of all
them yt were i^ this land: and would have had this land to his own use: and
took castelles about: and let the^ be arrayed. and after this falsenesse he
did an other great wrong: for against ye law of cryste^ te he took his own
emys wife as a traitor should: ordained him a great host against arthurs coming:
to hold ye land against him with stre^gthe for ever more: and to slay king
Arthur if he might and sent by ye see and by land: and let assemble paynems
and christian people. And he sent to Saxons and to Danys for to help him. and
also. Mordred sent to Cheldrik to send men to hy mour of. Saxon yt was a
worthy duke / and promised him if that he brought with him much people he
wild grant him. Inherytaunce for ever / all the land fro Humbre to
Scotlonde / and all the land that Engist had of. Vortigers ye^re / when that
he spowsed his daughter. And cheldrik came with a great strength and power of
people / and. Mordred had assembled also on his half / that they had.xl.
thousand of strong knights when that they had need.

How Arthur enchanced Mordred the traitor and how he was slain / and also
king Arthur wounded to the death.
AS this tidings came to king. Arthur there that he was in Bourgoyne he was
full sore anoyed / and took all France to Howell for to keep with the half
deal of his men. And prayed him that he would it keep till he came again. For
himself would pass in to Brytayne / and avenge him upon. Mordred that was his
traitor. And forth with Arthur went his way and came to wytsande / and made
his men to go in to ship and would have arrived at Sandwyche / and brought
with him a grace host of Fre^shemen also with his own land men / But or that
he might come to land with his people that were come out of his ships.
Mordred was come with all his power / and yaue a strong battle / so that
king Arthur lost many a man are that he might come to land. For there was.
Gawayne his neuewe slain / and Anguysshell that held Scotlonde / and many
other whereof king. Arthur was full sorry. But after they were come to land.
Mordred might not against them endure. But anon was dyscomfyted and flydde
thens the same night with his men / and upon the morn came to^ London. But tho
of the cite would not suffer him to come in. And from thens he fled to
