wynchestre / and there he him held with his people yt came with him. King
Arthur let take the body of. Gawyne his cofyn / and the body of. Anguysshell /
and let ye one be borne in to Scotlonde / and the other to Dover and buried
Anon after king. Arthur took his way for to destroy mordred / and he fled
thens in to Cornewayle. And ye quen Gun^or yt was king Arthurs wife yt
thosoiourned (...) york / herd ye Mordred was fled thens and that he might
not endure against king Arthur she was fore aferde and had great doubt / and
wist not what was best of all for to done. For she understood well that her
lord king. Arthur would never of her for to have marcy for ye great shame
that she had done unto him / And took her a way pryuely with four men without
moo / and came to. Karlyon / and there she dwelled all there live / and never
after was seen among the folk her life during. King Arthur wist that Mordred
was fled in to Cornewayle / and let send after his men in to. Scotlonde and
Northomberlonde unto Humbre / and let assemble folk without nombre / and came
fro thens in to. Cornewayle to seek and pursewe after Mordred. And Mordred had
assembled to him all the folk of. Cornewayle and had people without nombre
(...) wist that Arthur was coming / and had lever to deye and take his chance
/ than longer flee and abode and yaue an hard battle to king. Arthur and to
his people so that much people was slain what of one side and what of that
other / that noman wist who had the better party. But so it befell at the last
that Mordred was slain and al his folk / and the good chyualry that king.
Arthur had gadred and nourysshed of dyuer lands and also the noble knights of
the round table / that so much were praised thorugh out all the world were
there slain / and king Arthur himself was wounded unto death. But he let him
to be borne to Auioun to be heeled of his wounds. And yet the. Brytons
supposed that he lived in an other land / and that he shall come yet and
conquer all Brytayne. But certes this is ye prophecye of Merlyn. He said
that his death shall be doubtous / and said sothe. For thereof yet men have
doubt / and shall have for ever more as men say. For me^ wot not wyther that
he is on live or deed. Arthur was borne at Auioun the.xxii. year of his regne
after the. Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu Christ.v.C.xlvi. year.

How king Arthur delivered the reame unto Constantyne the sone of Cador his
neuewe
AS king Arthur wyste that he might no longer regne / he let come before
him Constantyne yt was Cadors sone Earl of Cornewayle his cosyn and to him
betoke all his reame and took him said / and bad him thereof to be king till
that he came again / for as much as he had none heeyre of his body begoten. And
great damage was it / that so noble a king and so doughty as he was / had
no child of his body begoten. But all thing that god woll have done must be
done / whose name be blessed without end

How king Constantyne was vexed of Mordred two sons.
THis Constantyne was a noble knight and a worthy of body. And tho two sons
that. Mordred had begoten had great envy of Consta^tyne that tho was crowned
king. And so it befell yt they meued war against him. And assembled a great
host of them that were before with Mordred / and had been driven a way / and
that did much sarowe and anguysshe thrughout all that land. That one brother
ordained / and purposed him toward the ancient Cite of London for to take ye
cite And that other went to wynchestre. But Constantyne came to London and
slew him yt was there. And after he went to wy^chestre and slew him yt was
there also. So yt both his enmyes were deed. And when Constantyne had reigned
well and worthily four year / he deyed and lies at London.

Of the kings Adelbryght and of Edell.
AFter king Constantynes death there were two kings in Brytayne / ye one was
called. Adelbryght yt was a danoys. And he held the country of. Norfolk and.
Southfolke. That other hight Edell and was a. Bryton \ and held Nicholl.
Lendeser / and all the land unto. Humbre. These two kings fast warred
together / but after accorded they were and loved together / as they had been
borne of oo body. The king Edell had a suster that was called Orewenne. And he
gaf her thrught great freodshyp to king. Adelbryght to wife. And he begat upon
her a daughter that was called. Argentyll. And in the third year after came
upon him a strange sykenesse that needs he must deye. And he sent to king.
Edell his brother in law that he should come and speak with him / and he came
to him with a good will. Tho prayed he the king and coniured him also in the
name of god / That after when he were deed / he should take his daughter
Argentyll and the land / and that he kept her well / and nourysshe her in
his chamber. And when she were of aege / she should be married to the strongest
and worthyest man that he might find / and then he should yield up her
land again. Edell it granted and by oath confermed his prayer. And when
Adelbryght was deed and enteryd / Edell took the damoysell. Argentyll / and
nourrsshed her in his chamber: and she became as fair as any might be.

How king Edell married that damoysell to a knave of his kechyne.
THis king Edell that was uncle to Argentyll: be thought how that he might
falsely have the land fro his nyce for ever more: and falsely aynst his oath
thought to dysceyue ye damoysell: and to marye her to a knave of his kechyne
that was called Curan: and he became ye worthyest and strongest man of body
that any man wist in any land that tho lived: and to him he thought her
shamfully have married for to have had her land afterward / but he was clean
dysceyued. For this Curan was Hauelockis sone that was king of. Kyrkelane in.
Denmark: and this. Curan conquered his wives land after ward and slew king
Edel that was h^ wives uncle and had al her land / as in an other place it
tells more openly: and he reigned but.iii. year for Saxons and. Danes hi^
slew and that was great harm to all Brytayn and Srytons bare him to.
Sto^henge and entyred him honorably.

Of king Conan that was Curans cosyn.
AFter this Curan reigned his cosyn Conan that was a wonder proud knight. And
reigned and could have no manner of love / but ever he was medlynge with his
people. And took his uncle with war and slew his two chyldern. The Saxons
warred against him oftentimes: but he them over came: and so he was in peace all
his life tyme^ And he reigned.xiiii. year: And after he deyed and lies at London.

Of king Cortyf and of Gurmonde that came thorugh the paynems in to Brytayne.
AFter this Conan reigned his cosyn cortyf that was behated of all his people and
no thing beloved. and this. Cortyf lost all Brytayne through war. And i^ his
time fell ye great myscheyf in Brytayn ye crystendom was destroyed and all ye
Brytons were dryue^ out of the land and the land lost with out any recover.
But after ward left the land to the Saxons as ye afterward shall here. For
in that time there was a paynem that was called Gormo^de / that was the kings
sone Daufrices of the panems folk that had the reame after his fader / and
was king / sauf he bequaue and yaue it to his brother. And said that he would
never be king / but if that he might get and conquer a reame in a strange
country. For he was bold and strong of body. And of him prophesied Merlyn
and said / that hesholde be a wulf of the sea. And he let assemble paynems
without nombre / and let appareylle ships / and went by many lands / and
took homages and feautees of many. And so he went by the sea and conquered
many diverse lands. So that he came in to Irlonde / and conquered that land /
that often times warred upon. Brytons / and Brytons upon them and often won and
often lost and yaue hostages to Brytons. And so they sent to Gurmonde there that
he was in Irlonde / that he should come in to Brytayne and help them against ye
Brytons / to help them to deliver that land of them / and they would him
hold gladly for their lord. For he was a paynem / and they were paynems and
the Brytons were crystened. well ought he them for to help / so as they were
all of one law. wha^ Gurmonde herd this prayer he hasted him as much as he
might and arrived in Scotlonde / and came in to Northomberlonde there that the
Saxons were dwelling and they confermed the couenau^tes between them that were
made by oaths and by hostages / for to bear him true fay / and hold him for
lord and pay to him truage by the year Tho began the. Saxons and ye.
Affricans to destroy rob and brenne towns / and destroy all theng^ in
asmoche as they might and spared neither man woman ne child learned ne lewd /
But all they slew / and cast down towns castles and chirches / and so put
they all the land in great destruccyon. And as soon as they might flee /
they fled thens as well poor as rich / bishops / abbottes / chanons / and
all other great and small / some in to little Brytayne / and some in to
Cornewayle / all tho ye ships myghht have.

How the king. Gurmonde drove king Cortyf to Chechestre / and slew the
Brytons / and through craft and engyne gate the same town.
COrtyf the king fled thens in to Chechestre that tho was strong / and there
held him.xx. days / and this Gurmonde came and it besyeged. But the cytee was
so strong that he might not get it by no manner of wise with engyne that they
might do. Tho bethought they upon a subtylte for to brenne the town. They
made engynes with glewe of nets / and took pecys of thunder and of fire and
bond it to sparowes feet and than let them flee and they ano^e flewe and
lodged the^ in ye town there yt their nestis were / and in stackes and
euesynges of houses / and ye fire began to kyndle and burnt all ye town / And
when the. Brytons saw that in every side they hyed them out and fought / but
anon they were slain and dyscomfyted / And while battle dured the king
pryuely hid him and stale away in to walys / and men wist never where he
became / and so was the town of Chechestre taken and destroyed. And after.
Gurmonde went and destroyed towns and cytees that never were after made again
/ as it is seen yet in many places of this land.

How this land was called England for the name of Engyst / and how many
kings were made after in this land.
SO when. Gurmonde had destroyed all the land through out: he yaue the land to
the Saxons: and anon they took it with good will / for the Saxons long time
had desired it. For asmoche as they wereof. Engistes kynred that first had all
the land of. Brytayne and let them be called. Englyssmen: for by cause of
Engistes name: and the land they let call England in their langage: and the
folk ben called Englyshmen: for asmoche as in this time it was called Engistes
land when he had conquered it of. Vortiger: that spoused his daughter But fro
the time yt Brute came first in to England: this land was called. Brytane:
and the folk Brytons. But sith the time yt this Gurmonde conquered it eftsoon
and yaue it unto the. Saxons: they anon right changed the name as before is
said. And when this was done. Gurmonde passed over in to France: and there
conquered many lands: and destroyed all christian people there that he came. And
the Saxons dwelled in this land and began fast to enhabyte it at there own
will. And they would have made new kyngis and lords: but they might never
assent to have only oo king for to be to them attendaunt / and therefore they
made many kings in diverse shyres: as it was in Engistes time. The first
kingdom was Kente: and that oath. Southsexe: and the third westsex / the
fourth Eestsex / and the fyfth Nothu^berlonde / and ye sixth Estangle that is
to say Northfolke / and Southfolke and the seventh Mercheryche / and that is
the Erldoste of Nycholl. Hu^tyngdon. Herforde. Gloucetre. wynlchestre. were wyke
and Derby / and so departed all England in to.vii. parties. And after that it
befell that tho kings warred often times together. And ever he that was strongest
took him that was feblest / and so it was long time yt they had no king
crowned among them / ne no christian man was tho among them / ne crystendome
nather. But were paynems till that saint Gregory was pope of: Rome / that had
seen childern of the nacyon of England in the cite of Rome / that were wonder
fair creatures / and had great will and desire them to behold. And axed of
ye merchants whens they were / and of what nacyon. And men told him that
they were of England / and Inglysshe they were called / but they and all the
people of England were paynems: and byleued not upon god. Alas said saint
Gregory: well may they be called English: for they have the vysages of
angels and therefore well ought they to be crystened. And for this cause saint
Gregory theresente saint. Austyn in to England and.xl. good me^ with him that
were of good life and holy men to preche and teache and to comuetre the English
people and them to torn to god: and that was in the.vi. year that saint
Gregory had be pope of Rome / that is to say / ofter thyn carnacyon of our
lord Ihesu Christ.v.C.lxxxv. years as the Cronycle tells.

How saint Austyn baptized and converted king Adelbryght and the bysshoppes
that he made his fellows.
AS saint Austyn came first in to. England / he arryuen in the isle of Tenet
and so passed forth and came unto Caunterbury and there soyourned. And king
Adelbryght of Kent that was the lygnage of Engist goodly received saint Austyn
and his fellows with much honor / and them found all that them neded. And
more over he yaue them a fair place / that now is called the abbay of. Shynt
Austyn / in which place he lyth him self shryned. This king Adelbryght was a
good man and with good will herd saint Austyns predycacyons / and yaue him
leave to preche thrughout all his land before said of Kente / to torn and
convert to him all ye people that he might. It befelle so after thorugh
gods grace / that in little time the king himself was converted to god / and
all his peop of his land were baptized. And in the mean while the people
turned them to god. Saint Austyn came to. Rochestre / and there he preched the
word of god. And the paynems therefore him scorned / and cast upon him reygh
taylles / so that all his mantell was hanged full of these reygh tails / and
for more dyspyte / they cast upon him the guts of reyghes and other fysshe.
wherefore the good man Saint Austyn was sore anoyed and grieved. And prayed to
god that all tho chyldern of that cite that should be borne after ward / that
is for to say in the of Rochestre / might have taylles and so they had And
when the kynger herd of this vengeance that was fall through saint Austyns
prayer. He let make an house in the honor of almighty god / wherein wymmen
should be delivered of their childern at the bryges end / In the which house
yet wymmen of the cite ben delyuerde of child. when that saint Gregory had
hrede tell how the English people were turned to god and comuerted he sent
unto saint. Austyn his pallyon by a b^sshop / that was called Paulin and made
him Prymate and Archebysshop of England And sent word that he should ordeyne
and make dysposynge the land. And anon Austyn had the pallyon of the dygnyte
of the Archebysshyp. He made two bishops of his fellows that came with him fro
Rome and one was called Mellite and he dwelled at London and that other was
called Justin that held the dygnyte at. Rochestre. And this bishop Mellite
tho went to preche in to Estsex and erystened the king of the country that
was called Sicwith that was king Adlebrytes cosyn his systers sone. This
Iustyn went to preche in Southse^ and turned much of the people to god. And
Saint Austyn himself preched thorugh out England.

How saint Austyn went in to waels there the Brytons were / and how they would
not beobedyent tothe. Archebysshop of Canterbury.
SO when all England was crystened and turned to god / saint Astuyn went in to
that land there that the Brytons were for to keep them from Englysshmen /
that is* to say in to ways. And there he found monks and abbayes and.vii.
bishops. For ye Brytons always destroyed the christian people that saint Austyn
had converted. And he said to the bishops that he was a Legate of Rome and
Prymate of all. England / and that they should by all reason to him be
obedyenc and they said they nolde / but to the. Archebysshop of Carlyon they
would. They would never for no manner thing be obedyent to the English men
For the Englysshemen they said ben our adversaries and our enmyes and have
driven us out of our country / and weben christian men and ever have be. And the
Englysshemen have ever be paynems / but now of late that they ben converted.
Saint Austyn of them might have none answer otherwise / but said pertly that
they would never them meke to him / ne to the pope of Rome. And saint Austyn
turned again tho to king Adelbryght yt was king of Kent and told him that his
folk would not be to no man obedyent / but to the. Archebysshop of Carlyon.
And when the king herd this / he was sore anoyed and said that he would them
destroy / and sent to Elfryde king of Northunberlonde that was his friend /
that he should come to him with all the power that he might and that he would
mete him at Leycetre / and fro thens they would go in to walys / and there
destroy the Archebysshop of Carlyon / and all tho that had refused saint Austyn

How king Adelbryght and the king Elfryde slew Brecinall that was a king of
Brytons that held the country of Leycetre.
IT be tell so that there was a king of Brytons that held the country of
Leycetre and all the country about / his name was Brecinall. And this Bryton
herd tell that tho two English kings would mete there at Leycetre for to
goo in to walys. He let ordeyne all the power that he had for to goo fight
with these two kings / but little it auayled him / for his folk that he had
were slain and himself fled / and lost his lands for ever more. And these
two kings Adelbryght and Elfryde dwelled a while at Leycetre / and departed
the land among them / and took homages and feautees of the folk of the
country And after they went to ward walys and thot of walys herd tell of
these comfyture that Breic^all had at Leycetre / and were wonder for adrad of
tho two kyngees. And took and those among them good men and holy of hemytes
monks and priests / and of other people great plentye that went bare foot
and wulwarde for ta have mercy of these two kings / but tho kings were so
stern and so wyked yt they would never speak to the^ but them slew euerychone
Alas for sorrow / for they ne spared them noomore than the wulfe does the
sheep / but smot of their heedes euerychone / and so they were all martrd that
to them came / that is to understand.v.C. and.xl. After they went fro thens
to Bangor for to slay all those that there might there find of the Brytons.
And when ye Brytouns herd that / they assembled and ordened all there power for
to fight with thyem. Two was there a baron in walys that was called. Bledrik of
Cornewayle that some time was lord of Deuenshyre but the king. Adelbright had
dreuen him out in to walys and after there he yaue them battle. And at that
battle was king Adelbright slain and Efrydesore wounded and forsook the
field / and the most party of his people slain. And Elfryde flede in to
Northumberlonde that was his own lo^de^ And after that the people of Leycetre
shyre made with strenght Cadewan yt was Brycinals sone king of Leceytre / And
he afterregned nobly and with great honor.

How Cade wan king of Leycetre and Elfryde king of Northumberlonde were
friends / and of the debate yt after was between Edwyn and Cad walyn that were
both their sons
ANd after that this bataylle was done yt Brytons assembled them and went
thens and came to Leycetre / and made there Caudewan that was Brecinals sone
king of Leycetre and of all the country. Aed he took homages and feautes of
all the folk of the country. And after that he assembled a great host and
said he would goo in to Northumberlonde / to destroy king Elfryde and sle him
if he might. And when he was come thither / friends went so between them that
they accord them in this manner / that Elfryde should hold all the land fro
Northumberlonde to Scotlonde. And Cadewan should have all the land a this side
Humbre to the Southe / and after they were good friends all their life / and
loved as they had been brethern. And this Elryde had a sone called Edwyn that
held all^ the land of Northu^berlonde after his fathers death as his fader
had hold all his life time And Cadewa^ had another sone called Cadwalyn that
held his faders land as he it held while he was alive / and these loved as
brethren. And ye love lasted betwyxt them but only two year / and after began
debat betwyxt them through a synple enuyous cosyn of Cadwalins. called Bryens
/ so yt they assembled a great host in both parties. And at the last it be
fell ye Cadwalin was dyscu^forted / and Edwen him pursued and drove him fro
place to place so at the last he fled in to Irelonde. And ye other destroyed
and pylled his land / and cast down castles and burnt his manners / and
departed all Cadwalins land among his friends. And long time after came
Cadwalen again fro Irlonde with a strong pour / and in plain battle slew
Edwyn and all his friends / and namely tho yt with held his lands by Edwyns
yefte.

How king Oswallde was slain though king Cadwalin and Peanda / and how
Oswy that was saint Oswaldes brother reigned after him and slew Peanda.
AS Edwyn was slain. Offris his sone undertook that war ayenste Cadwalin his
came / so yt this Offris deyed during ye war. And after ye death of this
Offris tho reigned a gentyl christian man that much loved god almighty yt had all
the land of Northumbrelonde by heritage / yt was called Oswalde and he was
king of all the land. But for as much as he was friend to Edwyn / and held
a great part of the land of Cadwalin. This same cadwalyn warred upon him and
drove him to ward Scotlond. And when Cadwalin saw that he would not abide.
Cadwalin would no longer him pursue / but took some of his folk to Peanda his
brother in law and prayed him to pursue after Oswalde / till that he were taken
and slain / and Cadwalin toruned home again. when Oswalde herd these tidings
that Cadwalin turned home again / he would no le^ger flee / but abode Peanda
and yaue him battle / and Peanda was dyscomfort^e and fled and came again to
Cadwalyn and said that he would never hold one foot of land of him / but if
so were that he would avenge him of Oswalde. Cadwalin let assemble a great
host for to fight with Oswalde so that he and Peanda came to Northumberlonde
and yaue battle unto Oswalde And in the same battle was Oswalde slain and
his heed smyten of / and after he was entered at the abbay of Berdenay in
which place god had wrought for him many a fair miracle / both there and
else where. And anon Oswy his brother seized all the land in to his hand
that was this Oswaldis And the folk of Northumberlonde loved him wonderly well
/ and held him for their lord. But he had men of his kynne worthy enough that
would have departed the land / and they warred togyed well. And for asmoche as
they were not strong enough / they came to Peanda and prayed him of help and
socour. And behyght him of ye lord largely upon this covenant that he would
them govern and help / and counseyl Peanda herd their prayer and so spoke
with Cadwalyn / that he should ordain a great host and fast ordained him in
to Northumberlonde for teyght with Oswy. And Oswy was a meke man / and much
loved peace and charity and prayed Peanda of love and peace and profe^ede him of
gold and silver great plentye. And this Peanda was so proud yt he nolde
grant him peace fo no manner thing but for all thing he would with him fight.
S^o at the last there was set a day of battle. And Oswy ever trusted upon
god and Peanda trusted tomoche upon pride and upon his host that he had. And
to gyder they smote egerly but Peanda was anon dyscomforted and slain. And
this was After the Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu Christ.v.C.lv. year And this
Oswy reigned.xxviii. year And a king that was called Oswyne / that was Peandaes
cosyn warred upon him and together fought / But Oswy had the victory of
Oswyne. And Oswyn was dyscomforted and slalyne / and lies at Tynnemouth.

How king Cadwaldre that was Cadwalins sone reigned after his fader / and was
the last king of Brytons.
AFter the death of Cadwelin reigned his sone Cudwaldre well and nobly. And his
mother was ye sister of Peanda. And when he had reigned.xii. year / he fell in
to a great sykenesse / and then was there a great dyscorde between the
lords of the land / that every of them warred upon other. And yet in that
time there fell so great derth and scarsyte of corn and other viteylles in this
land / that a man might go.iii. or iiii. days fro town to town yt he
should not find to bye for gold ne silver bread / wine ne none other vitayle
where which a man might live. But only the people lived by rotis of herbs /
for other living had they none / so much was it faylled all about / Fysshes
/ wild bestes / and all other thing so that yet to this mysauenture / there
fell so great mortalyte and pestelens among the people by the corrupcyon of
the air that ye living people suffysed not to burye the deed bodies. For they
deyed so suddenly / both great and small lord and servant / in etynge
going and speaking they fell down and deyed / so that never was herd of more
sodeyne death among the people For he that went for to burye the deed body /
with the same deed body was buried. And so they that might flee fled and
forsook their lands and houhes / as well for the great hungre derth and
scarsyte of corn and other vitayll / as for the great mortalyte and pestylence
in the land / and went into other lands for to save their lives and left
the land all deserte and wast / so yt there was noman for to travail and
tylthe the land So that the land was barayne of corn and all other fruytes
for defawte of tyllyers / and this mysauenture dured.xi. year and more that
noman might ere ne sow

How Cadwaldre went out of this land in to little Brytayne.
CAdwaldre saw great hungre mortalyte and pestylence / and the land all poor
/ and faylynge corns and other vytaylles / and his folk perysshed / and saw
also the most party of his land all wasted and void of people. He
apparelled him and his folk that were left alive / and passede over in to
little Brytayne with a little navy unto king Alayne that he much loved / that
was his cosyn and that his fader had much loved in his time. And as they
sailed in the sea / he made much lamentacyon / and so did all tho that were
with him and said. (Dedisti nos domine tanquan^ oues escaru^. et in gentibus
dispersisti nos)

ANd then began Cadwaldre to complain him to his folk pyteously and sayd^
Alas said he / to us wretches and caytyues is sorrow for our great synnys / the
which we would not amend us while we had space / and now repentance is comen
upon us through my sauenture / which chaced us out of our reame and propre
soil. And out of the which sometime Romans. Becottes. Saxons / neither Danys
might not exyle us. But what auaylleth it now to us that before time / often
times have gotten many other lands / sith it is not the will of god that we
abide and dwell in our own land. God that is very Judge yat all things
knows before they ben done or made / he sees that we would not cesse of our
sins / and that our enmyes might not us ne our lygnage exyle fro / and out
of our reame He would that we amend us of our folyes and that we see our
propre defautes.

And therefore has showed to us wrath / and woll chastyse us of our misdeeds.
Syche that he does us with out battle / or strength of our enmyes / by grace
companyes / wretcchedly to leave our reame and propre land. Torn again ne ye
Romanys / torn again ye Scotts torn again ye Saxxons / torn again ye
Frau^soys. Now seweth to you Brytayne all deserte the which your power might
never make deserte / ne yet our power has not put us now in exyle But only
the power of the king allmyghty whom we have often offended by our folyes /
the which we would not leave until he chastyced us by dyuyne power Among the
worlds and lamentacyon that the king Cadwhldre made to his folk / they
arrived i^ little Brytayne / and came to king Alayne before said And the king
received him with great Joy / and made him to be seruede wonder nobly. And
there abode they long time after The Englesshe people that were left a live
and were escaped the great hungre and mortalyte / lived in the best wise that
they might. And much people sprange and came of them And they sent in to
Saxonye where that they were borne to there friends for men / wyemen / and
children / to restore the cytees with people and the towns that were all void
of people / and for to labor / traueyll and tylthe the earth. when the Saxons
herd these tidings / they came in to ye land wonder thyeke in great
companyes / and herborowed therselfe in the country all about where that they
would / for they found no man them for to let ne withstonde. And so they
waxed and multeplyed gretely. And used the manners and customs of the country
whereof they were come. And they used also the laws and the langages and speech
of their own land that they came fro. And also they changed all the names of
Cytyes / twones / castelles / and brought / and yaue them names and called as
they now ben called And they held the Counrees. Baronages and lordeshyps in
manner as the Brytons before time had compassed them / And among other great
companyes that came from Germayne in to this land / came the noble queen that
was called Se^burga with men and wymmen without nombre^ And arrayed in the
country of Northumberlonde / and took the land from Ilbion unto Cornewaylle
for her and for her folk. For there was none that might the^ let / for all
was desolace and void of people / but it were a few poor Brytons that were
left on mountayns and woddes until that time. And fro that time forth lost
the Brytons this reame for all their days. And the English people begane to
regne / and departed the lord between them. And they made many kings about
by diverse parties of the land as here ben dyuyded. The first of westesexe /
The second^ Merchenriche / The third Estangle / the fourth Kente / the fyfth
Southsex. All those reigned in this land after ye Cadwaldre was passed out of
this land / and dwelled in little Bryten with king Alayne his cosyn and true
friend. And when he had long dwellede there / and had knowing that the
mortalyte and pestelence was ouerpassed / and that the land was replenysshed /
again with people / he thought to torn again in to his land And prayed king
Alayne his cosyn of socour and help yt he might be restored again to his owoe
propre reame and first dygnyte / And king Aleyne granted him his asking.
Then did he appareylle him to take his wayt and vyage in to this land. And
prayed god allmyghty devoutly that he would make to him demonstracyon / if his
prayer to this land were too hyme plesaunt or none / for ayenste the will of
god allmyghty he would no thing do. wha^ he had thus devoutly made his prayer
/ avoys fro heaven to him said. And had him leave ye Iurney a way in to
England / and that he should goo to the pope of Rome for it was not the will
of almighty god yt the Brytons should regne more in Brytane / ne never
recovered it unto the time of the prophecye that Marlyn said before he
fu^fylled. And that should never be unto ye time were come / that the relyques
of his body shall be brought fro Rome and translated in to Brytayne / And when
the ralykes of other saints that have been hedde for ye persecucyon of the
paynem folk shall be found and openly showed / thenn shall they recover
their land again / the which they have so long time lost through their
deserts. whane Cadwaldre had herd this answer / he maruayled gretely and
told it to the king Aleyne Thene king Aleyne did send for the clergy of
his land / and made them to bring the stories and prophecyes that Merlyn and
Sybyll had said in their prophcyes. And when he knew that the prophycye that
Festom had prophesied of the Egle. And other prophecyes accorded to the dyuyne
answer that Caddewalldre had herd. He counseled him and right faithfully
desired him to leave his people and his navy / and submytte him to the
dyspocysyon of god / and do all that the angel had commanded him. Thenye
Cadwaldre called y^or his sone and ymori his cosyn that was his systers sone /
and said to them. Takes said he my folk and my navy that is here all ready /
and pass into walys and be ye lordees of Brytons that no dyshonoure come to
them by interrupcyon of the Paynem folk for defaute of lords. And thene
himself left his reame of Brytayne and his folk for ever more / and took
his way unto the pope of Rome Sergius the which worshypede him much / and so
he was confessed / and took penance for his sins. And he had not long
dwelled there that he ne deyed / the.xii. Kalendis in May ^ the year of
grace.v.C.lxxii.

How king Offa was sovereign above all the kings of England / and how every
king warred upon other.
IT befell so that all the kings in that time that were in you land. as they
of westsex. Marchenryche. Estangle / of kente / and of Southsex and of other
costs each warred upon other And he that most might took the land of him
that was most feblest. But there was a king among them that was called Offa
/ that was saint Oswaldes brother. This Offa conquered all the kings of ye
land / and reigned all above them all. And s^^ great was the yt war in every
there between greeks / that no man might wit how the land went. But abbottos
pryours / and men of Relygyon wrote yt lives and deeds of kings / and how
long every of them reigned and in what country and in what manner every king
deyed / and of bishops also. And thereof made great bokys and let call them
Chronicles. And the good king Alured had that book in his ward. And let
bring it unto wynchestre / and let it be fast tacked to a pylar that men
should it not remeue / ne bear it thens / so that every man should it see and
thereupon look For therein ben the lives of all the kings that ever were in
England.

How the king of Northumberlonde Osbryght forlaye the wife of Buerne Bocarde
through strength / and after this Buerne conquered the king with power and
strength.
ANd thus it befell in ye same time / that there was a king in Northumberlond
^e that was called Osbryght / and soyourned at york. And this king went
him upon a day in to a wood him for to / dysporte. And as he came again / he
went pryuely in to a good man's house / that was called Buerne / and the good
man of that place was gone that time to the sea. For oftentimes there he was
wont to spy thieves and robbers that oftentimes were wont to come in to the
land / to rob / brenne / and slay. The lady that was Buernes wife was a
wonder fair woman. And the king came unto her when that herhusbode was
absente / and she trusted none harm unto the king / and welcomed him with
much honor / and worthily him served in all thing. when the king had eten
/ he took the lady by the hand and ^adde her in to a chamber and said. He
would speak with her a counseyll. And all the folk he made void fro the
chamber / save only the lady and he. But the lady wist not wherefore he it did
/ till that he had done all his will. And when he had done this deed / He
turned again to york. And the lady he left there sore weeping for the deed
that the king to her had done. And when he^ lord was came home and saw her
weep and such sorrow and morning make / he axed of her what she had done /
and why she made such sorrow. Sire she said / subtylly and falsely the king
Osbryght^ has do me shame and vylanye ayeast my will. And told him all the
truth how the king had ^orlayne her with strength / wherefore she said she
had lever to be deed than tolyue. Fair love be stylle said he / for against
strength feblenesse is yltell worth / and therefore of me shalt thou
nevertheless beloved and namely for thou have told me the treuthe. And if
almighty god grant to me my life I shall the aueng. This Buerne was a great man
and a mighty lord / and was well beloved and great friends had. And let
send for the grettest lords of the land / and to them made hes complaynte of
the despyte / that the king to him had done and said / he would be avenged
how ever yt were. And all his friends counseylled him that he should goo unto
york there that the king was him to defye. And Buerne took his main and came
to the king. when the king him saw / he called him curtously Buerne by name.
And Buerne him answerred to him said. Sire I you defye / and yield up feautes
homages and lands / and as much as I have holden of you / and fro this time
for ward I will never of the nothing hold. And so he departed fro the king
without more speech or any abiding and took leave of his friends and went in
to Denmark / and playned to the king Godern / and told him of the despyte of
that the king Osbryght to him had done of his wife. And prayed him of
socour / and help him for to avenge. when king Godern of Denmark and the
danys had herd the complaynt of this Buerne / and the prayer that he badde /
they were right wonder glasde in their hertes / for as much as they might
find a cause for to goo in to England for to warree upon Englesshe men / and
for to aenge Buerne of the despyte that the king Osbryght had done unto his
wife. And for as much as Buerne was sybbe unto the king of Denmark / anon
they let ordeyne a great host of men and let ordeyne them ships / and
as much as them need for to have to that vyage. And when all the host was
ready / the king made his two brethern chyef capytayns / that were noble
knights of body and also bold. That one was called Hunga / and that other
Hubba.

How the Danys took york / and slew the king Osbrygt / and soon after
slew king Eelle.
Sall was ready yt two brethern took leave ofthe king Godren. and went toward
the sea for to passe^ over in to Inglonde as fast as they might speed Now is
Buerne so well comforted and fast hyed him with the Danys that they ben
arrived in the North country and comen through out Holdernes / and destroyed all
the country and brenned towns / and robbed folk / and slew all that they
might take till that they came unto york. And when king Osbryght saw them
come / He took all his people that he had with him and came out of the cytee
and faught with them / but no foyson he ne had against them / and much of
the people that there was were slain on both partyas. And king Osbryght him
self there was slain / and the cite anene was take and the Danys went in. And
there was also an other king in Northumberlonde / that Buernes friends had
those and held him for king / a man that was called Elle / for as much as
they would not to king Osbryght be attendan^t / for the despyte that he had
done unto Buerne their cosyn. It befell thus that the king Elle was gone in to
the wood him for to dyosporte and of the venyson some he had taken. And as he
sat in the wood at meet / to a knight he said. we ha^ well spedde and much
venyson taken. And with that word came in a man and to him said if yeso much
of venyson have won / an hodred times so much more there against have ye
lost. For all this country the Danys have gotten / and taken the Cytee of
york / and against you shall it hold / that never ye shalcome therein / and for
so much they have slain king Osbryght. when king Elle herd these words /
he let assemble all the folk of he country and ordained all the power that
he might have and would have gotten the town of york with strength. But the
Danys came out anon and yaue him a strong battle. And selwe the king Elle
and the most part of ye people yt he had brought with him. And the same place
there they were slain / shall ever more be called Elle crofte / and that
place is a little from york. And the rested the Danys never till that they
had conquered all Northumberlonde. And in that country they made wardeynes /
and went further in to the land / and took Notyngham. And there they abode
all ye winter / and dyed all the sorrow that they might And after when Somer
time came they remeued from Notyngham and came in to Nicholl and Lyndesey /
and to Holonde. For no man might them wythstande / so much power and
strength they had

How saint Edmo^de the king was Martyred
ANd so far had the Danys passed from / country to country. and ever
more brynnynge and robbynge and destroyenge all that they might tylle they came
unto / Tetstforede. and in that country they found a Christian king / that
much loved god and his works that was called Edmonde. And he was a king of
Norfolk and Southfolke This saint Edmonde king ordained as much folk as he
might / and fought with the Danys / but he and his folk were dyscomfyted /
And the king himself driven unto the castle of F^amelynham. And the Danys
him purshewed / and came unto ye same castle / And when king Edmonde saw
that the castle might not them withstand he came ayenste them / with whom
the Danys first did speak. And anon they a^ed of him where king Edmonde was.

How forsothe said he when I was in the castle / there was the hyng / and
when I went out of the castle he went out also / and whether he shall escape
or deye / at gods will must it all be. when saint Edmonde had named god
/ by that word wyste they well that it was him self And anon Hubba and
Hu^gar took him and said / that he should god forsake and all christian laws /
as many other had done him before^ And saint Edmonde said that he would never
/ but rather he would suffer death for gods love and his laws to.

Tho took they king Edmonde and bond him unto a tree / and made their archers
to shote at him with arowes / till that his body sty^ked as fulle of arowes as
an orchen is fulle of pryckes. But for all the pain that they him did he
would never god for sake. And in the same pain / and torment he deydd / and
betoke his soul unto almighty god. And when they saw that he was deed / they
smote of his heed. And of this manner as ye have herd was saint Edmonde
martred.

How Hubba and Hungar took the town of Redynge
SO when Saint Edmonde was martred. Hungar and Hubba yede thens with all the
Danys unto Redynge. and as they went thyderwarde they burnt towns and tyees
/ and slew all christian pele yt wolde^ opnote forsake hod / and cast down
church and came to Redynge and took the town and there held them till that
the king Edelf of westsex came thither with all his power for to take the
towns Tho came out the Danys for to give battle to Edelf / and at that
battle was slain an earl of the Danys that was called Sidrak. Upon the morrow
came king Eldred and his brother Alured with a strong power and a great
host. And the king Edelf came again that had foughten the day before to
that bataylle And the Danys tho came out for to fight with them / and the
bataylle was wonder strong For many a man was there slain and the Danys that
day had the vyctorye / and the king Eldred and his brother Alared that day
were dyscomfyted. But the fourth day after ward the Danys and the English
fought tohyder an other time upon Elkedene / and there was slain a king of
Denmark that was called Rafin and four earls of great power. And that day
had the Danys shame / for they were driven unto Engilfelde. And the.xv. day
after the Danys and the English men fought an ather time at Rafynge and there
were the Englysshemen dyscomfyted / and from thens a dane yt was called Roynt
went to redynge with his host and destroyed all that he might take. And king
Eldred faught with him / but he was wounded sore wherefore he deyed / and he
reigned but.v. year / and lies at womborn.

Circa annu^ dm^.iii.C.xlix.
LEo the first was Emperor after Marcianus.xvii. year. In his time were the
Ragacyon days ordained before ye Ascensyon of saint Marmer bishop of Vyenne.
The pope of Rome at that time hight Leo a noble clerk / and with him had many
clerks. Hellar us was pope after Leo.vii. year This man ordained yt no bishop
should ordeyne his successary) vt pz.viii.ix.i. Simplicius was pope after him /
which ordained that no clerk should take no garment to be clothed in after
the seculer manner of a lay man / by the reason of his office or of his
benefyce. zeno was Emperor after. Leo.xv. year / and this man was an heretyke
and cruel against criste^ men. And in this man's days the bodies of saint
Mathewe the Euangelyst and saint Barnaby were found / and with them the
gospel that saint Mathewe wrote. About this time there was a certain common
woman bare.vii: chyldern at on birth / of the which one was made after king
of Lombardye. Felix the third was pope after Symplicius three year and.viii.
months. This man ordained that respyte should be yeuen to a man that was
accused that he might auyse him how heshlode answer And that the Iuges and the
accusers should be such / and that they should take all suspeccyon and
spytte. Gelasius a Romayne was pope after Felix.v. year This man ordained the
Canon of the mass. with the Preface / ympnes / tractes / orysons / as saint
Ambrose made them / and that ordres should be yeuen four times in the year.
Anastasius was Emperor after zeno.xxvii. year / and he was a cursed man and an
heretyke / and hateful to god and man. And he was slain with lyghtuynge^ And
in his time deyed saint Patryke the first bishop of^ Irlonde / in the.C.xxii.
year of his aege. And his fellow was ye abbot of Columba and saint Brygyda whom
saint Patryk made a Nonne And they were buried in one tomb / and at diverse
times and this is the Epitaphi (Hii tres i^ gelido: cumulo tumulantur in vno.
Brigida patricius: atque columba pius) Anastasius a Romayne was pope after
Gelasyus two year and three months. The which ordained that no pressed for
wrath ne hate should leave of to say his dyuyne service in the church /
except the mass. And he cursyd the emperor Anastasius for he was an heretyke /
and yt is written of him / that afterward he turned for dread to the opinion of
the emperor. And he is called ye second evil famed pope yt is in (Catholico
pontificu^) And before him was Liberius famed in heresye.

Anno dm^.iiii.C.lxxxiiii.
SIinachus was pope after him.xv. year / and with him was ordained an other
pope that was called Laurencius / and betwext them was a great dyscencyon. And
they both put them to the Judgment of Theodoria the king and he Iuged that
he that was first ordened and that most men of the church held with should
be pope. And Symachus preualid the which loned the church and pore men and
for Paschalius the deaken Cardynal held against Symachus with the part of
Laurence to his death Therefore he was put to the pains of purgatori / to keep
the batthes after his death / as Gregory says in his book of Dyalogis. This
man ordained that) Gloria in excelsis) should be said every Sunday and feestes
of martyrs.

Nota. That England was long time Crystened before France.
CLodianus the first Christian king of France / was this same thyme baptized
of saint Remigio / and he had a crystyn woman to his wife / and she meued him
many times to the faith and said. He should be fortunable and victoryous if he
would torn / and so he was and never before. Hornusda was pope after
Synachus.ix. year. This man was of great mercy and alms to poor men / and
ornamentis he gave many to chyrches. And here consyled ye Greeks / yt which
were cursed for their heresye. Justinius was emperor after Anastasasius^ And he
reigned ix. year and was a very christian man / and all that ever the emperor
Anastasius had done ayeust the church / he revoked / and obeyed the pope
Hornusda / and called again the bishops that were exyled be his prede cessours.
Priscanus gramaticus was this time. And this year the which is the.lxxi. fro
the coming of the Saxons / began the kingdom of west Saxon / and Cerdico was
king Ioha^nes was pope after Hornusda three year and.ix. montches. and
Theodocius the king of ytaly an heretyke took the pope with other Senators and
sent them to the Emperor Justinius / determining yt and he would not let
the heretykes be in peace he should slete all christian folk in ytaly. And after
he took pope John^ and Simachu^ patriciu^ and Boyclu^ the Senators and slew
them in prison. But Boys defended him by ye reason of thauctoryte of the
Senators / and he sent him to ye cite of Papy for perpetuell exyle / where he
made the book De consolatio^e philosophy And at the last the country of
Mediolanen^ he caused Boys throat to be cut / and so he deyed. Felix pope
succedded John^ four year. This man command yt syke men should be aneled for
the death / but christ ordained ye first. Iustinianus was Emperor xxxviii. year
/ this man drew the law of the Romans out of almoost.ii.M. books.
and.iii.C. verses over long and according in to oo volumen of.xii. books and
called it Justinian. He made also the Digestes and divided the^ in to.iii.
bokys. Bonifacius the second was pope after Felix two year / and little of him
is written. Ioha^nes the second was pope after Bonifacius / and this man had a
great stryf with Iustinianus the emperor / whether ye christ was of.ii. natures
or one. The pope said he had two natures. One of god and an other of man. The
emperor said / other co^sente to us / or thou that go in to perpetuell exyle.
The pope answered I desire to come to Iustilianus the most c^isten Emperor /
but as me seems I have found Dyoclesyan the persecutour of christian man But
certainly I dread not thy malice / Ne I fere not thy threthynges. Then the
Emperor meked hymslef and fell down to the ground / and asked mercy and
absolucyon.

Anno dm^.v.C.xxxiiii.
AGapitus a confessor was pope after John^ two year / this Agapitus turned
Iustimanus fro the error fully of the heretykes. This man ordained that
processyo^s should be done the Sondayes and then he dyed art Constantynoble.
and Siluerius a martyr was pope after this man three year. He was exyled fro
christian faith / and slain by the proctour of Theodory. For he would not
restore ye bishop of Athenes an heretyke to his benefyte aye^. Virgilius was
pope after him.xviii. year. And he entered evil to his benefyte / but he
governed him well. And he suffered his persecucyon pacyently. And he was exyled
fro Rome. And at the last after great passyo^s of Theodory in Constantynople
deyed. Synodus quatra constantinopolitana co^tra theodoru^ and o^^s hereticos
alios fuic isto te^pore. Ista synodus dampnauit heresim theodori ^ Qui dixit
alium esse deu^ veru^. and aliu^ cristu^. Et quoth beata virgo non sit dei
genitrix. sed hominis tantu^ Pelagius was pope after Vigilius four year and.x.
months: This man ordained that heretykes Scismatykes and Rennegates / should
be punysshed by the seculer power. Johannes the third was pope after this
man.xiii. year. Of this man little is written / but that he restored the
chyrcheyerde of ye appostles Philyp and Jacob. Justinius the second after
Justinian was Emperor.xi. year. This man despised poor men He robbed ye
Senators. He was yeuen to all coueytousnesse / so that he made chestes of iron
/ for to keep his moyneye in. Then anon he fell in heresye / and wexed out
of his mind. And then was chose Tyberyus a good man for to govern the common
people. Tyberius ye second was Emperor aftest Justinius.vii. year. This man
was a virtuous man. He yaue Innumerable good to poor men In so much many
times yt his wife chydde with him and said that he cast away the goods of the
Empire as stones. And he answered again and said. I trust in god that our
chestes shall never lack of money / and we put tresour in to heaven. And upon
a certain day when he went by his palys at Constantynople / he saw in the
mar^yll pament a cross graven / And thought ye should not be trodden upon and
commanded that stone to be left up. For the cross ought to be put in the
hertes of faithful men and there he found Inestymable tresoure of gold. This
man subdued Herses / and deyed blyssydly. Benedictus was pope after Iohanes
four year: This man suffered great persecucyon of hungre pestelence and enmyes.
This man brought many a thousand quarter whete from Egypt / when Rome was
besyeged by king Albanack / and almoost lost for vytayll. wherefore they wrote
on his grave this Epitaphi. Magna tuis monimenta pater benedycte re iquis:
virtutum ti^tulus et decus atque dolor Pelagius was Emperor after
Benedictus.v. year. In his time Rome was besyged by the Lombardes / and little
he did in his days. Mauricius was Emperor after Tyberyus.xxi. year. This man
was a very christian man and subdued Persas and Armenyas / and in the later end
of his days he dyscorded with saint Gregory and intended to have slain him.
And then^e appeared a man in Rome clothed a in relygyous habyte / holding a
naked sword in his hand / and cried about the Cite in this wise. The
Emperor shall be destroyed. The which the emperor herd / and he corrected
him self of his trespaas and prayed to god to withdraw his sentence. To whom
our lord apperyd in his sleep and said. will thou that I spare the now or i^
time to come. And he was a lover of wretches / and said / give me here my
reward. Then^e was he Emperor after many a deye And when he should have
corrected his knytes for the extorcyon that they did / they asked him why yt he
would not pay them their wages. And so they fell at varyaunce / and chose Foka
for to be Emperor and slew him and his three sons. This time saint Austyn
came in to England and ordained two Archebysshops that is to say of London /
and of york by the commandment of saint Gregory. And remember that many
times is made me^cyon of diverse regyons and countries / that of time they have
be turned to ye faith For always the faith abode not in them for diverse causes
So it is of England. France. Persia. Iewery. And in this thing Rome was
pryueleged / for the faith of Peter never failed. Focas was Emperoor after
Maurici his master / whom he and other slew. And by cause he began evil he
ended naught. For in his days the Romans faught strongely against the Persees
/ and the Romans were dysco^fyted and lost many a prouynce. And at the last
he was overcome and slain of Heraclius. For as he did unto other men / so he
was done unto.

Anno dm^.v.C.lxxxiiii.
GRegory the first a Romayne and amonke was pope after Pelagyus.xiii. year.
This man was called Gregoryus magnus for many things yt he exceded in: He
passed other men in power / in riches / in virtue / in noblynesse / in wisdom
/ in holiness / in fame / and in experyence. and under this man the evil
things of cursydnesse passyd were sessed. and many a nobled book he worte to
the Incomparaple profit of all holy church / He was one of the pryncypall
doctors of all the four doctors of ye church / This man forsooth alone with
saint Fabyan after saint Peter / was chosen of god in all the ordres of the
popes of Rome / Many things he ordained in the church / as is showed in his
regystre (Deus in adyutoryu^) for to be before the begynnygge of ye hours he
commanded to be said. He renewed and made all ye officers of the church in a
fair and a more compendyous manner / the which abides yet unto this day /
and is called Gregorianu^. and shortly for to conclude on this holy man /
man's tongue cannot express lightly ye louynges of this man what in wrytynges
/ and also in example of virtuous deeds. and Saninianus was pope after Gregory
one year and.v months This man ordained tyngynge of belles at the hours of
the day / but this man bachyted saint Gregory for his lyberalyte that he had
to poor men and thought he spe saint Gregory rebuked him thryes for it. And
the four the time he lay in his bed / and thought saint Gregory smote him on
the heed / and he waked and deyed anoe This was the third pope among the
popes the which is noted to deye a dredefull death B^^facyus the third was
pope after Saniniamus.viii. months. He ordained yt none but white clothes
should be put upon the awter^ Bonifacius the fourth was pope four year and
^viii. months / this man purchased of the Emperor Focas the church of
saint Peter of Rome should be the heed of all the church in the world. For
before Constantynople was the heed church. Also he gate lyce^ce yt the church
called Panton the which was dedy^ate to the honor of Neptunus and other falls
gods / where christian men many times were slain of deuylles / might be
dedicate to ye worship of all saints in heaven. This man ordained that monks
might use the office of prethynge / crystenynge / and confessing.

Heraclius was Emperor after Focas.xiii. year. And in the third year of his
regne. Cosdras the king of Perse burnt Iherusalem and other worshypfull
places. zachary the patryarke with other much people he took in captyuyte The
part of the holy cross / the which Eleyne left there he took with him in
to his country. But the.xii. year of Heraclius. Cosdras was slain of
Heraclyus and the cross was brought again / the people were delivered. And when
Heraclius would have entered the cytee proudely / the yates of the cite by power
of god shytte therself / and the Emperor meked him to god above and the yates
opened. And then was the feste of the exaltacyon of the cross made. Deus
dedit was pope after Bonifacius three year / this was an holy man. For on a
certain day when he kyssed a lyppre / anon the leppre was hole. This time a
Cyteyzin of London through ye mocyon of Ethelbryghte builded a church of saint
Peter in the west part of London / in a place that was called Thorneye.

Circa annu^ dn^i.vi.C.xliiii.
BOnyfacyus the fyfthe was pope after Deus dedit five year. The which ordened
that noman should be taken out of the chiccheyarde. And little else of him is
wryteu.

Nota Machomitum.
Machomite the duke of Sarrasyns and Turks was this time. And he was ye
dysseyuer of all the world / a faulse profete / ye messenger of the devil.
The forgooer of antecryst ye fulfyller of herecye / and of all falls men the
meruayllest^ Of whom the dominacyon thus began^ There was a certain famous
clerk at Rome and / could not speed in his matters yt desired to have speed in.
Thene he recedde from Rome over the sea and procured many a man to have gone
with him. Among whom was this Machomyte a great man of wit. And this clerk
promised him to make him duke of the country if he would be gyded after him
There he nouryssed a douue / and put all the corn that ye douue ete in
Machom^ ee^e and so this douue had never no meet but in his eere The foresaid
clerk on a day called the people and meued the^ to these such a p^^nce as
the holy ghost would show to them in likeness of a douue. And anon this clerk
secretly let flee this douue / the which after his old custom that he
wont to / fell anon to ye sholdyr of Machomyte and put his bylle in his eere.
And the people saw this / anon he was chose^ duke of that people of Corosame
/ he said that he was the very prophet of god Then he made a book of his
law that was called Alkaron. But he did it by Informacyon of three of his
masters. To whom the devil minystred the autoryte and the conning. The
first master was a Jew a great Astronomyer and a Nygramancer. The second
was John^ de Anthiochia. The thurde was Sergius an herytyke. And these three
made an ungracious law and an unhappy. And what someuer was hard of believe
and noyous to do / they left that out of the law / and they put that thing
in the law / the which the worldly men were prove and ready to do. That is to
say. Glotony / Lethery / repyne / and such other. And also this Machomyte
ordained that a man should have as many wives as he might occupye and find /
and refuse them twyes or thryes / or four times / and take them agayye / and
many meruayllous and falls things ht made in his law / the which were to
long to reherce here But they be plain in his book of. Alkaron^ And ever he
wrote in his book / that our lord spoke to. Machomyte his prophet / saying
on this wise / or on this. Thus by his false means he dysceyued the people.
And when his masters and he had made this that was so delectable. He wrote it
in a book with letters of golden And also he nourysshed a mighty camel
secretly in a pryue place / and alonly with ye hondes of. Machomyte was always
fed / and there pryuely he tied this book of the law that he had made about
the camels neck \ and put this camel forth on a time in to the field before
day. And this camel Ioyed in his lyberte for he was never lose before. And he
would suffer no man to come and touch him. And so there was a great fame of
such a camel / and the people ran to see him. Among whom was this
Machomyte. But when the camel saw him that had fed him al way. Anon he
ran unto him. And he had taught this camel before time to fall down on his
knees and lycke his hondes. And so he did before all that people. The people
then cried and said / that there was a very ensample yt he was the true
prophet of god. Then they prayed Machomyte to open that holy book with his
holy hondes / the which was sent from heaven ever more to be kept. In ye
which book is showed how the people shail worship god. And Machomyte said /
this book was written with angels hand / So by these falls means / he turned
to his law all the land of. Perse / and all the Eest Imperyall against.
Heraclium the Emperour^ And he occupied unto the end of Ale^dndre and Egypt.
Libya. Arabya and Siria. Then after he enfected all Affrycam. And but the
grace of god wythstode him / He had enfected all Spain and France. And many
other things he did which were to much to write in this book.

COnstantyne the third / the sone of Heraclii was Empour.xxvii. year. This
Constantyne was a great tyrant and a cursyd man / and an heretyke. Falls /
subtle / and odyous to christian men. Ne he gaaf no place to pope. Mertyne / and
he raised a great host against the Lombardes. And there he lost the field /
and fled unto Rome. And honorably was received of the pope Viteliianus / and
other of the the cite. And he rewarded not them like after their merytes as a
prince should have done. But used forth tyranny and heresye. wherefore at the
last he was slain of his own knights in a bath / the which would no longer
suffer his tyraunye. And so he wretchedly lived / and deyed unhappily. Martinus
the first was pope after Theodorum.vi. year. This Martynus was a very holy man
/ and ^rongely strove for the faith of god And when ^e ^ge mass oon a certain
day a^ the (...) / there pursewed him to slay* him a man yt was called
Spataryus of Olymphe. And when he would have smyten him / he was blind
suddenly. This same man called a Synody in the Cite of Rome: and dampened Syrum.
Alexandrun Sergium. Pyrum: and Paulum heretykes. wherefore. Constantyne the
Emperor exyled him: and he deyed a saint. Eugemus a Romayne was pope after
Martyne almoost three year: and was an holy man: but of him little acts is
written. Vitellianus was pope after him.xiiii. year. This man made the song
that the. Romans use: And accorded it also with the orgayns. And he also had
the grace of the emperor: the which was worth with his predecessors.
Nevertheless after ward he stood not i^ his concord. Ne hitherto I could not
find that ever the church of Rome. had fully after the death of.
Constantyne the mighty lordshyp of the cite and of other the which he yaue to
the church.

Anno dm^.vi.C.xliiii.
ADeodatus a. Romayne was pope after Vitellianus four year / and in his days
was translated the body of saint Benedictus / with the body of saint Scolastica
his sister fro the hylle of Cassyn unto ye monusterye of Floriecens nyghe
Aurelian. Consta^tyne the fourth was Emperor after his fader Constantyne the
cursyd man. This Constantyne was a good man and hated heretyk ^ over all
thing. The church he repeyred / and grace he recounsyled again to the
church ^ come and he with ye pope gadred together the.vi. general Synodus in
ye which was granted to prestes of Greece / for to use their leyfull wives /
and to the priests of ye Eest for cause of great he^e / but not to those of
the west party by no means For they (...)ytted chastyte in ye time of saint
Gregory. And every man may auertyse and prondre how much the goodness of a
prince is wroth / to the quyete state of ye church / and to the promocyon of
the faith / and also the contrary / how much the malice of a prince hurts
that thing. These two Constanyns the fader and the sone showed openly. For in
the faders days the church never had rest and in ye sons time it was quyete.
yet nevertheless our lord suffered the Sarrasyns and the Bulgars to enter in this
land / that he them might not with stand / but that he made his peace with
them / and paid to them yearly a truage / so nyghtely preuaylled that cursyd
sect of Machomyte / and after he deyed blessydly. Nota. That there were.vi.
general Synodus / and most pryncypall of the which the auctoryte is equal
to ye gospel for ye truth of the gospel is declared by them against the.vi.
pryncypall heresies the which strongely trowbled the church for the subtyltee
of these heretykes to dysceyue simple men. This time deyed Saint Cedde of
Lytchefelde / the third year of his bysshopryche. Demus a Romayne was pope
after Adeodatus three year. Of this man little is written. Bonyfacyus was pope
after him / and little of him is written / but that he lived ly^e a priest.
Agatho was pope after him / and he was a very holy man. For on a day when he
kyssed a lepre / the lepre anon was made hoole. Iste et de consensu princypys
iussit celebrari sextu^ sinodum apud constantinopolin.CC.lxxx. ep^orum. in qua
asseret duas naturas et duas voluntates esse in xp^o. Leo the second was pope
after Agatho three year / this Leo was an holy man and suffycyently taught in
latin and greek / this man ordained that the pax should be yeuen after agnus
dei / and dyed a blessed man. Benedictus the second pope after Leo almost
three year. This man above all thing was vertous and his name accorded with his
dedys. And in his time was a great pestylence. Iustinianus the second was
Emperor this time / and he was a very good man / a prudent and a large / and
he encreaced ye Empire of Rome myghtely / But he charged the office of the
church over much. Many laws he made / and after was not good he intended to
have let the dycrees of the.vi. Synodus / wherefore the.x. year of his. Empire
he was taken of Leo the prince of patrici^ and Tyberio / and they cut of his
nose and his tongue and exyled him to Crysona^. There was then turbacyon in the
church for strive and heretykes. And know all men when varyaunce falls
betwixt great lords Then errors ben multeplyed / for there is no man
corrected them / therefore that is often time preued in the cyirche. Then
after fell a varyaunce betwixt Leo and Tyberio. And Tybereo preuaylled / and
he exyled Leo / and cut of his nose the third year of his regne / and reigned
for hym^ Iustinianus fled to the Sarrasyns and the Bulgars / the which
restored him again to his Empre / and slew Leo and Tyberio / ye which favored
heretykes. Then this same Iustinianus reformed himself to the church of god
/ and had great repentance But he venged him to cruelly on his adversaries /
so that he would have slain the ^r Innocent childern Therefore he was slain
with his sone / of Phylyp whom he exyled.

Anno dm^.vi.C.lxxxiiii.
Johannes the fyfth was pope after Benedyctus too year / he was a good man /
but he decessyd aone. zeno was pope after him. And he was a very holy man / for
he would not meddle with seculer matters. And i^ beauty he was an angel / quyete
in virtues / and meke in soul and very demure in langage of his relygyous life
/ this man was chosen at the last with one accord of the church and lay men.
But there was a great distruccyon / for ye clergy intended to have chose Perys
ye Archebysshop. And the host of lay men would have had Theodorum a priest.
But at the last the holy gooste turned the will of all this people in to this
holy man. Sergius was pope.ix. year. This man was virtuous and comendable i^
his life. And in his eleccyon a great dyscorde was / for one party of the
clergy chose Theodoru^ / and an other party Paschalem. But as our lord
would at the last they turned all to this man. This man translated the body of
saint Leo. He also found a great part of the holy cross by miracle. And he
crystened Cad waldre the last king of Brytayne. He commanded (Agnus dei) to
be said or song thryes at mass. And decessyd blessydly. Nota. Saint Beda the
worshypfull preeste was this time a great man of fame in England / the which
was take the.vii. year of his aege to Benedycte the abbot Gyrwyen^ monastery to
be taught. And then after to Colfrido the abbot after the death of benedict.
And at the.xix. year of his aege he was made Deaken of ye bishop of york.
And at.xxx. year he was made priest / in the which year he began to write So
he continued all the time of his life in that monastry / in gyuynge his labors
to writing and scripture to be expowned. He made.lxxviii^ books / the which
he nombreth in the end of his Edglysshe book. This man was ever in labor
other in prayer or in singing daily in the church / or to learn teache or
write. For which thing men may Judge by reason that he was never at Rome /
all though some say he went to Rome that he might see yt his books accords
with the doctrine of ye holy church. But it was certain that he was blind /
and went to preche / and had a servant that was not good / and made him to
preche to a mighty multitude of stones and said / that they were men. And when
all his sermon was done / the stones answered and said Ame^. But that he went
to Rome thryes / and found written three arres / three effes / and expowned them
/ it was never found in no book of auctoryte. There was after the talkyng of
the people such a writing on the yates of Rome (RRR. FFF) And such an
exposycyon (Regna Rome Ruent. Ferro Flama Fame) But it is certain that Beda
was desired to come to Rome by the writing of sergius the pope to Colfrido his
abbot. And this Beda translated the gospel of saint Johan in to English
tongue / and dyssessyd blessydly. The fame says that now he lies at Deuelyn
with Saint Curberte / and there is buried with him the knowledge of the deeds of
England almoost to ye conquest. Leo the second was Emperor / and little of
him is written. Liberius was Emperor after him.vii. year / he rose against Leo
and entered his kingdom / and kept him in prison as long as he reigned In this
time Iustinianus the second which in old time was exyled to Crysonam openly
said / he would recover his Empire again. wherefore the people of that country
/ for the love of Liberius / were about to slay that Iustinianus. wherefore he
fled to the prince of Thurcorum and wedded his sister. And thorugh help of
his brother and the Bulgars he recovered his Empire and slew Liberius and Leo
the vsuper of his reame And as many times almoost as he wyped any drope from
his nose / the which they kytte of / so many times he made one of his enmyes
to be slain Leo the third was pope after Sergius two year. This man was made
pope by the power of the Romans and was not put in the nombre of popes / for
the evil entered / but he did none evil. Johannes the.vi. was pope after him
a Greek. And he was a martyr / but of whom and wherefore the cause is not
found in hystoryes. It is said / yt it was of the dukes of Lambardy for they
were enmyes to the church myghtely. Johannes the.vii. a Romayne was pope after
him three year / but no thing of him is written. Iustinianas was Emperor again
with his sone Tyberius.vi. years. And this was he the which was reued the
Empire before by Leo / And when this man was restored again he took him to the
right faith / and worshypped the pope Constantyne. And certainly he destroyed
Creson the place where he was exyled unto / and all that dwelled in it / except
the chyldern he slew them / And he came again an other time to have slain the
Innocents. And the men of that country made them a capytayne / a certain man
that was called Philyp an outlawe / yt which anon went to him in battle /
and slew him for his outragyous cruelnesse against those chyldern. Sysinnius
was pope twenty days / and then was great strife / and he decessyd \ but
little of him is written. Constantine was pope after him vii. year. This man was
a very meke man and so blessed / that of all men he was beloved. He went over
the sea to Iustinianus the Emperor / and was received with great honor / and
deyed a blessed man. Philyp ye second was Emperor one year / the which
fled in to Scicilis for the host of the Romans And he was an heretyke / and
commanded all pyctures of saints for to be bestroyed. wherefore the Romans
cast a way his coin / ne would not receive no money that his name or image
were written upon Anastasius thseconde after he had slain Philyp was Emperor
three year. This man was a christian man / and helyued well. But by cause he put
out phylipis eyes / and slew him after ward. And therefore Theodosius faustht
against him and overcame him / And then he was made a priest / and lived so
quyetly.

Anno dm^.vii.C.xiiii.
GRegoryus the second was pope after Constantyne.xvii. year / this Gregoryus
was a chaste man and a noble man in scripture And about this time the popes
began to deal more temporally with the Emperors than they were wont for
their falsnesse and their he resye. And also for to remeue thempyre fro oo
people to an other as the time required / this man cursyd Leo ye Emprrour by
cause he bre^te the images of saints. This same Leo commanded / Gregorius the
pope yt he should brenne chirches and destroy them. And he set no thing of
his saying / but commanded the cou^trary manly. And so it is openly showed /
yt the destruccyon of the Empire of Rome / was the cause of heresy. For
certaynely faithful people with the prelates with one will / drew to the pope
and constrained the Emperors for to leave their tyranny and their heresye. And
this time in the eest part of ye world strongly faylled the very faith / for
that cursyd law of the false Machomete^ Theodosius was Emperor and reigned but
one year And he was a very christian man / and even as he did so was he done
unto. For Leo deposyd him and made him a priest. Leo ye third with Constantyne
his sone was Emperor.xxv. year this Leo when he was mighty he deposyd
Theodosyus and reigned for him / and was desceyned by a certain Apostata / the
which badde him yt he should take and brenne all the images of saints.
wherefore he was punysshed both in battle and in pestylence / and with other
Infortunes. And by cause he was accursyd of Gregoryus / and bode there in three
days / therefore the pope with ye common people took for him the best part of
his Empire / co^mau^dynge yt no man should obey him ne socour him / by cause he
lived like an heretyke. Holy men said against him. And many by him were marted
and exyled. And at ye last in his misbyleue he deyed wretchedly. and in this
manes days / but that Karolus Marcellus help the Christian faith / and faught
manly nyenst the Sarrasyns / and drove them backewarde in Spain the which
they had subdued else they had entered in to France. And Karolus slew three
hundred thousa^de Sarasyns and moo^ And of his people were slain but.xv.
thousand. Nota. This man for the contynuall battle took to lay men the
tresoure of the church. wherefore Saint Eucharius the bishop of Aurelian / as
he was in his prayers / saw that same Karolus in soul and body payned in
hell. And the angel that showed the bishop this man said. That yt was the
Judgment of all those that took a way the goods of the church / or of poor
men. And to fortifye that / that the bishop said and ^ue it / the abbote of
saint Deuys went to the sepulcre there that Karolus was burye^ (...) opened
the cheste that he lay in And there th^^ see a great dragon go out but he had
no (...) Gregorius the third a Romayne (...) pope after Gregoryus the second.
The (...) confermed the woorshyppes of the (...) saints / with ye counsel
almooste of a thou^^^de bishops. And he cursyd horrybly all the despyers of
these images. As the Emperor and other that were of ye condycyon. Constan^nus
the fyfth was Emperor a^te: his (...) Leo.xxxv. year He was a cursed man and a
p^^e heretyke / to yt he did sacrefyse to the deuylles He pursued the church.
And (...) is good of him is written. And so by ye ^ce of god the church was
trowbled long t^me. About this time were many maruayl^es and there were
merueyllous earth quakys. And certain cytees that were set on mountayns they
were remeued and borne away with ye hills in to the feldes.vi. mile thens as
they stood and the cytees were not broken ne hurt In the land of Mesopotanian
the earth was broken by the space of two mile / And also there was a mule that
spoke in a man's voys. Ashes fell fro heaven And in the sea of Poncico there
was yse for great froste that was.xxx. cubytes of thykenesse. And the sterres
fell fro heaven so myghtely that men trowed that ye end of the world had be
comen. All these betokened meruaylus things for to come.

Anno dm^.vii.C.xliiii.
Acharias was pope after Gregorius. x. year. This zacharis was a noble man and
arrayed with all virtue / with all men he was loved for his mekeneste. And he
deposyd the king of France Hydery / and put in his place Puppynus / for he
was more profitable. Here may ye see what power the thyrche had yt time / the
which translated that famous kingdom fro ye very heirs / to ye kingdom of
Pippinus / for a leyfull cause ( Vthab^t.xv. q. v. alius) Stephanus the second
a Romayne was pope after zacharyas.v. year. This man in all thing was
profitable unto the church / as well in word as in doctrine And he governed
the spyrytualtee and the temporaltee noble. He was the lover and the defender
of poor men. This man anointed Pyppynus the king of France / and sent him
against the Lombardes / that he should compel them to restore the church of
such goods as they had with hold from them long time vnryghtwys^y the
which he did. He also translated the Empire of the Greeks to ye Frensshemen.
Paalus a Romayne was pope after him.x. year. This was a very holy man / for he
did great alms to fadlesse chyldern and prisoners wydowes / and other poor
men / yt he might be a follower of saint Poule Constantyne a Romayne the second
was pope after Poul two year. This Constantyne was a lay man and suddenly was
made a priest / as a tyrant / and took on him the dygnytee of the pope. And
with a great slau^dre to the church was pope a little time. But the faithful
men put him out / and put out his eyes. And this was the fyfth Infamed pope /
among so many herd tofore. So the holy ghost ye holy apostels sete kepyin al
honor and holiness Infynyte martyrs were made this time by Constantyne ye
emperor for he was such an heretyke. And men trow that there was never
Emperor ne no pagon that slew so many martyrs^ And in his time the church
was trowbled full sore / and very precyously bought the worshyppynge of the
images of the holy saints / for the great shedynge of blood of martyrs. And
certainly ye cursyd Emperor was not unpunished. For when that he deyed he
cried with an horrible voys and said. I am taken to a fire / yt is unable for
to be destroyed. And so he yielded up the ghost to everlasting pain. The
Empire of rome was divided about this time For Stephanus the pope translated
ytaly and other unto Karolus a young man. And Constantyne held the land of
Greece with other lands over the sea with a great labor and many rebellynge.
This time Karolus magnus was a noble young man. And he began for to regne upon
France / and was the sone of Pippinus / and his mother was called Berta^
Stephanus the third was pope after Paulus three year. And he amended all the
errors of Constantyne. And he degarded all those the which Co^stantyne
ordained in a general Synodus.

Anno dm^.vii.C.lxxxiiii.
ADrianus a Romayne was pope after Stephanus.xxiiii. year. This man was
myghtely worshypped of the people / no man greter before him in honor / riches
/ and buyldyng. This man set two solemn Syno^is. The first of the three
hundred and fyfty faders The second in Rome with an hundred and fyfty faders
