being present Charles the king of France / to whom it was granted the
lyberte of eleccyon of the popes and to ordeyne the appostles sete. Leo the
fourth reigned Emperor with the Greeks five year This Leo was a cursyd man /
but not so much as his fader was. And he was a covetous man / and he took a
way a certain crown of a church and put it upon his heed. And anon^ he was
corrupted with an axes and sore deseased. And he had a cursed wife / yt which
reigned after him with her sone. Constantyne was Emperor after Leo / and he
was a meke man / and put a way his mother fro the kingdom / that she might take heed unto her wymmens work. But she with a feigned rancour put out his eyes
after ward and his childern also / and reigned again three year. And at ye last
she was about for to have be wedded And when the Greeks perceived that she would
be wedded to great Karolus / they took her and shytte her up in a monastery /
and took Nychoferum to be their Emperor. The.v. vnyuershall study the which
in old time was translated from Anthenes unto Rome / about this time was
translated to Paris / by Karolus king of France. Nychoferus was Emperor
after Constantyne. He was a very nygon / and was exalted to his Empire by the
Grekys But he profyted not / for i^ his time all ye E^st Imperyall was brought
to naught. For the Romans put them under Karolus magnus Jerusalem about this
time was recovered by Karolus / with all the holy land. And the sect of the
Sarrasyns was destroyed strongly^ For the struccyon of wretches came then^e
Michael was Emperor two year / and he was a very christian man / and he was well
beloved / and also he was connyge in all scyences. And tho that Nychaferus had
hurt and drestressyd of their goods by his coueytousnesse / this Mychaell
restored them and made them rich again. Nota. Karolus. magnus the first saint
was Emperor after Michaell. And he was crowned Emperor by Leo the pope /
from the which time the Empire was translated from the Greeks to France and
Germane. And for the translacyon of that Empire / the Greeks always were
defectyue unto the Romans And the Greeks strove ever more with them. But it
was more with venomous words thanne with strenghthe / and more with craft
thanne with batayyll. For they had so great envy at the Romans / that they
would not obey ye church of Rome. For certainly when that the popes would
write unto them / for to obey the church of Rome / they wrote again and
said. ye have taken from our kynrede the Empire / and therefore we would not
obey / And we us take from you / And for this noble Emperor Rarolus it is to
be understand / this man when he was a young man / he was anointed king of
France by Stephanus ye pope. In the year of our lord Ihesu Christ.vii.
hundred.liiii. when his fader Pippinus lived. Under whom / and with whom he
reigned ^xv. year unto the death of his fader. Then after his fader under the
year our lord god vii. hundred.xlviii. This Karolus with his brother
Karolomannus reigned two year. And then his brother deseased in the second
year. And this Karolus there held all the hoole kingdom.xiiii. year / to the
year of our lord.vii. hundred.lxxxiiii. In ye which year he went to Rome /
that he might be crowned Emperor of the pope Adrianus. And he reigned
emperor.xvi. year / to the year of our lord.viii.C. when pope* Leo confermed
him again the Emperor. And after that he was Emperor xiiii. year. And he
dysseased in the year of his aege.lxxii. The which was the year of our
lord.viii.C. and.xiiii. if ye will see more of Karolus / goo to the book of
Turpinus and Libraminus his master / for they wrote his noble acts. Leo the
fourth was pope after Adrianus.xx. year / this man when he went on a certain
day with the Lentany to saint Peter's church on Saint Marks day / he was
taken with cursyd people / and both his eyes put out and his tongue cut of
But our lord merueylously restored him again his sight and his speech / so
that he spoke without tongue and saw by miracle. Afterward he went with
Karolus in France. And he came with him unto Rome / and venged the pope on his
enmye. And then he crowned Karolus. And he late before crowned / confermed him
again. Lodouicus the meke the first begoten sone of Karolus was Emperor
after his fader.xxvi. year / in whose time was put a way that clerks should
use no gyrdes with precious stones / ne strange arayment. This Ludouicus of
his first wife gate two childern and both had an evil end. In all thing that
went against him he was pacyent / and in the last end he ever over ca^e. For
against god he abode devout. And his childern followed him in co^dycyons / he
dyssessyd a blessed man. Stephanus the fourth was pope after Leo three year.
This Stephanus redeemed many captyue men / and crowned Lodouicus ye Emperor.
And then^e he dyssessyd and was buried at Rome. Paschall was pope after
Stephanus. This Paschall was a great dylygence to relyques of Saints. And he
took up Innumerable bodies of saints / and buried them worshypfully as in the
vysyon of saint Cecile he was commanded. Eugenius the fourth was pope after
Paschall / and he was a very holy man. And all those things that were for
christ he took head to. This man was crowned a martyr / and by the lay men of
Rome he was buried in saint Peter's chyrcheyerde.

Circa annu^ on^i.viii.C.xliiii.
VAlentinus was pope after Eugenius xl. days / and little of him is written.
Gregorius the fourth was pope after him xii. year / this Gregorius saw many
heavy times / for the plages among the common people And at this man's
petycyon. Lodouicus the Emperor / and Marcio the prince of Lombardy exyled al
ye Sarrasyns fro ytaly. And at the last he dyssessed after Innumerable good
deeds and works yt he had done at saint Peter's. Lotherius the first sone of
Ludouicus was Emperor.xv. year in ytaly and Rome and the parties of Germayne
next to the hills of. Alpy. This Lotherius rose against his brother Ludouicus
and. Karolus for the kingdom of Duchelonde / the which some time Pyppynus
their brother held. And they fought at a place called Fomanecu^ / where
Lotherius was dyscomfyted. And there was such slaughter made oon both the
sides / that they had no men for to resyste their adversaries. This understood
a falls christian man / and sent unto Soudan of the Sarrasyns yt he should come
anon. And he took Rome / and saint Peter's church was made a stable for their
horses. But Ludouycus with the Frenshemen and Lombardes all ye Infynyte nombred
destroyed / and that with great shedynge of christian blood. Sergius ye second
was pope after Gregorius two year. This man was called first. (os porci) in
English / hoggesmouth. where fore yt man and all the popes names are changed
when they are chosen And yt for three causes. The first for Christ changed the
names of those men yt which he made popes. The second / for as much as they
are changed in the name / should they be changed in perfectyon of life / The
third leest he which is chosen to an exceeding degree should he hurt in
name. Leo was pope after Sergius. viii year. This Leo was an holy man / and
also he was in prudence as sharp as a serpente / and in his deeds as meke as a
douue. And he was brought forth virtuously in a monastery And when that he was
made pope / he labored to repeyre his chirches again / the which false
Sarrasyns one after an other had destroyed. This man was a mighty writer and a
great precher / and myghtely labored in watch and prayer and so deyed / and
was buried and lies at saint Peter's. Benedictus a Romayne was pope after Leo
two year. This Benedictus had the name of ye thing. For in all thing he was
blessed. This man ordained ye clerks should go ordynatly and honesty. Ludouicus
the sone of Lotherius was Emperor this time / and anointed of Sergius the pope
/ and a while reigned with his fader / and after reigned.xxi. year alone. This
man had a sone ye high Karolus / in to whom the devil entered and vexed him a
fore his fader. And then^e he conspyred his faders death And in his time many a
meruaylle fell. Nota. Johannes Anglicus of the nacyon of Maguncin about this
time was pope / and she was a woman arrayed in man's garments. But she
profyted so in holy scripture that there was found none like her Then^e she
was chose^ pope / but after ward she was with child. And when she should have
gone openly in processyon / she traveled and decessyd. And this is the sixte
pope / the which to this time had the name of holiness / and were vycyous And
this person as other popes were was punyssed of god / ne she was not nombred
in the book of popes. Nicholaus a Romayne was pope after this woman.ix. year.
This Nicholaus was of great holiness / that there was no man comparable to him
after ^ Gregory ye pope. And when he was made. Ludouicus the Emperor was
present. And after he decessyd a very good man and was buried in saynte^
Peter's chyrcheyerde. Adrianus a Romay^ was pope after Nicholaus. This Adrianus
cursed Lotherius brother to the emperor ye king of Lotharynge for his aduoutry.
But wha^ he came to Rome to excuse him of his aduoutry / he said that he was
cursyd wrongfully. And he brought with him all the noble men of his regyon / and
all were deed within one year and the king deyed in the way when he came to
the ^yte of Placenciam.

Anno dm^.viii.C.lxxiii. Of king Alured / and how the Danys in his time prayed
him of mercy that they might goo out of the land. This time came the Danys in
to England.


AFter the death of this Eldred reigned his brother Alured that Dolfynes was
called. Tho went the Danys and assembled them / And went for the to seek
Alured yt tho was king new made of Southsex / and there they found him at
wylton with a little people / And nevertheless he faught with them / but at
the last he fled thens from the field / and went in to westsex and ordained
so much people of his own reame / and also of other till that he had a
strong host so that the Danys had no power against him to withstand. And
he came to London with his host / and there were the Danys soionrned. And
there he would have foughten with them. But ye Danys durst not with him fight
/ but prayed him of peace / and that they might goo again in to their own
country / and never to come in to England again / that is to say any harm
for to do And upon this covenant they should give him to pledge good hosta^es
and such as the Englysshmen would are.

How Hubba and Hungar were slain at Chyppenham / and how the Danys brought
their king to our king.
ANd the same day that the Danys departed from London / so fast they rode
both nyghe and day / and never took rest of going till that they came unto
Excestre / and took tho the town / and there held them. When king Alured
herd these rydynges / anon he let take the hostages / and went from thens
unto Excestre with all the power that he had / And when the Danys herd tell
of his coming / they went from thens unto westsix / and came unto Chyppenham
/ and there they did much harm in the country / they robbed folk / and
brough them in prison. The king Alured them pursewed and came upon them right
soon and fyersely them assailed. And there were slain both Hubba and Hu^gar
his brother / and Buerne Bocader. And in this bataylle were much folk slain
in that one and in that other. But the gre^ of that field bode with the Danys /
for as much as the king came with few folk. The king hasted him as much as
he might for to goo again. And when the Danys found Hubbaes body lyeng deed
they buried it / and laid upon it a great logge / and let call it Hubeslowe /
and so it is called unto this day. And that place is in Deuenshyre. The
Barons of Somerset^ wyltshyre and dorset herd tell how that their king was
dyscomfyted and ordained all the power that they might have and came to the
king there he was / and thanked god that they him yet found alive / for they
had wend that ye Danys had him slain. Tho took they a counseyll the king
and his barons / that would go and seek the Danys with them for to fight. And
so they rode all and night them for to seek and came on the morrow about
Pryme to Abyndon there that the Danys were. The king Alured and his barons to
assembled and there assaylled the Danys egerly / and there yaue them a stonge
battle. And the Danys put them a long time that no man wist whether part
more people were slain. But this it befell as god would that the king Alured
had the victory with much honor. For the Danys were so driven that ne wist
whyther for to torn. And.xv. days the ^yng them pursewed at his will / that
gladly and ^ayne they were for to speak of peace and accord / and took him good
hostage / and said they would never more upon him war ne no debate arere. And
more over they behyght unto the king Alured / that they would go and b^ynhe
their own king unto him and that their king and they all should be baptized.
And upon this condycyon king Alured grant them life and lymme. And said unto
them / that they should gone their king for to seek / and at a certain day
to come again yt to them was set. And so they went forth fast and came again
at a day that to them was assygned^ And all ye Danys brought their king with
them. The king Alured anon let them ^e baptized / and their names changed.
And so the king of Denmark was called Athelstone And.xxx. of his fellows
names were changed also / and the other were baptized to the right believe. And
all this was done at westmestre. And after that king Alured held with him
king Athelstone and all his Danys.xii days at soiourne with much solempnyte
/ and yaue th^^ great yeftes. And after that they were baptized and so
departed. Tho was king Alured all at ease / when he had his enmyes over
comen / and that they were turned to ye right by leave of god almighty.

How the Danys that came in to France with Gurmonde came again in to England
/ and of the death of king Alured.
ANd thus it befell after ward / that the Danys of Northumberlonde yt were
paynems came with a great strength and an huge host of France / that is to
understood \ with them that went in to France with Gurmonde of Affyke / when
he had conquered England and yaue it unto ye Saxons. And tho yt came fro
France arrived in Kent and sent in to Northumberlonde that they should come to
them / and when those two hosts were come and assembled / anon they yede to
destroy all the christian people of England from place to place / and did
much sorrow. It befelle thus as almighty god would an hard chance in to
England. For the good king alured yt was wont to abate ye Danys deyed ^n the
mean time. This king Alured reigned.xxx. year / and a good king had he and
well could chastyse his enmyes. And also he was a good clerk / and let make
many books and a book he made in English of adventures of kings / and of
bataylles that had been done in the land / and many other books of Gestes he
let them write that were of great wisdom and of good learning / through
which books many a man may him amend / that woll them read and upon them
look / Upon whose soul almighty god have marcy. And this king Alured lies at
wynchestre.

IOha^nes the.viii. was pope after Adryan.viii. year. This Johannes anointed
Karolus the Emperor. And he suffered great wrong of ye Romans for he favored
not ye said Emperor. And therefore he put the said pope in keeping. Also he
degarded the bishop of Portuense / the which was ye occasyon of all his
sorrow. Karolus ye second was Empour after Ludouicus. This Karolus had a
brother the which was called Ludouicus / and he was the king of Germayne / and
he ordained battle against his brother / but karolus or they faughte was
poysened. And he made many a monasterye. Martynus was pope after Ioha^nes one
year. This Martynus little profyted for he lived but little time. Adrianus ye
third was pope after him oo year. And of him is no thing wrynten. Stephanus
the fyfth was pope after him.vi. year. And no thing of him in written / but yt
he translated the body of saint Martyn. Karolus the third was Emperor after
the second.xii. year. This Karolus had in possessyon peassyble all France and
all Germayne / and was crowned Emperor of Ioha^nes the pope. And after this
glorious vyctory / he turned all Normandye to the faith of god almighty / and
he might no more recyste the Frenshemen but four year he reigned on them / He was
unprofitable to them / and therefore they put him a way. Arnulphus was emperor
after Karolus.xiii. year. This Arnulphus utterly constrained the Norma^s the
wyiche destroyed the Frenshemen.xl. year Then he was syke and had no
comfort of no leche / for he was i^ a meruayllous sykenesse / so that he was
consumed with life and was deed. Formosus was pope after Stephanus.v. year /
this man first was bishop of Portuensys. And pope John^ was depryued for his
Inobedyence / and was degrated to the lay fee. But by Martyn ye pope he was
restored. And against his oath / he came not aloonly to Rome but to offer him
the dygnyte of the pope / for yt which there was great alteracion. Bonfacius
the.vi. was pope.v. days. Stephanus the.vi. one year and three months.
Johannes three months and.xii. days. Iona also three months and twelve
days. Theodorus the second twenty days. Johannes the enleue^th was two year
and.xv. days. Benedictus the fourth a year and two months. Leo the fourth
was.xl. days. Xpristoforus the first.vii. months. All these.viii. popes
were but little time / and therefore we can not tell of them none notable
things / But if we should write sclau^dre of them that might be fon^de / for
ye vnharde strife and contencion in that holy appostles sete. For one strove
against an other / and repreued the deeds of an other. And for to tell how they
strove / it were no great honor to show for ye holy appostles sete.
Lodouicus the third was emperor after Arnulphus.vi year. This man had not ye
popes blessing / for the unstableness of them yt which reigned in ytaly^ And
he was constreyned to expulse Berynge. And this man was ye last Emperor of
all the kynred of Karolus king of france. This time the Empire was remeued
and translated and dyuyded. For the Frenshemen halpe not the church / the
which their faders had edifyed and fortefyed / but destroyed / ne halpe not ye
Romans against Lombardes / the which vexed the Romans right sore. Therefore by
the comyns assente they were excluded fro the Empire / and the ytalyens began
to be Emperor in ytaly / and the Almayns in Almayne / until Ottanen the
which reigned in both the places. The Frenshemen were constrained to abide in
their own country / and no more to be emperor for their mysheuous living.
Beringarius the first. Conradus and Beryngarius the second / and Hugo were
Emperors after Lodouicus But they are not nombred among the Emperors. For
some were but in Almayne / and some were in yralye.

Of king Edward that was king Alucedes sone.
ANd after this Alured reigned his sone Edward / and was a good man and a wise
/ that was called Edward / and was wonder curteys. The danys did much sorrow
in the land / and their power encreaced and began for to were from day to
day. For the Danys came often with their companyes in to this land. And when
the king saw that he might no better do / then he took peace with them
granted them this trewes. And nevertheless the trewes dured not long that
the Danys ne began strongly for to war upon the Englysshmen and did them
much sorrow. wherefore king Edward did assemble a great host for to fight
with them And then this king Edward deyed when god would. This king Edward
reigned.xxiiii. year / and lies at wynchestre beside his fader.

Anno dm^.ix.C.xiiii.
SErgius ye third was pope after Xpistoforus.vii. year / This man was a
Cardynall of Rome / and was expulsed by Formosus the pope / and then he went to
the Fernsshemen. And so thorugh the help and favor of the^ he came again to
Rome and anon expulsed sed Xpristoforus the pope. And then was pope
himself. And for to avenge and work his exyle / he took out the body of pope
Formosus where that he was buried. And arryed him in the popes arraymente and
caused him to be heeded and to be cast in the water of Tybre by Rome / Then
fysshers found him and brought him in to the church. And the holy images of
saints bowed down to him / when the body of him was brought in to the
church / that all men might see / and honorably him halsyd. yet Sergius
destroyed all that thing the which ye holy man had ordained. Anastasius was
pope after him two year. Laudo was pope.v. months / and little they did.
Johannes the.x. was pope then^e. This Iohanes was the sone of Sergius pope /
does of nature and of manners And he was pope by mighty. And wretchedly slain
of Guidois knights for they put on his mouth a pylowe and stopped his brethe.
And after him was a another put in / but anon he was out / and therefore he is
not named as pope. Henricus the duke of Saxone was Emperor of Almayne.xvii^
year / this Henricus was a noble man / but he is not nombred among
themperours. for he reigned but aloonly in Almayne. And he had a very holy woman
unto his wife / and her name was Matylda / on whom he gate two sons / yt is to
say. Otto and Harry And Otto succedded him in the Empire And Harry had much
land in Almayne. And he gate an other sone yt hygh^ Brimen and he was a very
holy man / and was bishop of Coleyne. And he founded the monastery of
Panthal^o^.

Of king Adelstone.
NOw after this Edward reigned Adelstone his sone^ And wha^ he had reigned four
year he held battle against the Danys. And drove king Gaufride that was king
of the Danys and all his host unto the sea / and ^ested by Scotlonde / and
took strongely all the country an hoole year. And after yt tho of Comberlonde
and of Settes of westmerlonde began to war upon king Adelstone. And he gave
the^ so strong battle / yt he slew so many of them that no man conde tell
the nombre of them. And after yt he reigned but three year / and he reigned in
all.xxv. year / and lies at Malmesbury.

Of king Edmonde.
Then after this Adelstone reigned edmo^de his brother. For king Adelstone had
no sone / and this Edmo^de was a worthy man and a doughty knight of body / and
a^ noble also. And the third year after that he was king / he went over
Homber in to that country in the which country he fonude two kings of
Danys. That one was called Enelaf. And that other Renant^ This king Edmonde
drove them both fro the land / and after went / and took a great proye in
Comberlonde. This Edmonde reigned but.vii. year / and lies at Glastenbury.

Of king Eldred
ANd after this Edmo^de reigned Eldred his brother that avenged Edward his fader
of his enmyes that did him slay. And after he seized all Northumberlonde in to
his hand. And made the Scotts for to bow and meke unto his will. And in the
second year of his regne came Arnalaf Guyran that was king of Denmark / and
seized all Northumberlonde / and held that land two year. And after that came
king Eldred and drove him out of this land. And this king Eldred was a noble
man and a good / Of whoos goodness Saint Dunstane preched. And this king Eldred
reigned.xi. year / and lies at whynchester.

Of king Edwyn.
ANd after this Eldred reigned Edwyn the sone of Edmonde. And he was a simple
man to ward god and the people. For he hated folk of his own land / and
loved and honored strange men. And set little by holy church. And he took
of holy church all the tresour that he might have. That was great shame and
vylany to himself / and peril to his soul. And therefore god would not that he
sholne regne no longer than four year and deyed / and lies at wynchestre^

LEo the syxt a Romayne was pope.vi. months. Stephanus the.vii. was after him
two year. Johannes the.xi. a Romayne was pope three year. Stephanus the.viii. a
germayne was pope after him.viii. year / Martinus the third was pope after him
three year / and of these.vi. popes is noothynge had in scripture. For what
cause I can not tell.

Anno dn^i.ix.C.liiii.
AGapitus a Romayne was pope after Martinus two year and.viii. months / and
no thing of him is written / Iohe^s the.xii. a Romayne was pope after Agapitus
viii. year / and he had a fader yt hight Albertyke and was a worthy man in ye
chyte of Rome. He induced ye noble men to swear yt after the death of Agapytus
they should these Ottauianus his sone pope / and so it was done and was named
John^ / and he was a hunter and a lecherous man so that openly he kept wymmen
wherefore certain Cardynalles wrote unto Otto the Emperor of Saxon / that he
should come to Rome for to help to destroy the sclau^dre of the church. This
the pope perceived / and ye hand that wrote ye pystle he made to be carte of
And many times he was warned by the Emperor and the clergy that he should
correct himself but he nolde for no thing / Then he was deposyd / and Leo
was put in to a place. wherefore the Emperor was anoyed / and came again and
besyeged Rome so long till they took Benedycte to him / and restored Leo.

Of king Edgar that reigned above the kings of Scotlonde and of walys / and
how he^ was begyled thrug the taking of his wife.
ANd after this Edwyne reigned Edgar his brother a man that much loved god and
peace / and the right of holy church also. And he was a worthy man / and a
great lord of blood and mighty / and maycened well this land in peace. And this
Edgar was lord and king above all the king of Scotlonde and of walys / fro
the time that Arthur was gone / and never was sythen king of his power. And
this Edgar was saint Edwardes fader. And when Edgars wife was deed yt was saint
Edwardes mother and entryd / he herd speak of the fayrnesse of Estrylde / that
was Orgarus daughter a baron of Deuenshyre that was so fair a woman / that all
men did speak of her. He called one of his knyhhtes that he much loved and
trusted upon and told him. Go^ said he to the noble baron Orgarus of
Deuenshyre / and see if that his daughter be fair as men speak of / and if it
be sothe I will have her unto my wife. This knight that was called Edelwolde
went forth his way as the king him had said / and came there that the lady
was And when he saw her so fair / he thought to have her himself to wife. And
thereof spoke to Grgarus her fader. And her fader was an old man and no man
chyldern but oonly her / and saw yt Edelwode was a fair young knight with the
king / and thought his daughter should well be married and be set upon him /
and granted him his daughter if the good lord ye king would consent thereto.
And then this Edel would came again unto the king and cold him / that she
was fair enough upon to see / but she was wonder lothly. Tho answerede the
king and said that he took but little charge. Sir said Edelwolde / she is her
faders heir / and I am not rich of lands / and if ye would consent and
grant that I might her have / then should I be rich enough. In gods name
said the king. I consent thereto. Edel would tho thanked the king right
mothe / and went again in to Deuenshyre and spowsed the damoysell / and in that
country he dwelled. And thus it befell upon a time / that he told his
counsel and all this thing unto his wife / how and in what manner he had
begyled his lord the king that would have had her to wife. And anon as she
it wist / she loved him never more after ward as she did before. This lady
conceived by him a sone. And when time wan that the child should be borne.
Edelwolde came to the king and prayed him to have a sone of his at the font
stone. The king him granted / And let call him Edgar after his own name.
And when this was done he thought that all was syker enough for the king /
that he would not take his wife for as much as his lord was a Ioly man and an
amerous.

How that king Edgar wedded Estrylde after the death of Edel wolde^
THus it befell that all men in king Edgars court then^e spoke and said / yt
Edel would was rychely auaunced / through the foresaid marriage of his wife. And
yet they said he was auaunced an hundred fold more^ For he had spowsed the
most fairest creature yt ever seen. And ye king herd speak so much of her
beauty / yt he thought he would have him dysceyued / and begyled. And thought
pryuely in his heart / that he would goo into Deuenshyre / as it were for to
hunte for the heart and for ye hynde and other wild beestes / and then^e he
should see there the lady or he departed thens. And this lady was dwelling at
manner place beside the forest / there that the king would hunte / And a^ that
manner he was her borrowed all night. And when time came that the king should
suppe / and the son shone / the king asked after his gossyppe and after his
godsone^ And Edelwolde made her to come before the king And nevertheless if
it other wise might have be she should not have come in his sight by his will.
The lady welcome^ the king and swetely him kyssed. And he took her by ye hand
/ and to next by him her sa^te / and so souped they together. And there was a
custom and an usage in this land that time. That so when on drake to an other
/ the drynker should say wassayll. And that other should answer / and say
Drink hayll. And this did the king and the lady / and kyste many times. And
after supper when time was for to go to bed / the king went to bed / then
king hertely on the ^ayrnesse of that lady / and then^e was over come for her
love / that him thought that he should deye / but if he had his will on her.
Upon the morrow the king aroos and in the foreest went him for to dysporte
with hearts and hyndes and all other wild beestes. and of the hertes great
plente he sense to ye lady. And thryes he went for to solace and to speak with
that lady the whiles he dwelled there in that country. And after that the king
remeued thens / and thought him how he might best deliver Edelwod fro his wife
/ as he had him first desceyued. And the king anon after.viii. days
ordained a parlyament at salysbury of all his baronage counseyll to have. And
for to ordeyne how the country of Northumberlonde should best he kept that
the Danys came not there / the land for to destroy. And this Edelwode came
unto the kings parlyament. And the king sent him to york / for to be keeper
of that country. And thus it befell that knew him not slew him by the way.
And anon as the king herd tell that he was deed / he let send after the
lady E^^^ylde that he should come unto the cite of London and there he wedded to
the king with great solempnyte and worship. And held a solemn feast. And he
ware a crown yt was of gold and the queen an other. And saint Dunstane on the
morrow came unto the king in to the chamber / and found the king in bed
an^ the queen togyders. And sayn^ Dunstane axed the king who she was / And the
king answered and said / yt she was the queen E^^yllde. And the Archebyssop
saint Dunstance said that he did great wrong / and against gods will to
take a woman to wife whose child ye had take at font stone. And ye queen for
that word never loved saint Dunstance after. And the good man warned of that
folly to be left / but it auaylled but little / for the love between them was
so much. The king begat upon her a sone that was called Eldred^ when this
child was.vi. year old / the king his fader deyed. And about that time he
had reigned.xvii. year / and lies at Glastenbury.

BEryngarius ye third was Emperor after Henrycus ^vii. year / this
Beryngarius was Emperor in ytaly. In whoos time was great dyuysyon. And
Henricus the emperor decessed / and. Otto began to regne in Almayne. Lotharius
reigned after him two year / and decessed when. Otto reigned in Almayne. And
had a wife that hight Dalnyham. The which after wedded Otto. Beringarius the
fourth was after him / this man with great tyranny subduedytaly / wherefore the
pope and other romans called Otto that he might deliver them which he did.
And he took Beryngaryus by strength / and twyes he outlawed him. And he took
Lotharius wife the which the tyrau^t had prysoned. Leo the.viii. was pope
after Benedictus one year and four months. This man was chosen with the
common voys / and Johannes was deposyd. This Leo ordained that no pope should be
made without consent of ye Emperor For the malice of ye Romans the which
oppressyd them. This man granted all the yeftes to Otto and his successors /
the which were yeuen by Iustinianus and Karolus to ye church / that he might
defend ytaly from the reberlyons. Iohanes the.xii. was pope after him
almoost.viii. year \ this Iohe^s suffered great wrong of ye Romans For he was
take and exyled but Otto bare this heuyly. For he slew the noble men of Rome /
and certain of them exyled for ever more. Benedyctus the.vi. was pope after
him.vi^ year / this man was take / and in the castle Angel was strangled.
Nota. The Empire in this time was translated to the Almayns. And the same cause
is here as was before / for the ^ycyous living. Ne these unhappy men cowde not
be Informed / that they should eschew that ^o woyce / through the which they
sa^e so many noble men to perysshe. Otto was Emperor after Beryngarius.xii.
year. This Otto was the first Emperor of Almayne. And he was all virtuous as
an other king karolus for he was the defender of the church of god / and the
syngular promoter for the which he was worthy to be Emperor Many men of falls
believe he converted And he held with him pope Benedictus the usurper of the
popeherd in to Soxony. And there he decessyd in his exyle. And this Emperor
decessyd a rich man in virtue and goodness. Otto the second was Emperor after
his fader. And he was a noble man to the church as his fader was. And many a
battle he had against the false men of believe. And at the last he almoost lost
all his host in Kalabur / yet for sothe with all his mind besought saint
Peter to help. And meruellously saint Peter delivered him And his wife was the
daughter of ye Emperor of Constantynopolytan of the Romans blood And this man
was crowned of Benedictus the pope.

Of saint Edward the martyr how Escrylde his stepmoder let kylle him / for
to make Eldred her own sone king.
ANd after this Edgar reigned Edward his sone / that he begat upon his first
wife / that will and nobly governed the land. For he was full of all manner of
goodness and led a full holy life. And above all thing he loved god and holy
church. And the queen Escrylde that was his stepmoder let slay him by cause
to make her own sone Eldred king. And this on a day he was slain / as ye
shall here afterward. It befell thus upon a day that tha^ king Edward went
in to a wood for to play / in the southe country be side a town that is
called warham. In yt which foreste was great pleyntye of hearts and hyndes.
And when he had been while there him for to play he thought upon his brother
Eldrede that was with his mother the queen / for her place waste nygh the
foreste / and thought for to goo thither and vysyte and see his brother. And
took with him but a little meyne / and went him toward his stepmoders house /
that in that time soiourned in the castle of Corfe. And as he read in ye
thyckensse of a wood is speye his game / it befell that he went amysse and
lost his meyne that with him came. And at the last he came out of the wood.
And as he lo^d him about / he saw there there fast besides a ^e that his
stepmoder dwelled in / and thither ward he went alone And anon it was told
the queen / how that the king was comen alone with out any company. And
therefore she made Joy enough / and thought how that she might do that he were
slain as pryuely as she might / called to her one of her knights. To whom
she had told much of her counseyll between them. And both they came to the
king and curteysly him received. And the king told that he was come to
vysyte / and also for to speak with Eldred his brother The queen many times him
thankyd. and him prayed for for alyght / and her borugh with her al yt night
The king said / that he might not. But again he would goo unto his folk / if
he might them find. And when the queen saw that he would not abide / she
prayed him that he would ones drink / and he granted her. And anon as the
drink was come / the queen drank unto the king. And the king took the
cup and set it to his mouth. And in the mean while that he drank / the
false knight yt was with ye queen with a knyfe smote the king unto the heart.
and there he fell down deed unto the earth of his palfroy. The queen for this
deed gave the knight gold and silver great plente and of other riches enough
And the knight anon as this was done went him over the sea. And so escaped he
out of this land. When this king Edward was thus martred. It was in the year
of the Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu Christ.ix.C.lxxx. And he had reigned.xii.
year and an half / and lies at Glastenbury.

Of the king Eldred / and how the king Swyne of Denmake held England. and
how Eldred that saint Edwardes brother was not beloved in his Realm / and
therefore he fled in to Normandye.
SO after this Edward reigned Eldred his brother. And saint Dunstane crowned
hym^ And this saint Dunstane deyed soon after that he had foryeuen the queen
her trespa^s / by cause that she was cause of king Edwardes death. And saint
Dunstane had her assoylled / and penance had her ^^oyned. And she lived
after a chaste life and a clean. This king Eldred wedded an English woman /
and on her begat Edmonde Irensyde and an other sone that was called Edwyne.
And after deyed the queen their mother. And in that time came Swyne in to
England that was king of Denmark / for to challenge and to conquer all that
his auncetrees had before that time. And so he conquered and had it all his
axyng. For the good earl Cuthberte of Lynd eseye and all the people of
Northumberlonde / and almoost all the greece of England held with Swyne that
was king of Denmark / for so much as they loved no^ king Eldred / for by
cause that his good brother Edward was slain for love of him. And therefore no
man set but little by him. wherefore king Swyne had all his will / and took
all the land. And Eldred the king fled the in to Normandye. And so spoke
to the duke Richard / that the duke yaue him his sister Emme to wife Upon the
which he gate two sons that one was called Alured and that other Edward. And
when Swyne had conquered all the land / he reigned nobly and lived.xv. year and
then he deyed and lies at york.

How king Eldred came aye^ from Normandy / and how knoght the Dane reigned /
and of the war betwixt him and Edmonde Irensyde.
THus after ye death of Swyne that was a Dane. Knoght his sone dwelled in
England / and would have been king. And tho came again Eldred out of
Normandye with much nombre of people / and with a strong meyne that Knoght
durst not abide / but fled thens in to Denmark. The king Eldred had again
his reame / and held so great worship / that he began for to destroy all tho
that halpe Swyne that was a Dane ayenste him. And afterward came again this
Knoghte from Denmark with a great power / so that king Eldred durst not with
him fight but fled from thens unto London / and there he held him. Tho came
Knoght and him besyeged so long / till that king Eldred deyed in the Cytee of
London / and lies at saint Poules. And he reigned.ix. year.

BOnu^ was pope after Benedictus one year. This man abode but a little time
Bonifacius was pope after him five months. Benedictus was pope after him.x.
year / This man crowned Otto the seedde / and made many Romans to be taken And
he gadred a counseyll against the king of France / where Gylbert the
Nygramancer was deposed. Johannes the ^xiiii. was pope after him.viii.
months. And he was put in the castle Angel / and was famyned to death.
Johannes the.xv. was pope after him four months. Johannes the.xvi. was pope
after him almoost.xi. year. This man was taught in arms / and made many books
/ and else little of him is written. Gregorius the.v. was pope after this man
almoost three year. And this Gregorius was made pope at the Instaunce of the
Emperor Otto third / for he was his consyn / And when he had be a little
while pope / and the Emperor receded from the cite of Rome. Placentinus was
put in by Crecensius a Counsul for money / And then was strife a few days.
But the Emperor came soon after / and took Crecensius the Consul / and
stroke of his heed / and put out the eyes of this man Placencius pope / ye
which put out his cosyn of the dignyte of the pope* And maimed him on other
members / his knights ne his dukes halpe him no thing. For he did that
thing that he should not have done. And he suffered that that he deserved.
Nota. This Gregorius with the Emperor Otto ordained the chesers of the Empire
/ the which from thens forth has a bode unto this day. For the Frensshmen
ne none other might not break that ordinance. And those the^ers of the Empire
by the pope and Otto were not made for any blame of the Saxons / but to eschew
the euylles to come. And their names ben written for learned men in latin in
these verses. (Maguntinensis Treuerensis Coloniensis Quilibe^ imperu fit
cancellarius horum. Et Palatinus da^ifer Dux Portitorensis. Marchio prepositus
camere. Pincerna Bohemus Hustatuunt dominum cuntis persecula summum. Palatinus
est comes ren^. Marcio est Brandebur gensis Dux saxorum et rex Bohemorum. veru^
vt quidam dicunt. Through this occasyon the Egle has lost many a feder. And
in the end he shall be made naked. Otto the third was Emperor.xviii. year.
This man was a worthy man all the days of his Empire. And after the wisdom
of his fader / he was a very holy faithful man to the church. And in many
bataylles he prosperyd by cause he was devout unto almighty god and his
saints. And yaue mighty worshyppynge to ye relykes of saints. And oftentimes
he vysyted holy places. This man was crowned by Gregorius his cosyn. And at
the last he decessyd at Rome.

Anno dm^.M.iiii.
SIluester the Second was pope after Gregorius four yere^ And he was made
pope by the help o^ the devil / to whom he did homage / for he should give
him all thing that he desired. And he was called Hylbecte^ And his enmye gate
him the grace of the king of France / and he made him the bishop of Remensis
/ but anon he was deposyd And after he gate the grace of the Emperor / and
was made the bishop of Rauennie / and after the pope / But he had an end
anon and so have all that put their hope in falls deuylles. yet men trust in
his salvation / for certain demonstracyon of his sepulcre / and for the great
penance that he did in his last end. For he made his hand and in his legs
to be curte of / and dysmembred in all his body and to be cast out at the
door to fowls / and then his body to be drawn with wild beestes and there
to be buried where someuer they rested as an hand. And they stood still at
saint Johan lateranensis / and there he was buried And that was sign of his
saluacon. Johannes the.xviii. was pope five months. Johannes the.xix. was
pope after him five year. And these two did little things. Henricus the
first was Emperor in Almayne.xx. year / This henricus was duke of Barry / and
all according he was chosen for his blessed fame and good name the which he
had. And it is read / that many of these dukes of Barry werre holy men / not
all only in absteydynge of flesshely dysyres / but also in virtuous living.
And this man had a sister that was as holy as he / the whom he yaue to wife
unto the king of Hu^gry And she brought all Hungry unto the right believe and
the christian faith. And his wives name was (sancta Konnogundis) with whom he
lived a vyrgyne all his lives days. And also he did many a battle / as well
in ytaly / as in Almayne against the rebellyous / and prosperyd right wysly.
At the last with a blessed end he decessyd. And in the life of saytn
Laure^ce he and his wife be put for ensamples. Benedictus was pope after
Ioha^nes.xi year. This man had great strife in his days / for he was put out
\ and a another put in. And this Benedictus after that he was deed was seen of
an holy man bishop in a wretchyd figure / and he had great pain. And this
figure said. He trusted no thing in the mercy of god. And no thing profyted
him yt was done for him / for it was gotten with extorcyon and unjustly. Then
this bishop left his bysshopryche for dred of this sight and went in to a
monastery and lived virtuously all his days. Ioha^nes the.x. was pope after
him ^xi. year / and little profyted.

Of king Knoght that was a Dane.
ANd after the death of Eldred Knoght that was a Dane began to regne. but
Edmonde Irensyde that was king Eldredes sone by his first wife / ordained a
great power of men / and began for to war on king Knoghte / And so he did
many times and often / And the war was so strong and hard / ye wonder it
was to wyte^ And the queen Emme that dwelled tho in westmestre / had great
dread of her two sons of the war Alured and Edward / lest they should be
defoyled and mysdone thorugh this war. wherefore she sent them over ye see
in to Normandy to ye duke Richard their uncle. And there they dwelled in
saufte and peace long time. This Edmonde Irensyde and Knoght the Dane warred
strongely to gyder. But at the last they were accorded in this manner / yt they
should depart ye reame betwixt them both / and so they did / and after they
became good friends. And so well loved to gyder as they had been brethern gotten
of one fader and of one mother borne.

How king Edmonde Irensyde traytoursly was slain thorugh a traitor / that
was ralled Eldred of Strotton.
ANd after tho reigned king Irensyde and Knoght the Dane. But thus it befell
afterward / that in the same year that they were accorded / and so much loved
to gyder. wherefore a falls traitor had enuytee to the love that was betwixt
them and frendshyp / whoos name was Edrith of Stratton / yt was a great lord /
that was Edmonde Irensydes man / and of him held all the land that he had.
And nevertheless he thought his lord to betray and make Knoght king of the
land / to the entente rychely to be auau^ced / and with him be well beloved /
wherefore he prayed his lord Edmonde Irensyde upon a day with him for to ete.
And the king him curteysly granted and to him came at his prayer And at the
mete ye king ryally was served with diverse meetees and drynkes. And when the
night came yt he should go unto bed. The king took his own meyne and went
unto the chamber there yt he should take his nyghtes rest. And as he looked him
about / he saw a fair ymyge and well made / and in semblau^t as it were an
Archer with a boowe / and in the boowe a fine arowe. King Edmonde went tho
nere for to behold it better what it might be. And anon the arowe smote him
thrughe the body and there slew the kynge^ For that engyne was made for to
slay his own lord traytoursly. And so when king Edmo^de was thus deed and
slain he had reigned but.x. year. And his people for him made much sorrow. And
his body they ba^e unto Glastenbury and there them him en^yred And this false
traitor Edrith anon went unto the queen / that was king Edmondes wife / that
wist not of her lords death. Anon he took from her tow sons that were fair
and young / that her lord had upon her gotten that one was called Edward / and
that other Edwyn And law them with him to Londen and took them unto king
Knoght / yt he should do with them what his will were. And told him how
subtylly he had slain king Edmonde / for by cause and love of him / so that
king Knoght all England in his power holy might have. O thou falls traytoure
/ haste thou my true brother that was so true thus slain for me / man I most
loved in ye world. Now by my heed I shall for thy traueyll well reward as thou
have deserved / and anon let him be take and bound hand and foot in manner
of a traitor / and let cast him there in to Tamyse / and in this manner the false traitor ended his life. The king took the two childern and put them unto
the abbot of westmestre to ward and to keep till that he wist was best with
them to do.

How king Knoght sent king Edmondes sons both in to De^marke to be slain /
and how they were saved.
SO it befell soon after that king Knoghte had all the land in his hand /
and spowsed the queen Emme thorughe consent of his baronage. For she was a
fair woman the which was Eldredes wife and the dukes sister of Normandye / and
they lived together with much love as reason would. The king axed upon a day
counseyll of the queen what was best to do with the sons that were Edmonde
Irensydes. Sire said she. they ben the right heirs of ye land / and if they
live they will do much sorrow with war / and therefore let send them in to
a strange land a far to some man that may them defoyle and destroy. The
king anon let call a dane that was called walgar / and commanded him that
he should led tho two childern / in Denmark / and so to do and ordeyne for
them / that he should never here more of them. Sir said this walgar / gladly
your commandment shall be done and anon tho two chyldern he took and ladde
them in to Denmark. And for as much as he saw that the chyldern were wonder
fair and also meke / he had of them great pity and ruthe / and would them slay
/ but ladde them to the king of Hungry for to noursshe / for this walgar was
well be known with the king and well beloved. Anon the king axed whens the
childern were / and walgar told him and said / that they were the right
heirs of England and therefore men would destroy them / And therefore sir unto
you they be come mercy and help for to seek. And for sothe if they may live /
your men they shall become / and of you they shall hold all their land. The
king of Hungry received them with much honor / and let them worthily be
kept. And thus it befell after ward that Edwyne ye younger brother deyed / and
Edward ye elder brother lived / a fair man and a strong / and a large of
body and gentle / and curteys of condycyons / so yt all men him loved / And
this Edward in the Chronicles is called among the Englysshmen Edward ye
outlawe. And when as he was made knight / the kings daughter of Hu^gry him
much loved for his goodness and his fayrnes / that she him called her derlyng.
The king that was her fader perceived well the love that was betwixt them two
/ and had no heir but only that daughter / and the king vowche sauf his
daughter to no man so well / as he did to him that she loved so well and he
her / and yaue her unto him with a good will / and Edward her spowsed with
much honor. The king of hungry sent after all his baronage and made a
solemn feast and a rich wedding. And made all me^ to understand / that
this Edward should be king of that land after the decesse of him. And of
that tidings they were all full glad. This Edward begat upon his lady a
sone / that was called Edgar Helynge / and afterward a daughter that was
called Margarete that afterward was queen of Scotlonde. And by the king of
Scotlonde yt was called Mancolin she had a daughter that was called Maude yt
was queen afterward of England / through king Henry that was the first sone
of the conqueror that her wedded And he begat on her a daughter that was
called Maude that afterward was Empress of Almayn. And of this Maude came ye
king of England that unto this day is called Henry the Empress sone. And
yet had this Edward an other daughter by his wife that was called Christian
and she was a Nonne.

How king Knoght that was proud man conquered Normandy / and how he became
afterward meke and mylde.
NOw have we herd of Edmonde Irensydes sons that king Knoght wend they had been slain as he had commanded walgar before^ And this king Knoght had in
his hand all the reame of England and denmark. And after that they went
unto Norwaye that land for to conquer. But the king of the land that was
called Elat came with his people / and wend his land to have well kept and
defended / and so there he faught with him till at the last he was slain in
that battle. And tho this Knoght took all the land in his hand. And when he
had conquered Norway and taken feaute and homages there / he came again into
England / and held him self so great a lord / that him thought in all the
world his pere no man was. And he came so proud and hauteyne that it was
great wonder. And so it befell upon a day as he had herd mass at westmestre
/ and would have gone in to his palace / the ways of the Tamyse so swyftely
against him came that almoost they touched his feet. Tho said the king with a
proud heart I command the water to torn again / or else I shall make the \
The wawes for his commandment would not spare / but flowed ever in heyght
more and more. The king was so proud of heart that he would not flee the
water and beat it with a rod that he had in his hand / and commanded the
water that it should go no ferder. But for all his commandment the water
would not cesse / but ever wexed more and more on high / so that the king was
all wete and stood deep in the water. And when he saw that he had abyden there
to long / and the water would no thing do his commandment tho soon he with
drew him / and tho stood he upon a stone and held his hondes on high and
said these words herynge all the people. This god that makes the sea thus
arise / is king of all kings / and of all myghtes most. And I am a catyf and
a man deedly / and he may never deye / and all thing does his commandment
/ and to him obedyent. To that god I pray / that he be my warraunt. For I
knowledge me a caytyf feeble / and of no power And therefore I will goo unto Rome
without any long lettynge / and my wickedness for to punysshe and me to
amend. For of god I claim my land for to hold / and of none other. And anon
made ready his heir and him self went to Rome without any lettynge. And by
the way did many alms deeds / and when he came to Rome also. And when he
had be there / for his sins do penance / he came again in to England /
and became a good man and a holy. And lived and left all manner pride and
stoutenes / lived an holy life after / and made two abbayes af saint Benet /
one in England and an other in Normandye / for as much as he loved saint
Benet more specially thanne other saints. And much he loved saint Edmonde the
king. And often he yaue great yeftes to the how se / wherefore it was made
rich. And when he had reigned.xx. year he deyed / and lies at wynchestre.

Anno dm^.M.xviii.
BEnedictus the.ix. was pope after Johannes / and he was a great lechour / and
therefore he was dampened / and he apperyd to a certain man under a meruaylous
figure and an horrible. His heed and his tail was like an ass / that other
part of his body like a bear. And he said to this man to whom he apperyd. Be
not aferde / for I was a man as ye now be but I apeyre now / for I lived
unhappily in old time like a be when I was pope. In this man's time there
was great dyuysyon and sclau^der to ye church for he was put out and in two
times. And here Tholomeus notes / that the pride of bishops had ever an
evil end. And it was ever the occasyon of much unrest and battle. Conradu^
ye first was Emperor after Henricus.xx. year. This man made many laws / and
commanded peace to be kept most straytly of any man. But the earl of Ludolf
was accused / and he fled from his land / and desired more to live like a
churl than like a gentle man / and yet meruayllously his sone was made
Emperor by the commandment of god against the will of Conradus. And at the
last they were accorded. And he took Corodis daughter to his wife.

Of king Harold that lever had goo on foot than ride on horse.
THis Knoght of whom we have spoken of before / had two sons by his wife Emme
/ and that one was called Hardyknoght / and that other Harold. And he was so
light of foot that men called him most comynly Harolde Hare foot. And this
Harold had no thing the condycyons and the manners of king ^noghte that was his
fader. For he set but little price of chyualrye / ne no curteyse another
worship / but only by his own will And he became so wicked that he exyled his
mother Emme. And she went out of ye lord in to Flau^dres / and there dwelled
with the earl / wherefore after there was never good love betwixt him and his
brother For his brother hated him deedly ^ and when he had reigned two year and
little more / he deyed and lies at westmestre.

Of king Kariknoght that was Haroldes brother.
AFter this Harold Hare foot / Reigned his brother Hardiknoght a noble knight
and a worthy man / and much loved chyualry / and all manner of goodness / And
when this Hardiknoght had reigned a little while / he let vncouere his brother
Harold and smote of his heed / that was his brother at westmestre / and let
cast the heed in to a gonge / and the body in to Tamyse. And after came
fysshers and took the body with their nets by night / and bare him to saint
Clementes church and there him carried. And in this manner avenged him
Hardiknoght of his brother for in none other manner he might be auengeb^ This
king Hardiknoght was so large a yeuer of meet and drink / that his tables
were sete every day three times full ryall meets and drynkes for his own
meyne / and for all that came unto / his court to be rychely served of ryall
meets. And this king Hardiknoght sent after Emme his mother / and made her
come again i^ to England / for she was driven out of England while that Harold
Hare f^ot reigned / through counseyll of the earl Godewin / yt tho was the
grettest lord of England next the king / and most might do through out all
England what he would his commandment / for as much as he had his spoused
daughter of ye good king Knoght / that was a Dane / which daughter he had by
his first wife. And when this queen was driven out of England / and come to
the Earl of Flaundres / that was called Balde wine her cosyn / he found her
there all thing that her neded / unto the time that she went again in to
England / that the king Hardiknoght had sent for her that was her sone and
made her come again with much honor. This king Hardyknoght when he had reigned
five year he deyed and lies at westmestre.

Of the vylany that the Dany^ did to ye Englysshmen. wherefore fro ye time
after was no Dane made king of this land.
ANd after the death of this king Hardyknoght / for as much as he had no
thing of his body begoten / The earls and barons assembled / and made a
counsel / that never more after no man ye was a Dane / though he were never
so great a man among them / he should never be king of England for the
despyte that the Danes had done to Englysshmen. For euermoore before and if
it were so that the Englysshmen and the Danys hapened for to mete upon a bridge
/ the Englysshmen should not be so hardy to meue ne styre a foot / but stand
still till the Dane were passed for the. And more over if ye Englysshmen had
not bowed down their heedes to do reverence unto the Danys / they should have been beten and defoylled. And such manner despytes and vylany did the Danys to
our Englysshmen. wherefore they were driven out of ye land after time that
king Hardyknoght was deed / for they had no lord ye them might mayntene. And
in this manner avoided the Danys England that never they came again. The earls
and barons by their common assent and by their counselles sent unto Normandy for
to seek those two brethern Alured and Edward yt were dwelling with the duke
Richharde that was their came in entente for to crown Alured the elder brother
/ and him make king of England. And of this king to make an end / the earls
and barons made their oath. But the Earl Godewin of westsex falsely and
traytoursly thought to slay the se two brethern anon as they should come in to
England / in intent / to make his sone Harolde king the which sone he had
begote up on his wife / the which was king Knoghtes daughter that was a Dane.
And so this Godewin pryuely him went to South hampton for to mete there the
two brethern when that they should come unto london. And thus it befell the
messengers that went in to Normandy / found but oonly Alured that was the
elder brother For Edward his brother was gone in to hu^gry for to speak with
his cosyn Edward the outlawe / yt was Edmonde sone with the Irensyde. The
messengers told and said Alured / how that earls and barons of England sent
after him / and that he boldly should come in to England and receive the
reame. For king Hardiknoght was deed and all the Danes driven out of the land.

How Godewin the false traitor took Alured upon Gyldesdowne when that he came
from Normandy to be king of England and how he caused him to be martyred in
the isle of Ely.
AS Alured herd these tidings he thanked god. And in ship went with all the
have yt he might and passed the sea / and arrived at Southhampton there Godewin
the false traitor was. And when this traitor saw that he was come / he
welcomed him and received him with much Joy and said / that he would led him
to London there ye all the barons of England him abode to make him king. And
so they went on their way to ward London / And when they came on Gyldesdowne
tho said the traitor Godewin unto Alured Take keep about you both on the left
side and right side / and of all ye shall be king / and of such and hundred
more Now forsothe said Alured. I behyght you and if I be king. I shall ordeyne
and make such laws / wherefore god and man shall (...) ^ell pleased. Now had
the traitor co^m^ (...) al his men yt were with him That wh(...)re come upon
Gyldesdowne that the(...)lee all that were Aluredes company / that ^^re with
him fro Normandy / and after that take Alured and led him in to the isle of ely
and after put out his eyes of his heed and afterward bring him to ye death /
and so they did. For they slew al ye company that there were / ye no^bre of
xii. gentylmen that were come with him fro Normandy / and after took they
Alured and in ye isle of Ely they put out his eyes and rent his womb and took
the chyef of his bowels / and put a steke in the ground / and an end of ye
bowels there to fastened / and with nedles eylesse of yren they prycked the good
child / and so made him to go about ye stake till yt al his bowels were drawn
out of his body / and so dyed Alured there through treason of the earl Godewin.
When the lords of England had herd and wist how Alured that should have be
their king was put to death through the false traitor Godewin they were wonder
wroth. And swore between god and the^ that he should deye a more wors death /
than did Edrith of Stratto^ / yt had betrayed his lord Edmonde Irensyde / and
they would have pute him to death / but ye theyf traitor fled thens in to
Denmark / and there held him four year and more / and lost all his land in
England.

SIluester the third was pope after Benedictus. This Siluester was chose / and
Benedictus was expulsyd. And after ward was he expulsyd / and Benedictus was
put up again. And after he was put out / and Gregorius was made pope. And he was
but a simple lettred man / and therefore he chose an other man for to be
consecrate with him And when many men were dyspleased with this godynge of two
popes / the third was brought in the which should occupye the place of both
the tow. And so they strove among themself. But Henry the Emperor came then
to Rome and deposyd them all and made Clement the second pope / whom he made
anon to crown him. And he said to the Romans / they should never chese pope
without his assente. And so five being popes / sixte was put in. And many men
say / this Gregorius was an holy man. Damasius the second was after
Clemente.xx. days. This man was an usurper of the popeheed / and so he deyed
suddenly. And anon the Romans asked to have a pope / and that the Almayns
should have none. For they were so hard herted / that they myhht not enclyne
to the entence of the Emperor / the which said. There should be no pope
chosen but if he would be of counseyl of the eleccyon. But for all that the put
in this holy man Leo / and after he had of that conscience and refused. And
anon he was chosyn by the common assent / this Leo put Christ in the form of
a Laser in his own bed / and in ye morrow he found no thing there.

Of saint Edward the confessor / that was Aluredes brother / and how he was
king of England.
ANd when this was done / all the barons of England sent an other time in to
Normandy / for that Edw^rde should come in to England with much honor. And
this Edward in his chyldehode loved almighty god and him dradde. And in
honest and clennesse had his life and hated sin as death. And when he was
crowned and anointed with a ryall power forgate not his good manners and
condycyons that he first used. And forgate not all good customs for no manner
of honor / ne for riches / ne no manner hyghnes. But evermore and more yaue
him to goodness and loved god and holy church passing all other manner
thing. And poor men also be loved / and them held as they had been his
own brethern. And to them often he yaue great alms with full good will.

Of the first special love that god she(...) to saint Edward living.
IT befell on a day / as he went from the church of westmestre. And had
herd mass of saint Johan the Euangelyst / for as much as he loved saint
John^ euangelyst more specially after god and hour lady than he did any other
saint. And so there came to him a pelgryme / and prayed him for the love of god
and our lady and saint Johan the euangelyst some good him for to give. And the
king pryuely took his ring of his fynder / that no man perceived it and yaue
it to the pelgryme / and he it received and went thens. This king Edward
made all the good lawas of England / that yet ben most used and holden. And
was so mercyable and so full of pity / that no man might be more.

How the earl Godewyn came again in to England and had again all his land / and
afterward saint Edward weded his daughter.
AS the Earl Godewin that was dwelling in Denmark had much herd of the
godnesse of king Edward / and yt he was so full of mercy and of pity. He
thought yt he would go again in to England / for to seek and to have grace of
the good king Edward that so mercy full was / that he might have again his
land in peace. And arrayed him as much as he might and put him to ward the sea
and came in to England to London there the king was that time and all the
lords of England / and held a parlyament. Godewin sent to him yt were his
friends / and were the most grettest lords of the land / and prayed them to
beseech the kings graet for him / and that he would his peace and his land
grant him. The lords led him before the king to seek his grade. And anon
as the king him saw / he apeled him of treason and of the death of Alured his
brother and these words unto him said. Traitor Godewin said the king I the
appele / yt thou have betrayed and slain my brother Alured. Certes sir said
Godewin. saving your grace and your peace and your lordshyp. I him never
betrayed / ne yet him slewe^ and therefore I put me in reward of ye court. Now
fair lords said the king. ye yt ben my lyeges / earls and barons of the land
that here be assembled / fulle well ye herd my appele / And the answer also
of Godewin / and therefore I woll that ye a ward and does right. The earls and
Barons tho gadred them all together for to do this a ward by themself / and so
they spoke dyuersely amu^ge them. For some said / there was never alyaunce by
homage seriment service ne by lordshyp between Godewin and Alured / for which
thing they might him draw. And at the last they deuysyd and demed / That he
should put him in ye kings mercy all together. Tho spoke ye earl Leuerik of
Couentree a good man to god and to all the world / and told his reason in
this manner and said. The earl Godewin is the best fended man of England after
the King / and well it might not be again said / ye without counsel of
Godwin Alured was never put to death / wherefore I a ward as towchynge my part
/ that himself and his sone and every of us.xii. earls that been his friends goo
before the king / charged with as much gold and silver as we may bear
betwyxt our hondes / praynge ye king to forgive his evil will to the earl
Godewin / and receive his homage / and his land yield again. And they accorded
unto that a ward / and came in this manner as is abouesayd every of them with
hold and silver as much as they might bear between her hondes before the
king / and there said the form and the manner of they accord and of their a
ward The king would not them again say / But as much as they ordained / he
granted and confermed And so was ye earl Godewin accorded with the king / and
so he had again all his land. And afterward he bare him so well and so wisely
/ that the king loved him wonder much / and with him he was fulle preuy. And
within a little time they loved so much / that there the king spowsed
Godewyns daughter / and made her queen. And nevertheless though the kyngge had
a wife / yet he lived ever in chastyce and cle^nesse of body without any
flesshely deed doing with his wife. And the queen also in her half ladde an
holy life two year / and deyed. And afterward the king lived all his life
without any wife. The king yaue the erledome of Oxenforde to Harolde that was
Godewyns sone / and made him earl. And so well they were beloved / both the
fader and he / and so pryue with the king / both the fader and the sone that
they might do by right what thing that they would For against right would he
nothing do for no manner man / so good and true he was of conscience. And
therefore our lord Ihesu Christ great special love unto him showed.

How king Edward saw Swyne king of Denmark drowned in the sea in the time of
the Sacrament as he stood and herd mass.
IT befelle upon wytsondaye as king Edward herd his mass in the great
church of westmestre nyghe at the leuacyon of Ihesu Crystis body / and as
all men were gadred in to the church. and came night the awter for to see the
sacrynge. the king his hondes life up on higher and a great laughter took up.
Wherefore all that about him stood gretely ganne wonder. And after mass / they
axed why the kings laughter was fair lord said king Edward. I saw Swyne
the younger that was king of Denmark come in to the sea with his power for to
have come in to England upon us for to war. And I saw him and his folk
drowned in the sea / and all this I saw in the leuacyon of Crystis body
between ye priests hondes and I had therefore so great Joy that I might not my
laughter withholde. And the earl Leueryk beside him stood at the leuacyon / and
openly saw ye form of bread torn in the likeness of a young child / and
took up his right hand and blessed the king and after the earl and the earl
anon turned him to ward ye king for to make him see ye holy sight. And to
said ye king Sire Earl said he I see well yt ye see / thanked be god that I
have honored my god my sauoyour vysybly Ihesu Christ in form of man. whoos
name he blessed in all worlds.

How the ring that saint Edward had given to a poor pelgryme / for the love
of god and saint Johan Euangelyst came again to king Edward.
This noble man Saint Edward reigned.xiii. year. And thus it befelle upon a
time are he deyed / that two men of England were gone in to holy land / and
had done their pelgrymage / and were going again in to their own country
where they came fro And as they went in ye way / they met a pilgrim that
curtely them saluwed / and axed of them in what land and in what country
they were borne. And they said in England. Tho axed he who was king of
England. And they answered and said. the good king Edward. Fair friends said
tho the pelgryme / when yt ye come in to your countres again. I pray you yt ye
will go unto king Edward / and oftentimes great him in mine name and
oftentimes him thank of his great curteysy that he to me has done and namely
for the ring that ye have me when he had herd mass at westmestre for saint
Iohans love Euangelyst. And took it to ye pelgremes and said. I pray you go and
bear this ring and take it unto king Edward / and tell him that I send it him
and a full rich yefte I will him give. For upon the.x. day he shall come unto
me / and evermore dwell in bless without any end. Sir said ye pelgremes /
what me^ be ye / and in what country is your dwelling. Fair friends said he I
am John^ the Eua^gelyste / and I am dwelling with almighty god / and your
king Edward is my friend / and I love him i^ specyal for by chause that he
has evermore lived in clennesse and is a clean maid and I pray you my
message fulfill as I have you said. when ye saint Johan the euangelyst had them
thus charged suddenly he voyded out of their syghtes both / The pelgrymes tho
thanked almighty god and wene forth their way. And when they had gone two or
three mile. they began to wax weary and set them a down for to rest them /
and so they fell one sleep / And when they had slepte well one of them a woke
and life up his heed and looked about / and said to his fellow. Arise up and
walk we in our way. what said that one fellow unto that other / where be we
now. Certes said that other / it seems me yt this is not the same country
there we laid us down in for to rest and sleep. For we were from Jerusalem
but three mile. They took up their hondes and blessed them / and went forth in
their way And as they went in their way / they saw shep^ going with their
sheep ye spoke none other langage but english. Good friends said one of the
pelgrymes / what country is this and who is lord thereof. And one of the
sheperdes answered and said. this is ye country of kent in England / of the
which the good king Edward is lord of. The pelgrymes ^anked tho almighty god
and saint John^ Euangelyst and went forth in their way and came to
Caunterbury / and fro thens unto London / and there they found the king And
told him all from the beginning unto ye ending asmoche as saint John^ had
them charged and of al things how they hadsped by the way. And took the
ring to the king Edward / and he took it ^ and thanked almighty god and
saint John^ Euangelyst. And tho made him ready every day fro day to day to
depart out of this life / when god would for him send.

How saint Edward dyed ye Twelfth day.
ANd after it befell thus on Crystmasse even / as the holy man Edward was at
goods service Matyns for to hereof that high solemn feast. He became full
like and in the morrow endured with much pain the mass for to here. And
after mass he let him be ladde in to his chamber / There for to rest him.
But in his halle among his barons and his knights might he not come them for
to comfort and solace / as he was wont for to do at ye worthy feast. wherefore
all their mirth and comfort among all that were in the halle was turned in to
care and sorrow / by cause they dradde for to lose the good lord ye king. And
upon Saint John^ day Euangelyste that came next / the king received his
ryghtes of holy church / as yt befaylleth to every christian man and abode the
mercy and the will of god. And ye two pilgrims he let before him come and
yaue them rich yeftes and betoke them to god. Also the abbot of westemestre
he let before him come and took him that ring in the honor of god and
saint Mary / and of Saint Johan the euangelyst. And the abbot took it and put
it among other rekyles / so that it is at westmestre / and ever shall be so
lay the king syke till the twelfth eve. And tho deyed the good king Edward
at wehmestre / and there he lies. For whoos love god has showed many a
fair miracle. And this was in the year of the. Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu
Christ.M.lxv. And after he was translated and put in the shryne by the noble
martyr saint Tomas of Caunterbury.

VIctor the second was pope after Leo And of him little is written. Henry the
second was Emperor after the first Henry.xvii. year / this man was cosyn to
Conradus / and he was borne in wood / and twyes taken for to be slain when he
was a child / but god defended him evermore. when he was made Emperor / many
amonastery he made in the same place in the wood where he was borne. This man
was a victoryous man / and he entered i^ to ytaly / and there he took Padulphus
the prince of Campany. Stephanus the.ix. was pope after Victor.ix. months.
Benedictus after him / and he took the dygnyte of the pope Stephanus by
strength and keep it.ix. months / and then decessyd. Henry the third was
Emperor after Henry the second / This Henry was an Inquyete man / and many
times troubled that holy man Gregorius the.vii. And first he axed foryeuenesse
and was assoyled^ But he perceyuered not long but brought in to an other pope
against him / and said he was an heretyke. And Gregorius cursyd him. And the
chesers of the Emperor they those the duke of Baxon for to be Emperor / whom
this Henry in battle overcame. And then^e he came to Rome with his pope and
pursewed pope Gregorius and the Cardynalles also. And then^e anon Robert ye
king of Naples drove him the^s and delivered the pope and his Cardynalles.
Nevertheless yet he was a man of great alms. and.iii. times he faught in
battle / and at ye last he deyed wrytchedly / for he was put there by his own
sone. For so as he did to other men / so was he done unto. Nicholaus ye
second was pope after Benedictus two year / this Nicolaus called a counsel
against yt Archedeken of Turonoseus / ye which was an heretyk / and taught
against ye faith. For he erred in ye sacrament / and after he was converted and
was an holy man but he could never convert his dyscyples. Nota Alexander ye
second was pope after him xii. year / this Alexander was an holy man. and he
ordained yt under pain of cursynge yt no man should here a priests mass
whom men knew had a lemman. (Vt pz.xxxii. p^cer hoc) He had strive with one
Codulo / but he expulsyd him as an usurper / and put him out as a symonyer.

How Harolde that was good wyns sone was made king / and how he escape from
the duke of Normandy.
AS saint Edward was gone out of this world / and was passed to god and
worthily enteryd as to such a great lord ought / the barons of the land
would have had Edward Elygus. sone to Edward the outlawe that was Edmonde
Irensydes sone to be king / For as much as he was most kyndest kings blood
of the reame. But Harolde sone through the earl Godewyn / and ye strength of
his fader Godewyn / and through other great lords of the reame / yt were of his
kynne and unto him sybbe seized all England in to his hand / and anon let
crown him king after the enterement of Saint Edware. This Harolde that was
Godewynes sone the second year before that saint Edward was deed / would have
gone in to Flaundres / but he was driven through tempest in to the country of
Pountyse / and there he was taken brought to duke wyllyam And this Harolde
wend yt tho this duke wyllyam would have be avenged upon him for by cause yt
the Earl Godewyn yt was roldes fader / had let slay Alured that was saint
Edwardes brother / and pryncipally for by cause that Alured was queen Emmes
sone / ye was Rychardes mother duke of Normandy / that was ai^enll to the duke
wyllyam And nevertheless when the duke wyllyam had Harolde in prison and under
his power / for asmoche as this Harolde was a noble wise knight and a worthy of
body / and that his fader and he was accorded with good king Edward / and
therefore would not mysdo him. But all manner things that betwext them was
spoken and ordained. Harolde by his good will swore upon a book / and upon ^oly
saints that he should spouse and wedde duke wyllyams daughter after the death
of saint Edward / and that he should besely do his devour for to keep and
save the reame of England unto the profit and auantage of duke wyllyam. And
when Harolde had thus made his oath unto the duke wyllyam he let him goo /
and yaue him many a rich yeftes. And he tho went thens / and came in to
England / and anon did in this manner when Saint Edward was deed / and as
a man falsely for sworn / He let crown him king of England / and falsely
brake the coue name yt he had made before with duke wyllyam / wherefore he was
wonder wroth with him and swore / that he would upon him be avenged what some
ever him befell. And anon duke wyllyam let assemble a great host and came
in to England to aueng^ him upon Harolde / and to conquer the land if that
he might. And in the same year that Harolde was crowned. Haralde Herestynge
king of Denmark arrived in Scotlo^de and thought to have be king of England
and he came in England and robbed / and destroyed all that he might / till
