that he came to york / and there he slew many men of arms a thousand and a
hundred priests. wha^ this tidings came to the king / He assembled a great
power / and went for to fight with Haralde of Denmark / and with his own
hondes de him slew / and the Danes were dyscomfyted / and tho that were left
a live with much sorrow fled to their ships. And thus king Harolde of
England slew king Haralde of Denmark.

Anno dm^.M.lxvi. How wyllyam Bastard duke of Normandy came in to England /
and slew king Harolde Here come Normans and expulsyd Harolde a Saxon.


ANnd wha^ this bataylle was done. Harolde be came so proud / and would no
thing part with his people of the thing that he had gotten / but held it all
to him self. wherefore the most part of his people were wroth and from him
departed / so that oonly with him abode no moo but his soldyurs. And upon a
day as he sat at meet / a messager came to him and said / that wyllyam
bastard the duke of Normandy was arrived in England with a great host / and
had take all the land about Hastynge / and also mined the castle. wha^ the
king had herd this tidings / he went thither with a little power in all the
have that he might for there but few people with him left. And when he was
come thither / he ordained to give battle to duke wyllyam. But the duke axed
him of these three things / if that he would have his daughter to wife as he
made and swore his oath and behyght / or that he would hold the land of him
in truage / or he would determyne this thing in battle. This Harolde was a
proud man and a strong and trusted wonder much upon his strength and faught
with duke wyllyam and with his people. But Harolde and his men in this battle
were dysco^fyted / and himself there was slain / and this battle was ended
at Tombryge in the second year of his regne / upon sanyt Calixtus day / and
so he was buried at waltham.

Of king william bastard and how he governed him well and wisely / and of the
great war between him and the king of France.
AS willi^m Bastard duke of Normandy had conquered all the land / upon
Crystmasse day then next let crown him king at westmestre and as a worthy
king yaue unto Englyshmen largely lands / and to his knights And after ward
he wene him over the sea and came i^ to Normandy / and there he dwelled a
while. And in the second year of his regne he came again in to England / and
brought with him Maude his wife and let crown her queen of England oon
wytsondaye. And tho anon after the king of Scotlonde / thoe was called
Malcolin began to strive and war with the king wylyam. And he ordained him
toward Scotlonde with his men both by lord and by see / for to destroy king
Malcolin But they were accorded / and the king of Scotlonde became his man /
and held all his land of him. And king wyllyam received of him is homage and
came again in to England. And as king wyllyam had be king.xvii. year. Maude
the queen deyed / on whom king wyllyam had begote many fair chyldern / that
is for to say. Robert Curthos wylllyam Rous Richard also that deyed. Henry^
Beauclerke / and Maude also that was the earls wife of Bleynes / and other four
fair daughters. And after his wives death / great debate began betwixt him and
the king of France Philyp but at the last they were accorded And tho dwelled
ye king of England in Normandy / and no man him warned / and he no man long
time. And the king of France said upon a day in scorn of king wyllyam
had long time lain in child bed / and long time had rested him there. And
this word came to the king of England there that he did lie in Normandye at
Rome. And for this word was tho euylle apayed / and also wonder wrath toward
the king of France. And swore by god / that wha^ he were arysyn of his
sykenesse / he would lyghten a thousand condelles to the king of France /
and anon let assemble a great host of Normandy and of English men. And in
the beginning of the Heruest he came in to France / and burnt all the towns
that they came by through the country and robbed and did all ye sorrow that he
might through out all France. And at ye last he brenned the cite of Mandos /
and commanded his people to bear wood / and as much as he might brenne. And
him self halpe there to all ye he might with good will. And there was a great
hete / what of the fire what was so great / and of the son that it was
wo^dder hot / that it stuffed him so yt he became and fell in to a great
disease and sykenesse And when he saw yt he was so strong syke / he ordained
and assgned all Normandye to Robert Curthos his sone / and all england to
wyllyam the Rous / and bequone to Henry Beaclerke al his treasour. And when he
thus had done / he received all the sacraments of holy church / and deyed
ye.xx. year of his regne \ and lies at Cane in Normandy.

Anno dm^.M.lxvi.
GRegorius the.vii. was pope after Alexander.xii. year / this man ordained in a
general Synodus / that no priest should have a wife ne should dwell with
wymmen / but tho that the holy Synodus of Micena and other decrees had suffered.
And then^e the priests set naught or little pondred his ordinance. This
pope commanded that no man should here mass of a priest that had a concubyne
And he on acertayne time when he was Cardynall and Legate in to France /
proceeded sharply against prelates and / that were symomers. And among other
was one bishop there that was gretely famed with symonye. And those that
accused him / pryuely hyered them to say the countraye. The which the Legate
conceived / and afor^ all the people he said. Let the Judgment of this men
cesse at this time / for it is dysceyuable / and let god dyspose for it. And
said / thus it is certain. That the dygnyte of a bishop is the yeuer of the
holy ghost. And whosomeuer byeth a bysshopryche / does against the holy ghost.
Then^e if thou bishop did not against the holy ghost say openly before all the
people (Glori^ petri et filio et speritui sancto) And many times he began to
say it / but he could never speak (spiritui sancto) Then he was deposyd of
his bysshopryche / and after he could speak it will enough. Victor the third
was pope after him oo year / and this man was poisoned with venym in the
chaly^. Vrbanus was pope after him two year. This man cursyd ye king of
France for his adu^^^erys. And he called a counseyll at Claurum in the which
he ordained / that matyns of our lady should be said every day / and on
Saturday her solemn mass. And it is said / that this was showed unto ye
freres of Cartusis. Also he called an other counseyll at Turan for the holy
land to be won aye^ / and pryuoked the people to that matere / and within a
little time after that matere / the holy land was recovered and the sepulcre
of our lord / and Anthioche with many other cytees taken fro the Sarrasyns.
And it is said and byleued that.CC.M. christian men went to that Iourny For
there went of states old men and young / and also rich and poor / and no
man compelled them. And this passage was made by the vysyon of our lady. And
the princes of this peaple were diverse One was Godfroy de Boloynt a full noble
man of all the world / and a virtuous man / and an other was Beemonde the Duke
of Neaples. And ye third was Hughe the kings brother of France / and many
other / the which / did full nobly for the faith of god. And it were to long
in this book to reherce the glorious acts that they did. Of king wyllyam
Rous that was king williams bastardes sone ye destroyed towns / and houses of
Relygyon for to make ye new forest.

ANd after this wyllyam bastard reigned his son wyllyam the Rous.
And this wyllyam was a wonder contraryous man to god and holy church / and
let amend and make the town of Cardies / that the Paynems had destroyed.
This king wyllyam destroyed holy church and their possessions in what part
he might them find. And their fore there was so much debate between him and
the Archebyssop of Caunterbury Ancelmus. For by cause that he repreuyd him of
his wickedness / that he destroyed holy church. And for that cause the king
bare to him great wrath. And so he exyled him out of this land / and the
Archebysshop went to the court of Rome / and there dwelled with the pope / And
this king made the new forest / and cast down and destroyed.xxvi. towns.
and.lxxx. houses of Relygyon / all for to make his forest longer and broder^
And became wonder glad and proud of his wood and of his forest. And
nourysshed ye wild beestes yt were within / that it was marvel for to wit /
so that men called him keeper of wodes and of pastures. And the more longer that
he lived / the more wicked he became both to god and to all holy church and to
all his me^ And this king let make the great halle of westmestre. So upon a
day in the wytsontyde he held therein his first feast / and he looked him
about and said / that the halle was to little by the half deal. And at the
last he became so contraryous / that al thing yt pleased god dyspleased him /
and all thing that god loved / he hated deedly. And so it befell that he
dremyd upon a night a little or that he deyed / that he was let blood / and
bledde a great quantyte of blood / and a streme of blood lepte on high to ward
heaven more than a hundred fadom and the clerenesse of the day was turned unto
night and derkenesse of the fyrmamente also And when that he a woke he had
great dread so that he not wist what for to do. And told his dreme to men of
his counseyll and said that he had great dread / and supposyd that to him was
some myscaunce to come. And the second night before a monk dremyd of ye
household / that the king went in to a church with much people / and he was
so proud that he despised all the people that were with him and that he took
ye image of the Crucefire and shamefully bote it with his teeth. And the
Crucefixe mekely suffered all that he did. But yer y^ king and as a wood man
rent of the arms of the Crucefixe / and cast it under his feet / and
defoylled it / and threw it all a broad / And ^ great fire came out of the
Crucefixe mouth. Of which dreme many a man had great meruaylle and wonder.
The good man that had dremyd this strange dreme / told it to a knight that
was most pryue with the king of all men / and the knight was called Hamondes
Soon the monk and he told the dremes to the king and said. That it should
betoken other thing than good / And nevertheless the king laughed there at twyes
or thryes / and little se^te thereby / and thought that he would go and hunte /
and play in the forest. And men counseylled him ye he should not go ye day for
no manner thing ne come in the wood / so that he abode at home before meet /
But oonly as he had eten no man him might let / but he would go unto the wood
for to have his dysporce. And so it befell that one of his knights that hight
walter Tyrell / would have shot to a harre / and his arowe glensyd upon a
branch / and thorughe mysauenture smote the king to the heart And so he
fell down deed to the ground with out any word speaking / and so ended his
life days. And it was no meruaylle / for the day yt he deyde he had let to
ferme the Archebisshop rich of Canterbury / and xabbayes also / and ever more
did great destruccyon to holy church / through wrongful taking and axenges /
for no man durst withstand that he would have done. And of his lewdenes he
would never withdraw / another to amend his life. And there fore god would
suffer him no longer to regne in his wyckednes. And he had be king.xiii. year
and.vi. wekes / and lies at westmestre.

Anno dm^.M.lxxxviii.
PAschall was pope after Vrbanus.xviii. year and.v. months / the wiche
ye.xiii. ye^e of his bysshopryche with his cardynalles was put in prison / by
Henry ye fourth Emperor and they might not be delivered until the pope had
swore that he should keep peace with him / and that he should never curse him /
and on that promise / the pope yaue the Emperor a preuylege / and the year
after the pope damned that preuylege / and said on this wise. Let us
comprehend all holy scripture the old testament and the new the laws of the
prophecyes the gospel and the canons of appostles / and all the decres of the
popes of Rome / that all they held I hold / and that that they dampened ^
dampne / and most specya^le that preuylege granted to Henry the Emperor /
the which rather is granted to venge his malice than to multeplye hes
paceyence in virtue. For evermore I dampne ye same preuylege

Of king Henry Beauclerk that was william Rous brother / and of the debate
between him and Robert Curthos his brother.
ANd when wyllyam Rous was deed. Henry Beauclerk his brother was made king
because wyllyam Rous had no child begoten on his body. And this Henry
Beauclerk was crowned king at London the fourth day after that his brother
was decessyd / that is to say / the fyfthe day of August. And anon as
ancelmus that was Archebysshop of Canterbury that was at the court of Rome
herd tell that wyllyam Rous was deed / he came again in to England and the
king Beauclerk welcomed him with much onour. And the first year that king
Henry reigned and was crowned. He spowsed maude ye was Margaretes daughter the
queen of Scotlonde. And the Archebysshop Ancelmus of Caunterbury wedded theme
And this king begat upon his wife two sons and a daughter / that is to say.
wyllyam and Richard and Maude. And this Maude was after ward the Empress of
Almayne. And in the second year of his regne / his brother Robert Curthos /
that was duke of Normandy came with an huge host in to England for to challenge
the land. But thrughe counseyle of wise men of the land / they were accorded
in this manner. That the king should give his brother the duke a thousand
pound every year. And which of them that lived lengest should be that others
heir and so between them should be no debate ne strife. And then when they
were thus accorded / ye duke went home again in to Normandye^ And when the
king had reigned four year. There a rose a great debate between him and the
Archebysshop of Caunterbury Ancelmus. For by cause that the Archebysshoh would
not grant to him for cale^ges of chyrches at his will. And the reforde
personse the Archebysshoppe Ancelmus went over the sea unto the court of Rome
and there he dwelled with the pope. And in the same year the duke of Normandy
came in to England to speak with his brether. And among all other things the
duke of Normandye. for yaue unto the king his brother the forsayde thousand
pound by year that should pay unto the duke. And with good love the king and
the duke departed / and there the duke went again in to Normundy. And when tho
two year were agone / Through the entycement of the devil and of simple me^ / a
great debate arose between the king and ye duke / so that through counseyll
the king went over the sea in to Normandy / and when the king of England
was come in to Normandy / all the great lords of Normandye turned unto the
king of England and held against the duke their own lord / and him forsook
/ and to the king them held / and all the good castelles and towns of
Normandy. And soon after was the duke taken and ladde with the king in to
England. And the king let put the duke in to prison / and this was the
vengeaun^e of god. For when the duke was in the holy land god yaue him such
might and grace that he was chosen for to have be king of Iherusalem / and he
forsook it and would not take it upon him / And therefore god sent him that
shame and dyspyte for to put in his brothers prison / Tho seized king Hery all
Normandye in to his hand / and held it all his life time. And in the same
year came the bishop Ancelmus for the court of Rome in to England again. And
the king and he were accorded. And in the next year coming after / there
began a great debare between the king Phylyppe of France and king Henry of
Englende / wherefore king Henry went in to Normandye / and there was strong
war between them two. And tho deye^ the king of France and lowys his sone
was mad king anon after his death. And tho went king Henry again into England /
and married Maude his daughter unto henry ye emperor of Almayne.

Of the debate that was betwixt king Lowys of France and king Hery of
Eenglonde / and how kynhe Henryes two snes were lost in the high se^.
AS king Henry had be king.xvii. year / a great debate arose betwixt king
Lowys of France and king Henry of England / for by cause that the king had
sent in to Normandy to his men / that they should be helping unto therle of
Bloys as much as they might in war against the king of France / And that
they should be as ready to hy^ as they were to their own lord / for by cause
that therle had spowsed his sister dame maude. And for this cause the king
of France did much sorrow to Normandy. wherefore ye king of England was
wonder wroth / and in have wen^e over the sea with a great power / and came in
to Norma^dye for to defend that land And the war between them lasted two
year / till at the last they two faught to geder. And the king of France was
dyscomfyted / and uneaths escaped away with much pain / and the most
party of his men were taken. And the king did with them what him best lyked
/ And some of them he let go freely / and some he let be put unto the death.
But afterward those two kings were accorded. And when king Henry had oonly
all the land of Normandy / and dysco^fyted his enmyes of France / he turned
again in to England with moche^ honor. And his two sons wyllyam and
Richard would have come after the fader and went to the sea with a great
company of people. But are that they might come to land / the ship came
against a roche and all were drowned that were there in / save oo man that was
in ye same ship that escaped. And this was upon saint Katheryns day / and
these were ye names of them that were drowned. Wyllyam and Richard the kings
sons / the Earl of Chestre Ottonell / his brotger Geffroy Rydell Walter
Emurci. Godefray Archedeken / the kings daughter / the countess of Perches
the kings nece the countess of Chestre / and many other. When king Henry and
other lords arrived in England / and herd these tidings / they made sorrow
enough / And all their myrthe and Joy was turned in to morning and sorrow.

How Maude the Empress came again in England / and how she afterward wedded
to Geffroy therle of Angoy.
ANd when that two year were agone yt the Earl had dwelled with the king / the
earl went from the king / and began to war upon him and did much harm in
the land of Normandy / and took there a strong castle and there he dwelled
all that year. And tho came to him tidings yt Henry the Emperor of Almayne yt
had spowsed Maude his daughter was deed / and that she dwelled no longer in
Almayne / and yt she would come again in to Normandy to her fader And wha^ that
she was come unto him / he took her tho to him and came again in to England /
and made the Englysshemen to do oath and feaute to the Empress And the first
man that made the oath was wyllyam ye Archebysshop of Canterbury And that
other David king of Scotlo^de / and after him all ye barons and earls of
England. Also after that ye noble man therle of Angoy yt was a worthy knight
/ sent unto ye king of England / yt he would grant him for to have his
daughter to spowse / that is to say Maude the Empress. And for by cause yt
her fader wist that he was a noble man / the king him granted and consented
there to. And tho took he his daughter and ladde her in to Normandy / and came
to the noble knight Geffroy / and there he spowsed the forsayde Maude with
much honor / and the Earl beg^te upon her a sone / yt was called Henry ye
Empress sone. And after when all this was done / king Henry dwelled all that
year in Normandy. and after ye long time a grievous sykenesse took him where
thorugh he deyed. And this king Henry reigned.xxxv. year and four months. And
after deyed as is before said in Normandy. And his heart was enteryd in ye
great church of our lady in Rouen. and his body was brought with much honor
in to England and enteryd at Redynge in the abboye / of ye which abbaye he
was begynner and founder.

HEnrycus the fourth was Emperor in Almayne after Harry the third.xv. year.
This man put his own fader in prison / and there held him till he deyed. And
took pope Paschall with his Cardynalles / and present them as it is said
before. For the which cause as it is supposed he lacked issue. For he wedded
the kings daughter of England Maude. But after ward he came to grace / and
all the laws of ye church freely he resyned to Calixtus ye pope. And besought
him to give him in penance that he should never come again to his Empire / that
he might have remyssyon of his trespaas. And after ye oppynyon of many a man /
he was wylfully exyled and deyed and his wife both at Chestre in England.
Gelasius was pope after Paschall two year. And fled from Henry the Emperor
in to Bourgoyne and there decessyd. This Emperor those Benedyctus a Spanyarde
to be pope / the which strove with Calixtus. Calixtus was pope after him two
year and five months. This Calixtus was the sone of the duke of Bourgoyne and
was chosen in the place of Gelasius / And when he should come to Rome / he took
the for said Benedictus / and made him to ride before him shamefully. For he on
a mule turned his face to the tail of ye mule / and held the tail in his
hand as a brydell / till he came through the cite / and there he was put in
prison. And this pope made peace with the Emperor. Honorius was pope after him
two year / and little of him is written. Nota. Hary the fourth Emperor of
Almayne decessyd this time and was buried with his progenytours / after some
men with such an Epytaphe (Filius hic: pater hic Auus hic: proauus iacet
istis) But it is lykely to be truer that ye Geralde said (in Itinerario walk)
wherefore he says / that after he had prysoned his carnal fader / and his
sperytuell fader the pope with his Cardynalles / after he was reconsyled and
wylfully he was exyled. And he left Maude his wife the kings daughter of
England pryuely / and lived an heremytes life at Chestre.x. year where he might
live as no man knew him. And he called himself Godyscallus / the which
Godysson is called. So the Emperor secretly went away / and Maude his wife
the Empress there / she went unto her fader Henry in to Normandy. where anon
after she was wedded unto Geffroy Plantaginet the duke of Andegame upon whom he
begat Henry the second afterward king of England. Under whom saint Thomas
of Caunterbury reigned and deyed Lotharius was Emperor aftey Henry the
fourth.xii. year / And little of him is wrytem / but that he was manerely to
the church. And that he subdued Roger the usurper of the king of Cycyle. Hugo
de sancto Victory was a noble man this time at Paris / and a noble doctor /
of the nacyon of Saxons. The order of saint Johan Baptyst at Iherusalem began
this time / by the worshypfull man Reymonde myghtely dysposed unto the we^ke of
mercy. All this order make their way to serve poor men.

Anno dm^.M.C.xxxiiii.
INnocencius was pope after Honorius xiiii. year. and.vii^ months. This man
was a very devout man / and with such men he accompanied him and he had stryf
against* Perys of Lion the which named him Anocletus. And by strenth he took
the popehede. The which Innoce^cius saw / and with two Galeys he fled in to
France / and was worship fully received of saint Bernarde the which that time
had all the kings and princes in his hand. And he provoked them for to
bring this pope Innocencius in to dygnyte again. And at the last all thing was
sessyd / and his enmyes were destroyed through the Judgment of god. And he was
pope again / and lived prouffytably / and was buried at Latranence^

How Stephen yt was king Henryes systers sone / was made king of England.
AFter this king Henry that was the first / was made king his neuewes sister
sone. Stephen earl of Bolonye. For anon as he herd the tidings of his uncles
death / then he passed the sea and came in to England thrught counseyll and
strength of many great lords in England / against the oath that they had made
to Maude the Empress / took the reame / and he let crown Stephen king of the
land. And the Archebysshop wyllyam of Caunterbury / that first made the oath
of feaute to Maude the Empress / set the crown upon Stephens heed and him
anoynetd. And bishop roger of Salysbury mayntened the kings part in as much
as he might. The first year ye king Stephen began to regne / he assembled a
great host and went to war Scotlonde / for to have warred upon the king of
Scotlonde. But he came against him in peace and in good manner and to him
trusted. But he made to him none homage / for as much as he had made unto
thempresse Maude. And in the fourth year of his regne Maude the Empress came
in to England and tho began debate between king Stephen and Maude thempresse.
This Maude went unto the cite of Nicholl / and the king her besyged long time
and might not speed / so well the cite was kept and defended. And tho yt were
within ye cite / meruaylously escaped a way without any manner of harm. And tho
took ye king the cite / and dwelled therein till Candelmasse And tho came the
barons that held with the Empress. That is for to say / the earl Radulphe of
Chestre the earl Robert of Glocestre. Hugh Bygot. Robert of Morley / and these
brought wtth them a strong power and faught with the king / and yaue him a
great bataylle In ye which bataylle king Stephen was taken / and set in
prison in the castle of Brytowe.

How Maude the Empress went fro wynchestre to Oxenforde / and after she
escaped to walynforde / and of the sorrow and dyscease that she had.
NOw as the king was taken and brought in to ward in ye castle of Bristow /
this Maude the Empress was made lady of England / and all men held her for
lady of the land But those of Kent held with king Stephens wife / and also
wyllyam of Prece and his retenewe halpe them and held war against Maude them
press. And anon after the king of Scotlonde came to them with a huge nombre
of people And tho went their together to wynchestre / there that the Empress was
/ and would have taken her But the Earl of Glocestre came with his power and
fought with them. And the Empress in the mean while that the battle dured
escaped from them and went unto Oxenforde and there held her. And in that
bataylle was the earl of Glocetre dyscomfyted and taken and with him many other
lords. And for his delyueraunce / was king Stephen delivered out of prison.
And wha^ he was delivered out of prison / he went thens unto Oxenforde and
besyeged thempresse yt was tho at Oxenforde. And the seyge endured fro
Myghelmasse unto saint Andrews tide. And the Empress let clothe her tho all
in white lynnen clothe (...) by cause she would not be known. For (...) same
time there was much sorow^ and ^^e escaped by ye Tamyse from them a way that
were her enmyes. And from thens ^he w^nte to walyngforde and there held her.
And the king would have beseyged there / but he had so much to do with the
earl Radulphe of Ch^ and with Hugh Bygot that strongely wa^d upon him in every
place ^ that he wyste whether for to torn. And the earl of Gloucester ^alpe him
with his power.

How Gaufryde ye earl of Angoy ^au^ unto Henry the Empress sone all Normandy
ANd after this the king went unto wylton / and would have made a castle
there. But tho came to him the earl of Glocestre with a strong power and there
almooste he had taken the king but yet the king escaped with much pain. And
wyllyam Mar^ell there was taken. And for whoos delyuera^ce they yaue unto the
earl of Glocestre ye good castle of Shyrborn that he had taken. And when this
was done / the earl Robert and all ye kings enmyes went unto Faryngdon and
began there for to make a strong castle / but the king came thither with a
strong power and drove him thens / And in that same year the earl Radulphe of
Chestre was accorded with ye king and came to his court at his commandment
And the earl demed sauely for to come. And the king anon let take him / and
put him in to prison. And might never for no thing come out till that he had
yielded up to the king the castle of Nicholl / the which he had taken from
the king with his strength in the.xv. year of his regne. And Gaufride the
earl of Angoy yaue up unto Henry his sone all Normandy. And in the year that
next ensewed / deyed the earl Gaufryde. And Henry his sone tho ano^e turned
again to Angoy / and there was made earl wy^h much honor of all his men of the
land. And to him did feaute and homage the most party of the land. And tho
was this Henry the Empress sone earl of Angoy / and also duke of Normandy. In
the same year was made a dyuorce bytwnene the king of France / and the queen
his wife that was right heir of Gascoyne. For because yt it was known and
proved / that they were sybbe and nyghe of blood. And tho spowsed her Henry the
Empress sone earl of Angoy and the duke of Normandy / and duke of Gascoyne. In
ye.xviii year of this Stephen this Henry came in to England with a strong
power / and began for to war upon this king Setphen. and took the castle of
Malmesbury / and did much harm. And the king Stephen had so much war
that he wist not whyther for to go. But at the last they were accorded through
the Archebysshop Theobaldus / and through other worthy lords of England / upon
this condycyon. that they should depart the Realm of England but wene them
two / so yt Henry the Empress sone should holy have the half of all the land
of England. And thus they were accorded and peace was cried thrughout al
England. And when ye accord was made between tho two lords / king Stephen
became so sorry / for because that he had lost half England / and fell in to
such a malady / and deyed in the.xix. year / and.viii. wekes and.v. days of
his regne all in war and in contake. And he ^yeth in the abbaye of Feuersham
/ the which he lets make in the.xvi. year of his regne.

CElestynus the second was pope after Innocencius.v. months. And little he
did. Lucius was after him and little proffyted / for they deyed both i^ a
pestylence. Eugenius the second was pope after him.v. year and four months.
This man fryst was the dyscyple of saint Bernarde / and after the abbot of
saint Anastasius by Rome. And came to ye church of saint Cesary and was chosen
pope by the Cardynalles / he no thing knowing thereof / And for dread of ye
Senators he was consecrated without this cite / this man was an holy man / and
suffered trybulacyon. And at the last he decessyd / and lies at saint Peter's
And after anon decessyd Saint Bernarde. Petrus Lombardus the bishop of Paris
brother to Graciam / compyled the four books of the Sentence this time. Petrus
Co^mestor brother to Gracia^ and to Pyerrs Lombardus / made Hystoriam
Scolasticam / and other books. Fredericus primus after Conradus was emperor in
Almayne and in Rome ^xxxiii. year. This man after the death of Adryan the pope
the which crowned him / did cursydly with Alexander to him great preiudyce
For he did help four that strove against the appostles sete. And he faught
myghtely ayenste the king of France. through power of the Danys and other
nacyons. But Richard ye king of England halpe for to expoulse him. And he
destroyed medyolanu^ to the ground / Of the which cytee / the walls were
higher than the walls of yny other cytee / This man at the last after that he
had done many vexacyons to the pope / he was recounsyled / for he dradde lest
the Lombardes would have rebelled ayenste him / he axed for yeuenes of the
pope. And took the cross upon him / and went unto the holy land / and did
many meruayllous things there / almoost as much as ever did Karolus magnus.
And there he came by a town that men call Armeniam and in a little water he
was drowned / and at Tyrum he was buried. Anastasius was pope after Eugenius
four year / and more. This man was abbot of Rufy / and then he was chose
Cardynall / and after pope.

Of king henry the second that was the Empress sone / in whose time saint
Thomas of Caunterbury was Chaunceller.
ANd after this king Stephen reigned Henry the Empress sone / and was crowned
of the Archebysshoppe Theobaldus the.xvii. day before Crystemas. And in the
same year Thomas Beket of london Archebysshop of caunterbury was made the
kings Chaunceller of England. The second year that he was crowned / he let
cast down all the new castles yt were longyngt to the Crown / the which
king Stephen had give unto diverse men / and them hade made earls and barons /
for to hold with him and to help him against Henry thempresse sone. And the
fourth year of his regne he put under his own lordshyp the king of walis. And
in the same year the king of Scotlond had in his own hand / yt is to say /
ye cite of Karleyll the castle of Bambrugh / and the new castle upon Tyne /
and the erledom of Lancastre. The same year the king with a great power went
in to walys / and let cast down woods and made ways and made strong the
castle of Rutlonde Basyngwark. And among ye castles he made an house of the
Temple. And in the same year was Richard his sone borne / that afterward was
earl of Oxforde And the fourth year of his regne / he made Gaufryde earl of
Brytayne. And in that year he changed his money. And the.vi. year of his
regne he ladde a great host to Tolouse and conquered it. And the.vii. year of
his regne deyed Theobaldus the Archebisshop of Caunterbury / and tho almoost all the cite of Canterbury through myschyef was bre^te. The.ix. year of his regne
Thomas beket that was his Chau^celler was chosen Archebysshop of Caunterbury^
And upon saint Bernardes day he was sacred. And in that year was borne the
kings daughter Eelenore. And in the.x. year of his regne saint Edward ye king
was translated with much honor. And the.xi. year of his rgne he held his
parlame^te at Northampton / and fro thens sledde saint Thomas Archebysshop of
Counterbury for the great debate that was betwixt the king and him. For if he
had be found on the morrow he had be slain / and therefore he fled thens
with three fellows on foot oonly / that no man wyste where he was \ and went
over the sea to the pope of Rome And this was the pryncypall cause. For asmoche
as the king would have put clerks to death that were ataynt of felonye /
without any preuelegye of holy church. And ye.xii. year of his regne was Johan
his sone borne. And the.xiii. year of his regne deyed Maude ye Empress that
was mother. The.xiiii. year of his regne the duke of Saxon spowsed Maude his
daughter. And he begat upon her three sons / that were called Henry. Othus.
and. Wyllyam And in the xv. year of his regne deyed the good Earl Robert of
Glocestre / that founded the abbaye of Nonne of Eton. And in the same year
Mark king of Jerusalem conquered Babylon And the.xvi. year of his regne / he
let crown his sone Henry at westmestre^ and him crowned Roger Archebysshop of
york / i^ harmyng of Tho^as archebysshop of Canterbury. wherefore this same
Roger was accusyd of ye pope.

How king Henry that was sone of king. Henry the Empress sone / and of the
debate that was between him and his fader while that he was in Normandye.
AFter the cornacyon of king Henry the sone of king Henry the Empress lone.
That same Henry thempresse sone went over to Normandy and there he let mary
Elenore his daughter of the Dolphyn yt was king of Almayne. And in the.vii.
yepe that the Archebysshop saint* Thomas had be^ our lawed / the king of
France made the king and saint Thomas accorded. And then^e came Thomas the
Archebysshop to Chaunterbury aye^ to his own church. and this accord was
made in the beginning of Aduente and afterward he was slain and martred the
fyfth day of Crystmasse then following. For king Henry though^ upon saint
Thomas the Archebysshop upon Crystmasse day as he sat at his mete and these
words said That if he had any good knights with him / he had be many a day
passe^ avenged upon the Archebysshop Thomas^ And anon sir Wyllyam Breto^ sir
Hugh Moruile / sir wyllyam Tracy and sir Reygn^l^de Fitz vrse / beers sone in
English pryuely went unto the sea / and came in to England unto the church
of Canterbury and there they hy^ martred at saint Benets awter in the mode^
church. And that was in ye year of the Incarnacyon of Ihesu Christ.M.C.lxxii.
year. And anon after Henry the new king began for to make war upon Henry
his fader and upon his brothern wyllyam and Othus. And so upon a day the king
of France and al ye kings sons / and the king of Scotlonde and all the
gretest lords of England were risen against king Henry the fader. And at the
last as god would / he conquered all his enmyes. And the king of France and
he were accorded^ And tho sent king Henry specially unto the king of France
/ and prayed him hertely for his love that he would send to him the names by
letters of them yt where ye begynners of ye war against him. And ye king of
france sent again to him by letters ye names of the^ that began that war
against him. The first was John^ his sone / and Richard his brother / and
Henry ye new king his sone. Tho was Henry ye king wonder wroth / and cursyd ye
time ye ever he him begat / and while ye war dured. Henry his sone ye new
king deyed sore repe^tyng his misdeeds and most sorrow made of any man for
because of saint Thomas death of Canterbury. and prayed his fader with much
sorrow of heart mercy for his trespaas. And his fader forgaaf him / and had of
him great pity. And after he deyed the.xxxvi. year of his regne / and lies at
Redynge.

How the christian men lost all the holy land in the foresaid kings time by a
falls Christian man that became a sarrasyne.
ANd while this king reigned / the great bataylle was in the holy land between
the christian men and the sarrasyns but Christian men were there slain through
great treason of ye earl Tyrpe / that would have had to wife the queen of
Iherusalem / that sometime was Baldewynes wife / but she forsook him and took to
her lord a knight a worthy man / that was called sir Gnyperches / wherefore the
earl Tyrpe was wroth / and went anon right to the Soudan that was Soudan of
Babylon / and became his man and forsook his crystendome / and all christian
law. And the cerysten men wist not of his deeds / but wend for to have had
great help of him as they were wont to have before. And when they came to the
bataylle / this false Cresten man turned unto the Sarrasyns / and forsook his
own nacyon. And so were the christian men there slain with the Sarrasyns. And
thus were the christian men slain and put to horrible death / and the cite of
Jerusalem destroyed / and the holy cross borne a way. The king of France
and all the great lords of the land let them be crossyd for to go in to the
holy londe^ And among them went Richard king Henryes sone / first after
the king of France / that took the cross of the. Archebysshop of Toures /
But he took not the vyage at that time for cause that he was let by other
manner ways / and needs to be done. And when king Henry his fader had
reigned.xxxvi. year and.v. months and four days / he deyed and lies at
Fonntenerad.

Anno dm^.M.C^lvi.
ADrianus the fourth was pope after Anastasius ^v. year. This pope was an
English man and the voys of ye common people says he was a bound man and to
the abbote of saint Albon in England. And when he desired to be made a monk
there he was expulsyd and he went over see and gave him to study and to
virtue. And after was made bishop of Albanacens / then he was made Legate in
to the land of wormacian / and he converted it to the faith. Then he was
made pope and for the woundynge of a Cardynall he enterdyted all the cytee of
Rome / And he cursyd wyllyam the king of Cecyle / and caused him to submytte
him. This man the first of all ye popes with his Cardynalles dwelled in the
old cite. Alexander the third was pope after him.xii. year. This Alexander
had strife ^xvii. year / and the four stryuers that the Emperor set against
him / he overcame them and cursyd them / and all deyed an evil death This man
also accorded Frederyke the Emperor and* Emanuell of Constantinoble / and the
king of seculoru^ And this man nourysshed saint Thomas of Caunterbury in his
exyle. Nota. Saint Bernarde was canonysed by this Alexander / and his abbot for
bode him he should do no miracles / for there was so mighty concours of people.
And he obeyed to him when he was deed and did no moo. Lutius the third was
pope after Alexander.iiii. year and two months. Of him little is written. In
his days decessyd Henry the first sone to Henry the second / and this is his
Epytaphy. Omnis honoris honor decor et decus vrbis et orbis. Milicie splendour
gloria lumen aper. Julius ingenio virtutibus hector. Achellis viribus. Augustus
moribus ore paris. Vrbanus the third was pope after Lucius two year / this man
decessyd for sorrow wha^ he herd tell that Jerusalem was taken with the
sarrasyns^ Gregorius the viii. was pope after him four months And he
practysed myghtely how Jerusalem might be won again / but anon he decessyd.

Clemens the third was pope after him three year / and lytyell he did.

Of king Richard yt conquered again all the holy land / yt the christian men had
lost.
ANd after this king Henry reigned Richard his sone a stowte man and a strong
and a worthy / and also bold. And he was crowned at westmestre of the
Archebysshop Baldewyn the third day of Septembre. And in the second year of
his regne / king Richard himself and Baldewyn the Archebysshop of Caunterbury
/ and Hubert bishop of Salysbury / and Radulf earl of Glocetre / and other
many lords of England / went in to the holy land / And in that vyage deyed
the Archebysshop of Caunterbury. And king Richard went before in to the
holy land and rested not till that he came forth in his way unto Cypres /
and took it with great force. And after that king Richard went forth to
ward the holy land / and gate there as much as the christian men had there
before lost. And conquered the land again thoruhh great might / saufe only the
holy cross. And when king Richard came to the cite of Acres for to get the
cytee / there arose a great debate between him and ye king of France / so yt
the king of France went again in to France and was wroth toward king Rychard
but yet for all yt / are king Richard went again / he took the cite of Acres.
and when he had take it / he dwelled in the cite a while. But to him came
tidings / that ye earl John^ of Oxenforde his brother would have seized all
England in to his hand / and Normandy also / and would let crown him king
of all the land. And when king Richard herd tell of these tydynge / he
went again toward England with all the speed that he might. But ye duke of
Ostryche met with him and took him and brought him unto the Emperor of
Almayne / And the Emperor him brought unto prison. And afterward he was
delivered for an Huge raunson / that is for to say / an hundred thousand
pound. And for the which raunson to be paid / each other chalyce of England
was molten and made in to money. And all the monks of the order of Cysteaux
yaue all their books through out all England / for to do them to selle /
and the raunson for to pay.

How king Richard came again from the holy land / and avenged him of his
enmyes.
SO as this king Richard was in prison / the king of France warred upon him
strongly in Norma^dye / and John^ his brother warred upon him in England. But
the bishops and the barons of England with stood him with all their power
that they might get / and took the castle of wyndesore and other castelles.
And the forsayde John^ saw yt he had no might ne power against the barons of
England for to fight But anon went him over the sea unto the king of
France. And when Richard came out of prison / and was delivered and came in
to England / anon after Candelmasse in great haste / he went unto Notyngham /
and the castle of Notyngham to him was yolden / and tho dyscomfyted he his
brother Johan and tho that with him held. And after he went unto the cite of
wynchestre / and there he let him crown king of England. And after he went
unto Normandy for to war upon the king of France And the king of France
came with.vi. hundred knyghtis to ward Gisors. And king Richard met him /
and tho would have yeuen him bataylle. But the king of France fled tho /
and hundred knights of his were taken and two hundred stedes that were trapped
with yren. And anon after went king Richard for to besyege the castle
Gaillarde ^ And as he rode upon a day by the castle for to take a uysemente
of the castle an arbarlaster somte him with a quarrel that was enuynymmed. And
the king drew out the shafte of the quarrel / but the quarrels heed abode still
in his heed. And it began for to rancle / that he ne might not help himself
/ ne meue his arms. And tho he wist that he had dethes wonde upon him / that
he might not be hoole for no manner of thing. He commanded ano^e sharply
all his men for to assoyle the castle. So that the castle was taken or he
deyed. And so manly his men did yt al ye people that were in the castle were
taken / and the king did with them what he would. And commanded his me^ that
they should bring before* him the man yt him so hurt and so wounded. And when
he came before ye king / the king axed him what was his name. And he said my
name is Bertham Gurdon wherefore said the king haste thou me slain / sith I
did the never none harm. Sir said he. Though ye did me never none harm / ye
your self with your own hand slew my fader and my brother. And therefore I have
quyte now your trauaylle. Tho said king Richard. He yt dyed upon ye cross /
to bring man's soul fro pain of hell / foryeue yt my death and I also
foryeue it the. Tho commanded he that no man should him mysdo. But for all ye
kings defending some of ye kings men him followed and pryuely him slew. And
the.vi. day after the king did shryue him / and sore repentance having of
his misdeeds / and was houseled and enoynted. Rud this king reigned but.ix. year
and.xxx. wekes / and deyed and lies beside his fader at Fontenerad.

HEnyicus ye fyfth was Emperor.viii. year This Henricus was sone to frederyk /
and he wedded Constaunce the kings daughter / of Cecyle / and though the
occasyon of her he subdued all the kingdom of Apulye / and he drove all the
people out ye enhabyte that land. Celestinus the third was pope after Clemens
almost three year. This man was crowned upon Eester day / and the day
following he crowned Henry the emperor. And he made a palace at saint Peter's /
and decessyd. Innocencius ye third was pope after him.viii. year and.v.
months. this man was well lettred and he made a book of the wretchydneste of
man's co^dico^n. and he made speculu^ miss and he mad many co^stytucyons.
This man dampened ye book of John^ Ioachim / yt which he made against master
Peyrs Lombarde / the maker of the Sentence. This time decessyd ye Emperor
Henry. And the princes of almayne discorded for some chose Otto / and some
chose Phylyppe brocher to Henry. Then Phylyppe was falsely slain / and Gtto
was crowned of Innocencius in France / yt which anon afught with the Romans
/ for they yaue him no dew honor. And for that cause / against ye popes will
he took the kingdom of Apulye from Frederyk / wherefore the pope cursyd him.
Then after the fourth year of his regne / the princes of Almayne made
Frederyk Emperor / and victoryously he subdued Otto. wyllyam of Paris this
time began the order of the freres Austyn / the which ben called (fratres
mendicantes) Franciscus an ytalyon a man of great perfeccyon and an ensample to
many a man / did many a miracle this time. And he ordained the friar Minors.
And the.vi. year of pope Innocencius the third / the order of the friar
prechers began under Domynyke / but it might not be confermed tylle the
first year Honorius.

Of king John^ / that in the first year of gis regne lost all Normandye.
AS king Richard was deed / by cause that he had none heir / another sone / ne
daughter / then^e his brother John^ was made king / and crowned at westmestre
of Hubert that tho was Archebysshop of Caunterbury. And when he began for to
regne / he became so meruaylous a man / and went over in to Normandye / and
warred upon the king of France. And so long they warred together / till at
the last king Johan lost all Normandy and Angoy / wherefore he was sore
anoyed / and it was no meruaylle. Tho let he assemble before him at London
Archebysshops / bishops / abbots / and pryours / Earls and Barons and held
there a great parlyament and axed there of the Clergy / the tenthe of every
church of England / for to conquer and get again Normandy and Angoy yt had
lost. They would not grant that thing / wherefore he was wonder wroth. And in
that same time deyed Hubert. The pryour and ye covent of Canterbury chose
against the kings will to be Archebysshop Stephen of Langton a good clerk /
that dwelled at the court of Rome / and sent to the pope their cleryon / and
the pope confermed it / and sacred him at Viterbi^ When the king wist these
tidings / he was wonder wroth / and drove ye pryour and the couente fro
Counterbury / and exyled out of England / and commanded that no letter that
come fro Rome / ne commandment / should be received ne pleryd in England.
When these tidings came to the pope / he sent king Johan his letter / and
prayed him with good will and good heart / that he would receive Stephen ye
Archebysshop of Caunterbury to his church / and suffer ye pryour and his
monks to come again to their own dwelling. But the king would not grant it
for no thing.

How king John^ would no thing do for the popes commandment. wherefore all
England was enterdyted and suspended.
ANd at the last the pope sent by his auctoryte / and enjoined to the bishops
of England / that if the king would not receive the pryour of Caunterbury and
his monks / that they should do general enterditinge through out all England.
And granted full power to four bishops to pronounce the enterdytynge / if he
it warned^ The first was bishop wyllyam of London / and that other bishop
Eustace of Ely / and the third was bishop Walter of wynchestre / and the
fourth was bishop Gyles of Hertforde. And these four bishops prayed the
king / knelynge on their knees / and sore werynge / that he would do ye popes
commandment. And showed him ye popes Bulls of the entertydynge / but for no
prayer that they might pray he would not consent thereto. And when ye bishops
saw this / they went fro the king. And in the morn after the Annunciacion of
our lady / they pronounced ye general enterdytynge thrughout all England so
that the church doors were shytte with keys and with other fastings and with
walls. And when the enterdytynge was pronounced / then the king began for
to wexe all out of mesure / and anon took in to his hand al ye possessions of
ye four bishops / and of all the clergy through out of all England / the
lord he took / and ordained men for to keep it / that the clerks might not
have their living. wherefore ye bishops cursyd all them / that put / or should
meddle with holy church goods / against the will of them that ought them. And
when the king would not of his malice cesse for no manner thing. These four
bishops before said went over the sea / and came to the bishop of Caunterbury
/ and told him all thing. And ye Archebysshop to them said / that they should
go again to Caunterbury / and he should come thither to them / or else he would
send unto them certain persons in his stead / that should do as much as of
he himself were there. And when the bishops herd this they turned again in
to England / and came unto Caunterbury. The tidings came to the king / that
the bishops were come again to Caunterbury / and himself might not come
thither that time he sent thither bishops Earls / and abbotes / for to create
with them / that the king should receive tharchebysshop Stephen / and the
pryour and all the monks of Caunterbury / that he should never after that time
no thing take of holy church against the will of them that owes ye goods.
And that the king should make full amends to them / of whom he had any goods
taken. And that holy church should have all fraunchyse / as ferforth as they
had in saint Edwardes time the holy Confessor.

How Stphen of Langton came again* in to England through the popes commandment
/ and how he went again.
SO when the form of accordemente thus was ordained. It was in a payer of
endentures / and their seals to that one par^e and they yt came in the kings
name put their seals to that other part of ye endentures. And four bishops
above said took that one part of the endentures to them. And that other part
of the endentures \ they bare with them to show to the king. When the king
saw the form and understood / he held him full well apayed of all manner
things as they had ordened / saving as touching / restytucyon of the goods
for to make again. To that thing would not accord / and so he sent word again
to the four bishops / that they should do out and put away that one point of
resty^ucyon. But they answered / that they would not do one word out. Tho
sent the king to the Archebysshop by the four bishops yt he should come to
Caunterbury for to speak with him there / and sent unto him saufcondyte under
pledges. that is to say / his Justices Gylbert Peyteum. Wyllyam de la Brener ^
and Johan fitz Hugh / that in their conduyte / sauely he should come and go
again at his own will And thus in this manner tharchebysshop Stephen came to
Caunterbury. when the Archebysshop was come / the king came to Chill^^ For he
would no nyghe Caynterbury at that time. But he sent by his Tresorer bishop
of wyncester yt he should do out of the endentures the clause of restytucyon /
for to make of ye goods And tharchebysshop made his oath that he would never
do out oo word thereof ne yet ^^ change of yt the bishops had spoken and
ordained. And tho the Archebyssop yede again to Rome without any more doing.
King Johan was wrother tha^ ever he was before and let make a common cry
through out all England / that all tho yt had holy church rentes / and went
over the sea / yt they should come again in to England at a certain day / or
else they should lose their rentes for ever more. And yt he commanded to every
Shyref through out all England / that they should inquire if any bishop abbot
or pryour / or any other Prelate of holy church / fro ye day afterward /
receive any commandment that comes fro the pope. That they should take the
body / and bring it before him / and that they should take in to the kings
hondes all their lands of holy church / that were give to any man / by the
Archebychop or by the pryour of Canterbury / from the time of eleccion of the
Archebysshop. And commanded that all the woods that were the Archebysshops
should be cast down unto the ground / and all sold.

How king John^ destroyed the order of Cesteaux.
ANd in the same year / the Irysshe men began to war upon king John / and
the king ordained him for to go in to Irlonde / and let arere an huge tax
thrughout al England / that is for to say.xxx. thousand mark. And thus he
sent through out all England unto monks of the order of Cisteaux that they
should help him of ^vi. thousand mark of silver. And they answered and said /
that they durst no thing do without their chyef abbot if Cisteaux. wherefore
king Johan when he came again from Irlonde / did them so much sorrow and care
/ that they wist not wheder to a bide / for he took so much raunson of every
house / and the sum amou^ted to.ix. thousand and.iiii. hundred mark / so
that they were clean lost and destroyed / and voyded cheyr houses and their
lands thrughout all England. And the abbot of wauersaye draded so much his
menace / that he forsook all the abbaye and went thens and pryuely ordained him
over the sea to ye house of Cisteaux. when the tidings came to the pope / that
the king has done so much malice / then he was to ward the king full wroth
And sent to Legates unto the king / that one was called Pandulf / and ye other
Duraunt / that they should warn the king in the popes name / that he should
cesse of his persecucion yt he did unto holy church / and amend the wrong
and the trespass / yt he had done to the Archebysshop of Caunterbury / and to
the pryour and unto the monks of Caunterbury / and to all the clergy of
England. And that he should rest ore all the goods again yt he had taken of
them against their will and else they should curse him by name / And to do this
thing / and to conferme the pope took them his letters in bulls patentes.
These two Legates came in to england / and came to the king to Northamton /
there yt he held his parlyamente / and full curteysly they him salewed and
said. Sir we come fro ye pope of Rome / the peace of the holy church and the
land to amend. And we admonest you first in the popes half / that ye make
full restytucyon of the goods yt ye have rauysshed and taken of holy church
and of the land. And that y^ receive Stephen Archebysshop of Caunterbury in to
his dygnytee / and the pryour of Caunterbury / and his monks. And that ye
yield again unto the Archebysshop all his lands and rentes / without any
withholdynge. And sir yet more over / yt ye shall make restytucyon / unto all
holy church / whereof they shall hold them well apayed. Tho answered the king
as touching the pryour and his monks of Caunterbury. All that ye have said I
will do gladly / and all thing yt ye will ordeyne. But as touching the
Archebysshop. I shall tell you in my heart as it lies. That the Archebysshop
leave his archebysshoppryche / and that ye pope then^e for him would pray / and
then^e upon adventure / me should like some other bysshopryche to give him in
England And upon this condicyon I will him accept and receive And nevertheless
as Archebysshop in England if he abide / he shall never have so goods
saufconduyte / but that he shall be take. Tho said Pandulf unto the king /
Sire holy church was wont never to dyscharge an Archebysshop without cause
reasonable. But ever it has be wont to chastyse princes / yt to god and holy
church were In obedyence. What how now said the king menace ye me. Nay said
Pandulf / But ye now openly have told / as it stands in your heart. And to
you we will tell what is the popes will. And thus it stands / yt he has you
holy enterdyted and accursyd / for the wrongs that ye have done to holy
church and to the clergy. And for as much as ye dwell / and beth in will to
abide in malice and in wretchedness / and will not come out thereof / ne to
amend ye shall understand / yt this time after ward the sentence is upon you
yeuen and holds stead and strength / and upon all tho that with you has
comuned before this time / whether they ben earls / barons / or knights / or
any other what so ever yt they be we them assoylle / saufly unto this day^ and
fro this time after ward of what condycyon someuer yt they ben we them accurse
/ yt with you comyne any word / and do wene sentence upon them openly and
specially And we assoyle clean / earls / barrns / knights / and all other me^
of their homages / seruyces and feautres / that they should unto you do / And
this tydynge to conferme / we give plain power / to the bishop of wynchestre
/ and the bishop of Norwhiche. And the same power we give in to Scotlo^de to
the bishop of Rochestre and of Salysbury. And in walys we give the same power
to the bishop of saint Dauyd and of Landaf and of saint Ass. And more over we
sent through out all Crystendom / that all the bishops beyond the sea / that
they do accurse all tho that help you / or any counseyl yeueth you in any
manner need that ye have to do in any part of the world. And we assoyle them
also all / by auctoryte of ye pope / and commau^de them also with you for to
fight / as with him that is enmye to all holy church. Tho answered ye king.
what may ye do more to me Tho answered Pandulf. we say to you in the word of
god / that ye ne no heyr that ye have / never after this day may be crowned.
Tho said ye kyne. By him that is almighty god / and I had wist this are that ye
came in to my land / that ye had brought me such tidings. I should have made
you ready all one year. Tho answered Pandulf / Full well wend we at our first
coming / that ye would have be obedyent to god and holy church / and have
fulfilled the popes commandment / and now we have showed unto you / and
pronounced the popes will / as we were charged therewith / And as now ye have
said / that if ye had wist the cause of our coming / that ye would have do us
to ride all an hole year. And as well ye might have said / that ye would have
taken an hoole year of respyte / by the popes leave. But for to suffer what death
ye could ordeyne / we shall not spare for to tell you holy all the popes
message and his will / that we were charged with.

How Pandulf delivered a clerk that had falsyd and counterfetyd the kings
money before the king himself.
ANd anon tho commanded the king the Syrefs and Baylyfs of Northampton /
that were in the kings presence / yt they should bring forth all ye prisoners
/ that they might be done to death before Pandulf / for by cause the king wened
that they would have gaynsayd their deeds / for cause of the death all thing
that they had spoken before When the prisoners were come before the king the
king commanded some to be hanged / and some to be drawn and some to draw
out their eyes out of their heed. And among all other / there was a clerk
that had falsyd ye kings money. And the king commanded that he shoyde be
hanged and drawed^ And when Pandulf herd this commandment of the king / he
sterte him up right quyckly / and anon axed a book and a candell / and would
have cursyd the king / and all them that would set upon ye clerk any
hand. And Pandulf him self went for to seek a cross. And the king followed
him / and delivered him the clerk by the ho^de that he should do with him
what he would. And thus was the clerk delivered and went thens. And Pandulf
and Duraunt his fellow went fro the king / and came again to the pope of Rome.
And told him that king Johan would not amended be. But ever abode so acrcusyd
And nevertheless the pope granted that year thorughout all England that
priests might sing mass in couenable chyrches / and consecrate our lords
body ^ and give it to syke men which were lykely to pass out of this world.
And also that men might christian chyldern over all the land. And when the pope
wist and saw that the king would not be under the rule of holy church for
no manner thing. The pope then^e sent to the king of France in remysseon of
his sins / that he should take with him all the power that he might / and go
in to England for to destroy the king Johan When these tydyges came to king
Johan / then was he sore anoyed and sore dradde lest he should lose his reame
and him self be done to the death. Then sent he to the pope messengers and
said. He would be Justified / and come to amendment in all things / and
would make satysfaccyon to all manner of men after the popes ordinance. Then^e
sent the pope again in to England Pandulf and other messenger / and came to
Caunterbury to the king and there abode^ And the.viii. day of May / the king
made another for to stand to the popes ordinance / before Pandulf ye Legate
in all manner of things in which he was accursyd. And that he should make full
restytucyon to all me^ of holy church and of relygyon / and of the goods that
he had taken of them against their will And all the great lords of England
swore upon the book and by their holydom / that if ye king would not hold his
oath / they said ye they would by strength make him hold it. Then put the
kymge him to the court of Rome / and then gaaf he up the reame of England
and of Irlonde for him and for his heyers for ever more that should come after
him / so that king Johan and his heyers should take the two reames of the
popes hondes And should every year pay ferme unto the court of Rome a
thousand mark of silver. And tho took ye king ye crown of his heed and sete
it upon his knees And these words said he in herynge of all ye great lords of
England. Here Iresygne up the crown and the reame of England in to the pope
Innocencius hondes the third / and put me holy in his mercy and in his
ordinance. Tho received Pandulf the crown of king John^ and kept it ^yue
days as fore ceasing / taking of two realms / of England and of Irlonde.
And co^fermed all manner things by his Chartre that follows afer.

Of the letetr oblygatorye ye king John^ made to the court of Rome / wherefore
the Peter's pens ben gadred thrughout al England.
TO all christian people throghout all the world dwelling. Johan by the grace
of god king of England gretynge to your university. And be it known that for
as much as we have grieved and offended god and our mother holy church of Rome.
And for asmoche as we have need unto the mercy of our lord Ihesu christ. And
also we may no thing so worthy of^re / as competent satysfaccyon to make to
god and to holy chirch / but if that yt were owr own body / as with our reames
of England and of Irlonde. Then^e by the grace of god we desire to meke us /
for the love of him that meked him to the death of the cross Thorugh counsel
of these noble earls and barons / we offer all freely / grant to god and to
the appostle saint Peter and saint poule / and to our mother church of Rome /
and to our holy fader pope Innocencius the third / and to all the pooes that
comes after him all the reame and patronages of chirches of England and of
Irlonde / with their appertenaunces / for remyssyon of our sins / and for
help and health of our kynne souls / and of all christian soul is So that from
this day after ward we will receive / and hold of our mother church of Rome
/ as fee ferme / doing feaute to our holy fader pope Innocencius the third /
and so to all the popes that comes after him / in the same manner above said.
And in presence of the wise man Pandulf ye popes Subdeaken / we make lyeges
homage / as it were in the popes presence / and before gym were. And shall do
all manner things above said / And thereto we bind us / and all that comes
after us / and our heirs for ever more / without any again saying to the pope
/ and eke the ward of church vacauntz. And in token for this thing for ever
to last / we will conferme and ordeyne / that our special rentes of the
foresaid r^ame / saving saint Peter's pens in all thing to the mother church of
Rome paye^ge by year a thousand mark of silver and two terms of ye year for
all manner customs that we should do for the foresaid reames / that is to say
to Myghelmas / and at Eester. That is to say.vii. hundred mark for England
/ and three hundred mark for Irlond Saving to us and to our heirs our
Justices / and other fraunchyse / and other ryaltees / that perteyne unto the
crown And these things and before ben said we will / that it be ferme and
stable without end. And to that oblygacyon / we and our successors and our
heirs in this manner be bound / that if we / or any of oyr heirs / thorugh
any presumpcyon fall / in any point against any of these things above said /
and he be warned / and will not right amend / he shall then lose the foresaid
reame for evermore. And that is chartre of oblygacyon and our warraunt for ever
more / be ferme and stable without any gaynsayenge. we shall front this day
afterward be true unto god and to the mother of holy church of Rome \ and to
the pope Innocencius the third / and to all that comes after hym^ And the
realm of England and of Irlonde / we shall maynten truly in all manner
points against all manner men by our power through goods help.

How the clerks that were outlawed came again and how king Johan was
assoylled.
SO when this chartre was made and ensealed / the king received again his
crown of Pandulfus hand And sete anon unto the Archebysshop Stephen / and to
all his other clerks and lewede men / that he had exyled out of this land /
that they should come again in to England / and have again their lands and
allo their rentes. And that he would make restytucyon of the goods that he had
taken of theyrs against their will. The king himself tho and Pandulf and earls
and barons went unto wynchestre against the Archebysshop Stephen. And when he
was come the king went against him and fell adowne to his feet / and thus to
him said. Fair sire ye be welcome. And I cry you mercy by cause that I have
trespassed against you. The Archebysshop took him up tho in his arms / and
kyssyd him curteysly oftentimes / and after led him to ye door of saint
Swythunes church by the hand / and assoylled him of the sentence / and him
reconsyled to god and to holy thyrche. And that was on saint Margaretes day.
And the Archepysshop anon went for to sing mass. And the king offered at the
mass a mark of gold. And when the mass was done / all they went for to
receive their lands / without any manner gaynsayenge. And that day they made
all mirth and Joy enough. But yet was not the enterdytynge releaced / by cause
the pope had set that the enterdytynge should not be done / till the king
had made full restytucyon of the goods that he had taken of the holy church.
And that him self should do homage to the pope by a certain Legate / that he
should send in to England. And then took Pandulf his leave of the king and
the Archebysshop / and went again unto Rome. And the Archebysshop anon let
come before him prelates of holy church at Redynge / for to treat and
counseyll how much / and what they should axe of the king / for to make
restytucyon of the goods that he had taken of them. And they ordained and
said that the king should give to the Archebysshop three thousand mark for the
wrong that the king had done unto him. And also by procyons to other
clerks.xv. thousand mark. And the same time Nycolaus bishop of Tuscam
Cardynall Penytenciarius of Rome came in to England through the popes
conmaundement / the fyfth kalendas of Octobre and came to London / the fyfth
Nonas of Octobre / for by cause that king Johan and all the kings that came
after him / should ever more hold the reame of England and of Irlonde / of
god and of the pope / payenge to the pope by year as it is above said.

How the enterdytynge was undone in England / and of the debate that was
between king Johan and the barons of the reame.
AS king Johan had done his homage to the Legate that showed him the popes
letter / that he should pay to Iulyan and yelne again that was king Rychardes
wife the third part of the land of England and of Irlonde that he had
withholde sith that king Richard deyed. When king John^ herd this / he was
wonder wroth. For utterly yt enterdytynge might not be undone till yt he had
made gre^ and restytycyon to the foresaid Iulyan / of that she asked. The Legate
went then again to the pope after Crystmasse. And ye king sent over see to
Iulyan that was king Rychardes wife for to have a relate of that she axed of
him. And so it befell that Iulyan deyed anon after Eester. And in so much the
king was quyte of that thing that the axed. But then at the feast of saint
Johan that came next after / thorugh the popes commandment / the
enterdytynge was first releasyd thrughout all England (...) day of Iulii.
And.vii. year was the land ^terdyted. And on the morning m^n rough and said
mass thorugh out all London and so ^^ter thorugh out all Englonde^ And the
ne^^ year after there began a great debate between king Johan and the lords
of England ^or by cause that he would not grant the law^^ and hold / the
which saint Edward had ordeyn^d / and had been used and holden unto that time
that he had them broken. For he would hold no law / but did all thing that
him lyked / and dysheryted many men without consent of lords and perys of ye
land. And wo^ dysheryte the good earl Radulf of Chestre for by cause that he
undertook him of his wickedness / and for by cause that he did so much shame
and vylany to god and to holy church* And also for he held and haunted his
own brothers wife / and lay also by many wymmen great lords daughters. For
he spared no woman that him lyked for to have. wherefore all the lords of the
land were wroth / and took the cite of London. To cesse this debate the
Archebysshop and lords of the land assenbled before the feast of saint John^
Bap^yst in a medowe beside the town of Stanys / that is called Romney mede.
And the king made them there a chartre of fraunchyse / such as they would axe
/ and in such manner they we^e accorded / and that accordement lasted not full
long. For the king himself soon after dyed against the points of the same
chartre that he had made. wherefore the most part of the lords of the land
assembled and began to war upon him again / and brenned his towns / and
robbed his folk / and did all the sorrow that they might / and made them as
strong as they might with all the power they had / and thought to drive him
out of England / and make Lowys the kings sone of France king of England.
And king John^ sent tho over see and ordained so much people of Normans / and
of Pycardes / and of Flemynges / so that the land might not sustain them /
but with much sorrow. And among all this people ^ there was a man of
Normandye that was called Fawkis of Brent / and this Norma^ and his company
spared another chirches ne houses of relygyon / but they burnt and ^obbed it /
and bare a way a^l that they might take so that the land was all destroyed /
what one side and other. The barons and lords of Englonge ordained among
them the best spekers and wysest men / and sent them over the sea to king
Phylyp of France / and prayed him / that he would send Lowys his sone in to
England to be king of England / and to receive the crown.

How Lowys the knges sone of France came in to England with a strong power
of people ^ to be king of Englonde^
Anon as king Phylyp of France herd these tidings / he made certain
alyaunce between them by their comune eleccyon / that Lowys king Phylyps sone
of France should go with them in to England / and drive out king Johan of
the land. And all that were in presence of Lowes / made unto him homage / and
became his men. And the Barons of England held them still at London / and
abode Lowys the kings sone of France. And this was the next Saterdaye before
the Ascensyon of our lord / that Lowys came into England with a strong
power. And that time king John^ had taken all the castles of England in to
Alyens hondes / And tho came Lowwys / and besyeged Rochestre castle / and
took yt with strength. And the thursdaye in wytson weke let hang all the
Alyens that were therein / And ye Thursdaye next se wynge / he came to London /
and there he was received with much honur of the lords that abode him there /
and all to him made homage. And after ward on the Tewysdaye next after the.
Trynyte sunday he took the castle of Reigate. And on the morrow after the
castle of Gilforde / and the Frydaye next after the castle of Farneham. And
the Mondaye next after the cite of wynchestre to him was yolde / and the
morrow after Saint Iohans day the manner of wu^ueseye to him yelden* And the
Tewysdaye after the Vtas of saint Peter and Poule they took the castle of
Odyham. And the mondaye after saint / Margaretes day / he ordained him to ward
Bawmore / for to syege the castle / and there he dwelled.xv. days and might
not get the castle / and then went he thens and came to London and the
Toure to him was yolden.

How ye pope se^te in to England a legate yt was called Swalo and of ye death
of king Johan.
ANd in the same time the pope sent in to England a Legate / that was called
Swalo / and he was priest Cardynall of Rome / for to mayntene king Iohans
cause / against the barons of England. But the barons had so huge part and
help / thorugh lowys the kings sone of France / that king John^ wist not to
^orne ne go. And so it befell that he would have gone to Nycholl^ And as he
went thither ward / he came by the abbaye of Swynes head / and there he abode
two days And as he sat at mete / he axed a monk of ye house how much that a
loof was wroth that was set before him upon the table / And the monk said
that the loof was wroth but an half penny. O said the king tho. Here is great
chepe of bread. Now said he tho / and I may leave any while such a loof shall
be wroth.xx. shelynges or half a year be gone. And so when he said this word
/ much he thought / and often he syghed / and took and ete of the bread / and
said by god / ye word that I have spoken / it shall be sothe^ The monk that
stood before the king was for this word full sorry in his heart / and thought
rather he would him self suffer death / and thought if he might ordeyne therefore
some manner remedy. And anon the monk went unto his abbot and was shryuen of
him / and told the abbot all that the king had said. And prayed his abbot for
to assoyle him / for he would give the king such a drink that all England
should be glad thereof and Joyful Tho yede the monk in to a gardeine / and
found a great tode therein / and took her up and put her in a cup and prycked
the tode thorugh with a broche many times till that the venym came out of every
side in the cup And tho took the cup and fyllyed it with good ale / and
brought it before the king knelynge saying. Sir said he wassayll / for ever
the days of all your life drunk ye of so good a cup. Begyne monk said the
king. And the monk drank a great draught / and took the king the cup /
and ye king drank also a great draught / and set down the cup. The
monk anon right went in to farmere and there deyed anon / on whoos soul god
have mercy Amen. And five monks sing for his soul specially / and shall
while that the abbaye stands. The king rose up anon full evil at ease and
commanded to remeue the table / and axed after the monk. And men told him
that he was deed / for his womb was broken in sondre. When ye king herd this
/ he commanded for to trusse / but it was for naught / for is belly began to
swelle for the drink yt he had dronke / and within two days he deyed on ye
morrow after saint Lukys day / and had many fair chyldern of his body begaten
/ that is to say. Henry his sone yt was king after Johan his fader / and
Richard that was Earl of Cornewaylle / and ysabell that was Empress of Rome /
and Elenore that was queen of Scotlonde. And this king Johan when he had
reigned.xiiii. year and five months and five days / he deyed in the castle
of ne work. And his body was buried at wynchestre.

Anno dm^.M.CC.
FRedericus the second was Emperor xxx. year / This man was crowned of
Honorius the pope against Otto for by cause that he should fight with him / the
which he did / and expulsyd him. And first he nourysshed the church / and
afterward he dyspoyled it / as a stepmoder^ wherefore Honorius cursyd him / and
all tho that were contrary to his opinion the pope assoyled. And the same
sentence Gregorius the.ix. renewed And this same man put Henry his own sone in
to prison / and there murdered him. wherefore when this Emprerour an other season
was like / by an other sone of his own he was murdered / in the time of
Innocentius the fourth. Honorius the third was pope after Innocencius.x. year
/ and confermed the order of friar Prechers and Mynors^ And made certain
Decretalles.

Of king Henry the third that was crowned at Gloucetree
ANd after this king Johan reigned his sone Henry / and was crowned at
Gloucette when he was.ix. year old / on saint Symondes day and Iyde of Swalo
the Legate of Rome through counseyll of all the great lords that held with
king Johan his fader that is to say / the earl Radulf of Chestre. wyllyam
earl Marshall earl of Penbroke. Wyllyam ye Brener earl of Feries. Serle ye
manly baron. And all other great lords of England held with Lowys the kings
sone of France. And anon after when king Henry was crowned Swalo the Legate
held his counseyll at Brystowe at saint Martyns feast. And there were xi.
byssops of England and of walys / and of other prelates of holy church a
great nombre / and earls and barons / and many knights of England. And all
tho that were at that counseyll swore feawte unto Henry the king that was king
Iohn^s sone. And anon after the Legate enterdyted walys / for cause that they
held with the barons of England. Also all tho that help / or yaue any
