counseyll to meue war against the new king Henry he accursyd them. And at
the beginning he put in the sentence the kings sone of France Lowys. And
nevertheless the same Lowys would not spare for all that. But went and took the
caastell of Barchamstede / and aleso ye castle of Hirtfo^ And from that day
afterward / the Barons did there so much harm thrughout all England. And
pryncypally ye frensshemen that were with king Lowys. wherefore the great
lords / and all the common people of England let them dress / for to drive
Lowys and his company out of England / but some of the barons and Frensshemen
were gone to the cite of Nycholl / and took the town and held it to king
Lowys profit. But thither came king Henryes men with a great power / that is
to say the earl Radulf of Chestre / and Wyllyam earl Marshall / and Wyllyam
the Brenererle of Feryers and many other lords with them / and yaue battle
unto Lowys men. And there was slain the earl of perchees and Lowys men were
foul dyscomfyted. And there was taken Serle earl of wynchestre / and
Humfroyde. Boune earl of Hertforde / and Robert the sone of walter / and many
other that began war against the king / there they were taken and ladde unto
king Henry / that was king Iohn^s sone. And when the tidings came to Lowys of
the dyscomfyture / yt was the kings sone of France. He remeued fro thens and
went unto London / and let shytte the yates fast of the cite. And anon
after the king sent to the Burgeys of London / that they should yield them
unto him / and the cite also. And he would them grant all their fraunchyses
that ever they were wont to have before. And would conferme them by his great
new chartre under his broad scale.

And in the same time a great lord that was called Eustace the monk came out
of France with a great company of Lords / and would have come in to England
/ for to have helped Lowys the kings sone of France. But Hubert of Brugh /
and ye five por^es with.viii. ships tho met with them in ye high see ^ and
assaylled them egerly / and over came them with strength / and smote of Eustace
the monks heed. And took also.x. great lords of France and put them in to
prison. And slew almoost all the men that came with them / and anon drowned
the ships in the sea.

How Lowys corned again in to France / and of ye confermacyon of king Iohans
hartre.
SO when Lowys herd these rydynges he dradde sore to be deed and lost. And
let or^^yne / and speak between the king and Lowys by the Legate Swalo And
through the Archebysshop of Caunterbury / and through other great lords that
all the prisoners on that one half and that other should be delyuerd and go
quyte. And Lowys him self should have for his costs a thousand pound of
silver. and should go out of England / and come neure more there in again. And
in this manner was ye accord made between king Henry and Lowys. And tho was
Lowys assoylled of the popes Legate / ye was called Swalo of the sentence that
he was in / and the Barons of England also. And after this king Henry and
Swalo the Legate and Lowys went to Merton and there was the peace co^fermed /
and between them ordained. And after Lowys went from thens unto London and
took his leave and was brought with much honor unto the sea with the
Archebysshop of Caunterbury and with other bishops / and also with earls and
barons / and so went in to France. And after ward the king and the
Archebysshop / and also earls and barons assembled them and came to the cite of
London at Myghelmas that next came tho sewynge and held there a great
parliament at London / And there were tho reuewed all the frau^chyse ye king
John^ had granted / at Romney mede \ and king Henry tho confermed by his
chartre / the which yet ben holden through out all England. And in that time
the king took of every plough lord.ii. shleynges / and Hubert of Brugh was
made tho cheyf Justice of England And this was in the fourth year of king
Henryes regne And in the same year was saint Thomas of Caunterbury translated
the.l. year after his martyrdom. And after it was ordained by all the lords
of England / that all Alyens sold go out of England / and come no more
therein. And king Henry took tho all the castelles in to his hand / ye king
Johan his fader had give and take to Alyens for to keep yt held with him. But
the proud Fawkys of Brytayn rychely let array his castle of Bedforde /
which he had of king Iohn^s yefte / and held that castle against king
Henryes will with might and strength. And the king came thither with a strong
power / and besyeged the castle. And the Archebysshop master Stephen of
Langton / with a fair company of knights came to the king him for to help.
And from the Ascensyon of our lord unto the Assumpcyon of our lady lasted the
syege. And tho was the castle won and take. And the kynhe let hang all tho
that went in to the castle with their good will. for to hold the castle.
That is for to say.lxxx. men. And tho after ward fawkys himself was found
and had in a church at Couentre / and there he forswore all England with
much shame / and went again in to his own country. And whiles that king
Henry reigned. Edmonde of Abyndon / that was ^relorer of Salysbury was
consecrated Archebysshop of Caunterbury. And this king Henry sent over the sea unto the earl of prouynce / that he should lend him his daughter in
England / that was called Ellenore / and he would spowse her. And tho she came
in to England after Crystmas. And on the morrow after saint Hylaryes day / ye
Archebysshop Edmonde spowsed them together at westmestre with great solempnyte.
And there was a sweet sight between them. That is to say Edward that was
next king after his fader / flower of curteysy and of largeness and
Margarete that was after quen of Scotlonde / and Beautrice that was after
countess of Brytayne / Katheryne that deyed maid in relygyon.

Of the quinzeme of goods that were granted for ye new chartre / and of the
purueaunce of Oxforde.
ANd thus it befell that ye lords of England would have some addycyous moo in
the chartre of Fraunchyse that they had of the king / and spoke thus between
them. And ye king granted them all their axenge. And made to them two
chartres / that one is called the great chartre of fraunchises / and that other
is callad the chartre of forest. And for the grant of these two chartres /
prelates / Earls and Barons / and all the comyns of England / yaue to the
king a thousand mark of silver. When king Henry had be king.xliii. year the
same year he and his lords / Earls and Barons of the reame went to Oxforde /
and ordained a law in amendment of the reame. And first swore the king
himself / and afterward all the lords of the land / that they would hold
that statute for evermore / and who that them brake should be deed. But the
second year after that ye ordinance / the king through counseyll of Edward
his sone / and of Richard his brother / that was earl of Cornwaylle / and also
of other repented him of that oath that he made for to hold that law and
ordynau^ce^ And sent to ye courtre of Rome to be assoylled of that oath. And
in the year next coming after / was the great darth of corn in England For a
quarter of whete was worth.xxiiii. shelynges. And the poor people ete netles
and other wedes for hu^gre. And deyed many a thousand for defawte of mete. And
in ye.xlviii. year of king Henryes regne began war and debate between him
and his lords / for by cause he had broken the couenauntes that were made
between them at Oxforde. And ye same year was the town of Northamton taken /
and folk slain that were within / For by cause that they had ordained wild
fire for to brenne the cite of London. And in the monethe of May that the next
after / upon saint Pancras day / was the Battle of jews / that is to say /
the wenesday before Saint Du^stans day. And there was taken king Henry him
self / and sir Edward his sone / and Richard his brother earl of Cornewaylle /
and many other lords. And in the same year nextse wynge sir Edward the kings
sone brake out of the ward of sire Symonde of Mountforth / earl of Leycetre at
Hertforde / and went unto the barons of the March / and they rceeyued him
with much honor. And the same time Gylbert of Claraunce earl of Glocetre that
was in the ward also of the foresaid Simon de thorugh the commandment of
king Henry / that went fro him with great heart / for cause that he said /
that ye foresaid Gylbert was a fool / and held him with king Henry And on the
Saterdaye next after the mids of August / sire Edward the kings sone
dyscomfyted sir Symonde de Mountforth ac Kelyngworth / but the great lords
that were there with him were taken / that is to say. Baldewyne wake. And
Wyllyam de Mouchentye and many other great lords. And the Tewysdaye next after
was ye battle done at Eusba^. And there was slain sir Symonde de Mou^tforth.
Hugh the Spenser / and Mountforth that was Raufe Bassectes fader of Drayton and
other many great lords / And when this battle was done / all the gentylmen
that had been with the earl Symonde were dyshery^ed / and ordained together and
did much harm to all the land. For they destroyed their enmyes in all that
they might.

Of the syege of Kenylworth and how ye ge^tylmen were dysheryted thorugh
counseyll of the lords of the reame of England and how they came again and
had their lands.
ANd the next year coming in May / the fourth day before the feast of saint
Dunstane / was the bataylle and scomfyture are Chestrefelde / of them that were
dysheryted / and there was many of them slayne^ And Robert Earl of Feriers
there was take / and also Baldewyne wake / and Johan delahay / with much
sorrow escaped thens. And oon saint Iohan^ the Baptyst tho sewynge / began the
syege of the castle Kenylworth / and the syege lasted to saint Thomas eve the
appostle. in which day sir Hugh Hastynge had the castle for to keep / yt
yielded up the castle unto the king in this manner / that himself and the
other yt were within the castle / should have their lives and lymme / and as
much thing as they had therein both horse and harneys / and four days of
repyte / for to deliver clenly the castle / of them self and of all other manner
thing / as they had within ye castle / and so they went fro the castle.
And sir Symonde Nou^tforth the younger / and the countess his mo^ were gone
over ye see in to France / and there held them as people yt were exyled out
of England for ever. And soon after it was ordained by the Legate Octobone /
and by other great lords / the wysest of England that all tho that had be
ayenste the king and were dysheryted / should have again their lands by
grievous rau^sons / after that it was ordained. And thus they were accorded with
the king and peace cried thorughout all England and thus the war was ended.
And when yt was done the Legate took his leave of the king and of the queen /
of ye great lords of England and went tho to Rome the.lv. year of king
Henryes regne ^ and Edward king Iohn^s sone of Brytayne Johan Vessi. Thomas
of Clare. Rogere of Clyfforde. Oaths of Grau^stone Robert le Brus. John^ of
Verdon / and many other lords of England / and of beyond the sea took their
way to ward the holy land. And the king Henry deyed in the same time at
westmestre / when he had reigned.lv. year and.xix. wekes / on saint Edmonds day
the Archebysshop of Caumterbury. And he was enteryd on saint Edmondes day the
king / in the year of the Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu Christ.M.CC.lxxii.

Prophecye of Merlyn of the king Henry the the expowned that was king Iohans
sone.
ANd of this Henry prophesied Merlyn and said / that a lamb should come out of
wynchestre / in the year of ye Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu criste.M.CC.
and.xvi. with true lyppes and holiness written in his heart / And he said sothe
/ for the good Henry the king was borne in wynchestre / in the year abouesayd
/ and he spoke good words and sweet / and was an holy man and of good
consyence. And Merlyn said / that this Henry should make the fairest place of
the word / that in his time should not be fully ended / and he said soth. For
he made the new work of the abbaye of saint Peter's church at westmestre / yt
is fayrer of sight than any other place yt any man knows thorugh out al
crystendom. But king Henry deyed are that work were fully at an end / and
that was great herme. And yet said Merlyn / yt this lamb should have peace the
most part of his regne And he said full soth / for he was never noyed thorugh
war / neither dyseased in no manner wise / a little before his death / and
Merlyn said in his prophecye more / and in ye regne and end of the foresaid
lamb / a wulf of a strange land shall do him much harm thorugh his war /
and that he should at ye last be master thorugh help of a reed fox / that
should come forth of the North west and should him overcome. And that he
should drive him out of the water / and ye prophecye full well was known. For
within a little time or ye king deyed Symonde of Mou^tforde Earl of Leycerre /
yt was borne in France / began ayenste him strong war / thorugh which
doing / many a good bacheler destroyed was and deyed / and dysheryted. And
when kyng^ Henry had the vyctory at Eusham / and Symonde the earl was slain
thorugh help and might of Gylbert of clare earl of Glocetre / that was in
keeping and ward of the forsayde Symonde / through ordinance of king Henry
that went again unto the king with much power. wherefore the foresaid Symonde
was destroyed and that was great harm to the comyns of England / that so good
a man was slain for the troth / and deyed in thar^y^e / and for the common
profit of the same folk / and therefore almighty god for him has syns showed
many a fair miracle to diverse men and wymmen of ye sykenesse and dyscease that
they have had for the love of him And Merlyon also said in his prophecye / that
afer that time / the lame should live no while / and then his seed should be
in strange land without any pasture / and he said sothe / for king Henry
lived no while after that Symonde Mounforde was slain / that king Henry ne
deyed anon after him. And in the mean time sire Edward his sone / that was
the best king of the world of honor / was tho in the holy land and gate
there. Acres. And in that country he begat there upon dame Elenore his wife
Johan of Acres his daughter / that afterward was countess of Glocetre / and
made such a vyage in the holy land / that all the world spoke of his
knyghthode / and every man dradde him hye and low thorughout all crystendome /
as the storye of him tells / as afterward ye shall here more openly. And
from the time yt king Henry deyed / till that sir Edward was crowned king /
all the great lords of England were as faderles childern without any socoure /
that them might mayntene and govern / and defend against their deedly enmyes.

GRegorius the.ix. was pope after Honorius / this man canonysed many saints /
and defended myghtely ye church against Frederyk / therefore the took many
prelates and two Cardynalles / the which went to counseyll against him This
pope was segyd in the cite of Rome by the Emperor / and he saw the Romayne
were corrupt by the money of the Emperor. Then he took in his hand the
heedes of the appostles Peter and Poule / and went with processyon fro the
church of saint John^ Latranente / to saint Peter's church. And so he gate the
hertes of the Romans / and the Emperor went fair a way fro the cite. This
pope made friar Ianond to compyle the five books of Decretales / of many
pystles and decrees. And after with many trybulaco^ns of chyptyrau^t and other
/ he decessyd and went to heaven. Celestinus the fourth was pope after
Gregorius almoost a month / and he was in his life and in his conynge laudable.
And he was an old man and a feeble and decessyd / and there was no pope after
him almoost a.xii. month. Innocencius the fourth was pope after him almoost.xi.
year and.vi. months / this man canonysed many saints / and Frederyke the
Emperor he deposyd as enmye unto god in the third year that he was made pope
/ and he was help by the Ianuences. Then was Henry the sixth chosen and
wyllyam / by the popes commandment against Frederyk that one after an other /
but they prevailed not to overcome his tyranny / for he was ouermyghty / ne
these were not crowned / for they decessyd anon. Thomas de Alquine an holy
doctor Albertus magnus the bishop of Ratysponens. Eustacius. Bonouenture a
devout doctor were this time / the which destroyed much heresye enfected by
the Emperor. Alexander was pope after Innocencius.viii. year / and little of
him is written Vrbanus was after him three year and three months / This man
drove away the host of the Sarrasyns by men marked with the cross / the
which Maufred had sent against the church / And the pope took the kingdom of
Cecyle to the kings brother of France / yt he should fight with Maufrede /
and then he decessyd. And Maufrede after lost his life and his kingdom by
Karolus^ Alpho^sus the king of Castle Rychardes brother to the king of
England earl of Corn waylle / were chosen Emperors after the long vacacyon
of the Empire / for the chesers of the Emperor were diuyded in sondre and
there was great strife many year. At the last decessyd Richard / and Alphonsus
came agaye before Gregorius the.ix. by the sign of peace ^ and utterly renou^ced
all this title of the Empire and he had any / for he was a very wytty man /
and a noble astronemer / and his tables ben very famous the which he made /
for they be compendyons Clemens the fourth was pope after Vrbanus.iii. year
and.ix^ months this Cleme^s was an holy man / and said through the spyryte of
prophecy / yt the enmyes of the church should perysshe as the smoke. And it is
to byleued that god cessyd the trybulacyons of the church thorugh his merytes.
This man before had a wife and chyldern / and when he was priest and after
bishop he was sent in to England Legate / and he no thing knowing was
chosen pope / and after decessyd blessydly for his virtuous living. Gregorias
the.x. was pope after him four year / after he was made pope for the desire
that he had to the holy land. the which he intended to vysyte personally /
a^e London in France he made a solemn counseyll / in the wihche the
counseyll of the Greeks and the Tartars were and there the Greeks promised to
be reformed by the unity of the church. And the Tartars were but a little
before baytysed / and promised the same. And there were gadred.vi.C. bishops
and.M. prelates / and therefore a certain man said Gregorius gadred together
all kind of people / and there was decreed / that all persons and vycaryes
should be called priests / and no prelates / and yt no man should assygne his
tithes to what church he would / and they dyed before. But they should be paid
to his mother church. And he dampened ye pluralyte of benefyces / and deyed a
blessed man. Innocencius the.v. was after him.v. months / and little he did.
Adrianus was after him ^o monethe / and did lesser Ioha^nis the.x^i. was after
him.viii. months / and he was in diverse scyences a famous man / but in manners
a fool and decessyd anon. Nicholaus the third was pope after John^ oo year.
This man was in his days in buldynge a noble man. and well governed the cite
all his days. and the second year he decessyd. Radulphus was Emperor.xviii
year / this man was Earl of Hanebrough a wise man in arms / noble and
vyctoryous and was chosen at Basyle^ And he took ye cross on him for the holy
land. Thimperyall blessing he had not / but the pope allowed the eleccyon for
favor of the holy land:

Anno dm^.M.CC.lxxiiii.
MAr^inus ye.iiii. was pope after Nycholaus.iiii. year. this man was a great
lover of relygyous men / and great attendynge to virtuous works. This man
cursyd the Emperor of Constantynople / in so much as he promised for to torme
to the faith in the general counseyl* and did not / for the which he suffered
many passions and all holy church. Also he cursyd the king of Aragon / for he
expulsyd the king of Cecyle fro his kingdom. And after he had done many
bataylles against men of mysbyleue and many trybulaco^ns suffered / he decessyd
and did many miracles. Nycholaus delira a noble douctour of dyuyte was this
time at Paris this man was a Jew of nacyon / and he was converted and myghtely
profyted in the order of friar Mynours. and he wrote over all the Bible.
Grelles he was in the year of our lord.M^CCC.xxx. and some man say he was a
Braban and yt his fader and his mother were crystne but for pouerte he vysyted
ye scole of ye Jews / and so he learned the Jews langage or else this
Nycholaus was informed of the Jews in his young aege. Honorius ye fourth was
pope after Martynus two year / and little of him is written / but that he was a
temperat man and a dyscerte. Nicholaus the fourth was pope after him four year
/ this man was a friar Mynor / and although he was a good man in himself / yet
many unhappy / things fell in his time to ye church. For many a battle was
in ye cite through his occasyon / for he drew to much to the one part. And
after him three was no pope two year and.vi. months.

How king Edward that was king Henryes sone.
ANd after this king Henry reigned Edward his sone the worthyes knight of the
world in honor / for gods grace was in him / for he had the vyctorye of his
enmyes and as soon as his fader was deed / he came to London with a noble
company of prelates / earls and barons / and all me^ did him much honor. For
in every place ye sir Edward rode in London / the streets were covered over
his heed with sylke of tapiscery / and other rich couerynges. And for Joy of
his coming / the burgeys of the Cite cast out at their wyndowes gold and
silver hondes full / in tokenynge of love and worship / service and reverence.
And out of condyte of Chepe ran white wine and reed / as stremes both of the
water / and every man drank thereof ye would at their own will. and this king
Edward was crowned and enoynted as right heyer of England with much honor.
And after mass ye king went in to his place to hold a ryall feast among
them that did him honor. And when he was set to meet / The king Alexander
of Scotlonde came to do him honor and reverence / with a q^eyntesye and an
hundred knights with him well horsyd and arayde. And when they were alyght of
their stedes / they let them go whether they would / and who that might take
them took at their own will / without any chalenge^r And after came sire
Edmonde king Edwardes brother a curteys knight and a gentle of renown / and
the earl of Corn wayllle / and the earl of Glocestre. And after then came
the earl of Penbroke / and the earl of Garenne. And each of them by themself
ladde in their hand an hundred knights gayly dysgysed in their arms. And
when they were alyghted of their horses / they let them go whether that they
welde / and who yt might them catch / them to have still without any challenge.
And when all this was done / king Edward did his dylygence and his might for
to amend and dress the wrongs in the best manner that he might to the
honor of god and holy church / and to mayntene his honor / and to amend
the noyannce of the common people.

How ydeyne that was Lewelyns daughter of walys / prince Aymer / that was ye
earls brother of Mou^forde were taken in the sea.
THe first afterward ye king Edward was crowned Lewelyn prince of wales
sent in to Faraunce to the earl Mou^forde / that thorough cou^seyl of his
friends / ye earl should wedde his daughter. And the earl tho auysed him upon
this thing / and sent unto Lewelyn and said. that he would send after his
daughter. and so he sent Aymer his brother after the damoysell. and Lewelyn
arrayed shyphes for his daughter and for Sire Aymer. and for her faare company
that should goo with her. And this Lewelyn did great wrong. for it was
couenau^ted that he should give his daughter to no manner man / without
counsel and consent of king Edward. And so it befell that a Burgeys of
Brystow came in the sea with wine laden. and met them and took them with
might and power. And anon the Burgeys sent them to the king. And when Lewely
herd this tidings he was very wroth / and also sorowfull^ and began to war
upon king Edward and did much harm unto Englysshmen / and beat down ye
kings castles / and began for to destroy king Edwardes land. And wha^
tidings came unto ye king of this thing he went in to walys and so much he
did thorough gods grace and his great power that he drofe Lewelyn unto great
myschyef / that he fled all manner of strength and came and yielded him unto
king Edward. and yaue him.l. mark of silver to have peace. And took the
damoysell and all his heritage. and made an oblygaco^n to king Edward to come
to his parlyamente two times of the year And in the second year after that
king Edward was crowned / he held a general parleamente at westmestre /
and there he made the statutes for defaute of law by the comune assent of all
his baronage / and at Ester next sewenge / the king sent by his letter unto
Lewelyn prince of wales that he should come to his parliament for his land /
and for his holding in wales / as the strenthe of his letter oblygatory
wytnessyd. Tho Lewelyn had scorn and dyspyte of the kings commandment / And
for pure wrache again began war upon king Edward. and destroyed his land.
And tho when king Edward herd of these tidings / he wexed wonder wroth unto
Lewelyn and in have assembled his people / and went him to ward wales. And
warred so upon Lewelyn the prince / till that he brought him in much sorrow
and disease. And Lewelyn saw that is defense might him not auaylle / and came
again / and yielded him to ye kings grace / and cried him mercy. and long time
kneled before the kings foot. The king had of him pity / and commanded him
for to arise. And for his mekenes foryaue him his wrath / and to him said /
that if he trespassed to him a another time that he would dystroye him for
evermore. David that was Lewelyns brother that same time dwelled with king
Edward / and was a fell man and a subtle and enuyous and also far casting
/ and much treason thoughte^ and evermore made good semblame / and semyd so
true that no man might perceive his falsnes.

How Lewelyn through eggynge of his brother Dauyd werryd again upon king Edward
IT was not long after that time ye king Edward yaaf to Dauyd Lewelyns
brother the lordshyppe of Frodesham. and made him a knight and so much honor
did he never after to man of walys by cause of him king Edward held his
parlemente at London when he had do in walys that he would and changed his
money / that was full ill kytte / wherefore the people playned sore. So that
the king enquered of the trespassours. And three houndred were atteynted of
such manner falsnes / wherefore some where hanged and sum drawn and after
hangyd. And afterward the king ordained / that the sterlynge halfpeny should
go thorugh out all his land / And commanded that no man fro that day
afterward yaue ne feoffed house of religyo^ with land / tenemente without
special leave of the king. And he yt did should be punysshed at the kings
will / and the yeft shall be for naught. And it was not long after ye Lewelyn
prince of walys through the tycemente of Dauyd his brother / and both their
consent / they thought to dysheryte king Edward / in asmoche as they might /
so that thorugh them both ye kings peace was broken. And when king Edward
herd of this / anon he sent his barons in to Northumberlonde and the Surreys
also / yt they should go and take their vyage upon ye traitors Lewelyn and
Dauyd. And wonder herd it was for to war tho / For it is winter i^ walys /
when in other cou^tres is Somer. And Lewelyn let ordeyne and well arrayed and
vytayll his good castle of Swandon. and was there in an huge nombre of people /
and plente of vytaylles so that king Edward wist not where for to enter And
when the kings men it perceyuer and also the strenth of walys they let come
in the sea bargees and botes. and great plankys as many as they might ordeyne
and have: for to go to the said castle of Swandon. with men on foot and also
on horse. But the walsshmen had so much people / and were so strong. that they
drove the Englysshmen again / so yt there was so much press of people at ye
tornynge again that ye charge and the burden of men made ye bargees and the
botes to synke and there was drowned many a good kynght / yt is to say. sir
Robert Clyfford sir wyllyam of Lyndeseye yt was^ sire Iohn^s sone Fitz Robert.
and sir Rychard Tanny and a^ huge nombre of other / and all was through there
own folly. For if they had had good espyes / they had not be harmyd. when king
Edward herd tell that his people were so drowned* He made sorrow enough. but
tho came sir Johan of Vessy from the king* Aragon. And brought with him much
people of bachelors and of Gascoynes / and were souldyurs. And dwelled with the
said John of Vessy and received of him wages and with him were witholde. and
noble men they were for to fight and burnt many towns / and slew much
people of walsshmen. All that they might take. And all tho with strenth and
might made assawte unto the castle of Swandon and gate the castle / And when
Dauyd the prence brother herd of this tidings he ordained him to flight and
Lewelyn the prince saw that his brother was fled / then he was sore abashed
for he had no power to his war for to mayntene. And so Lewelyn began for to
flee / and wind well for to have scapedde. But in a morrow sire Roger mortymer
met with him oonly with.x. knights. And set him round about. And to him
went / and smote of his heed / and presented ye same heed unto king Edward.
And in this manner Lewelyn the prince of walys was taken / and his heed smyten
of / and also all his heirs dysheryted for evermore through right full dome of
all the lords of the reame.

How Dauyd that was Lewelyns brother prince of walys was put to death.
David that was the princes brother of walys / through pride wend to have be
prince of walys / after his brothers death / and upon this he sent after
walsshemen to his parleament at Dynbygh and folysshely made walys to arise
against the king and began to meue war against king Edward and did all the
sorrow and disease that he might by his power. when king Edward herd of
this thing / he ordained men to pursewe upon him. And Dauyd fyersly him
defended / till ye he came to the towned of saint Morice / and there was Dauyd
take as he fled. and ladde to the king. And the king commanded that he
should be hangyd and drawn / and smite of his heed / and quarter him / and
send his head to London and the four quarters send to the four chyef towns
of walys. For they should take ensample thereof and beware. And afterward king
Edward let cry his peace through out all walls and seized all the land in to
his hand and all the great lords that were left alive came to do feaute and
homage to the king Edward as to their kind lord / And tho let king Edward
amend the laws of walys that were defectyue And he sent to all ye lords of
walys by letter patentes / that they should come all to parliament And when they
were come you king said to them full curteysly lordynges ye be welcome / and me
behooves your counseyll and your help for to go unto Gascoyne for to amend
the trespass yt to me was done when I was there And for to entreat of peace
between the king of Aragon and the prince of Morrey / and all ye kings lyege
men earls and barons consented and granted thereto. And tho made him king
Edward ready and went in to Gascoyne. and let amend all the trespasses yt him
was done in Gascoyne. And of the debate yt between the king of Aragon and the
prince of Morrey he sessyd and made them accorded. And while good king Edward
and Elynore his wife were in Gascoyne. The good earl of Cornewayll was made
wardeyn of England till that king Edward came again. And tho enquered he of
his traitors yt coniected falsenesse against him. And each of them all
received there dome after that they had deserve. But in the mean time that the
good king Edward was beyond the sea to do / them for to make amends that
against him had trespassyd there was a false the if / a traytoure that was called
Rysap Merydok / began for to make werre against king Edward. and yt was for
cause of sir pain Typtot. wrongfully grieved and dysceased the forsayde Rysap
meradok. And when king Edward herd all this matere and it well understood
anon he sent by his letter pryue seal to the foresaid Rebellyo^ Rysap Merydok
that he should begin in no manner wise for to make and reyse werre but yt he
should be in peace for his love / and when he came again in to England he would
under take the quarrel and amend al yt was mysdon. This foresaid Rysap Merydok
despised the kings commandment and spared not to do all the sorrow that he
might to the kings men of England But anon after he was take and ladde to
york / and there he was drawn and hangyd for his felonye.

Of dressyng that king Edward made of his Justices and of his clerks that
they had done for there falsnes and how he drove the Jews out of England for
there usury and mysbyleue.
AS king Edward had dwelled three year in Gascoyne a desire came to him for to
goo in to England again. And when he was come again he found so many playntes
made to him of his Justices and of his clerks that had done so many wrongs
and falsnesse yt wonder it was to here and for which falsnesse sire Thomas
waylond ye kings Justice / for swore England at the toure of London / for
falsnesse that me^ put upon him / wherefore he was atteynt / and proved fals^
And anon after when the king had done his will of the Justices tho let he
enquere and espy how the Jews dysceyued and begyled his people / thorugh the
sin of falsnesse and of usury. And let ordeyne a preuy parliament among his
lords. And they ordained among them / that all the Jews should void out of
England for their mysbyleue / and also for their falls usury that they did
unto christian men. And for to spedde and make an end of this thing / all the
common alte of England yaue unto the king the.xv. penny of all their goods
meuable / and so were the Jews driven out of England. And tho went the
Jews in to France. And there they dwelled / thorugh leave of king Phylyp that
tho. was king of France.

How king Edward was seized in all the land of Scotlonde through co^sente
and grant of all the lords of Scotlonde^
IT was not long after that Alexandre king of Scotlonde was deed / and Dauyd
the earl of Huntyngdon that was the kings brother of Scotlonde axed and
claymed the kingdom of Scotlond after his brother was deed for cause yt he was
ryghtfull heir / But many great lords said nay. Wherefore great debate arose
between them and there fre^des for asmoche as they would not consent to his
coronacyon / and the mean time the foresaid Dauyd deyed / and so it befell that
ye said Dauyd had three daughters yt worthyly were married / the first daughter
was married to Bayloll / the second to Brus / and the third to Hastynges. The
foresaid Bayloll and Brus challenged ye land of Scotlonde / and great debate
and stryf arose between them by cause each of them would have be kynge^ And
when the lords of Scotlonde saw the debate between them / came to king
Edward of England. and seized him in all the land of Scotlond as chyef lord.
and wha^ the king was seized of ye foresaid lords ye foresaid Baylol Brus and
Hastinges came to the kings court axyd of the king which of them should be
king of Scotlonde And king Edward ye full gentle and true / let inquire by
the Chronicles of Scotlonde / and of the gretest lords of Scotlonde / which of
them was of the eldest blood. And it was found that Baylol / was the eldest.
And that ye king of Scotlond should hold of the king of England / and do him
france and homage. And after this was done Baylol went in to Scotlo^de / and
there was crowyed king of Scotlonde. And ye same time was upon the sea great
war between the Englysshemen and the Normans But upon a time the Normans
arrived all at Dover. and there they martred an holy man that was called Thomas
of Dover / And afterward were the Norma^s slain. that there escaped not one
of the^ And so afterward king Edward should let the duchye of Gascoyne
through king phylyp of France through his false casting of the Dousepers of the
land / wherefore sir Edmond that was king Edwardes brother yaue up his damage
unto the king of France. And in the time the clerks of England granted to
king Edward half ^eale of holy church goods in helping to recover his
land again in gascoyne. And the king sent thither a noble company of his
bachelors. And himself would have gone to Portelmouth / but he was let thrughe
one maddok of walys yt had seized the castle of Swandon in to his hand and
for that cause the king turned to walys at Cristmasse / and by cause that the
noble lords of England yt were sent in to Gascoyne had no comforth of there
lord the king they were take of sir Charlys of France / yt is to say / sir
John^ of brytayne / sir Robert Tiptot / sir Raufe Tanny / sir Hugh Bardolfe /
and sir Adam of Cretynge / And yet at the assensyon was Maddok take in walys
and a another that was called Morgan And they were sent to the tour of London
and there they were byheded.

How Sire Johan Baylol king of Scotlonde with said his homage.
ANd when sire John^ Baylol king of Scotlonde understand ye king Edward was
werred in Gascoyne / to whom ye reame of Scotlond was delyuerd / Falsely tho
against his oath with said his homage through procuring of his folk and sent
unto ye court of Rome through a falls suggestyon to be assoylled of that oath yt
he swore unto the king of England and so he was by letter enbulled. Tho chose
they of Scotlonde dousepers / for to brnyge Edward of his right. And in ye time
came two Cardynalles from ye cource of Rome fro the pope Celestme / to trete of
acorde between ye king of England. and as tho cardinals spoke of accord.
Tha^ as turbeluyll was taken at Lions and made homage to the ward of Paris and
put his sons in hostage / and thought to go in to England aspye the country /
and tell them when he came to England that he had broken the kings prison of
France by right and said that he would do yt all Englysshmen and walshemen
should about the king for to bring to the end he swore / and upon this
covenant deeds were made between them / and that he should have by year a
thousand pou^des worth of land. to byrnge this thing to an end. This false
traitor took his leave / and went thens and came in to England unto the king
and said. that he was broke out of prison and yt he had put him in such
peril for his love wherefore the king cowde him much thank and full glad
was of his coming. And the false traytoure fro that day / aspyed all the
doing of the king and also his counselle / for the king loved him full well
and with him full preuy But clerk of England / that was in the kings hows of
France: herd of this treason / and of the falsnesse / and wrote to another
clerk / that tho was dwelling with Edward king of England. all how Thomas
Turbeluyll had done his false c^niectynge / and all the counselle of England
was write for to have send unto the king of France. And thoruhhe the
forsayde letter that the clerk had sent fro France it was found upon.
wherefore he was led to London and hangyd and draw there for his treason. And
his two sons that he had put in France for hostage. were then beheeded.

Of the Conquest of Berwyke.
SO when the two Cardynalles were gone again in to France for to trete of
the peace of cambroy the king sent thither of his earls and barons. This is to
say sir Edmonde his brother earl of Lancastre and of Lecetre / sir Henry Lacy
earl of Nychol / and Wyllyam Vessy Baron / and of other baronettes.
about.xiii. of the best and wysest of England And in the same time the king
Edward took his vyage to Scotlonde / for to werre upon John^ Baylol king of
Scotlonde. And sir Robert Roos of Berwyk sledde fro ye Englysshmen / and went
to the Scotts. And king Edward went him toward Berwyk / and besegyd the
town. And tho that were within manly them defended and set a fire and burnt
two of King Edwardes ships / and said in dyspyte and reprey^ of him (wenyth
king Edward with his long shankys / to have get Berewyk all our vnthankes
gas pykes him / and when he was done gas dykes him) when king Edward this
scorn / anon thorugh his myghtenesse / he passed over the dyches and
assaylled the town / and came to the yates / and gate and conquered the town
/ and thrughe his gracyous power slew.xxv. thousand and.vii. hundred scotts.
and King Edward lost no man of renoune saufe sir Richard of Cornewayle. and
him killed a Flemynge out of the red halle with a quarrel as the foresaid
Richard did of his helm. And commanded them for to yield them / and put
them in the kings grace. And ye Scotts would not wherefore that halle was
brent and cast down. And all tho that were therein were burnt and king
Edward lost no moo men at that vyage of simple estate but.xxvii.
Englysshemen. And the wardeyn of the castle yaue up the keys of ye castle
without any assawte And there was taken sire Wyllyam Douglas Symonde Frysell
and the earl patryk yielded them to the peace. But Ingham of Humbresmylle and
Robert the Brus that were with king Edward forsook king Edward and held
with the Scotts. And afterward they were taken and put in to prison And tho
let kynhe Edward close in Berwyk with walls and with dyches / and after
Robert Rous went to Tyndale / and set wuyerbrydge a fire and Exham / and
Lamerstok and slew and robbyd the folk of the country. And after that he
went fro thens to Dunbarre. And the first wenesdaye of March the king sent
the earl of Garenne. sir Hugh Percy and sire Hugh Spenser with a fair company
for to besege the castle. But one that was called sire Richard Sywarde a
traytoure and a falls man ymagyned for to begyle the Englysshme^ / and sent to
the Englysshmen them for to deseeyue / and said / That he would yield to them
ye castle. if they would grant them.viii. days of respyce / that he myhht
send and tell to sir Johan Bayloll that was king of Scotlonde how is men
fared that were within the castle. And him word but if he would remeue the
sege of the Englysse men / that they would yield that castle unto the
English men. The messenger tho came to sir Johan Baylol that tho was king of
Scotlo^de where that he was with his hooste / and the messenger told him all
the caas / And sir Johan took his host and came on the morrow erly toward the
castle. and sir Richard sywarde saw him come yt was master of the counseyll
and keeper of the castle and said unto the Englyssgmen O said he. now I see a
fair company and well apparelled I will goo ayenste them / and with them to
mete / and them assaylle. And sir Hughe Spenser saw the falsnesse of hym^ and
ye treson^ And said to him O traitor take and prove your falsnesse shall not
auaylle you. And Hughe Spenser commanded anon to bind him. And all in have
went against there enmyes / and slew of Scotts.xxii. thousand. For the Scotts
had that time no man with them of honor saufe Patryke Graham that manly
fought / and long at the last he was slain. And tho said the Englysshmen
in repreyf of the Scotts (These scaterande Scotts hold I for sottes of
wrenches un ware. Erly in a morning in an evil tymynge went ye fro Du^bare.
As tho that ware within the castle saw the scomfyture they yielded up the
castle unto the Englysshmen. And bound their bodies gods and castles to
king Edward. And so there were take in that castle three earls.vii. barons /
and.xxxviii. knights and xi. clerks / and.vii. Pycardys and all were
presentyd to king Edward And he sent the^ to the tower of London to be kept.

How king Edward of his great grace delivered again the Scotts out of
prison that were cheyftayns of that land and they drew them to the
Frensshemen through counseyll of Wyllyam waleys.
AS king Edward had made tho an end of ye werre. and taken the chey^^eyns of
Scotlonde. tho came sir Johan Baylol and yielded him unto king Edward and put
him in his grace and he was led to London and when king Edward was come
thither they were brough before him / And the king axed how they would make
amends of the trespaas and loss that they had done to him and they put them
in his mercy. Lordynges said the king I will not of your lands ne your
goods / but I will that ye make to me an oath upon goddys body to be true to
me and never after this time against me bear armies* And all they consentyd to
the kings will and swore upon goddys body. That is to say sir John^ of Common.
the earl of Scra^hron / the earl of Carryk / and also four bishops undertook
for all the clergy and so the king delivered the^ / and yaue them sauf
conduyce to go in to there own land. And it was not long afterward that they
ne arise against king Edward / for cause that they wist well that king
Edwardes folk was take / in Gascoyne / as before is said But sir John^ Bayloll
king of Scotlonde wyste well. that his land should have sorrow and shame /
for their falsnesse^ And in have went him over the sea to his own lands and
there he held him and came never again wherefore the Scotts chose unto their
king wyllyam waleys / a rybaude and an harlot comen up of naught / and much
harm did to Englysshmen and king Edward thought how he might have
delyueraunce of his people that were take in Gascoyne. And i^ have went him
over the sea in to Flaunders for to werre upon the king of France. And the
earl of Flaunders received him with much honor and grayntyd him all his
londys at his own will. And when the king of France herd tell the king of
England was aryued in Flaundres and came with a great power him for to
dystroye. He prayed him of trewes for two year / so that the English
merchants and also French might saufly go and come in both sides. The king
Edward granted ^^. so that he must have his men out of prison that were in
Gascoyne and the king of France anon granted and so they were delyuerd. And
in ye same time the Scotts sent by ye bishop of saint andrews in to France
to the king and to sir Charles his brother. ye sir Charles should come with
his power and they of Scotlo^de would come with their power / and so they
should go in to England / that loud to dystroye from Scotlonde unto they came
to ^ente. and the Scotts trustyd much upon the Fre^sshmen but of ye thing
they had no manner grant and nevertheless ye Scotts beg to rob and kylle in
Northu^berlond / and did much harm.

How wyllyam waleys let reyse ye land of Scotlonde as cheyf lord. And sir
Hugh of Cressynham and of the battle of Fonkyrke.
AS tidings was come to king Edward that wyllyam walys had ordained such a
strong power. And also that all Scotlonde to him was attendaunt and ready for
to slay Englysshmen and to dystroye the land he was sore anoyed / and sent
anon by letter to therle of Garrenne / to sir Henry Percy / and to wyllyam
Latomer / and to sir Hughe of Cressynham his tresoroer. that they should take
power / and go in to Northumberlonde. and so forth in to Scotlo^de. For to
keep the countres and when wyllyam waleys herd of their coming. He began to
flee and the Englysshmen him followed and dr^ue him till he came to Stryuelyn and
there he held him in the castle. And the walsshmen every day them escryed
and menacyed / and did all the dyspyte that they might so that Englysshmen
upon a time in a morning went out fro the castle / the mou^tenaunce of.x.
miles / and passed over a bridge and william waleys came with a strong power /
and drove them abak / for the Englysshmen had against him no power tho but
fled. and they that might take the bridge escaped. but sir hughe the kings
tresorer there was slain / and many other also / wherefore was made much
sorrow. Tho had king Edward sped all his matters in Flau^dres / and was come
again in to England / and in haste took his way in to Scotlonde / and came
theder at the Ascencyon tide. And all that he found he set a fire and burnt
/ But the poor people of Scotlonde came to him wonder thyck and prayed him for
goddys love / that he would on them have Mercy and pity tho the king commanded
yt no man should do them harm yt were yolden to him / ne to no man of order
ne to no house of relygyon / ne no manner church. but let espy all that he
might where yt he might find any of his enmyes tho came a spy unto the king
and told where that ye Scotts were assembled to abide bataylle. And on saint
Mary Mawdelyns day / ye king came to Fonkyrk and yaue bataylle to the Scotts
and at that bataylle were slain.xxx. thousand Scotts / and of
Englysshemen.xviii. and no mo. Of the which was a worthy knight slain yt was
a knight hospytelere that was called Frery bryan Iay. For when Wyllyam waleys
fled from the battle that same Frery bryan him pursewed fyersly / and as his
horse ran it stert in a mire of a marys up to the belly And Wyllyam waleys
turned tho again and there slew the forsayde bryan. and that was much harm.
And that while king Edward went thorugh Scotlonde / for to enquere if he
might find any of his enmyes. And in that land he dwelled / as long as him
lyked / And there was no enmye that durst him abide. And soon after King
Edward went to Southampton for he would not abide / in Scotlonde in winter
season / for esement of his people And when he came to London / he let amend
many mysdedys that were done against his peace and laws he being in Flaundres.

Of ye last marriage of king Edward / and how he went ye third time in to
Scotlo^de.
ANd after it was ordained thrughe the court of Rome / that king Edward
should wedde dame Margarete / that was king Phylyp sister of France. And the
Archebysshop Robert of wynchelse spowsed them to gyders / through the which
Marriage there was made peas^ between king Edward of England and king Phylyp
of France. King Edward went tho the third time in to Scotlonde and tho
within the first year he had enfamyned the land / so that he left not one
that he ne came to his mercy. sauf such as were in the castle of Estreuelyn
that well were vytaylled and stored for.vii. year.

How the castle of Estrefelyn was be seged and won.
King Edward came to ye castle of Estreuelyn with a huge power and beseged
the castle / but it little auaylled. for he myhht do the Scoctes no harm /
for the castle was so strong and well kept. and king Edward said ye and
bethought him upon a queyntesy^ and let make anon two payr of high galowes
before the tour of the castle. and made his oath that as many as were within
the castle. Notwithoutstandynge were he Earl of Baron / and he were take with
strength but if he would the rather him yield / he should be hangyd upon the
same galowes. And when tho that were within the castle herd this. they came
and yield them all to the kings grace and mercy / and the king for yaf the^
all his male talent and there were all the great lords of Sfotlonde swore to
king Edward / that they should come to London to every parliament and shode
stand to his ordynance.

How Troylebaston was first ordened.
THe king Edward went thens to london and wend to have had rest and peace of
his war in which werre he was occupied.xx. year. that is to say in Gascoyne
in walys and in Scotlonde / and thought how he might recover his tresour yt he
had spended about his werre / and let enquere through the reame of all the
time that he had be out of his reame that men called Troylebaston and ordained
thereto Justices / and in this manner he recovered tresoure without nombre: And
his purpose was for to have goon in to the holy land / to have werred upon
gods enmyes by cause he was crossyd long ty^e before And nevertheless ye law
that he had ordained did much good through out all England to them that were
mysbode For tho ye trespassed were well chastysed. and after more meke and
better and ye pore comyns were in rest and peace And the same time king
Edward prysoned his own sone Edward / by cause that Walter of Lanton bishop
of Chestre / that was the kings tresorer had complained on him and said the
foresaid Edward thrughe counsel and entysynge of one Ganasto^ asquyre of
Gascoyne had broke the parkes of the foresaid bishop. And this Peers counselyd
and ladde the same Edward and for that cause the king e^yled his sone out of
England.

Of the death of Wyllyam waleys the false traytoure.
ANd when this king Edward had his enemies overcome in walys Gascoyne and
Scotlonde and dystroyed his traitors / all but only that rybaude Wyllyam ^les
/ that never the king would him yield and at the town of saint Dominyk. in
the year of king Edward regne.xxxiii. ye falls traitor was take and presentyd
to the king. But the king would not see him / but sent him to London to
receive his Judgment: and upon saint Barthylmewes eve was he hangyd and draw /
and his head smite of and his bowelles take out of his body and burnt and his
body quartered and sent unto four of the best towns of Scotlonde / and his
heed put upon a spear* and let upon London bridge. In ensample (...) the
Scotts should have in mind for to do a mysse against their lyege lord
eftsoon.

How the Scotts came to king Edward for to amend their trespass that they
had done against him.
ANd at Myghelmas tho nexe coming king Edward held his parliament at
westmestre / and thither came ye Scotts that is to say the bishop of saint
Andreas: Roberte the Brus earl of caryk. Symonde Frysell / Johan the earl of
Athell and they were accorded with the king and bound by oath swore that they
afterward if any of them mysbare them against king Edward that they should be
dysheryted for evermore. And when their peace was thus made they took their leave
pryuely / and went home in to Scotlonde.

How Robert Brus chale^ged Scotlonde.
SO after this Robert the Brus earl of Caryk sent by his letters to the earls
and barons of Sotlonde that they should come to him to Scone in the morrow
after the Concepcion of our lady for great nedys of the land. And the lords
came at the day assygned. And the same day sir Robert the Brus said Fair
lords fulle well ye know / yt in my person dwelled the right of the reame of
Scotlonde / and as ye wot well I am ryghtfull heyer Sith that sire John^
baylol yt was our king us has forsake / and left his land. And though it so
be ye king Edward of England with wrongful power has made me to him assent
against my will / if that he will grant that I may be king of Scotlonde I
shall keep you against king Edward of england / and against all manner men /
and with ye word the abbot of Scon / arose up / and before them all said /
that yt was reason for to help him and the land to keep and defend. And tho
said in presence of the^ all yt he would give him a.M. pound for to mayntene
ye land. and all the other granted the land to him and with there power him
for to help / and defied king Edward of England. and said ye Robert Brus /
should be king of England.

How sir John^ of Common against said the crownynge of sir Robert Brus.
LOrdynges said sir Johan of Common. think on the truth and oath ye made to
king Edward of England and touching my self I will not break mine oath for no
man / and so he went from ye company at ye time. wherefore Robert ye brus and
all tho ye to him conse^ted were wroth / and menaced sir John^ of common Tho
ordened they another counsel at Dumfrys to which came ye for said sir John^
of Common / for he dwelled but two mile fro Dumfris. there he was wont to
soiorne and abide.

How sir John^ was traytoursly slain.
SO when Roberte the Brus wist that all the great lords were come of Scotlond
to Scon / sauf sir John^ Common ye so^ourned nyghe scon he sent specially after
the said sir John^ to come and speak with him. And upon that he came and spoke
with him at the grayfreres in Dumfris and yt was the thursday after
Ca^delmasseddy. and sir John^ granted to go with him. And when he had herd
mass / he took a soope and drank and after ward he bestrode his palfroy and
rode to Dumfris / when Roberte the brus saw him come at a wyndow as he was in
his chamber made Joy ynoygh / and came against him / and collyd him about ye
neck / and made with him good semblau^t. And when all the earls and barons of
Scotlonde were present Robert ye Brus said syrs ye wot well ye / cause of this
coming and wherefore it is. if ye will grant that Ibe king of scotlonde as
right heir of ye land. And all the lords that were there said with one voys
that h should be crownede king of Scotlond* and yt they would him help and
mayntene against all manner men on live / and for him if it were need to deye /
the gi^tyll knight tho John^ of Common answered certes never form. ne for to
have of me asmoche help as the value of a baton. For that oath that I have made
unto king Edward of England I shall hold while my life woll last. And with
that word he went from the company and would a light upon his palfroy. and
Roberte the Brus pursewed him with a drawenswerde / and bare him through the
body and sir John^ Common fell down unto the earth. But when Roger yt was sir
John^ Comyns brother saw the falsnesse. He stert to sir Robert the Brus and
smote him with a knyfe But ye falls traitor was armyd under. so that ye stroke
might do him no harm. and so much help came about sire Robert the Brus so
ye Robert Common was there slain and all to hewn in to pieces. and Robert the
Brus turned again there yt sir John^ Common ye noble baron lay wounded. and pyned
to ward his death / beside the high awter in the church of the graey freres /
and said unto sir Johan common. O traytoure thou shall be deed / and never
after let mine auauncement / and shoke his sword at the high awter. and smote
him on his head / that ye brain fell down upon the ground. and the blood
storte on high upon the walls / and yet unto this day is that blood seen
there that no water may wasshe it a way. And so deyed that noble knight in
holy church.

ANd when this traytoure Roberte the Brus saw. that no man would sete his
coronacyon / he cu^mau^ded all the^ that were of power should come unto his
crownynge to saint Iohans town in Scotlonde^ And so it be fell upon our lady
day the Annu^cyacyon the bishop of Glaston and the bishop of saint Andrews
crowned for there king this Roberte the Brus in saint Iohans town / and made
him king And anon after he drove all thenglyssshemen out of Scotlonde. And
they fled. and came and compleyned them unto king Edward / how that Robert
ye Brus had drive them out of the land / and dysheryted them.

How that king Edward dubbyd at westmestre.xxiiii. score knights.
ANd when king Edward herd of this myschyef / he swore that he should be
ouenged thereof / and said / That all the traitors of Scotlonde should be
hangyd and drawn / and that they should never be raunsonned. And king Edward
thought upon this falsnesse that the Scotts had to him done And sent after
all the bachelors of England / that they should come unto London at wytso^tyde
/ and he dubbyd at westmestre.xxiiii. score knights. Them ordened the noble
king Edward for to go in to Scotlonde / to werre upon Robert the Brus / And
sent before him in to Scotlonde sir Aymer the valaunce earl of Penbroge. And
sire Henry Perey baron with a fair company / that pursewed ye Scotts and
burnt towns and castles. And afterward came the king himself with earls and
barons a fair company.

How Robert Brus was dysco^fyted / in battle / and how Symonde fryselly was
slain.
THe Frydaye next before the Assumecyon of our lady king Edward met Robert
Brus beside saint Iohans town in Scotlo^de and with his company / of the
which company king Edward slew.vii. thousand / when Robert Brus saw this
myscheyf he began to flee / and hid him that no man might him find / But sir
Symonde fryseld pursewed him sore / so that he turned again and abode battle /
for he was a worthy knight and a bold of dody. And thenglysshmen pursewed ever
sore in every side and slew the stead that sir Symonde rode upon / and they
took him and ladde him unto the host. And sir Symonde began for to flatre and
speak fair / and said lords I shall give you four thousand mark of silver /
mine horse / harneys and all mine armor / and become a beggar. Tho answered
Theobaude of Peuens that was the kings archers. Now so god me help it is for
naught that thou spekeste. For all the gold in England I would. not let the
go with out commandment of king Edward / and tho was he had unto king
Edward and the king would not se him but commanded to lead him a way / to
have his dome at London. and on our ladies eve Natiuite he was hangyd and drew
and his heed smite of. and hangyd again with cheynes of yern upon the galowes.
And his heed was sete upon London bridge vpod a spear / and against Crystemasse
the body was burnt by cause that the men / that kept the body by night they
saw so many deuyls rampyng with great yren hokes renynge upon the galowes and
horrible tormented ye body. and many yt them saw anon after they deyed for
dread / and some wexed mad^ / fore syknes they had. and in that battle was
take ye bishop of Baston and the bishop of saint Andrews / and the abbot of
Sco^ne all armyd with yren as men of arms. as falls traitors and falls prelates
against their oath. And they were brought to the king and the king sent them
unto the pope of Rome. that he should do with them what his will were.

How Johan therle of Alethes was taken and put to death.
ANd at that bataylle fled sire Johan earl of Alethes / and went to a
church and there hid him for dread / but he might have there no refute for
cause that the church was enterdyted through general sentence / and in the
same church he was taken. And this sir Johan went well to have escaped fro ye
death / for cause yt he claymed kynred of King Edward. and the king would not
longer be bytrayed of his traitors but sent him to London in have. And there
was hangyd and his head smyten of and his body brent all to ashes. But at the
prayer of the queen Margerete / for cause that he claymed of king Edward
kynred his drawing was for yeuen him.

How Johan that was Wyllyam waleys brother was put to death.
AS the grettest master of Scotlonde were thus done to evil death and
destroyed for their falsnesse. Johan that was Wyllyam waleys brother was take
and done unto death. as sir Johan earl of Alethes was.

How Robert the Brus fled from Scotlonde to Norway.
ANd at ye same time was robert ye / brus much hated among the people of
scotlonde / so yt he wyste not what he was best to do and for to hyde him he
went to Norway to the king that had spowsyd his sister. and there held him
socour for to have. and Robert the Brus might not be found in Scotlonde.
Sokynge Edward tho let cry his peace thrught out all the land / and his lawas
were vsyd / and his mynystrys served through out all the land.

How king Edward deyed.
SO as king Edward had abatyd his enemies turned south ward. and sykened at
Burgh upon sand in the march of Scotlonde. and called to him Henry Lacy earl
of Nichell. sir guy earl of warwyk. sir Aylmer earl of Penbroke / and sir
Robert of Clyfforde baron and prayed them upon the faith that they him ought
/ that they should make Edward of Carnaruan king of England as soon as they
might. And that they should not suffer Peers of Ganaston come again in to
England / for to make his sone to riot / and they granted him with good will.
And the king took his sacrament of holy church as a good Christian man
should. and deyed in repentance And when he had been king.xxxv. year he
deyed / and was buried at westmestre with much solempnyte / Upon whose soul
god have mercy.

Of Merlyns prophecyes that were declared of king Edward. That was king
Henrys sone.
OF this king Edward prophecyce Merlyn / and called him a dragon the second of
the.vi. kings that should regne in England and said / that he should be
meddled with mercy / and also with strenthe and fyernesse. That should keep
England from cold and hete. And that he should opene his mouth toward
walys and that he should set his foot in wyk and that he should close with
walwes / that should do much harm to his sede. And he said sothe. For the
good king Edward was meddled with mercy and with fyernesse / with mercy
against his enmyes of walys / and after of Scotlonde with fyernesse / when he
put them to death for there falsnesse / and traytourily as they had deserved.
And well keped he England from cold and heet / sithe he kept it from all
manner of enmyes that ran upon him to do him any wrong. And well he
opened his mouth to ward walys / and made it quake thrughe hydour of his
mouth / when he conqueryd it thruoghe dynte of sword. For the prince Lewelyn
and Dauyd his brother. Ris and Morgan. were put to death thrughe their
falsnesse and their folly / And he set his foot in to wyk / and conquered
Berwyk at the which conquest were slain.xxv. thousand and.vii. hundred / out
take such as were burnt in the red halle. And the walls yt he let make
shall be noyous / unto his sede. As men shall here after inthe life of sire
Edward of Carnaruan his sone. And yet said Merlyn that he should make ryuers
ren in blood and with brain. and ye semyd well in his wars there as he had
ye maystry And yet Merlyn said yt there should come a people out of ye nortwest
during the regne of the foresaid dragon yt should be ladde by an ill greyhou^de
/ yt should the dragon crown king. that afterward should fle over ye see for
dread of the dragon without coming again. and that was proved by sir John^
Baylol ye king Edward made to be king of Scotlonde. ye falsely aroyse against
him* and after he fled to his own lands of France / and never he came again
in to Scotlond for dread of king Edward: And yet said Merly: that people yt
should led ye said greyhou^d should be faderles unto a certain time soth he
said. For the people of Scotlonde greatly were dysesyd after sir Johan baylol was
fled. And merlyn said the sone should become in his time as red as any blood
in tokenynge of great mortalyte of people And that was know well wha^ the
Scotts were slain. And sith said Merlyn / ye same dragon should nouryshe a
Fox. that should meue great werre against him / yt should not in his time be
ended / and that seemed well by Robert the Brus. that king Edward nourysshed
in his chamber that sythen stale a way and meued grett werre against him /
which werre was not ended in his time And yet said merlyn that the dragon
should deye in ye march of an other land / and that his land should be long
without a good keeper. And that men should were for his death from the isle of
Shephey unto the isle of Mercyll / wherefore alas shall be there song among the
common people faderles in the land wastyd And that prophecy was know over all
full well. For the good King Edward deyed at Burgh up sandys / that is upon
the March of Scotlonde the englyssmen were dysc^mferced and sorowed in
Northumberlonde / For cause that king Edwardes sone sete by the Scotts no
force. for the riot of Peers of Ganaston / wherefore alas was the song through
out all England / for defawte of their good wardeyne from ye isle of Shephey
unto the isle of Mercyll / the people made much sorrow for good king Edwardes
/ death. For they wend that good king Edward should have gone in to the holy
land / For that was holy his purpoos. Upon whoos soul god for his high and
Inginyte grace have mercy

Anno. dm^.M.CC.lxxxiiii.
CElestinus was pope after Nicolas five months / and nothing noble of him is
written / but that he was a virtuous man. Bonefacyus the eight was pope after
him.viii. year. This bonifacius was a man in those things the which
perteyneth to court for he was very expert in such matters / And because he
had no pere / he put no mesure to his prudence. And took so great pride upon
him that he said / he was lord of all the world. and many things he did with
his might and power^ the which failed wretchedly in the end / He yaue an
ensample to all prelatis yt they should not be have ne proud. But under the
form of a very shepeherde of god they shod ^ more study for to beloved of
other subgectes: tha^ dradde / This man is he / of whom it is said yt he entered
as a fox. He lived as a lion / and deyed as a dog. This time ye year of grace
was ordained from an hou^dred year to an hundred year. And the first Iubyle
was in the year of our lord Ihesu Christ a thousand three hou^dred Benedictus
the enleuenth was after Bonefacius.xi. months. This man was an holy man / of
the order of the friar prechers / and little while lived but dyssessyd anon.

ADulphus was Emperor.vi year / This man was earl of Anoxone / And this
Adulphus was not crowned by the pope / for he was slain in battle. Albertus
was Emperor after him ^x. year. This man was the duke of Astryr and first was
repreued of the pope / and after was confermed by the same pope for the malyces
of the king of France / ye which was an enmye unto ye chyrche^ and to ye
alberte the same pope yaue the kingdom of France as he did other kyngdoms.
But it proffyted not / for at ye last he was slain of his neuewe. Clemens was
pope after Benedictus almost.ix. year / and he was a great buylder of castles
and other things. And he dampnyd the order of Templaryes / and he ordained the
seven book of the Decretales / the which be called the questyons of
Clementyns. And anon after in a counseyle the which he held at Vyenna he
reuokyd the same book the which is successary Johan called again in corporyd it
and publysshyd it. This Clement first of all popes teanslatyd the popes set
fro Rome to Auinion / and whether it was done by the mocyon of god. or by the
boldenes of man diverse men meruaylle. John^ the ^xxii. was pope after bym.viii.
yrre. This man was all glorious / as for those things that were to be used
through the actyf life. And he publysshed ye Constytucyons of the clementynes and
sent the^ to all the vnyuersytees. And many saints he canonysed and these
fat bysshopryches he deuydyd and he ordained many things aye^ste the
pluralytae of benefyces / and many herytykes he dampened / but whether he was
saved or not our lord would not show to those be louyd very well. Henry
the.vii. was Emperor after Albert.v^ year / this Henry was a noble man in
war. and he coueyted to have peace by land and water. He was a glorious man
in battle. And never overcome with enmyes and at the last he was poysened
of a friar when that he howselyd him by receyuynge of the sacrament.

Of king Edward that was king edwardes sone.
ANd after this king Edward reigned Edward his sone / that was borne at
Carnriuan / and this Edward went him in tho France. and there he spowsyd
Isabell the kings daughter of france. the.xxv. day. of Ianuari at the
church of our Lady at Boloyne in the year of our lord Ihu^ Christ.M. CCC vii.
And the.xx. day of Feuerer the next year that came after / he was crownyd
solemply at westmestre of the Archebysshop of Caunterbury. And there was so
great press of people. that sire Johan Bakwell was slain and murdered. And
anon as the good king Edward was deed. sir Edward his sone king of
england. sent after Pers Ganaston in to Gascoyne / and so much louyd him / yt
he called him brother. and anon after he yaue unto him the lordshyp of
walyngforde. And it was not long after yt he yaue him therldom of Cornewaylle
against the lords will of england. And tho brought sir walter of langton
bishop of Chestre in to prison and durau^ce. in the toure of London. with two
knaves alonely him to serve. For the king was wroth with him / fore by cause
that sire water made complaynt on him to his fader / wherefore he was put in
prison in the time of Troylebaston. and the for said Pers of Ganaston made so
great maystreys. that he went in to the kings tresory in ye abbay of
westmestre / and took the table of gold with ye trestls of ye same and many
other rich Jewels / yt sometime were the noble and good king Arthurs / and took
the^ to a merchant that was called ameri of Frisco^bande / for he should bear
them over ye see in to Gascoyne. and so he went thens and they came never again
after wherefore it was a great loss to this land And when this Pers was
rychely auau^syd / he became so proud and so stowte. wherefore all ye great
lords of the reame had him i^dyspyte for his great berynge / wherefore sir
Henry Lacy earl of Nicholl. and sir Guy earl of warwyk ye which great lords /
the good king Edward sir Edwardes fader king of England / chargyd that Pers
of Ganaston should not come in to England for to bring his sone Edward in to
riot. And all the lords of England assembled them a certain day at the friar
prechers at London: And there they spoke / of the dishonor ye king Edward.
did to his reame and to his crown and so they assentyd all / both earls and
barons / and all the comyns that the for said Peers of Ganaston should be
exyled out of England for ever more / and so it was done / For he for swore
England and went in to Irlonde / and there the king made him cheyfteyne / and
governor of the land by his commyscyon. And there this Pers was cheyfteyne of
all the land / And did there all that him lykyd* and had power what he would
/ and that time were the templers exyled through all cristiantee. for by cause
that mine put upon them / that they should do things against the faith and
good believe. King Edward louyd Peers of Ganaston so much / that he might not
for bear his company. And so much the king yaue and behyght to the people of
England / that the exylyge of the foresaid Peers should be reuokyd at
Stamforde / through them yt him had exyled / wherefore Pers of Ganaston came again
into England / And when he was come again in to his land he despised ye
grettest lords of this land / And called sir Robert Clare Earl of Gloucetre
horesone. And the Earl of Nycholl sir Henry Lacy brustenbely / and sir Guy Earl
of warwyk the black hound of Arderne: And also he called ye noble earl Thomas
of Lancastre churl. / and many other scorns and shamys them said / and many
other great lords of Inglonde / wherefore they were to ward him full angry and
wroth and right sore anoyed. And in the same time deyed the Earl of Nycholl.
But he chargyed or yt he was deed / Thomas of Lancastre Earl that was his sone
in law that he should mayntene his quarrel against this same Peers of Ganaston
upon his blessing. And so it befell thorugh help of the earl Thomas of
Lancastre and all so of the Earl of warwyk that the foresaid sir Peers was
heeded at gauersich beside warwyk in the.xx. day of June. in the year of
grace.M.CCC. and.xii. wherefore the king was sore anoyed / and prayed god that
he might se that day to be avenged / upon the death of the forsayde Peers. And
so it befell afterward as ye shall here Alas ye time. For the foresaid Earl of
Lancastre and many other great barons were put to a pyteous death. and martred
for by cause of the forsayde quarrel. The king was to at London. And held a
parleament and ordained the laws of Symonde Mountforde / wherefore the earl of
Lancastre / and the Earls and all clergy of England. made an oath through
counseyll of Robert of wynchelse for to mayntene the ordynauntes for ever.

How Robert Brus came aye^ in to Scotlonde and gadryd a great power of / men
for to werre upon king Edward.
ANd when sire Robert the Brus that made him king of Scotlonde / that before
was fled in to Norway for dread of death of the good king Edward. And also
he herd of the debate that tho was in england between the kynhe and his
lordys. he ordained an host and came in to Inglonde in to Northumberlonde /
and clean dystroyed the country. And when king Edward herd this tyynges he
let assemble his host and met the Scotts at Edstreyelyn in the day of the
Natiuite of saint Johan Baptyst in the third year of his regne / and in the
year of our lord.M.CCC. and.xiiii. Alas the sorrow and loss that there was
done. For there was slain the noble Earl Gylbert of clare sir Robert Clefford
baron and the king Edward was scomfyted and Edmonde of maule ye kings
Steward for dread went and drowned himself in a fresshe river that is called
Bannokysborne wherefore they said in repreyf of king Edward for asmoche as he
louyd to go by water and also for he was dyscomfyted at Ba^nosborne / therefore
ye maidens made a song thereof in ye country of king Edward* and in this
manner they so^ge Mayde^s of England sore may ye morn / for tyt have lost
your le^mans at ba^nokysborne / with heuelogh. what wenyth the king of England
to have got Scotlond with rombylogh.

AS king Edmonde was dyscomfyted wonder sore and fast he fled with his
folk that were left alive and went unto Berwyk / and there held him. and
after he took hostages.ii. chyldern of the richesse of the town. And the king
went to London. and took cou^seyl of things that were needful to ye reame of
England And in ye same time it befell / that tho was in England a rybaude.
that was called Johan Ta^ner. And he yede and said that he was ye good king
Edwardes sone and let hem call Edward of Carnariua^. And therefore he was
take at Oxforde / And there he chale^ged friar carmes / church that king
Edward had give them which was the kings halle. And afterward was this
Johan ladde to Northampton / and drawn and hangyd for his falsnesse and or yt
he was deed he confessyd and said before all tho that were there. that the
devil beyhyght him that he should be king of England and that he had served
the devil three year.

How the town of Berwyk was take through treason / and how two Cardynales were
robbyd in England.
ANd on mydlente Sunday. in the year of our lord.M.CCC.xvi. Berwyke was lost
thorugh false treson of oon Pers of Spaldynge. the which Pers the king had
put there. For to help that same town with many burgeyses of the same town /
wherefore the children that were put in hostage thrughe the burgeyses of Berwyk
followed the kings march^^se many days fettred in strong yrens And after ye
time two Cardynalles in to England / as the pope had them sense for to makepe
as between England and Scotlonde. And as they went to ward Durham / for to
have sacred master Lowys of Beamont bishop of Durham they were take and
robbed upon the moore of wynglesdom / Of which robbery sir Gylbert of mytton
was atteynt and take and hangyd and drawn at London and his heed smytte of.
and put upon a spear / and set upon new gate / and the four quarters sent /
to four cytees of England. and that same time befell many myscheues in
England / for the poor people deyed in England for hungre / and so much and
so fast deyed. that vnethe me^ might bury them For a quarter of whete was
at.xl. shelynges* and two years and an half a quarter of where was worth.x.
marck^ and of time the poor people stole chyldern and ete them / and ete also
ye hou^des that they might take: and also horse and cattes And after there fell
a great myrreyne among bestes in diverse countrees of england during king
Edward lives time.

How ye Scotts robbyd Notu^berlonde.
ANd in the same time came the Scotts again in to England and dystroyed
Northumberlonde / and bre^^t and that land / and robbyd it / and slew me^
wymmen and children that lay in there cradyls / and brent also holy church /
and destroyed crystendome / and took and bare English mennys gods as they
had been sarasyns / or paynems. And of the wyckydnesse that they did / all the
world spoke of it.

How the Scotts would not a mende their trespass. and therefore Scotlonde was
enterdyted.
SO pope Johan the.xxii. after saint Petir herd of the great sorrow and m^che
y^ that the Scotts wrought he was wonder sorye / that crystendome was so
dystroyed thrughe the Scotts / and namely they destroyed so^ holy chyrches
wherefore the pope sent a general sentence under his bulls of l^ed unto the
Archebysshop of Caunterbury. And to tharchebysshoppe of york that if Robert ye
Brus of Scotlonde would not be Iustyfyed and make amends unto the king of
England Edward their lord / and make amends of his loss / and of his
harms that they / had done in England. And also restore the goods that they
had taked of holy church / that the sentence should be pronouncyd thorughe out
all England. And when the Scotts herd this / they would not leave their
malice / for the popes commandment wherefore Roberte the Brus. Iamys Douglas
