and Thomas Radulf earl of Moref and all tho that with them comyned or them
help in word or deed were accursyd in every church through out all England
every day at mass.iii. times And no mass should be song in holy church
through out all Soctlonde but if the Scotts would make restitucyon of the
harms that they had made unto holy church wherefore many a good pressed and
holy men therefore were slain through ye reame of Scotlonde / because they would
not sing mass against ye popys co^maundemet and against his will and to do and
fulfill the tyrauntes will.

How sire Hughe Spensers sone was made the kings chamberlayne. And of the
bataylle of Mitone.
ANd it was not long after ward / that the king ordained a parlemente at
york / And there was sir / Spensers sone made Chambrelayne. And the mean time
while the werre lasted / the king went again in to Scotlonde / that it was
wonder for to wit and beseged the town of Berwyk / but the scotts went
over the water at Sole wath. that was three mile from the kings host and
pryuely they stole a way by night / and came in to England / and robbyd and
dystroyed all that they might / and sparde no manner thing till that they came
unto york / and when the englysshmen that were left at home / herd these
tydi^ges / all tho that might traueyll / as well monks / prestes freres /
chanons / and seculers came and met with the Scotes at Myton up swale
the.xii. day of Octobre. Alas for sorrow / for the English husbonde men that
could no thing of yt werre kyllyd and drowned in an arm of the sea And the
cheyftyenes sire wyllyam of Melton Arche bishop of york and the abbot of
selby with there stedes fled / and came to york / and that was their own
folly / that they had that myschaunce. For they passed the water of Swale. And
the Scotts set a fire the sta^kes of hey and the smote there of was so huge /
that ye Englysshmen might not se ye Scotts. And wha^ the englisshmen were gone
over the water tho came ye Scotts with their wynge in manner of a shield / and
came to ward the Englyssme^ in array. And the Englysshemen fled. For ^neth
they had any men of armies. For the king had them almoost lost at the syege
of Berwyk / and the Scotts hobylers went between the bridge and the
Englysshmen / And when the great host them met / the englysshemen fled between
the hobylers and the great host. And the Englysshmen almoost were there slain
/ and he that might go over the water were saved / But many were drowned. Alas
for there were slain / many men of relygyon / seculers priests and clerks /
with much sorrow tharchebysshop escaped. and therefore the Scotts called that
battle the white battle.

How king Edward did all manner thing that sir Hugh Spenser wolde^
NOw as king Edward herd this tidings he remeued his sege from Berwyk and
came again into England. But Sir Hugh Spenser that was the kings Chamberlayne.
kept so the kings chamber. that no man might speak with the king. But he had
made with him a fret for to do all his need. and that over mesure. And this
Hugh bare him so stowte that all men had of him scorn and dyspyte. and the
king himself would not be governed / ne ruled by no manner of man but only by
his fader and by him. And if any knight of england had wodes maneyrs or
lands that they would coueyte anon the King must give it them or else the
man that ought it. should be falsely endyted of forfeyt or felony. And through
such doing they dysheryted many a bachelere / and so much land he gate that
it was great wonder and when the lords of enlonde saw the great couetyse and
falsnesse of sir Hugh Spenser the fader and of sir Hugh the sone / they come to
the gentle earl of lancastre / and axyd him of counseyll of the dysese. that
was in the reame / though sir Hugh Spenser and his sone. and in have by one
assente they made pryue assemble. at shirburne^ Elmede and they made there an
oath for to break and dystouble ye doing between the king and sir Hugh
Spenser and his sone upon their power. And they went in to the march of walys.
and dystroyed the land of the foresaid sir hughes.

How sir hugh Spenser and his fader were exyled out of Englonde^
SO when king Edward saw ye great harm and dystruccyo^ that tho Barons of
England did unto sire hugh Spensers land. and to his sone in every place
that they came upon the king tho through his counseyl ill exyled sir Monbraye.
sir Roger Clyfforde and sir Gosselyn Dauyll. and many other lords yt were to
them consent / wherefore the barons did tho more harm than they did before
/ and wha^ the king saw that ye barons would not sesse of their cruelte / the
king was sore adradde lest they would dystroy him and his reame for his
mayntenau^ce / but if he assented to them. And so he sent for the^ by his
letters that they should come to London to his parliament at a certain day as
in his letters were contained and they came with three bataylles / well Armyd at
al points. and every batayl had cotarmours of great clothe. And thereof the
right quarter was yelowe. with white bendes / wherefore ye parlemente was called
the parliament of the white bend. And in ye company was sir Hunfrey de bohoune
earl of Herford and sire Roger Clyfforde. sir Johan Monbray. sir Glosselyn
Dauyll. sir Roger Mortymer uncle of sir Roger mortymer of wygmore. sir Henry of
Trays sir John^ Gyffarde and sire Barthylmewe of Badelessemore that was ye
kings steward. yt the king had sent to Shyrborne in Elmede to ye earl of
Lancaster / and to all yt with him were for to trete of accord / ye him alyed
to the barons / and came with that company. and sur Roger Dammory and sir Hugh
dandale yt had spousyd the kings neces sister. and sir Gylbert of clare earl
of Gloucetre yt was slain in Scotlonde as before is said. And tho two lords
had tho two parties of the erldom of Gloucerte. and sur Hugh Spenser had third
party in his wives half / the third sister and tho two lords went to the
barons with all their power against sir Hugh their brother in law. And so there
came with them sir Robert Clyfforde sir Johan Mo^bray. sir Goselyn Dauyll. sir
Roger Mortymer of werk. sir Roger Mortymer of wykmore his neuewe. sir Henry
Trays sire Ioha^ Gyffarde. sir Barthylmewe of Bardesmore. with all their
company. and many other / that to them were consent. all the great lords came
unto westmestre to ye kings parlemente. And so they spoke and did. that both
sir Hughe Spe^ser the fader and also the sone / were out lauwed of england for
evermore And so sire Hugh the fader went unto Dover and made much sorrow /
and fell down upon the ground by the sea bank. a cross with his arms / and
sore weeping said Now fair England and good England to almighty god I the
betake And thryes kyssed the ground and wenyd never to have come ayen^ And
weeping cursyd ye time that ever he begat sir Hugh his sone. and said for him
he had lost all England. And tho in presence of the^ all that were about him
yaue him his cursee and went over see to his lands But Hugh the sone would not
go out of England / but held him in the sea. and his company robbyd.ii.
dromedores beside Sandwyth and took and bare a way all the godoes that was in
them to the value of.lx.M.li.

How the King exyled earl Thomas of Lancastre and all that held with him and
how the Mortymer came and yielded him to the king / and of all the lords.
IT was not long after that the king made sir Hugh Spenser the fader / and
sir Hugh the sone / come again in to England ayenste the lords will of the
reame. And soon after the king with a strong power came and beseged the
castle of Ledys. and in the castle was ye laby of Bladelesmore for cause that
she would not grant that castle to the queen Isabel king Edwardes wife but
the pryncypall cause was / for sir Berthylmewe was against ye king / and held
with the lords of England. and nevertheless the king by help and socoure of
men of London / and also of help of Southeren men gate the castle maugre of
them all yt were with in / and took with them all that they might find. And
when the barons of England herd these tidings / sir Roger Mortymer and many
other lords took the town of Brugge wroth with strenth. wherefore the king was
wonder wroth / and let outlawe Thomas of Lancastre / and Vmfroy de Bohoune
earl of Herforde and all tho that were assenting to the same quarrel. And the
king assembled an huge host and came against the lords of England wherefore the
Mortymers put them in the kings grace. And anon they were sent to the toure
of London and there kept in prison. And wha^ the barons herd this thing they
came to poutfert there that ye earl Thomas soiourned and told him how that
Mortymers both had yield them to the king. and put them in his grace.

Of the syege of Tykhyll.
SO when Thomas Earl of Lancastre herd this he was wonder wroth and all that
were of there company and greatly they were dyscomfyted / and ordained there
power together. and besyeged the castle of Tykhyll / But tho that were with in
manly defended them / that the barnos might not get the castle. and when the
king herd yt his castle was beseged he swore by god and by his names. that
the lege should be remeued. and assembled an huge power of people / and went
theder ward to rescowe the castle. and his power encresyd fro day to day.
when the earl of Lancastre and the earl of Herforde and the barons of there
company herd of this thing they assembled all their power and went them to
Burton upon trent and kept the bridge that the king should not pass over* but
it befell so on the tenthe day of March in the year of grace.M.CCC.xxi. the
king and the Spensers sir Aymer Valaunce earl of Penbroke / and Johan earl of
Araundell and their power went over the water and dyscomfyted therle Thomas
and his company^ And they fled to the castle of Tetbury and from thens they
went to Pountfret. And in that ^yage deyed sir Roger Daumore in thabbay of
Thebury. And in that same time the earl thomas had a traitor with hyme yt was
called Robert Holonde knight. that the earl had brought up of naught / and had
nourysshed him i^ his butrye. and had give him a thousa^de mark of land by
year. And so much the earl louyd him that he might do in the earls court all
that him lyked both among them high and low / and so craftly the theyf bare
him ayenste his lord / that he trustyd more upon him than any man on live. and
the earl had ordained by his letters for to goo in to the erledome of Lancastre
/ to make men arise to keep him in that vyage / That is to say.v. hundred men
of armies. But the false traitor came not there: no manner men for to warn ne
for to make arayse to help his lord. And when that the false traitor herd
tell yt his lord was dycomfyted at Burton upon Trent. as a falls traitor theyf.
stele a way and robbyd in Raue^sdele his lords men that came fro the
scomfyture. And took of them horse and harneys / and all that they had and slew
of them all that they might take / and came and yeldyd him to the king. when
the good earl Thomas wyste that he was so bytrayed. He was so abashed / and
said to himself / O almighty good how might Robert Holonde find in his
herteme to betray / sithe that I louyd him so much O god well may now a man
se by him yt no man may dysceyue a another rathar than he yt he trustyth most
upon. He has full evil yielded me my goodness and the worship yt I have to him
done and through my kyndnesse have him auau^cyd and made him high where yt he
was low. And he makyth me go from high unto low / but yet shall he deye an
evil death.

Of the scomfyture of Brurbrygge.
THe good Earl Thomas of Lancaste. Humfroy de Bohoune ele of Herford and the
barons yt with them were took counsel between them at ye frre prechers in
Pou^tfret. tho thought Thomas upon the traitor Roberte Holonde. And said in
repreyf / Alas Robert Holonde has me betrayed / and is the red of some evil
shred. And by the common assent they should goo to the castle of Dunstanbrughe
/ the which perteyned to therldome of Lancastre / and yt they should abide
there till that the king had for give them his male talente. But when the good
earl Thomas this herd / he answered in this manner and said. Lords said he /
if we go to wade the North / the Northen men woll say that we go to ward ye
scotts / so we shall be holden traitors / for cause of dystau^ce that is
between king Edward and Robert ye Brus that made him king of Scotlonde. And
therefore I say as touching my self that I will not go no ferder into the North
/ than to mine own castle at Pou^tfret. And when sire Roger Clyfford herd
this he arose up anon in wrath. and draw his sword on hye / and swore by
god almighty and by his holy names / but if yt he would go with them / he
should him slay there. the noble and gentle earl Thomas of Lancastre was sore
a ferde and said. Fair* syres I will go with you whether some ever ye me bydde.
Tho went they together in to the North / and with them they had.vii.C. men of
armies came to Burbryg. And when sir Andrew of Herkela that was in the north
country through ordinance of the king. For to keep ye country of Scotlonde /
herd tell. how yt Thomas of Lancastre was scomfyted and his company at Burton
upon trent / he ordened him a strong power / and sir symonde ward also that
was the shyref of york / and met the barons at burburgge. and anon they
brake the bridge that was made of tree And when sir Thomas of Lancastre. herd
ye sir Andrewe of Herkela had brought with him such a power he was sore
adradde. and sent for sir Andrewe of herkela / with him spoke. and said to
him in this manner sir Andrewe said he. ye may well understood that our lord
ye king. is ladde and mysgouerned by much falls counsel through sir Hugh Spenser
the fader and sir Hughe is sone: sir Johan earl of Aru^del / and through master
Robert Baldok a falls pylled clerk. yt now is in the kings court dwelling
wherefore I pray you that ye will come with us with all your power that ye
have ordained / and help to dystroie the venym of England. and ye traitors
that been therein. and we will give unto you all the best part of five Erldoms /
that we have and hold. and we will make unto you an oath. that we will never
do thing without your counsel / and so ye shall be left as well with as ever
was Robert Holande Tho answered sir Andrew of Herkela and said sir Thomas yt
would not I do ne consent thereto for no manner thing without the will and
commandment of lord the king / for them should I be holden a traitor for
evermore. And when that ye noble earl Thomas of Lancaster saw that he would
not consent to him for no manner thing sir Andrew he said will ye not consent to
dystroy the venym of the reame as we be consent at one word sir Andrewe I tell
the that are this year begoo^ / that ye shall* be take and hold for a
traitor. and more than any of you hold us now / and in worse death ye shall
deye than ever did any knight of England. And understand well / that ye did
never thing That sorer ye shall you repent. And now go and do what you good
lykyth / and I will put me in to the mercy of god. And so went the false
traitor tyrau^ce a falls forsworn man For through the noble earl Thomas of
Lancastre he received the armies of Chyualrye / and thrughe him he was made a
knight. Tho might men se archers draw them in that one side and in that other
and knights also. And fought tho together wonder sore. And also among all
other Humfroy de Boughon Earl of Herforde a worthy knight of renoune through out
all crystendom stood a fought with his enmyes upon ye bridge. and as the noble
lord stood and fought upon the bridge a theyf rybaude sculkyd under the bridge
/ and fyersly with a spear. smote the noble knight in to ye fu^dement / so yt
his bowellys came out about his fete there. Alas for sorrow and pity. For there
was slain the flower of solace and of comforth / and also of curteysye. And
Sir Roger Clyfforde a noble and a worthy knight stood ever and fought / and
well and worthyly him defended as a noble baron. But at the last he was sore
woundyd in his heed / And sir Wyllyam of Sullaynde. and sir Roger of Benfeelde
were slain at that battle. when sir Andrewe of Herkela saw that sir thomas
me^ of Lancaster / lassed and slakyd. anon he and his company came unto the
gentle knight sir Thomas and laid unto him in an high voice yield the
traitor yield the. The gentle earl Thomas of Lancastre answered then and
said Nay lords traitors we ben none and to you we will never us yield while
that our lives last But lever we had to be slain in our thruth than yield us
unto you. And sire Andrewe ^en gardyd upon sir Thomas and his company /
yellynge and cryenge like a wode wulf yield you traitors taken yield you / and
said with an high voys Beware syres yt none of you be so hardy upon life and
lymme to mys do Thomas body of Lancaster / And with that word the good earl
Thomas yede into the castle / and said knelynge upon his knees and turned his
vysage to ward the cross and said almighty god to the I yield / and holy I
put me unto thy mercy. and with that the vylaynes and rybaudes lept about him
on every side as tyrau^tes and wood tormentours and dyspoyled him of his
armoure and clothed him in a ^obe of ray^ that was of his squyres lyuetay ^ and
forth ladde him unto york by water. Tho might men see much sorrow and care
For the gentyl knights sledde on every side and ye rybaudes and the vyllayns
egerly. them dyscryed / and cried on high yield traitors yield you. And when
they were yelden they were robbyd and bounden as theuys. Alas the shame and
dyspyte that the gentle orde of knyghthode had there at that battle. And the
land was tho without law For holy church had tho no more creuereence than it
had be a burdell house / And in that batyall was the fader against the sone ^ and
the uncle against the neuewe. For so much unkindness / was never seen before
in England / as that time among folks of one nacyon. For one kynred had no
more pity of that other. than an hungry wulf has of a sheep / And it was no
wonder. For the great lords of England were not all of one nacyon / But were
medlyd with other naco^ns / That is for to say some / Brytons / some Saxons /
some Danys / some Pehypes / some Frenssemen / some Normans / some Spanyerdes /
some Romans / some Henaude some Flemynges and other diverse nacyons the which
nacyons accordyd not to the kind blood of England. And if so great lords
had be oonly weddyd to English people. Then should peace have been and rest
among them without any envy. And at that battle was Roger Clyfforde take.
sir John^ Mombray sir wyllyam Tuchy^ Sir wyllyam fitz wyllyam / and many other
worthy knights there take at that battle and Sir Hugh Dandell net day
after was taken and put in to prison / and should have be done to death if he
had not spousyd the kings nece / that was Earl Gylbertes sister of
Gloucestre ^ and anon after was sir Berthylmewe of Badelesmore taken at Stow
park a maneyr of the bishop of Lyncoln that was his neuewe and many other
barons and baronetters. wherefore was made much sorrow.

How Thomas of Lancastre was heedyd at Pountfret / and.v. barons hangyd and
drawn there
ANd now I shall tell you of the noble earl Thomas of Lancastre. wha he was
take and brought to york / many of the cite were full glade and upon him cried
with an hight voys O sir traitor ye be welcome. blessed be god for now ye
shall have the reward / that long ye have deserved. And cast upon him many
snow balls / and many other repreues they did him. But the gentle earl all
suffered / and said another o word nor other. And at the same time ye king herd
of this sco^fyture / and was full glad and Joyous / and in great have came to
Pou^tfret. And sir Hugh Spenser. and sir Hugh his sone / and sir John^ earl of
Arundell and sir Edmonde of wodestoke ye kings brother earl of Kent. and sir
Aymer of valaunce earl of Penbroke and master Robert Baldoke. a falls pyllyd
clerk / that was pryue / and dwelled in the kings court / and all came theder
with the king. And the king entryd in to the castle and Sir Andrewe of Herkela
a falls tyraunte through the kings commandment. took with him the gentle
Earl. Thomas to Pountfret and there he was prysoned in his own castle that he
had new made that stood ayenste the abbaye of king Edward. And sir Hugh
Spenser the fader and the sone cast and thought how and in what manner the good
earl Thomas of Lancastre should be deed / without Judgment of his perys.
wherefore it was ordained through the kings Iusticus that the king should put
upon him points of treason. And so it befell that he was led to bar before
the kings Justices bare heed as a theyf / in a fair halle in his own castle
yt he had made there in many a fair feste. both to rich and to poor. And
these where is Justices sir Hugh Spe^ser the fader. and Aymer of Balaunce earl
of Pe^broke / sir Edmonde of wodstok earl of Kent / sir Johan of Brytayne earl
of Rychemonde / and sir Robert Malemethrop Justice and sire Roberte him a
couplyd in this manner. Thomas court excludes you of all manner answer Thomas
our lord the king / puttyth upon you* that ye have in his land ryden with
baner dysplayed against his peace. as a traitor. And with ye word the gentle
earl Thomas with an high voice said / Nay lords forsooth and by saint Thomas I
was never traytoure The Justice said again tho. Thomas our lord the king
puts upon you that ye have robbyd his folk / and murdered his people as a
theyf. Thomas also the king puttythe upon you that he dysco^fyted you and our
people with his folk / in his own reame / wherefore. ye went and fled to
the wood as an outlaw* and thomas as a traytoure ye shall be hangyd by reason.
but ye king has foryeuen you that Judgment / for love of queen Isabell. And
Thomas reason would yt ye should be hangyd / but ye king has foryue you that
Judgment for by cause and love of your lygnage. But for asmoche. Thomas as ye
were taken fleenge / and as an outlawe. the king: woll that your heed shall
be smyten of / Anon have him out of prees and bring him to his Judgment.
When the ge^tyll knight Thomas had herd all these words / with an high voice
he cried sore weeping and said alas saint Thomas fair fader. Alas shall I be
deed thus Grant me now blessydful* god answer. But all auayled him no thing
For the cursyd Gascoyns put him hither and thither / and on him cried with an
high voys. O king Arthur most terryble and dredefull / well known and
showed now is thyn open traitor. And an evil death shall thou right anon
deye. Haste thou not right well deserved it. And then these cruel folk
set upon the good knyhht Thomas for very scorn an old chaplet that was all
to rent / yt was not worth an half penny. And after that they set him upon a
white palfroy full unseemly / and also all bare / with an old brydell. And
with an horrible noise they drove him out of the castle to ward his death /
and they cast upon him many balls of snow in dyspyte. And as the traitors
lad him out of the castle tho said he these pyteous words. And his hondes
held up on high to ward heaven Now the king of heaven give us mercy for the
erthly king has us forsaken and a friar precher went with him out of the
castle till he came to the place that he ends his life. unto whom he shroue
him all his life. And the gentle earl held the friar wonder fast by the
clothes and said to him Fair fader abide with us till yt I be deed. for my
flesh quakyth for dread of death. And the sothe for to say / The gentle earl
set him upon his knees / and turned him to ward the eest: but a rybaude that
was called Hygone of mos^^on set hand upon the gentle Earl and said in
dyspyte of him Sir traitor torn the toward the Scotts / thy foul death to
receive / and turned to ward the Nosth. The noble earl Thomas answered tho
with a mylde voys and said now fair lords I shall do your will And with that
word ye friar went from him sore weeping. And anon a rybaude went to him /
and smote of his heed / the.xi. Kalendas of Auerell. In the year of
grace.M.CCC. and.xxi. Alas that ever such a gentle blood should be don to
death withouten cause and reason. And traytoursly the king was counseylled /
when he through the false counseyll of the Spenser suffered sir Thomas his uncles
sone to be put to such a death / and so he beheeded against all manner of reason
/ And great pity it was also / that such a noble king should be dysceyued and
mysgouerned through counsel of the false Spensers / the which tho he mayntened
thrughe loselry against his honor and also his proffyte. For after ward there
fell great vengaunce in England. for by cause of the forsayd^ Thomas death.
when the gentle earl of his life was passyd. ye pryour and the monkys of
Pounfret gate the body of sir Thomas of the king and buried it before the
high awter on the right side. That same day that this gentle knight was deed
/ were hangyd and drawn / for the same quarrel at Pou^tfret sir Wyllyam Tuchet.
Sir Wyllyam. Fitz Wyllyam. sir werreyn of Isell. Sir Henry Bradborn / and sir
Wyllyam Cheyne barons al / and John^ page esquyrer. and soon after at york
were drawn and hangyd sir Roger Clyfforde / sire Johan of Mambray barons. and
sir Goselyne Devil knight. And at Brystowe were drawn and hangyd / Sir Henry
of wemyngton / and sir Henry Moun^torde barons And at Gloucerre were drawn and
hangyd sir John^ Gaffarde and sir Wyllyam of Elmebrughe barons / and at London
were hangyd and drawn Sir henry Ties baron. And at wynchelse sir thomas
Clepepyr knight. And ferthermore to tell of this cruel occyon at wyndsore
was draw and hangyd sir Fraunc^s walde^ham baron / and at Caunterbury was
drawn and handyg sir Berthylmew Badelesmore and sir Berthylmew of Asshe
bourucham barons and at Cardyf in walys sir Wylyam Flemmynge baron.

How king Edward went into Scotlonde with an hundrde thousand me^ of armies
/ and might not speed.
SO when king Edward of England had brought the flower of cheua^* unto their
death. through counsel and con^ente of sir Hugh Spenser the fader / and sir
Hughe the sone he became as wood as any lion* and what so ever the Spensers
would have it was done So well the king louyd them yt they might do with him
all thing that them lyked wherefore the king gaaf unto sir Hughe Spenser the
fader ye erldom of wynchestre and unto sir Andrewe of Herkela the erldome of
Cardoyll^ in preiudyce and in harming of his crown. And king Edward tho
through counsel of the Spensers dysheryted all them that had be against him in
any quarrel with Thomas of L^castre. And many other were dysheryted also / by
cause that the Spensers coueyted for to have their lands. And so they had all
that they would desire with wrong / and against all reason. Tho made the king
Robert Baldok a fal^e pylled clerk Chaunceler of England. through counsel of
the forsayde Spensers. And he was a false rybaude / And a coueytouse. And so
they counseylled the king much / that the king let take to his own ward
all the gooddes of the lords that were put wrongfully to the death in to his
own hand. And as well they took the goods yt were within holy church / es
the goods yt were without / and let them be put in to his tresoury in London
/ and let them call his for feytes. And by there counsel ye king wrought
for ever more he dysheryted them that the gods ought / and through there
counsel let arer a talegge of all the goods of England / wherefore he was
the rychest king yt ever was in England. after wyllyam Bastard yt comquered
England. / And yet thrughe counsel of them him semyd yt he had not enough.
But made yet every town of England for to find a man of armies upon their
own costs / for to go and werre upon the Scotts yt were his enmyes /
wherefore the king went in to Scotlonde with an houndred thousand men of armies
at wytsontyde in the year of our lord Ihesu Crist.M.CCC.xxii. But the Scotts
went / and hyd them in mou^teyns and in wodes and carried the Englysshmen fro
day to day / that the king might for no manner thing find the^ in plain
field / wherefore many Englysshmen that had lytyl vytaylles deyed there for hungre
wonder fast an suddenly in going and coming and namely tho that had been
against Thomas of Lancastre and robbyd his men upon his lands. when king
Edward saw that vytaylles failed him / he was wonder sore dyscomfyted.
because also yt his men deyed. and for he might not speed of his enmyes. So at
the last he came again in to England / and anon after came James Douglas and
also Thomas Radulph with an huge hooste into England in to Northumberlonde /
and with them the Englysshmen that were driven out of England / and came and
robbed the country / and slew ye people / and also burnt the twone yt was
called Northallerton and many other twones to york. And when the king herd
this tidings he let so mane all manner men that might trauyllee. And so the
Englysshmen met the Scotts at ye abbay of Beyghelande the.xv. day after
Mygelmas. en the same year above said / and the Englysshmen were there
dysconfyted. And at that dyscomfyture was take sir Johan of Brytayne Earl of
Rychmonde that held the country and the erldome of Lancastre and after he
paid an huge raunsonne and was let goo. And after that he went in to France
and came never after again.

How sir Andrewe of Herkelay was take and put to death / that was Earl of
Cardoil.
THen at that time was sir Andrew of Herkela / ye new was made earl of Cardoil
/ for cause that he had taken the good earl Thomas of Lancastre. He had
ordained through the kings commandment of England. for to bring him all the
power yt he might for to help ayenste the Scotts as the abbaye of Beglonde.
And when ye falls traitor had gadred all the people that he might and should
have come to the king unto the abbaye of Beyghelande / ye falls traitor ladde
them by a another country thrughe Copelonde. And thrughe therldome of Lancastre
/ and went through ye country and robbed and slew the folk all yt he might.
And ferthermore the false traitor had take a great sum of gold and silver of
sir James Douglas for to be against the king of England. and to be helping and
holding with the Scotts / through whose treason the king of England was
scomfyted at Beyghelande or yt he came thither. wherefore the king was to ward
him wonder wroth. and let pryuely enquere by the country about how yt it
was. And some men enquered and aspeyed / so at the last the trough was found
and sought. And he atteynte and take as falls traitor / as ye good earl Thomas
of Lancastre him told of yt he was pute unto death at his ta^ynge at
Burbrugge. and to him said. Or ye that were done he should be take and hold a
traitor And so it was as the holy man said. wherefore the king sent pryuely to
sir Anthony of Lucy / a knight of the country of Cardoil that he should take
sir Andrew of Herkela and put him unto the death. And to bring this thing
unto the end. the king sent his Commyssion so that this same Andrewe was
take at Cardoill and ladde unto the bar in the manner of an earl worthyly
arrayed / and with aswerde gyrde about him / and hosyd and sporyd. Tho spoke
sir Anthoyn in this manner sir Andrewe said he the king puttyth upon the for
asmoche as thou have be orpyd i^ thy dedys / he did to the much honor / and
made the earl of Cardoil. and than as a traitor to thy lord laddest the
people of his countere that should have help him at the battle of Beyghel and
and thou laddest them away by the country of Copelande / and through the
erldom of Lancastre wherefore our lord the king was dyscomfyted there of the
Scotts through thy treason and falsnesse and if thou had come by times he
had had the bataylle and treason thou dydest for ye great sum of gold and
silver that thou received of James Douglas a Scot the kings enmye And our
lord the king will / yt the order of knyghthode. by the which thou received
al thine honor and worship upon thy body be all brought to naught and thyn
estate vndoyne. that other knights of lower degree mow after beware / which
lord has the auaunted hugely in diverse countrees of England and that al
may take ensample by there lord after ward. truly for to serve. Tho
commanded he anon a knave / To hew of his spores of his helys / and after he
let break the serde over his heed. the which the king yaue him for to keep
and defend his land there with when he / made him Earl of Cardoyll. And after
he let him be unclothed of his furred taberde and of his hode / and of his
furryd cotes / and of his gyrdell. And when this was done / Sir Anthony said
then unto him. Andrewe said he Now art thou no knight But a knave / and
for thy treason the king will that thou shalt be hangyd and drawn and thy
heed smyten of / and thy bowels take out of thy body and burnt before the /
and thy body quartryd and thy heed sent to London / and there it shall stand
upon London bridge / and the four quarters shall be sent to four towns of
England / yt all other may beware and chastysed by yt And as Anthony said /
so it was done all manner of thing in the last day of Octobre. in the year
of grace.M.iii.C.xxii. year. And the son turned in to blood as the people it
saw / and that dured from the morn till.xi. of the cloak.

Of the miracles yt god wrought for saint Thomas of Lancastre / wherefore the
king let close in ye church doors of ye pryory of Pou^tfert / that no man
should come therein for to offer
ANd sone after that the good earl Thomas of Lancastre was martryd there was a
priest that long time had be blind / dremed in his sleep / that he should go
to ye hylle there the good Earl Thomas of Lancastre was done unto death / and he
should have his syghte again and so he dremed three nyghtes sewynge. and the
priest led him to the same hill and wha^ he came to ye place yt he was martryd
on deuowtly he made there his prayers / And prayed god and saint Thomas / that
he might have his sight again / And he was in his prayers he laid his right
ho^de upon the same that the good man was martryd on / and a drope of dry
blood and small sonde cleuyd on his hand / and there with stryketh his eyes.
And anon through the might of god and saint Thomas of Lancastre / he had his
sight again. And thankyd tho almighty god and saint Thomas. And when this
miracle was known among men / the people came thither on every side. and
knelyd and made their prayers at his tomb that is in the pryory of Pountfret
and prayed that holy martyr of socour and of help / and god herd there
prayer. Also there was a young child drowned in a well in the town of
Pountfret and was deed three day and three nyghtes. And men came and laid ye
deed child the said Thomas tomb the holy martyr / and the child arose from
death to life. as many a man it saw. And also much people were out of there
mind / and god sent them their mind again. thorough virtue of that holy man.
And god has give there also to cryppyls their going / and the crokyd their
ho^des and there feet / and two blind also their sight. and to many syke folk
there ^elthe of diverse maladyes for the love of this good martyr. Also there
was a rich man in Cou^dom in Gascoyne and such a malady he had that al his
right side rotyd and fell a way from him / that men might see his liver and his
heart and so he stanke / that uneath they might come nyghe him. wherefore his
friends were for him wonder sorry. But at the last as god would. they prayed to
saint Thomas of Lancastre / that he would pray almighty god for that prisoner
and behyght for to go to Pountfret for to do their pilgrimage / he thought
that the Martyr saint Thomas came to him. and anointed all his sike body / and
therewith the good man a woke and was all hole / and his flesh was restored
aye^ that before was ro^yd and fallen a way. For which miracle the good man
and his fre^des louyd god and saint Thomas evermore after. And this good man
came into England And took with him four fellows: and came to Pou^tfret to ye
holy martyr. and did their pilgrimage. and the good man that was syke came
thither all nakyd / saufe his preuye clothes. And when they had done. they
turned home again in to their own country. and told of the miracle where so
ever that they came. And also two men have been heelyd there of the mormale
through help of ye holy martyr / though that evil be hold in curable. And
when ye Spensers herd yt god did such miracles for this holy man they nolde
believe yt in no manner wyse^ / but said openly that it was great heresye /
such virtue of him to believe. and when sir Hugh Spenser the sone saw all this
doing / anon he sent his massager from Pountfret there that he dwelled to
king Edward yt tho was at Graven at scypton / for cause yt the king should
undo ye pilgrimage / And as the rybaude ye messager went to ward the king for
to do his message / he came by the hylle the^e the good martyr was done to
death. And in the same place he made his ordure / and when he had done. he
rode to ward the king and a strong flyre came upon him or that he came to
york / and tho he shed all his bowelles at his fu^dment. And wha^ sir Hugh
Spenser herd this tygynges / somdele he was adradde and thought for to undo
this pilgrimage if he might by any manner a way / and anon he went to the
king / and said that they should be in great sklaundre thrughe out all
crystendome / for the death of Thomas of Lancastre if yt he suffered ye people to
do there pilgrimage at Pou^tfret and so he counseled the king that he
commanded to shyt the church doors of Pountfret / in the wyche church ye
holy martyr was enteryd. and thus they did against all frau^chyses of holy
church so ye four year after might no pilgrim come to the holy body. and
because the monks suffered men to come and honor that holy body of saint
Thomas ye martyr. through counsel of sir Hughe Spenser the sone / and through
counsel of master Roberte Baldok the false pylled clerk. that was ye kings
chau^celes. the king consented yt they should be let to their wages / and
let make wardeyns over there own good long time / and through commandment
of the foresaid sir Hugh Spenser.xiiii. Gascoynes well armyd kept the hylle
there that the good man saint Thomas was don unto his death so that no pilgrim
might come by that way / Full well went he to have take crystis might and his
power and ye great boos of miracles / that he showed for his martyr saint
thomas through all crystendom And that same time the king made Roberte of
Baldok the false pylled clerk. through prayer of sir Hugh Spe^ser sone. was made
Chau^seler of England. And in ye same time was ye castle of walyngforde
holden against the king thrughe prisoners that weren within the castle for
saint Thomas love of Lancastre / wherefore the people of the country came and
took the castle of the prisoners wherefore sir John^ of Goldyngton knight and
sir Edmonde of Becche prisoners were taken and sent unto the king to Pountfrete
and there they were done in prison. and the foresaid Roger was sent unto york /
and there he was drawn and hangyd. And anon after sir Roger Mortymer of
wygmore brake out of the tour of London in this manner. The foresaid Roger herd
that he should be draw and hangyd at London in the morrow after say^ Laurence
day and on the day before he held a fair feast in the toure of London and
there was sire Stephen Segraue constable of the tour and many great men with
them and when they should soupe / the foresaid Stephen sent for all ye officers
of the tour. and they came and sowped with him / and wha^ they should take
there leave of him. and squyre yt was called Stephen* that was full preuy with
the foresaid Roger through his counsel. yaue them all such a drink that the
leest of them all slept two days and two nyghtes. and in the mean time he
escaped a way by water / by the thamys and went over the sea and held him in
France. wherefore the king was sore anoyed / and put the same Stephen out of
his Constabellary.

How the queen Isabell went in to France / for to treat of peace between her
lord ye king of England / and the king of France her brother.
THe king went tho unto London and there through counsel of sir Hugh Spenser
the fader. and of his sone and of master Robert Baldok a falls pylled clerk
his Chau^cheler. let sease to all the queen's lands into his hondes. and also
all ye lands that were sire Edwardes his sone. and were so put to their wagys
/ against all manner of reason. and that was through the falsnesse of the
Spensers. And when the king of france yt was queen Isabelles brother herd of
this falsnesse he was sore anoyed against the king of England and his false
counselors. wherefore he sent a letter to king Edward under his seale^ yt he
should come at a certain day to do his homage / and thereto he somoned him. and
else he should lose all Gascoyne. And so it was ordained in England through the
king and his counsel / that queen Isabel should go into France / for to treat
of peace between her lord and her brother. and that Olyuer of yngham should go
into Gascoyne / and have with him.vii.M. men armies and moo / to be Seneschall
and wardeyne of Gascoyne. and so it was ordained that queen Isabell / came into
France and with her went sir aymer of Valaunce earl of Penbroke that was
there murdered suddenly in apreuysege / but that was through gods vengau^ce for
he was one of the Iustycys that consented to saint thomas death of Lancastre and
would never after repent him of that wicked deed. And all that time sir Olyuer
of yngham went over into Gascoyne / and did much harm to ye king of
France and tho he gate again that king Edward had lost. and much more
thereto.

How king Edward sent sir Edward his sone the eldest in to France.
THe queen Isabell had but a quater of a year dwelled in France when sir
Edward her eldest sone axed leave tho for to go in to France / for to speak
with his mother / Isabel the queen / and his fader the king grauntyd him with a
good will / and said to him go my fair sone in goddys blyssynge and mine / and
think for to come again as hastily as thou may / And he went over the sea in
to France and the king of France his uncle received him with much honor /
and said unto him / Fair son ye be welcome / and for by cause that your father
come not to his homage. for ye duchye of Guyon / as his auncetours were wont
for to do. I give you that lordshyp hold it of me in heritage as all
manerauncetours did before you wherefore he was called duke of Guyon.

How the king exyled his queen ysabell and Edward her eldest sone.
AS king Edward of England herd tell how the king of France had give the
ducye of Guyon unto sir Edward his sone / without consent and will of him and
that is sone had received the duchye he became wonder wroth. and sent to his
sone by letter / yt they should come again in to England in all ye haste that
they might / And the queen Isabel and sir Edward her sone were wonder sore a
dradde of the kings menaced. and of his wrath / pryncypally for the falsnesse
of the Spensers / both of the fader / and also the sone. and at his
commandment they would not come wherefore king Edward was full sore anoyed /
and let make a cry at London / that if queen Isabell and Edward his eldest
sone / came not in England that they should be hold as our enmyes / both to
the reame and also to the crown of England and for that they nolde come into
england / but both were exyled the mother and her sone. When the quen herd
these tidings. She was sore adradde to be dystroyed / thrughe the false
conyectynge of the Spensers / and went with ye knights that were exyled out
of England / for saint Thomas cause of Lancaster that is to say sir Roger of
wigmore. sir wyllyam Trusell sir Johan Cromwell and many other good knights
wherefore they took their counsel and ordained among them / for to make a
marriage between ye duke of Guyhenne ye kings sone of England and ye earls
daughter of Henaude / that was a noble knight of name. and doughty in his time.
and if that thing might be brought a bowte then^e stood they trowynge with the
help of god and with his help to recover their heritage in England / wherefore
they were put out through the false cocnectynge of the Spensers.

How king Edward through counsel of the Spensers sent to the Douzephers of
France. yt they should help that ye queen Isabell and her sone sir Edward
were exyled out of France.
AS king Edward and the Spensers herd how that queen Isabell and sir Edward
her sone* had alyed them to the Earl of Henaude / and to them that were exyled
out of england for cause of thomas of Lancastre they were so sorry that they
wist not what for to do / wherefore sir Hugh Spenser the sone said to sir Hugh
the fader in this manner wise. Fader cursyd by the time and the counsel that
ever ye consented that the queen Isabell should goo in to France / for to
treat of accord between the king of England and her brother the king of
france for that was your counsel. for at that time for soch your wytt failed
/ for I dread me sore / leest through her and her sone we shall be dystroyed.
But if we take the better counseylle. Now fair syres understand / how
merueylous felony and falshede the Spensers ymagyned and cast. For pryuely they
let fill five barelles ferrours with silver / the so^me amou^tyd.v.M. pound.
and they sent those barelles over ^ee pryuely by an alyaunt / that was called
Arnold of Spain / that was a broker of London That he should go to the
Douzepers of France / that they should procure / and speak to the king of
France / that queen Isabell and her sone Edward were driven and exyled out of
France. And among all other things. That there were braught to ye death as
pryuely as they might but almighty god would not so / for when this Arnold was
in the high see / he was take wi^h Selanders that met him in the high see
and took him and ladde him to the earl of Henaude their lord and much Joy
was made for that taking. And at the last this Arnold pryuely stele a way
from thens. And came to London And of this taking and of other thyn^^s the
earl of Henaude said to the queen Isabell. Dame make you merry and be of good
there for ye be rycher than ye wened for to be / and take these five barelles
full of silver. that were s^^te to the Dourpers of France for to slay you and
your sone Edward. and think you hastily for to goo in to England / and take
with you Sire Johan of Henaude my brother / and.v. hou^dred men of armies. For
many of them of France in whom ye have had great trust done you for to
scorn. and almighty god grant you that grace your enmyes to overcome. The
queen Isabell sent tho through Henaude and Flaundres / for her souldyours / and
ordened her every day for to go in to England again / and so she had in her
company sir Edmonde of wodstok. that was earl of Kent. that was sir Edwardes
brother of Englde.

How king Edward let keep the costs by the sea. and let try all the
price men of armies and foot men through England.
AS king Edward herd tell ye quen Isabell and Edward her sone. would come
in to england / with a great power of alyau^tes. and with them yt were
outlawed out of england for there rebellyousnesse. he was sore a dradde to be
put down / and for to lose his kingdom wherefore he ordained to keep his
castles in walys as well as in England / with vytayllers and their appa^ylles /
and let keep his ryuers and also ye. and at ye feast of Decolacio^ of saint
John^ Baptyst ye Cytezyns of London sent to the king to Prochestre an.C. men of
armies. and also he commanded by his letters ordeyend / yt every hundred and
wepe^take ^otrye as well men of armies as men on foot. and yt they should be put
in.xx. so^me. and in an hundred so^me / And commanded ye all tho men were
ready when any shoute or cry were made / for to purpose and take the alyauntis
yt came in to England for to ben bme him the land for to put him out of his
kyngdon / And more over he let cry thorugh his patent in every fair and in
every market of England / yt the queen Isabell and sir Edward his eldest
sone. and the earl of Kent. yt they were take. and saufly kept without any
manner harm unto them doing / and all other manner people yt come with them.
anon smite of there hedys. without any manner raunsom taking of them. And what
man might bring sir Rogeres mortymer heed of wygmore. should have an hundred
pound of money for his trauall. And ferthermore he ordened by his patrent and
commanded to make. a fire upon every hill / beside the ryuers and in low
countrees. for to make high bekenesse of rymbre. That if it so were that the
alyuntes came unto land by night time that then^e the Inhabycauntys there
about should endeuoyr them self in goodly have to light and fire ye bekenes
that the country may be warned and come and mete there enmyes. And in ye time
deyed sir Roger Mortymyer his vcle in the toure of London.

How the queen Isabell and sir Edward duke of Guyhenne her sone came in to
London at her with / and how they did.
AS queen Isabell and sir Edward her sone duke if Guyhenne sir Edward of
wodstok earl of Kente / and sir John^ the earls brother of Henaude and there
company. dradde not the menace of ye king ne of his traitors for they trusted
all in goddys grace / and came to Her with in South floke ye.xxiii. day of
Septembre / in the year of grace.M.CCC.xxvi. And the queen and sire Edward her
sone sent letters to the Mayre and comynalte of London requyrynge them / that
they should be helping in the quarrel and cause that they had / that is to
say to dystroye the traitors of the reame. But none answers were sent again:
whe^fore the queen and sir Edward her sone sent a another patent letter under
the seases the tenor of which letter here folowyth in this manner. Isabell by
the grace of god queen of england / lady of Irlonde / and countess of Pountyf
/ and we Edward the eldest sone of the king of England. duke of guyon / earl
of Chestre of Pauntyf / and of moustroyl. to the Mayre and to all the
comynaltee of the cytee of London sendyth gretynge for asmoche as we have
before the time / sent to you by your letters / how we be come into this land
in good arraye and in good manner / for the manner / for the honor and profit
of holy church and of our dear lord ye king and all the reame with all the
reame with all our might and power / to keep / and mayntene / as we / and all the good folk of the foresaid reame are holden to do. And upon that we pray
you that ye would be helping to us in as much as ye may in this quarrel that
is for the comune profit of the foresaid reame / and we have had to this time
none answer of the forsayde letters ^ ne know not your mind in that party.
wherefore we send to you again and pray and charge you chat ye bear you so
ayenste us / that we have no cause to grieve you / but ye ye ben unto us
helping by all the ways that ye may or may know / For wit ye well in
certain that we and all that be come with us into this reame / think not to do
any thing. but that thing that shall be for the common profit of all the
reame / but oonly to destroy Hugh Spe^ser our enmye and enmye to all the reame
as ye it well know. wherefore I pray you / and charge you in ye faith that ye
owe unto our lyege lord ye king and to us / and upon all that ye shall mow for
fair again us. that if the said spenser our enmye come within your power / that
ye do him hastily to be take / and saufly keep until ye have ordained of him
our will and ye ye leave it not in no manner wise as ye desire honor and profit
of us all and of all ye reame. Understanding ye right well that if ye do this
our prayer and streyghte commandment / we think us so much the more
beholdynge unto you. And also ye shall get you worship and also profit. if ye
send as hastily answer of all your will again at Baldok the syxte day of
Octobre. which letter in the dawning of the day of saint Denis / was tackyd
upon the new cross in Chepe / and many topyes of the same letter were tackyd
upon wyndowes and doors and upon other places in the cite of london / that all
men passing by the way might them read and se / And in the same time king
Edward was at London in the toure at his mete / And a messager came in to the
halle and said / that the queen Isabell was come to land at Herewhiche. and
has brought in her company sir Johan of Henande and with him me^ of arms
without nombre. And with that word sir Hugh Spenser ye fader spoke / and thus
unto the king said. My most worshypfull lord and king of England now make
good chere for certainly they ben all ours. The king saw this word
comfortable. yet he was fulle sorrowful and pensyf in his heart And the king
had not fully eten but there came in to the halle a another messager / and said
that the queen Isabell was arrived at Her which beside ypswytche in Soutfolke
Sir Hugh Spenser the fader spoke to the messager and said / Tell sothe in good
faith my fair friends: is she come with a great strenth. Now c^^tes the sothe
for to say sir said the messager. She ne has in her company but v^. hou^derd
men of armies. And with that word sir Hughe Spenser the fader cried with an
high voice and said / Alas alas we ben all betrays. Fortes with so little
power she had never come to land / but if folk of this lord were unto her
concente. And therefore after there mete they took counsel. and went to ward
walys for to arere the walsshmen against the queen Isabell and Edward her sone
/ all for to right and so they were in purpose every chone.

How master water Stapylton bishop of Excetre that was ye kings tresorer was
heedyd at London
ANd in the same time king Edward was sore adradde. leest that men of london
would yield them unto the queen Isabell And to her sone Edward / wherefore he
set master walter Stapylton his tresorer for to be wardeyne / and keeper of
the cite of London / with the Mayre / And so came to the Gyldeha^^e of London:
and axed the keys of the yates of the Cite / thrughe virtue and strength of his
commyssyon and would have had the keeping of the cite And ye comuners answered:
and said that they would keep the cite to the honor of king Edward and of
Isabell the queen / and of ye duke the kings sone without any more. the
bishop tho was sore onoyed / and swore oaths / they all should abye it anon
as the king Edward were come out of walyes. And ye comuners all anon of the
cite took ye bishop and lad him anon amyddes of the Chepe / and there they
smote of his heed / and set his heed in his right hand And forth with the same
comyns of the cite of London by heedyd two of his squyres yt held with the
bishop / and one of them was called wylliam of wayle / yt was the bishops
neuew And that other was called John^ of Padynto^. And also they took a burgeys
of London yt was called John^ Mershall. that was sir Hugh spe^ser espy the
fader and smote of his heed also: and in that same time ye bishop had in
London a fair toure in making in his close / upon the river Temse yt was
without temple bar / and he failed stone to make thereof an end and he
commanded his men to go the friar Carmes / and there they took stone to make
there with the toure / and much sonde and mortar and old robous that was left.
And for the dyspyte the bishop had done unto holy church / he and his two
squyres were buried in that sonde. As though they had been hounds / and there
they lay.xi. wekes till that the queen Isabell sent her letters to the
comuners / and prayed them that they would suffer and grant. that the bishop
might be take out of that place / and be buried at Excetre at his own church
And so he was / and his two squyres were buried at saint Clementes church
without temple bar. And it ^ was no wonder though that bishop deyed an
evil death. For he was a coueytous man and had with him no mercy / and evil
counseylled the king. And soon after was Arnold of Spain take. that asse^tye
to lead the.v.M.li. of silver in five barelles feryers unto ye douzepers of
France / for to help and haste the queen Isabell to her death. And Edward her
sone also. and this Arnold was put to death without the cyte^

How king Edward and sir Hugh Spenser and the earl of Arundell were taken.
AS king Edward had sent master walter Stapylton / his tresorer in to
London / for to keep the cite unto him against the queen Isabell his wife / and
against Edward his sone anon himself took with him sir Hughe Spenser the sone.
and sir John^ of Arundell and master Robert Baldok his Chaunceler a falls
pylled clerk and took their way to ward Brystowe / And there the king abode
a little time / and made sir Hugh Spenser the fader as Conestable and keeper of
the castle. Ane the king and that other Spenser went to ship / and saylled
to ward walys / and took no leave of the kings Steward / ne of none of the
kyngys household / and went over in to walys for to arere the walsshmen against
dame Isabell the queen and the duke her sone / And the earl of Kente / and sir
John^ Henaude / And he went and pursued after them / And their power encreacyd
every day / So at the last the king was taken upon an hill in walys / and
Sir Hugh Spenser the sone in that othersyde of ye same hylle / and the false
pylled clerk master Robert Baldok there fast beside them. And were brought
again in to England / as almighty god would / And the king himself was put in
sauf keeping in the castle of Kenylworth / and him kept sir Henry yt was saint
Thomas brother of Lancastre / and sir Hugh the fader came and put him in the
queen's grace and Edward her sone duke of Guyon / but sir Hugh Spenser after ye
time that he was take. would never eete no more meet ne drink no manner drink
/ for he wyste to have no mercy / sauf only to be deed. And the queen and her
counsel had ordained / that he should have be done to death at London. But he
was so feeble for his much fasting yt he was nygh deed and therefore it was
ordained. yt he should have his Judgment at her forde. and at a place of the
toure his heed was take from his body and also fro Robert Baldok yt was a falls
pylled clerk and the kings chaunceler. And men set upon their heedys
chaplettys of sharp netles / and two squyres blewe in there eerys / with two
great bugle horns / upon the two prisoners. that men might here there blown
out with horns more than a mile. and one Symond of Riding ye kings Marshall
bare before them upon a spear there armies reuersyd / in token / that he should
be undone for evermore. And upon the morrow was sir Hughe Spenser the sone
dampened to death and was drawn hangyd and heedyd. and his bowels taken out of
his body. and brent. and after yt he was quartred / and his four quarters were
sent to the four towns of England / and his heed sent to London bridge / And
this Symond for cause yt he dyspysyd queen Isabell / he was drawn and hanged
in a stage made a mids the foresaid sir Hughes galowes. And the same day a
little from thens was sir Johan of Arundell be heddyd by cause he was one of
sir Hugh spensers counselers. And anon after was sir Hughe Spenser fader
hangyd and drawn / and heedyd at Brystow / and after hangyd aye^ by the armies
with two strong ropes. and the fourth day after he was hewn all to pecys /
and hounds ete him. And because that ye king had yeuen him ye erldom of
wynchestre his heed was sent thither and put upon a spear / And the false Baldok
was sent to London and there he deyed in prison among thieves / for men did him
no more reverence / than they would do unto an hounde. And so deyed the
traitors of England blessed be almighty god. And it was no wonder. for thrughe
there counsel the good earl Thomas of Lancastre was doo^ unto death and all
that held with Thomas of Lancastre through ye traitors were undone and all
their heirs dysheryted.

How king Edward was put down / and his dygnyte take from him.
ANd anon after as all this was done. the queen Isabell and Edward her sone
and all the great lords of England at one assente / sent to king Edward to
the castle of Kenylworth / there as he was in keeping under the ward of sir
Johan Hachin. that was the bishop of Ely. and of sir Johan of Pereye a baron /
for because that he should ordeyne his parliament at a certain place in England
for to redress and amend the state of ye reame. And king Edward them
answerde and said Lords said he ye se full well how it is. Lo here my seal /
and I give to you all my power for to call and ordeyne a parliament where that
ye will. And then they took their leave of him and came again to the barons of
England / And when they had the kings Patent of this thing / they showed
it to the lords. And tho was ordained / that parlemente should be at
westmestre. at the Vtas of saint Hylary / And all the great lords of England
let ordained them there against that time that the parliament should be And at
which day ye parliament was the king would not come there for no manner of
thing / as he had sete hy^ self and assygned. And nevertheless the barons sent
unto him oo time and other. And he swore by goddys souie. that he would not
come there oo foot wherefore it was ordained by all the great lords of England
/ that he should no longer be king / but be depesed And said / that they would
crown Edward his sone / the elder / that was ye duke of Guyhenne. And sent
tidings unto the king there that he was in ward under sir Johan Earl of
Garen. and sir John^ of Bothun. that was bishop of Ely / and sir Henry Percy a
baron / and sir wyllya^ Trusell a knight / that was with ye Earl sire Thomas of
Lancastre ^ for to yield up there homages unto him for all them of England.
And sir wyllyam trussell said these words. Sir Edward for cause that he have
trayed your people of England and have undone many great lords of England
without any cause / ye shall be deposyd / and now ye be with stand thankyd be
god / And also for cause that ye would not come to the parliament as ye ordained
at westmestre / as in your letter patent is contained / for to treat with
your own lyege men as a king should. And therefore thrughe al ye comyns
assente / and all the lords of England / I tell unto you these words * ye
shal^e understood sir / that ye barons of England at one assente / will that
ye be no more king of England but utterly have put you out of your ryalte
for ever more / And the bishop of Ely said tho to the king sir Edward I
yield up feaute and homage for all the Archebisshops and bishops of England
and for all the clergy Tho said sir Johan earl of Garenne sir Edward I yield
up here unto you feaute and homage for me and for all the earls of England.
And sir Henry Percy yaue up also his homage for him and for all the barons of
England. And tho said sir wyllyam Cruscell / I yield up now unto you mine
homage for me and also for all the knights of England and for all them that
hold by seryau^tre. or by any other thing of you so that from this day after
ye shall not be clamyd king / another for king be hold for a synguler man of
all the people. And so they went thens to London that the lords of England
them abode / and sire Edward abode in prison in good keeping / And this was on
the day of the Conuersyon of saint Poule in the.xx. year of his regne.

Of the prophecye of Merlyn declared of king Edward the sone of king Edward
the first.
OF this king Edward prophesied merlyn and said that there should come a got
^t of Carre that should have horns of silver and aberde as white as snow. And
a drope should come out of his nosethrylles / yt should betoken much harm
Hungre / and death of people and great loss of his land / And that in the
beginning of his reyge should be hau^ted much lechery. And he said sothe.
alas ye time For king Edward yt was king Edward sone was borne at
Carnaryuane in walys for sothe he horns of silver: and a berde as white as
snow when he was made prince of walys to much he yaue him to riot. and to
folly And so much Merlyn in his prohhecye yt there should come out of his nose
a drope. For in his time was great hungre among the poor people / and strong
death among the rich / yt deyed in strange land with much sorrow / and in
were in Soctlonde. And after he lost Scotlonde and Gascoyne / and while that
himself was king there was much lechery hau^tyd. And also Merlyn told and
said that this got should seek the flower of life and of death and he said sothe.
For he spowsyd Isabell the kings sister of France And in his time Merlyn said
/ that there should be made brydges of folk upon dyches of ye see / and that
was well seen at Bannockysborne in Scotlonde when he was dysco^fyted there of
the Scotts / And Merlyn told also that stones should fall from castles. and
many towns should be made plain. And he said sothe / For when that king
Edward was dysco^fyted in Scotlonde and came tho south ward / ye Scotts
besegyd the castles / and did them much harm and brent towns in to the
herd earth And after ward Merlyn told that an Egle should come of Corn wayle
/ that should have feders of gold / yt of pride should have no pere and he
shield despise lords of blod and after he should dey through a beer at
Gauersych and that prophecye was full well know and funde sothe For by the
egle understand sir Pers of ganaston that tho was earl of Corn wayle yt was a
wonder proud man that despised ye baronage of England. but after ward he was
heeded act Gauersich thrughe the earl of Lancastre and through therle of warwyk.
And merlyn told / that in his time it should seem that the beer should brenne
and that battle should be upon an arm of the sea in an field / arrayed like a
shield where should deye many white hedes. And he said sothe. For by the
brynnynge of the beer yt betokenyd great dread through kyttyng of swerdes at
that bataylle of Myton / for there came the Scotts in manner of a s^elde / in
manner of a wynge and slew men of relegyon prestes and seculers / wherefore the
Scotts called that battle in dyspyce of the Englyssmen / the which battle.
And after Merlyn said the forsayde beer should do the got much harm. and
that should be upon the south west. and also upon his blood / And said also /
that the got should lose much deal of his land. till the time ye shame
should him over come / and them he should clothe hm in a lions skyn^e should
win again that he had lost and more through people that should come out of the
Northwest / that should make him to be a ferde. And him avenge upon his enmyes
through counsel of two owls / ye first should be in pa^yll to be undone. And
that tho two owls should go over see in to strange land. And there they should
dwell unto a certain time. and then they should come in to England again /
And tho owls should do much harm unto many one. And that they should
counsel the got to meue war against the foresaid beer. And the got and the
owls. should to an arm of the sea at Burton trente / and should go over / and
that for dread the beer should flee with a swanne in company to Bury toward
the. North. through an unkind outpulter / and that the swanne then^e shall be
slain with sorrow / and the beer should be slain full nyghe his own nest.
that should stand upon pounfret / upon whom the son shall shede his beemes.
And many folk him shall seek for virtue. And he said sothe. For the good earl
Thomas of Lancastre was borne in ye Northwest And cosyn to the king. and his
uncles sone. and by law he made the king lose much land / the which he had
purchacyd wylfully. till at the last the king took thereof shame / and him self
slew with cruelte And after he gate again that he had lost / and much more
through folk that he ^ette assemble out of ye Northwest / tha^ made him to be
adradde. And auengyd him on his barons / through counsel of sir Hugh Spenser
the fader / and of sir Hugh the sone that before were outlawed for their
wyckydnesse^ But afterward they came again in to England / sir ^e wer^^ upon
Thomas of Lancast^^. So yt the king and the Spensers and the earl of Arundell
and their power met with Thomas of Lancastre (...) Burton upon trente / and
him there dyscomfyted and sir Vmfroy earl of her forde was in his company. And
after fled ye foresaid Thomas and Humfroy with their company to burbrugge
metinge with sir Andrew of Herkela / that is called the unkind outpulter / and
also sir* Symonde ward earl of york came and met with Thomas of Lancastre
with an huge power / and the^ dyscomfyted and in that scomfyture the earl of
Herforde was slain upon the bridge cowardly with spear in the foundement. and
the earl Thomas was take and ladde unto Pou^fret. and tho was heedyd beside his
own castle. But afterward many him sought for miracles that god did for
him. And in that time Merlyn said. for sorrow and harm should deye a people of
his land / wherefore many lands should be upon him the more bolder / and he
said sothe for because of his barons that were done to death for saint Thomas
quarrel of Lancastre. people of many lands became the bolder / for to meue
werre upon the king / for their blood was turned to many nacyons. And
afterward Merlyn told and said that the foresaid owls should do much harm
unto the flour of life and death / and they should bring her to much / dysese.
So that she should go over see into France. for to make peace to the flower
delight. and there should abide till a time her sede should come and fetch her
/ and tho they should abide both till the time that they should clothe them
with grace / and tho two owls she should seek. And put the^ to pyteuous death.
And that prophecy was full well know. and was full sothe / for sir Hugh
Spenser the fader. and sir Hugh the sone / did much sorrow and persecucyon
unto ye queen Isabel through their procurement to her lord the king / So they
ordained among them. that she was wagys. That is to say.xx. shelynges in the
day wherefore ye king of France her brother was sore anoyed. and sent into
England by his letters unto king Edward to come unto his parliament to Paris
in France. But king Edward was sore adradde to come there / for he wend to
have be arestyd till yt he had made amends for the trespase ye sir Hugh
Spenser the fader and the sone had done and for ye harm that they had done
unto queen Isabell h^^ sister / wherefore thrughe his ordinance and consent of
the. Spensers. the queen Isabell went over see in to France for to make
accord between king Edward and the king of France her brother. And there
dwelled she in France till Edward her Eldest sone came her for to seek / and
so they dwelled there both till that alyaunce was made between the^ and the
gentle earl of Henaude / that if they with there virtue might dystroye and
overcome the venym and the falsnesse of the Spenser / that sir Edward should
spowse dome Phylyp the worshypfull lady / and the earls daughter of Henaude /
wherefore the queen Isabel and Edward her sone / and sir Edward of wodstok the
kings brother of England / and sir John^ of Henaude / and sir Roger Mortymer
of wygmore / and sir Thomas Rocelyn and sir Johan of Cromwell and sir wyllyam
Trussell / and many other of the alyaunce of the gentle earl Thomas of
Lancastre / that were exyled out of England for his quarrel / and were
dysheryted of their lands / ordained / them a great power / and arrived at
Here with in South folk / And soon after they pursewed ye Spense^s till that
they were taken and put pyteuous death as before is said. and their company
also for the great falsnes yt they did to king Edward to his people. And
Merlyn said also more that the got should be put in great distress and in
great angusshe and in grte sorrow he should be led his life / and he said sothe
For after the time that king Edward was take he was put into ward till that
the Spensers were put to death / and also because that he would not come unto
his parliament at. London as he had ordained and assygned himself unto his
baronage / and also would not govern. and rule his people / ne his reame as a
king should do. Wherefore some of the barons of England came and yield up
there homages unto him / for them and all the other of the reame. in the day of
the co^uersyon of saint Poule in the year of his regne.xx. And they put him out
of his ryaltee for evermore / And ever lived afterward in much sorrow and
anguysshe.

LOdowicus was Emperor after Henry four^ year. this Lodowicus was duke of
Banare and he despised the coronacio^ of ye pope wherefore ye pope hy^ / and
much labor and deposyd many perils he had aft. and he trowbled greatly the
unity of holy church. And the^ was chosyn against him Frederyk ye duke of
Ostryche. and he over came the duke and abode a rebelyon to his end. and in
great peril to his soul / And at the last Karolus was chosyn against him / the
which preuaylled / and suddenly Lodowic fell down of his horse and dyscessyd.
John^ Mandeuyll a douctour of physyk and a knight borne was in England abowte
this time. And he made a merueyllous pilgrimage. For he went almoost abowte all
the world And he wrote his dedys in three langages. and decessyd^ and was
buried at Saint Albons. Benedictus the.xxii. was pope after John^.vii. years
and more / this man was a monk / and in all his ynogthe he was of good
conuersacyon / and a doctor of dyuinite. And when he was made pope he
reformed thorder of saint Benet in that thing yt was nescessary / and he was
a hard man to grant benefyces / lest he had grau^tyd it to an vncunnynge man
/ he made a decretall / the which began (Benedictus deus in donis suis) And he
was very cruel in faith / and for that of sommen little louyd / he was so
stout a man that almoost he would not know his own cosyns.

Anno dm^.M.CCC.xxii. Of king Edward the third after the Conqueste.
ANd after this king Edward Carnariuan reigned sir Edward of wyndsore his sone
/ the which was crowned king / and anointed at westmestre / through counsel
and consent of all the great lords of ye reame. the Sunday in Candelmasse
eve. in the year of grace. M.CCC.xxvi. that was of aege at that time but.xv.
year. And for cause yt his fader was in ward in the castle of Kenilworth and
also was put down of his ryaltee / the reame of England was without king from
ye feast of saint Katheryn from the year above said to the feast of
Candelmasse. And tho were all manner plees of the kings bynche astente. And
tho was commanded to all the Shyrefs of England thrughe writ to warn the
parties to defendau^tys / through somnynge again. And also ferthermore / that all
prisoners yt were in the kings gayolles / that were attachid through Shyrefs
should be let go quyte. The king Edward after his coronacyon / at the prayer
/ and besechynge of his lyege of ye reame grau^tyd them a chartre of steadfast
peace to all them that would it axe / And sir Iohnn of Henaude. and his company
took his leave of the king and of the lords of the reame. and tornyd home to
their own country again. And each of them hade full rich yeftes. every men as
he was of value and estate. And tho was England in rest and peace / and great
love between the king and his lords. And comynly englysshmen said among them
that the devil was deed but the innumerable / tresour of the king his fader /
and the tresour of the Spensers / both of the fader and of the sone / and of
the earl of Arundell / and of master Robert Baldok that was the kings
chau^celer was departed after the queen Isabelles ordinance and sir Roger
Mortymers of wygmore / so that the king had no thing thereof. but at her
will and her delyuerrau^ce / ne of their lo^des as afterward ye shall here.
How king Edward went unto sta^thop for to mete ye scotts.

ANd yet in the same time was the King in the castle of kenilworth under the
keeping of sir Henry / yt was earl Thomas of Lancastres brother. that tho was
earl of Leycetre. And the king grau^tyd him ye erldome of Lancastre / that ye
king his fader had seasyd in to his hand and put out Thomas of Lancasters
brother. and so was he earl of Lancastre and of Leycetre / and also Stywarde of
England as his brother was in his time But sir Edward that was king Edwardes
fader made sorrow without end / by cause he might not speak with his wife. ne
with his sone / wherefore he was in much myscheyf / For though it was so that
he was led and ruled by falls counseyll / yet he was king Edward^ sone called
Edward with the long shankys / and came out of the worthyest blood of the
world. and they to whom he was wont to give great yeftes and large. were most
pryue with the king his own sone / and they were his enmyes both night and
day / and procured to make debate and contake between him and his sone / and
Isabell his wife But the friar prechers were to him good fre^des ever more and
cast both by night and by day. how they might bring him out of prison. And
among their company that ye freres had privily brought / there was a friar yt
was called / Dunhened ^ and he had ordained and gadryd a great company of folk
to keep at that need / but ye friar was taken and put in (...) of Pountfret /
and there he deyed in prison / and sir Henry earl of Lancastre / that had ye
kings fader in keeping / through co^mau^deme^te of the king. delivered Edward
ye kings fader by ende^ture of sir Thomas of Berkelay. And so sir John^
Matreuas and they ladde him from ye castle of kenylworth to the castle of
Berkelay / and kept him there saufly. And at Ester next after his coronacyon:
the king ordained a great huge host / for to fight against the Scotts And sir
John^ the earls brother of Henaue came from beyond the sea / for to help
king Edward / and brought with him.vii.C. men of armies and arrived at Dover
/ and they had leave for to go forth till they came to york There the king
them abode / and the Scotts came thither to ye king / for to make peace and
accord / but the accordement lasted not between them bat a little time And at
that time ye Englysshmen were clothed al in cotes and hodes painted with
letters and with flowers full semely with long berdes and therefore the Scotts
made a byl that was fastenyd upon ye church doors of Saint Petyr toward
stangate. and thus said ye scripture in dyspyte of Englysshemen Long berdes
hertles / prynted hodes wytles gay cotes graceles / makyth England thryftles

SO in the Trinyte day next after began the contak in the cite of york
between the Englysshmen and ye Henaudes: and in ye debate were slain of ye
erldom of Nicholl and murdered lxxx. men. and after they were buried in saint
clementis church in Folgate. and for cause that the Henaudes came to help the
king. there peace was ^ryed upon pain of life and lymme. in that other half it
was found by an enquest of the city that the Englysshmen began the debate.

How the Englysshme^ stoppyd the Scotts in the park of Stanope and how they
turned again into Scotlonde.
This time the Scotts had assembled all their power and came into England and
slew and robbyd all yt they might take and brent and dystroyed all the North
country through out / till that they came unto the park of S^a^hope in
weridale / and there ye Scotts held them in a bussment / but wha^ ye king
had hard thorou spies where ye Scotts were anon right host desegyd them
within the foresaid park so that ye scotts wist not where to go out but only
unto there harms. And they abode in the park.xv. days / and vytaylles faylled
them in every side. so that they were greatly peyred of bodies and sith that
Bruce came first into Brytayne unto this time / there was never seen so fair
an host / what of Englysshmen / and of alya^ces and of men of foot / the
which ordained them for to fight with ye Scotts / through eggynge of sir
Henry of Lancastre and of sir Johan Henaude. yt would have gone over the water
of with for to have fought with the ^ Scotts. But sir Roger Mortymer co^sentyd
not thereto / for he had pryuely taken mede of the Scotts them to help that
they might go away into their own country. And this same Mortymer counseylled
somoche Thomas of brotherton ye earl Marshall that was king Edwardes uncle.
that ye foresaid Thomas should not assemble at ye time unto the Scotts. And he
assentyd. but wyste not the doing between the Scotts and the foresaid Mortymer
/ And by cause yt he was Marshall of England / as to him perteyned ever after
ward. he sent hastily to the earl of Lancastre / and to sir John^ of Henaude /
yt they should not fight with the Scotts / in preiudyce and harming of him
and his fee / and if they did that they should stand to their own paryll.
And the foresaid earl Marshall was all arrayed with his battle. at the reredoos
