of the earl of Lancastre / for to have fought with him and with his folk if he
had go to fight with the Scotts / and in this manner he was deceived and wyste
no thing of the treason And thus was the king pryncypally dysceyued. And when
it was night Mortymer / yt had the watch for to keep of ye host / that night
distrobled ye watch yt no thing might be done. And in the mean while the
Scotts stele by night to ward their own country as fast as they might. And so
was the king fasly betrayed that wenyd that all ye traitors of land had been
brought to an end as it was said before. Now here you lords how tratoursly
king Edward was dysceyued. and how meruayllously. and boldly the scotts did
of werre / For James douglas with two hundred men of armies rode thrught out all
the host of king Edward / the same night the Scotts escaped toward their
own country as is above said / till that they came to ye kings pauylyon / and
slew there many men in their beds / and cried Naward naward / and another time
a Douglas a Douglas wherefore the king that was in his pauylyon and much other
^^lke were wonder sore a frayed / But blyssyd be almighty god ye king was not
taken / and in greto peril was tho the reame of England. and that night the moon shone full clear / and bryghte. And for all the kings men the Scotts
scapyd harmeles. And oon the morrow when the king wyste that the Scotts were
escapyd in to their own country he was wonder sorry / and fulle hertely wept
with his young eyne / and yet wyste he not who had him done that treason^
But that falls treasone was fulle well I known a good while after as the
storye makyth mencyon. Tho king Edward came again unto york full sorrowful And
his host departed / and every man went in to his own country with full heavy
chere and morning semblaunt / And the Henaudes took their leave and went in to
their own country. And the king for their trauayll / hugely reward them.
And for because of that vyage / the king had dyspended much of his tresoure
and wastyd. And in that time were seen two moons in the fyrmament / ye one was
clear / and that other was derke* / as men might see through the world. And a
great debate was that same time against pope Johan the.xxii. after saint Petyr.
and the emperor of Almayn tho made him emperor against ye popys will that tho
held his see at Auinyon. werfore the emperor made his cry at Rome and
ordained a another pope / ye hight Nycholas / yt was a friar Mynor / and that
was ayeng the right of holy church. wherefore he was cursyd. and the power of
that other pope soon laid. And for cause that such merueylles were seen /
men said that the world was nygh at an end.

Of the death of king Edward of Carnaryuan.
ANd now go we again / to sir Edward of Carnaryuan yt was king Edwardes fader
sometime king of England. and put down of his dygnyte. Alas for his
trybulacyon and sorrow that him befell through falls counsel. yt he louyd and
trustyd upon to much. yt after ward were dystroyed thrughe their falsnesse as
god would. And this Edward of Carnariuan / was in the castle of Berkelay under
ye ward and keeping of sir Moryce of Herkelay / and also of sir John^ Matreues
and to them he made his complaynte of his sorrow and of his dysesee. and often
times axyed of his wardeyns. what he had trespassyd against dame Isabell his wife
and sir Edward his sone. yt was made new king / that they would not vysyte
him. And tho answerde one of his wardeyns and said. My worthy lord dyspleyse
you not yt I shall tell you the cause is for it is done them to understand /
that if my lady your wife came any thing nyghe you^ that ye would her
strangle and slay / and also that ye walde do to my lord your sone in the
same wise. Tho answerde he with simple there Alas alas am not I in prison / and
all at your own will / now god yt wot I thought yt never / and now I would
that I were deed / so would god that I were. For then were all my sorrow
passyd. It was not long after that ye king through counsel of Roger Mortymer
/ grau^tyd the ward and keeping of sir Edward his fader unto sir thomas
Toioursy and to the foresaid sir Johan Matreuers through the kings letter / and
put out holy the foresaid sir Moryce of the ward of the king. And they took
and ladde the king unto the castle of Corf. the which castle the king
hatyd as any death. And they kept him there tylle it came unto saint / Mathewes
day in Septembre in the year of grace.M.CCC.xxvii. that the forsayde sir Roger
Mortymer sent the manner of the death / how and in what wise should be done to
death. And anon as the foresaid Thomas and Johan had see the letter / and
commandment / they made king edward Carnariuan good there: and good solace
/ as they might at that soupere / and nothing the king wist of the traytory.
And when time was for to go to bed the king went to his bed and lay and
slepte fast. And as the king lay and slepte the trautours falls forsworn
against their homage and feaute came pryuely into the kings chamber / and their
company with them / and laid an huge take upon his womb / and with men
pressyd / and held fast down the four corners of the table on his body /
wherwyth the good mane a woke / and was wonder sore adradde to be deed and
there slain / and turned his body up tho so down. Tho took the false
traitors / and tynauntes an horn. And put it in to his foundemente as deep as
they might / and a spyt of copre brennynge / and put it thrughe the horn in
to his body and so they slew their lord / that no thing was perceived /
And after he was enteryd at Gloucetree.

How king Edward spowsyd Phylyp ye earls daughter of Henaude at york.
ANd after Crystmasse tho next sewynge sir Johan of henaude brought with him
Phylyp his brothers daughter / yt was earl of Henaude his nece in to England /
and the king spowsyd her at york. with much honor. And sir Johan of
Bothum bishop of Ely / and sir wyllyam of Melton Archebysshop of york / sange
the mass the Sunday on the even of the Conuersyon of saint Poule / In the
year of grace.M.CCC.xxvii. But because that the king was but young and tender
of aege when he was crowned full many wornges were done while that his fader
lived / because that he trowed / the counserllers that were falls about hy^ /
that cou^syelled him to do other wise tha^ reason would wherefore great harm
was do to ye reame and to ye king / and all me^ dyrected it the kings deed /
and it was not so almighty god it wot / wherefore it was ordained at the
kings crownynge. that ye king for his tender aege / should be governed
by.xii. of the grettest lords of England / without whom no thing should be
done. That is to say tharchebysshop of Caunterbury / tarchebysshop of york /
the bishop of wynchestre / and the bishop of Herforde / the earl of Lancastre
/ therle Marchall / and the earl of kent / that were ye kings uncles. and the
earl of Garenne / sir Thomas wake. Sir Henry Percy. sir Olyuer yngham and Johan
Rous barons / all these were sworn truly for to counseyll the king. And they
should answer every year in parliament / of that that should be done in the time
of their gouernall / but that ordinance was sone undone / and that was much
harm to all England / For the king and all ye lords that should govern him
were governed and ruled after the queen his mother dame Isabell. and by sir
Roger Mortymer: and as they would all thing was done / both among high and
low. And they took unto them castles towns lands / and rentes in great
harm. And loss to the crown. and of the estate out of all mesure.

How the peace was made between the Englyssheme^ and the Scotts and also of
Iustyfyenge of Troylesbaston.
King Edward at wytsontyde in the second year of this regne thrughe the
counsel of his mother / and sir Roger Mortymer / ordained a parliament at
Northampton. and at that parliament ye king thrughe his counsel / and none
other of ye land / within aege grauntyd to be accordyd with ye scotts in this
manner. that all ye f^autees and homages. that ye scotts should do to the
crown of England / foryaue them for evermore / by his chartre ensealed. And
ferder more an endenture was made of the Scotts unto king Edward / that was
king He^ries sone / which endenture they call it regman. In ye which were
contained all the homages and feautees / First of the king of Scotlond and of
the prelates / earls barons of ye reame of Scotlonde with their seals set
thereon and other chartres and reme^brau^cis that king Edward and his barons
had of their right in ye foresaid reame of Scotlonde / it was foryeue again holy
church / and also with the blake cross of Scotlond ye which the good king
Edward conquered in Scotlo^de and brought it out of ye abbay of scone that is
a full precious relyque / and also ferthermore / he relacyd and fully forgave
the land that the noble barons had before that ty^e in ye ream of Scotlond /
by old conquest. And ferthermore yt this peace for to be holden and co^tynuelly
last the Scotts were bound unto ye king in xxx. thousand pound of silver
to be paid within three year / that is every year.x.M. pound by eue^ procyons.
And ferthermore above all this they spoke between the parties above said. ye
Dauyd Drytonautyer that was king Roberte Brus sone / ye falls tyrant* and falls
forsworn against his oath yt arose against his leyge lord ye noble and good
king Edward. and falsely made him king of Scotlonde / yt was of aege.v. year.
And so this cursyd counsel David spoused at Berewyk dame John^ of ye Toure /
that was king Edwardes sister / as the gestes tellyth upon Mary Mawdeleyns
day. in the year of grace. M.CCC.xxviii. to great harm and empayrynge of all
the kings blood whereof that gentle lady came. alas the time / For wonder
much ye fayer da^oysell dysperagyd / sith that she was married against all the
comyns will and assent of England. And from the time that Brute had conquered
Albyon^ and named the land after his own name. Brytayne: that now is called
England after the name of Engyst And so the reame of Scotlonde was hold of
the reame of England / and of ye crown by feaute and homgae. For Brute
conquered that land and yaue it to Albanak / yt was his second sone / And he
called ye land Albayn after his own name / so that his heirs yt came after
him. should hold of Brute and of his heirs / yt is to say of the kings of
Brytayn / by feaute and homage: And from that time unto this time of king
Edward / the tame of Scotlond was hold of the reame of England by feaute and
service / as above is said in the Chronicles of England and of Scotlonde and
berythe witness more plainly. And accursyd be ye time that this parliament was
holden at Northampton For there by falls councyll. the king was there falsely
dysheryted and yet he was with in aege. And yet when that king Edward was put
out of his ryalte of England yet men put not out of the feautes and seruyse
Scotlonde. Ne of the fraunchyses dysheryted him for ever more. And nevertheless
the great lords of england were against to conferme the peace and the ^rwes
abouesayd / sa^f only queen Isabell / yt tho was the kings mother Edward / and
the bishop of Ely / and the lord Mortimer. But reason and law would not that
a fynalle peace should be made between them without the common assente of
England.

Of the debate that was between queen Isabell and sir Henry earl of Lancastre
and of Leycetre / and of the riding of Bedforde.
THen as the for said Dauyd had spowsyd dame Iohan^e of the toure in ye town
of Berwyk as before is said / The Scotts in dyspyte of ye Englysshmen called
dame Iohanne the countess make peace / for the cowardly peace yt tho was
ordained. But ye kings person bare all the wit and blame with wrong of
making of the accord / And all was done through the queen / and Roger
Mortymer. And it was not long after that the queen Isabell ne took in to her
hondes all the lordshyp of Pountfret almost all the lands that were of any
value that apperteyned to the crown of England / So the king had not to
dyspendede / but of his uses and of his escheker / For the queen Isabell and
the Mortymer had great main of the retenewe yt followed ye kings court ever
more and went and took the kings pryces for her penny worthes at good ch^pe /
wherefore the country that they came in were / fullsore addrade / and almoost
dystroyed of them. Tho began the comyna^te of England for to have envy to
Isabell the queen. yt somoche louyd her before when she came again for to pursue
ye falls traitors ye Spensers fro France. And in that same time the false
traitor Roberte of Holonde / that bytrayed his lord sir Thomas of Lancastre.
was tho delyuerde and out of prison / and was wonder preuy witth the queen
Isabell / and also with Roger Mortymer. But that auaylld him but little For he
was taken at Myghelmasse yt tho came next after / as he rode to ward queen
Isabell to London / and sir Thomas whyther smote of his heed besides the town
of saint Albons And this sir Thomas dwelled with sir Henry earl of Lancastre /
and he put him aside for dread of the queen / For the queen loved him wonder
much. And prayed unto the king for him that ye same Thomas might be exyled out
of England. And the noble earl sir Henry of Lancastre had often times herd
the common claymore of ye Enghysshmen / of ye disease that were done in England
/ and also for diverse wro^ges that were done to the common people. of the which
the king bare the blame with wrong For he was but fulle young and tender of
aege. and thought as a good man / for to do away / and slake the sklau^der of
ye kings person / if that he might in any manner a wise / so as the king was
thereof nothing gylty / wherefore he was inperyll of life and lymme^ And so he
assembled all his retenuwe and went and spoke with them of the kings honor
/ and also for to amend his estate. And sir Thomas Brotherton earl of Marchall
/ and sir Edmond wodstok / that were the kings uncles / and also men of London
made their oath him fo. to mayntene in ye same quarrel. And their cause was
this / that the king should hold his house and his meyne / as a king ought
for to do / and have all his ryalt^e^ And that the queen Isabell should deliver
out of her hondes in to the kings hand all manner of lordshyps rentys /
towns and castles that apperteyneth unto the crown of England as other
queen's have done here before / and meddle with none other thing. And also that
sir Roger Mortymer should abide and dwell upon his own^ lands / For much
people / In so much that the common people were dystroyed and gretely domaged /
thoroughe such wrongfulle taking. And also the enquere how and by whom that
the king was betrayed and falsely dysceyued at Stanhope / and thrughe whose
counseyll that the Scotts went away by night from the king / And also how
and through whoos counseyll the ordinance that were made at the kings
coronacyon / was put down. That is to say / that the king for amendment and
helping of his reame / and in honor of him should be governed and ruled
by.xii. of the grettest and wysest lords of the reame / and without them
Should no thing be grauntyd ne done / as before is said / which couenauntes
were malicyously put down fro the king / where many harms. shamys and
repreues have fall to the king and his reame / and that is to understand for
asmoche as Edward king of England some time / was ordained by assent in
plain parliament for to be under ward and governance of Henry earl of
Lancastre his cosyn / for salvation of his dody he was take out of the castle
of Kenilworth / there that he was in ward. and through color of queen Isabell
/ and of the Mortymer without consent of any parliament they took and ladde him
there that never after none of his kynred / might with him speak ne see. and
after tratorursly took and morored him for whose death arose a sklau^dre through
all crystendom when it was done. And also the tresore ye sire Edward of
Kernaruian left in many places in England and in walys was wastyd and borne
away / without the will of king Edward his sone / in dystruccyo^ of him and
of al his folk. Also thrughe whose counseyll / that ye king yaue up the
kingdom of Scotlond / for the which reame / the kings au^cetours had full
sore traueiled / and so did many a noble man for their right / and was
delivered unto dauyd that was Robert brus sone all ye right / yt no right had
to the reame. as all the world it wist. And also by whom the chartres and
reme^braunces yt they had of the right Scotlond were take out of the tresory /
taken to the Scotts the kings enmyes / to dysheritynge of him and of his
successors / and to great harm of his lyeges / and great repreef to all
Englysshemen for ever more. Also wherefore dame Johan of the toure the kings
sister Edward / was dysperagyd and married unto Dauyd that was Robertbrus sone.
that was a traitor and enmye unto England. and through whoos counseyl she was
take into our enmyes hondes out of England. And in this mean while. ye good
earl Henry of Lancaster and his company took counseyl how those points above
said might be amended to the worship of the king and to his profit and to the
profit of his leyges / and the queen Isabel thrughe coniectynge and also of
the Mortymers let ordeyne a parliament at Salysburye. And at ye same parliament
/ the Mortymer was made earl of March against all the barons will of England
in preiudyce of ye king and of his crown And sir Johan of Eltham the kings
brother was gyrde with a sword of Corn waylle. and tho was called earl of
Corn waylle. and ever more queen Isabell procuryd so much against her sone ye
king / that she had the ward of ye forsayde sir Edward and of his lo^des. And
at that parlemente the earl of Lancastre would not come / But ordained all his
power against queen Isabel and the Mortymer / And men of London ordained them
with five hundred men of armies. When queen Isabel wist of the doing (...)
swore by god and by his names full angerly / that in an evil time he thought
upon tho points / Tho sent the queen Isabell and the Mortymer after their
retenwe and after the kyngys retenewe / so that they had ordained among them
an huge host. And they counseylled the king / so that upon a night ^ they
rode.xxiii. miles to Bedford / there the earl of Lancastre was with his company
/ and thought to have him dystroyed / and that night she rode beside the king
her sone as a knight for dread of death. And it was done the king to understand
/ that the earl Henry of Lancastre and his company would have dystroyed the
king and his counseylle for ever more / wherefore the king was somdele to
wards him heavy and anoye^ When the earl Marshall and therle of Kente the
kings brother herd of this tidings / they rode so in message between them
/ that the king grauntyd him his peace to therle Henry of Lancastre / for a
certain raunsomme of an leven thousand pound / But that was never paid
afterward. And these were the lords that held with Sir Henry of Lancastre.
Sir Beaumont / sir Fouk fytz waren sir Thomas Rocelyn / Sir wyllyam Trusdr^^
^ynghtes moo that were to him consented / and all those were exyled thrughe
counseylle of the queen Isabell and of Mortymer. For ye Mortymer waited to have
their lo^des if that he might through any manner coniectynge / For he was to
coueytous and had to much his will and that was great pity.

How king Edward went over the sea for to do his homage unto the king of
France / for the duchye of Guyhenne.
IT was not long after that the king of France / through counseyll of his
Donzepers / sent to king Edward of Englode that he should come to Paris and
do his homage as reason it would / for the duchye of Guyon / and so thrughe
counsel of the lords of England king Edward went over see. And at the
Ascyon tide / he came unto Paris / the third year of his regne / for to do his
homage unto the king of france. and the king received his homage / and made of
him much Joy and worship / but when king Edward had done his homage hastyly
he was sent for in to England through the quen Isabell his mother and anon
hastyly he came again in to England / upon wytsonday without any taking leave
of ye king of France. wherefore he was wonder wroth.

How sir Roger Mortymer bare him proudely and so high.
ANd now shall ye here of sir roger mortymer of wygmore that desired and
coueted to be at an high astate / so that the king grauntyd him to be called
earl of March thorughe out all his lordshyp. And he became so proud and
hauteyn / yt he would lose and forsake the name yt his elders had ever be fore
/ and for ye cause he let him call earl of march. And none of the comnyns of
England durst call him by other name / for he was called so by ye kyngys
cry. that men should call him earl of March And mortymer bare him so hauteyn
and so proud that wonder it was for to wit. and also dysguysed him with
wo^nder rich clothes out of al manner of reason / both of shapynge and of
werynge. where of the Englysshmen had great wonder / how / and in what manner he
might contryue or find such manner pride. and they s^yd among them comynly /
yt his pride should not long endure. And the same time sir Gyffray Mortymer
the young / that was mortymers sone. let call him king of folly / and so it
befell after ward in deed / for he was so full of pride and of wretchydnesse
/ that he held a round table in walys / to all men that the der came / and
cou^terfeted the doing and the manner of king Arthurs table / but openly he
failed / for the noble king Arthur was ye most noble lord of renomme / that
was in all the world in his time and yet came never none such after / For all
ye noble knights i^ all cryste^dom of dedys of armies assayed / dwelled with
king Arthur / and held him for there lord and sovereign / And that was well
seen / for he conquered in a bataylle a Romayne yt was called Froll. And gate
of him the reame of France and slew him with his own hondes / and also he
faught with a gyaunt that was called Dynabus / and slew him that had rauysshed
fair Elayne that was king Howels ne^e / king of little Brytayn and after he
slew in bataylle the Emperor of rome / yt was called Lucye / that had
assembled against Arthur / for to fight with him so much people of Romans and
Pebytes and sarasyns / that no man cowde nombre them / and he dyscomfyted them
all as the story tellyth And in that same thyme common voice spronge in England
through coniectynge and ordinance of the friar prechers / that sir Edward of
Carnariuan / that was king Edwardes fader of whom the geste tellyth / said
that he was alive in the castle of Corf / whereof all the comyns of England
almoost were i^ sorrow and dread / whether that it were so or not / For they
wist not how traytoursly Mortymer had him done murthred.

How Edmonde of wodstok that was earl of Kente and the kings brother Edward
of Carnaryuan / was heedyd at wynchestre.
ANd upon a time it befell so / that sir Edmonde of wodstok earl of Kent
spoke unto pope Johan the.xxii. at Auinion / and said that almighty god had
often times done for Thomas love of Lancastre many great miracles to many men
and wymmen / yt were thrughe diverse maladyes undone. As unto the world / and
thrughe his prayer they were brought unto there health. and so sir Edmonde
prayed the pope hertely that he would grant him grace / the forsayde Thomas
might be traunslatyd. But the pope said nay that he should not be
traunslatyd / unto the time that he were better certyfyed of the clergy of
England and seen by their obedyence what thing god had done for the love of
saint Thomas of Lancaster after the suggestio^ that the foresaid earl of Kent
had unto him made And when this Edmonde saw that he might not speed of his
purpos: as touching the traunslacion He prayed hy^ of counsel. as touching
sir Edward of Carnariuan his brother / and said. that not long agon he was
king of England / what thing might best be done as touching his
delyuerau^ce / sithe yt a comune fame was through England yt he is alive. hole
and sauf wha^ ye pope herd hy^ tell yt sir Edward was alive. He commanded ye
earl upon his blyssynge. that he should help with all the power that he might
/ that he were delivered out of prison / and save his body in all manner that
he might. And to bring this thing to an end he assoyled him and his company
a pena et culpa) and all that to his delyuerau^ce. Tho took Edmond of wodstok
his leave of ye pope and came again into England / and wha^ sir Edmonde was come
/ some of ye friar prechers came and said that sir Edward his brother yet was
alive in ye castle of Corf / under ye keeping of sir Thomas Gurnay. tho sped
hy^ the foresaid Edmonde as fast as he might / till he came to ye castle of Corf
/ and acquaynted him and spoke so fair to John^ Dauerel / that was conestable
of the same castle / and yaue him rich yeftes for to have acquayntaunce of
him and to know of his counsel. And thus it befell that the foresaid Edmonde
prayed specially to tell him pryuely of his lord his brother sir Edward / if
that he lived or were deed / and if he were alive he prayed him ones to have a
sight of him. And this sir John^ Daueryl was a high herted man and full of
courage / and answerde shortly to sir Edmond and said / that sir Edward his
brother was in health. and under his keeping. and durst not show him unto no
man sith it was defended him in the kyngys half Edward / yt was Edwardes sone
of Carnuariuan and also by the commandment of queen Isabel ye kings mother /
and of sir Roger Mortymer / that he should show his body to no man of the
world sauf only to the^ upon life and lym^e and disherytynge of his heirs for
ever more. But the false traitor falsely lied. For he was not in his ward / but
was take the^s and lad to the castle of Berkeley by sir Thomas of gurney by
the co^mau^demente of Mortymer till he was deed as before is said / But sir
Edmonde of wodstok wist no thing that sir edward his brother was deed /
whereupon he took a letter unto king Edward his brother as to his worthy lord
and received ye letter of him and behyght him right faithful to do his message
without fayll. And with that sir Edmonde took leave of the foresaid John^ / and
yede into his own country and lordshyp in kent that he had there. Anon as
this same Johan wist. that sir Edmonde was gone into Kent his own lordshyp.
anon he went in all ye have that he might fro the Castle of Corf and came
unto sir Roger Mortymer and took him the letter that sir Edmond of wodstok earl
of Kent had taken him closyd and ensealed with his own seal / And when sir
Roger Mortymer had received the letter / he unclosed it / and saw that was
contained therein / and began it to read. whereof the beginning was this.
Worshyppes and reverence with brother alyegaunce and subieccyon / sir knyt
worshypfull and dear brother ^ if it you please I pray you hertely that ye be
in good co^forthe / for I shall so ordeyn for you yt ye shall come out of
pryso^ and be delivered of that dysese that ye ben in / and vnderstondyth of
your great lordshyp / that I have to mine assenting all most all the great
lords of England with all their apperyll / that is to say with armor with
tresour without nombre / for to mayntene your quarrel so ferforth / that ye
shall be king again as ye were before / and that they have sworn to me upon a
book / and as well prelates as earls and barons. When sir Roger Mortymer saw and
understood / the might and the strenth of the letter anon his heart for wrath
began to boll and evil heart bare to ward sir Edmo^de of wodstok that was earl
of kent. and with all the have that he might / he went unto dame Isabell the
queen / that was ye was the kings mother / and showed her sir Edmonds letter /
his will and his purpose and how that he had coniected and ordained to put
down king Edward of wyndsore her sone. of his ryalte and of his kingdom /
Now certes sir Roger said she has sir Edmonde done so now by my faders soul
said she / I will be thereof avenged / if that god grant me life / and that in
a short time. And with that queen Isabell went unto king Edward her sone /
there he was at the parlemente at wynchestre. to have amend the wrongys and
the trespasses that were done among the people of his reame / and tho she took
and showed him the letter that sir Edmond of wodstok had made / and ensealed
with his own seal and badde him upon her blessing. that he should be auengyd
upon sir edmond as upon his dedely enmye. Tho was the queen sore wroth to
ward sir Edmonde earl of Kente. And sessyd never to pray until her sone /
till that he had sent in all the have after him. And upon that the king sent
by his letters after sir Edmoode of wodstok / that he should come and speak
with him at wynchestre all manner thing left. And when sir edmond saw that
the king sent after him with his letters ensealed / ye hastyd him in all yt
he might tylle that he came to wynchestre. But when the queen wist that sir
Edmonde was come to wynchestre tho anon she prayed and so fast wend unto
king edward her sone / that the good earl was arested anon / and ladde unto
the bar before Robert of Hamonde that was Coroner of the kings household.
And he assocyed unto him sir Roger Mortymer. And tho spoke the for said Roger
and said sir edmonde earl of Kent / ye shall understood that it is done us to
wit / and pryncypally unto our lyege lord the king edward of england
almighty god him save and keep / that ye be his deedly enmye / and a traytoure
/ and also a comune enmye to the reame and that ye have been about many a day.
For to make pryue delyueraunce of sir edward sometime king of england your
brother / the which sometime was put down of his ryaltee by ye common assent of
the lords of england / in peasynge of our lord the kings estate / and also
of his reame. Tho answered the good man and said / For soth sir understand well
that I was never traytoure to my king / ne to the reame / and that I do me on
god / and on all the world / and therefore by my kings leave. I shall it preue
and defend as a man ought for to do. Tho said Mortymer. sir Edmonde. it is so
ferfor the know that it may not be well gaynsayd / and that in presence of all
that here been. it shall be well prouyd. Now had this false mortymer the same
letter that sir edmonde had take to Sir Johan Daueryll in the castle of Corf
for to take to king edward his brother that sir Edmonde wist not of ne
supposed no thing that sir John^ Daueryll had be so falls to deliver his letter
in such wise unto Mortymer. And thought no manner of thing of that letter.
Then Mortymer said to sir edmonde / and showed a letter sealed. and axed him
if that he knew ye letter and ye seal. This sir edmonde lokyd thereon / and
auysed him long time on the prynte of the seal / for he might not see the
letter with in. and wist well that it was his seal / and thought that it had
be sum letter that had bore no great charge / and thought no thing of that
other letter. And said openly in herynge of them all / ye for soth this is my
seal. and I will it not for sake. Lo said the Mortymer / syres ye here al
what he has said / and that he knowlegyth him that this is his letter and his
seal. And now ye shall here what is contained therein / and then Mortymer
opened the letter that he had fold tofore together. and read it openly word
by word in herynge of them all / and when the letter was read / he said /
Loo syres ye have herd all ye herin is wryte^ / and that he has knowlegyth
that this is his letter and his seal. and he may not go therfro / And then
they cried and yaue dome / that he should be hangyd and drawn / and his heed
smyten of in a manner of a traitor and he and his heirs dysheryted for ever
more / and so he was ladde forth and put in to prison. and when this was done.
and the queen wist that he was dampened by way of law / both of life and of
lym^e / and his heirs dysheryted for evermore. through open knowlegynge in
playncourt / where them thought that it were good / that the foresaid sir Edmond
were hastyly slain / without wyttynge of the king / or else the king would
lightly foryeue him his death / and then it shode torn them so much sorrow
/ so as he was empechyd / And anon the queen through counseyll of the Mortymer
/ and with out any other counsel sent in have to the Baylyfe of wynchestre
that they should smite of Sir Edmondes heed Earl of Kente without any manner
abiding or respyte upon pain of life and lymme. And that he should have none
other execusyon / By cause of caryenge not withstanding the Judgment. Tho took
the Baylyes sir edmonde out of prison / and ladde him beside the castle of
wynchestre / and there they made a gonfermer smite of his heed / for none other
durst it do / and so he deyed there / alas the while. That is to say the
tenth day of Octobre / the third year of king Edward regne. And when the
king wist thereof / he was wonder sorry / and let entyere him at the friar
Mynors at wynchestre.

Of the death of sir Roger Mortymer Earl of March.
ANd so it befell at that time that sir Roger Mortymer earl of ye March / was
so proud and so hauteyne that he held no lord of the reame his pere. And tho
became he so coueytous / that he followed dame Isabell the queen's court that
was king Edwards mother and beset his penny worth with the officers of the
queen's house hold in the same manner that the kings officers did. And so he
made his taking / as touching of vytayle and also of caryages / and all he
did for because of expencys / and to gadre tresoure / And so he did without
nombre in all that he might. Tho had he made him wonder preuy with the queen
Isabell / And so much lordshyppe and rete we had / that all the great lords
of England of him were adrad wherefore the king and his counseylle / to ward
him were agreued / And ordained among them to undo him thoroughe pure reason
and law for cause that king Edward that was ye ky^ges fader traytoursly
through him was murdered in the castle of Corf as before is said more plainly in
some part of his book / of his death. And some that were of the kings
counseyll louyd Mortymer / and told him in preuyte / how that ye king and
counsel were about from day to day / him for to dystroye and undo wherefore
Mortymer was sore anoyed and angry as the devil against them of the kings
counseyll / and say he would of them be avenged / how so ever he took on. It
was not long afterward / that king Edward and dame Phylyp his wife / and dame
Isabell the kings mother. and sir Roger Mortymer / ne went unto Notyngham
there for to soiurne / And so it befell that queen Isabel through counsel of
Mortymer / took to her the keys of the yates of the castle of Notyngham. So
that no man might come another in ne out but through commandment of Mortymer /
ne the king / ne none his cou^seylle. And that time it fell. that the Mortymer
as a devil for wrath bolled / and also for wrath that he had against the
kings men Edward / and pryncypally against them that had him accusyd to the
king / of the death of sir Edward his fader. And pryuely a counsel was take
between queen Isabell and the Mortymer and the bishop of Lyncoln and sire
Symo^de of Bedford / and sir Hugh of Trompyngton / and other preuy of their
counseyll / for to undo them all that the Mortymer had accusyd unto the king
of his faders death / of treason and of felonye. Wherefore all tho that were of
the kings counsel / when they wist of the Mortymers casting: pryuely came
to king Edward and said / that Mortymer would them dystroye / because that
they had him accusyd of king Edwardes death. his fader \ And prayed him that
he would mayntene them in their right. And these were the lords that pursued
this quarrel / Sir wyllyam of Mountagu / sir wyllyam de Bohum / Sir wyllyam his
brother / sir Rauf Stafforde / sir Robert of Herforde / sir wyllyam of Clynton /
sir Johan Neuell of Hornby and many other of their consent. And all these swore
upon a book to mayntene the quarrel / in as much as they might. And it befell
so after^ that sir wyllyam Mountagu ne none of the kings friends must not be
herberowed in the castle for the Mortyme^ but went and took their herberowe in
diverse place of the twone of Nothyngham. And tho were they sore a ferde /
leest that mortymer should them dystroye. And in haste they came unto king
Edward sir wyllyam of Mauntagu and other that were in the castle. And pryuely
him told / that he ne none of his company. should not take the Mortymer.
without counseyll and help of wyllyam of Elande. constable of the same
castle. Now truly said the king I love you well^ and therefore I counseyl
you that ye go to the foresaid conestable / and commau^de him in my name / that
he be your friend and your help / for to take the mortymer / al thing yleft
upon peril of life and lym^e. Tho said Mountagu Sir my lord grant mercy Tho
went forth the foresaid Mountagu / and came to the Conestable of the castle /
and told him the kings will. And he answerde and sayde^ The kings will
should be done in as much as he might. and that he would not spare for no
manner of death / And that he swore and made his oath. Tho said sir wyllyam of
Mou^tagu to the constable / in herynge of them all. that were helping to the
same quarrel. Now certes dear friend / us behouyth to work and do by your
aduys for to take the Mortymer / sith that ye be keeper of the castle. and has
the keys in your ward. Sir said the Constable / will ye understand / that
the castle yates ben lockyd with the keys that dame Isabell sent hither. and
by night she has the keys there of and lays them under the lursell of the
bed unto the morrow. and so ye may not come in to the castle by the yates /
by no manner of wise / But I know an aleye that stretchythoute of the ward
under the earth in to the for said castle / that gothe in to the weste.
which aleye dame Isabel the queen / ne none of her men ne the Mortymer / ne
none of his company knowith it not. And so I shall led you through ye aley /
and so ye shall come in to the castle without aspyenge of any man yt are your
enmyes. And the same nyghe sir wyllyam Mountagu / and all the lords of his
quarrel / and the same Constable also went them to horse / and made semblau^t
as it were for to go out of Mortymers sight But anon as Mortymer hard this
tidings / he wend yt they would have gone over see for fere of him. And anon
right he and his company took a counsel among them for to let their
passage / and snetelletters anon to the porters so that none of the great
lords should go home to their owned countries / but if they were arested and
take. And among other things wyllyam Elande Conestable of the for said
castle. pryuely ladde sire wyllyam of Mountagu and his company by the for said
way under the earth / till they came in to the castle and went up in to the
toure that Mortymer was in. But sir Hughe of Trompynton them ascryed hydously
and said a traitors it is all for naught. that ye ben common in to this castle
ye shall deye yet an evil death euerychone. And anon one of them that was in
Mountages company up with a mace / and smote the same Hugh upon the heed / that
the brain braste out and fell on the ground / and so was he deed of an evil
death. Tho took they mortymer as he armyd him at the toures door / when he herd
the noise of them for dread. And when the queen Isablell saw that the
Mortymer was taken she made much sorrow in heart / and these words unto them
she said / Now fair syres / I pray you that ye do no harm to his body a
thy knight our well-beloved friend and our dear cosyn. Tho went they thens / and
came and brought Mortymer / and presentyd him unto king Edward / and he
commanded to bring him in save ward. But anon as they that were consenting
unto mortymers doing / herd tell that he was taken they went and hid them
/ and pryuely by night went out of the town each one his way / with heavy
heart and morning chere and lived upon their lands as well as they might.
And that same year that Mortymer was take. He had.ix. score knights without
quyres and sergau^tes of armies / and footmen / And then^e was mortymer ladde
to London / and sir Edmonde of Bedforde was ladde with him / and was taken to
ye constable of the toure to keep. But after ward was the Mortymers life
examyned at westmestre before the king / and before all the geate lords of
England / for peril that might fall to the reame / And to enquer^ also
which were consenting to sir Edwardes death the kings fader / and also
through whom the Scotts escaped fro Stanhope in scotlonde / without leave of
king Edward. And also how ye chartre of ragman was delivered unto the Scotts
them the homages and feautees of the lords of Scotlo^de were contained that
the Scotts should do ever more to the English king for the reame of
Scotlond / wherefore he was Iugyd to be drawn and hangyd for his treason / And
this myscheyf came unto him on saint Andrews even. In the year of the
Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu christ.M.CCC.xxx.

How king Edward gate again unto him gracyously the homages and feautees of
Scotlonde / whereof he was put out thrughe ye false counseyll of the queen
Isabell his mother and sire Roger Mortymer. that was newely made Earl of Match.
NOw have ye herd how Johan Bayllol in the time of peace was chosen to be king
of Scotlonde for cause that he came of the eldest daughter of the Earl Dauyd of
Huntyngton / that was king Alysanders brother of Scotlond / that deyed without
heir of his body begoten / And how this Johan made his feaute and homage to
king Edward / Henryes sone the third. for his lands of Scotlonde / And how
he afterward with said his homage / through counseyll of the Scotts / in the
year of our lord ^M.CC.lxxiiii. and sent unto the pope through. a falls
suggestyo^ that he made his oath unto the foresaid king Edward over his estate
and his will / of the which oath the pope him assoyled thrughe his bullys to
him ysent. And anon as king Edward wist thereof / he ordeyne anon his barons
and came unto Berwyk / and conquered the town. at the which conquest there
were slain.xxv. thousand and.vii. hundred. and Bayllol that was king of
Scotlond came and yeldyd him to good king Edward / and ye king delivered him
out of the toure of London. and all the great lords with him yt tho were taken
at Berwyk and yaue them saufconduyte / to goo into Scotlonde. And the Scotts
sithe through their falsnesse / warred upon the good king Edward. And when sir
Johan Bayloll king of Scotlonde saw all this / he went over see unto Dunpier
and lived there upon his lands as well as he might. till that ye Scotts would
amend them of their mysdedys and trespaas / and ladde with him sir Edward
his sone. wherefore the Scotts in dyspyte of him called him sir Johan
Turnlabard / for because that he would not ne offend ne trespaas against the
good king Edward of England. And so he for soke his reame of Scotlonde /
and set thereof but little price. And this sir Johan dwelled long time in
France / till that he deyed there and sir Edward his sone received his
heritage / and did homage to the king of France / for his lands of Dunpier
/ And so it befell afterward / that Edward that was Johan Bayllols sone / had
with him a squyre of England yt was in york shyre / that was called Johan of
Barnaby / and this Edward Bayllol louyd him much / and was nyghe him / and
full preuy. And so this John^ of Barnaby was in debate with a French man in
the town of Dunpier / and so he slew him and went his way in all the haste
that he might in to the castle. For to have socoure and help of his lord.
And anon came officers of the town. to take John^ of Barnaby as a felon. and
sir Edward his lord help him / and rescowed him / and by night made him go
out of the castle / and so he went his way and came in to England without
any harm. And when the king of france saw that sir Edward had rescowed his
felon. He became wonder wroth against sir Edward. and anon let him arestyd
and took into his hondes all his lands. Tho dwelled sir ^ Edward in prison /
unto the time that sir Henry of Beaumount came into france / the which Henry
sometime was earl of Anguysshe in Scotlonde and was put out thereof when
chacordement was between England and Scotlond through the queen Isabell and sir
Roger Mortymer and their company for ye moryage that she made between Dauyd /
that was Roberte Brus sone and dame Iohanne of Tour king Edwards sister of
England / and well understand this / that at the end he should come to his
right / but if it were sire Edward Baylloll / that was right heir of the
reame of Scotlonde. And the king of france Lowys louyd much this sir Henry.
And he was with him full preuy / and thought for to make a delyueraunce of sir
Edward Baylloll / if he might in any manner of wise. Tho prayed he the king
that he would of his grace gau^t him sire Edward Bayllols body / unto the
next parliament. that he might live with his own rentes in the mean time /
and that he might stand to be Iugyd with his perys at the parliament. And the
king grauntyd him his prayer / and made the forsayde Edward to be delivered
out of prison / in the manner above said And anon as he was out of prison sir
Henry took him forth with him and ladde him in to england / and made him
dwell pryuely at the manner of Sandhall upon Ouse in york shyre with the
lady Vescy. And so he ordained him there an huge retenewe of Englysshmen and
also of alyuntes / for to conquer again his heritage / and so he yaue much
silver unto ye souldyours and alyauntes for to help him ^ And they behyght for
to help him in that they might / but they faylled him at his most need. And
at that time Dauyd earl of Moryf herd tell how that sir Edward Bayloll was
pryuely come into england. And came to him and made with him gerte Joy of his
coming and said unto him and behyght him that all the great lords of
England / should be to him entendaunte / and should him hold for king as
right heir of Scotlo^de / and did to him feaute^ Tho came sir Henry of
Beaumonte to king edward of England. And prayed him in the way of charity /
that he would grant of his great unto sir Edward Baylloll that he might
sau^ly goo by land from Sandhall / unto Scotlonde / to conquer his right and
herytaunce in Scotlond. The king answerde and said / if that I suffer
Bayllol. go through my land in to Scotlonde. then the people would say / yt
I should be assenting unto the company. Now sir I pray you yt ye would give
him leave to take with him souldyours of Englysshmen that they might saufly led
him through your land to Scotlonde / And sir vpno this couenaunte that if it so
befall / as god it for bydde that he dyscomfyted in bytayll through the Scotts
/ that I and also all the lords that hold with Bayllol / ben for ever more out
of our rentes that we have in england. And there the king upon this
couenaunte / grauntyd their bone / as towchynge him / and tho that were of the
same quarrel the which claymed for to have lands and rentes in the reame of
England And these were the names of tho lords that pursued this for said
matere and quarrel. That is to say / sir Edward Bayllol / the which
chalengyd the reame of Scotlonde. sir Henry Beaumonte earl of Angusshe / sir
Dauyd of Stroboly earl of a theles / sir Geffray of Mombraye / walter Common and
many other that were put out of their heritage in Sctlonde when the peace was
made between England and Scotlonde as before is said / And ye shall
understand that these lords took with them five houndred men of arms. and
two thousand Archers and of footmen. and tho went in to ship at Raven.
pore / and sailed by the sea / tylle that they came unto Scotlond. and came to
land at Kynkehorne.xii. mile fro saint Johannes town / And anon sent out
there ships again / for that they should not be hurt / ne empeyred / neither
taht no man should go in to the ships again though that they had need / but
abybe all perils and not flee but stand / and rather suffer death than flee
for to mayntene their true quarrel. when the earl of Fyffe. a fyers man and a
stern / hard that Bayllol was come / for to taste the land of Scotlond / he
came in have to Kynke horn / with ^iii. thousand Scotts / for to dystroye him
/ that he should not come to land / But sir Edward Bayllol and his company
there him dyscomfyted / at the which dyscomfyture sir Alysa^der Seton was
there slain / and many other. The Earl of Fyffe / was the sore and full evil
ashamyd / that so little a company had him dyscomfyted / and shamefully put him
and all his company that were alive for to flee. Tho came sir Edward Bayllol
and took the coo^ tree all about him. till he came unto the abbay of
Du^fermlin. and there he found vytaylles for him and for his folk / and among
all other thing he found in a chamber about five houndred of great staves of
^ fine oak with long prykes of yren. and of stele And he took them and
delyuerd them to the most stro^gest men of his company. And anon after he
yede fro thens. And lodged him in a field.ii. miles from saint Ioha^nes town.
And when the burgeys of the town herd how the earl of Fyffe was dyscomfyted
thrughe Baylloll. brake ye brydges that they had made over the water of Erne.
so that Bayllol might not go over / wherefore he lodged him there all that night
/ but little head he took of rest. and said unto his people / Now dear lords
ye know full well. that been now lodged between our enmyes / and they may us
hampre / there is no bote but death. wherefore if we abide stylle all this
nyght^ I wene it shall torn us to much harm. For the power of Scotlonde may
every wexe and encrece and we may not so do. And we ben but lytylle people
ayenste them wherefore I pray you for the love of almighty god make we us
bold and hardy and that we may myghtely take the Scotts this night / and
boldly werre upon them. and let us pursue them this night. And if they be
trauaylled thorugh us. and see our hardynesse. other Scotts that see them so
traueylled and wery^ the sorer woll they be adradde with us to fight and
fyersly then shall we fight with them. And on them pursue. So that thrughe
the grace of god / all the world shall speak of the doughtynes of our
chyualry. And syres understands well that all the company that came with sir
Robert Baylloll / granted well unto that counseyll / and were thereof right
glad. and anon pursued upon the Scotts. that they became wonder weary. And
Baylloll and his company sore followed them / and did them much harm and
sorrow / through there assente. so that thy might not for feblynesse them help
and for lytyl people. But tho said the Scotts among them / what is now
befall that so little a people as Baylloll has in wynge does us so much
traueyll and sorrow Now certes it semyth us that he werketh by grace / for he
is wonder gracyous in his quarrel and we certes shall be deed or that we may
come to him us for to yield Since that his fader sete of us no price. And among
all his other things Baylloll and his people passed the water of Erne so that
Robert Swynerton the sone was fyers and angrye / and went forth and they saw
people of armies full well arrayed. and forth they went unto them and with them
faught And slew and took as many as would abide: And nevertheless at that
assewte they wend it had be the great host of Scotlond. And when it came to
the morrow. they gadred them together / and restyd them a whyle^ And while the
Englysshemen rested them / the noble baron Thomas Vescy / and the noble baron /
Stafforde / pryckyd their horse up and down by the hills / for to keep the
estrees of the country / and as they pryckyd up and down. they saw a great
host of good array ordained in their wynge with helmes and sheldes shynynge
coming upon them. and then^e came tho two barons again unto Bayllols folk /
and said. Now for the love of god almighty be of good co^forth for ye shall
have battle an one right. And tho spoke sir fouk the sone of Garenne^ a baran
of great renown and of dedys of armies / Syres understand what I will say /
I have seen many diverse wings / as well among sarasyns and Jews / as among
the Scotts / and yet saw I never the fourth part of the wynge fight. and
therefore if ye will abide our enmyes / we ben enough for them. but if we be not
of good heart and of good courage we been but lost. And therefore for the love
of god. take to us good heart / and let us be bold / ad think we never of
our wives ne of our children / but only to co^quere our enmyes in battle. And
through the help of our lord we shall them overcome And with that came the
host of the Scotts to ward them full serely / and against sir Edward
Baylloll in three bataylles well arrayed in armoure. And wonder fyersly they came
to ward the Bayllols company / But when sir Donald earl of Marcell that was
with the Scotts / saw all this / he said unto Roberte Brus the sone of Robert
the Brus these words / Sir Robert said he full fore me for thynkyth at my
heart / that these people that Baylloll has brought with him should deye with
dy^te of Scotts swerdes / sithe that they ben christian men as we ben. And
therefore me thynkyth that it were great charity for to send unto them / for
to yield them / unto our mercy / and raunsomme them unto grievous raunsomme /
for as much as they have taken our lands and done ill. Now certes said sir
Roberte the Brus / I have well rerceyued / that thou art an enmye and a
traitor unto Scotlonde / sithe that thou will consent to save our dedely
enmyes / that have done us much sorrow and shame and now it semyth well that ye
be of their assente Now certes Robert said sir donald / falsely ye lie. I am
not of their company ne of their consent / and yt hastyly ye shall se for I
will fyz^e with them rather than any of this company / and certes sir Robert
said he I shall in mauger of thy head assayll they or thou And with yt they
pryckyd their stedys fye^sly upon Gaskemore. and their wynge them followed on a
reng. and tho came they and met with Baylloll and his company at an hanging
bough of the more i^ a strayte passage and so fast they hastyd the^ unto ye
Englysshmen ye thousand / fell unto the ground echone over upon other into an
hepe horse and man bayllol and his men myghtyly stood against them / and fast
slew the Scotts to the ground / and many they wounded / so long / till
that they stood upon them and foyned them with their swerdes and speres
thrughe their bodies / and fulle sore they were trauaylled upon them / tylle
that they became wonder weary / and wyste not what for too do. And the Scotts
that were let alive fled away / for to save them self in the best manner
that they might. And tho pursued them sire Edward baylloll and his men / and
slew of them till it was night. And fro the^s they went to Saint Johannes
town / and took it. and held them there and vytaylled them self at there own
will / for they found enough wherewith to make merry. Tho made Baylloll his men
yt were wonded goo to ship / to sayll in to England / to hele there wounds.
and in ye time there was a fle^mynge in the sea. a stonge theyf And a robber
that was called crab and this fle^mi^ge was driven out of Flaundres for his
wyckydnesse and therefore he came into Scotlond to hold with the scotts / and
did as much harm to the Englysshmen as he might do. And this Crabbe met
Bayllols men in ye see that were wounded before in battle yt were sent again
into England. for to hele their wounds. and this crabbe yaaf to them a get
assawte. and would have slain them every chone. But the Englysshmen defended
them well and manly and dyscomfyte Crabbe and his company and tho began he fle
into Scotlond. And as he came toward saint Ioha^nes town / he found a great
conpany of scotts / yt were come again together after the dyscomfyture at
Gaskemore. the which byseyged Bayllol and his men i^ the same town of saint
Iohan^ And anon told told the Scotts how that he was dyscomfyted of the
Englysshmen / yt were woundyd at Gaskemore / that went toward England / forts
hele their wounds / And said to the Scotts / yt they should have another power
ne might ne grace against Edward Bayllol / by cause that he scomfyted / and
empeyred all the chyualry of Scotlond with a handfall of men as to ^o^pte
against the Scotts that were slain. wherefore he cou^seylled to remeue the sege
from saint Johannes town / and keep them in the best manner that they might.
The Scotts understood that crabbe said sothe / for soke the sege and went
thens by night. when this thing was know thrughe Scotlonde how that the
lords and knights were dyscomfyted at Gaskemore of Scotlonde thrughe sire
Edward Bayllol / ye shall understand yt the lords and ladies / and the
gentyls of Scotlond came wonder fast to saint Johannes town / and yeldyd
them unto Bayllol. and to him did homage and feaute for their sondes and yield
them to his peace and he them received freely / And fro thens he went to the
abbay of Scone. and there he was crowned king of Scotlond / and after he let
cry his peace thrughe out all the land. And at that same time it befell that
king Edward held his parliament among his leyges at the new castle upon
Tyne for to amend the trespaces and the wrongs that had been done in his
land. And sir Edward Bayllol king of Scotlonde came to him thither / and
did to him homage and feautee / for the reame of Scotlond And in this manner
king Edward of England gadred again his homages and feautees of Scotlonde /
where of he was put out / thrughe counseyll and assent of dame Isabell his mother
/ and of sir Roger Mortymer earl of March / Tho took Bayllol king of Scotlond
his leave of king Edward of England / and went thens in to his own land of
Scotlonde and set but little by such as had counseylled him / and helped him
in his quarrel / wherefore they went from him and went and lived by their own
lands and renttes in Scotlond. And so it befell after ward not long / that
that the king of Scotlonde ne remeued and came to the toure of Anande and
there took his dwelling / and thither came to him a company of knights
strong men and worthy / and yielded them unto the king. And bare them so fair
in deed and in cou^tenau^ce / so that he trustyd much upon them And anon as
the traitors saw that he trustyd much upon them / they ordened among them
fyfty in a company / and would have slain their lord the king / But through
the grace of almighty god / he brake through a wall an hole in his chamber /
and as god would scapyd their treachery / and all his men were slain / and he
escaped with much dred unto the town of Cardoyll / And there he held him
sore anoyed. And this befell upon our ladies even ye co^cepcyon. Tho sent king
Edward Baylloll to king Edward of. England / how falsely and tratoursly he
was in little time / put to shame and sorrow thrughe his lyege men / upon whom
he trustyd wonder much. And prayed him for ye love of god that he would
mayntene him and help him against his enmyes. the king of england had of him
great pity / and behight to help him and socour him. and sent him word that
he should hold him in peace still in ye forsayde cite of Cardoyll / till yt he
had gadred his power. Tho ordained king Edward of England a counseyll at
London / and let gadre his men in diverse shyres of England. and when he was
all ready / he went toward the town of Berwyk upon Twede / and theder came
to him king Edward Baylloll of scotlond with his powere / and beseged the town
/ And made without the town a fair town of pauylyons and dyched them all
abowte / so that they had no dread of the* Scotts / and made many assawte
with ^onnes and with other engynnes to ye town. wherwyth they dystroyed many
fair houses / and chyrches also were beten down to ye earth with great stones
/ the spitously came out of gonnes and other engynes. And nevertheless ye
Scotts kept right well the town / yt tho two kings might not come therein
long time. and n^theles the kings abode there so long / till tho that were
within ye town failed vytaylles and also they were so weary of waking. that
they wist not what for to do. And ye shall vnderstende that tho scotts yt were
within ye town of Berwyk / through common counseyl and their assent. let cry
upon ye wallys of the twone. that they might have peace of the Englysshme^ and
thereof they prayed the king of his grace and mercy and prayed gym of trwes
for.viii. days upon this couenaunte / yt if they were not rescowed in that
side of the town toward Scotlond of ye Scotts within.viii. days yt they
would yield them unto ye king and the town also / And to hold this covenant
/ they prouffred to the king.xii. hostages out of the town of Berwyk. When
the hostages were delyuerde / unto ye king / anon tho of the town sent unto
ye scotts / and told them of their sorrow and myscheyf / And the Scotts tho
came pryuely over the water of Twede to ye bought of the abbaye. and sir
wyllya^ Dyket that was tho Steward of scotlonde. and many other that came with
him / put them their in great peril of themself at that time and of there life
/ For they came over a bridge yt was to broke and ye stones away / and many of
their company were there drowned / But the foresaid wyllyam went over / and
other of company / and came by the ships of England / and slew in a barge of
Hull.xvi^ me^ and after they went into the town of Berwyk by the water side /
wherefore the Scotts held tho the town rescowed / and asked their hostages
again of the king of England / and the king sent them word aye^ that they
axyd their hostages with wrong sith thath they came into the town of Enlonde
side / for covenant was between them that the town should be rescowed by the
half of Scotlonde and anon tho commanded king Edward to yield the town /
or he would have the hostages and the Scotts said the town was rescowed well
enough and thereto they would them hold / when king Edward saw the Scotts
break their couenauntes that they made / he was wonder wroth. and anon let
sir Thomas. Fytz wyllyam and sir Alysa^der of Feton warden of Berewyk the
which Thomas was person of Dunbarre. and let the^ be take first before that
other hostages for cause that Sir Alysanders fader was keeper of the town. And
tho commanded every day two hostages of the town / till that they were all
do to death. But if they yielded the town / and so he should teache them for to
break their couenauntes. And when they of the town herd these tidings they
became wonder sorry and sent to the king that he would grant them other.viii.
days of respyte. So that between two hundre men of armies and.xx. men of arms
might by strenthe go between them to ye town of Berwyk them for to vytaylle /
that the town must be hold for rescowed. And if so were that.xxi. or.xxii.
or more were slain of tho two hundred before said. that the towsholde not be
hold for rescowed. And this couenaunte to be hold. they sent to him
other.xii. of the foresaid town in hostage / the king of England grauntyd
them their prayer and took the hostages. on saint Margaretes eve. in the year
of grace.M^CCC.xxxiii. the Scotts came fyersly well arrayed in four wings for
to mete king Edward of England. and Edward the king of Scotlonde / with
their power / and came fast and sharply against euensonge time / And the same
time was flood at Berwyk in the water of Twede / that no man might goo over
on his horse / nor on foot ^ and the water was between tho two kings and ye
reame of England. And that time abode the Scotts in that other side for cause
that the englyssgmen should have be drowned.

This was the arraye of the Scotts / how that they came in battle against the

allon foot. and king Edward of England / and Edward Bayllol king of
Scotlonde / had well apparelled their folk in four bataylles / for to
fight on foot against the Scotts their enmyes. And the Englys the mynstrels
blewe their trumpetes and the. yr claryons / and hydously ascryed the Scotts.
And tho had every English battle two wings of price archers. The which at
that battle shot arowes so fast and so sore: that the Scotts might not
help themsefle. And they smote the Scotts thousands unto the ground. And
they began for to flee fro the englysshmen for to save their lives: And when
the Scotts knaves saw the scomfyture and the Scotts fall fast to the ground
/ they preckyd fast their masters horse with the sporis for to kept them
from peril / and sete their masters at on force And when thenglyssmen saw that
they lept on their horses / and fast pursued the Scotts / and all that abode
they slew down right. There men might see the doughtinesse of the noble king
Edward and of his men how manly they pursewed the Scotts / that flow for
dread. And there men might see many a Scottysshman cast down unto ye ground
/ and the baners dysplayde hackyd in to pieces and many a good haberyoyne of
stele in the blood bathe / And many a time the Scotts were gadred in to
co^panyes / but ever more they were discomfyted. And so it befell as god
almighty would. that the Scotts had that day no more fayson ne might against
the Englysshemen than.xx. sheep among.v. wulues. And so were the Scotts
dyscomfyted / and yet the scottees was well.v. men against one englysshmen And
ye battle was done on Halydoune hill beside the town of Berwyk. At the which
battle were slain of the Scotts.xxxv^ thousand and.vii. houndred and.xii.
And of the Englysshemen but only.xiii. And this victory befell to the
Englysshmen on saint Margyretes even the holy virgyn and martyr in the year of
our lord Ihesu christ.M.CCC.xxxii. And while this doing lastyd the English
pages took the pylfre of the Scotts that were slain / every man that he might
take. without any chalengynge of any man. And so after this gracyous victory.
the king turned him again unto the same syege of Berewyk. And when they be
syeged saw and herd how king Edward had speed / they yielded to him the
town with the castle / on the morrow after saint Margaretes day. And then
the king did ordeyne sir Edward Baylloll / with other noble and worshypfull
men / to be kepers and governors of all Scotlonde in his absence. And himself
turned aye^ and came into Enlo^de after this vyctorye / with much Joy and
also worship and in the next year following after / that is for to say in the
year of the Incarnacyon of our lord Ihesu eryste.M.CCC.xxxiii. And of king
Edward.vii^ he went again in to Scotlonde / in winter time At the which
vyage the castle of kylbrygge in Scotlonde / for him and for his men that were
with him he recovered and had against the Scotts All at his own lust. And in
that same year sir Edward Bayloll king of Scotlonde / held his parliament in
Scotlonde with many noble lords of England that were at that same parlemente
/ because of their lands and also lordshyps that they had in the reame of
Scotlonde. And held all of the same Baylloll. And in the.viii. year of his
regne / abowte the feast of saint Johan Baptist sir Edward Bayllol they vere
and true king of Scotlonde / as by heretage and right line / made his homage
and feaute unto king Edward of England for the reame of Scotlonde at new
castle upon Tyne. In the present of many a worthy man and also of comyns
both of the reame of England / and also of Scotlonde^ And anon after in the
same year king Edward of England / received of the duke of Brytayne his
homage / for the erldom and lordshyp of Rychmonde. And so following in the.ix.
year of his regne after Myghelmas rode into Scotlond And there was fast by
saint Ioha^nes town almoost all the winter time / And so he held his
Crystemas at the castle of Rokersbourgh And in the same year trughout all
England / abowte saint Clementys tide in winter. Chere arose such a
sprengynge and wellynge up of waters / and also flodes / both of the sea and
also of the fresshe ryuers and sprenges that the sea banks / walls and costs
/ brake up / that mennys bestes and housys in many places and namely in low
countrees / vyolently and suddenly were drowned / and fruit driven away of
the earth / through contynaunce and abundaunce of waters of the sea / over more
afterward were turned into more saltness and soreness or sauoure. The.x.
year of king Edwardes regne. king Edward entered the Scotts see after
Mydsomer. And to many of the Scotts he have bataylle / and overcame them and
many he treatyd and bowed unto his peace / thrughe his doughtynesse and
hardynesse. And after the feast of saint Myghell then next following was the
earl of Moryf had and taken at Edenbrugh and brought into England and put
into prison. And in the months of June and Iulii tha^ next following in the
xi. year of his regne was seen and apperyed in the fyrmament a beme sterre the
which clerks call stella Cometa and that sterre was seen in diverse parts of
ye fyrmament. Where after anon there followed in England good chepe and
wonder great plente of chaffare vytaylles and marchandyse / and there against
honger scarsyte myscheyf and need of monye. In so much that a quartre of whete
at London was sold for two shellynge and a good fat ox at a noble / and
five good douues birds for a penny. In which year deped sir John^ of ^l^am
earl of Cornewaylle that was king Edwardes brother and lies at westmestre.

How king Edward made a duchye of the Erldome of Cornewayle and also of six
other Earls that were new made / and of the first challenge of ye kyngdodome
of France.
IN the year of our lord a.M.CCC.xxx.vii. and of king edward.xii. in the
month of march during the parliament at westmestre in lent time king
Edward made of the erldome of Cornewayle a duchye and let it call the duchye
of Cornewayle / the which ducye he gaaf unto Edward his first sone with the
erldom of Chestre. And also king Edward made at that same time six other
earls / That is for to say Sir Henry the earl of Lancastres sone earl of
Leycetre / Wyllyam of Bughu^ earl of Northampto^ / wyllyam of Mountagu / earl
of Salysbury / Hughe of Awdell earl of Gloucestre / Roberte of V^orde earl of
Southfolke / And wyllyam of Clyton Earl of Huntyngeton. And in that same year
it was ordained in the same parlemente that no man should were no clothe that
was wrought out of England. as clothe of gold ne of sylke or velvet or damask
or satyne baudkyn ne none such other ne none wild ware ne furs of bind yt
see. But such as might spend an hundred pound of rent by year. but this
ordinance and statute was but of lytyl effect For yt was no thing holden. In
the.xiii. year of his regne king Edward went over see into Braban with queen
Phylyp his wife there beryng a child at And warpe there he dwelled more than a
year for to treat with the duke of Braban and other alyed unto him of the
chalengynge of the kingdom of France. to king Edward of England by right
and by heritage after the death of Karoll the great king of France brother
Gerymayne of queen Isabell king Edwardes mother / the which was holden and
occupied unrightful by Phylyp of Valoys the e^mys of king Karoll / the wheche
duke and all his in ye foresaid things and all other longing there to with
all his men and goods king Edward found ready unto him and made and behyght
him suerte by good faith and trust / and after that ye king has him again into
England and lelft there the queen still be hynde him in Braban. Than in
ye.xiiii. year of his regne when all ye lords of his reame and other that
oughten to be at his parliament were called and assembled together in ye same
parliament holden at London after the feast of saint Hylarye / The kings needs
were put forth and promothed as touching the kingdom of France. For which
needs to be spedde the king axed the fyfte part of all the meuable goods of
England and the wulles and the.ix. sheep of every corn / And all the lords
of every town where such things should be taxed and gadryd should answer to
the king thereof / and had it and held it at his own lust and will wherefore if
I should knowleche the very troth / the ynner love of the people was turned in
to hate And the common prayers in to cursinge / for cause that the comune people
were so strongely grieved. Also the for said Phylyp Valoys of France had
gadred unto him a great host and destroyed in his parties and kingdom / many
of the kings friends of England with towns and castles many other of their
lordhypoes and many harms shamys and dystytes did unto the queen / where fore
king Edward when he herd this tidings strongely meued therwythe and red. and
sent diverse letters over see to ye queen and to other that were his friends
Glagynge them certefyenge them yt he would be there himself in all the haste
that he mygh. And anon after Ester when he had sped of all things yt him
neded to have / he went over see again. Of whose cominge ye queen and all his
friends were wonder glad and made much Joy And all that were his enmyes and
held against him made as much sorrow. In the same time the king thrughe
counseyll of his true lyeges and counsel of his lords that there we
represent with him write the kynhe of Frau^ces name / and took and meddled the
kings arms of France quartred with tharmes of England and commanded forth
with his coyen of gold under dyserypcyon and writing of the name of england
and of France be made best that might be / and that is to say the floreyne
that was called the noble price of.vi shellynge.viii pens sterlynge / and the
half nobell the value.iii^ shellynge and.iiii. pens / and the far things the
value of.xx. pens.

How king Edward came unto the scuys and dyscomfyted all the power of
France in the haven.
ANd in the next year after / that is to say the.xv. year of his regne he
commanded and let write in his chartres wryttes and other letters the date of
the regne of france the first And while that he was thus doing and
trauayllynge in france thrughe his counseyll he wrote to all the prelates dukes
earls and barons and the noble lords of the country / and also to diverse of
the comune people diverse letters and maundementes berynge date at Gandaue the
viii. day of February. And anon after within a little time he came again in to
england with the queen and her children. And in the same year on mydsomer even
he began to saylle to ward France again / and manly and fyersly he fell upon
Phylyp of Valoys the which long time lay and had gadryd to him a full long
and boystous meny of diverse nations in the haven of Sceuys / and there they
foughten together the king of france and he with their hosts fro myddaye to
three of the clock in the morn / in the which battle were slain.xxx.
thousand men of the kings company of france / and many ships and cogges
were taken And so through gods help he had there the vyctorye. and bear
thens a glorious chyualry And in the same year abowte saint James tide without
the yates of Saint Omers Robert of Arthoys with men of England and Flaun
faught against ye duke of Burgon and the Frensshemen / at which battle were
slain and take of the frensshmen.xv. barons and.lxxx. knights and ships and
barges were take unto the nombre of CC. and.xxx. The same year the king
making and abiding upon the sege of ^ornay the earl of Henaude with English
archers made assaul^^ unto the town of Saint A^ande where they slew.l.
knights and many other and also destroyed the town. And in the.xvi. year of
his regne following in the winter time the king stylle upon the foresaid seyge
and sent of time into england unto his tresorer and other purueyours for gold
and money that should be se^te unto hy^ there i^ his need but his proctours
and messyngers cursedly and full slouly served him at his need and deceived him
/ on whoos defaute and latches the king took trewes between him and the king
of france / And then king Edward full of shame and sorrow in his heart
with drew him fro the sege and come into Brytayne and there was so great
strive of battle that he lost many of his people. And when he had done there
that he come for he dressyd him over see in to England ward. And as he saylled
to ward England in the high see the most myshappes storms and tempests
thondre and lyghtnynge fell to him in ye see / the which was said that it
was done and yraysyd through evil spirytes made by sore ery and nygro mancye of
them of france / wherefore the kings heart was full of sorrow / and a^guysshe
welllynge and syghynge and said unto our lady in this wyse^ O blessed lady
Saint Mary what is the cause that ever more going into france al things and
wethers fallen to me Joyful and liking and as I would have them / but always
tornynge into England ward all things fallen unprofitable and very harmfull
nevertheless he scapyd all perelles of the sea as god would / and came to the
tour of London by night. And the same year the king held his Crystmas at
Meneres and sent word to the Scotts by his messagers that he was ready and
would do fight with them. but the Scotts would not abide that but fled
over ye Scotts see and hyd them a well as they might. And in the.xvii. year of
his regne about the feast of the Co^uersyon of saint poull king Edward when
he had been in Scotlond and saw that ye scotts were fled tho he come again
into England. And a little before lent was the turnement at Dunstable / tho the
which tourmente come all the young bachelary and chyualry of England with
many other earls and lords. At the which turnemente king Edward himself was
there present And ye next year following in the.xviii. year of his regne at his
parlemente holden at westmynster the auyzeme of paske king Edward the third
made Edward his first sone prince of walys. And in the.xix. year of his regne
anon after in Ianyuer before lent the same king Edward let make full noble
Iustes and great feestes in the place of his birth at wyndsore that there was
never none such seen there before. At which feast and ryalte were two kings
and two queen's the prince of walys the duke of Cornewayle.x. Earls.ix.
Countesses barons and many burgeys the which might not lightly be no^bred /
and of diverse lands beyond the sea weren many strangers. And at the same
time when the Iustes were done. king Edward made a great souper in ye which
he ordened and began his round table and ordened and stedfasted the day of
the round table to be holden there at wyndesore in the wytsone weke never
more yearly. and this time Englyssh men so much haunted and cleuyd to the
woodnes and folly of the strangers / that from time of coming of
Henaudes.xviii. year passed they ordained and changed them every year diverse
shappes and dysguysynge of clothing of long large and wide clothes dystytute
and dyserte frem all old honest and good usage. And an other time short
clothes and strayte wastyd gagged and kyt and on every side slatered and
botoned with sleues and tapytis of surcotes and hodes over long and ouermoche
hanging / that if I the sothe shall say they were more like to tormentours
and deuyls in their clothing and shokynge and other array than to men and the
wymen more nycely yet passed the men in array and euouslyer / for they were so
strayte clothed that they lefe hang fore tails sewyd byneth within there
clothes for to feel and hyde their arsers / the which dysguysynges and pride
parauenture / afterward brought fourth and caused many myshappes and
myschyef in ye reame of England. The.x^. year of king Edward he went over
in to Brytayne and Gascoyne In whoos company went the earl of warwyk / the
earl of Souffolke. the earl of Huntyngton and the earl of Arundell / and many
other lords and comune people in a great multitude with a great Nauye of.CC.
and.xl. ships / anon after mydsomer for to avenge him of many wrongs and
harms to him done by Phylyp of Valoys king of France ayene the trewes
before hand grauntyd / the which the trewes he falsely and vntrewely by
cauelacyons and dysquatter

How king Edward saylled in to Normandy and arrived at hogs with a great
host.
IN the.xxi. year of his regne king Edward through counseyll of all the great
lords of England called and gadred together in his parlemente at westmestre
before Ester ordained him for to pass over the sea again for to disease and
dystrobled the rebels of France. And when his Nauye was come together and
made ready he went with a great host the.xii. day of Iulii. and saylled in to
Normandye and arrived at hogs. And when he had rested him there.vi. days for
by cause of trauaylyng of the sea and for to have out all his men with all
their necessaryes out of their ships / he went toward Cadomun brenuynge
