wastinge and destroyenge all the towns that he found in his way. And
the.xxvi. days of July at the bridge of Cadony manly and nobly stre^gthed and
defended with Normans he had there a strong battle and a long during /
through which a great multitude of people were slain / And there were taken of
prisoners the earl of Ewe / the lord of Thonkeruyll / and an hundred of other
knights and men of arms / and.vi. hundred of foot men nombred and the town
and the subbarbes / unto the bare wall / and of all things that they might
bear and caryen out was robbyd and dyspoyled. After the king passed forth by
ye country about the bread of.xx. mile he wastyd all manner thing yt he found
when Phylyp of Valoys perceived this / all thought he were fast by him with a
strong host yet he would not come nygh him but break all the brydges beyond
ye water of Seyn fro Royn to Paris / and himself fled unto the same cite of
Paris with all the have that he might. For sothe noble king Edward when he
came to Paris bridge and found it broken / within two days he let make it
again / And in the morrow after the Assumpco^n of our lady king Edward
passed over ye water of Seyn goyege to ward Crescy and dystroyed by the way
towns with the people dwelling there in / and in the feast of saint
Bartholomewe he passed over the water of so^me unhurt with all his host there
as never before fond any manner way ne passage. where.ii.M. were slain of
them that let their passage. over. Therefore the.xxvi. day of Auguste /
king Edward in field fast by Frescy having three batayls of Englysshmen en
cou^tred and met with Phylyp of Valoys haui^ge with him.iiii. batayls of
which the leest passed greatly the nombre of english people. And when these
two hosts met together / there fell upon him the kyngh of Beme / the duke of
Loreyn. and earls also of Flaunders / Dalau^son / bloys harecourt / Aumarle and
Neuors / and many other Earls barons lords and knights and men of arms ye
nombre of a.M.v.C.xlii. without foot men and other men armed that were no
thing rekened. And for all this the vngloryous Philyp with drew him with the
resydue of his people. wherefore it was said in common among his own people.
Nere^ be all soy retreyt. that is to say our fair with draws him. Than
king Edward and our Englysshme^ thankyd almighty god for such a vyctory after
there great labor take to them all thing needful to their sustynaunce / and
saving of their lives and for dread of their enmyes rested them there. And
full erly in the morning after ye Frensshmen with a great passing host come
again for to give battle and fight with the Englysshmen / with whom met and
encountered the earl of warwyke Northampton and Norfolk with their company and
slew.ii. M. and took many prisoners of the gentyls of them. And the remenaunt
of ye same host fled three mile thens. And the third day after ye battle ye
king went to Calays ward destroyenge all ye towns as he rode thither / wha^
that he come^ that is to say ye third day of Septe^bre he began to besege ye
town with ye castle and continued his sege fro the foresaid third day of
Septembre to ye third day of August ye next year after. And in the same year
during ye syege of Calays the king of Scotlo^de with a great multitude of
scotts came in to England to Neuyles cross / about saint Lucas day the
Eua^gelyst hoping and trusting for to have found all ye land void of
people for as much as the king of England was beyond the sea / sauf oonly
prestes and men of holy church and women and children / and plowmen and such
other laborers / and there they come and robbyd and did much preuy sorrow.
But yet found they enough that them withstode by ye grace of almighty god /
and so a day of battle was as sygned between them and certain lords and me^
of holy church yt were of ye country with other comune people fast by the
cite of Duresme. at which day through the grace and help of god almighty the
Scotts were ouercomen and yet were there three times so many of the^ as of
englysshemen^ And there was slain all the chyualry and knyghthode of the reame
of Scotlond. And there was taken as they would have fled thens Dauyd of king
of Scotlonde himself and the earl of mentyf Sir wyllyam Douglas and many other
great men of Scotland. And after that our Englysshemen when they had rested
them a few days and had ordained their kepers of the North country. they
came to London and brought with them sire Dauyd the king of Scotlonde and all
the other lords that were taken prisoners unto the toure of London with all
the haste that they might. and left them there in sauf keeping unto the kings
coming and went home again in to their own country. And after ward was the
king raunson of Scotlond taxed to an hundred thousand mark of silver to be
paid within.x. year / that is to say every year.x. thousand mark.

How king Edward besyeged Calays and how it was won and yolden unto him.
IN the.xxii^ year of king Edwardes regne went over see in the winter time /
and lay al ye winter at the sege of Calays / the which year while the syege
lasted and endured Phylyp the king of france cast and purposed traytoursly
and with fraud to put away the syege and came the ^xxvii. day of Iuyll in
the same year with a great host and strong power and neyghed to the sege of
Calays. The which Phylyp the last day of Iulii. sent to the king Edward
word that he would give him plain battle ye third day after ye about
Eue^songe time if he durst come fro the sege and abide. And wha^ king Edward
herd that any without long taryenge or long auysentente accept gladly ye
day and hour of battle yt Philyp had assygned And when the king of France
herd that / ye next night after he set his tentys a fire and remeued and went
his way thens cowardly. Then they that were in ye town and in the castle
besyeged saw all this that they had none other help ne socour of ye king of
France ne of his men And also that their vytayls within them were spended and
wastyd and for fault of vytayls and of refresshynge they eten horses hounds
cattes and myse for to keep their troth as long as they might And wha^ they
saw and was found among them at the last that they had no thing among them
for to ete ne live by ne no socour ne rescowe of the frenssheme^ / of that
other side they wist well that they must needs deye for defaute or else yield
the town / and anon they went and took down ye baners and the arms of
france on every side that were hange^ out and went on ye walls of ye foresaid
town on diverse places as naked as ever they were borne sauf only their
shertes and their pryue clothes. and held their swerdes naked and the point
donward in their hondes / and putte^ ropes and halters about their necks and
yielded up the keys of the town and of the castle to king Edward of England
with great fere and dread of their lives and goods and dread of heart / And
king Edward saw all this as / a mercyable king and lord receyyed them to
grace / and few of the grettest prisoners of estate and governance of the
town he sent into England there for to abide their raunson and the kings
grace. And all the comynallte of the town the king let goo weder they would
in peace and with out any harm / and let them bear with the^ all their things
yt they might bear and carye away keeping ye twone and the castle to hymself^
Then through meditacyon of Cardynales that were sent from the pope / trewes
was take there by twene France and england for.ix. months than next
following. And about Myghelmas king Edward come again into Enlond with a
glorious vyctory. And in the.xxiii. year of his regne. in the Eest parties of
the world there arose and began a pestylence and death of Sarasyns and Paynyms
that so great a death was never herd of a fore / that wasted away the people so
that uneath the tenth person was left alive. And the same year about the such
countrees and also in the west countrees there fell so much rain and so great
waters that from Crystmas to myd somer there was uneaths no day ne night but
that it rayned some what / through which waters the pestylence was so enfected
and so habu^daunte in all countres. and namely about the court of Rome. and
other places and see costs that there were left living folk for too bury
they^ that were deed honestly But made great dyches and pyttes that were
wonder broad and deep and therein buried them / and made a renge of deed bodies
and cast a little earth to feel them above / and than cast in a another renge
of deed bodies / and an other renge above them / and thus were they buried and
none other wise / but if it were so that they were men of great estate so yt
they were buried as honestly as they might. And after all this in the.xxiiii.
year of king Edwardes regne it was done him to wete and understand of a
treason that was begone at Calays and ordained for to sell that town for a
great so^me of Florens unto king Phylyp of France thrughe the falsnesse and
or dynau^ce of a knight that was called sire Geffrey of Cherney was wonder
preny with king Phylyp of France And when king Edward herd this he took
with him the noblest and gentyllest lords and many other worythy men of arms
that were there present with him for the solempnyte of that high feast. And
well wisely in all the have that he myghe / and as pryuely as he might he went
over see to ward Calays. And that same year the good king edward held his
crystmas at Hauerynge. And the morn after new yers day the king was in the
castle of Calays with his men of arms that none of the alyens wist there of.
And that fais conspiratour and traitor Geffrey of Cherney sith that he might
not openly have his purpose of the castle / pryuely and stelyngly he come in
and held ye town with a great host. And wha^ he with his men were comen in /
he paid the for said sum of floreyns as couenaunte was to a Geneweye in the
town that was keeper of the castle and consentinge to the same Geffrey in all
his falsnesse and trechorye and bounden the English mynstrels and servants
that were in the castle yt they might not helep themself ne let them of
their purpos. And than wenyng that they had been sure enough / then they spaken
al their wickydnesse and falnesse openly on high yt all men might here. and now
shall ye here how they were deceived / for they came in by a preuy posterne
over a little bridge of tree / and wha^ they were comen in subtyly and pryuely
the bridge was drawn up and kept that no^e of them that came in might go out
ne no moo might come to them / and anon our Englysshmen went out at preuy
holes and wyndowes and over ye walls of the town and of the castle and went
and faught manly with the frensshmen that were without and had the better of
them / the which when they were occupied by them self on their side / the
king that was within the town having scarsely but.xxx. men of arms drew out
his sword and with a loud voys he creyed on high. Osaynt Edward. Osaynt
George. And when the people herd that / they come rennynge to him and gaaf
there to their enmyes so great assawte that there were moo than two hundred
men of arms and many mo other slain and many fled a way. And so by grace of
god almighty the vyctory fell unto the Englysshmen. Then the king took with
him this Geffrey that was fynder of this trechory And also many other Frenssh
prisoners / and then within a while after he come again in to England. And
in this same year and in the year before and also in ye year next following was
so great a pestylence of men from the eest in to ye west and namely through
botches that tho that sykened / as on this day deyed on the third day after
/ to the which men that so deyed in this pestylence had but little respyte of
lyssynge. The pope Clemente of his goodness and grace gaf them full remyssyon
and forgyuenesse of all their sins that they were shryuen of / and this
pestyle^ce lasted in London fro Myghelmas unto August. next following almoost
an hole year. And these days was death without sorrow / weddynges without
frendshyp / wylfull penance / and derth without scarsyte. And fleing without
refute or socour. for many fled from place to place by cause of pestylence. But
they were enfected and might not escape the death / after that the prophet
Isay sith who that flees fro the face of dread he shall fall into the dyche.
And he that wyndeth him out of the dyche he shall be hold and eyed with a
grenne / but when this pestyle^ce was cessyd as god would uneaths ye tenth
part of the people was left on live. And in ye same year began a wonder thing
that all that ever were borne after that pestylence had two cheketh in their
heed less than they had before.

How king Edward had a great battle with Spanyardes in ye see fast by
wynchelse.
ANd in the.xxv. year of his regne about saint Iohans day in harvest in the sea fast by wynchelse king Edward had a great battle with men of Spain
where yt their ships and nauye lay chayned together / that other they must
fight or be drenched. And so when all other worthy me^ and of the sea costs
fast by wynchelse and romeny were gadred together / and our nauye and ships al
ready to the war / the Englysshemen met manly and strongly with their enmyes
coming fyersly against them. And when the Spayns vessels and nauye were closed
all about / there men might se strong battle on both sides and long during
in ye which bataylle was but few that faught but they were rytously hurt.
And after the battle there were.xxiii. ships taken and so the Englysshemen
had the better. And in the next year following of his regne. that is to say
the xxvi. year the king through his counseyll let ordeyne and make his new
money / that is to say the penny the grote value of.iiii. pens and the half
great of.ii. pens. But it was of less weight than ye old sterlynge was be.v.
shells. in the pound. And in the.xxvii. year of his regne was the great derth
of vytayls yt which was called the dear somer. And the.xxviii. year of his
regne in the parliament holden at westmestre after Ester. sir Henry earl of
Lancastre was made duke of Lancastre and in this year was so great a drought
that from the monethe of March to the Monethe of Iuyll there fell no rain on
therth / wherefore all fruytes seeds and herbs / for the most part were lost
in defaute wherefore come so great disease of men and beestes and derth of
vytayls in England that this land that ever before had been plenteuous had
need that time to seek vitayls and refresshynge at other out yles and countres.
And the.xxix. year of king Edward it was accorded granted and sworn between
the king of France and king Edward of England that he shode have again all
his lands and lordshyppes that lo^ged to ye duchye of guyhen of old time the
which had be^ withdrawn and wrongfully occupied by diverse kings of France
before hand to have and to hold to king Edward and to his heirs and
successors for evermore. freely pesybly and in good quyete upon this covenant
that ye king of England should leave of and releasen all his right and claim
that he had claymed of the kingdom of france and of the title that he took
thereof / upon which speech and couenauntes it was sent to the court of Rome
on both sides of the kings. that ye foresaid covenant should de enbulled. but
god ordained better for the kings worship of England. for what through fraud
and dysceyte of the frensshme^ and what through lettynge of the pope and of the
court of Rome the foresaid couenau^tes were dysquate and left of. And in the
same year the king revoked by his wise and dyscrete counsel / the staple of
wulles out of flaundres into England with all ye lybertees fraunches and fre
customs that longed thereto and ordained it in England in diverse places /
that is for to say at westmestre / Caunterbury. Chychestre. Brystowe.
Lyncoln. And Hulle with all the foresaid things that longen thereto. And that
this thing that should thus be done the king swore himself thereto / and prince
Edward his sone with other many great witnesses that there where present. And
the xxx^ year of his regne anon after wytsontyde in the parlemente ordained
at westmenstre it was told and certefyed to the king that Phylyp that held
the kingdom of France was deed. And that Johan his sone was crowned king.
And that this Johan had given Karoll his sone the duchye of Guyhen. of the
which thing king Edward when he wist thereof he had great Indygnacyon unto
him and was wonder wroth and strongly meued. And therefore before all the
wrothy lords that there were assembled at that parliament called Edward his
sone unto him / to whom ye duchye of Guyhen by right heritage should long to
and gave it him there bidding and strenthynge him that he should ordeyne him
for to defend him and avenge him upon his enmyes and save and mayntene his
right. And afterward king Edward himself / and his eldest sone Edward went
to diverse places and saints in England on pilgrimage for to have the more
help and grace of god and of his saints. And ye.ii. kal of Iuyll. when all
thing was ready to that vyage and battle and all his retenue and power
assembled and his navy also ready he took with him ye earl of warwyk the earl of
Suffolk the earl of Salysbury and the earl of Oxforde and a thousand men of
arms and as many archers / and in the Natyuyte of our lady / took their
ships at plu^mouth and began to sayll. And when he come and was arrived in
Guyon / he was there worshypfully taken and recyued of the most noblest men
and lords of that country. And anon after king Edward took with him his
two sons. that is to say. sir Lyonell earl of Vlton and sir John^ his brother
earl of Rychemonde and sir Henry duke of Lancastre with many earls and lords
and men of arms and two thousand Archers and saylled toward France and
rested him a while at Calays and after the king went with his host aforsayd
and with other souldyours of beyond the sea that there abode the kings
coming the second day of Nouembre and took his Journey toward king John^
of France there as he trowed to have found him fast by Odomarum as his
letters and covenant made mencyon yt he would abide him there with his host.
And when king Johan of France herd tell of the kings coming of England /
he went away with his men and caryage cowardly and shamfully fleing and
wasting all vytayls that Englsshme^ should not have there of. And when king
Edward / herd tell that he fled he pursued him with all his host till
Henede / and than he beholdynge the scarsyte and waiting of vytayls and also
the cowardyse of the king of France he turned again wasting all the country.
And while all these things were a doing / ye scotts pryuely and by night.
took the town of Berwyk sleynge them that withstode them and no man else. But
blessed be god the castle was saved and kept by Englysshmen that were therein
when the king perceived all this / he turned again in to England as wroth as
he might be / wherefore in the parliament at westmynstre was grauntyd to the
king of every sack of wulle.l. shellynges during ye term of.vi. year that
he might myghtlyer fight and defend the reame ayenste the Scotts and other
mysdoers. And so when all things were ready the king hasted him to ward the
syege.

How king Edward was crowned king of Scotlonde / and how prince Edward took
the king of France and sir Philyp his younger sone at the battle of Peyters.
ANd in the.xxxi. year of his regne the.xiii. day of Ianyuere the king being
in the castle of Berwyk with a few men / but he hauynge^ there fast by a
greote host. The town was yolden unto him without any manner defense or
dyffyculte. Tha^ the king of Scotlond that is for to say sir John^ Bayloll
considering how that god did many meruaylles and gracyous things for king
Edward at his own will fro day to day / he took and gaaf up the reame of
Scotlonde and the crown of Scotlond at Rokesburgh in ye kings hondes of
England under his patent letter there made. And anon after king Edward in
presence of all the prelates and other worthy men and lords that were there
let him crown king of Scotlond. And when all things were done and erdeyned
in that countres at his will / he turned again into england with a great
worship. And while this vyage was in doing in Scotlonde / sire Edward
prince of wales as a man enspyred i^ god was in Guyhen in the cytee of Burdeux
treating and spekyge of the challenge and of the kings right of England that
he had to the reame of France / and that he would be aue^ged with strong
hand / and to the prelateg peers and might men of that country consented
well to him. Than sir Edward the prince with a great hooste gadred to him
the.vi. day of Iuyll went from Burdeux going and traueylynge by many
diverse countrees / and he took many prisoners moo than ^vi. thousand mem of
arms by the country as he went and took the town of Remorantyne in
Saloygne and besyeged the castle.vi. dayes^ And at the.vi. days end they
yolde the castle unto him / and there was taken the lord of crown and sir
Bursygaude and many other knights and men of arms moo than.lxxx. And fro
thens by Toren and Peten fast by Chyneney his noble men that were with him
had a stonge battle with Frensshmen / and an hundred of their men of arms
were slain. And the earl of Dance and the steward of / france were taken
with an hundred men of arms In the which year the.xix. day of Septembre
fast by Pyeters the same prince with a thousand and.ix. hundred men of arms
and archers ordained a battle to king Johan of france coming tho the prince
ward with.vii. thousand chosen men of arms and much other people a great
nombre / of the which were slain the duke of Burbon and the duke of Athenes
and many other noble men and of the princes men of arms a thousand and of
other the true account and reckoning.viii.C. And there the king of France
was taken and sir Phylyp his younger sone and many dukes and noble men and
worthy knights and men of arms about two.M. and so the vyctory fell there
the prince / and to the people of England by the grace of god. And many that
were taken prisoners were set at their raunson and upon their truth and
knyghthode were charged and had leave to goo. But the prince took with him
the king of France and Philyp his sone with all the reverence that he might
and went again to Burdeux with a glorious vyctory / the sum of the men that
there were taken prisoners and of them that were slain the day of
battle.iiii.M.iiii.C.xl. and in the.xxxii. year of king Edward the.v. day
of May prince Edward with king John^ of France and Philyp his sone and many
other worthy prisoners arrived gracyously in the haven of plu^mouth And
the.xxiiii. day of the same month about three after none they came to London
by London bridge and so went forth to the kings palace at westmynstre /
and there came so great a multitude and press of people abowte them to
behold and se that wonder and ryall syghte that uneaths fro maddaye tylle
night might they not come to westmyster. And the kings raunson of France
was taxed and set to three myllyons of scutes / of whom two should be worth a
nobell. And ye shall understand that a myllyon is a thousand thousand / and
after some mennys raunson was set at three thousand thousaynde floreyns and
all is one effecte^ And this same year were made Iustes solemn in Smytfende
being present the king of England / the king of France / and the king of
Scotlonde / and many other worthy and noble lords. The.xxxiii. year of his
regne the same king Edward at wynsore as well for love of knight hode as for
his ownne worship and at reverence of the king of france and other lords
that were there at that time / he held a wonder ryal and costly feast of saint
George passing any that ever was holden before. wherefore the king of france
in scornynge said that he saw never ne herd such a solemn festes ne ryaltes
holden ne done with taylles without payenge of gold or silver. And in
the.xxxiii. year of his regne the.xiiii. kalendas of Iulii. Sire Johan earl of
Rychmonde king Edwardes sone wedded dame blaunche duke Henryes daughter of
Lancastre cosyn to the same Johan by dyspencyon of the pope. And in the mean
time were ordained Iustes at London three days of roga^yons / that is for too
say. The Mayer of London with his.xxiiii. aldermen against all that would come
/ in whoos name and stead the king pryuely with his four sons Edward /
Lyonell / Johan and Edmonde and other.xix. great lords helden the field. with
worship. And this same year as it was told and said of them that saw it
there come blood out of ye comb of Thomas sometime earl of Lancastre as fresshe
as that day that he was done to death. And in the same year king Edwade chose
this sepulture and his lyggynge at westmestre fast by the shryne of saint
Edward. and anon after the xxvi. day of Octobere. he went over see to
Calays making protestaco^n that he would never ^^me again into England till he
had in ends the war between france and him And so in the.xxvi. year of his
regne in the winter come king Edward was and trauaylled in the Ryne costs. And
about saint Hyllarye tide he departes his host and went to Burgon ward / with
whom than met peasybly the duke of Bourgon. behyghtynge him.lxx. thousand
floreyns that he should spare his men and h^s people / and the king grauntyd
at his request. And dwelled unto the.xvii. day of March yt which time come
to king Edwardes eere that strong thieves were on the sea under the earl of
saint Poule the.xv. day of March ^yggynge a wait upon the towns of Rastynge
Rye and other places and vyllages on the sea cost hadden entered as enmyes in to
the town of wynchelle / and slew all that ever withstode them and with said
their coming. wherefore y king was greatly meued and wratthed and he turned
again so ward Paris. and commanded his host to dystroye and sle all with
strench of sword that he had before hand spared. And ye.iii. day of Apryl
the king come to Paris and there departed his host in diverse batayls
with.iiii.C. knights new dubbyd on that one side of him. And sir Henry duke
of Lancastre under peace and trewes went unto the yates of the cite proferynge
to them yt would abide a battle in the field under such condicyon yt if the
king of England were over comen there / as god forbid it should / yt than he
should neued challenge the kingdom of france. And there he had of them but
short and scornful answer and came and told it to the king and his lords
what he had herd and what they said / And then^e went forth the new kynghtes
with many other making assawte to the cite and they dystroyed the subbarbes of
the cyty. And while al these things were doing the Englysshmen made them ready
for to be avenged upon the shame and dyspyte that was done ye year at wynshelse
and ordained a nauye of.lxxx^ ships of men of London and of other merchants
and.xiii. thousand men of arms and archers and went and serched and sku^med
the sea and manly token and held the isle of Caux. wherefore the Frensshmen that
is for to say the abbot of Cluyn the earl of Tankeruyll and bursygaude yt tho
was steward of France with many other men of the same country by ye comune
assent of ye lord Charles yt the was reigned of France they hastyd them and
went to the king of England asking and besechynge him steadfast peace and
everlasting upon certain condyco^nes yt there were showed written / The which
when ye king and his counsel had seen it / it pleased him never a deal. but
sith it would be none other wise ye time of better accord and delyberacyon /
ye Frensshemen besely and with great in stau^ce asked trewes for the sea
costs. and the king grau^tyd them. And in the morrow after the vtas of Pasche
the king turned him with his host to ward Orlyau^ce destroyenge and wasting
all ye country by the way. And as they went theder ward there fell upon them
seche a storm and tempest yt none of our nacyon never herd ne saw none
such. through the which thousands of over men and thryr horses in their
Journey as it were through vengeance suddenly were slain and perysshed. the
which tempests were full great yet fered not ye king ne much of his people
but they went forth in their vyage yt they had bego^ne / wherefore about ye
feast of Phylyp and Jacob in May fast by in Carnocu^ the for said lords of
France metynge there with the king of Engelonde apsyble accord and a fynall
upon certain condyons and grau^ts artycularly gadred written together evermore
for to last dyscertly made and to both the kings proffytable and to both
their reames of one assente of Charles the regner and governor of France and
of Paris of the same reame written and made under dare of carnocu^ the.xv. day
of May. they offered and proffred to ye king of England requyring his grace in
all things written yt he would benyngl^ admyt them and hold the^ ^erme and
stable to the^ and to their heirs for evermore thens for the / the which
things and artycles when king Edward had seen the^ he grau^tyd them so yt
both parties should be sworn on gods body / and on the Euangelyst yt the for
said covenant should be stablysshe and so they accorded graciously Therefore
were ordained and dressed on every side two barons two baronettes and two
kynghtes to admit and receive that oaths of ye lord Charles rege^t of France
and of sir Eeward the first sone and heryre of kings Edward of England. And
the.x^ day of May there was songen a solemn mass at Paris. and after the
Agnus dei said with dona nobys pace^ in presence of ye for said men yt were
ordained to Admit and receive the oaths and of all other yt there might be.
So Charles laid his right. hand on the patent with gods body and his left
hand on the myssall and said we. N. sweren on gods body and the holy gospels
yt we shall trewly and steadfastly hold toward us ye peace and ye accord made
between the two kings / and ^ all his lords for more love and strenth of
witness he deased and departed the relyques of ye crown of Christ to the
knights of England and they token curtously their leave / and the friday next
the same oath in presence of the forsayde knights and of other worthy me^
prince edward made at Lovers. Afterward both kings and their sons and the
most noble men of both reames. within the same year made ye same oath and for
to strength all these things before said the king of England axyd ye gretest
men of france. and had his asking that is to say.vi. dukes.viii. earls
and.xii. lords all noble barons and good knights And when ye place and time
was assygned in which both kings with their counsel should come to gyders.
al ye foresaid things between them spoken for to retefye and make ferme and
stable / the king of England anon went toward the sea and at Hountflet began
to saylle leuynge to his hosts that were left behind him by cause of his
absence made much heaviness and after the.xix. day of May he came in to England
and went to his palace at westmynstre of saint Dunstons day and the third
day after he vysyted Johan King of / france that was in the tour of London
and delyuerd him freely from all manner of prison / sauf first they were accorded
of three myllyons of floreyns for his raunso^me / and the king comfortyd him
and cheryd him in all places with all solace and myrthes that longen to a king
in his going home ward. And the.ix. day of Iulii in the same year this same
Johan king of / france that before lay here in hostage went home again / in
too his own land to treat of tho things and other that land and fallen to
the governance of his reame. And afterward met and came together at Calays
both two kings with both their counseyll about all Halowen tide. And there
were showed the condicyons and the points of the peace and of the accord of
both sides written / and there with out any with saying of both sides
gracyously they were accorded And there was done and songen a solemn mass
and after the third Agnus dei / upon gods body and also upon the mass book
both the kings and their sons and the grettest lords of both reames and of
their counseyll that there were present and had not sworn before the forsayde
oath that they had made and tytled between them they behyghten to keep / and
all other couenauntes that there between them ordeyned^ And in this same year
men beestes trees and houses with sudden tempeste and strong lyghtnynge were
perysshed / and the devil apperyd bodily man's lyknes to much people as they
went in diverse places in the countrees / and spoke to them in that lyknes.

How the great company arose in / france / and the white company in Lombardye
and of other meruaylles.
King Edward in the.xxxvi. year of his regne anon after Crystenmasse in the
feast of the conuersyon of Saint Poule held parlemente at westmestre / in the
which parlemente was put forth and showed the accord and the treates that
was stablisshed and made between the two kings which accord pleased to
much people. And therefore by the kings commandment / there were gadred and
come together in westmynster church the first sunday of lent. That is to
say the.ii. kal / february. the foresaid Englysshemen and frensshmen where was
song a solemn mass of the Trynyte of the Archebysshop of Caunterbury
master Symonde Issepe. And when Agnus dei was done the king being there with
his sons / And also the kings sons of france. and other noble and great
lords / with candell light and crosses brought forth / and that were called
thereto / that were notte sworn before swore ye same oath that was written upon
gods body and on the mass book in this wise / we /.N. and.N: sweren upon
gods body and on the holy gospels steadfastly for to hold and keep toward us
the peace. and the accord made between the two ky^ges and never for to do the
contrary / and when they had thus sworn they took their scrowes that their
oaths were comprehended into the notaryes. And in this same year in the
Ascencyons even about myddaye / was seen the clypses of ye son / And there
followed such a drought that for defaute of rain there was great brennynge of
corn fruit and hey. And in the same month the.vi. kal of June there fell a
sanguyne rain almost like blood at Burgon. and a sa^guyne cross from morn
unto pryme apered and was seen at Bolyn in the heir the which many men saw /
and after it meued and fell in the mids of the sea. And in the same time
(...) france and England and many other lands as they that were in plain
countre^s and d^serte / baren withnesse suddenly there apperyd two castles / of
the which went out two hosts of armed me^. And that one host was closed in
white and that other in black. and when Battle between them was begone the
white over came the black took heart tho them and over come the white and
after that they went again in to their castles: and tha^ the castles and all
the host vanysshed away. And in this same year was a great and an huge
pestylence of people and namely of me^ / whoos wives as women out of
governance took husbondes as well strangers as other lewd and simple people.
the which forgetynge their honor and worship coupled and married them with
the^ that were of low degree and little repuracyon In this same year deyed
Henry duke of Lancaster. And also in this same year Edward prince of walys
wedded the countess of Kente that was sir Thomas wife of Holo^de yt which was
departed sometime and deuorced fro the earl of Salysbury for cause of the same
knight And about this time began and rose a great company of diverse nasoyns
gadred together of whom their leders and governors were English people and
they were called a people with out any head the which did much harm in the
party of fraunce^ And not long after there arose an other company of diverse
nacyons that was called the white company / the which in the parties and
countrees of Lombardy did much sorrow. This same year sir Johan of Gaunt the
sone of king Edward the third was made duke of Lancastre by reason and cause
of his wife yt was the daughter and the heir of Henry sometime duke of La^caster.

Of the great wind / and how prince Edward took the lordshyp of Guyhe^ of
his fader and went theder^
ANd in the.xxxvii. year of king Edward the.xv. day of Ianyuer / that is too
say on saint Maryes day about euynsonge time there arose and come such a
wind out of the southe with such a fyersnes and strenthe that it brasted and
blewe down to the ground high houses and strong buyldynges toures chirches
and steples and other strong places and all other strong works that stoden
stylle were shaken there with that they ben yet and shall evermore be the febler
and weyker while they stand. And this wind lasted without any cessynge.vii.
days contynually^ And anon after there followed such waters in the hey time
and in the harvest time that all field works were strongely let and left
vndoyn. And in the same year prince Edward took the lordshyp of Guyhen and
did to king Edwyrde his fader homage and feaute thereof / and went over see
in to Gascoyne with his wife and children. And anon after king Edward made his
sone Lyonell duke of Clarence. and sir Edmonde his other sone / earl of
Cambridge / and in the.xxxviii. year of his regne it was ordained in the
parliament that men of law both of the church and temporeslawe should fro that
tym for the plete in their mother tongue. And in ye same year in to England three
kings that is to say the king of France the king of Cypres and the king
of Scotlonde by cause to vysyte and for to speak with ye king of England. And
after that they had be here long time two of them went home in to their own
countres and kyngodms / but ye king of France throughte great sickness and
malady that he had abode stylle in England. And in the.xxxix. year of his
regne. was a strong and a great froste and that lasted long that is to say
fro Saint Andrews tide to the.xiii. kal of Apryls / that the tylthe and
sowynge of the earth and other such feld works and hand works were much
let and left vndoyne for cold and hardness of the earth. And at orray in
Brytayn was ordained a great dedely bataylle between sire John^ of Mountforde
duke of Brytayne and sir charles of Bloys / but vyctory fell to the foresaid sir
John^ thrughe help and socour of thenglysshmen. And there were taken many
knights and squyres and other men that vnno^bred / in ye which battle was
slain Charles himself with all yt stood about him and of Englysshmen were
slain but seven. and in this year deyed at sauoy Johan the king of france
whose service and exequyes king edward let ordeyne and did in diverse places
worhypfully to be done / and at Dover of worshypful men ordained him worthily
tho be led with his own costs and expe^ces / and fro thens was brought to
france and buried at saint Denis. In the.xl. year of king Edward the vii. kal
of Februer was borne Edward prince Edwards sone ye which when he was.vii.
year of-aege he deyed^ And in the same year it was ordained yt saint Peter's
pens fro ye time forth should not be paid the which king yuo sometime king
of England of the country of west saxen yt began to regne ye year of our lord
god.vi^ hundred.lxxix. first granted to Rome for ye scole of England thereto be
continued. And in this same year there fell a great rain in hey time yt it
wasted and dystroyed both corn and hey. And there was such debate and
fyghtinge of sparowes by diverse places in these days yt men found
innumerable deed in the feldes as they went. And there fell also such a
pestylence yt never seen such in no man's days yt than lived / for men yt
went to beded hole and in good point suddenly they dyed. Also ye time a sykenes
that men call the pockes slew both me^ and women through their enfectinge.
And in the xli. year of king Edward was borne at Burdeux Richard the second
sone of prince Edward of England / the which Rychard king Richard of
Amorycan heueden at the fou^^ stone after whom he was called Rychard. and this
same Richard when his fader was deed and king Edward also / he was crowned
king of England the.xi. year of his aege through right line and heritage / and
also by the com^ne assent and desire of ye comynalte of the reame. About this
time at king Edwardes commandment of England when all the castles and towns
were yolden to him that long were holden in / france by a great company
assembled together sir Bartram Claykyn a noble knight and a good warryour went
and purposed him to put out Pers king of Spain out of his kingdom with help
of the most party of the foresaid great company trusting also upon help and
favor of the pope for as much as it come to his eeres that ye same pers
should led and use a sinful life / the which Pers smyten with dread of this
tydynge fled into Gascoyne to prince Edward for to have socoure of him. And
when he was fled out of Spain Henry his brother that was bastard by assent
of the most party of Spain and thrughe help of ye ferefull company that I
spoke of first was crowned king of Spain. and ye nombre of that same company
was rekened and set at the nombre of.xl.M. fytynge men. This same year in the
month of June there come a great company and a nauye of ye Danes gadred them
together in the North see purposynge them to come into England to reave and to
rob and also to sle with whom they countred and met in the sea. maryners
and other good fytynge men o^ the country and dysperpled them. And they
ashamyd went home again into their own country / but among ye other there was
a boystous vessel and a strong of their nauye that was over saylled by the
Englysshmen and was perysshed and drenched In the which the Steward and other
worthy and great men of Denmark were taken prisoners / and the king of
England and his counsel prysoned them. the which lords the Danes
afterward sought them all about for to have had them again with. their goods
yt they had lost / and they not well apayed ne pleased of ye answer that they
had / and they turned homwardes again leuynge behind the^ in there Innes
preuely written in scrowes and on walls. yet shall Danes wast the wanes Then
happed there an English writer and wrote against the Duke in this manner (here
shall Danes fette their banys) And in this time pers the king of Spain with
other kings that is to say. the king of Nauerne and the king of Malogre
being means wenten between and prayed counseyll and help of sir Edward the
prince whose counseyll when he had understanding their artycles and desire that
he was required of tho kings / loathe he was and ashamed to say nay and
contrary to them. But netheles he was a gast lest it should be any preiudyce
against the pope and long time tarried them or that he would grant or consent
thereto till he had better counseyl rauysemente with good delyberacyon of king
Edward his fader. But when they were with him every day and contynually
besechynge of many noble men required and spoken to / and with many prayers
sent and made between them. tha^ prince edward sent to his fader both by
co^playnyng letters and also by confortable conteynyng al their suggestyons and
causes with all ye other kings epystles and letters for to have comfort and
help of the wrongs not only done to the king Spain. but also for such
things as might fall to other kings. Also if it were not ye sooner helped and
amended through the done and help of knyghthode to the^ that it asked and
desired. The which letter when the king and his counseyll had seen such a
king spoylynge and robbynge with much merueyll. And sent again comfortable
letters to prince Edward his sone and to that other kings and warned them for
to arm them and ordeyne them against that misdoer and to withstand them by
the help of god that were such enmies to kings. wha^ this noble pry^ce had
received this letters / him self with that other kings before said all there
counseyl called togider or that he would undertake the quarrel he bound and
knytte sore ye king that was deposed with a great oath / that is to say that
he should ever after mayntene the right believe and faith of holy church / and
also with all their mynysters ryghtes and libertees to defend from all their
enmyes and all euylles. And all that were there against bytterly to punysshe and
destroble and al ye ryghtes lybertes preuyleges of holy church increase and
mayntene / and amend all things yt were wronfully taken withdrawn and bore^
a way by him or by any other by cause of him hastily to restore again and to
drive and put out sarasyns and all other mysbyleued people out of his kingdom
with all his strenth and his power and suffer ne admit none such for no
manner thing ne cause to dwell therein / And that when he had taken a christian
woman he should never come in to none other woman's bed / ne none other man's
wife to defoyle. All these for said things trewly for to keep continue and
fulfill as all his life time he was douuden by oath before notaryes in presence
and witness of tho kings with other princes. And than that gracyous prince
Edward undertook the cause and the quarrel of the king that was deposed and
behyghte him with the grace of almighty god to restore him again to his kingdom
/ and let ordeyne and gadre together forth with in all haste his nauye with
men of arms for to war and fight in his for said cause. And in this same
year upon the sand of the Scotts see yt many a man saw it three days together
there were seen two Egles / of the which ye one come out of the southe and
that other out of the north and cruelly and strongly they fought together and
wrastled together / and the south elge first overcome ye north Egle and all to
rent him with his bylle and his claws yt he should not rest ne take no birth
and the south Egle fleyth home to his own costes^ And anon after there
followed and was seen in the morn after ye son rysynge and after in the last
day of Octobre saving one many sterres gaddred together on an hepe fell down
to the earth leuynge byhynde them fire bemes in manner of lyghtnynge / was
flammes brent and consumed men's clothes and men's here wallyng on ye earth as it
was seen and known of many a man. And yet yt northern wind yt is ready and
destymate to all ylle fro saint Katherynes eve till three days after lost
great good without nobre. And in this same days there fell and also come such
lyghtnynge thondre snow and hayll that it wasted and destoyed men bestetes
howses and trees.

Of the battle of Spain beside the watre of Naxers that was between prince
Edward / and sir Henry bastard of Spain.
IN the year of our lord a.M.CCC.lxvii and of king Edward.xlii. the third
day of Aprylle there was a strong battle and a great in large field called
Pryazers fast by the water of Nazers in Spain between sire Edward the prince
and sir Henry the bastard of Spain / but the vyctory fill to prince Edward
by the grace of god. And this same prince Edward had with him sir John^ duke
of Lancaster his brother and other worthy men of arms about the nombre of.xxx.
thousand. And the king of Spain had on his side men of diverse nacyons to the
nombre of an hundred thousand and moo / wherefore the sharpness and
fyersnesse of his adversary with his fill boystous and great strenthe made and
drive ye ryghtfull party a back a great way but through the grace of almighty
god passing any man's strenth that great host was dysparpled myghtefully by
the noble duke of Lancastre and his host / or ye prince Edward came nyghe
him. And when Henry bastard saw that / he turned with his men in so great
haste and strenth for to flee / that a great company of them in the for said
flood and of ye bridge there of fellen dowen and perysshed. And also there were
taken the earl of Dene and sir Bartram Cleykyn that was cheyfmaker and cause of
ye war and also cheyftayne of the vauntwarde of the bataylle with many other
grease lords and knights to the nombre of two thousand / of whom two
hundred were of France and many also of Scotlonde. And there were felled in
the field on our enmyes side of lords and knights with other meyn people to
the nombre of.vi. thousand and moo / and of Englysshmen but a few. And after
this the noble prince Edward restored ye same Peers to this kingdom again / the
which Peers afwarde through treachery and falsnes of the foresaid basterd of
Spain as he satte at his mete he was strangled and deyed. But after this
vyctorye many noble men of England / and also hardy in Spain thrug the flyx
and diverse other sekenes took their death. And also in the same year in the
March was seen stella Come ta between the north costs and ye west whoos bemes
stretched toward france. And in the next year following of king Edwardes
regne xliii. in Apryll sir Lyonell king Edwardes sone that was duke of
Clarnece went to ward Melayne with a chosen meyne of the ge^tyls of England
for to wedde Galoys daughter and have her to his wife / by whom he should have
half ye lordshyp of Melayne but after that they were solemply wedded and about
ye Natyuyte of our lady the same duke of Melayne deyed. And in the same year /
frensshmen brake the peace and the trewes riding on ye kings ground and
lordshyp of England in the shyre and country of Puu^tyfe / and token and held
castle and towns / and bear the Englysshmen on hand falsely and subtle that
they were cause of brekynge of trewes. and in this same year deyed the duches
of Lancaster and is buried worshypfully in saint Poules church. The.xliiii.
year of king Edwardes regne was the gretest pestylence of men and of great
bestes and by the great falling of waters yt fell at that time / there fell
great hyndrynge and destroyenge of corn in so much that ye next year after a
busshell of whete was sold for.xl.d. And in this same year about the last
end of May king Edward held tho his parliament at westmyster in which
parliament was treated and spoken of the oath and trewes that was broken between
him and the king of / france and how he might be avenged upon his wrong In
this same year in the Assumpcyo^ of our lady deyed queen Phylyp of England a
fulle noble and good lady and at westmyster full worship fully is buried and
entered And about mydsomer ye duke of Lancastre and the earl of Herforde with
a great company of knights went into france where as they gate them but
little wroshyp and name / for there was a great host of the frensshenmen upon
Calkhull bridge / and an other host of Englyssemen fast by the same bridge
that long time had lived there And many worthy and great men of England
ordained and yaf counseyll for to fight and yaf battle to the frensshemen but
the foresaid lords would not consent thereto for no manner thing. And anon
after it happened that ye earl of warwyke come thyderwarde for to war / and
when the frensshmen herd of his coming of that he came fully to land they
left their tents and pauylyous with all their vytayls and fled and went a
way pryuely. And when the earl was come^ to land with his men he went in all
have toward Normandy and destroyed the isle of Caux with strenthe of sword and
through fire But alas in his retornynge to England ward home again at Calys he
was taken with sykenes of pestylence and deyed not leuynge behind him after
his days so noble a knight of arms. In which time reigned and warred ye
noble knight sir John^ Hawkewod yt was an Englysshman borne / having with him
at his governance the white company that is a forsayde. yt which o time
against holy church and an other time ayenste lords warred and ordained great
batayls and there i^ that same country he did many merueyllous things. And
about the co^uercyon of saint Poule the king when he had ended and done the
entering and exequyes with great costs and ryaltes about ye sepulture of and
buryeng of queen Phylyp his wife he held a parliament at westmyster in which
parliament was axed or ye clergy a three years dyme / that is for to say a
great dyme to paid three year during / and the clargye put it of and would not
grant it unto Ester next coming / and than they granted well that in three
year by certain terms that dyme should be paid and also of the lay fee was
a three year.xv. granted to the king.

How sir Robert Knolles with other certain lords of the reame went over see
in to france and of their governance.
ANd in the.xlv. year of king Edward in the beginning king Edward with
unwise counseyll and indiscreet borrowed a great so^me of gold of the prelates
merchants and other rich men of his reame saying that it should despended in
defendyn he of holy church and of his reame netheles it profyted no thing /
wherefore about mydsomer after he made a great host of the worthyest men of his
reame Among whom were some lords yt is to say the lord Fytzwater and the
lord graunson and other worthy knights of which knights the king ordained
sir Robert Knolles a proud kny^t and a well assayd in deeds of arms for too
be gouerneur / and that through his counseyl and governance all thing should be
governed and dressed And when they come into / france as long as they dwelled
and held them hole together yt frenshemen durst not fall upon them. And at
the last about ye beginning of winter for envy and couetyse that was among
them / and also dyscorde they sondred and parted them into diverse co^panyes
unwisely and folesly. But sir Robert Knolles and his men went and keped thym
saufe within a castle in Brytayne. And when the frensshmen saw yt our men and
felaushyp were diuyded into diverse companyes and places not holding ne
strengthynge thym togyders as they out for to do / they fell fyersly on our
men / and for the most party took them or slew the^. and tho that they might
take led with them prisoners. And in ye same year pope Vrban^ came fro rome
to Auynyon for this cause that he should accord and made peace between ye king
of France and the king of England for ever more. But alas or he began his
treates he deyed with ye sickness the.xxi day of Decembre / and was buried as
for the time in the cathedral church of Auynyon fast by the high awter. and
the next year after when he had lain so his bones were taken out of the earth
and buried new in the abbay of saint vyctorye fast by Marcylle / of the which
abbaye he was sometime abbot himself. And in both places that he was baryed in
there he many great myrcales done and wrough through the grace of almighty god
to many man's help and to the worship of god almghty. And after whom followed
next and was made pope Gregorye Cardynalle Deken that before was called Pyers
Roger. In the same year Lymoge rebelled and faught against the prince as other
cytes did in Guyhem for great taxes cossages and raunsons yt they were put and
sete to by prince Edward / which charges were importable / wherefore they
turned fro him and fellen to the king of France. And when prince Edward this
he was sore chafed and agreued / and in his tornynge home ward again in to
England with sore scar musshes and fytynge and great sautes fought with them
and took the foresaid cytee and destroyed it almoost to the ground and slew
all that he found in the cite. And than for to say the sothe for diverse
sekenes and maladyes that he had and also for defaute of money yt he might not
with stand ne tarry on his enmyes he hyed him again in to England with his wife
and menye leuynge behind in Gascoyne the duke of Lancastre and sir Edmond earl
of Cambrydge with other worthy and noble men of arms. In the.xlvi. year of
king Edward at the ordinance and sengynge of king Edward / the king of
Nauerne come to him to Claryngdon to treat with him of certain things
touching his war in Normandye where king / Edward had left certain syeges
in his stead till he come again. But king Edward might not speed of that that
he seked him. And so the king of Nauerne with great worship and great gifts
to his leave and went home again. And abowte beginning of March when the
parlemente at westmyster was begone the king asked of the clergy a subsydye
of.l.M. pound the which by a good auysement and by a general co^uocao^n of
the clergy it was granted and ordained that it should be paid and raised of
the lay fee. And in this parliament at the request asking of the lords in
hatred of men of holy church. the Chaunceler and the tresourer that were
bishops and the clerk of the pryue sale. were remeued and put out of office
and in their stead were seculer men put in. And while this parliament lasted
there come somlepne embassatours fro the pope to treat with the king of peace
and said that the pope desired to fulfill his predecessors will but for all
their coming they sped not.

Of the besygynge of Rochell and how the earl of Penbroke and his company was
taken in ye haven with spanyerdes and all his ships brent.
THe.ix. day of June king Edward in the.xlvii. year of his regne held his
parlemente at whynchestre and it lasted but.viii. days / to the which
parliament were sompned by write of men of holy church.iiii. bishops and.v.
abbottes without any moo. This parliament was holden for merchants of London
of Norwhiche and of other diverse places in diverse things and points of
trason that they were defamed of / that is to say that they were rebel and
would arise against the king this same year the duke of Lancastre and the earl
of Cambrydge his brother come out of Gascoyne into Enlonde and took and wedded
to their wives peter's daughter sometime king of Spain Of which two daughters
the duke had the elder and the earl ye younger. and that same time there were
sent two Cardynals fro the pope / that is to say an English Cardynall and a
Cardynal of Paris to treat of peace between these two reames / yt which when
they had been both long each in his prouynce and countreees fast by treating
of the foresaid peace / at the last they took with them the lettes of
procuracye and went again to Rome without any effect of their purpose. In this
year was there a strong Battle in the sea between Englysshmen and flemynges
and ye Englysshmen had the victory and took.xxv. ships with salt and sleynge
and drenchynge all ye me^ that were therein vnwetynge they they were of that
country. And much harm should have fallen thereof had not peace and accord
sone be made between them. And in this same year the frensshmen besyeged the
town of Rochell wherefore the earl Penbroke was sent into gascoyne with a great
company of men of arms for to dystroye the syege / which passed the sea and
came sauf to the haven of Rochell / and when they were there at the haue^ mouth
or that they might enter / suddenly come upon them a strong nauye of
Spanyardes ye which overcame the Englysshmen in much blemysshynge hurtinge
and sleynge of many people for as much as the Englysshmen were than not ready
for to fight ne were ware of them. And as the Spanyerdes came upon them all the
Englysshmen other they were taken or slain / and.x. of them were sore wounded
to the death and all their ships burnt / and there they took the earl with a
great tresour of the reame of England and many other noble me^ also on
mydsomer even the which is saint Edeldredes day and led them with them into
Spain. And of this myscheyf was no great wonder for this earl was a full ylle
liver as an open lechoure And also in a certain parlemente he stood and was
against the ryghtes and fraunchyse of holy church And also he counseylled the
king and counseyll that he should axe mo of men of holy church than other
persons of the lay me^. And for the king and other men of his counseyll
accepted and took rather ylle opynyons and causes ayenste men of holy church
than he did for to defend and mayntene the right of holy church / it was
after seen many times for lack of fortune and grace they had not ne bare away
so great vyctory ne power against their enmyes as they did before. This same
year the king with a great host entered the sea to remeue the syege of Rochell /
but the wind was ever contrary unto him and suffered him not long time to go
fer fro the land / wherefore he abode a certain time upon the sea costs
abiding after a good wind for the^ and yet come in not So at ye last he come
thens with his me^ to land ward again. and anon as he was a land yt wind
began to torn and was in an other cost than he was before.

How the duke of Lancastre with a great host went into / flaundres and passyd
by Paris through Burgon and through all france till he come unto Burdeux.
Soon after in the.xlviii. year of the regne of king Edward the duke of
Lancastre with a great power went into / flaundres and passed by Paris through
Burgon and thrughe all / france till he came unto Burdeux without any manner
wythstandynge of the / frensshemen \ and he did them but little harm saufe he
took and raunsoned many places and towns and many men and let them go after
freely. The same year the king sent certain embassatours to ye pope prayenge
him that he should leave of and meddle not in his court of the kepi^ge and
reseruacyo^s of benefyces in England. And that tho that were chose^ to
bysshoppes sees and dignetees freely and with full might Joy and have and be
confermed to the same of their metropolytans and Archebysshops as they were
wont to be of old time Of these points and of other touching the king and
his reame / when they had their answer of the pope / the pope enjoined them
that they should certefy him again by their letter of ye kings will and of his
reame or they determined ought of the foresaid artycles In this same year deyed
Johan the Archebysshop of york / Johan bishop of Ely / wyllyam byssop of
worcestre. In whoos stedes followed and were made bishops by auctoryte of pope.
master. Alexander Neuyll to the Archebysshop of york. Thomas of Aru^dell to
the bysshopryche of Ely. and sir Henry wakfelde to the bysshopryche of
worcestre. In the which time it was ordened in ye parliament that all
Cathedral chyrches should Joy and have their elecco^ns hole and yt the king fro
that time afterward should not writ against the^ that were chosen / but rather
help them by his letters to their confyrmacyon and this statute did much
profit. And in this parliament was grau^tyd to the king a dyme of the clergy
and a.xv. of lay fee. In the.xlix. of the regne of king Edward deyed Master
wyllyam wytlesey Archebysshop of Caunterbury and the monks of the same church
asked and desired a cardynall of England to be Archebysshop. and therefore the
king was agreued and meant and purposed to have exyled the monks of the same.
and they spended much good or they might have ye kings grace again and his
love but yet would the king not consent ne grant to their elecco^n of ye
Cardynall ne of the pope also ne his Cardynalles. And at the begynnyge of
August it was treated and spoken at Bruges of certain points / and artycles
hanging between the pope and the king of England / this treates lasted
almoost too year. And at the last it was accorded between them that the pope
fro that time forth should not use ne dele with the reseruacyons of benefytes
in England / and that the king should not grant ne let no benefyces by his
writ yt is called (Quare impedyt) But as touching the eleccion abouesayd
there was no thing touched ne done. And that was wyted and put upon certain
clerks the which rather supposed and hoped to be auau^ced and promoted to
bysshhpryches which they desired and coueyted by the court of Rome rather than
by any other eleccyons / This same year about Candelmasse there met together
at Bruges many noble and worthy men of both sides and reames to trete of peace
bitwene tho two kings. And this tretes lasted two year with great costs and
large expensens of both parties. And at the last they went and departed thens
without any accord or effect. The next year after the.l. year of king Edward
ye.iiii. Non^ of May being yet void and vacaunt the Archebysshopryche of
Caunterbury master Symonde sudbery bishop of London was made Archebysshop
and master wyllyam courteney that was bishop of Herforde was than made
bishop of London / and the bishop of Bangor was made bishop of Herforde. And
this same time in a certain treates and speaking of peace trewes was taken
between them of France and England fro mydsomer to mydsomer come again an hole
year and about the beginning of Aprell ye duke of brytayne with many earls
barons and worthy lords and men of England went over see in to Brytayn where
he has had all his lust desire and purpose ne had the for said trewes be so
soon taken the which let them. This same time the isle of Constantyne where
that the castle of saint Saueour is in. that long time was foughten at and
besyeged of the Frensshmen than yield to the Frensshmen with all the
apportenau^tes in to great harm and hyndrynge of ye reame of England And this
same year there were so great and so passing hetes and there with all a great
pestylence in England and in other diverse parties of ^he world yt it
destroyed and slew vyolently and strongly both men and wymen without nombre.
This same year deyed sir Edward ye lord spencer a worthy knight and a bold
and in the mynster of Teukesbury worshipfully is buried. And lasting this
pestilence the pope at the instaunce and prayer of an English Cardynale
granted to all people that deyed in England that were sorry and repentau^t for
their sins and also shryue^ full remyssyon by two bulls under led.vi.
months than next to last. In this same year the earl of Penbroke was taken
and rau^soned by Bartram Clayken between Paris and Calays as he come toward
England upon saint Atheldredes day yt which saint as it was said the earl
oftentimes had affe^ded / and within a little while after he deyed. And in
Nouembre next after there met at Bruges the duke of Lancastre and the duke of
Angoy with many other lords and prelates of both reames for to treat of peace.

Of the death of prince Edward and of the lord Latymer and dame Alyce peers
thrughe whom and her maynteners ye Reame many a day was mysgouerned.
NOt long after the.li. year of King Edwardes regne he let ordeyne and hold
at westmynster the grettest parliament yt was seen many a year before. In the
which parlemente he asked of the comynaltee of the reame as he had done before
a great subsydye to be granted to him for defe^dynge of him and of his reame
but ye comunes answered that they were so often day by day grieved and charged
with so mani talag^s and subsydyes yt they might no le^ger suffer no such
burtho^s and charges and that they knew and wist well enough that the king
had enough for saving of him and of his reame if the reame were well and
truly governed / But that it had be so long evil governed by ylle officers
/ that the reame might another be plenteuous of chaffre and marchaundyse ne also
with richesse. And in these things they profyred themself if the King would
certainly to preue it and stand by. and if it were founde^ and proved
afterward that the King had need they would gladly every man after his power
and state him help and lene. And after this were publysshed and showed in the
parlemente many playntes and defautes of diverse officers of ye reame and namely
of the Lord Latymer the kings chamberlayne both to the King and eke to the
reame. And also at the last there was spoken and treated of dame Alyce Pers
for the great wrongs and evil governance yt was done by her counseyl in the
reame The which dame Alyce pers that ye king had holden long time to his
lemman wherefore it was the last wonder though through the frealter of the
woman's excytynge and her steringe he consented to her lewdness and evil
cou^seyl the which dame Alyce and also the lord Latymer and other such ye
meued the king to evil governance against his profit and the reame also /
all the comynalte asked and desired that they should be remeued and put away
and in their stedes wise me^ and worthy that were true and well assaied and
proved and of good governance. should be put in their stedes. So among al
other there was one among the comunes that a wise knight and a true / and an
eloquent man whoos name was Pers delamare. And this same pers was chosen to be
speker for the comunes in the parleament And for this same Pers told and
publysshed the truth and rehearsed ye wrongs ayenste the foresaid dame Alyce
and other certain persons of the kings counseyll as he was bydde by the
comyns. And also trusting much to be supported and mayntened in this matter by
help and favor of the. prince anon as the prince was deed at the instaunce
and request of the foresaid dame Alyce / this Pers de amare was Iugyd to
perpetual prison in the castle of Notyngham. And in the.vi. kal. of Iule
lasting ye same parlemente deyed prince Edward king Edwardes first sone /
that is to say in trynyte sunday in worship of which feste he was wo^te every
year where that ever he were i^ ye world to hold and made the most
sole^pnyte that he might. whose name and fortune of knyghthode but if it had be
of an other Ector all men both christian and hethen while that he lived and was
in good point wo^dred much and dradde him wonder soore / whoos body is
worshypfully buried in Crychyrche at Caunterbury. And in this same year the me^
and the earls tenauntes of warwyk arose malycyously against ye abbot and covent
of Euesham and their tenauntes. and destroyed thabbaye. and the town and
wounded and beat their men and slew many of them / and went to their manners
and places and did much harm / and brake down there parkes and closes and
slew their wild bestes and chaced them brekynge their fysshe pounds and
hedes and let the water of their pondes stews and ryuers run out and took
the fysshe and bare it with them. and did them all the sorrow that they
might. in so ferforthe that forsooth they had destroyed perpetual that abbay
with all their members and apportenaunces but if the king the sooner had not
helped it and taken head thereto. and therefore the king sent his letters to ye
earl of warwyk chargyng him and co^mau^dynge him that he should stynt redress
and amend tho evil doers and brekers of his peace. and so by means of lords
and other friends the peace was made bitwene them. and for this hurtynge as it
is said ye king would not be governed as that time by his lords that there
were in ye parliament. but he took and made his sone the duke of Lancastre his
gouerneur of the reame / the which stood so still as governor till ye time
that he dyed. The same year after. ca^delmasse or the parliament was done / the
King asked a subsidye of the clargy and of the lay fee and it was grau^tyd hy^
/ that is to say that he should have of every person of ye lay fee both man
and woman that passed fourtene year of aege four pe^s out taken pore beggars
that were known openly for need pore beggars. And that he should have of every
man of the holy church that was benefyced or promoted twelve pens and all
other that were not promoted iiii. pens out taken the.iiii. ordres of the friar
beggars This same year after Myghelmasse Richard prince Edwardes sone was made
prince of wales to whom the king gaf ye duchy of cornewayle with ye erldom of
chestre. And about this time ye Cardynale of England ye.iiii. day before mary
Mawdalenes day after dinner suddenly was smite with the paslye and lost his
speech / and on mary Mawdalen^s day deyed.

Of ye death of King Edward and how sir Johan Monster warch knight. was
drawn and hanged for his falsnesse.
Right anon after in the.lii. year of King Edward in the beginning of
Octobre pope Gregorye the.ix. brought and remeued his court with him from
Auy^yon to come. And the.xii. day of Apryl. Johan Monsterwarthe. Knight at
London was drawn and hangyd and than quartred and sent to four cheyf towns of
England and his heed smyten of and sete upon londen bridge / for this same
John^ was full untrue to the king and to ye reame and coueytous and unstable
/ for he took oftymes great so^mes of money of the king and his counsel for
men of arms wages that he should have paed them and took it to his own use /
and he dradde that at the last he should be shent and accused for the same
cause and fled pryuely to the king of France and was sworn to him and become
his man and behyghte him a great nauye out of Spain in to confucyon and
destroynge of England / But the ryghtfull god to whom no preuyte is unknown
suffered him first to beshente and spylt or that he so traytoursly and falsely
betrayed his lyege lord the king of England and his people in his reame in
the which ground this same John^ was borne and wyckydly thrughe battle
destroyed or he brought about his cursed purpose. In the feast of Saint George
tho next king Edward gaaf to Rychard of Burdeux his heyr yt was prince
Edwardes sone at wyndsore thordre of knughthode and made him knight the which
king Edward when he had reigned.li. year the.xi. kal of June he deyde at Shene
and is buried worshypfully at westmyster on whose soul god have mercy. This
king Edward was for soth of a passing godenes and full gracyous among all
the worthy men of the world for he passed and shone by virtue of grace gauen
to him from god above all his predecessors yt were noble men and worthy and he
was a well hearted man and an hardy / for he drade never no myshappes ne harms
ne evil fortune yt might fall a noble warryoure and a fortunate / for both on
land and see and in all batayls and assembles with a passinge glory and Joy he
had the vyctory he was meke and benygne homely sobre and soft to all me^ as
well to strangers as to his own subgettes and to other yt were under his
gouenau^ce. He was devout and holy both to god and holy church / for he
worshypped help and mayntened holy church and their mynystres with all manner
reverence / he was treatable and well auysed in temporal and worldly needs
wise in counseylle and dyscrete and meke to speak with / in his deeds and
manners gentle and well taught / having pity of them that were in dyseace /
plecteuous in geuynge of been faytes and almoses besy and curyous in bayldynge
/ and lightly he bare and suffered wrongs and harms and when he was given to
any occupacyon he left all other thing for the time and tended there to semely
of body and a meyne stature / having al way to high and to low a good
chere. And here spronge and shone so much grace of him that what man had
behold his face or had dremed of him he roged that day that all thing should
hap to him Joyful and lysynge. And he governed his kingdom gloryously unto
his aege / he was large in geuynge and wys in spentes / he was fulfilled with
all his honest of good manners and virtues / under whom to live it was as for
to regne. wherefore his fader and his loos spronge so far that it came in to
hethenes and Barbary showing and telling his worthynes and manhood in all
lands / and that no land under heaven had brought forth so noble a king so
gentle and so blessed or might reyse such an other when he was deed
Nevertheless lechery and meuynge of his flesh hauntyd him in his aege /
wherefore the rather as it is to suppose for unmeasurable fulfyllynge of his
lust his life shorted the sooner. And hereof take good hedelyke as his dedys
bears wymesse for as in his beginning all things were Joyful and liking
to him / and to all people. And in his myddel aege he passed all people in
high Joy worship and blyssydnes. Right so when he drew in to aege drawing
donwarde thrughe lechery and other sins little and little all tho Joyful
and blessed things and prosperity decreasyd and mysshcaped and unfortunate
things and unprofitable harms with many euyls began for to spring and the
more harm is yt continued long time after.

CLemens the.vi. was pope after Benedict.x. year / this man in name and deed
was virtuous / and many things that Benedict was rygous in / he made easy /
and certain that he depryued he restored / and the rygousenes of the faith of
Benedict was laudable ^ But much more laudable was the meekness of Clement.
This man was a noble prechour and many sermons he gadred / and let no man
pass from him but he gaaf him good counseyll / and decessyd a blessed man.
Karolus the.iiii. was Emperor after Lodewyk.xxxi. year. Chis man was king of
Beme a wise man and a mighty. And this man was chosen Emperor by the
commandment of Clemens Lodewyk being a live in his contemacy / and because
he asked mekely the poopes blessing and too be crowned of him as other good
kings did. therefore he was protected of god and preueyled over all his
enmyes. And many favorable laws he made spyrytuall men / the which yet are
called Karolma / at the last he decessed a rich man in virtue and gooddes^
Innocentius the.vi. was pope after Cleme^te.x. year / and he was a great lover
of relygous men and he founded a monestery in France of the order of
Cartusyens. and was a great canonyst. Vrbanus the.v. was pope after Innocent.
this man was abbot of Myssolens of the order of Saint Benet a doctor and is
taken for a saint. he made the cross too be preched against the Turks / and he
made a passage to the Turks / And to him saint Brygt was sent from Christ
for the confyrmacyon of their rule and thanne he was poysened and decessyd.
Gregory the.ix. was pope after him.viii. year This Gregory did little. And
after him followed the trybulacyon the which our lord showed to saint Brygyt
for the sin of the clargye Venselaus sone to Karolus a foresaid was
Emperor.xiiii. year. And he was a child and was chosen when his fader was on
live / but he took no keep of them pyre / and when he was warned many times
for to take heed unto it and would not. He was deposed / For he gaaf all his
delight and lust to lechery / and his end was without honor for he went
greatly from the manners and the virtues of his noble fader. And he was crowned
with themperyall dyademe. and the wisdom of his fader passed into Sygysmonde
his brother as after it shall appyre. Trbanus was pope after Gregory.vi. year /
this Urban was chosen in the cytee of Rome by the strenth of ye Romans but the
Cardynals did yt fo. dread and not wyllyngly / Wherefore they fled unto the
Cite of Foundoru^ And they said yt he was not pope / and chose in his place
sir. Robert of Gebennys the same year the which was called Clement the.vii^
Nota. And here began ye.xii. strife in the church. And it was more worse than
ever was any other before / for it was so subtle / that ye wysest me^ that
were and ye best of conscience could not deserve with whom it was best to
say and to hold. And this strife dured xl. year with a great sclaunder unto
the clergy and great peril unto mennys souls for heresies and other evil
things the which were brought in than. In so much that there was no doctrine
in the church for mysdoynge and therefore from this day Vrbane the.vi. unto
Martyne I know not who was pope. The feast of the vysytaco^n of our lady was
ordained by Vrbane the.vi. after the form of the sacrament of the awter for
a peace and an unity to be had among them through the merytees of our blessyn
lady. Bonefacias the ^ix. was pope after Vrbane.xv year. This Boneface was
chosen at Rome in the stead of Vrbane / and the strife continued For Benedictys
was chosen in Auynyon in the place of clement and was called Petrus de luna and
he dured to the counseyll of Constantinus / and then he would not obaye but
ever abode obstynate. And at the last he decessed in the Kingdom of Aragon.
And he commanded his Cardynals to these an other pope the which they did
anon. And they sete upon an ydoll and named him Clement / but they profyted
not.

Circa annu^ dm^.M.CCC.lxxx. And after king Edward the third that was borne
in wyndesore reigned Richard of Burdeux that was prince Edwardes sone of wales
/ the which prince Edward was king Edwards sone.
ANd after the good king Edward the third that was borne at wyndesore reigned
Richard the second that was the good sir Edwardes sone / prince of wales. the
which king Richard was borne in the cy^ee of Burdeux in Gascoine / and was
crowned at westmynster in the.xi. year of his aege. And in the second year of
his regne / for ye debate that was between the lord Latymer and sir Rauf
Feryers knight that was against Hawell and S^akell squyre for ye prisoner yt was
take in Spain / by these two squyres / and the which prisoner the lord
Latymer and sir Rouf Feryers would have had / the which prisoner was the Earl
of Dene that they took in the battle of Spain / wherefore these two lords
come into the church at westmynster and they found this one squyre to
herynge his mass beside saint Edwardes shryne and there they saw him yt
