which was called Hawell. And Shakell was arested and put into the Toure of
London And there he was long time for he would not deliver the earl of Dene
his prisoner unto these two lords / by sir Aleyn Burhyll constable of the
Tower / and by Sir Raufe Feryes one of his adversaries / till the king had
granted him grace. In the third year of king Richard came the Galays of*
france into England unto diverse ports and brent and robbed and slew much
people of England that is to say / at wynchelsee / Rye / and Hastinge
Portysmouth. and Hamp^on \ Stormore and Grauesende / and they did much harm
and went home again. And in this same / year was a parliament holden at
westmynster. And at that same parliament was ordened that every man woman and
child that were at the aege of.xiiii. year and above through out all the reame
pore folk and other should pay to the ta^age / four pens / wherefore came and
befell after ward great myscheyf and much disease to all the comynalte of the
reame. And in the.iiii. year of king Rychardes regne the comynes arose up in
diverse parties of the reame and dyden much harm / the which time they
called the hurynge time. And they of Kent and of Estsex made them two
cheyftayns for to rule and for govern the company of Kente and of Estsex. That
one was called Jack straw and that other watte Tyler / and they come and
assembled them upon black hethe in Kente. And on Corpus chirsti day after
they came down South work / and taken up the prison house / that is to say
the kings bynche and the Marchelsee and delyuerde out all the prisoners. And
so the same day they came in to London and there they robbed the people and
slew all the alyens that they might find in the cite and about the cite and
dyspoyled all there good and made auowe. And on the fryedaye next folowinge
after that was on the morrow and than they came to the toure of London and ye
king being there in / they fette out of the Toure the Archebysshop of
Caunterbury. sir Symonde Sudbery / and sir Robet halys hospyteler pryoure and
master of Sayn^ Iohans house / and a white friar that was co^fessoure unto king
Richard and brought them unto the Tower hylle and there they smote of their
heedes and came again in to London and slew in oath people of the City. And
then they went unto the. Dukes place of Lancastre beyond saint Mary of the
stronde that was called the Sauoy / and there they devoured and destoyed all
the goods that they therein might find and bare them away and than they burnt
up the place. And than after ward they went to saint John^ without smyth
field and destroyed the gods there and burnt up ye house to the hard ground
/ and went to westmynster and saint Martyns the grant and made them go out
of sent wary all that were with in for any manner of gylthe / And that come unto
ye Temple and to al other Innes of men of law and dyspoyle them and rob
them of their gods and also took their books of law / and then they came
to London and brake up the prison of Newgate and drofe out all ye prisoners
felons and other / and of both countrees and all the people that were with in
them and destroyed all the books of the counters. And thus they continued both
saterdaye and sunday unto the mondaye next after in all their malice and
wyckydnes. And than on mondaye king Richard with his lord that were with him
that time and with the mayer of London wyllyam walworth that was that time come
with the aldermen and the comunes of the cite / and they come in to South
work to here and to know the entoncyon of these rebels and mysgouered
pefple. And this Jack straw made a cry in the elde that all tke people of
accord should come nerer and here his claymours and his cry and his will. And
the lords and the mayer and the aldermen mith the comynaltee having
indygnaco^n of his rouetyse and falsnes and his foul presumpco^n / Anon
wyllyam walworth that time being mayer drew out his knyfe and slew Jack
straw / and anon right smote of his head and sete it upon a spear and so it
was borne through London and set upon London bridge. Anon these rysers and
mysgouerned people were vanysshed as it had not be they / and then the king of
his great goodness and by prayer of his lords made there.vi. knights of
good and worthy me^ of the cite of London / yt is to say wyllyam walworthe art
ye time mayer and slew Jack straw and the second was Nycholas brembre / and
the third Johan Phylipot / and ye fourth Nycholas twyforde / and the fyfte
Robert laundes / and the syxte Robert gayton. And than the king with his
lords and knights returned again to the tour of London and there he rested him
till his people were better cessed and set in rest and peace. And than by
process of time as they might take and get these rebels and rysers they
honge them upon the next galothrugh out every lordshyp in the reame of
England by.xl. by.xxx. by.x. and by.xii. ever as they might be gote^ and taken
in any parties. And in the.v. year of king Rychardes regne was the great earth
quake and was general through out the world the wenesbaye after wytsonday in
the year of our lord.M.CCC.lxxxxi. wherefore all manner people were sore aghast
and aferde long time for dread of vengeau^ge that our lord showed and did.
And in the.vi. year of king Rychard / then sir Henry spe^ser bishop of
Norwiche went with a great company over see into Flaundres and there they get
the town of Grauynge and the town of burbrugge Dunkerk and Newport and there
they laded and fraughted.li. ships with pelage for to have comen into England
with these ships and goods. And the bishop of Norwiche and his counseyll
let brenne these ships with all the plege in the same haven all into hard
ashes and at Dunkerk was done a great battle between the Flemynges and the
Englysshemen. And at that battle were slain a great multitude of the
Flemynges and a great no^bre. And tha^ went ye bishop with his retenue to
sypers and besyeged it a long time but it might not be gotten. And so left that
syege and came again into England / for our Englysshmen were foully destroyed
and many deyed on the flyx. and in this year come queen Anne into England for
to be spoused to king Richard and her fader was Emperor of almayne and king
of Beme / and with her come the duke of Tassy her uncle and many other worthy
lords and knights of her country of Beme and of other duche tongues to do
her reverence and worship. And sir Symonde beuerle a worthy knight of the
garter and other knights and squyres that were the kings embassatoures
brought her in to England and so forth to London^ And the people of the
cite / that is to say the mayer and the aldermen and all comynes roden
ayenste her to welcome her. And every man in good array and every craft with
his mynstralsye in the best manner wise and met with her on the black hethe
in Kente and so brought her unto London through the cite and so forth unto
westmynster unto the kings palace. And there she was spoused unto king
Richard well and worthily in the abbaye of westmynster and there she was
crowned queen of England. And all her trendes that came with her hadde^ great
gifts and were well cherysshed and refresshed as long time as they aboden
there. And in this same year there was a battle done in the kings palace at
westmester for certain points of treason between sir Johan Ansley knight
defendau^t / and Carton squyre the appellaunt. But this sire Johan of Ansley
overcame this Carton and made him to yield him within the lystes. And anon was
this Carton dyspoyled of his harneys and drawn out of the lystes and so forth
unto Tyburne and there he was hangyd for his falsnesse. And in the.viii. year /
of the regne of king Richard the second / sir Edmonde of Langley the. Earl
of Canbrydge king Rychardes uncle went in to Portyngale with a fair company
of men of arms and archers in strengthynge and helping the king of
Portyngale against the king of Spain and his power / and there the king of
Portyngale had the victory of his enemies through help and comforth of our
Englysshmen. And when that Journey was done the earl of Cambridge come home
aye^ with his people in too England in haste blessed be god his blessed gifts
Amen^ And this same year king Richard held his Crystemas in the manner of
Eltam. And the same year and time the king of armony fled out of his own
land and came into England for to have help and socoure of our king against
his enmyes that had driven him out of his own reame. And so he was brought
unto the king to Eltham there as the king held his ryall feast of Crystmasse.
And there our king welcomed him and did much reverence and worship and
commanded all his lords to make him all the chere that ever they could. And
than he besought the king of his grace and of help and of his comforthe in
his need and that he might be brought again to his kingdom and land. For the
Turks had devoured and destroyed the most part of his land ^ and how he
fled^ for dread / and come hyder for socoure and help. And then the king
having on him pity and compassyon of his great myscheyf and grievous disease
anon he took his counseyll and asked what was best to do. And they answerde
and said if it lyked him to give him any good it were weldone. And as
touching his people for to travel so far into our lands it were a great
Ieoperdye. And so the king gaf him gold and silver and many rich gifts and
Jewels and betaught him to god / and so he passed again out of England. And in
this same year king Richard with a ryall power went into Scotlonde for to
war upon the Scotts for the falsnes and destruccyon that the Scotts had
done unto Englysshemen in the Marches. And than the Scotts come down to ye
king for to treat with him and with his lords for trewes as for certain
years. And so over king and his counsel gau^ted them trewes for certain
years / and our king turned him again in to England. And when he was comen
unto york there he abode and rested him there sir John Holonde the earl of
Kentes brother slew the earls sone of Stafforde and his heir with a daggar in
the cytee of york / wherefore the king was sore anoyed and grieved and remeued
thens and came to London And the mayer with the aldermen and the comyns with
all the solempnyte that might be done ryden against the king and brought him
ryally thrught the city and so for the unto westmynstre to his own palace.
And in the.ix. year of king Rychardes regne he held a parliament at
westmynster and there he made two dukes and a marqueys and five earls. The
first that mas made duke was the kings uncle sir Edmonde of Langle earl of
Cambridge and him he made duke of york / and his other uncle sir Thomas of
wodstok that was earl of Bukyngham him he made duke of Gloucestre. And sir
Lyonuer yt was earl of Oxford him he made marqueys of Deuelyne. and Henry of
Balyngbrok the dukes sone of Lancastre him he made earl of Derby. And sir
Edward the dukes sone of york him he made earl of Ruttelond / And sir Johan
Holonde that was the Earl of Kentes brother and him he did make earl of
Huntyngdon^ And Sir Thomas Mombraye / him he made earl of Notyngham and the
earl Marshalle of England. And sir Mychell de lapole knygh^ him he made earl of
Southfolke and Chaunceler of England. And the Earl of the March at that same
parliament holden at westmynster in plain parliament among all the lords and
comyns was proclaimed earl of the March and heir Parente to the trowne of
England after king Richard / the which earl of the Macche went over see in
to Irlonde / unto his lordshyppes and lands / for the earl of March is earl
of Vlster in Irlond and by right line and heritage. And there at the castle of
his he lay that time / and there came upon him a great multitude in busshmentes
of wild Irysshmen for to take him and destroy him. and he come out fyersly of
his castle with his people and manly faughte with the man's there he was taken
and he wen all to pieces and so he deyed upon whose soul god have mercy. And in
the.x. year of kyge Rychardes regne the earl of Arundell went to the sea with
a great nauye of ships and armed with men of arms and good archers / And
when they come in the broad see they met with the hole flete that come with
wine lade from Rochell the which wine were enemies goods. And there our
nauye sete upon them and took them all and brught them unto diverse ports
and havens of England and some to London / and there ye might have had a tonne
of Rochel wine of the best for.xx. shellynges sterlynge / and so we had great
chepe of wine in England that time thanked be god almighty.

How the five lord arosen at Rattecote bridge.
ANd in the regne of king Richard the.xi. year then five lords arosen at
Rattecote bridge in the destruccyon of the rebels that were ye time in all ye
reame. The first of these five lords was sir Thomas of wodstoke the kings
uncle and duke of Gloucestre / and the second was sir Richard earl of
Arundell / and the third was sir Richard earl of warwyk / the fourth was sir
Henry Balynbrok earl of Derby / the fyft was sir Thomas Monbray earl of
Notyngham. And these.v. lords saw the myschyef and mysgouernaunce and the
falsnes of the kings counseyll / wherefore they that were that time cheyf of
the kings counseyl fled out of his land over see that is to sir say Alysander
Neuyll the Archebysshop of york / and sir Robert Lewe marqueys of Deuelyne and
earl of Oxforde and sir Mychell de la pole Earl of Southfolke and Chaunceler of
England. And these three lords went over see and came never again for there
they deyed. And tha^ these five lords above said made a parlemente at
westmynster and there they took sir Robert Tresilyam the Justice and sir
Nycholl Brembre knight and cytezeyn of London and sir John^ Salysbury a knight
of ye kings household and vske sergeaunt of arms and many moo of other people
were taken and Iuged unto the death by the counseyll of these.v. Lords in that
parleme^te at westmester for the treason that they put upon them be drawn
from ye tour of London through out the cite and so fourth unto Tyburne and there
they should be hanged and their throtes to be cut and thus they were served
and deyed. And after the in this same parliament at westmynster was sir Symonde
Beuerle that was a knight of the garter and sir John^ Beaucha^p knight that
was steward of the kings household / and sir James Berners werefore Iuged
unto the death and than they were led on foot to the toure hylle and there
were there hedes smyten of and many other moo by these.v. lords. In this same
parliament and in the.xii. year of king Rychardes regne he let cry and
ordeyne a general Iustes that is called a turnement of lords and knights.
And this Iustes and turnement were holden at London in smythfelde of all manner
of strangers of what land or country that ever they were and thither they
were right welcome and to them and too all other was holden open household and
great festes and also great gifts were given to all manner of stranges. And of
the king side were all of one suit their cotes there armure sheldes horse
trappure and all was white hertes with cownes abbout their necks and chains
of gold hanging thervpo^ and the crown hanging low before the hertes body /
the which heart was the kings leueraye that he gaafe too Lords and ladies
knights and squyres for to know his household from other people. And in this
feast camen to the Iustes.xxiiii. ladies and ladde. ^ xxiiii. lords of the
garter with chains of gold and all the same suits of hertes as it is before
said from the Toure on horsbacke thrughe the City of London into smytfelde
there that the Iustes should be holden. And this feeste / and Iustes was holden
generalle for all tho that would come theder of what land and nacyon that ever
they were. And this was holden during.xxiiii. days of the kings costs and
these.xxiiii. lords too answer all manner people that would come thyd. And
theder came the earl of saint Poule of france and many other worthy knights
with him of diverse parties full worthily arrayed. And out of Holande and
Henaude came the lord Ostruau^t that was ye dukes sone of Holande and many
other worthy knights with him of Holand and full well arrayed. And when this
feast and Iustynge was ended the king thanked this strangers and gaf the^
many rich gifts. And so they token their leave of the king and of other
lords and ladies and went home again into their own cou^tres with great love
and much thank. And in ye.xiii. year of king Rychardes regne there was a
battle done in the kings palace at westmynster between a squire of Nauerne
yt was with king Richard / and an other squyre yt was called John^ walssh for
poy^tes of treason that this Nauerne put upon this walsshman. but this Nauerne
was ouercome^ and yield him recreau^t to his adversary. And anon he was
dyspoyled of his armure and drawn out of the palace to Tyburne and there was
hanged for his falsnes And the.xiiii. year of king Rychardes regne sir Johan
of Gaunt duke of Lancastre went over see into Spain for to chaleng his right
that he had by his wyfes title unto the crown of Spain with a great host of
people and me^ of arms and archers. and he had with him ^ duchess his wife and
his three daughters over see into Spain / and there they were a great while /
and at the last the king of Spain began to treat with the duke of Lancaster
and they were accorded together through their both counseyll in this manner /
that ye king of Spain should wedde the dukes daughter of Lancastre that was
the right heir of Spain and should give unto ye duke of Lancastre gold and
silver that were cast into great wegges and many other Jewels as much
as.viii. charyetes might carye. And every year after duringe the dukes life of
Lancaster and of the duches his wife.x. thousand mark of gold Of which gold
the adventure and charges should be to them of Spain and yearly bring unto
Bayon to the dukes assygnes by suerte made. And also the duke married an other
of his daughters unto the king of Portyngale the same time* and wha^ he had
done so he come home again into England and his good lady his wife also / but
many worthy men deyed upon the flyx. In the.xv. year of king Rychardes regne
he held his crystmasse in the manner of wodstok and there the earl of Penbroke
a young lord and tender of aege would learn to Just with a knight that was
called sir John^ of saint John^ and roden together in the park of wodstoke. and
there this worthy earl of Penbroke was slain with that other knights spear as
he cast it from him when that they had coupled / and thus the good earl made
year his end / and therefore the king and the queen made much sorrow for his
death. And in the xvi. year of king Rychardes regne Johan he^de being that time
mayer of London and John^ wall worth and Henry vanner being shreues of London /
that same time a bakers man bare a basket of horse bread in to Fletstrete to
ward an hostre and there came a young man of the bishop of Salysbury that was
called Romayn and he took a bors lofe out of the basket of ye bakers / and he
asked him why he did so / and this Romayn turned again and brake the bakers
heed / And neighbors came out and would have arested these Romayn and he brake
from them and fled to his lords place and ye Constable would have him out /
but the bishops men shette fast the yates and kept the place yt no man might
enter and than much more people gadred thither and said that they would have
him out or else they would brenue up ye place and all that were with in / And
than came the mayer and shreues with much other people and cessyd the malice
of the comyns and made every man to go home to there hoses and keep peace. And
this Romans lord the bishop of Salysbury master Johan waltham that at ye
time was tresorer of England when sir Thomas Arundell Archebysshop of york
and Chaunceler of England / and there the bishop made his complaynte unto the
Chaunceler on the people of the cite of London. And than these two bishops of
great malice and vengeance come unto the king at wyndesore and made a great
co^playnt upon the mayer and shreues. And anon all the cite after ward came
before the king and his counseyll / and they cast unto the City a grievous
heart and a wonder great malice / And anon suddenly ye king sent after ye
mayer of London and for the two shreues / and they came to him unto the castle
of wyndsore. And the king rebuked the mayer and shreues full foul for the
offense that they had done against him and his officers in his chamber at London
/ wherefore he deposed and put out the mayer and both shreues / and this was
done the.xiiii. days before ye feast of saint John^ Baptyst. And than ye king
called to him a knight that was called sire Edward dalyngrygge and made him
wardeyne and governor of the cite and chamber of London and over all his
people there in. And so he kept that office but four wekes because that he was
so gentyl and tender to the Cytezens of London / wherefore the king deposed him
and made sir Bunde wine radyngton knight that was Conrtrouller of the kings
household wardeyne and governor of his chamber of his people there in / and
chose to him worthy men of the cite to be shreues with him to govern and keep
ye kings laws in the cite / that one was called Gelbert Mawefelde and that
other Thomas ne wenton shreues. And than ye mayer and the two shreues and all
the aldermen with all the worthy crafts of London went on foot unto the toure
of London / and there came out the Conestable of the tower and gaaf the mayer
and ye shreues their oath and charge as they should have taken in the Escheker
of westmynster in ye kings court of his Justices and Barons of the Escheker
and than went they home again. And than the king and his counseyll for the
great malice and despyte yt they had to the Cite of London remeued all his
courts from westmynster unto the Cite of york / yt is to say the Chau^celer
the Escheker the kings bynche and the comune place / and there they held all
these courts of law fro mydsomer / that is to say the feast of saint John^
Baptyst unto the feast of Crystmasse next coming. And than the king and his
counseyll saw it not so proffytale there. as it was at London / than anon he
remeued yt again to London and so to westmynster for great ease of his officers
and a vauntage to the king and all the comunes of the reame. And when the
people of London saw and knew that these courts were come^ again / and the
king and his people also / than the mayer and the aldermen with the chyef
Comunes of the Cite gave a great sum of gold of all the Comunes of the Cite
/ and ordained and made great ryaltees again his coming too London for to have
his grace good lordshyp and / also their lybertees and Fraunchyses geau^ted
unto them aye^ as they were wont to have before time. And through great
instaunce and prayer of the queen and of other lords and ladies the King
granted them grace. And this was done at Shene in Sutherey. And than the
King within two days after came to London / and the mayer of ye Cite with the
shreues alderme^ and all the worthy men of the afterward rode against him in
good array unto the hethe of his side of Shene the mayer submyttynge them
homely and mekely with all manner obeyssaunce unto him as they oughten too do.
And thus he brought ye king and the queen to London. And when ye king came to
the yate of London bridge there they presenttd him with a milk white stead
sadled and brydled and trapped with cloth of gold and reed partyed to gyder.
and the queen a palfrey all white in the same ararye trappyd with white
andreed / and all the conduytes of London ran with wine both white and reed /
for all manner people to drink who would. And between saint Poules and the
cross in chepe there was made a stage a ryall standing upon high and theyn
were many angels with diverse melodyes and songs. And than an angelle came
down from the stage on high by a vice and sete a crown of gold pyght with
rich perles and precious stones upon the kings heed and an other upon the
queen's heed. And so the cytezeyns / brought the king and the queen to
westmynster into their palace. And than on the morn after the mayer and ye
shreues and the aldermen of London camen unto the king to his palace at
westmynster and present him with two basyns of silver and ouergylted full of
coined gold the sum of.xx. hou^dred pound prayenge him of his high mercy
and grace and lordshyp and specially grace that they might have his good love
with the lybertees. And fraunchyses like wise as they were wo^te for to have
before times and by his letters patentes and his chartre confermed. And the
queen and other worthy lord and ladies fell on there knees and besoughte the
king of grace to conferme this. Than the king took up the queen and granted
her all her askenge. And than they thanked the king and the queen and went
home again. And in.xvi^ year of king Rychardes regne certain lords of scotlonde
came into England for to get worship as by feet of arms / this were the
persons. The earls Mar and he chale^ged the earl Marshall of England to
Just with him certain points on horsbak with sharp speres and they rode
together as two worthy knights and lords certain courses / but not the full
challenge that the Scotts earl made / for he was call both horse and man and
two of his rybbes broken with that fall and so he was borne the^s out of
smythfelde home to his Inn. And within a little time after he was carried home
in a horse lytter and at york he deyed. And sir Wayllyam Darell knight and the
kings banerer of Scotlonde than made an other challenge with sir Peers
courtayne knight and the kings banerer of England of certain courses yet on
horsbacke in the same field / and when he had ryden certain course and assayed
he might not have the better he gaaf it over and would no more of his challenge
with sir pers courtayne knight and the kings banerer of England and turned
his horse and rode home unto his own Inn. And one Cockeborne a squyre of
Scotlonde challenged sir Nycholl Haberke a knight of certain courses yet with
sharp speres and roden five courses together and at every course the Scot was
cast down both horse and man / and thus over English Lords thanked be god
had the field. And in the.xvii year of king Rychardes regne deyde the good
gracyous queen Anne that was wit to king Richard in the manner of Shene in the
shyre of Surrey upon wytsondaye / and than was she brought to London and so
to westmynster and there was she buried and worthily entered beside Saint
Edwardes shryne on whoos soul almighty god have pity and in his mercy. Amen.

How king Richard spowsed dame Isabell the kings daughter of France in the
town of Calays and brought her in to England and let her be crowned queen
in the abbaye of saint Peter's of westmynstre.
IN the.xx. year of king Rychardes regne he went himself ouersee unto Calays
wih dukes earls lords and barons and many other worthy squyes with great array
and comune people of the reame in good array as longed to such a king and
prince of his noble and of his own person to do him reverence and obseruau^ce
as ought to be done to their lyege lord and so mighty a king and Emperor
in his own to abide and receive there that worthy and gracyous Lady that should
be his wife a young creature of.xix. year of aege dame Isabell the kings
daughter of France and other worthy lords of great name both barons and
knights with much other people yt camen to the town of Grauenynge and tow
dukes of France that one was the duke of Burgoyn and that other the duke of
Bar that would no furtherlesse than they had pledges. And than king
Richard delivered two pledges for them for to go sauf and come saufe his two
worthy uncles the duke of Gloucestre and the duke of york and these two went
over the water of grauenynge and abode there as for pledge to the time yt the
marriage was done / and thates these two dukes of France were come again unto
Grauenynge water. And than two worthy dukes came over the water at Grauenynge
and so to Calays with this worthypfull Lady Dame Isabell that was the kings
daughter of France and with her came many worthy lord and eke lady and
knights and squyres in the beast array that might be and so brought her in to
the t^wne of Calays^ And there she was received with all the sole mpnyte and
worship yt might be done unto such a lady. And that they brought her unto the
king. And the king took her and welcomed her and all her fair company and
made there all the solempnyte that might be done. And than the king and his
counseyll asked of the Frensshe lords whether all the couenauntes and
forwards with the composycyon that were ordained and made on both parties
should be truly kept and hold between them. And they say ye / and there
they swore and took their charge upon a book and made their oath well and truly
it to hold in all manner of points and couenauntes without contradyccyon or
delay in any manner wise. And than was she brought to saint Nycholas church in
Calays and there she was worthily wedded with the most solempnyte that any
king or queen might be with Archebysshops and bysshoppes and all the mynystres
of holy church. And than they were brought too the castle and set to mete
And were served with all delycasye of ryall metes and drynkes ple^teuously to
al manner of strangers and a^ other and no creature warned that feast. but all
were welcome / for there were great halles and tents set upon the grene
without the castle to receive all manner of people. And every office ready for
to serve them all. And thus this worthy marriage was sole^ply done and ended
with all ryalte. And than these two worthy dukes of Fraun^e with their people
token their leave of the king and of the queen and went again unto Grauenynge
water. And there the Frensshe lords / that is to say the two dukes and all
their menye were comen over the water to Grauenynge and they met with our two
dukes / and every chone took leave at other and so they departed / and our
lords camen again unto calays / and the Frensshe lords went over the water and
so home in to France again. And anon after the king made him ready with the
queen and all his lords and ladies and all their people with them and came
over the sea in to England and so unto London. And the mayer and the shreues
with all the aldermen and worthy commens roden against them unto the black he
the in to Kent / and there they met with the king and the queen and welcomed
them and that in good array / and every men in the clothing of his craft and
their mynstrels before them. And so they brought them unto saint Georges bar
in South warke and there they token their leave. And the king and the queen
rode to Kenyngton and than the people of London turned home again / And in
tornynge again to London bridge there was so great press of people both on
horse and on foot that there were deed on the bridge.xi. persons of men and
women and children on whose souls al mighty god have mercy and pity. Amen. And
than afterward the queen was brought to the tower of London / and there she
was all night and on the morn she was brought thruge the cite of London and
so forth unto westmynster and there she was crowned queen of England / and
than she was brought again unto the kings palace and there was holden open /
and ryall feast al her coronacyon of all manner people that ^heder come / and
this was done the sunday next after the feast of saint Clemente. in. the.xx.
year of king Rychardes regne. And than the.xxv. day of August / next after by
veyll excytacyon and falls counseyll and for great wrath and malice that the
king had of old time unto his uncle the good duke of Gloucestre and to the
earl of Arundell to the earl of warwyk. Anon the king by his euuyll
excytacyon and his evil counseyll and malice late in the evening on the same
day above said made him ready with his strenth and rode into Estsex unto ye
town of Chemesforde and so come to Plasshe suddenly there sir Thomas of
wodstok ye good duke of Gloucestre lay / and the good duke came to welcome the
king anon. And the king arested the good duke himself with his own body /
and so he was ladde down to the wa^^^ and anon put into a shype and anon had
too Calays and brought in to the Capytayns ward ^o be kept in hold by the
kings commandment of England. And ye time therle Marchall was Capytayne of
Calays. And anon after by commandment of the king and by his false counseyl
commanded the capytayne to put him to death. And anon certain yemen that had
the good duke in keeping took their counseyl how that they should put him unto
death. And this was their appoyntemente that they should comen upon him when he
were in his bed and a sleep on a fetheren bed / and anon they bound hand
and foot and charged him to lie still. And when that they had done thus they
token two small towelles and made on them two riding knottes and cast the
towelles about his neck. And than they took the fetheren bed that lay
under him and cast it about him and than they drew their to wells each ways
and some lay upon ye fetheren bed upon him unto the time that he was deed
because that he should make no noys and thus they strangled this worthy duke
unto the death / upon whose soul god for his high pity have mercy. Amen. And
when the king had rested thus this worthy duke and his uncle and sent him
to Calays he came again to London in all the haste with a wonder great people.
And as soon as he was comen he sent for the earl of Aurundell / and for the
good earl of warwyk and anon as they came he arested them himself. And sir
Johan Cobham and sir John^ Chyne knights he arested them in the same. manner
till he made his parliament. and anon they were put into hold / but the earl
of Arundell went at large unto the parliament time / for he found soffycyent
suerte / to abide ye law and to answer to all manner points that the king
and his counseyll would put upon him And the.xxi^ year of king Rychardes regne
he ordained him a parliament at westmynster the which was called the great
parlemente. And this parliament was made for Judge this three worthy lords and
other moo as they list at that time / And for that Judgment / the kynhe let
make in all the have a long house and a large of ty^bre the which was called
an halle and covered with tyles over and it was open all about on both sides
that all manner of men might se through out / and there the dome was holden upon
these foresaid lords and Judgment given at this forsayde parlemente. And for to
come unto this parliament the king sent his wryttes to every lord baron knight
and every squyre in every shyre through out England that every lord should
gadre and bring his retenue with him in as short and in the best array that
they might get in maintenynge and in the strengthyng of the king against them
that were his enemies / and that this were done in all haste and come to him in
pain of death. And the king himself sent into Chestreshyre to cheyftayns of
that country / and they gadred and brought a great and an huge company of
people both of knights and squyres and prencypally of yome^ of Chestreshyre
the which yemen and archers the king took to his own court and gaate them
bowge of court and good wages to be kepers of his own body both by night and
by day above all other persons and most loved and best trust / the which
soon afterward turned the king to great loss and shame hyndrynge and his
utterly undoing and destruccyon as ye shall here afterward. And that time
came sir Henry of Derby with a great menye of arms and archers / and the earl
of Rutlonde came with strong power of people both of men of mares and archers
And the Earl of Kente brought a great power of men of arms and archers. the
Earl of Marshall came in the same manner. And the lord Spenser in this same
manner. The earl of Northumberlonde and sir Henry Percy his sone and sire
Thomas Percy the earls brother. And all these worthy lords brought a fair
menye and a strong power and each man in his best array. And the duke of
Lancastre and the duke of york came in the same manner with men of arms and
archers following the king. And sir Wyllyam strop tresourer of England came in
the same manner. And thus in this array came all the worthy men of this land
unto our king and these people came to London in one day / in so much that
every street and lane in London and in the subarbes were full of them lodged
and.x. or.xii. mylle about London on every way. And these people brought the
king too westmynster and went home again to their lodging both horse and man
/ and than on the mondaye the.xii. day of Septembre the parlemente began at
westmynster the which was called the great parliament. And on the frydaye next
after the earl of Arundell was brought in to the parleamente among all the
lords / and that was on saint Mathewas day the appostle and euangelyst /
there he was for Iuged unto the death in this halle that was made in the palace
at westmynster / And this was his Judgment / he should go on foot with his
hondes bound behind him from the place that he was Iuged in. And so forth
through the cite of London unto the toure hylle and his heed to be smyten of and
so it was done in deed in the same place.vi. of the grettest lords that sat
on his Judgment roden with him unto ye place there he was done to death / and
so to se that the excucyon were done after the dome. And by the kings
commandment / with them went on foot men of arms and archers a great
multitude of Chestreshyre men in strenthynge of the lords yt brought this
earl to his death / for they dredde lest terle should be rescowed and taken
from them when they come in to London. Thus he passed forth the City unto his
death. And there he took it full pacyenly / on whoos soul god have mercy /
Amen. And than come the friar. Austyns and took up the body and the head of
this good Earl and bare it home to their place and buried him in their quyre.
And in the morn after was sir Richard earl of warwyk brought in to the
parlemente there as the earl of Arundell was for / Iuged / and they gaf the
earl of warwyk the same Judgment that ye for said earl had / but the lords had
compassyon of him by cause he was of more getoer age and released him in to
perpetual prison / and put him in to the ylonde of Man. And then on the
mondaye next after / the lord Iohanne Cobham of Kent / and sir Johan Cheyn
knights were also brought in to the same parlemente in the same halle / and
there they were for Iuged for to be hanged and drawn / but through the prayers
and great Instaunce of all the lords that Judgment was foryeuen to them and
released in to perpetual prison. And in this same year was Richard wyttyngdon
mayer of London / and Johan wodecoke and wyllyam Askam shreues of London. And
they ordained at every yate of London during this same parliament strong wache
of men of arms and archers and thrughout every ward also And the king
made.v. dukes and one markeys and four earls / and the first of them was the
earl of Derby and he was made duke of Herforde And the second also was the
earl of Rutlonde and he was made duke of Awemarle. And the therde was the earl
of Kent and he was made duke of Surre. And the fourth was ye earl of Hu^tyngdon
and he was made duke of Excestre / And the fyft was the earl of Notyngham and
he was made duke of Northfolke. And the earl of Somerset he was made markeys of
Dorseet^ And ye lord Spenser was made Earl of Gloucestre / And the lord
Leuyll of Raby was made earl of westmer land And sir Thomas percy was made
earl of worcestre. And sir wyllyam scrope that was tresourer of England was
made earl of wylteshyre^ And sir John^ Montagu earl of Salysbury. And when the
king had thus done he held the parlemet and ryall feast unto all his lords
and to all manner people that thither would come. And this same year deyed sir
John^ of Gau^t the kings uncle and duke of Lancastre in the bishops Inn in
Holborne. and was brought fro thens to saint Poule and there the king made and
held his enterement well and worthily with all his lords in the chyche of
saint Poule in London / and there he was buried beside dame B^unce his wife yt
was daughter and heir unto ye good Henry that was duke of Lancastre. In ye
same year there fell a dyscencyon bytwne the duke of Herforde and ye duke of
Norfolk in so moshe that they waged batayl and caste^ down their gloves and
than they were take up and ensealed and ye battle Joined and ye day set and
ye place assygned where and when and this should be at Couentre. And thither
come ye king with all his lords at yt day and was set in ye field and
than these two worthy lords came into ye field well and clean armed and well
arrayed with all their wepen and ready to done their battle and were ready in ye
place for to fight at vtteraunce But ye king bad the^ cesse and took the
quarrel in to his hond And forth with right there present exyled the duke of
Herford for term of.x. year and the duke of Northfolke for evermore. And sir
Thomas of Arundell Archebysshop of Caunterbury was exyled the same time for
ever and deposed out of his see for malice of the king / and anon these three
worthy lords were commanded and defended the kings reame. And anon they
gate them ships at diverse haue^s and went over see into diverse lands
each his way. And ye duke of Northfolke went to Venece and there he deyed on
whose soul god haue^ mercy. Amen. And than king rychard made a clerk of his
sir Roger walden Archebysshop of Caunterbury. And in the.xxii. year of king
Rycharbes regne by falls counsel ymagynacyon of coueytous men that were about
him were made and ordained blanke chertres and made them to be enseled of all
manner rich men thrughout the reame. In so much that they compelled diverse
people to set their seases therto^ And this was done for great couetyse
wherefore all good hertes of the reame were clean turned away fro the king for
ever after. And that was utterly his dystruccyon and end to him that was so
high and so excellent prince and king and through covetous and falls counseyll
falsely betrayed. Alas for pity that such a king might not se. And than king
Richard set his kingdom and his ryall land of England to ferme unto four
persons / the which were these. Sire wyllyam strop earl of wyltshyre and
tresourer of England / and sir Johan Busshe / and Henry grieve / and sir Johan
Bagot knights that which / turned them to myscheyf and death within a little
time as ye shall find here afterward written. And than king Richard made
great ordinance and went himself over see in to Irlond and many great lords
with him with a great host for to strenth their king with me^ of arms archers
and much great stuff and right good ordinance as longed unto war. And or
he passed over see he ordained and made sir Edmo^de of Langley his uncle the
duke of york / his lyueteaunte of England in his absence with the governance
and counseyll of these four knights that had taken England to ferme of the
king. And than he passed the sea and came into Irlonde and there he was well
and worthily received. And these rebels that been called wild Irysshmen came
down to the king and yolde them to him both body and goods all at his own
will / and swore unto him to be his lyege men / and there did to him homage
and feaute and good seruyse and thus he conquered the most part of Irlonde in
alytyll time And while that king Richard was thus in Irlonde / sir Henry of
Bolyngbroke earl of Derby that the king had made before duke of Herforde / the
which duke the king had exyled out of this land was comen again into Enlonde
for to challenge the dukedom of Lancaster as for his right and true heritage /
and he came down out of France by land unto Calays And the^ met him sir
Thomas of Aru^dell that was Archebysshop of Caunterbury that was exyled out of
England. and with him came the earl of Aru^dell his sone and heir the which
was in keeping of sir John^ shelly knight sometime with the earl of Hu^tindon and
with the duke of Excestre the which was tho in the castle of Reygate in
Soutsex / and there he stale him a way and came to Calays and there he was
keped well and worthily till these other two lords were comen / to Calays. And
than this worthy duke and sir Thomas of Arundell Archebysshop of Caunterbury
shypped in the haven of Calais and drew their course norwarde and aryued in
york shyre at Rauensporne fast by wydlyngton / and there came and en^red
first the land and two lords with him and their nauye. And so than much
people of the reame that when they herd of his coming and knewen where that
he was and anon they drewen unto him and welcomed these lords and so gaaf
them courage in all manner thing and so passed forth into the land and
gadred much people to them. And when king Richard head and wyste that these
two lords were comen again in to England and also were lo^ded / Than the king
left his ordinance in Irlonde and come into England ward in all the haste
that he might and come the castle of Flynte and there he abode to take his
counseyl and what might he done. But to him come none. And thanne sir Thomas
Percy earl of worchestre that was the kings steward wist and knew all this /
anon he came into the halle among all the people / and he brake the yerde of
the ryall kings household / and anon every man was dysparple and went his
way and forsook their master and sovereign lord and left him allone. And
thus King Richard brought down and destroyed and stood himself allone
without comforth or socoure or if any good counseyll of any man / alas for pity
of this ryall king. And anon came word that sire Henry of Bolyngbroke was up
with a strong power of people and that all the squyres of England reyson up
the shyres in strenthynge of him against king Richard. And thus sone he was
come out of the North country to Brystowe and there he met with sir wyllyam
S^rope earl of wyltshyre and tresourer of England and with sir John^ Busshe
and sir Henry grene and John^ Bagot but he escaped from them and went over
see in to Irlonde / and the sethre knights were taken and their hedes smyte^
of and thus they dyed their for falls couetoyse. And than was king Richard
taken and brought unto ye duke / and anon the duke put him in fast ward and
strong hold unto his cominge to London. And than was there a rumore in London
and a strong noise that king Richard came to westmynster / and the people of
London ran thither and would have done much harm and hurt in there
woodnesse had not the myyer and the alder men and other worthy me^ cessed them
with fair words and turned them home again unto London And there was Sir Johan
Slack dene of ye kings chapel of westmynster taken and brought to London /
and put in prison in Ludgate. And Johan Bagot was taken in Irlonde and so
brought to London and put in prison in Newgate there to be kept and abide his
answer. And soon after the duke brought king Richard pryuely unto London
and put him in the toure under sure keeping as a prisoner. And than came the
lords of the reame with all their counseyll unto the Toure to king Richard
and said to him of his mysgouernaun^e and extorcyon that he had done made and
ordained to opresse all the comyne people and also to all the reame. wherefore
all the comyne people of the reame would him have deposed of all his kyngdom^
And so he was deposed at that time in the Toure of London by all his lords
counseyll and comune assent of all the reame / And than he was put from the
Toure unto the castle of Ledes in Kente and there he was kept a while And
thanne he was had from thens unto the castle of Pounfret in the North
country to be kept in prison / and right soon after there made his end. And
than when king Richard was deposed and had resygned his crown and his
kingdom and was kept fast in hold / than all the lords of ye reame with ye
comyns assent and by accord chosen this worthy lord sir Henry of Bolyngbroke
earl of Derby duk of Herforde and duke of Lancaster by right line heritage and
for his ryghtfull manhood that the people found in him before all other they
chose him and made him king of England amo^nges them.

INnocencyus the.vii. was chosen at rome and lived but two year and than
Gregory.xii. was after him.xii. and ever was debate. Than was Alexander chosen
in the counsel of Pysan and he was called first Petrus de Candyda and so was
put stryf to stryf euerychone of those three said he was pope. Than was there a
counseyl at Pysan where they began to make a cu^corde and there they deposed
the two and third stood and so was worse deuysyon made than before. For that
they ordained prevailed not. Robert was Emperor after wenselaus.i^. year /
this man was duke of Bauary and Earl of Palatyn a Just man and a good / and
was crowned of Bone face the.ix. This man entrde ytaly with a great host of.
Almayns ayenste Johan the duke of Galyas / but with an heavy hoowe he turned
again and was had de worthy to suffer for his ryghtwysnes. Johan the.xxiii.
succeeded Alexander.iiii. year and first he began well for an unity / and he
was in the counseylle a^te Constantis and offered him to resygne the popehode.
and after secretly and worthily he feldde away but it profyted him notte for
he was taken and constreyned to peace and was made a Cardynall and buried at
Florens. Sygysmundus was Emperor after Roberte.xxvii. year / and he was sone
too Karolus and king of Vngarye and most christian prince. And was so devout
to god that he deserved to be canonysed. This man help the church thrughe his
merueylous prudence and wit / for he spared no labor ne no thyynge that he
had till he had made a full peace among ye clergy. And he had.ix. Batayls
against the Turk. And ever he had the vyctorye / and what more all thing that
ever was wryte^ in loving to Constantyne Theodosio Karolo Otto may truly be
written of him. And he was crowned in Vngarye and decessed a blessed man.

Circa Annu^ dm^.M.CCCC.vii. Of sir Henry of Bolynbroke Earl of Derby that
reigned after King Richard / which was the fourth Henry after the conquest.
ANd after King Richard the second was deposed and out of his kingdom the
lords and the comynes all with one assente and all other worthy of the reame
chosen Henry of Bolyngebroke Earl of Derby sone and heir of Johan the duke of
Lancastre for his worthy manhood that often time had be found in him and in
deeds preued. upon Saint Edwardes day the confessor he was crowned king of
England at westmynster by assente of all the reame next after the deposynge
of kange Richard. Than he made Henry his eldest sone prince of wales and duke
of Cornewayle and earl of Chest^e. And he made sir Thomas of Aru^dell
Archebysshop of Caunterbury again as he was before. And sir Roger walden that
king Rychard had made Archebysshop of Caunterbury be made bishop of London
for that time it stood void. And he made the Earls sone of Arundell that came
with him over the sea from Calays in to England. He made him earl of Arundell
as his fader had be^ and put him in possessyon of all his lands. and he made
homage and feaute unto his liege lord the king as all other lords had don.
And than anon deyed king Richard in the castle of Pou^fret in North country
/ for there he was enfamed unto death by his keeper / for he was kept there.iiii.
or.v. days from meet or drink / and so he made his end in this world yet
much people in England and in other lands said he was alive many a year
after his death. But whether he was alive or deed ye people held their falls
opinion and believe that many had and much people came to great myscheyf and
foul death as ye shall here aftewarde. And when king Henry wist and knew
verily that he was deed he let sere him in the best manner and closed it in a
fair chest with diverse spyces and bawmes and closed him in a lynny^ cloth al
sauf his vysage and that was left open that al me^ myghtse his person from all
other men. And so he was brought to london with torche light bre^nynge to Saint
Poules church and there he had his mass and dyryge with much reverence and
solempnyte of service. And wha^ all this was done than he was brought from
Saint Poule into the abbay of westminster and there he had his hole service
aye^. And fro westmynster he was brought to Langley and there he was buried
upon whoos soul god have mercy. Amen. And in the first year of king Henryes
regne he held his Crystmasse in the castle of wyndesore. And oon the.xii. even
came the duke of Awemarle unto ye king and told him that he and the duke of
Surri and the duke of Ex^estre and the earl of Salysbury and and earl of
Gloucestre and other moo of their affynyte werre accorded to make a mommynge
unto the king on.xii. day at night / and there they purposed ^ee the king
in the revelling. And thus he the duke of Awemarle warned the king And when the
king came ye same night to London preuely ne all ye have that he might to get
him help socoure and comforth and counsel / And anon these other that would
have put the king to death fled in all the haste that they might / for they
knew well that their counseyll was bewrayed. And than fled the duke of Surrey
and the Earl of Salesbury with all their menye unto the town of Cycestre. And
there the people o^ the town wodle have arested them And they would not stand
to their arestynge but stood at defense and faught manly But at the last they
were ouercomen and taken. And there they ^mote of the dukes heed of Surrey and
the Earls heed of Salybury and many other moo and these they put their quarters
in to sackes and their hedes on poles borne on high and so they were brought
through he cite of London to London bridge and there these hedes were set upon
^^ghe / and there quarters were sent unto other good towns and Cytees of
England and set up there. At Oxforde was taken Blon^e knight and benet Cely
knight / and Thomas wy^tersell squyre and ye there by heded and quartred and
the knights hedes were set upon pooles and brought to London and set upon
London bridge. and the quartres sent forth to other good towns. And in the
same year a^ Pryetell well in a mylle in Estser there sir John^ Holonde the
duke of Excestre was taken with the comynes of the country / and they brought
him from the mylle to the Plasshe and to the same place that king Richard
had restyd sir Thomas of wodstok ye duke of Gloucestre and right there in the
same place they smote of the dukes heed of Excestre and brought it unto London
upon a poole and it was set upon London bridge. And in the same year at
Brystowe was taken the lord Spenser ye king Richard had made earl of
Gloucestre / and the comyns of the town of Brystowe took him and brought him
into the market place of the town and there they smote of his heed and sent
it unto London / and there it was set unto London bridge. And in this same year
was sir Bernard brokeyns knight taken and arested and put in the Tour of London
and sir John^ shelly knight and sir John^ Mawdelyn and Sir wyllyam Feryb^
^ersones of king Rychardes and they were arested and put in to the Toure of
London / And thither came the kings Justices and satte upon them in the Tour
of London and there they were dampened all four unto the death. and the dome
was given unto Sir Bernarde Brokeys that he should go on foot from the Toure
through the Cytee of London unto Tyburne and there to be hanged and after his
heed smyten of / and sir Johan Shelly knight and sir Johan Mawdelyn and sir
wyllyam Fery^e persons were drawn through out ye cite of London to Tyburne and
there they were hanged and their hedes smyten of and set on London bridge. And
in this same year king Henry sent queen Isabell home again in to France the
which was king Rycharder wife and gaaf her gold and silver and many other
Ieweles and so she was dyscharged of all her power sent out of England. And in
the second year of king Henry the fourth was sir Roger Claryngton knight and
two of his men and the pryoure of Launde and ^viii. freres mynors and some
masters of dyuynyte and other for treason that they wrought against the king
were drawn and hanged at Tyburne all.xii. persons And there began a great
dyscencyon and debate in the country of wales between the lord Gray rythen and
Owen of Glendere squyre of wales and this Owen arered a great nombre of
walsshmen and keep all that cou^cre about right strongly and did much harm
and dystroyed ye kings towns and lordshyppes thrughe out all wales and robbed
and slew the kings people both / English and walesshe and thus he endured
a.xii. year largely. And he took the lord Gray rythen prisoner and kept him
fast in hold till he was raunsoned of prisoners of the march and kept him
long time in hold. And at the last he made him wedde one of his daughters
and kept him still with his wife and soon after he deyed. And than king Henry
knowing this mischeyf destruccyon and treason ye this Owen had wrought And
anon he ordained a strong power of me^ of arms and archers and much other
stuff ye longed to war for to abate and dystroye the malice of this false
walsshe man. And than ye king came in to wales with his power for to dystrye
this Owen and other rebels falls walsshemen. And anon they fled in to the
Montayns and there might the king do them no harm in no manner wise for the
montayns / and so the king came again in to England for lesynge of much of his
people / and thus he spedde not there. In this same year was great scarsyte of
whete in England for a quarter of whete was at.xvi. shellynge. And there was
marchaundyse of England sent in to Prure for whete / and anon they had lade
and fraughtshypoes Enough and came home in saufte thanked be god of all his
gifts. And in the.iii. year of king Henryes regne there was a sterre seen in
ye fyrmament that showed him self through all the world for diverse tookens
that should befall soon after / the which sterre was named by clergy^ Stella
cometa / and on saint Mary Mawdelenes day next following in ye same year / was
the bataylle of Shrowesbury. And thither came sir Henry Percy the earls sone of
Northu^berlonde with a great multitude of men of arms and archers and gaaf a
battle to King Henry the fourth through the false and wicked counseyll of sir
Thomas Percy his uncle earl of worchestre / and there was sir Henry Percy
slain and the most part of his people in the flede / and sir Thomas Percy
taken and kept fast in hold two days till the king had set in rest his
people on both sides. And than sir Thomas Percy was Iuged to the death to be
drawn and hanged and his heed smyten of for his false treason at Shrowesbury
and his heed brought to london and sete on london bridge. And the other people
that there was slain oon both parties the king let burye. And there were
slain on the kings side in that battle the Earl of Stafforde and sir walter
Blunte in the kings cote armur under the kings baner and many moo worthy men
upon whoos soul god have mercy. Amen. And in the fourth year of king Henryes
regne came the Emperouer of Constantynople with many gretee solaes and knights
and much other people of his country in to England to king Henry with him
to speak and to dysporte and to se the good governance and condycions of our
people and to know the co^mydytees of England. And our kynge^ with all his
lords goodly and worshypfully received and welcomed him and all his menye
that came with him and did him all the worship that they could and might.
And anon the king commanded all manner officers that he should be served as
worthily and ryally as it lo^ged to such a worthy lord. And Emperor on his
own cost as long as the Emperor was in England and all his men that came
with him. And in this same year camen dame Jane the duches of Brytayne into
England and londed at fallemouthe in Cornewayle / And from thens she was
brought to the Cytee of wynchestre and there she was wedded unto king Henry
the fourth in the abbaye of saint Swythynes of wynchestre with all ye
solempnyte yt might be done and made. And sone afterward she was brought from
thens to London. And the mayer and the alderme^ with the comunes of the cite of
London rode against her and welcomed her and brought her through the cite of
London to westminster and there she was crowned queen of England and there the
king made a ryall and solemn feast for her and for all manner of men ye thither
would come. And in this same year dame Blau^che the eldest daughter of king
Henry ye fourth was sent over see with ye earl of Somerset her uncle and with
master Rychard Clyfforde than bishop of worcestre and with many other lords
knights ladies and worthy squyres as longed to such a ky^ges daughter and
came into Colayn. And thither came the dukes sone of Bar with a fair menye
and received this worthy laby and the bishop of worcestre wedded and sacred
them together as holy church it would. And there was made a ryall feast and a
great Iustynge in the reverence of worship of the^ and all people ye thither
came when this marriage and feast was done the earl and the bishop and al their
menye took their leave of the lord and the lady and came home again into England
in saufte thanked god. And in the.v. year of king He^ryes regne the lord
Thomas his sone went over see and the earl of Kent and many other lords and
knights with me^ of arms and archers a great no^bre to chastyse ye rebels
that before had done much harm to our Englysshmen and merchants / and to
many towns and ports in England on the sea costs. And the lord Thomas the
kings sone came into Flaundres before a town that is called / Scluse among
all ye ships of diverse nacyons that were there / and after there they rode^
with their ships among them and went on land and sported them there two
days and came again to their ships and took the broad see and there they
met with three Carackes of Iene that were laden with diverse marchau^dyse and
well ma^ned. and they fought together long time but the Englysshmen had the
vyctory and brought the Carackes into the Cambre before wynchelse and there
they cun^ed these goods / and one of these Carackes was suddenly burnt there.
And the lords and their people turned them home again and went no further at
that time. And the same time Serle yoman of king Rychardes robbes came in to
England out of Scotlonde and told to diverse people that king Richard was
on live in Scotlo^de and so much people byleued in his words wherefore a great
part of ye people of the reame were in great error and grutchynge aye^ste the
king through informacyo^ of lies and falls lesynges that this^ Serle had made.
For much people trusted and byleued in his saving. But at the last he was
taken in the North country and there by law Iuged to be drawn through every
cite and good brugh towns in England and so he was served and at the last he
was brought to london unto the gylde halle before the Justice and there he was
Iuged for to be brought to ye toure of. london and there to be laid on an
hurdell and than to be drawn through the cite of London to Tyburne and there to
be hanged and thanne quartred and his heed smyte^ of and set on London bridge
and his quartres to be sent to four good towns of England and there set up
and thus ended he for his treason and decessed. And in the.vi. year of king
Henryes regne ye fourth the earl of Mar of Scotlonde by cause conduyt come
into England to challenge sir Edmonde earl of Kent to certain courses of war
on horsbacke. And so this challenge was accepted and granted and the place
taken in smythfelde at london. and this earl of Mar ye Scot came proudly into
the field as his challenge asked. and anon came the earl of Kent and rode unto
the scot and manly rode together with sharp sp^res dyuerses courses / but the
earl of Kent had ye field and gate him much worship and thank of all manner
men of his manful deeds. And in the.vii. year of king Henryes regne ye four the
sir Richard Scrop Archebysshop of york and the Earl Marchall of England
gadrede unto them a strong power against king Henry. And the king herynge
there of in all ye have yt he mighty came with his power Northwarde and met
with them at york / and there were these two Lords taken and brought to the
king. And anon the Iuges were set and these two lords brought forth and
there they were dampened unto death and both their heedes smyten of and there
they made an end on whose souls god for his pity have mercy Amen. And when
this was done the king came to London again and there rested hym^ Anon god of
his great goodness wrought. and showed many great miracles for these worthy
clerk Archebysshop of york that thus was done to death. And in the.vii. year
of king Henryes regne dame Luce the dukes sister of Melayne came in to England
and so to London and there was wedded to sir Edmonde earl of Kente in ye
pryory of saint Marye oueres in south warke with much solempnyte and great
worship / The king was there* himself and gafhyr at the church door and when
that they were wedded and mass was done the king his own person brought and
ladde this worthy lady in to the bishops place of wynchestre and there was a
wonder grate feast hold on to all manner of people that would come. And the same
year sir Robert Knolles knyt a worthy warryour deyed at his manner in Northfolk
and from thens he was brought to London on a horse bear with much torche light
and so he was brought unto the white freres in Fletstrete and there was do and
made for him a solemn feast and a ryall enterement for tho that thither would
come / both rich and poor and there lies buried by dame Constance his wife in
the mydde of the body of the church on whoos soul god for his pity have mercy
/ Amen. And thus in this same year sir Thomas Rampston knight and Constable of
the Tour of London was drenched at London bridge as he came fro westmyger In
wards to the Tour in a barge and all through lewdenesse. And in the same year
dame Phylyp the younger daughter of king Henry was ladde over see with sir
Richard the dukes brother of yolke and sir Edmond Courteney bishop of
Norwiche and many other lords kynghtes and squyres ladies and gentyl women
that apparteyned to such a kings dougher and came in to Denmake / and the
king received this worthy lady for his wife / and welcomed these worthy lords
and did unto them much worship / and they were brought unto a town that was
called London in Denmark / and there was this lady wedded and sacred to the
king of Denmark Norway and Swythen and there was crowned queen of Denmark
with much solempnyte and there was made a ryall feast. And when this feast and
marriage was done and ended these lords and ladies took their leave of the
king and the queen and came again in to Enlonde in saufte thanked be god. And
in the.viii. year of king Henrys regne there was a man that was called the
walsshe clerk / and he apelyd a kynght that was called sir Percyuale Snowdone
of treason / and there they were Joined to fight unto ye vtterau^ce with in /
Lystes and the day and place and time assygned and lymytted to be done and
ended in smythfelde / at ye which day tho two persons came in to the field
and foughten sore and myghtely togoder / but at the last the knight over come
the clerk and made him yield him as recreaunt of his false enpechement that he
had said on him / and than was he dyspoyled of his armure and drawn out of ye
field to Tybu^ne and there he was hangyed and the knight taken to grace and was
a good man. / And in the same year the Earl of Northumberlonde and the lord
Bardolfe came out of Scotlonde in preiudyce and dystruccyo^ of king Henry /
wherefore they of the North country aroson upon them and fought with them
and scomfyted them and took them and smote of their hedes and quartred their
bodies and sent the head of the earl and a quarter of the lord Bardolfe to
London and there they were sets upon London bridge for falls treason that they
had purposed against the king. And in the ix. year of king Henryes regne was
sire Edmonde Holonde Earl of Kente made Amerall of England for to keep the sea
/ and he went to the sea with many ryall ships that were full well arrayed
and enparelled and enarmed with many a good man of arms and arches and of good
defense of war in the kings name of England / and so he londed at the
last in the cost of Brytayne in the isle of Bryak with all his folk / and he
besyeged the castle and assau^ted it and they withstode him with great defense
and strenth. And anon he laid his ordinance and in the lyenge of a go^ne
there come a quarrel and smote the good earl Edmonde in ye heed and there he
caught his deed wound / but yet they left not tylle that they had gotten the
castle and all that were therein. And there this good Lord deyed on whoos
soul god have mercy. Amen. And than this menye came home again into England
with the Earls body and was buried among his au^cestres right worthily. And
in the same year was a great frost in England that dured.xv. wekes. long. And
in the.x. year of king Henryes regne the fourth came the Soneschall of
Henaude with other menye in England to seek auentures and to get him worship
in deeds of arms both on horsback and on foot at all manner points of war^e.
And the seneschal challenged the earl of Somerset and the earl delivered him
full manfully of all his chalenges and put his adversary unto the worst in all
points and wa^ne him there great worship and the degree of the field. And on
the next day after came into the field an other man of arms of Seneschals
party. And against him came sir Richard of Arundell knight / and the Henaude
had the better of him on foot in on point for he brought him on his knees. And
on the third day come in an other man of armer in to the field / and against
him trere came. sir John^ Corn waylle knight / and manly and knyghtly he
quyte him in all manes points ayenste his adversary and had the better in the
field And on the fourth day came a another man of arms of Henaude in to the
field / and ayenste him came sir John^ Chains sone and manly quyte him ayenste
his adversary. For he cast horse and man into the field / and the king for his
manhood at that time dubbed him knight And on the fyfte day there came an other
man of arms of the Henaudes party into the field / and to him came in Sir
Johan steward knight / and manfully he quyt him in all manner points and had
the better. And on the syxte day after came an other Henaunde / and to him
came Wyllyam porter squyre and manfully he quyte him and had the better in ye
field / and the king dubbed him knight that same time. And on the seuenthe day
after came an other man of arms of Henaude in to the field and to him came
Johan standisshe squyre and manfully he quyte him on his aduersarye and had the
better of him in the field and there the king dubbyd him knight that same
day / And on the same day came an other man of arms of Henaude / and to him
came a squyre of Gascoyne / and proudely and manly he quyte him of his
adversary and had the better of him in the field / and anon the king dubbed
him knight. And on the.viii. day came into the field two other men of arms of
Henaude and with them met two souldyours of Calays the which were two
brethren that were called Burghes / and they well and manly quyte them self
upon their adversaries and hadde^ the better of them in the field. and thus
ended these chalenges with many great lordshyppes And then the king at the
reverence of these worthy strangers made a great feast and gaafe unto them
many great and rich gifts and then they took their leave and went home aye^
into their own country. And in the.xi. year of king Henryes regne the
fourth there was a great batayl do in smythfelde between two squyres / that
one was called Gloucestre that was the parliament. And Arthur was the
defendaunte / and well and manly they foughten together long time / and the
king for their manfulnesse and of his grace took their quarrel into his hand
and made them to go out of the field at ones and so they were divided of the
batayl and ye king gaf them grace. And in the.xii. year of king Henryes regne
the fourth. Rysdye a squyre of wales that was arybelle a ryse^ and supporter to
Ome^ of Glendre yt did much dystruccyon to the people of wales was taken and
brought to London and there he came before the Justices and was dampened for his
treson / and than he was laid on an hurdell and so drawn to Tyburne through
the cite and there he was hanged and let down aye^ and his heed smite^ of and
the body quartred and sent unto four towns and his head sete on London
bridge. And in the.xiii. year of king Henryes regne tho deyed sire Johan
Beauforde earl of Somersette. that was Capytayne of Calays and was buried at
the abbaye of the Tour hill on whose soul god have mercy Amen. And in the same
year the lord Thomas king Henryes sone wedded the Countess / of Somersette.
And in this same year came ye embassatours of France in to England from the
duke of Burgoyne unto the prince of England king Henryes sone and heir for
to have help and socour of men of arms and archers against ye duke of
Orlyaunce. And tho went over see the earl of Arundell. sir Gylbert Vmfreuyll
earl of Keme / and the lord Cobham sir John^ Oldecastelle and many other god
knights and worthy squyres and men of arms and good archers in to France and
came to Paris to the duke of Burgoyn And there he received and welecomed these
Englysshmen ye lords and all other meny. And than it was done him to wete that
the duke of Orlyan^ce was comen to Semttlowe fast by Paris with a great no^bre
of arms and arbalasters / and thither went our Englysshmen and fought with
them and gate the bridge of Sem^clowe and there they slew moch^ people of
Frensshmen and arbalasters and the remenaunte fled and would not longer
abide. And than our Englysshme^ came again to Paris and there they took their
leave of the duke and came again in to England in saufte and the duke gaafe them
great gifts / and anon following ye duke of Orlyaunce sent enbassatours in
England to king Henry the fourth bese chynge him of his help and socure /
against his dedely enmye ye duke of Burgoyn. And than the king made Thomas his
sone duke of Clarence. And his other sone John^ duke of Bedforde / and his
other sone Humfrey duke of Gloucestre and Sir Thomas Beauferd earl of Dorset
and the duke of Awe marle he made duke of york. And tha^ the king ordained
his sone sir Thomas the duke of Clarence Thomas Beauforde earl of Dorset and
sir John^ cornwyll with many other lords knights and squyres and men of arms
archers for to go over see i^ to France in helping and strengthynge of the
duke of Orlyau^ce. And these whothy lords with there retenue shypped at
Hampton and saylled over the sea in to Normandye and londed at Hogs. And
there met with them the lord Hambe at their londynge with.vii. thousand
men of arms of Frensshmen and three Serge auntes of arms with them and all
were put to flight and taken of them ^vii. hundred men of arms and.iiii.
hundred horses with out tho that were slain in the field. And so they rode
forth through out all France and token castles and towns and slew much people
of frensshmen that with stood them and took many prysoneere as they roden And
so they passed forth till they came to Burdeux and there they rested them a
while and set the country in peace and rest till the wind was ready for to
sayll. And than the duke with his menye come home in to England in saufte
thanked god / And in ye same year was the kings coin changed through out
England by the king and his counseyll / yt is to say ye noble half noble and
ferthynge of gold. And the.xiiii year of king Henryes regne the fourth he let
make Galays of war for he had hoped to have passed the great see and so forth
to Iherusalem and there to have ended his life / but god vysyted him so soon
after with Infyrmytees and great sickness yt he might no well endure no while
so fervently he was taken and brought in bed at westmynster in a fair
thambre And as he lay in his head he asked his cha^berlayll what they called
that chamber that he lay in and he answered and said Iherusalem. And than he
said that the prophecye said yt he should make an end and deye in Iherusale^
And than he made him did unto god and dysposed all his will. And so on after he
dyed and was carried by water from westmynster in a barge unto Feuersham and
from thens he was carried to Caunterbury by land with much torche light
brennynge into the abbaye of Crechyrche and there he was entered and buried
beside saint Thomas of Caunterburyes shryne and thus ended the worthy king
Henry and about mydlente sunday in the year of our lord a. M.CCCC. and.xxi.
upon whoos soul god have mercy Amen.

MArtyn the.v. was pope after John^.xiii. year / this man was chosen by the
counseyll of Constantynoble and the other was deposed that strof. and so came
peace in the church the which long time before was desired and necessary for
the defense of the faith. This was the myghtyest pope yt ever was of richesse /
and a great Judge. He edefyed towns walls streets and he destroyed heresies /
and he did much good thrughe the noble prince Sygysmonde. And he gadred much
money for to geten the holy land again / but death came upon him and let
him and he made a counseyll before his death for ye matter and there he decessyd.
Eugenius was pope after Martyn.xvii. year / this Eugenius was chosen peasyble
after ye death of Martyn / and no man doubted but he was pope / but soon after
he was expulsed from Rome / for it was so that he fled naked also he was
cyted to the counseyll of Basylyens and deposed / but he dyscharged him not /
and for that began the stryffe again the which stood to his death. And those yt
favored him said he was worth much loving / and the contrary said those
that were against him but what someuer he was after he had taken the dygnyte
upon him before he was of great obstynaunce and of good fame.and what he did
after that I leave to the Judgment of god^

Circa Annu^ dm^. M.CCCC.xxi. Of king Henry the fyfte that was king Henryes
sone.
ANd after the death of king Henry the fourth reigned king Henry his sone that
was borne at Monmouthe in wales that was a worthy king and a gracyous man and
a great conqueror. And in the first year of his regne for great love and
goodness he sent to the ferres of Langley there as his fader had do burye
king Rychard the second and let take his body out of the earth again and did
bring it to westmynster in a ryal chare covered with black velvet and baners
of diverse arms about and all the horse drawing the chare were trapped in
black and beten with diverse arms / and many a torche brennynge by all the
way till he came to westmynster / and there he let make for him a ryall and
solemn enteremente and buried him by queen Anne his wife as his own desire
was on ferther side of saint Edwardes shryne in the abbaye of saint Peter's in
westmynster on whose soul god have mercy Amen And in this same year were a
certain of lollers taken and falls herytykes that had purposed through falls
treason for to have slain our king / and for to have destroyed all the
clargye of the reame and they might have had their falls purpose. But our lord
god would not suffer it / for in haste our king had warning thereof and of
all their falls ordinance and werkinge and came suddenly with his power to
Saint Iohans without smythfelde and anon they took a certanye of the Lollers
and falls herytykes and brought them to the kings presence / and there they
told all there falls purpose and ordinance how they would have do and
wrought if they might have reigned and had their will / and there they told
which were their Capytayens and governors and than ye king commanded them
to the Tower of London / and thanne took moo them both within the City and
without and sent them too Newgate and to both / counteers. And thanne they
were brought in examycyon before the clergy and the kings Justices and there
they were conuycted for their falls heresy and dampened before the Justice for
their falls treason. And this was their Judgment that they should be drawn
from the Towr of London to Saint Gelys field and there to be hanged and burnt
on the galowes. And there was taken sir Roger Acton knight for heresye and eke
for treason ayenste the king and the Reame / and he came before the clergy and
