was conuy^te for his heresye and dampened before the Justice too be drawn from
the Tower of London thrughe the Cite to Saint Gelys and to be hanged and
burnt. And in the second year of King Henryes regne the fyfthe he held a
counseylle of all the lords of the reame at westmynster and there he put
him this demand and prayed and besought them of their goodness and of their
good counseyll and will to show him as touching the title of the right that
he had to Normande Gascoyne and Guyhen the which the king of France
wythelde wrongfully and vntyghte fully / the which his auncestrees before him
had by true title of conquest and right heretage / the which Normandye
Gascoyn and Guyhen the good King Edward of wyndesore and his auncestres
before him had holden all their lives time. And his lords gaaf him counseyl
to sendde enbassatours unto the king of France and his counseyll that he
should give up unto him his right heritage / that is to say Normandye Gascoyne
Guyhen the which his predecessors had holden before him or else he would it
wyn^e with strength of sword in short time with the help of almighty god.
And thanne the Dolphyn of France answered to our enbassatours and said in
this manner that the King was over young and to terder of aege for comak any
war as ayenste him and not like yet to be a good warroure to do and make
such aconqueste there upon him. And somewhat in scorn and dyspyte he sent to
him a tonne fulle of tenes balls because he would have some what for to play
with all for him and for his lords / for that would be come him better then
for to^ mayntene any war. And then anon our Lords that werre
enbassatours took their leave and came in to England again and told the king
and his counseyll of the ungoodly answer that they had of the Dolphyn / and of
the present ye which he had sent to our king. And when the king had herd
their words and the answer of the Dolphyn he was wonder sore agreued and
right evil apayed toward the Frensshemen and toward the king and the Dolphyn
/ and thought to avenge him on them as soon as god would send him grace and
might / and ano^e let make tenes balls for the Dolphyn in all the have that
might be / and they were great gonstones for ye Dolphin to play with all / And
than anon ye king sent for all his lords and held a great counseyll at
westmynster and told unto them the answer yt they had of the Dolphyn and of
the worthy prese^te that he sent to him and to his lords to play with all.
And there the king and his lords were accorded yt they should be ready in arms
with there power in the best array that might be done and get men of arms and
archers yt might be gotten and all other stuff that longed to war and to be
ready with all their retenue to mete at Southampton by Lammasse next following
without any delay. wherefore the king ordained his nauye of ships was with
all manre stuff and vytayll ye longed to such a warryoure of all manner of
ordinance in the haue^ of Southampton in to the nombere of.CCC. and.xx.
saylles. And than fell there a great disease and a foul myschef for there
were.iii. lords which that the king trusted much on / and through falls
couetyse they had purposed and ymagyned the kings death and thought to have
slain him and all his brethren or he had taken ye see the which three lords
were named thus sire Richard earl of Chambrydge brother to the duke of york /
the second was she lord Scrop tresourer of England / the third was sir
Thomas Gray knight of the North country. And these three lords before said for
lucre of money had made a promise unto the Frensshmen for to have slain
king Henry the fyfte and all his brethern by a falls train suddenly or they
had be ware. But god almighty held his holy hand over them and saved them
from these peryllous menye. And for to have done this they received of the
Frensshemen a Myllyon of gold / and that was there openly known / and for
their falls treason they were al three Iuged unto the death / and this was the
Judgment that they should be laadde thrughe Hampton and without Northgate
there to be heded / and thus they ended their lives for thyr false couetyse and
treason / And anon as this was done the king and all his men ye made them
ready and went to ships and saylled forth with fyften hundred ships and
aryued with in Seyn at Kydecause upon our ladies even the Assumpcyon in
Normandy with all his ordinance. And so went him forth to Harflet and he
besyeged the town all about by land and eke by water and sent to the
Capytayne of the town and charged him to deliver town. And Capytayne said yt
he would deliver him none he would him yield / but bad him do his best. And
than our king laid his ordinance unto the twone / that is to say Gonnes
Engynnes and trypgettes and shotten and cast at the walls and eke unto the
town / and cast down both towers and town and laid them unto the earth /
and there he played at the tenes with his hard gone stones. And they that were
within the town when they should play their songs was well away and Alas
that ever such tenes balls were made / and cursyd all tho that war began
and the time that ever they were borne. And on the morn the king did cry at
every gate of the town that every man should be ready on the morn erly to make
assaute unto ye towe. and wyllyam Boucher and Johan Grant with.xii. other
burgeys worthy men came to the king and besought him of his ryall pryncehode
and power to wythdrawe his malice and destruccyon that he did to them and
besought him of.viii. days of respyce and trewes if any rescowe might come to
them / and else to yield up the town unto him with all their goods And than
the king sent forth the Capytayne and kept the remenaunt still with him and ye
lord Gaucort that was Capytayn of the town went forth to Royn in all the have
unto the Dolphyn for help and socour but there was none ne no man of rescowe /
for the Dolphyn would not abide. And thus this Capytayne come again unto the
king and yielded up the town and delivered him the keys and bad him go and put
out all the Frensshmen both men women and children and stuff his town of
Har^et with English people. And than the king sent in to England and did
cry in every good town of England that what crafty man would come thydes and
enhabyte him there in that town he should have house and household to him and
to his heirs for ever more. And so tho went many diverse merchants and
crafty men and enhabyte them there to strength the town and were welcome. And
when the king saw that this town was well stuffed both of vytayls and of me^
this worthy prince took his leave and went to Calays ward by land / and the
Frensshme^ herd of his coming they thought for to have stopped him his way that
he should not pass that way and in all the have that they might braken all
the brydges where that as any passage was for horse and man in so much that
there might no man pass over the River another on horse ne on foot but if he
should have be drowned. And therefore our king with all his people went and
sought this way far up to Paris ward and there was all the ryall power of
France assembled and ready to give him battle and for to dystroye all his
people. But almyghte god was his guide and saved him and al his menye and
defended him of his enmyes power and purpose thanked be god that saved so his
own knight and king in his ryghtfull title. And than our king be holding
and seyenge the great multitude and nombre of his enmyes to wythstande his way
and give him battle / than the king with a meke heart and a good spyryte lift
up his hondes to almighty god and be souhht him of his help and socoure and
that day to save his true servants. And than our king gadred all his
lords and other people about and bad them all to be of good there / for they
should have a fair day and a gracyous vyctorye and the better of all their
enemies / and prayed the^ all to make them ready unto the battle. For he would
rather be deed that day in the field. than to be taken of his enmyes for he
would never put the reame of England to raumsome for his person.

An the duke of york fell on his knees and besought ye king of above that he
would grant him that day the auauntwarde in his battle / and the King
grauntyd him his asking and said / gramercy cosyn of york and prayed him to
make him ready. And than he had every man to ordeyne him a stake of tree and
sharp both ends that ye stake might be pyght in the earth a slope that their
enemies should not overcome them on horsback for that was there falls purpose
and arrayed the^ for to over ride our enmye suddenly at the first coming on
of them at the first brunte. And all the night before the battle the /
frensshmen made many great fyers and much reuyll with howtynge ^ showtynge and
played our king and his lords at the dyse. And archer always for a blanke of
their money / for they we^de yt all had be^ theyrs the morn arose the day
ganne spynge. And the king by good auyse let array his battle and his wings
and charged every me^ to keep the^ hoole together and prayed them all to be of
good there. And when they were ready he asked what time of the day it was and
they said pryme Than said our king now it is good time for all England prayed
for us / and therefore be of good chere and let us goo to our Journey. And
than he said with high voys in the name of almighty god and saint George
auaunce Baner and saint George this day thyn help. And than this Frensshemen
came pryckynge down as they would have over ryden all our meny. but god and
our archers made the^ right sone to stomble / for our archers shote never
arowe amysse but it perysshed and brought unto ye ground both horse and man /
for they shote that day for a wager. And our stakes made them top over terue
each one over other that they lay onhepes two hepes lenth of high. And our
king with his menye and with his men of arms and archers that sthacked on
them so thycke with arowes and laid on with staves and our king with his
ho^des fought ma^ly that day. And thus god almighty and saint George brought
our enmyes to ground and gaf us that day the vyctory. There werre slain of
Frensshmen ye day in the field of Agyngcourt moo than.xi. thousand with our
prisoners that were taken and there were nombred that day of Frensshme^ in the
field moo than sir score thousand. But god that day faughte for us. And after
came there tidings to our King that there was a new battle of Frensshmen
ordained ready for to stele on him and came toward him. And anon our King
let cry that every man should do slay his prisoners that he had taken /
and anon to make them again ready for to fight with the Frensshe men / And
when they saw that our men killed down their prisoners than they did
wythdrawe / them and brake their battle and all their array. and thus our
king was a worthy conqueror had that day the vyctory in the field of
Agyngcourte in Pycardye / And than our king return again there that the
battle was for to see what people were slain of Englysshmen / and if any were
hurt that they might be helped. And there were deed in the field the duke of
Barrye ye duke of Alau^some ye duke of Braban the Earl of Nauerne chyef
Constable of France / and.viii. earls and the Archebysshop of Sau^ce and of
good barons an hundred and mo / and of worthy Knights of great alyau^ce of
cote armures a thousand and.v. hundred. And so of Enelysshe men was deed the
duke of york and ye earl of Southfolke / and of all other Englysshmen there
were not deed passing.xxvi. bodies thanked be god. And this battle was on a
friday which was saint Cryspyne and Crispymanes day in the month of Octobre
/ and anon the king commanded to bury them and the duke of york to be
carried forth with him and the earl of Southfolke. And there were prisoners the
duke of Orlyau^ce the duke of Burbon the earl of Vendome the earl of ewe the
earl of Rychemonde and sir Bursygaunt Marchall of France and many other worthy
lords were taken there in this battle of Agyngcourte and were brought unto
the town of Calays and so over the sea with the king in to England and
landed at Dover in Kente with all prysoneres in saufte thanken bo god almighty
/ and so came to Caunterbury and offered at saint Thomas shryne and so he rode
forth thrught the country of Kente the next way unto Eltham and there he
rested till that he would come to London. And than the mayer of London and the
aldermen shreues / with all the worthy comuners and crafts came to the black
hethe well and worthily arrayed / for to welcome our king with dyuer melodyes /
and thanked almighty god of his gracyous vyctory that he showed for him And so
the king and his prisoners passed forth by them till he came to saint thomas
waterynge / and there met with him all relygyous men with processyon and
welcomed him and so the king came tydynge with his prisoners through the Cite
of London where that then was showed many a fair sight at all the conduytes and
at the cross in chepe as in heavenly array of angels archau^gelles patryarkes
prophets and virgynes with diverse melodyes sensynge and synginge to welcome
the king and all the conduytes rennynge with wine and the king passed forth
to saint Poules and there met with him ^xiiii. bysshopes all reuessed and
mytred with sensers to welcome the king / and there they song for his
gracyous vyctory. Tedeum laudamus. And there the king offered and took his horse
and rode to westmynster / and than the mayer took his leave of the king and
rode home again. And in ye third year of king Henryes regne the fyfth come the
Emperor of Almayne king of Rome and of Hungrye in to England and so to the
cite of London. And the mayer and the aldermen with the shreues and worthy
crafts of London by the kings commandment met with him on the black
hethe in the best array that they could ^on horsbacke. And there they welcomed
him and brought him unto London with much honor and great reverence And at
saint Thomas wateryng there met with him the King with all his lords in good
array. And there was a worthy metynge between the Emperor and King Henry the
fyfte and there they kyssed together. And enbraced each other / and than the
King took the Emperor by the hand and so they came riding through the cite
of London unto saint Poules and there they alyghted and offered and all the
bysshoppes stood reuesshed with sensers in their ho^des sengynge to them. And
than they took their horses and rode unto westmynster And the King lodged the
Emperor in his own palace and there he rested him a great while and all at
the Kings cost. And soon after came the duke of Hollande into England to
come and se there the Emperor and to speak with him and with our King Henry
of England. And he was worthily received and lodged in the bishops Inn of
Ely and all at the kings cost. And when the Emperor had well rested him and
seen the land in diverse parties and knew the commodytes tha^ by the process
of time he took his leave of the king / but or he yode he was made knight of
the garter and retained and wered ye lyueray. And than he thanked the king and
all his lords. And than the king and he went over the sea unto Calays and
aboden there long time to have an answer of the Frensshe king. and at ye
last it came and plesed him right naught / and so the Emperor took his leave
of ye king and passed forth in gods name / and our king came over aye^
into England in all the have that he might and that was on saint Lucas even
that he came to Lambythe / and the mondaye next he came in to ye parleme^te
at westmynster. And in this same year was a great derth of corn in England.
but thanked be god it lasted not long.

ANd in the fourth year of King Henryes regne the fyfthe he held his
parleamente at westmynster in the beginning of Octobre and last to the
puryfycacyo^ of our lady than next after. And there was granted unto him to
mayntene his wars both of spyrytualtee and of te^poralte an hoole ^are and a
dyeme. And than anon the king prayed all his lords to make them ready to
strength him in his right. And anon he let make a new retenue and charged
al his me^ to be ready at Hampton in wytson weke than next after with out any
delay. And there the king made the duke of Bedford protector and defender of
his reame of England in his absence and charged him to keep his laws and
mayntene both spyrytuall and temporal. And when the king had thus do and
set all thing in his kind. On saint Marks day he took his horse at
westmynster and came ridynge to Poules and there offered and took his leave /
and so rode forth through the cite takenge his leave of all manner of people as
well poor as rich prayenge them all in general to pray for him. And so he
rode forth to saint Georges and there offrede and took his leave of the mayer
chargynge him to keep well his chamber. And so he rode forth to Hampton and
there abode tylle his retenue were ready and come^ for there was al his nauye
and ships with his ordinance gadred together and well stuffed as longed to
such a ryall king with all manner of vytayls for such a ryall people as
well for horse as for man as longed for such a warryoure. That is to say
gonnes trypgytes engynes sowes bastyles / Brydges letge^ sclynynge ladders
malles and spades shoueles pyckes pauys bows and arowes bows strings and
to^nes chestes and pypes fulle of arowes as neded for such a worthi warryoure
that no thing was to seche wha^ne time come / thither came to him ships
laden with gonnes and gonpoudre. And when this was ready and his retenue come ye
king and all his lords with all his ryall hooste went to ship and took the sea and sailed into Normandye and londed at Touke upon Lammasse day than next
after / And there he made.xlviii. knights at his londynge. And than the king
herynge of many enmyes upon the sea / that is for to say.ix. great Carackes
husks Galays and ships that were coming to dystroye his nauye. And anon he
commanded the earl of March to be chyef chyeftayne and many other worthy
lords with him and with men of arms and archers to goo to ye see that none
enemies defouled his nauye ne entered his vyage ne his Journey. And anon the
earl took his menye and went to ship and scommed the sea and kept the sea
costs that no manner of enmyes durst rowte upon the sea / and anon the
king sent his heraudes unto the Capytayne of Touke and charged him for to
deliver him his castle and his town and else he would neither leave man ne
child alive. And anon the Capytayne and four other burgeses of the town
brought the keys to the King and besought him of grace. And the King
delivered the keys to sir Johan Kyke^a^e and made him Capytayne and commanded
him for to put out all Frensshmen both of castle and of the town. And there
beside was the castle of Lovers and thither the king sent the earl Marchall
with a fayremenye and assauted ye town / and anon it was yolden to the earl
and brought him the keys / and he brought them to the King and the King
took them to him again and made him Capytayne of the castle of Lovers and of
all that longed thereto / and charged him to deliver out all the frensshme^ /
and than the king held forth his way to Cane yt was a strong town and a
fair and a ryall castle therein / and anon he sent his Heraudes to the
Capytayne and charged him to deliver the town and his castle or else he would
get them with strenght of hand. And they answered and said. that he took
them none to keep ne none the would delyuere unto him. And so anon he laid
his syege unto the town and laid gonnes on every side and cast done both
walls and towers and slew much people in their houses / and also in streets.
And the good duke of Clarence laid down the walls on his side unto ye bare
groande / And so with in a while the king by his counseylle assauted the town
all about And anon the Duke of Clarence was entered in to the towe and slew
down right till he came to the king and spared another man no child / and
ever they cried a Clarence a Clarence and saint George / And there was deed on
the walls on the kings side a worthy man that was called Sprynges yt which
ye king commanded to be buried in the abbaye of Canefast by wyllyam
Conqueror. on whose soul god huue mercy amen. And than the king came in to
the towe with his brother the Duke of Clarence and many other worthy lords with
much solemnyte and myrthe. And then ye king commanded the Capytayne for to
deliver him his Castle. And he besought ye king to give him xiiii. days of
respyte if any rescowe would come / and if none would come to deliver him the
keys and the castle at his commandment. And under this comeposycion was ye
town and the castle of Bayous with other towns fortresses and vyl^ages in to
the nobre off xiiii^ upon the hylle be fore the Castle of Cane our king pyght
all his tents that seemed a town as much as the Cane and by that time came
tidings that none resowe would come there And so at the.xiiii. days end the
Capytayne of the castle came out and delivered the keys of the castle to our
king / and bayous and the other xiiii. towns were delivered unto him also /
and anon the king delivered the keys to the duke of Clarence and made him
Capytayne both of the town and also of the castle / and made him Capytayne of
Bayorus and of all the other townys also / And so he entered the town and the
castle / and there he held saint Georges feeste / and there he made xv.
knights of the bathe / there was sir Lowes Robert salyn Chaynye Mougomerye and
many other worthy men and the king commanded them for to put out all the
frensshemen and women / and no man so hardy to defoule no woman ne take no
manner of good away from them but let them pass in peace on pain of death.
And there passed out of the town in one day moo than xv. hundred women / And
than the king let stuff the town and Castle with Englysshemen and ordained
there two Capytayns that one for ye town and an other for the castle. And
charged them upon their lives to keep well the town and the castle. And or
that our king went thens he gate Valeys Newelyn and laid asyege to Chyrburgh
/ and that seyge laid the Duke of Gloucestre with a strong power and a mighty
/ and by process of time and made there a Capytayne of the same town. And this
same time the good Eerle of warwyk laid a seyge unto Donnfronte and gate it
and put therein a Capteyne. And for to speak more of the Eerle of March that
the king ordained tho for to scomme the sea and to keep the costs of England
for all manner of enmyes. The wind rose upon them that they wend all to
have be^ lost / but thorough the grace of almaghty god and good governance
they rodden before the isle of wight all that storm. And there was lost two
Carackes and two Balyngers with marchaundyse and other great goods / and all the people that were within them. And an other Caracke broke up before Hampton
and threw his maste over the walls of the town and this was on saint
Barthelomeus day / And when all this storm was cessed. This worthy Earl of
march took his ships with his menye and went to the sea and londed in
Normandye at Hogs and so roden forth to wards ye king / And ever as he came
the Frensshemen fled / and there came to them an Anthony pygge and followed
the hooste all the way Till they came to a great water and there they dradde
to have be drowned or drenched / For the water closed them so that they
might no where get out / But at the last god almighty and this Anthony
Pygge brought them all in saufte out / And there they caughte them a gyde
that knew the Country about and he brought them thorough a quycke Sand /
And so forth in to an I Will. and also they took many prisoners by the way to
ward the king in their Iourneye / and so they to men unto the castle Cane And
there the king welcomed him and took his Journey at Argentun and anon tho
^t was yolden to the king and they had their lives and went their way. And
than our king remeued unto a strong town that tho was called Cese / and
there was a fayer mynster and they yield it up anon unto the king. And thanne
the king went from thens to ^lau^some and wanne the town and the bridge /
and the king sent the Earl of warwyk to a town that was called Belesme with a
great and strong power and anon they yield it and put them al to the kings
grace and in his mercy / and so did many strong towns and castles that were
in tho parties. And from thens they went to Vernyll in Perch. and anon it
was yolden unto the king both the town and the castle and bodies and gods
to the kings good grace / and so the King gate and conquered all the towns
and castelles pyles strengthes and abbays unto the cite of rone. And in the
fyfth year of king Henryes regne the fyfth / sir Johan Oldcastell that was ye
lord cobham was arested for heresy and brought unto the Tower of London /
and anon afte he brake the Tower and went into wales and there he kept him
long time. And at the last the lord Powys took him / but he stood at great
defense long time and was soore wounded or he would be taken and so the lord
Powys men brought him out of wales unto London again in a whyrlcole and so he
was brought to westmynster and there was examined of certain points that were
put upon him. and he said not nay and so he was conuyte of ye clargye for his
heresye / And dampened before the Justices unto the death for treason. And then
he was ladde to the Toure again / and there he was laid on an hurdell and
drawn through the city to saint Gelys field and there was made a new pair of
galowes and strong and a coler of yren for him and there he was hanged and
bre^te on the galowes and al for his lewdness and his false opynyons.

ANd in the.vi. year of king Henrye the fyfth. He sent his uncle sir Thomas
Beauforde duke of Excestre with a fair menye of me^ of arms and archers
before the cite of Rone and there dyspleyed his Baner and sent herodes unto
the town and badde them yield that cite unto our king their lyege lord and
they said he took them none to keep ne none he should have there but if it
were dear bought and meued with their hondes for other answer would they none
give but gonnes. And there the duke took good any seme^t of ye ground all
about. And anon there issued out of the cytee a grette menye of men of arms
both on horsbacke and on foot and and anon our menye met with them and
over true a great hepe of them and there taken and slain xxx. persons of
full right good mennys bodies and the remenaunt fled aien in to the town /
and the duke went unto Pountlarge unto the king. and told him al how that he
had spedde and how that he lyked the ground. And anon as the duke was gone
they cast down all the subarbes about the Cite unto the hard ground. For
because the king should there no refusing. And upon the frydaye before
lammasdaye thanne next following. onre king with his host came before Rone /
and anon he sete his syege round about that City / and anon he let lay
his ordinance unto the town. And the king with his lords were logded within
the chartre house and great strength about them and that was in the Eest
party of the Cytee. And than the duke of Clarence lodged him with all his
strength and power at the weste end in a waste abbaye before proce Chanx.
And the duke of Exchestre with his menye in the North side before the port
Beauuesyn. And between the duke of Clarence and the duke of Excestre was the
Earl Marchall lodged with much people and a strong power before the castle
gate. And thanne the Earl of Ormonde with the lord Haryngton and also the
Lord Talbott with their Retenue and company next him And thanne Sir Johan
Cornewayle with many othere noble Knights and Squyres of name with all their
Retenue lay with the noble duke of Clarence. And thanne from the duke of
Excestre toward the king were lodged the Lord Roos / and the lord wylleby
with the Lord Phehewe and Sire wyllyam porter knight with their retenue before
the port of Saint Hyllary. And than^e was the Earl of Mortaye with his retenne
lodged in the abbaye of Saint Katherynes. And the Earl of Salesbury with his
retenue lay on that other side of Saint Katherynes / and Sir Johan Graye
knight was lodged at the abbaye that is called mount du saint Mychel And sir
Phylyp Leche. knight the kings tresourer was lodged between the water of Seyn
and the abbaye and kept the ward under the hylle And the baron of Carowe was
lodged under the water side for to keep the passage / and Ienyco the squyre
lay next him on the water side / and these two squyres kept manly the water
of seyn and fought with their enmyes often times. And on that other side of Seyn
lay ye earl of Hontyngdon and master Neuyll the earls sone of westmer london /
and sir Gylbert Vm^reuyll earl of Keme / and sir Richard earl of Arundell and
the lord Feryers with their retenue before port du pou^te and each of these
lords had strong ordinance / and the king did make at Pou^tlarge over the
water of Seyn a strong and amyghty chain of Iron and put yt thrught great
pylis fast pyght in the ground and that went over the River of Seyn that no
vessel might pass yt in to kind. And above that chayn the king let make a
bridge over the water of Seyn that man and horse and all other caryage might go
to and fro at all times wha^ need were. And than came ye earl of warwyke and
had gotten Dou^fronte unto king Henry of England. And anon the king sent the
earl of warwyk to Cawdebeke for to be seyge yt / And when he came before the
town he sent his Heraudes unto the Capytayne and badde him yield up the town
upon pain of death and anon he laid his sege. And the Capytayne besought the
earl that he might come unto his presence and it pleased him and speak with him
/ and so the good earl granted him for to come. And than he came out and
four other burgeys came with him and entreated so with this earl that this
same town was under composycyon to be done as the Cite of Rome did and the
Earl granted and consented tho^to vpoon this condycyon that the kings nauye
of England with his ordinance / might pass by them in saufte with out any
manner of let or dysturbaunce. And to his composycyon they sete to their
seals. And the ships passed up by them in saufte and came before the Cytee
of Rone in to an hundred ships and there they cast their ankers / and thanne
this Cite was besyeged both by land and by water. And when all this was done
and the ships comen up than came the earl of warwyke again to the king and
lodged him between the abbaye of saint Katherynes and the king till that the
abbaye enteraced and so was yolden unto the king. And thanne he remeued him
thens and lodged him before the port Martenuylye / and tho was the earl of
Salysbury commanded by the King for to make him ready for to ride but there
came hasty tidings and made him to abide. And so he returned again and lodged
him beside the good Earl of Huntyngdon tylle that syege was ended. And then
came the good duke of Gloucestre the kings brother from the syege of
Chyrbourghe the which he had gotten and stuffid it again unto the kings
behoue and profit unto the crown of England. And when he was comen to the
king before Rone he lodged with great ordinance before the port Saint
Hyllary more nerer the town and his enmyes then any other lay by.xl. rods
of lenthe within shote of quarrel. And with him lay the Earl of Southfolke and
the Lord of Bergeyeney with all his retenue and strong ordinance and manly
and proudly faughte every day with their enmyes ever when they issued out of
the cite. And thanne came the pryoure of Kylmayne of Irlonde over the sea to
the king with a fair meny of arms of their own country gyse the sum
of.xvi. hundred good mennys bodies / and the king welcomed them and made them
good there. And thanne came thydynges unto the king that the king of France
and the Dolphyn with the duke of Burgoyne would come down and rescowe the Cite
of Rone with a strong power of all manner of nacyons and break the syege And
casts him to enter on the north side of the hooste by cause that there was
the best entering and most plain and there for the king assigned the pryoure
of Kylmayne with his power and lodged him on the north side of the host for
to stop their passage and was by the foreste of Lions and of this ordinance
they were full glad and so they went forth in all haste and kept the
ground and the place that the king and his counseyll had assygned / and they
quyte them as good warryours unto thyer king. Now will I tell you which were
the chyef Capytayns and gouernoure of the Cytee of Rome. Monsyr ^uy Boteler was
cheyf Capytayne both of the cite and of the castle. And Mon sire Teymygan he
was Capytayne of port Canx. Mon sir de al Roche he was Capytayne of the
Dysners. Mon sir Anthony he was Lyuetenau^t to. Mon sir Guy Botyler / Henry
Chantfyen he was the Capytayne of the port dela Pounte^ Johan Materuas was
Capytayne of the port de la Castle / Mon sir de Preant he was Capytayne of
the port of Saint Hyllary / The bastard of Tyne he was Capytayn of ye port
Martenuylle / And grant Iakes a worthy warryoure he was Capytayne of al me^ of
war and he wys governor outward both on horsbacke and on foot of all men of
arms when they issued out of the cytee of all the ports than he arrayed them
al they should encountre with our menye. And each of the Capytayns ladde five
thousand / men of arms and some moo. And of the first coming of our King
their were nombred by Heroudes in to three hundred thousand of me^ and women
and children what young and old / and among all these was many a man full man
of his hondes and so the preued them when they issued out of the cytee both on
horsbacke and on foot / for they came never at one gate allone / but at three
or four gates and atte^ every gate two or three thousand of good mennys bodies
armed and manfully encou^tred with our Englyssme^ and much people slain
diverse times with gonnes quarelles and other ordinance. And this syege dured
^xx. wekes and every they of the town trusted to have be rescowed but there
came none / so at the last they kept town so lange that there deyed many a
thousa^des within the town for defaute of mete of men and children / for they
had eten their horses dogs and cattes that were in the town. And often times
the men of arms drofe out the pore people out at the gates of the town for
spending of vytaylles / and anon our Englysshmen drofe them into the town
again So at the last the Capytayne of the town saw the myschyef and that
they were not rescowed and also the scarsyte of vytaylle and that the people
deyed so for defaute of meet every day many thousands / And also saw young
children lie and souke their moders pappes and were deed. Than anon they sent
to the king besechynge him of his grace and mercy and brought the keys of
the town unto the king and delivered the town to him and all the soudyours
voyed the town with their horses and harnes and the comunes of the town for
to abide and dwell still in the town yearly / to pay to him and to his
successors for all manner customs and see fermes and katerenes. And than the
king entered in to the town and rested him in the castle till of ye wne was
set in rule and in governance.

How the king of England was made enheyrytoure and regente of France and how
he wedded queen Katheryne.
ANd anon after that Rone was gotten Deep and many other towns in the basse
Normandye gaf them over without stroke or syege when they understood that the
king had gotten Rone Also this year had be a peace made and sworn between the
duke of Bugoyne and the Dolphyn which were sworn on gods body that they
should love and assysse each other against their enemies. And after this
contrary to this oath duke John^ of burgoyne was slain and pyteously murdered
in the presence of the Dolphyn wherefore the Frensshmen were greatly deuydeb and
of very necessyte labored to have a treatye with the king of England. for
the king of England wanne daily of them towns castles* and fortresses. Also
this same year was queen Jane arested and brought unto the castle of Ledes in
Kent. And one ^rere Radulfe a doctor of dyuynyte confessor which afterward
was slain by the persoone of the Toure falling at words and debate. And
after ward queen Jane was delivered. And in the.vii. year both the king of
france and of England were accorded and king Henry was made heir and regent
of France and wedded dame Katheryne the daughter of / france at Troyes in
Champayne* on trynyte sunday. And this was made by the men of Phylyp new
made duke of Burgoyne which was sworn to king Henry to avenge his faders
death and was become Englyssh. And thanne the king with his new wife went to
Paris where as he was ryall^ received. And from thens he went with his lords
And the duke of bourgoyn. and many other lords of / france and laid syege to
diverse towns and castles that held of the Dolphyns party and wanne them but
the town of Milon held long time for therein were good defenders. In
the.viii. year the king and the queen came over see and londed on Landelmasse
day on the morn at Dover. And the.xiiii. day of / feuerer the king came to
London. And ye xxi day of the same monthe the queen came. And the.xxiiii. of
the same she was crowned at westmynster. Also that same year anon after Ester
the king held a palement at westmynster / at which parlemente it was ordained
that that gold in English coin should be weyed and none received but by
weight. and anon after wytsontyde the king saylled to Calays and passed forth
so in to France. And in the.xxii. day of March before the king came over the
duke of Clarence was slain in France and diverse other lords taken prisoners
as the earl of Huntyngdon the earl of Somerset with diverse other / and all was
because they would not taken none archers with them but thought to have
overcome the Frensshemen themself without archers. And yet when he was slain
the archers came and rescowed ye body of the duke which they would have carried
with them / god have mercy on his soul he was a valyaunte man. And the same
year between Crystmasse and ca^delmasse the town of Mylon was yolden unto the
king. In the.ii. year on saint Nycholas day in Decembre was borne Henry the
kings first begoten sone at wyndesore / whose god faders at the font stone was
sir Henry bishop of wynchestre and John^ duke of Bedford and the duchess of
Holonde was godmoder / and Henry chychelay Archebysshop of Canterbury was god
fader at confermynge. And in the.x. year ye Cite of Mews in Bry was gotten
which had been long besyeged And this same year the queen shypped at Hampon
and sailed over to the king in France where she was worshypfully received of
the king / and also of the king of Fraynce her fader and of her mother. And
thus king Henry wanne fast France and held great astate and sat at a
great feast in Paris crowned and ye queen also which had not been seen
before / and all people resorted unto his court / but as to the king of
France he held none astate ne rule but was left almoost allone. Also this
year the weder took was sete upon Poules steple at London. And this year in the
monethe of August the king waxed seek at Boys devyncynt / and when he saw he
should deye he made his testament and ordained many noble things for his soul
and devoutly received all the ryghtes of holy church / in so far for they
that when he was anointed he said the seruyse with the priest / and at ye
verse of the spalme of Miserere mei deus that was Benign fac dn^e in bona
voluntate tuasyon / vt edificentur mury Iherusalem / he badde tarry there and
said thus O good lord thou know that mine entente has been and yet is if I
might live to redyfye the walls of Iherusalem. And thanne the priest proceeded
forth and made anende. And anon after this most noble prince and dyctoryous
king flower in his time of christian chyualrye. whom all the world doubted
gaaf his soul in to the hands of god and deyed and made an en / de of his
natural life at the for said Boys / de vyncent beside Paris ye.xxxvi. year
of his aege / upon whoos soul god have mercy. Amen. Than was the body enbamed
and cyred and laid in a ryall chare and an image like to him was laid vpvon
the corpse open with diverse baners and horses covered rychely with the arms of
England and France / and also the old arms of saint Edward saint Edmonde
and other with great multitude of torches / with whom went the king of
Scotlonde and many other lords which accompanied the body till it came unto
westmynster by London in England and every town by the way he had solempnely
his dyryge on the eue^ and mass on the morn and much alms was given to
poor people by ye way And the.vii. day of Nouembre after ye corpse was brought
/ through London with great reverence and solempnyte to westmynster where as he
now lies / it was worshypfully buried / and after was laid on his tomb a
ryal image like hy^self of silver and gylde which was made at the cost of
queen Katheryne. And thus ended and is entered and buried the noble king Henry
ye fyfth / upon whoos soul and al cryste^ souls god have mercy Ame^.

Of ye law of king Henry ye fyfth and what he ordained for king Richard and
for himself after his death.
HEre is to be noted that this king Henry the fyfth was a noble prince after
he was king and crowned how it before in his yo^gth he had be wild recheles
and spared no thing of his lust ne desires but acco^plesshed them after his
lykyng / but as soon as he was crowned enoynted and sacred anon suddenly he
was changed into a new man and set all his intent to live virtuously in
mayntenynge of holy church / destroyenge of heretykes / keeping Justice and
defending of his reame and subgettes And for as much as his fader had deposed
by his labor the good king Richard and pyteously made him to deye / and for
the offense done to him against his legaunce he had sent to rome for to be
assoyled thereof For which offense our holy fader ye pope enyoyned him to make
him to be prayed for perpetually. and like as he had done to be taken from him
his natural life therefore he should do fyside four tapers to bre^ne perpetually
about his body that for the extyncco^n of his bodily life his soul may ever be
remembered and life in heaven in spyrytual life. And also that he should every
weke on ye day as come aaboute of his death have a solemn mass of requie^
and on ye eue^ before dyryge with.ix. lessons and a doole to poor people always
on that day of a xi. shellynges and.vii. pens to be deled penny mele / and ones
in the year at his annyuersary his terme^te to be holden in ye most honest wise
/ and ^ bedeled ye day.xx. pound in pens to poor people And to every
monk.xx. shellynge which all these thynhes performed this noble king for
his fader for king Henry the fourth / his fader performed it not during his
life of whom as it is said that god did touch him and was lepreor that he
deyed. And also this noble prince let do call all ye abbottes and pryours of
saint Benets order in England and had all them into the chapter house of
westmynster for the reformacyon of their order wherein he had comunycacyon / and
also with bishops and me^ of the spyrytualte / in so far forth that they
doubted sore as that he would have had the temporaltes out of their hondes /
wherefore by the advise labors and procuring of the spyrytuallyte encouraged
the king for to challenge Normandye and his right in France / to that entente
to set him a warke there that he should not seek none occasyons for to enter
into such matters And than all his life time afterward he labored and was besy
in the war and in conquerynge a great part of the reame of / france. and so
afterward yt by the grement of the King Charles he had the governance and
the rule of the reame of / france and he was proclaimed regnet and heir of /
france. And so notwithstanding for all this great war that he had /
nevertheless yet he remembered his soul and also thought that he was mortal and
needs must deye / for which cause he ordained by his life time the place of
his sepulture where as he is buried / and has every day three masses
perpetually songen in a chapel our his sepultur of the which ye myddyll mass
and the first and the last mass shall be as it is assygned by him as it
apperyeth by these verses following.

Henrici miss quinti sunt hic tabulate.
Que successiue sunt per monachos celebrate.

And yet the noble King Henry the fyfte founded two houses of relygyon on is
called Syon beside Braynforde of ye order of Saint Brygf^te both of me^ and
women and on that other side of the River Tamyse an hows of monks of
Chartrehous / in which two places he is contynually prayed for night and day
/ For ever when they of Syon resten than they of the Chaptre house do their
service and in like wise when they of the Chartre house resten the other gooth
to / and by ryngynge of the belles of either place each knows when they have
ended their seruyte which be nobly endowed / and do daily there great alms
deeds / as in Charter house certain children be found to scole. and at Syon
certain alms given daily. And yet beside all this he found a recluse the
which shall be always a priest to pray for him by the said Chartre house which
priest is suffycyently endowed for him and a servant Lo here may all princes
take ensample by this noble prince that reigned so little time not fully.x. year
and did so many noble acts as well for his soul to be perpetually remembered
and prayed for / as in his conquestes and he being in his most lusty aege
dysposyd to eschew sin and was a great Iusticer^ in so much yt all the
princes of crystendome dradde him and also of hethenes / and he had determined
in himself if god would have spared him to have warred on the Sarasyns and for
to know the aid of other princes and all the passages in ye Iourneye he
sent a knight of Henaude named Hugh de lanoye unto Iherusalem / but or he
returned he deyed at Boys de vencence in the.xxxvi. year of his aege. on whose
soul god have mercy Amen.

FElyx the.v. was pope wha^ Eugenyus was deposed.ix. year. This man Felyx was
duke of Sauoyen deuonte prince an old man. and he saw his ckyldes child This
man when he lived a holy life was chosen pope of the counsel of Basyle. and
eugeny was deposed. and there was strife long time. And he had no great
obedience for the deposycyo^ of eugenye: And at the last Eugenye decessed. and
than felyx ^esygned to Nycholas for favor of puas to be had and he was made
legate of France and Cardynal of Sabyanus This was the xxiii. strife bytwyxt
Eugeny and felyx and it dured.xvi^ year and this was a new cause and never seen
before for the counseill of Basyle deposed Eugeny they vere pope and there was
no mo for he obeyed not the decrees of the cou^seyl of Constantinople as they
said ne he charged not to obey the counsyel of basyle: but he said rather the
countrary should be done than as they decreed. wherefore there arose a great
alteracyon in ye matter / for some said one way and some an other and could
not accord to this day for that one party said that cou^^eyll was above the
pope. and an other party said the contrary ye the pope was about the
counsel. But they left it vndetermyned. And therefore god must dyspose for
the best. Albert was Emperor after Syghysmonde one year. this Albert was the
duke of Austre and neuewe to Sygysmonde / and therefore he was king of Beme and
of Vngray for his daughter for other heir he left none. This man was chosen
Emperor of almayne but anon he was poysened and dyed / and he was in althynge
a virtuous man yt all men said he was a presydent to all kings. Fredericus
the third was Emperor after him. this Frederyk was the duke of Osteryk and
chosen Emperor of Almayne but it was long or he was crowned of the pope for
deuysyon. And at the last there was made an unity / and he was crowned with a
great honor of the pope in ye cite and was a peasyble man and a quyete and of
a synguler pity and he hated not the clergy (he wedded the kings daughter of
Portyngale / and in his time whiles that heregned he made a great cu^uocacion
of princes in Ratyspona for the Incours of the Turks / and showed unto them yt
now within this ^xx. year crystendom was made less by two hundred mile. and
he warned them yt they should be ready to resyst him. And the Imperyal cite of
Constantynople was take at ye same time of the mysbyleuynge Turks and betrayed
by a Ianue^s whom for his labor the Turk made a king as he promised him. and
the fourth day he called him to him and did hang him for his dysceyte to
his master. And there was great sorrow and weeping among the christian people
for loss of ye noble Cite / formany a Christian man was slain and innumer able
were sold: and the emperor was slain and for envy the Turk caused his heed
to be smyten of when he was deed^ And almoost all the faith in ye land of
Greek failed. Nycholaus the.v. a Ianueus was pohe after Felyx.viii. year. This
Nycholas was chosen at Rome in the place of Eugenye^ and yet the strife hen
gestyll / by a little and a little they obeyed him and all men merueyled that a
man of so poor a nacyon should obtain against the duke of Sauoy the which was
cosyn and alyed all most to all the princes of crystendoome and euerychone
left him. Than in the year after there was a peace made / felyx resygned for yt
pleased our lord his name to be gloryfyed by an obiecte of the world as that
Ianuens was in comparyson of the duke the pope. This Nycholas was a master
indiuynyte and an actyue man and a rich man in conseytes and many things yt
were fallen he buyldyd again / and al ye walls of Rome he renewed for dred of
the Turk And there was a verse made of this unity and publysshed in the cite.
Lux fulsit mu^do: cessit felix Nychalao. And that in ye year of our lord. M
CCCC.xlix. The year of grace with a great devotion was confermed and
Innumerable people went to the appostels setes.

How king Henry the syxt reigned being a child not one year of aege / and of
ye battle of Vernayll in Perch.
AFter king Henry the fyfth reigned Henry his sone but a child and not fully
one year of aege. whose regnne began the first day of Septe^bre in ye year of
our lord.M.CCCC.xxii. This king being in his cradell was much doubted / and
drade because of the great conquest of his fader and also the wysdom and
guydynge of his uncles the duke of Bedford and ye duke of Gloucestre. This year
the.xxi. day of Octobre deyed Charles the king of France and lies buried
at saint Denis. And than the duke of Bedford was made regne of France and the
duke of Gloucestre was made protector and defe^dour of England. And the
first day of March after was sir wyllyam Tayloure priest degarded of his
preesthode and on the morn after he was brent in smythfeld for heresye. This
year sir James Steward king of Scotts married dame Jane the duchess daughter
of clarence the which she had by her first husbonde ye earl of Somerset at
saint Mary ouerys Also this year the xxvii. day of August was the bataylle in
Perch between the duke of Bedforde regne of france and the duke of Alou^some
which was a full great battle The duke of bedforde had on his side the elre of
salysbury mou^tagu and the lord talbot and all the power that they could make
in Norma^dye and the garnysons keep and also many Capytayns with much people
of the duke of Burgoyns. And on that other side was the duke of Ilaunsome. The
duke of Turon that was the earl of Doughan and the earl Boughan with many
lords of france and a great company of Scotts and Armynaxys. And than the
earl / Douglas called the duke of Bedforde in scorn Johan with the leden
sword. And he sent him word again yt he should find ye day that his sword
was of stele. And the batay^le Joined on both sides faught and long tyme^
that. there wist no man whoo should have the better a great while / but at the
last as god would the vyctory fell unto the English party. For there where
slain the earl Douglas which alytell before wasse made duke of Turon the earl.
Boughan the earl Almemere the earl of Tonu at the earl of Vau^tedor and the
vyscounte of Nerbon which was one of them yt slew the duke Johan of Burgoyne
knelynge before the Dolphyn and many moo unto the nombre of.x. thousand and mo
And there was taken presoners and duke of Alau^some and many other lords and
gentylles of / france. But Scotts that day were slain down right the
substance of the^ all. And the third year of king Henry the syxt the duke of
Gloucestre married the duchess of Holla^de and went over see with her into
henaude for to take possessyon of his wyue enherytau^ce where he was honerably
received and taken for lord of that land but soon after he was feign to
return home again into England. and let his wife and all his tresoure that he
had brought with him in a town yt is called Mounle in Henaude which promised
him to be true to him. Notwithstanding they delivered the lady to the duke of
Burgoyne which sent her to Gaunt. And from thens she escapyd in a mannys
clothing and came into zelande to a town of her own called Syryer And from
thens she went to a town in Hollonde called ye Gowde and there she was strong
enough and withstode the foresaid duke of Burgoyne. And soon after the duke of
Gloucestree sent over see in too zelonde the Lord Fytzwater with certain men
of arms and archers for to help and socoure the forsayde duchess of Hollande
which londed at a place in zeelande called. Brewers haven where the lords of
the country came down* and taught with him / in conclusyon he was feyne to
wythdraw him and his menye to the sea again But yet he slew and kylde and hutte
diverse lords and much people of ye same country / and returned home again into
England with his meny and prevailed no thing. And also this same ye^e the
earl of Salysbury / the earl of Souffolk^ the lord will by and the lord
Scales with their retenue laid syege to the cite of Manus the which cite was
yolde to them with many other strong towns and castles to ye nombre of.xxxvi.
This time all Normandye and a great part of / ^raunce unto Orlyaunce was under
the obeysaunce of the King of England / and all the remenaunte of / france
was in great tribulacyon and myschyef.

How three was like to have be a great fraye between the Cardynall and the duke
of Gloucestre. And of the coronacyon of King Henry the syxte both in England
and in / france.
IN the fourth year the same night that the mayer of London Johan Couentre had
taken his charge / was a great watch in London for a fraye yt was between ye
bishop of wynchestre. and the duke of Gloucestre protector etc^. For the
mayer with the people of ye cite would abide by ye duke of Gloucestre as
protector and defendour of the reame but by labor of lords that went
between / and in especyall by the labor of the prince of Portyngale / there
was a poyntement taken that there was no harm done. And after ye battle of
Vernayll in Perch the duke of Bedforde came over in to England. And on
wytsondaye this same year at Leycestre he dubbed king Henry knight. And forth
with the said king Henry dubbed all these / knights whose names of lowen / that
is to wit sire Richard duke of york / also the son and heir of the Duke
of Nurthfolk / the earl of Oxforde / ye earl of west merlonde / the sone and
heir / of ye earl of Northumberlond / the sone and heir of the earl of
Vrmonde / the lord Roos / sir Iamys bottelar the lord Martrauas / sir Henry
gray of Tankeruyle sir wyllyam Neuyll / lord Fawconbrydge / sir George Neuyll
lord Latymer the lord wellys / the lord Barkle / the sone. and heir of the
lord Talbot / sir Raufe gray of work / sir Robert veer sir Rychard gray / sir
Edmonde hongerforde sire Johan bottelar / sire Raynolde Cobham sir Johan
passheley / sire Thomas tu^stall. Johan Chydyok / sir Raufe langeforde / sir
wyllyam drury / sire wyllyam thomas / Richard Carbonell / sir Richard wide
wyle / sir John^ shrydelow sir wyllyam Chain / sir wyllyam Badyngton. sir
Iohnn June / and sir Gylbert beauchampe. Item in the fyfth year the duke of
Bedford with the duchesshe his wife went over see to Calayes and a little
before went over see Henry bishop of wynchestre. And on our ladies day
Annu^cyacyon in our lady thirche at Calays the bishop of wyncestre as he had
so^gen mass was made Cardynall and he knelyge before the high awter the duke
of Bedforde set the hat upon his heed / and there were his bulls red as
well of his charge as of ye reioysynge of his benefyces spyrytall and
temporal. And this same year was great habundaunce of rain / that the
substance of heye / and also of corn was dystroyed / for it rayned almooste
every other day. And this same yer ye good earl of Salesbury sir Thamas of
Mountagu laid syege unto Orlyaunce at the which syege he was slain with a
gonne that come out of the town on whose soul god have mercy. Amen. For sithe
that he was slain English men never gate ne prevailed in France / but ever
after began to lose little till all was lost. Also this same year a Bryton
murthred a good wedowe in her bed without Algate which wedowe found him for
alms / and he bare away all that she and. And after this he took the gyrthe of
holy church at saint George in Southwarke / and there he took the cross and
for swore this land. And as he went it happened that he came by the place
where he did this cursyd deed in the subarbes of London and the women of ye
same parysshe came out with staves and canell dounges and slew and made an
end of him there. Notwithstanding the conestables and many other men being
present for to keep him for there were so many women and had no pity. Also
this same year the duke of Northfolk with many gentylmen and yomen took his
barge / the.vii. day of Nouembre at Saint Mary oueres for to have gone
thrughe London bridge. And thrughe mysgydynge of the barge it ouerthrewe on the
pyles and many men drowned / but the duke himself with two or three leped upon
pyles and so were saved with help of me^ that were above the bridge with
casting down ropes / by the which popes they saved them self. This same year
on saint Leonardes day king Henry being vii. year of age was crowned at
westmynster / at whoos coronacyon were made.xxxvii. knights. This year on
saint Georges day he rassed over see to Calays to ward France. About this
time and a fore the reame being in great mesery and trybulacyon. the Dolphyn
with his party began to make war and gate certain places and made
distresses upon the Englysshmen by the mean of his Capytayns. yt is to say la
here and poton de sayntraylles / and espycyal. a maid which they named la
pucelle de dicu. This maid rode like a man and was a valiant Capytayne.
among the^ and took upon her many great enterpryses in so much that they had
a believe for to have recoueryd all their losses by her. Notwithstanding at the
last after many great f^autes / by the help of prudence of sir John^
Lukemburghe the which was a noble Capytayne of the duke of Burgon and many
Englysshemen Pycardes and Burgonyons which were of our party before the
town of Company the.xxiii day of May the for said pucelle was taken in ye
feld armed like a man and many other Capytaynes with her and were all brought
to Rone and there she was put in to prison. And there she was Iuged by the law
to be brent. And than she said that she was with child / whereby she was a
while respyted Butte in conclusyon yt that founden that the was not with child
/ and than she was brent in Rone / and the other Capytayns were put to ransom
and entreted as men of war ben acustomed. And this same year about Candemasse
Richard hunder a wulle packer was damned for an heretyke and brent at
Tourhylle. And about mydle^ten sir Thomas Baggely priest and vycarye of the
Mauen in Estsex beside walden was dysgraded and dampened for an heretyke and
burnt in smythfelde / And also in this same year whiles the king was in
France there were many heretykes and lolardes that had purposed make a rysynge
and cast hills in diverse places but blessed be almighty god the Capytayae of
them was taken whoos name was wyllaym Manndeuyll a weuer of Abendon and balyf
of the same towne^ which named himself Jack Sharp of wygmoreslonde in wales.
And after ward he was beheded at the foresaid Abendon in the wytson weke i^ the
tewesdaye. This same year the.vi. day of Decembre king Henry the syxth was
crowned king of France at Paris in the church of our lady with great
solempnyte / there being present the Cardynall of England the duke of Bed
fordt and many other lords of France and England. And after this coronacyon
and great feast holden at Paris the king returned from thens to Rone and so to
ward Calays / and the.ix. day of Feuerer londed at Dover / whom all the
comunes of Kent met at Beramdon between Caunterbury and / Dover al in reed
hodes. and so come forth till he came to the black hethe where he was met
with the mayer John^ wellys with all the crafts of London clothed all in
which / and so they brought him unto London the.xxi. day of the same month.
And this same year was a restraynt of the wulles of Caleys made by the
soudyours because they were not pay^d of their wages. wherefore the duke of
Bedford reigned of France being than Capitayns came to Calays the tewsday in
ye ester weke. And than on ye morn after many soudyours of ye town were
arested and put in ward. And in the same weke he rode to Terewyn / and by the
mean of the bishop of Terewyn he wedded the Earls daughter of Saint Poule and
came aye^ to Calays / And than the.xi. day of June on saint Bernabeys day
there were four soudyours of cal^is that were the chyef causers of the
restraynt of the wulles byheded / that is to wit John^ Madeley / John^ Launday
/ Thomas Palmer / and Talbot / and an hundred and.x bannysssed out of the town
that same time / and before were banysshed an hundred and.xx soudyours. And on
mydsomer eue^ after came the lord rege^ce and his wife to London.

ANd than about this time deyed pope Martyn. And after him Eugen^e^he fourth
was pope. This man was peasably chosen in the court of Rome by the Cardynals
and was very and indubytate pope. But within a short time after he was put and
expulced out of Rome in such amanere that he was feign for to flee naked. In
this same time was the counseyll of Basyle to the which counsel Eugenye the
pope was cyted to come. And because that he came not they deposed him / but he
rought not ne set not thereby but gate the cytee of Rome and abode stylle
pope.xii. year. This time about wytsontyde the heretykes of Praghe were
dystroyed. for at two Iourneys were dystroyed of them moo than.xxii. thousand
with their Capytaynes that is to wete Procapius Saplico and Lupus prespyter.
Also there was taken on live master Pers clerk an Englysshysshe man and an
heretyke. And also this same year was strong frost and a long duringe the
which lasted.xi. wekes / for it began upon saint Katherynes even and lasted
unto saint Scolastycus day in Fever year / in the which time the vyntage that
came from Burdeux come over shoters hill. This year was the counseyll of ara^
and a great treat between the king of England and the king of France where
were assembled many great lords of both parties. at which counsel was
ossred to the king of England great things by the mean of a Legate that
came fro Rome ye which was Cardynall of saint Cross / which of ^res were
refused by the Cardynal of England and other lords there were for the king.
wherefore the duke of Burgoyn yt which had been ^onge English sworn forsook
our party and returned Frensshe by the mean of the foresaid Legate. and made a
peace with the Frensshe king reteyuynge of king for recompensynge of his
faders death the count of Pon^ui / the lordshyp of Macon with much other as is
specyfyed in the said treaty. And so our embassatours came home again in horse
caas then they went out For they lost there the duke of Burgoyne which had been with his burgoynons and Pycardes a synguler help in all the conqueste of
Normandy and of France / This same year was a great batayl on the sea between
the Ienewes and the king of Aragon of which battle the Ienewes had the
vyctory / for they took the king of Aragon the king of Nauerne and the great
master of saint James in Galyce with three hundred knights and squyres and
much other people / and this was on saint Domynycus day. And this same year
were seen three sons atones / and anon followed the three fold governance in
the church / that is to wete of Eugenye of the counsel and of neutralyte.
Also this same year a.M.CCCC.xxxiiii. was a passing great wind by which
steples houses and trees were overthrown About this time was an holy maid in
Hollonde called Lyd with which lyned only by miracle not etynge any mete. This
year the duke of Burgoyn began his order at Lyle of ye gollden Fleys and
ordained certain knights of the same order and made statutes and ordynaunces
much according unto the order of the garter. Also this same year the
Frensshmen had enter prysed to have stolen Calays in the fyssynge time / for
many botes of France had safecondy^es to come to Calays for to take hetynge.
And ye soudyours of the town had a custom to come to the church door /
which staves the Frensshmen that were arrayed like fysshers had purposed for to
have stolen their staves and wepen for to have won so ye town. but one of
them lay with a comune woman the night before / and he told to her their
counsel / and she on the morn told it to the Lyuerenaunce which for the
with all commanded that every man should keep his wepen in his hand the
sakerynge time and other. And when the Frensshemen perceived this yt they were
myspoynted they saylled steeyghte to Dear and stale and took ye town. and on
New years day / af^ they took Harslet^ And thus the Englysshme^ began to lose
a little and lytyl in Normandye.

How Calays and Guynes were beseged by the duke of Burgoyne and how they were
rescowed by the duke of Gloucestre.
This year was a great noise all England through how the duke of Burgoyne
would come and besyege Calays / wherefore the earl of Mortayne with his army
that he had to have go with him into france / was commanded and charged that
he should go to Calays / which was at that time well vytayled and manned for
sir John^ Ratclyfe was Leuenetaunte of ye town for the king. And the baron of
Dudlay Lyuetenaunt of the castle. And the.ix. day of Iulii the duke of
Burgoyne. with all the power of Flaundres and much other people came before
Calays and sete his syege about ye town / and every town of Flaundres had
their tents by themself. And this syege endured there were In the mean while
ye duke of Gloucestre being protector of England took the most part of all
the lords of England and went over the sea to Calays for to rescowe the town
or for to fight with the duke and his host if they would have byden The time
London and every good town of England sent over the sea to his rescowe
certain people well arrayed of the best and chosen men for the war. And the
second day of August the foresaid duke of gloucestre aryued at Calays with all
his army and.v. hundred ships and moo. And the duke of Burgoyne and all his
host that lay in the syege / as soon as they aspyed the sails in ye see
before they approached Calays haue^ suddenly in a morning departed from the
syege / leuynge behind him much stuff and vytayle and fled in to Flaundres
and Pycardye And in likewise did the syege that lay before Guy^es where as
they of Gwenes took gregonne of brass called Dyg^on and many other great
gonnes and serpents. And than when the duke of Gloucere was aryued with his
host He went in to Flaunders and there he was.xii. days and did bute little
harm except that he burnt two fair vyllages Poperynge and Bell and other
houses which were of no strong building and so he returned home ayen^ And
this same year the king of Scotlonde besyeged Rokesburgh with much people. But
sir Raufe graye departed from the castle and ordained for a rescowe But as
soon as ye king of Scotlo^de understood his departing suddenly he brake his
syege and went his way and left much ordinance behind him / where he gate
him no worshyp^ This same year the second day of Ianyuer queen Katheryne the
which was ye kings mother and wife to king Henry the fyfte dei^ed and departed
out of this would and was brouht ryally through London and so to westminster. and
there she lies worshypfully buried in our ladies chapel And also this same
year the fourth day of Ianyuer fell down the gate with the tour on it on
London bridge to ward South ward with two arches and all the stone thereon This
same year was a great treat holde^ bitwene Grauenynge Calays between the king
and the duke of Burgoyne / where was i^ the kings name the Cardynall of
England the duke of Norfolk and many other lords / and for the duke of
Burgoyne was the duchess having fulle power of her lord as regnette and lady
of his lands where was taken by thaduyse of both parties an abstynence of
war for a certain time in the name of the duchess and not of the duke by
cause he had gone from his oath and legaunce that he had made to king Henry
the fyfte therefore the king never would write ne appoint ne have to do with
him after. but all in the duchess name. Also this same year queen Jane deyed
the second day of Iule which had been wife to King Henry the fourth and was
carried from Bermondsey to Caunterbury where she lies buried by king Henry
her husbonde. This same year deyed all the Lions in the toure of London. the
which had not ben seen many years before.

How Owen a squyre of wales that had wedded queen Katheryne was arested and of
the scisme between Eugenie and Felix.
IN the.xv. year of king Henry the sixth deyed Sygysmondus Emperor of Almayne
and knight of the garter / whose terme^te the king kept at saint Poules in
London tyally / where was made a ryall heerse / and the King in his astate
cladde in blewe was at even at dyryge and on the morn at mass. etc. And
after him was elect and chosen Albert duke of Osteryk which had wedded
Sygysmondus daughter for to be Emperor. This man was taken and received to be
King of Beme and Vngary by cause of his wife that was Sygysmondus daughter
which left none other heir after him. This Alberte was Emperor but one year
/ for he was poysened and so deyed some says yt he deyed of flix but he was a
virtuous man and pytefull much that all the people ye knew him said that ye
world was not worthy to hauy his presence. This same year one Owe^ a squyre of
wales a me^ of low birth which had many a day before secretly wedded queen
Kateryn / and had by her.iii. sons ^ one daughter / and he was taken and
commanded to Newgate to pryso^ by my lord of Gloucestre protector of ye
reame. And this year he brake the pryso^ by the mean of a priest yt was his
chapelayn and after was taken aye^ by my lord Bomo^de and brought aye^ to
Newgate / and afterward delivered at large. And one of his sons afterward
was ma^e earl of Rychemo^de and an other earl of Pe^broke and the third a
monk of westminster which monk d^yed sone after. This same year also on New
years day at Bernardes Castle fell down a stake of wode suddenly at after
none and slew three me^ myschyfly and foul hurt other. And at Bedforde on a
shyresdai were xviii. me^ murdered without stroke by falling down a stayr as
they come out of the comune ^alle and manifoule hurt. In the.xviii year sir
Richard Beaucha^p ye good earl of warwyke deyed at Rone he being ye time
lyuetenate of the ki^ge in Normandye and from thens his body was brought to
warwyke where he lies worshypfully in a new chapel on the south side of the
quere. And also this year was a great derth of corn thrughout all England for
a bussell of where was worth xl. pens in many places of England. And yet they
might not have enough wherefore Steven Brown that time Mayre of London sent
into pruce and brought to London certain ships laden with rye which did
much good to the poor people. For corn was so scarce in England that in
some places of England poor people made them bread of fern rotes. This year
ye general counsel of Basylyde posed Eugeny and they chose Felix which was
duke of sauoy. and than began the scysme which endured unto the year of our
lord.M.CCCC.xlvii. This felix was a devout prince and saw his sons sone /
And after lived an holy life. and was chosen pope of the counsel of Bysyle
and Eugeny deposed. And so the scysme was long time. and this Felyx had but
lyttll obedience by cause of the naturalyte. for the most part and well nyghe
al crystendome obeyed and reputed Eugeny for very pope of them both. gor
both occupied during the life of Eugeny. This same year sir Rychard which was
vycarye of Hermettelworth was degrated of his preesthode at Poules and brent at
toure hylle as for an heretic on saint Botulphus day. how well at his deche
he deyed a good Christian man / wherefore after his death much people come to the
place where he was bre^te and offered. and made an hepe of stones and set up a
cross of tree and held him for a saint till the Mayre and shreues by the
kings commandment and of bysshappes dystroyed it and made there a dou^ge
hylle. And also this year ye shreues of London set out of saint Martins the
grant of the sent wary five persons which after ward were restored again to
the sentwary by the kings Justices. And after Alberte the third. Frederyk was
chosen Emperor* This frederyk duke of Osteryk was long Emperor and
dyfferred to be crowned at Rome by cause of the scysme. but after that unity
was had he was crowned with the Imperyall dyademe with great glory and
tryumphe of pope Nycholas the iiii. This was a peasyble man. quyete. and of
synguler patience not hatyngethe chryche he wedded ye kings daughter of
portyngale. How ye duchess of Gloucestre was arested for trason and committed
to perpetual prison in ye isle of Man. and of the death of master Roger
Bolyngbrok.

IN this same year Elynoure Cobham duchess of Gloucestre was arested for
certain points of treason laid again her / whereupon she was examynde in Saint
Stephens Chapel at westminster before the Arche bishop of Caunterbury. And there
she was enjoined to do open penance to go thrughe the Chepe beryng a taper in
her hand and after to perpetual prison in the isle of Man under the keeping of
sir thomas stanley. Also that same time was arested master Thomas southwell a
chano^ of westminster master John^ have a chapelayne off the said lady. master
Robert bolyngbroke a clerk vsyng Nygromancye. and one Margery iouroemayn
called the which of Eye belyde westminster. there were arested as for being of
con^seyl with the said duchess of Gloucestre. and for master Thomas suthwel
deyed in ye tour ye night before he should have be reyned on the morrow. for he
himself said yt he should deye in his bed and not by Justices. And in ye.xx.
year master John^ hume and master Roger bolyngbrok were brought to ye gylde
halle in London. and there before ye Mayre ye lords and chyef of England were
reyned and dampened both to be drawn and hanged and quartred but master John^
hume had his charter by ye king. but master Roger was drawn to tyburn where
he confessed yt he deyed gyltles of this matter and never had trespaced in
that he deyed fore Notwithstondyng he was hanged heded and quartred whose soul
god have mercy Ame^. And margere iurdemayn was brent in smythfylde. and also
this year was a great fraye in london i^ fleet street by night time between
me^ of court and men of london. And diverse me^ slain and some hurt. And one
Herbotel was the chyef canser of the mysgouernau^ce and affraye. Also this year
at the chesynge of the mayre of / london the come^s named Robert Clopton and
Raulyn Holande talyor and the alderme^ took Robert clopton and brought him at
the right hand of the Mayre as custom is. And than certain talyour^ and other
h^de crafts men cried nay nay not this man but Raulyn holande wherefore ye
Mayre that was Padyslye sent them that so cried to Newgate where they abode a
great while and were punysshed^ In this year were diverse enbassatours sent in
to Guyon fro a marriage for the king for the Earls daughter of Armynake that
which was concluded. but by ye mean of the earl of Suffolk it was let and
put a parte^ And after this the said earl of Suffolk went hem self ouersee in
France and there he trated the marynge between the king of England and the
kings daughter of Cycyle and of Iherusalem / And the next year yt was
concluded fully that marriage. by which marriage the king should deliver to her
fader the duke of Angeo and the erldome of Mayne^ which was the keye of
Normandye / Then departed the earl of Suffolk with his wyfe^ and diverse
lords and knights in the most ryal astate that might be out of England
with new chares and palfreys which went through the chepe and so went over
the sea and received her and than after in the lenten brought her unto Hamton
where she la^ded and there was ryally received. And upon Candelmas even before
by a great te^peste of thondre and lyghenynge at after none. Poules styple was
set on fire on the mydddes of ye shaft in ye tymbre. which was quenched by
force of labor And specially by ye morrow mass preeste of ye Bow in chepe
which was thought impossyble sauf only the grace of god. This year was the
earl of Stafforde made and create Duke of Bukynghm therle of werwykd of warwyk
ye earl of Dorset markys of Dorset and the earl was made Marks of Soffolk.

How king Henry wedded queen Margarete. and of her coronacyon.
THis year king henry married at Suthwyk queen Margarete. and she came to
london ye.xxviii. day of may. And by the way al ye lords of England received
her worshypfully in diverse places. And i^ especial duke of Gloucestre. and on
the Black heth the Mayre with all the alderme^. and all the crafts in blewe
gowns broudred with the deuyse of his craft. yt they might be known met with
her with read hodes and brought her to london. where were diverse page^ris and
countenance of diverse hystoryes showed in diverse places of the City costely.
And the xxx. day of May. the foresaid queen was crowned at westminster and there was
Iustes three days during within the Sayntwary before ye abbaye This year the
pryour of Kylmain apeled therle of Vrmonde of treason. which had a day to
them assygued for to fight in Smythfelde. And the lystes were made and the
field dressed But wha^ it came to point. ye king commanded that they should
not fight. but took the quarrel in to his hand. And this was done at ye
Insta^ce and labors of certain prechers and doctors of london. as master
Gylbert worthyngton person of saint Andrews in Holbron. and other. Also this
year came a great embassate in to England out of france. for to have
concluded a perpetual peace. but in co^clusyon it turned in to trewes for a year
About this time dyed saint Bernardyne a gray friar which began the new
reformacyo^ of the order in many places in so much. yt they. that were
reformed. be^ called Obseruau^tes* which obseruauntes been greatly encreaced in
Italy and in almayn. this Bernardyn was canonysed by pope Nycholas the.v. in
the year of our lord.MCCCC.l. Ioha^nes de Capristrano was his dysciple which
profyted much to the reformacion of that order for god has showed many a
fair miracle. Also here is to be noted. that from this time forward. king
Henry never profyted ne went forward. but fortune began to torn from him on
all sides. as well in france Normandye. Guyon. as in England. so^ men holden
oppynyon that king Henry gave commyssyon preuarly to Sir Edward Hull sir
Robert Roos / Deane of Saint Senerynes and other / to conclude a marriage for
him. with the Earl of Armynakes sister. which was promised as it was said and
concluded / and after broken / and he wedded queen Margarete as before is said
/ and a full dear marriage for the reame of England / for it was know verily /
that for to have her delyuerde was ye duchy of Angeo and the erldom of Mayn
which was the keye of Normandye for the frenssme^ to enter / And about this
the said Markys of Suffolk axed in plain parlement^ a fyftene and an half /
for to fetch her out of france. Loo what a marriage was this as to the
comparyso^ of that other marriage. For there should have be delyuerde. so many
castles and Towns in Guyon / and so much gold should have be yeuen with her
