/ that all England should have be thereby enriched / but contrary wise fell
wherefore every great prince ought to keep his promise / For because of brekynge
of this promise / and for marriage of queen Margarete. what loss has the reame
of England had / by lesynge of Norma^dye and Guyon / by dyuysyon in the reame /
ye rebellynge of comyns against there prince and lords / what dyuysyon amoge ye
lords what murdre and sleynge of them / what feldes fought and made / in
conclusyon so many yt many a man has lost his life / and in conclusyon the
king deposed. and the queen with her soon feign to fle into Scotlo^de / and
from thens in to France. and so to Loreyne / the place that she came first
fro. many me^ deem that the brekyngege of the kings promise to the systyr of
the earl of Armynack / was cause of his great loss and aduersy^e.

How the duke of Gloucestre the kings uncle was arested at the parlyament of
Bury / and of his death / and how Angeo in Mayn was delyueredd.
IN the.xxvi. year of king Henry was a parlyament at Bury. called Saint
Edmondes bury / abowte which was commanded all the comyns of the country to
be there / i^ their most best defensyable array. for to wait upon the king
/ To which parlyament came the duke of Gloucestre. Vmfry the kings uncle
which had be protectoure of England all the noneage of the king. And anon
after as he was in his lodging he was arested by the Vycou^te Beaumont the
Conestable of England / whom accompanied the duke of Bukyngham / and many
other lords. And for the with all his servants were commanded to depart
from him And xlii. of the chief of them were arested. and sent to diverse
prisons. And anon after this said areste the said duke was on ye morrow deed.
on whose soul god have mercy. but how he dyed and in what manner the certente is
not know. Some say he deyed for sorrow some said he was murdered between two
federbeddes. some said yt a spytte was put in his fu^damente. But how he deyed
god knows. to whom no thing in hid. and then when he was deed he was
laid open yt all men might him se^ And so both lords and knights of the
shyre with Burgeys. came and saw him lie deed. but wound ne token could they
not perceive how he did Here may men mark what this world is This duke was a
noble man and a great clerk. and ruled worshypfully ye reame to the kings
behoue. and never cowde be found fawte to him. but envy of the^ yt were
governors and had promised the duchy of Angeo and the erldome of myan. caused
ye dystruction of this noble man. For they dradde yt he would empeshed ye
delyueraunce. And after they sent his boody to saint Albons with certain
lyghtes. for to be buried. And so sir Gerauys of Clyfton had then ye charge for
to conueye ye corpse. And so it was buried at Saint Albons in the abbaye. And
five persons of his household were sent to london / and there were they
reyned. and Iugyd to be drawn. and hanged. and also quarered. Of whom the
names were / sir roger chamberlayne knight. and one mydelton a squyre. and
Richard denham^ which v. persons were draw fro ye toure of london through
Chepe to tyborn^ and there let done quycke and them striped to have be heded
and quartred and then ye marqueys of Suffolk showed there for thez ye kings
perdon under his great seal. and so they were perdoned of the remenau^ce of
all ye other execusyon and had their lives. and so they were brought aye^ to
london. and after freely delivered Thus began trowble in this reame of
England. for ye death of this noble duke of Gloucestre. and all the comyns of
the reame began for to murmr for it and were not co^tent^ And after ye pope
Eugeny was deed Nycholas the fyfte was elect pope. this Nycholas was chose for
Eugenye yet hangyng these sysmo notwithstondyng he gate the Obedience of all
cryste^ reames. For after he was elect and sacred pope certain lords of
france and of England / were sent in to Sauoy to pope. felix. for to
entreat him to seasse of ye papacye. And by the special labor of saint
Ioha^nes. he sessed the second year after the pope Nycholas was sacred. And
the said. felix was made Legate of france and Cardynal of Sauoye^ and he
resygned the hole papacye to Nycholas. And after lived an holy life. and deyed
an holy man. And as it is said almighty god showed miracles for him. This was
ye.xxiii. scysme between Eugeny and Felyx. and dured.xvi. year. The cause was
this. the general counseyll of Basyle deposed Eugeny / which was oonly pope
and Indubytyte. for asmoche as he observed not and kept the decrees and
statutes of the counseyll of Constance as it is said before. Nether he rought
not to give obedyence to the gener all counseyll in no manner wise wherefore
arose a great alteracyon among writers of these matere (pro et contra) which
can not accord unto this day / one party says / that the counseyll is above
the pope. And that other party says nay. but the pope is above the counseyll.
God blessed above all thing give and grant his peace in holy church spouse
of christ amen. This nycholas was of Iene comen of low degree. a doctor of
dyuynyte / An actyf man he Reedyfyed many places that were broken / and
ruynous. and did make a wall about the palace. and made the wall new abowte
Rome for dread of the Turkis / and ye people wondered and gretely merueylled of
the ceasyng and resynyng of pope Felix to ye pope Nycholas / co^syderynge that
Nicholas was a man of so homely a birth ye other was of affynyte to all most
party of christian princes wherefore there was a uerse publysshed. as is a fore
said. How sir ^raunsoys Aragonys took Fogyers in Normandye / and of the loss
of Consta^tynople by the Turk.

IN the year of king Henry.xxvii. being trewes between france and England A
knight of ye Englisshe party named Sir Fraunces aragony took a town in
Norma^dye named Fogyese / aye^ste the trewes / of which taking began much
sorrow and loss for this was the occasyo^ / by the which the frenssmme^ gate
all Normandye. About this time the Cite of Co^stantynople / which was the
emperial city in all Greece / was taken by the turks* Infydels which was
bytrayde as some hold oppynyo^ / And the^peroure taken and slain. and the
ryall church of saint Sophya robbed and dyspoyled. and the relyques and images
and the rode drawing about the streets / which was done in spyte of Christian
faith and sone after all cryste^ faith in Greece perysshed and cessyd There were
many Christian me^ slain. and innumerable sold and put in captyuyte. By the
taking of this town. the Turk greatly was enhau^ced in pride. and a great
loss to all crystendome. In the.xxviii. year was a parlyament holde^ at
westminster) and from thens adyourned to the black freres at London / and after
cristmas to westmynster again. And this same year Robert of Cane a man of
westcountre with a few ships coming out of the bay. lade with salt which
ships were of Pruce flandres Hollande and zelande / and brought them to
Hampton wherefore the merchants of England being in Flaundres were arested.
in Brydges / Ipre and other places. and might not be delivered / ne their
dettes dyscharged / till they had made apoyntment for to raye ye hurtes of
ships / which was paid by the Merchants of the staple every penny. and in
like wise ye Merchants and goods being in Dansyke / were also arested / and
made great amends This same year the frensshme^ in a morning took by a train
the town of Pounte al Arche. and there in the lord Fawconbrydge was taken
prisoner. And after that in Decembre Rone was taken and lost being therein sir
Edmonde Duke of Somerset / and the Earl of Shrewesbury the which by a
poyntement left pledges and lost all Normandye / and came home into England.
And during the said parlyamente. the duke of Suffolk was arested. and sent
in to the toure and there he was a month. and after the king did do fetch
him out. for which cause all the comunes were in a great rumoure / what for
the delyueraunce of Aungeo and Main and after lesynge of all Norma^dye and in
especcyall for the death of the good duke of Gloucestre / in so much in some
places me^ gadred and made they^ Capytayns. as blewberde and other / which
were take and put to death / And then the said parlyamente adyounyd was to
Leycetre. And theder the king brought with him the duke of Suffolk. And wha^
the comyns understood that he was out of the Tower and come^ thither / they
desired for to have execucyo^ on them yt were cause of the delyuerau^ce of
norma^dye / and had because of the death of the duke of Gloucestre and had
sold gascoyne and guyan / of the which they named too be gylty / The duke of
Suffolk as chyef. The lord Say the Bishop of salysbury / dauyel and many
mo. And for to please you comyns the duke. of Suffolk was exyled out of
England for.v. year. And so during the parlyame^te he went into Norfolk and
there he took his shyppyng / for to goo out of the reame of England into
france / And this year as he saylled on ye see a ship of werre called
Nycholas of the toure met with his ship and found him therein whom they took
out. and brought him in to their ship to the maystre and the capytayne / and
there he was examyned and at the last Iuged to death And so they put him in a
caban and his chapylayne with him for too shryue him / And that done they
brought him into Dover rode / and set him into the boat and smote there of his
heed / And brought the body a land upon the sondes / and set the heed there
by And this was done the first day of May. Lo what auayled him now all his
delyueraunce of Normandye / And here may ye schow he was rewarded for the death
of the duke of Gloucestre / thus began sorrow upon sorrow / and death for death.

How this year was Insurreccyon in Ke^te of the comyns / of whom Jack Cade an
Irysshe man was capytayne
THis year of our lord. M^cccc. and.l. was the great grace of the Iubyle at
Rome where was greet pardon. in so much that from all places in crystendome /
great multitude of people restorcyd thither / And in this same year was a great
assymble and gaderynge to gyder of the comyns of kente in to great nombre. And
made an Insurreccyon. and Rebelled ayenste the king and his laws. And
ordained them a Capytayne called Ioha^n Cade an Iryshma^ which named himself
Mortymer / cosyn to the duke of york / And this Capytayne held them together
/ and made ordynau^ces among them. and brought them to the black hethe where
he made a byl of pe^ycyons to the king and his counseyll and showed what
Iniuryes oppressyons the poor comyns suffren and vnd coleur. for to come to
his above / and he had a great maltytude of people. And the.xxvii day of
June. ye king and many lords Capitayns^ and men of werre went to ward him
to the black hethe^ And when the Capytayne of kent understood the coming of
the king with so great puyssaunce. he wythdrewe him and his people to smok / a
little vyllage. And the.xxviii. day of June he being withdrawe^ and gone the
king came with his army set in order and enbatayl led to the black heth /
and by aduys of his counsel. sir Vmffrey Stafforde squyre two valiant
capytayns / with certain people for to fight with the capytayne and to take and
bring him and his accessaries to the king / which went to Senok. And ye
Capytayne with his felshyp and met with them. and fought against them. and in
conclusyon slew them both / and as many as abode and would not yield the^
were slain.

Duri^g this skyrmysshe. fell a great variau^ce among the lords men and
common people being on black has ayenste their lords and Capytayns /
saying plainly / that they would go unto the Capytayne of kente. to assyste
and help him / but if they might have execucyon on the traitors being about
ye king where to the king said nay. and they said plainly yt ye lord Say
tresourer of England. and the bishop of Salysbury. and the baron of Dubby. ye
abbot of Gloucestre. Drnyel. and treuilo^. and many mo were traitors. and
worthy to be deed wherefore for to plese the lords meny and also some of the
kings house: ye lord Say was arested and sent to the toure of london. and
then the king he ryuge tidings of the death and over throwenge of the
Staffordes he wythdrew him to london and from thens to kelyng worth / For the
king ne the lords durst not trust the town housholdemen. Then after yt the
capytayne had had this vyctorye upon the Staffordes / anon he took sir
Vmfreys fallete and. his bryngantynes smyten full of gylte na^les and also his^
gylte spo^ And arrayed him like a lord and a capytayne and resorted with all his
meny. and also moo tha^ he had before. to ye black heth aye^ To whom came the
archebysshop of Canterbury and the duke of Buckyngha^ to the black hethe and
spoke with him. And as it was said they found him wytty in his talking and
his request. and so they departed. And ye third day of July he came and entered
into London with al his people and there did make cries in the Kings name and
in his name / that no man should rob. ne take no manner gods but if he paid
for it And came rydyng thorough ye cite i^ great pride. and smote his sword
upon london stone in Canwycke street. And he being in the cite / se^te to ye
toure for to have the lord Say. And so they fette him and brought him to ye
yield halle before. mayre and chaldermen where that he was examyned And he
said. he would and ought to be Iuged by his petys. And the comyns of Kent took
him by force from ye mayre / and office^^ that kept him and took him to a
pressed to shrewe. him. And or he might be half shriue^ / they brought him to
the standerd in the chepe side. and there smote of his heed. on whose soul god
have merry. Amen. And thus deyed the lord Say Tresourer of England. And this
they set his heed upon a spear. and bare it all about the Cite And the same
day about Mile end: Cromere was beheded. And the day before at after none
the Capytayne with certain of his men went to Philyp malpaus house and robbyd
him. and took a way much good. And from thens he wen to saint. Margaretes
patens to one Gertis house. and robbyd him. and took away from him much good
also At which robbyng diverse men of London of their neighbors were at^ and
took part with them / For this robbyng the peples hertes fell from hym^ And
every thryfty men was a ferde / for to be served in like wise. For there was
many a man in London. that a waited and would fayn have seen a common robbery
which almighty god forbid. For it is to suppose if he had not robbyd he
might have goon far / or he had be wythstonde. for the king and all the
lords of the reame of England were departed except the lord. Scalys that
kept the toure of London And the fyfte day of In^ he did do smite of a ma^nys
head in south work. And the night after the mayre of London with the Aldermen
and the Comyns of the cyte^ concluded to drive away the capytayne. and his
hooste And sent to the lord Scales to ye toure and to Mathegough a capytayne
of Norma^dye yt they would that night assayll the Capytayne with them of
kente. And so they did come to London bridge in such work or the Capytayne had
any knowledge thereof and they fought with them that kept the bridge And the
ke^^ysshme^ went to harnes and came to the bridge and shote and fought with
the^ and gate the bridge and made they^ of London to flee and slew many of
them. and this endured all the night to and fro / till one of ye clock of the
morrow. And at the last they burnt the draw bridge. where many of them of
london were drowned. In the which night satton and alderman of London was
slain Roger heysaunte. Mathegough. and many other. And after this the
chaunseler of England sent to the Capytayne a pardon generalle for him and an
other for his meny and then they departed fro such work every man to his own
house / And wha^ they were al departed and gone there was proclamacyons made in
Kente South sex and other places. that what man could take the Capytayn quycke
or deed. should have a thousa^de pound. And after this one Alexander yde^ a
squire of kent took him in a garden in suthsex And in taken John^ Cade
capytayne was slain and beheded. And his heed set upon London bridge. And
anon after the king came in to kente / and did his Justices sytte at
Caunterbury / and inquired who was causers and chyef cause of this
Insurreccyon. And there were.viii. me^ Iugyd to the death in one day and in
other places mo And from thens the king went in to Southsex and in the weste
country where a little before was slain the bishop of Salysbury. And this
same year there were so many Iugyd to death that three hedes stood upon London
bridge at ones.

Of the field that the duke of york took at Drenched in kent / and of the
byrch of prince Edward / and of the first bataylle at Said Albo^s where the
duke of somerset was slain.
IN the.xxx. year of the king / the duke of york came out of the March of
walys with therle of Deuenshyre and the lord Cobham and great puyssaunce
reformacyon of certain Iniurys and wro^ges / and also to have Justice upon
certain lords being about the king and took a field at Brentheth beside
Detford in Kente. which was a strong field for which cause the king with
all his lords went unto black heth. with a great and a strong multitude of
people armyd / and ordained for the war in the best wise. And when they had
mustre on the hethe / certain lords were tho sent unto him. for to treat
and make apointme^t with him. which were the bishop of Ely. the bishop of
wyncestre / therles of Salysbury and of warwyk / And they concluded that the
duke of Somerset should be had to ward. and to answer to such artycles as ye
duke of york should put on him And then the duke of york should break his
field / and come to ye king. which was all promised by the king. And so the
King commanded. that the duke of Somerset should he had in to ward. And
then^e the duke of york brake up his field and came to ye king And when he
was come contrary to the promise before made / the duke of Somerset was
prese^te in the field / awaytynge and cheyf about the king / And made the
duke of york ride before as a prisoner thrughe london. And after they would
have put him in hold. But a noise arose that therle of March his sone. was
coming with.x. thousand men to London ward wherefore the king and his
counseyll feryd / And then^e they concluded that the duke of york should
depart at his owen will. Abowte this time began great dyuylyon ne Spruce
between the great master and the Knights of the duchye order which were
lords of that country. For the comyns and towns rebelled against the lords
and made so great werre / ye at ye last they called the king of Pole to be
their lord / the which king came and was worshypfully received / And
besyeged the castle / of Mar^engburgh / which was the cheyf castle of
strength of all the land. An^ wa^ne it / and drove out the master of Da^ske ^
and all other places of that land and so they that had been lords many years.
lost all their seygnourye and possessions in tho lands. And in the year of
the Incarnacyon of our lord.M.CCCC.liii. on saint Edwardes day. queen.
Margarete was delyuerde of a fair prince which named was Edward. That same
day Johan Norman was chose^ for to be Mayer of London. And the day that he
should take his oath at westmynster / he went thither by water with all the
crafts / where before time tho mayer / alderme and the crafts rode on
horsbacke the which was never vsyd after. For syn that time they have ever
goon by water in botes and barges. ye have well understand before how that
contrary to the promise of the king and also the conclusyons take between the
king and ye duke of york at Brentheth the duke of Somerset went not to ward
but abode about the king / and had great rule / And anon after he was made
Capytayne of Calays. and ruled the king and his reame as he would / wherefore
the great lords of the reame / and also ye comyns were not pleased: For which
cause the duke of york / the earl of warwyke / the earl of Salysbury with many
knights and squyres and much other people came to remeue ye said duke of
Somerset and other fro the king / And the king herynge of their coming /
thought by his counsel for to have gone westwarde and not for to have met
with them. And had with him the duke of Somerset ye duke of Bokyngham the earl
of Stafforde the earl of Northumberlonde \ the lord Clyfforde / and many
other. And what time that the duke of york and his felyshyppe understand /
that the king was departed with the lords from London / anon he changed his
way / and costed the country and came to saint Albons the.xxiii. day of May.
and there met with the king to whom the king sent certain lords / and
desired them to keep the peace / and depart: But in conclusyon why^e they
treated on that one side / the earl of warwyk with the March men and other
entered in to the twone on that other side / and fought against the king and his
party / and so began the battle and fyghtinge which endured a great while /
But in conclusyon the duke of york obtained. and had the vyctory of ye
Iourneye / In which was slain the duke of Somerset / the earl of
Northumberlonde. the lord Clyfforde. and many kynghtes and squyres / and many
moo hurt / And on the morn after they brought the king in great astate to
London / which was lodged in the bishops palace of London. And anon after
was a great parliament at London / in which parliament the duke of yerke. was
made protector of England / and the earl of warwyk Capytayne of Calays / the
earl of Salysbury Chaunceler of England. And all such persons as had the
rule before about the king were set a part / and might not rule as they did
before. And this same year deyed pope Nycholas ye fyfte. and after him was
Calixt the third. This Calixt was a Catalane / and the acts of him shall be
showed here after folowynge^ In this same year fell a great affraye in London
against the Lu^bardes. the cause began / because a young man took a dager from
a Lu^barde and brake it. wherefore the yo^ge man on the morn was se^te fore to
come before the Mayer and the alderme^ and there for offense He was committed
to ward. And then ye mayer departed fro the yield halle / for to goo home to
his dinner But in Chepe the young me^ Mercerye for the most party prentyses.
held the Mayre and the Shyrefs still in Chepe. And would not suffer them to
depart / unto the time that their fellow / which was committed to ward /
were delivered / and so by force they rescowed their fellow from prison. And
that done the Mayre departed and the Shrefes also. and the prisoner delivered.
which if he had be put to prison. He had be in Ieoperdye of his life. And
thene began a rumoure in the cite against the Lo^bardes. And the same evening
ye hond crafty men of the town arose / and ra^ne to the Lumbardes houses and
dyspoyled and robbed diverse of them. wherefore the Mayre and the Aldermen came
with the honest people of the cite. And drove them thens / and sent some of
them that had stolen to Newgate. And the young man was rescowed by his fellows
/ saw this great rumoure. affraye and robbed / ensewed / of his first
meuynge to the Lumbarde / departed and went to westmynster to saint wary. Or
else it had cost him his life. For anon after came down an Oyer
determyne. for to do Justice on all them that so rebelled in the Cytee ayenste
the Lumbardes / On which satte with the Mayre that time wyllyam Marowe / the
duke of Bokyngham And many other lords / to se execucyon done / But the
comynes of the Cytee secretly made them ready and did arm them in their
howses and were in purpoos to have rongen the comyne belle / which is called
bow belle but they let by side men / which came to ye knowledge of the duke
of Bokyngham and other lords. And in contynente they arose / for they durst
no longer abide / for they dowted that the hole Cite should have risen against
them. But yet neuerthels two or three of the cite were Iuged to death for this
robbery / were hangyd at Tyborne And anon after the king and the queen / and
other lords rode to Coue^tre and withdrewe them fro London. for this cause.
And a little before the duke of york was sent for to grenewych. And there was
dyschargyd of the protectourshyppe. And the earl of Salysbury of his
Chau^chelershyppe. And after this they were sent fore by preuy seal for to
come to Coue^tre where they were almoost disceyued and the Earl of warwyke also
and should have been dystroyed if they had not seen well to. How the lord
Egremo^de was take by ye Earl of Salysbury so^es / and of ye robbynge of
Sandwytche

THis year were taken four great fysshes between Ereth and london that one was
called Mors Maryne / the second was a sword fysshe and the other two were
whalys. In this same year / for certain affrayes done i^ the north country
between lord Egremo^de and the earl of Salysbury sons. ye said lord Egremond
who^ they had condemned in a great som^e of money to ye said Earl of
Salysbury. and therefore he was committed into prison in Newegate in London
where when he had be a certain space he brake the prison / and three prisoners
with him / and escaped and went his way. Also this year the earl of warwyk and
his wife went to Calays with a fair felisshyp and took possessyon of his
office. about this time was great reformaco^n of many monesteryes of relygyo^
in diverse parties of the world wiche were reformed after the first
Instytutycyon and co^tynued in many places This same year was a great battle
in the Marches between the land of Hu^gry and Turkey. at a place is called
Septedrad where Innumerable Turks were slain / more by miracle than^e by
man's hand / for oonly the hand of god smote them / saint Johan of
Capystrane was there presence. and prouokyd the criste^ people being then
aferde for to pursue after ye Turkys where an Infynyte multitude were slain
and dystryed and the Turkys said / yt a great no^bre of armyd me^ followed the^
that they were aferde to turn again and they were holy angels. This same year
the prisoners of Newgate in London brake their prison / and went upon the seeds
and fought against them of the Cytee / and keep the gate a long while / But
at the last the town gate the prison be them. And then^e they were sore
punysshed in ensample of other. In this year also there was a great erthquake
in Naples / in so much that there perysshed.xl. thousand people that sanke
there in to the earth. Also in the.xxxvi. year saint Osmonde sometime bishop of
Salysbury was canonysed at Rome by pope Calyst. and the.x day of July he was
translated at Salysbury by the bishop of Canterbury and many other
bysshoppes. And in August after sir Pers de brasay seneschal of norma^dye /
with the Capytayne of Deep and many other Capytayns / and me^ of werre went to
thee see with a great Navy. and into the downs by night. And on the more erly
before day they londed at Sandwytche / both by lord and water / and took the
town / and ryfled and dispoyled it / And took many prisoners. and left the
town all bare / which was a rich place and much good therein / And ladde
with them many rich prisoners / In this same year in many places of France
Almayne / Flaunders Holonde and zeelonde / children gadred them together by
great companyes / For to goo on pilgrimage to saint Myghels mou^te in
Norma^dye / which came fro far countries whereof the people merueyled. And
many supposed that some wicked spyryte meued them to do so. but it dured not
long by cause of the long way and also for lac / of vytaylle as they went.
In this year Reynolde Pecok bishop of Chestre / was found an herytyke / and
the third day of Decembre was endu^ed at Lambeth in presence of the
Archebysshop of Caunterbury and many other bysshoppes doctors and lords
temporal / and h^s books brent at Poules cross. And ye have herd before how
certain lords were slain at Saint Albons / wherefore was always a
grutchynge / and wrath had by the heirs of them that so were slain against
the duke of york / the Earls of wa^wyk and of Salysbury / wherefore the king by
the aduys of his counseyll sent for them unto London to which place the duke
of york came the.xxvi. day of Ianueri with four honderd men and lodged him
at Baynerdes castle in his own place. And the.iv. day of Ianuer came the
earl of Salysbury with five hundred men and was lodged in therber of his own
place. And then^e came the duke of Excetre and of Somerset with.viii.C. men /
and lay without temple bar. And the earl of Northumberlonde / and the lord
Egremonde the lord Clyfforde with.xv. hundred men / and lodged without the
town. And the Mayer that time Geffraye Boloyne / kept great watch with the
comyns of the cite / and rode about the cytee by Holborne and Fletestrete /
with a.v. thousand men well arrayed and armyd. for to keep the peace / And
the.xiiii. day of Feuerer the earl of warwyke came to London / fro Calays well
beseen and worshypfully with.v hundred men In red Iakettes broudred with a
ragged staff behind and before. and was lodged at the graye freres / And
the.xv. day of March the king came to London and the queen. And there was
accorded and peace made among the lords / and they were set in peace. And on
our lady day the xxv. day of March. in the year of our lord.M.CCCC.lviii^
the king and the queen and all the lords went on processyon at Poules in
London. and anon after the king and the lords departed. and in this year was
a great fraye in Fletstrete between me^ of court and men of the same street.
In which fair the queen's Attorney was slain

How the kings household made a fraye ayenste the Earl of warwyke / and of
the Iourneye at bloreheth.
ALso this same year as the Earl of warwyk was at counseyll at westmynster all
the kings household meny gadred them together / for to have slain the said
earl. But by the help of god and his friends he recovered his barge / and
escapyd their evil enterprise / how well the cokes came rennynge out with
spytes and pestels ayneh him. And the same day he rode to wards werwyk and
soon after he gate him a commyssyon / and went over the sea to ward Calays.
Soon after this therle of Salysbury coming to London / was encou^tred at
Bloreheth which the lord Audley. And much other people ordained to dystroy him
But he having knowledge that he should be met with was acco^panyed with his two
sons sir Thomas and sir John^ Neuell / and a great felyshyp of goodmen. And so
they faught together / where the earl of Salysbury wanne ye field / And the
lord Audley was slain / and many gentylmen of Chesshyre. and much people
hurt And the earls two sons were hurt. and going homewarde afterward they
were taken / and had to Chestre by the queen's menye. After Calixt Pius was
pope / and was chase this year.M.CCCC.lvlii^ and he was called before Eneas an
eloque^te man / and a poet laureate. He was embassatour of ye Emperors before
time. And he wrote in ye cou^seyl of Basyle a noble treatise for thactoryte of
ye same / Also he canonysed saint Katheryne of Senys / This pope ordained
great Indulge^ce and pardonne to them that would go and werre against the Turk
/ and wrote a pystle to the great Turk / exhorting him to become Christian.
And in thend he ordained a passage against the Turk at Ankon. to which much
people drew out all parties of criste^dome / of the which people he sent
many home again by cause they suffyced not / and anon after he dyed at the said
Anko^ / the year of our lord.M.CCCC.lxiii. the.xiiii. day of August.

How Andrewe Trollop and the souldyours of Calays forsook ye duke of york and
their master therle of warwyk in the weste country.
THe duke of york / the earls of warwyk and of Salysbury / saw the
governance of the reame stood most by the queen and her counseyll / and how
the great princes of the land were not called to counseyl but set a part. and
not only so / but it was said through the reame tho said lords should be
dystroyed as it openly was showed at Blorehethe by them yt would have slain
the earl of Salysbury. Then for sauacyon of their lives / and also for the
comynwele of the reame thought for to remedy these things assembled them
together with much people / and took a field in the west country to which the
earl of warwyk came fro Calays / with many of the old Souldeyours as Andre^we
Trollop and other / in whose wisdom / as for ye werre he trustyd much upon
And when they were thus assembled and made their field. the king sent out
commyssyons and preuy seals unto all the lords of his reame to come and wait
on him in their most best defensable array / And so every man came in such
wise. that the king was stronger / and had more* people than the duke of
york and therles of warwyk and of Salysbury. for it is here to be notyd that
every lord in England at this time / durst not dysobeye the queen / so she
ruled peasybly all that was done abowte the king which was a good and a well
dysposed man. And then when the king was come to the place where they were /
the duke of york and his felysshyp made their field in the strongest wise /
and purposyd verily to abide and have foute / But in the night Andrewe Trollop
and all the old soudyours of Calays with a great felyshyp / suddenly departed
out of the dukes host. And went strayte unto the kings field / where they
were received Ioyously. for they knew thentent of the other lords / and also
the manner of their field. And then the duke of york with the other lords.
seeing the^ dysceued / took a counseylle shortly in that same night. and
departed from the field leuynge behind the^ the most party of their people
too keep the field till on the morrow / Then the duke of york with his second
sone departed through wales toward Irlonde / Leuynge his eldest sone the earl
of March with the earls of werwyk and of Salysbury. which rode together with
three or four persons straight into Deuenshyre. and there by help and aid of
one Denham / gate a ship which cost a.xi score nobles / and with the same ship
sailed fro thens in to Gernesey and there refresshed them / and from thens
sailed to Calays. where they were received in to the castle by ye postern^ / or
they of ye town wist of it / And the duke of york took shypynge in walys. and
sailed over in to Irlonde where he was well received.

How the earls of March warwyk and of Salysbury entered in to Calays and how
the earl of warwyk wence in to Irlonde.
THen king Henry with his host in the field / not knowing of this sodeyne
departing / on the morrow found none in the field of the said lords. sent
out in all the have me^ for to follow and pursue after to take the^ / but they
met not with the^ as god would. And the^ the king went to Ludlowe and
dyspoyled ye castle and the town. And se^te the duchess of york and her
children to the duchess of Bokyngham her sister / where she was kept long
time after / And forth with the king ordained the duke of Somerset / to be
Capytayne of Calays and these of other lords so departed / as before is said.
were preclamyd rebels and great traitors. Then the duke of Somerset took to
him all the soudyours that departed fro the field and made hy^ ready in all the
haste / for to go to Calays. and take possessyon of his office / And when he
came he found therle of warwyk therein as Capytayne and the earls of March and
of Salysbury also / and then^e he londed by Scalys and went to gyues and there
he was received / And it fortuned that some of tho ships that came over with
him. came in to Calays haue^ by their fre will / for the shypme^ ought more
favor to the earl of warwyk tha^ to the duke of Somerset / and in which
ships were take diverse me^ / as Ienyn Fynkyll Johan fellow Kaylles and
Purser / which were beheded soon after in Calays. and after this came me^
daily over ye see to these lords to calays / and began for to wexe stronger.
and they borrowed much good of the Staple / and on that other side the duke of
Somerset being in Gynes gate people to him which came out and scarmysshed
with them of Calays / and they of Calays with the which endured many days
^ucyng much people came over daily unto thise lords The^ on a time by thaduys
and cou^seylle of the lords at Calays sent over master Denham with a great
felyshyp to Sandwhyche / which took the town and therein the lord Ryuers and
the lord S^alys his sone / and took many ships in the haven / and brought
them all to calays with which ships many maryners of there fre will / came to
calays / to serve the Earl of warwyk. And after the Earl of warwyke by the
aduys of the lords. took all his ships and manned them well and saylled
himself in to Irlonde. for to speak with the duke of york / and took his
aduys how they should enter in to England. And when that he had be there and
done his erandes / he returned again toward Calays / and brought with him his
mother the countess of Salysbury. And coming in the west country on ye see
the duke of Excetre Admyral of England being in the grace of du. acco^panyed
with many ships of war met with ye earl of warwyk and his flete. but they
faught not for the substance of ye people being with the duke of Excetre.
ought better will and favor to ye earl of warwyk tha^ to him / and they
departed and came to calays in sauf^e. The^ the kings counsel seeing yt
these lords had gotten those ships fro Sandwytche. and taken the lord Ryuers
and his sone ordained a garyson at Sandwytche to abide and keep the town. and
made one mou^tforde captain of ye town / and that no man vytayll / ne
merchant. yt should go to flaunders / should go to calays. The^ they of calays
seyenge this made Denham / and many other to go to Sandwytche and assailed ye
town by land and by water and gate ix. And brought the Capytayne over see and
smote of his heed / And yet daylymen came over to them fro all parties.

How the Earl of March and of warwyke and of Salysbury entered in to England
and of ye feld of Northa^pto^ where diverse lords were slain.
ANd after this the foresaid earls of march warwyke and Salysbury came over to
Dover with much people and there londed to whom all the country drew and
came to London all armyd / and for to let lords of the kings counsel know
their truth and also their entente / assembled them. and told them / that
they intended no harm to ye kings person / sauf that they would put from him
such persons as were about him. And so departed from London with a great
puyssaunce toward Northampton / where the king was accompanied with many
lords / and made a strong field without the town / And there both parties
met. and was fought a great battle In which battle were slain the duke of
bokyngham and therle of Shrewesbury / ye vycou^t Beamonde / the lord Egremonde
/ and many other knights and squyres / and othere also / and the king himself
was taken in the field And after ward brought to London / And anon after was
a parliament at westminster. during which parlyament ye duke of york came out of
Irlonde. with the Earl of Rutlande. riding with a great felyshyp in to the
palace / and come in to the parlyament chamber and there took the kings place
/ and claymed the crown as his propre enherytaunce and right and Cast forth
in wryttynge his tytele. and also how he was ryghtfull heir / wherefore was
much to do / but in conclusyon yt was appointed / and concluded. that king
Henry should regne and be king / during his natural life For as much as he
had be king so long / and was possessyd and aft his death the duke of york
should be king / and his heyers kings after him \ and forth with should be
proclaimed heir apparau^t and should also be protector and regence of england
during ye kings life with many other things ordained in the same parliment
and if king Henry during his life / wence from this poyntement or any
article concludyd in the said paylyament he should be deposed / and the duke
should take the crown / and be king all which things were enacted by
thauctoryte of the same / at which parlyament the comyn^ of the reame being
assembled in the common hons / co^mynyng and treatyng upon the title of the
foresaid duke of york / suddenly feldone the crown. which henge then in the
mids of the said house which is the frayter of ye abbaye of westminster. which
was taken for a prodice or toke^. that the regne of king Henry was endyd And
also the crown which stood on the highest toure of the styple in the castle
of dover / fell down this same year.

How the duke of york was slain and of the field of wakefelde. and of the
second Iourneye at saint albo^s by ye quene^ and the prince.
Because the queen with the Prince her sone / was in the north and absent her
fro the king. and obeyed not such things concluded in the parliament / was
ordained that ye duke of york as protector / should go north ward to bring in
the queen / and subdue such as wolne not obey / with whom went the earl of
salysbury. Sir Thomas Neuyll his sone with much people / And at wakefelde in
Crystmas weke. they were overthrow and slain by lords of the queen's party
that is to wit / the duke of york was slain. the earl of Rotlonde sir Thomas
Neuyll. and many moo / and the Eerle of Salysbury was take and other^ As Johan
horowe of london capytayne and Ruler of the fotmen and Hau^son of hull which
were brought to pou^fret. and there be heeded / and there heedes sent to york
/ and set upon the yates / And thus was the noble prince slain / the duke
off york / on whose soul god have Mercy / and this time therle of March being
in Shorwesbury / herynge the death of his fader / desired aid of the town to
avenge his faders death / and frothens went to walys. and at Candelmasse after
he had a battayll at Martymers Cross. ayenste therle of Penbroke and of
wylshyre where the earl of march had the vyctorye / Then the queen with those
lords of the north after that they had dystressyd and slain the duke of york
and his felysshyp. came south ward with a great multitude of people / for too
come to the king and defecte such conclusyons as had be take before by the
parlyame^t / against whose coming the duke of Northfolke. ye earl of warwyeke.
with much people and ordinance / went to saint albons. and ladde king Henry
with them / and there encou^tred to gyder in such wise, and faught so that
the duke of Northfolke and Therle of werwyke / with many other of there party
^^edde and lost that Iourneye. where that king Henry was taken with the queen
and prince Edward his sone. which two had got on that field. The queen and
her party being at her above. se^te anon to London / which was on an Asshe
wenesdaye the first day of lent for vytayl. For which the Mayre ordained by
thaduys of the alderme^ ye certain carts lade with vytayll should be sent to
saint Albons to the^. and wha^ tho carts came to Crepell yate / ye comi^s of
the Cite that kept ye gate. took the vytayles fro the carts and would not
suffer it to pass. Then were there certain Alderme^ and comyns appointed too
goo unto bernet / to speak with ye queen's co^seyll to entreat you the northren
men should be sent home again / in to their contree. for the cite of London
drad to be dyspoyled if they had come. And during this treatise / tidings
came. that the earl of warwyk had met with the Earl of March on Cotteswolde
coming out of walys with a great menye of welssheme^ and that they both were
coming unto London ward / Anon as these tytynges were know. the tratyse was
broke for the king / Queen Prince / and the other lords that were with them
departed fro saint Albo^s north ward with all there people / yet or they departed
thens they beheeded that lord Bonuyll and Sir Thomas Kryell. which were taken
in the Journey done on shrewe toursdaye. Then the Duchess of york being at
london. herynge of the loss of the field of saint Albons. sent ouersee her
two young sons George and Richard / which went to Vtrech. and Phylyp
malpas a rich merchant of London Thomas vaghan Squyre. master wyllyam
Ha^clyf and many other / ferynge of the coming of the queen to London / took a
ship at Anwerpe to have gone in to zelande / and on that other cost / were
taken of one Colompne a Fransshman / a ship of werre. And he took them
prisoners and broughte^ them in to france / where they paid great good for
their raunson / and there was great good and richesse in that ship.

Of the deposinge of king Henry the sixte and how king Edward the fourth
took possessyo^* and of the battle on Palm sunday. and how he was crowned.
THen when the Earl of warwyke had wette to gader on Cot^yswolde / in
contynent they concludyd to go to london. and sent word anon te ye Mayre and
to the City that they would come / and anon ye city was glad of their
coming / hoping to be releuyd by the^ and so they came too / london / and
wha^ they were come and had spoke with the lords and estates being there.
concluded for as much as king Henry was gone with the^ north ward. that he
had forfeyted his crown and ought to be deposed according unto ye acts made
passyd in the last parliament And so by the aduys of ye lords spyrytuall and
te^porall / then being at london. the er of March Edward by the grace of
god / eldest sone of the duke Rychard of york. As ryghtfull heir. and next
enherytour to his fader the fourth day of March / the year of our Lord
god.M.CCCC.lix. took possessyon of the Reame / at westminster. in the church of the
abbaye and offered as a king with ye ceptre ryall. To whom all the lords
spyrytuall and temporal did homage. as to their souerayn lord and King And
forth with it was proclaimed through the Cite king Edward the fourth by name
/ and anon after the King rode in his ryalle estate north ward with all his
lords to subdue his subyectis that time being in the north. and for to
avenge his faders death. And on Palm sunday after he had a great bataylle in
the north country at a place called Towcon not fer from york / where with
the help of god he gate the field and had the vyctorye where were slain of
his adversaries.xxx. thousa^de me^ and moo as it was said by them that were
there^ In which battle was slain the Earl of North thumberlande. the lord
Cly^^orde sir Johan Neuyll the Earl of westmerlondes brother andrewe Trollop.
and many knights and squers Then King Henry that had be king ^ being with
the queen and the prince at york herynge the loss of that field. And so
much people slain and overthrow / anon forth with departed all three with
the duke of Somerset the lord Roos. and other toward Scotland And the next
day after king Edward with all his army entered in to york / and was there
proclaymyd king and obeyed as he ought too be. And the Mayre and comyns swore
to be his lyegemen. and when they had tarried a while in the north and that all
the north and that all the north country had turned to him he returned south
ward. leuynge behind him the earl of werwyk in tho parties to govern and
rule that country And about Mydsomer after / the year of our lord.M.cccc.lx.
and the first year of his regne he was crowned at westminster / and anointed ki^ge
of england having possessyo^ of al ye reame

CAlyxtus ye third was pope after Nycholas three year and v. months. this
Calyxte was an old man wha^ he was chose pope. and was co^tynually seek / ne
he might not fulfill his desire. which he ente^ded to do against ye turkys / for
death came upon him. and he was chose in ye year of our lord.M.cccc.lv. and he
deyed ye.vi. day and he made ye fyguracyo^. also he canonysed saint vi^ce^t /
a friar precher / and there was a great reformacyo^ of many monasteryes of ye
world / and those reformacyons were made many times. but all most none abode.
but ye returned again home. by successyo^ of time / after ye death of the
worshypfull faders^ ye feste of the Transfiguracyo^ was ordained of Calyxt for
ye yefte of grace of ye merueylous vyctory done against the Turk in Hu^gary on
saint Syxtus day.M.CCCC.lvii. For there was a merueylous vyctory give to ye
Cryste^ me^ in Hungary against the great Turk and there he lost many a man
and fled sha^fully for dread of enemies. and noman followed him / but alone ye
ho^de of god feryd ye Turk and his host on saint Calyxte day saint John^ de
Caprystrano was there seen present. and he provoked the people yt were aferde
to follow the mysbeleui^ge Turks and there fell a great ve^geau^ce on them for
the Turks said / yt there was so great a no^bre of knights that followed the^.
That uneath they durst look bacwarde. and therefore they fled. and left al
there tresour behind the^. and they were angels that caused them to flee.
Nota

PRynters of books were myghtely multyplyed in Maguncie. and thrughoute the
world and there began fyrste^ and there held their crafts. and this time
myny me^ began to be more subtle in crafts and swyterf tha^ ever they were
before

PIus the second was pope after Calyxt.vi. year. This pius was chose i^ ye
year of our lord.M.CCCC.lviii. and he was called Eneas an eloque^t man a great
orator a laureate poet. and in the counsel of Basyle he wrote a noble
tretyse for thattoryte of ye same This man desired to have a passage to the
Turk and much people of diverse countres came to Rome. and he yaue them his
blessing and sent them home aye^ for they were not sufficient for the Turks
host and anon after he decessyd.

POules a venetia^ was pope after Pyus vii. year. This poule was chose in the
ye year of our lord.M.cccc.lxiiii. And anon he hallowed ye feste of the
presentacyo^ of our lady. as pius did This man was a toughma^ in right wysnes
and he said it was bett to make few things. and make them steadfastly than for
to make many. and sone revoke the^. And he mad a great pallays at saint Markys
and he decessed or he had ended it in ye year of our lord M.cccc.lxxi. Leodin^
ye land of luke was oppressed with many trybulacyons. and after in the year of
our lord.M.cccc.lxviii. vterly it was distroyed by Carolu^ ye duke of
Bourgoyn. that which wedded dame Margarete sister to king Edward the forth
of England. Also the same karolu^ entered in the land of Gelder. and conquyred
it holy. The year of grace also was changed by pope Poule for favor of
ma^nys soul from.xxv. year to.xxv. year. And by case ye cursydnesse abou^ded
so sore. grea^e abou^ded also sore.

SIxtus the fourth a Johannes. and a friar minor was pope after paul. This man
was geneall in ye order of ye friar mynors or he was Cardynal. And he was
chose^ in ye year of our lord.M.cccc.lxxi. And was called Fra^ciscus de
Sanona. of good fame and vertuost He was chose^ Cardynall without his Knowledge
till he was made. and ye same year yt he was chose^ pope. The turk had taken
fro me criste^ me^ two empyres. and four kingdoms.xx. proui^ces. and two
hundred cytyes^ and had destroyed me^ and wymme^ without no^bre. And ye meuyd
the pope yt he should dyspose him to goo to wythstonde him. And for an army to
be made against the Turk ye pope gave great Indulgentes of pardon of ye tresori
of the cyrche unto all cryste^ reames. yt he might ordeyne some tresore. to
withstand ye mysbeleued Turk. And in the lord of England / John^ abbot of
Abyngdon was the popes legate. to dyspose this goodli tresoure. of ye church
to every feythful man. yt was disposed and that would able him to receive it.

Here ends this present Cronycle of England with the fruit of times.
compyled in A book. And also newely Enprynted in the year of our lord
god.M.CCCCC. and.xv. by me Iulyan Notary dwelling in powlys church yard
beside ye westedore by my lords palyes

Here follows a little treatise the which treats of the descripcion of this
lord which of old thyme was named Albion. And after Brytayne And now is
called England and speaks of ye noblesse and worthynesse of the same.



It is so that in many and diverse places the common Chronicles of England /
ben had and also now late Enprynted And for as much as the dyscrypcyon of
this land which of old time was named: Albion / and after Brytayne / Is not
descryued ne comynly had / ne ye nobleness and worthynesse of the same is
not known: Therefore I entende to set in this book the descrypcyon of this
said isle of Brytayne and with the commodytes of the same.

In the first shall be told the name of the ylonde. Capitulo primo. Of the
setting boundynge lenthe and bread. ca. ii. Of the worthynesse and
perogaciones. ca. iii. Of the merueyles and of the wondres. ca. iiii. Of the
chyef parties of the same londe^ Capitulo^ v. Of the ylondes that been thereto
adiacente. Capitulo. vi. Of the kings high ways and streets. ca: vii Of the
famous Ryuers and stremes. ca. viii. Of ancient cytees and towns. ca. ix. Of
prouynces and shyres. ca. x. Of the laws and names of the laws. ca: xi. Of
kyngdoms of bounds and marks between them. ca. xii. Of bysshopryches and
their sees. ca. xiii. Of how many manner people. have dwelled therein. ca.
xiiii. Of the langages of manners and usage of ye people of that land. ca. xv.
Of the land of wales. ca. xvi. Of the name and why it is named: walls
Capitulo.xvii. Of the commodytees of the land of wales. Capitulo.xviii. Of the
manners and rytes of the walsshme^. Capitulo.xix. Of ye meruaylles wonders of
wales. ca. xx. Of the discrypcyon of Scotlonde sometime named Albanya. ca. xxi.
Of the dyscrypcyon of Irlonde. ca. xxii. Of the boundynge of Irlonde ca. xxiii.
Of the gretnes and qua^tyte of that Land. Capitulo.xxiiii. Of the defautes of
the land. ca. xxv. Of them that first enhabyted Irlonde. Capitulo.xxvi. Of
the condycyons and manners of Iryssh men. ca xxvii. Of the meruaylles and
wonders of Irlonde. ca. xxviii. Of the meruaylles of saints of Irlonde.
Capitula.xxix. Explicit tabula.

The names of this ylonde. Ca. primo
First as Galfrydus says this land was called Albyne the oldeste daughter
of Dyoclesyan and had.xxxii. systers. And they were first enhabyted this
land. And because she was the oldest sister she named this land Albion after
her own name as ye Cronycle rether seth. Other say that this Land was named
Albion as it were the white land of white rocks about the clyues of the sea
that were sen fro far. After ward Brute conquered this land and called it
Brytayn after his own name. And then Saxons or Englysshmen conquerde this
land and caled yt Anglia that is England Or it is called Anglia of a queen
that owed this land / that was named Angla and was a noble dukes daughter of
the Saxons. Or as ysad scyth Ethy.xv. anglia has that name as it were an
angle and a corner of the world. Or else as Beda says lii.: Saint Gregory
saw English children to sell at Rome and he accorded to the name of the
land. And said they ben southely Angles / for her face chyned as angels / for
the noblyte of the land shone in the childrens faces. Alfre. The Bryteysshe
Anglia is called the other world / and for great plente of all good the
great Charles called in his own Chamber. Solinus The edge of Frensshee clyfe
should be the end of the world / if the ylonde of Brytayne ne were not /
which is worthy to have the name of an other world. Alfry this ylonde is
called insula for yt is in salo / that is the sea / And is beten of with
diverse course of waters with stremes and with wawes of the sea.

Of the setting boundynge lenthe and bread of this land.
THis Brytayne is accounted a noble land both in our stories and also in ye
stories of Greeks. and is set ayenste Germania. Gallia. France and Spain
between the north and the west and the sea between. This land is fyfty mile
from the clyf of the men that be called morini gessiorico. Bedali.i. And for
this ylonde lies under the north head of the world. And it has light and
bright nights in ye somer time. So that of tentyme at mydnyght men have
quastyons and doubt whether it be enyntyte or dawynge / yt is for the time of
ye year that the son goes not far under the earth by night but passes by
the north side and comes soon in to the eest again. And therefore in ye somer
ben their days full long of.xviii. hours and the nyghtes of.vi. hours. And
after in the winter ben long nyghtes of.xviii. hours and short days of.vi.
houres^ Also in Armenia. Macedonia. Italya and in other lands of the same line
the lengest day and lengest night also is of.xv. hours. and the shortest day
or night is of.^x. hours. Plinius in meroe. That ylonde is chyef of black men
/ there is ye lengest day.xii. hours. In Alexandre i^ Egypt of.xiii^ ours in
ytalya of.xv^ hours. In brytayne of.xviii^ hours. In the ylonde named Tyle
all the.vi somer months is day and all the.vi. winter months in night.
Isyd li.xiii. Brytayn is set within Occian as yt were without the world /
and is set against France and Spain. Giraldus. Brytayne in endlonge and
larger in the myddell than in the ends. Orosius. Brytayne stretches in lenth
out of the south in to the north and in the south est it has France / in the
south Spain the north / Nowaye. and in the west Hybernia / that Is yrlonde.
when shyppemen passen the next clyf of that land they se a cite that heet
Rupty mouth. Beda.li.i^ That cite is now called shortly of Englyshmen
Reptacestre / Solinus / Brytayne is.viii. hondreth mile of lenthe and it be
moten fro ye clyf of Totenesse to the angle of Colydon. Alfre That is from
penwith street.xv. mile be yonde Mychels stowe in Cornwayle unto catenesse that
is beyond Scotlo^de and brytayn is more tha^ ^ii.C. mile broad from Meneuia
that is ye vtermest place in wales unto yarmoth in nothfolke. Beda Only out
take the lengest out sherynge of diverse for lands with the which Brytayne is
all about.xlviii. sithe.lxx. thousand paas.

Of ye worthynesse and perogacions. ca. iii.
AS France passes Brytayne so Brytayne passes Irlonde in fair weder and
noblyte but not in health. Beda.li. For this ylonde is best. to bring fort
threes and fruit Rutherne and bestes And wine grows therein in some place.
The land has plente of fowls and of beestes of diverse manner of kind The
land is ple^teuous and the sea also. The land is noble copyous and rich of
noble wells and Ryuers with plente of fysthe. There is great ple^te of small
fysshe of samon and of eeles. wilhel. de. pon.li.iii. So yt the people in some
place feed their swyne with fysshe. Beda li.i. there ben of tentymes taken
Dolphyns. See calves / and Balayne great fysshes / as whales kind. And
diverse manner shelfysshe among the which / shelfysshe been muskles That
within them have Margery peerles of all manner of color and hew of rody and
read purpure and of blewe / and specially and most of white there with fine
read / the rednes there of is wonder fair \ and stable / and stayneth never
with c^ode ne with heet* with wete ne with dry but ever the older the color
is the fayrer ^ There ben also salt wells and hot wells / there of rennynge
stremes of hot bathes departed in to diverse places according. For man and
woman of all manner age old or young. Basilius says. That the water that
renneth and passes by veins of certain metal takes in his course great
hete. This ylonde is plenteuous of veins of metalles^ Bras of iron of leede of
tyn / and of silver also. Plinius li.vi. ca. vi. In this ylo^de under the curfe
of the land is found good merle the thryfty of the fatnes dries him self
therein / So that ever the thycker ye field in merled the better corn it will
bear / There is also a another manner white merle / that the lord is the better
fourscore year that therewith is merled. Solinus In this ylonde grows a stone
that is called Gagates / if ye will know his fayrnesse / it is black as
ge^mes ben / if ye will know his kind / It brenneth water and quenches in
oil and as to his might / if the stone befroted and chaffed It holds what
him negheth as succu^^ a stone yt is so named. ysydorus.li.xv. There was sheep
that beren good wule There ben many hertes and wild beestes and few wulues.
therefore sheep ben the surer without kekynge left in the field. R. In this
ylonde also ben many cytees and towns fair and noble and rich. many great
Ryuers and stremes with great plente of fyshe / many fair wodes and great.
with right many beestes tame and wild. The earth of that land is copyous of
metal oor / And of salt wells of quareyes of Marbyll of diverse manner
stones / of reed of white of soft and of hard / chalk and of white lyme.
There is also white claye and read for to make pottes. crockes / stenes / and
other vessel and brent tyle to cover the houses and chyrches as it were in the
other samya yt is named samos also. Flanddres loves well the wull of this
land. And hollande the skynnes and felles of all manner of beestes. Guyan the
iron and the leed. Irlonde the oor and the salt. Al Europe loves and desires
the whete metal of this land / Alfredus Brytayn has enough of matter that
there needs to bye and sell or is nedelull to man's use / there lacks
neither salt ne iron / Therefore a versefyour in his meter prayseth this land
in to this manner / England is a good land fruytfull of wu^. but it is a
corner England is full of play free men well worthy to play / fre men / free
tongues. free hertes / and free ben all their things. their hand is more free.
and better than their tongue. Also England is beauteous of land flower of
lands all about / that land is full payede with fruit and good of his own.
that land reueleth strange men that has need thereto / And when honger
greueth other loondes that land fedeth them. That land bears fruit and
corn great plente enough / That land is well at ease as long as men live in
peace eeste and west in each land ben known well the hauenes of England / Her
ships foundes and often helps many lands Their mete and money men hather
more common always And for to learn men gladly give gyftos / In land and strong
wide speak men of England. Land honey milk these this ylonde thereof shall
bear the price. This ylonde has no need of other lands. all londos must seek
help at this alone / Of the liking of their woun / might wonder king Salomo^
The riches that there is an. would desire octauyan /

Of the meruayles and wondered ca. iiii.
IN Brytayne ben hot wells well arrayed and adressed to the use of manhood /
masters of thylke wells is the great spyrite minerua In her house the fire
endures always that never changes into asshen / but there the fire slaketh.
it changes into stone clothes^ Alfre. In Brytayn ben many wondres Nevertheless
four ben most wonderful / the first is at Peton there blows so strong
wind out of the chynes of the earth yt it casts up again ^lothes that me^
cast therein. The second is at Stonhenge besides Salesbury there ben great
stones and wonder huge. and ben teten on high as it were yates set upon
other yates Nevertheless it is not konwen clearly ne apperceyued how and
wherefore they be^ so arered and so wonderful honged. The third is at
Cherdboke there is a great holownes under the earth often many me^ have seen^
Ryuers and stremes But no where can they find none end The fourth is that
rayn is seen raised upon hills and none yspronge about in the feldes. Also
there is a great pound that contained.lx. ylondes couenable for men to dwell
in that ponde is beclypped about with syx score Roches and upon every roche an
egles neste and th^e score Ryuers rennen into that ponde. And none of them all
run into the sea but one / There is a ponde closed about with wall of tyle
and of stone. In that ponde men wasshe and bathe right often. and every man
feleth the water hoote or cold right as he will him self. There be^ salt
wells far from the sea and been salt all the weke long unto saterdaye at
none unto monday The water of these wells when it is soden torneth into small
salt fair and white Aso there is a ponde the water there of has wonder
werkynge. For though all an hooste stood by the ponde and turned their face
thither ward the water would draw him vyole^tly toward the ponde and wete
all their clothes / So should horse be drawn in the same wise. And if the
facebe turned a way fro the water the water noyeth not. There is a well that
no streme renneth fro ne neither thereto and yet four manner of fysshe be taken
there in. ye well is but xx. foot long and xx. foot broad And bears no
great depte but to the knee / And closes with high banks on every side. In
the country about wynchestre is a den or a cave / out of ye cave blows al
way a strong wind / so that no man may endure to stand to fore yt. den or
cave. There also is a ponde yt torneth tree in to iron if it be there in a year.
And so trees ben shapen in to whestones. Also there is in the top of an
hylle buryels every man that comes and meteth that buryell / he shall find it
even of his own lenth and mesure^ And if a pilgrim knele thereto anonr he
shall be all fresshe and feel no gryef of werynes. Git in^ top. Fast be the
mynstre of wynburney that is not far fro bathe is a wood that bears much
fruit / if the trees of that wood fall in to water or ground yt is nyghe and
lie there all a year. the trees tornen i^ to stones. Giritenere. Under the Cite
of Chestre renneth ye Ryuet Dee^ now departs England and wales. That River
changed every month his lords as men of the country tellen and leueth often
the channel / but whether the water draw more to ward England or to ward
wales to what side yt it be. that year men of yt side have the worst end and
over set. And men of ye other side shall have better end and be at their
above when the water so changes his course yt bodeth such happes. This River
Dee renneth and comes out of a lake yt heet. Pymblemere. in this River is
great plente of samon / nevertheless in the lake is never samon founden. will
held re le ii. Take heed how great light and bryghtnesse has been showed upon
Englysshme^ sithe they first turned to right believe. So that of no men in any
prouynce ben founden so many hole bodies of men after her death in sykenes of
euerlastyngnes yt shall be after the day of dome / as it well seems in these
holy Saints as Edeldrede / Edmonde / the king Elphege: Edgar Cutberde and
saint Edward and many other I trow yt it bedoo by a special grace of god
almighty for ye nacyon that is set as it were without the world take heed to
burye^ge of bodies without corrupcyo^ and rotynge / and ben the more bold and
steadfast for to trust on the fynall arysynge of deed dodyes for to last
evermore after the day of dome.

Of the chyef parties of ye same land. ca. v.
AFter the first Brutes time the ylonde of Brytayne began for to have the
pryncypall parties / that been Loegria Cambria that is that wales. And Albania
yt is now Scotlonde Loegria has that name of Locrinus that was Brutes oldest
sone / and heet / loegria as it were. Locrinus land / but now Loegrin is
called England. The bounds and Marks were there of sometime the Frensshe see
boothe by eest and by southe. Beda.li.i. ca. ii. And by north two arms of the sea that breketh far in to the land either against other But they reche not
together / The eest arm of thylke tweyne begins about a two little mile fro
the mynstre of Ebburcurynge. In the weste side of Penulton in that arm is a
town / that is called Guydy. the west arm of thylke tweyne has in the right
side a strong Cite that heet Alclyued which in their la^gage is called Clint
stone and stondeth upon a river yt is called Clynt also. R. Some men would mean
that Loegria ends at Humbre and stretches no ferther north ward. The
second party of Brytayne is caleo Albinia that is Scotlonde and has that
name of Albinactus Brutes sone and stretches fro the foresaid two arms of the sea north ward unto these of Norwaye. Nevertheless the south parties of
Albania where as pyetes dwelled sometime that lies from the water of twede
unto the Scottesshe see. All yt longed sometime to the kyngedome of
Northumberlonde Brenycorne the north sade of Northumberlonde fro the first time
of English king to that time when Kynadius king of Scotlonde that was
Alpinus sone did a way the Pyctes and so Joined that country to the kingdom of
Scotlonde. The^ third party of Brytayne is wales walia that heet Cambria also
/ and has that name Cambria of Cambre Brutes sone / for he was prince of
wales. In the eest side Seurnee departed some time between England and wales.
But in the north side the River of Dee atchestre and in the southe ye River
that is named Vaga at ye castle of Srygelyn departs England and wales. All
so king Offa for to have a dystynccyon for evermore between the kings of
England and of wales made a long dyche that dretched for the out of the
southe side by Brystowe under the hills of wales Seuerne and Dee almost to
the heedes and unto the mouth of the River of Dee beyond Chestre fast by the
castle it reenneth between Colehyll and the mynstre of Basyngwercke into the sea. This dytthe is yet in many places seen In saint Edwardes time walsshmen
should not pass that was at Earl Haroldes procuring as it shall be said
here after. but now in either sides both ayonde half and a this half the dyche
and specially in the shyres of Chestre of Shrowesbury and of Herforde in many
places been Englysshemen and walsshmen meddled togyders.

Of the ylondes that been thereto adjacent. Capitulo. vi.
BRytayne has three ylondes that been night and longing thereto all without the
ylondes Orcades / as it were answering to the three chyef partys of Brytayne.
For the isle of wyghte longs and lies to Leogrya that is England. The ylonde
Mon that is called Angleseya also longs to wales / and the ylonde Enbonia
that has two other names and is called Meneuia and Man also which longs to
Scotlonde. And all these three ylondes wight Mon and Man ben almoost alyke much
and the quantyte / of the which three all arowe follows our speech. Beda.li.i.
ca. iii^ Claudius sent Vespasianus. and Vespasianus wa^ne wight / And wight
stretches out of the eest in to ye west.xxx. mile long. And out of the south
in to the north.xii. mile / and is in the eest side.vi. mile fro the south
clyfe of Brytayne. And three mile fro the west side. Beda.li.iiii ca. v. The
mesure of this ylonde as Englysshmen guess is a thousand heusholders and two
hundred. Gir. in itinere. mon that is called. Angleseya also his departed from
north wales by a short arm of the sea as it were two mile broad. In Mon ben
three hundred towns.lx.iii. And ben accounted for Ca^dredes that been.iii.
hondredes. The ylonde is as it were.xxx. my^e long and.xii. mile broad
Candredus is so much land as conteyneth an hundred towns / that name
candredus is made out of two langages of Brytysshe and of Irysshe In praysynge
of this ylonde walsshmen were wont to say a proverb and an old saw. Mon
Mankembri / that is to say in English that land is so good that it seems
that it would find corn enough for all the men of wales. Therefore Virglys
verses may be according thereto / as much as guawes / bestes long Inneth
dawes So much efte brings cold dew in a night In that arm of the sea
that departed this land and north wales / is a swolowe that that draws
ships to it that sayleth by and swoloweth them in ryyght as does. Cylla and
Carybdis that been two peryllous places in the sea of myddel earth. Therefore men
may not sayll by this swalowe but slyly at full see. R. Of the merueylles and
wondres of the ylonde of Mon thou shall find in the chapter of wales. Gir. in
itinere. The third ylonde that is called both Eubonia and Meneuia that is
Manstondeth in the myddell between the Irysshe vlstere and the Scottesshe galle
way as it were in the navel of the sea. Beda.iiii. ca. ix. This ylondes. The
first is southe ward the more condtree. And the better corn land and
conteyneth.ix. hundred and.^x. housholdes^ The secon^e conteyneth the space
of.CCC. and moo as Englysshmen guess. Gir. in ^op: Sometime was stryf whether
this ylonde Man should long to Brytayne or to Irlonde and for as much as
venomous worms that were brought thither ly^ed there / It was Iuged that the
ylonde of Man should long to Brytayne. R. In that ylonde is ^ortylege and
which craft used. Fer women there selle to shypme^ wind as it were closed
under three knottes of threde. So that more wind he will have the moo knottes
he must undo. Chere often by day time men of that land seen men that be^
deed to fore hand byheded or hoole and what death they deyed. Alyens set
their fete upon feeet of the men of that land for to see such syghtes as the
men of that land done. Beda.li.ii. Scotts dwelled first in this ylonde
Thanatos that is Tenet and is an ylonde besides Kente o and has that name
Thanatos of death of serpe^tes for there be^ none. And ye earth thereof sleeth
serpe^tes yborn in other lo^des. There is noble corn lord and fruyt^u^. It is
supposed that this ylonde was hallowed and blessed of saint Austen the first
doctoure of Englysshmen for there he arrived fryste.

Of the kenges hye ways and streets. ca. vii.
MOlyuncyus king of Brytons^ was the / xiii. of them and the first that ga^
them law. He ordained that plowmen folowes / goods laws and high ways
that let den men to Cytees and towns should have the fredom of color so yt
every man that went to any of them for socour or for trespaas that he has
should be saufe for poursute of all his enemies. But afterward for the ways
were uncertain and stryf was had^ Therefore Belinus the king that was the
forfayd Moliuncius sone for to put a way all strife and doubt / made four
high kings ways preuyleged with all preueylege and fredome And the ways
stretche thrughe the ylonde. The first and gretest of all the four ways is
called Fosse and stretches out of the south in to the north and begins
from the corner of Cornewayle and passes forth by Deuenshyre by Somersete
and forth be sides Tetbury upon Cotteswolde beside Couentre unto Leycestre /
and so forth by wild playnes toward Newarke and ends at Lyncoln. The
second chyfe kings high way is named watlyngstrete and stretches thwarte
over Fosse out of the southeest in to ye norwest and begins at Dover and
passes by the myddell of Kente over Temse beside London by westmestre and so
forth by saint Albon in the west side by donstaple by Scratforde by Towcetre
by wedo^ by southe Lylleborn by Atheryston unto gylbertes hylle that now is
called wrekene and forth by Seuarne and passes besides wrokcestre / and
then^e forth to Stratton and so forth ay the myddell of wales unto Cardyka^
and ends at Irysshe see. The third way is called Erynnugestrete and
stretches out of the west nor weste in to the eest southeest / and begins
in Meneuia that is saint Dauyds land in west wales and stretches forth unto
Southampton: The fourth is called. Rykenylstrete and stretches forth by
worochestre by wycombe and by Brymyngeham by Lechefelde by Derby by
Chestrefelde by york and forth unto Tynmouthe.

Of the famous Ryuers and stremes. ca. viii.
THere ben three famous Ryuers renayn^e through Brytayne by ye which three
Ryuers merchants of beyond ye see coumen in ships into Brytayn wellnygh
out of all manner of nacyons and lo^des. These three Ryuers ben Temse. Seuarne
and Humbre The sea ebbeth and flows at these three Ryuers and departs the
prouynces of the ylonde as it were the three kyngdoms asondre. The three parties
ben Loegria. Cambria / and Northumbri^ That been myddel England: wales. and
Northumberlonde. R. These name Temse seems made one name of two names of two
ryuers that been Tame and yse for the River of T^me renneth besides Dorchestre
and falls in yse / therefore all the River fro the first heed unto the eest
see is named Tamyse or Temse begins besides Tetbury that is three mile by
north Malmesbury. There the Temse spryngeth of a well that renneth eest ward
and passes the Fosse and departs Glocestre shyre and wylshyre / and draws
with him many other wells and stremes and wexeth great at grecestre and
passes forth than toward Hampto^ and so forth by Oxenforde by wallynforde by
Riding and by London. Wilhelmus de pon. ca. ii. At haven of Sandwhyche it
fas^eth in to ye eest see / and holds his name.xl. mile beyond London / and
departs in some place Kente and Essex westsex and Mercia that is as it were a
great dele of myddell England. R. Seuarne is A River of Brytayne and is called
Habern in brytons / and has that name Habern of Habern that was Estryldes
daughter Guendolon the queen drenched this Habern therein / therefore the Brytons
called the River Habern after the woman that was drowned therein / by corrupt
latin it is called Sabria Seuarne in English. Seuarne begins in the
myddell of wales and passes first to ward the eest unto Shrowesbury / and
then^e turned south ward unto Bryggenorthe wyrcestre and Gloucestre and
falls in to the west see besides Brystow and departs i^ some place England
and wales. wilhel de pon.li.iii. Sauerne is swyft of streme / fysshe carft is
therein / wodenes of the swolowyng and of ye whyrlynge water casts up and
gadre to hepe great hepes of grauel Seuarne often aryseth and ouerfloweth the
ba^kes R: Hu^bre has ye name of Hu^bre king of. hunes. for he was drownde there
in. and ren^eth first a croke out of ye southsyde of york / and then it
departed ye prouynce of Lyndese ye ye longed sometime to ye merces from ye other
contre northu^berlonde Trente and Ous rennen in to Hu^bre and make^ the River
full grete^ Treuisa The merces were men as.ii. were of myddell England as it
shall be said here after.

Of ancient cytees and towns. ca. ix.
THe kingdom of Brytayne was sometime made fair with.xxviii. noble cytees
without right many castles that were walled with toures with yates and with
bars strongely builded. After these were the names of the cyteis. Caerlud
that is London Caerbra^k that is york / Caerkent that is Caunterbury
Taergoraukon that is worchestre. Caerlyryon that is / leycestre. Caerclon that
is Gloucestre Caercolde^ that is Colcestre Carray that is / chichestre. Saxons
called it sometime Cyssoncestre: carcery that is Cyrcerre / caergunt that is
wynchestre. Caergraunt that is / cambrygge caerleyll that is / lugibalia and
Karlylle. Caerporis that is Porchestre. caerdrom that is Dorchestre.
Caerludcoyt that is / lyncoln and. Lyndecolyn. Caermarthyn that is Merlyns Cite
/ cersege^t that is Sicestre and his upon te^se not fer from redynge leon that
is / caerlegeon also and hyghte first Legecestre and now is named Chestre
Caerbathon that is bathe. and hight sometime Athamanus Cite Caerpaladour that is
Septon that now hight Shaftesbury. R. Other cytees ben found in Chronicles for
understanding of stories / of whom it shall follow. Will de pon. London is a
ryal and a rich Cite upon. Tamyse. of burgeysses of riches of merchants of
cha^^are and of marchaundyse. Therefore it is that some time when derth of
vytayls is in all England comuly at London it is best chepe because of the
buyers and selles that been at London. Gaufre Brute the first kyynge of Brytons
build and edefyted this cite of London the first cite of London the fyryste
cite in remembrance of the cite of Troy that was distroyed and called it
Troy newich and triuantum that is new Troy After ward king Lud called it
Caerlud after his own name. Therefore the Brytons had indygnacyon as Gyldas /
tells Afterward Englysshemen called the cite London / and yet after ye
Normans called it Londers and is named in latin lo^donia Rudhudybras king /
leyles sone. was the.viii. king of Brytons / and he builded Canterbury ye
chyefeyte of Kent called it Caerkent. Afterward Englysshemen called it
Dorobernia / but yt is not Dover that stondeth upon ye clyf of ye Frensshe see
and from shis dover.xxii. English mile. After ward this Dorobernia was and
is called Caunterbury. The same king. Rudhudibrys builded wynchestre. and
called it Caergue^t and after Englysshme^ called it went and wynchestre after
ye name of one an English man that was bishop there All westsaxo^ was subget
to him ye same king builded paladour that is Septo^ that now is called
Shaftesbury Brytons telle^ that an Egle prophesied there sometime. Bladud.
Leyles sone a Nygramancer was the.ix. king of Bryto^s / he builded Bathe and
called it Caerbathon. Englyssmen called it after Athamannus cite. But at the
last men called it Bathonia that is Bath. Wilhell. depon.li.ii. in this cite
welleth up and spryngeth hot Bathes and me^ wene that Julius Cezar made there
such bathes. R. But Gaufre ^ monute^sis i^ his Brytons book / says that
Bladud made thylke bathes because wyllyam has not seen that brytysshe book
wrote so by telli^ge of other me^ / or by his own gessynge as he wrote other
things not best auysedly. Therefore it seems more sothely that Bladud made not
