ye hot bathes Ne Julius Cezar did such a deed though bladud builded and made
the Cite. but it accords better to kyndely reason that ye water re^ne the in
ye earth by veins of brymstone and sulphur and so it is kyndely made hoot in
that course and spryngeth up in diverse places of ye cite. And so there be^
hoote bathes that wassheth of ^e^es soores skabbes / Treuisa. Though men might
by craft make hoote bathe for to endure long enough / this accords well to
reason and to philosophy that treats of hot wells and bathes that be^ in
diverse lo^des though ye water of this bathe be more trobly and soruer of
savor and of smell tha^ other hot bathes been that I have seen at Akon in
Almayne. And eyges in Sauoye / which ben fair and clear as any well streme I
have be^ bathed therein and assayed them. R. Claudius / cezar married his
daughter to Aruiragus king of Brytons. This Claudyus Cezar builded Gloucestre
in the wedding of his doughter^ Brytons called this cite frist after Claudius
name but afterward it was called Gloucestre after one gloria which was duke
of ye country and stondeth upon Seuarne in the march of England and wales.
Shrowesbury a cite upon Sauarne in the march of England and wales set upon
the top of an hylle / and it is called / Shrowesburye of shrobbes and fruit
that grew there sometime on ye hylle / Brytons called it sometime Pengre wene yt
is ye head of a fair tree Shrowesbury was sometime the head of powesye ^
stretches forth thwarde over ye mydell of wales unto ye Irysshe see Notyngam
stondeth upon Trence and sometime heet Notyngham yt is the won^ynge of den^es /
for ye Danes dwelled there sometime and dygged dens and caves under hard
stones and rokes and dwelled there. R. Lyncolyn is cheyf of the prouynce of
Lyndeseye and was called sometime Caerlud coit and after ward Lyndecoln. It is
uncertain who builded first this cite but if yt were king Lud / and so it
seems by menynge of the name / for the Caer is brytysshe and is to say a cite
and a coit is a wood and so it seems ye Caerlud coit is to say Luddes wode
town King leyr^ was Bladuddes son and builded Leybestre / as it were in ye
myddell of England upon the River Sos and upon Fosse the kings bye wyye.

wylhel. de pon.li.iii.
York is a street cite in either side of the water of Ouse yt seemed as fair as
Rome unto ye tgme yt the king wy^liam had with bre^nynge and fire defoulde it
and ye coo^tre about. So yt a pilgrim would now weep and h^ saw it / if he
had known it tofore. Gaufre. Ebraneus ye.v. king of brytons builded york and
called it after his own name Caerbranck he baylded also two other cytees one
in scotlond and is called Edinburgh and an other toward Scotlond in thend of
England and called Edinburgh / and an other toward Scotlond in thend of
England and is called Alcliud. R. Edenburth is a cytee in ye land of Pictes
between ye River of Twede and the scottesshe see and hee^ sometime the castle
of Maidens and was called afterward Edinburgh of Edan king of Pictes ye reigned
there in eg^ridus time king of Northu^ber^ond. Alcliud was sometime a noble cite
/ and is now well nygh unknow to all Englysshmen. for under ye Brytons and
pyctes and Englysshmen it was a noble cite to ye coming of ye Danes. But after
ward about the year of our lord ^viii.c.lxx. it was destroyed when ye danes
destryed ye countries of Northu^berlo^d. but i^ what place of Brytayn ye cite
Alcliud was builded. Ductours telle^ dyuersely Beda.li.i. says yt it was
builded by west ye arm of ye see yt departed between the Bryto^s and the
Pyctes sometime there Souerus ^amous wall ends westward / and so it seems by
him that it is not fer from Caerleyl for ye cite is set at ye end of that
wall. Other writers of stories written yt the cite of Alcliud is ye cite that
now is caled Alo^burgh / yt is to say an old town / and stands upon ye
River Ous not fer fro barghbrydge / yt is.xv. mile westward out of york / and
it seems yt he preueth that by Gaufride in his book of deeds of Brytons / he
writes yt Elidurus king of bryto^s was lodged at ye cite Alcliud because of
solace and hu^tynge / and found his brode^ Argalon maskynge in a wode nygh
there beside that hight Calatery / but that wood Calatery which is caltres i^
english recheth almost to york and stretches toward ye north by Aldburgh
in length by space of.xx. mile / ye most dele of that wode is now drawn down
and ye lord ytylled other me^ would suppose that Alcliud was ye cite that now
is called Burgham in the north country of westmerlonde fast by Comberlond / and
stadeth upon the River Eden / the cite is there wonderly seen. Deem ye now
where it is builded. Treuysa. It is not hard to assoyle if men take heed / ye
many towns bear one name / as Cartage / in Africa and Cartago in spayn. new

other i^ westmerlonde / and one fast by ye right side of ye west arm of the sea yt departs England and Scotlonde / but ye Alcliud was a right strong
cite as Beda says. and ye cite stands fast by a River yt is called Cliud.
and there is no such River i^ yorkshyre in westmer land as of the country tell
me. Some men say yt the River Cliud is now named sulwach. Sulwa^che is but.v.

what this writtinge is to say I doubt somewhat but if it were some of the

/ But it seems better yt it is written in mind of Marius king of brytons that
was Aruiragus sone / This marius overcome in that place Roderyke king of
pyctes So says Gaufre in his brytysshe book / Wyllyam malmesbury saw never
that book At Hagustaldes church is a place.lxxx. mile / out of york Nor

That place longed sometime to the bysshopryche of york / there were sometime

There is dyfference between the pryuynce of Lyndeffare and the church

up ward about that two mile is a ryall Cite upon the brynke of twede / that

caeruske / also there the River of Vske falyeth into Seuerne fast by glamorgan
Bellynus king of Brytons sometime buyled the city and was sometime the chyef
cite of Demecya in south wales. Afterward in Claudius cezar^ time it was
called the cite Legyons when at prayer of Genius the queen Vespiciauus and
Aruiragus were accorded and / legyons of Rome were sent in to Irlonde. tho was
Caerleon a noble cite and a great auctoryte / and by the Romans ryally builded
and walled about with walls of brent tyle. Great nobley that was there in
old time is there yet in many places seen as the great palayses gyauntes
toures noble bathes / releef of the temples places high and ryall to stand
and syte in / and to behold about the places were ryally closed with ryall
walls that yet somdele stondeth right nyghe cloos / And within the walls and
without is great building under earth / water conduytes and ways under earth
and stews Also thou shall see wonderly made. with strayte side ways of
brethynge that wonderly cast up heete. In this City were sometime three noble
chyrches. one was of saint Julius the martyr and therein a great company of
vyrgynes that other was of saint Aaron that was of the order of black Chanon
that church was right nobly adourned / The third church was the chyf mother
church of all wales and the chyef se. But afterward the chyef see was turned
out of the cite into meneuya that is saint Dauyds land in west wales. In this
Caerleon was amphybalus born thaught saint Albon There the messagers of Rome
come to great Arthurs court. if it is leefull to trow. Treuisa. if Giraldus
was in doubt whether it were leefull for to trow or not ^ yt were a wonder
showing as men would went for too have evermore in mind and ever be in
doubt if all his books were such what lord were therein and namely while he
makes none euydence for in neither side he tells what meueth him so to R.
There is another cite of Legyons there his Chronicles were by trauaylled as it
is clerly known by the first chapter of this book Treuysa. That is to
understanding in ye latin wryttynge. For he yt made it in latin turned it not
into English ne it was turned into Englisshe in the same place yt it was
first in latyn^ The understanding of him yt made this Chronicles is thus the
begnnyng of this book. Presentem cronicam compliauit frater Ranulphus
Cestre^sis monachus. That is to say in English. Brother Ranuiphe monk of
Chestre conpyled and made this Book of the Chronicles / R. The of Legyons that
is chestre stondeth in ye march of England toward wales between two arms of
the sea yt been namedde and Mersee \ This City in time of Brytons was heed and
cheyf cite of all Venedocia / that is North wales The fou^der of this cite is
vnknowen^ For who that sees the fou^dementes of the great stones would rather
wene that it were Romans work or wercke off Gyauntes / than it were set by
werkynge of Brytons. This cite sometime in brytysshe speech heet Caerthleon
Legecestria in latin And Chestre in Englisshe and the cite of Legyons also /
Forther delay a winter the legyons of knyghten that Julius Cezar sent for to win Irlonde. And after Claudius cezar sent legyons out of that cite for to win the ylonde that be called Orcades / what ever wyllyam Malmeshury by
telling of other men mente of this cite. This cite has plente of lyuelode of
corn of flesh of fysshe / and specially of price of samon / This city
receives much marchaundyse and sends out also. Also nyghe this cite ben
salt wells. metell and oor / Nor thumbres dystroyed this cite sometime / But
after ward Elfleda lady of Marcia builded it again and made it much more. In
this same cite ben ways under the earth with vowtes and stone work wonderly
ywrought. there chabre works / great stones ygrauen with old mennys names there
in / There is also Julius Cezar name wonderly in stones ygraue / and other
men's also with the wryteynge about This is the cite that Edelfryde king of
northumberlonde. distroyed / and slew there fast by nyghe two thusande monks
of the mynst of Bangor / This is the cite that king Edgar come theder sometime
with.vii. kings that were subgette to him / Ametre breketh out in this manner
in praysynge this cite / Chestre castle town as it were. name takes of a
castle It is known what man bylded this cite new Tho Lengecestria these heet
now town of legyones Now walsshe and Englisshe hold this Cite of great
price / stones on wall. seems work Hercules al. There long with might
todure that hepe is a hight. Saxon small stones / set upon great ben attones.
There under ground. lotynge double voute is fond / that helps with sondes.
many men of western lo^des / Fysshe flesh and corn low. This city town
has yonwe Ships and chaffare. see water brings ynowe there. Godestall
there is that was emperourer this. And forth Henry king / Earth is there right
dwelling / Off king Haralde. poudre is there yet halde / Bachus and
marcurious. Mers and venus also Lauerna Protheus and plura. regnen therein the
town. Treuysa. God wot what this is to mean / dut poets in their manner
speech faynen as though every kind craft and living had diverse god eueryche
from other / And so they feigned a god of bataylle and of fyghtyng called him
Mars and a god of couetyse and richesse and marchaundyse and called him
mercurius / And so Bachus is called god of wine Venus goddess of love and
beauty. Lauerna god of theft and of robberyf Protheus god of falshede and of
gyle and Pluto god of hell. and so it seems that these verses would mean
that these foresaid gods regne and been served in Chestre / Mars with
fighting and tockynge / Marcurius with couetyse and richesse / Bachus with
great drinking. Venus with love lewdly. Lauerna with theft and robbery
Procheus with falshede and gyle. Then is pluto not unserved that is god of
hell. R. There babylon lore more might has troth the more /

Of prouynces and shyres ca. x.
Take heed ye england contained xxxii. shyres and provinces yt now be^ called
Erldoms reserved Cernewale and the ylo^de Alfre. these be^ ye names of ye
erldoms and shyres. Kente sothsex. sothery. ha^pshyre barkshyre yt has his
name of a bare oak yt is in ye foreste of wyndesore forther wont they to take
their cou^seyl. Also wylshyre yt heet sometime ye province of semeran somerset.
dorset. deynshyre yt now is called Deuonia in latin / These ix: Sourhshyres
the Tamyse departed foam the other deal of England which were some time
governed and ruled by the westsaxons law Eestsex Meddelsex Soulfolke
Northfolke Herdforthe shyre Huntyngdon shyre Beddeforsh shyre Bokyngham shyre.
Leycestre shyre Derby shyre Notyngham shyre Lyncolnshyre york shyre Durham
shyre Northumberlonde Ca^rleyll shyre with Cumberlonde Appelby shyre with
westmerlonde Lancastre shyre / that conteyenth five little shyres. These
fyftene North and Eest shyres were sometime governed and ruled by the law
called Mercia in latin and marchene in English It is to wit that york shyre
stretches from the River of Humbre unto the River of Teyse / And yet in york
shyre ben.xxii. hondredis. hundred and candredes is all one. Candrede is one
word made of walsshe and Irysshe / and is to menynge a country that
conteyneth an hundred towns And also in English called wepentake. For
sometime in the coming of a new lord tenauntes were wont to yield up their
wepen instede of homage. Duram shyre stretches from the River of Teyse unto
the River of Tyne. And for to speak proprely of Northumberlonde it stretches
fro the River of Tyne unto you River of Twede. That is in the beginning of
Scotlonde. Then if the country of Northumberlonde that was sometime from
Humbre unto Twede be now a counted for one ^hyre and one Erledome as it was
sometime. Then^e ben in England but.xxxii. shyres. but if the country of
Northumberlond be the departed in to.vi. shyres that been Euerwykshyre
Duramshyre Northumberlond Caerleylshyre Anpelbyshyre Lancastre shyre^ Then in
England but.xxxvi. shyres without cornewale and also without ylondes. King
wyllyam made all these prouynces and shyres to be dyscryued and moten. Then
were founden.xxxvi shyres and half a shyre Twones two and fyfty thousand and
four score Parysshe chyrches.xlv. thousand and two Knights fees.lxxv.
thousand / whereof men of relygyon have.xxvii. thousand and xv: knights fees.
But now the woods ben hewn down and the land new tylled and made much
more than was at that time and many towns and vyllages builded and so there ben
many mo vyllages and towns now than were in that time. And were as a fore is
written that Cornewale is not set among the shyres of England it may stand
among the^ well enough for it is nether in wales ne in scotlonde bute it is in
England and it Joins unto Deuenshyre / and so many there ben accounted in
England.xxxvii^ shyres and an half with the other shyres.

De legibus legu^que vocabilis:
DVnwallo that hyghte Molliuncius also made first laws in Brytayne the which
laws were called Moleuncius laws and were solempnely observed unto wyllyam
Conquerours time. Moliuncius ordained among his laws that Cytees Temples and
ways that leden men thereto / and plowe men solowes should have preuelege and
fredome for to save all men that fle thereto for socoure and refuge. Then
afterwade Mercia queen of Brytons that was Gwytelynus wife of her ye prouynce
had the name of Mercia as some man suppose. She made a law fulle of wit
and of reason / and was called Merchene law. Gildas that wrote the Chronicles
and hystores. of the Brytons turned these two laws out of Bryton speech in to
latin. And afterward king Aluredus turned all out of latin in to Saxons
speech / and was called marchene law also the king Aluredus wrote in
English and put to an other law that hight westsaxon law Then afterward
Danes were lords in this land / and so came forth the third law that heet
Dane law. Of these three laws saint Edward the third made one commune law
yt yet is called saint Edwardes law. I hold it well done to write here and
expowne. many terms of these laws Myndebrugh hurtynge of honor and worship.
I french bleschurd ho^nour. burbruck in French bleschurde cour^ou de cloys
Grichbruche brekyng of peace / Myskennynge chaungynge of speech in court.
Showing setting forth of marchaundyse. Hamsokne or Ha^fare a rere made i^
house Forstallynge wrong or bette down in ye kings high way Fritsoken surete
in defense. Sak Forfayte Soka suit of court and thereof comes soken. Theme Suit
of bondemen fighting wit Amersemente fighting. blodewytte A Mersemente for
shedynge of blood Flytwytte Amends for ^hydynge of blood Leyrwytte Amends
for lyenge (...) by a bound woman Gultwytte Amends / for trespass Scot a
gadry^ge to work of bayllyes. Hydage tayllage for hydes of land. danegheld
tayllage given to ye danes that was of every bona taterre That is every ox
land three pens A wepyntake and an hundred is all one for the country of
towns were wont to give up wepyn in the coming of a lord Lestage custom
chale^ged in chepynges fares and stallage / custom for standing in streets in
fair time.

Of kingdoms of bounds and marks between them. ca. xii.
THe kingdom of Brytayne stood without departing hoole and all one kingdom
to the Brytous from the first Brute unto Julius Cezars time / and fro Julius
Cezars time unto seuerus time this land was under trybute to the Romans.
Nevertheless kings they had of the same land from Seuerus unto the last
prince Gracyan successors of Brytayne failed and Romans reigned in Brytayne
Afterward the Romans left of their regnynge in Brytayne by cause it was
far from Rome / and for great business that they had in other side /
Then^e Scotts and Py^tes by mysledynge of Maximus the tyraunte pursewed
Brytayne and warred there with great strength of men of arms long time unto
the time that the Saxons come at the prayenge of the Bretons against the Pyctes
and put out Gurmonde the Irysshe king with his Pyctes and the Brytons also
with herus king that hyet Careticus and drose hem out of England in to wales
/ and so the Saxons were vyctours and every prouynce after his strength made
him a king. And so departed England in seven kingdoms. Netheles afterward
these seven kingdoms euerychone after other came all in to one kingdom. All
hole under the prince Adelstone Netheles the Danes pursewed this land fro
Adelwolfys time that was Aluredes fader unto the third saint Edwardes time
about a hundred.lxx. year that reigned contynuelly therein.xxiii. year and a
little more. and after him Haralde held the kyngedome.ix. months. And after
him Normans have reigned unto this time. But how long they shall regne he
woote to whom no thing is unknown. R. Of the foresaid seven kingdom and her
marks mares and bounds when they began and how long they endured here shall
I some what shortly tell. Alfre. The first kingdom was the kingdom of Kent.
that stretches fro the Eest Occyan unto the River of Tamyse. There reigned the
first Hengistis and began to regne by the acomptynge of Dyonyse ye year of our
lord a hundred.lv that kingdom dured three hundred and.lviii. year.iv. kings
unto the time that Baldred was put out and Egbert king west Saxon Joined ye
kingdom to his own the second kingdom was at soutsaxon that had in the Eest
side Kent. in the south the sea and the yele of wight / in the weste Hampshyre
/ and in the Northsothery there Ella reigned first with his three sons / and
began to regne the year after the coming of the Angles even.xxx. but that
kingdom within short time passed into the other kingdoms. The third
kingdom was of Eestsaxon / and had in ye eest side the sea / in the weste the
country of London / in the southe Temse and in the North southfolke. The kings
of this country of westsaxon fro the first. Sebertes time unto the time of
the Danes were.x. kings yt which were subgect somdele to other kings.
Nevertheless of te^^e and lengeste they were under the Kings of Mercia and unto
that time that Egberte the king of westsaxon Joined that kyngedome to his
own. The fourth kingdom was of Eest Angels and conteyneth Northfolke and
Southfolke / and had in the eest side / and in ye North side the sea / and in
the Northwest Cambrygeshyre / in the weste saint Edmondes dyche and
Herfordshyre / and in the south Estsex And this kingdom dured under twelve
kynhes unto the time that king Edmonde was slain. And then the Danes took
wrongfully both the kingdoms of eest Angels and of eestsaxon Afterward the
Danes were put out and driven away or made subget. And then the elder king
Edward Joined both the kyngdoms to his own. The fyfte kingdom was of
westsaxon and dured lengest of all the kingdoms / and had in the Eestsyde
southsaxon / in the north Tamyse / in the south and in the west yt see occean.
In ye kingdom reigned Serdryd with his sone Kenryk. and began to regne the year
of our lord five hundred and.xx. And then after ye coming of Angels.lxxi. so
says Denis the other kyngdoms passed in to this kingdom. The syxt kingdom
was of Mercia and was grettest of all. The marks and the meres thereof were in
the west side of the River Dear fast by Chestre and Seuarne fast by
Shrowesbury unto bristowe. in the eest ye eest see in the south Tamyse unto
london / in the north the River of Humber. and so westwarde and downwarde unto
the River Merse unto the corner off wyrhall. there Humbre falls into the west
see Penda wybbes sone reigned fyste in this kyngedome in the year of our lord
Ihesu Christ.vi. houndred.xxvi. so says Denis and fro the coming of Angels an
ho^dred.lxxv. year. This kingdom dured under.xviii. kings about two
hundred.lxiii. year. unto the last Colwulf the Danes betoke that kingdom to
keep wha^ burdred the king was put out. But the elder Edward the king put
out the danes and ^oyned the kingdom of Mercia to his own kyngedome. Netheles
at the beginning this kingdom of mercia was departed into three / in the west
mercia. in myddell mercia. and eest Mercia. The.vii. kingdom was Northamhym
broru^. that is the kingdom of Northumberlo^de. the meres and Marks thereof
were by west. and by eest the sea of Occian. by southe the Ryuere of Humbre and
so downwarde to ward the weste by the end of the shyres of Notyngha^ and of
Derby unto the River of merce and by north the Scotts see. that heet forth in
Scottesshe see in English. This kingdom of northumberlonde was first deled
in two prouynces. That one was the southe side and heet / Deyra and that other
was the North side and heet Brenycia / as it were two kingdoms and the River
departed these two kingdoms that time. for the kingdom of Deyra was from the
Ryuere of humbre unto the River of tyne The kingdom of Brenycia was fro Tyne
to the Scottysshe see. And when Pyctes dwelled there as Beda says.li.iii. cap.
ii. That Nynya^ that holy man converted men of the south side Ida the king
reigned there first and began to regne the year of our lord five hundred.xlvii.
so says Dyonyse. In Deyra reigned king elle the year of our lord five
hundred.xlix. These two kingdoms were other while as it is said departed
between two kings and sometime all hoole under one king. and dured as it
were.xx. English kings.ccc.xxi. year / At last Osbertus and Elle were
slain in the.ix. year of her kingdom the Danes slew them and
Northumberlonde was void without king.viii. year / Then afterward the danes
reigned in Northumberlonde.xxxvi. year unto the oonynge of the kingdom
Adelstone. he made subgecte the kings Danes Scottesshe and walshe and reigned
first allone in England and held the kingdom of England all hole and one
kingdom that was the year of our lord viii.C.xxviii. That River of Merse was
sometime the mark and were between the kingdom of Northumberlonde / that may be
showed in two manners first by this properte of this merse / is as much to say
as a see that is abound and a mere for it departed one kingdom from an otheri
Also it is written in Chronicles of Henry and Alfrede that king Edward ye
elder fastened a Castle at Mamcestre in Northumberlonde / but that City
mamcestre is from ye River of merse scarsely three mile.

Of bysshpryches and their sees. ca. xiii.
LVcius was the first king crystened of the Brytons. in his time were three
Archebysshops sees in Brytayne. one was at London / an other at york / And
the third at Caerusk the cite of / legeons in Glamorgan / that cite is now
called Caerleon / To these Archebysshoppes sees were called Flammes To the
Archebysshops see of / london was subget Corn wayle and all myddel England
unto humbre / To york all Northumberlonde from the bow of Humbre with all
Scotlonde to Caerbeon all wales. there were in wayles.vii. Bishops / and now
be^ but foure^ Tho Seuarne departed England and wales. Wihel. de pan. li.i.
But in the Saxons time though Saint Gregori. had granted / london the
preuylege of tharchebysshops see Netheles saint Austen yt was sent in to
England by saint Gregory turned tharchebysshop see out of / london into
Caunterbury. After saint Gregoryes days at the prayer of king Ethelbryght and
C^ and burgeyses of Caunterbury there tharchebysshops see has dured unto now
save yt in ye mean time of a king of mercia was wrought with men of
Caunterbury / and benam them that worship / and worshypped Adulphe bishop of /
lychfelde with the Archebysshops pally by assent of Adryan the pope upon Caas
(...) yeftes sent / Netheles under Kenulph the king it was restored to
Caunterbury again. The worship of the sea of york has dured there always and
yet dured though Scotlonde be withdraw fro his subieccyon by passing of time.
Gir intinere.li.i. the Archebysshoppes see was turned out of Caerleon into
Meneuia that is in the weste side of Demecya upon the Irysshe see in Saint
Dauyds time under king Arthur. From saint Dauyds time unto Sampsons time were
in Meneuya.xxiii. Archebysshops. Afterward fell a pestyle^ce in all wales of
the yelowe evil / that is called the Iau^dis. And then Sampson the
Archebysshop took with him the palle and went in to Brytayne Armonica the
less Brytayne and was there bishop of Dolensin. from that time unto the
first Henryes time king of England were at Meneuia which is called saint
Dauyds.xxi. bishops all without palle / whether it were for uncunning or for
pouerte. Nevertheless always fro that time ye bishops of wales were sacryd of
the bishop of Meneuia of saint Dauyds / and the bishop of Meneuia was sacred
of the bishops of wales as of his suffrigans and made no professyon ne
subjection to none other church. Other bishops that come after ward were
sacred at Caunterbury compellynge and heest of the king / in token of that
sacrynge and subieccyon^ Boneface Archebysshop of Caunterbury that was legate
of the Cross song in every Catheralle church of wales solempnely. Amas he
was ye first Archebysshop of Caunterbury that so did in wales / and yt was
dene in the second He^ryes time. R. But now ben but two primates in all
England of Canterbury and of york. To the prymate of Caunterbury ben
subgette.xiii. bishops in England and.iiii^ in wales. The premate of york
has but two suffrygans in England that been the bishop of Caerleyll and of
Durham: Of all these sees and chaungynge of other places I shall show you
here folwynge. Take heed in the begyngnynge of holy church in England
bishops ordained their sees in low places and simple that were couenable for
co^templacyon for prayers and devotion. But in william conquerours time by done
of law: Canon it was ordained that bysshoppes should come out of small towns
in to great cytees. Therefore was the sea of Dorchestre changed to Lyncoln:
Lychefelde to Chestre. Tetforde to Norwyche Shyrbron to Salysbury. wells to
Bathe. Conewayles to exestre / and Seleseye to Chichestre. The bysshopp of
Rochestre has no parysshe but he is the Archebysshops chapelayn of
Canterbury. Sith the sea of Caunterbury was first ordained by saint Austen /
it caunged yet never his place. Chychestre has under him oonly South sex and
the isle of wight / and had his see first in the time of the Archebysshop
Theodore / and the sea dured there.CCC.xxxiiii. year under.xx. bishops fro the
first wylfryede unto the last Sith and at the commandment of king wyllyam
conqueror changed the sea fro Seleseye to Chychestre.

De episcopis occidentalibbus wilhelmus.
Have mind that all the prouynce of west saxon had always one bishop fro
the beginning unto Theodorus time / by grant of king Islo king of
westsaxon the first Birrynus ordained a see at Dorchestre that is a simple
town by southe Oxenforde beside walyngforde between the metynge together of
Temse and Tame when Birinus was deed. Ke^walcus the king ordained a see at
wynchestre as his fader had purposed / there agylbert a Frenssheman was first
bishop of all the prouynce of westsaxon. For yt time the cite and ye see of
Dorchestre perceived and longed to ye prouynce of Meria / that cite stands
with in Temse. and the Temse departs between Mercia and westsaxon. And after
that Agylbert was pute out of wynchestre that tho hight winton then was there
an English bishop that was called wine. / Some men suppose yt this cite has
the name of this wine / and is called wynchestre as it were wine cite. At the
last he was put out and after him come Leutherius the foresaid Agelbertes
neuewe. After Leutherius hedda awhyle was bishop there. when he was deed.
Theodorus the Archebysshop ordained two bishops to the prouynce of westsaxon.
Danyell at wynchestre to him were subgette two cou^tres / Sothery and
southampshyre / and to him were subget syx countrees. Barkshyre wyltshyre
Somersete Dorseteshyre Deuenshyre and Corn walyle. Treuysa. It seems by this
yt westsaxon conteyted. Sotherye Southampeshyre Dorseteshyre Deuenshyre Corn
wayle Wilhell. After ward in elder Edwardes time to these two sees were
ordained by commandment of Formosus the pope three other sees. At wells for
Somersete. At Kyrton for Deue^shyre. and. At saint Germayn for Cornewayle. Not
long after ward the syxt see was set At Rammesbury for wyltshyre. At the
last by commandment of king wyllyam conqueroure all these sees save
wynchestre were turned and changed out of samlle Town in to great Cytees for
Shyrborn and Rummesbury were turned in to Salysbury. Now to that see is
subgette Barkshyre wyltshyre and Dorsete. The sea of wells was turned to Bathe
/ thereto is now subget all Somersete. The sees of kyrton and of Cornewale were
changed to Exestre thereto is subget Deue^shyre and Cornwale.

De orientalibus episcopis.
IT is known that the Eest Saxons always fro the beginning to now were
subgette to the bishop of London But the prouynce of the eest Angels that
conteyneth Norffolke and Souffolk had one bishop at Donwyk / the bishop heet
Felix and was a Bourgon and was bishop.xvii. year / after him Thomas was
bishop.v. year after him. boneface.xvii. year. Then Bysy afterward was
ordained by Theodorus and ruled the prouynce while he might endure by himself
allone / After him unto Egbertes time king of westsaxon an ho^dred.xliii.
bishops ruled that prouynce oone at donwyk and an other of Elyngham.
Nevertheless after Ludecans time king of Mercia left and was only one see at
Elyngham unto the.v. year of wyllyam conqueroure / when Herfastus the.xxiii.
bishop of the estrene changed his see to Tetforde / and his successor
Herbertus changed these fro Tetforde to Norwhiche by leave of king wyllyam the
reed. The sea of Ely that is night thereto the first king Henry ordained
the.ix. year of his regne / and made subgect thereto Cambrydgeshyre that was
tofore a part of the bysshopryche of Lyncoln / and for quytynge thereof / he
gaafte to the bishop of Lyncoln a good town called Spaldynge.

De episcopis Merciorum wilhelmus.
HEre take heed that as the Kingdom of Mercia was always greteste for the
time / so it was dealed in mo bysshopryches and specially by great hyrte by
king Offa. which was.xl year king of Mercia / he changed the Archebysshops
see fro Caunterbury to Lychfelde by assent of Adryan the pope. Then the
prouynce of Mercia and of Lyndeffar in ye first beginning of her crystendom in
king wulfrans time had one bishop at Lytchefeld the first bishop yt was
there heet Dwyna the second heet Celath and were both Scotts / after them the
third Trumphere / the fourth Iarmuanus / the fyfte Chedde But in Edelfydes
time that was wulfrans brother when Chedde was deed / Theodorus tharchebysshop
ordained there wynfrede Cheddes deken. Netheles apud Hyndon after that for he
was vnbuxum in some point / he ordained there Sexwulf abbot of Meda^stede that
is named burgh. but after Sexwulfus fourth year Theodorus tharchebysshop
ordained five bishops in the prouynce of Mer^ia. And so he ordained Bosell at
wyrcestre / Cudwyn at Lychfelde / the foresaid Sexwulf at Chestre. Edelwyn at
Lyndeseye at cite. Sydenia / and he took Eata monk of the abbaye of Hylde at
whyt by and made him bishop of Dorchestre beside Oxenforde. Tho this
Dorchestre heet Dorkynge / and so the sea of that longs to westsaxon in Saint
Byrynes time longed to Mercia from Theodorus the Archebysshops time Ethelred
king of Mercia had destroyed Kente / this bishop Sexwulf took Pyctas
bishop of Rochestre that come out of Kente and made him first bishop of
Herdforde at last when Se^fulf was deed Hedda was bishop of Lychefelde after
him and wylfryd flemed out of Northumberlonde was bishop of Chestre. Netheles
after two year Alfred king of Northumberlo^de deyed and wylfrede turned again
to his own se hagustalden / and so Hedda held both the bysshopryches
Lychfelde and of Chestre. after him come Albyn that heet worcester also and after him
come three bishops. Torta at chestre wytta at Lychfelde / And Eata was yet at
Dorchestre. After his death bishops of Lyndesey held his see.iii.
hundred.liiii. year unto ^emygius changed the sea to Lyncoln by leave of the
first king wyllyam But in Edgars time bishop Leot winus Joined both
bysshopryches to gyeer of Chestre and lyndeffa^ while his life edured.

De episcopis Northumbran Wilhel. de pon. li. ca. xi.
AT york was one see for all the prouynce of Northu^berlonde paulinus held
first the sea and was ordained of the bishop of Canterbury / and held ye
see at york.vii. year Afterward wha^ king Edwyn was slain and things were
dystroubled. Poulinus went thens by water away into Kent from whens he come
first and took with him the pall. Wilhel. li^iiii. And so the bysshopryche of
york ceased.xxx. year / and the use of the palle ceased there an hundred.xxv.
year unto that Egbart the bishop that was the kings brooder of the land
recovered it by auctoryte of the pope. R. when saint Oswolde reigned Aydanus a
Scot was bishop in bernica that is ye north side of Northumberlonde / after
him Finianus after him Salmanus. wylhel: vby. s. At last he went in to
Scotlo^de with great in dygnacyon / for wylfre under took him for he held
unlawfully Besterdaye.xxx. year after ye Paulinus was gone from thens wilfred
was made bishop of york. Beda li.iiii. But while he dwelled long in France
about his sacrynge at excytynge of quartadecimonorum / that were they yt held
Eesterdaye the.xiiii. day of ye moan. Chedde was ytake out of his abbay of
Lynstynge and wrongfully put out i^ to ye see of yorkesby assent of king Oswy.
but three year after ward. Theodorus tharche bishop did him a way and
assygned him to the prouynce of Mercia and restored wilfred to the sea of
york. But after by cause of wrath yt was between him and the king Egfryde was
put out of the sea by Theodorus help. tharchebysshop that was corrupt with
some manner mede this was done after ye wilfred had been bishop of york / and
Cumbert at Hagustalde church / and Eata at Lyndeffar church yt now is called
holy ylonde in ye River of Twede. Aydanus found first the sea. And Theodorus
made Eadhedus bishop of Ropoune that was comen again out of Lyndeseye.
wilfred had be abbot of Repune. Theodorus sent Trunwynus to ye land of Pyetes
in thendes of England fast by Scotlond in a place yt heet Candida casa. and
whiterne also. there saint Ninian a Bryton was first fou^der and doctor. But
all these sees out take york failed little and little for the sea of Candida
casa that is Galle way that tho longed to \ England and dured many years
under.x. bishops unto that it had no power by destroyenge of the Pyctes. The
sees of Hagalde and of Lyndeffar was sometime all one under.lx. bishops about
four score year and ten and dured unto the coming of ye Danes. In that time
under Hyngar and Hubba ardufe the bishop yede long about with saint Cuberts
body unto king Aluredes time king of west Saxon / and the sea of Lydeffar was
set at Kunegestre that is called Kunyngysburgh also / ye place is called now
Vbbesforde upon Twede At the last the.xvii. year of king Egbere king Edgars
sone / ye se was changed to Durham / and saint Cutber^tes body was brought
thither by the doing of Edmonde ye bishop / and fro that time forward the sea
of that Hagustalde and of lyndeffar failed utterly. The first king Henry in
the.ix. year of his regne made the new seat Caerleyll. The archebysshop of
Caunterbury has under him.xiii. bishops in England. and.iiii. in wales he
has Rochostre under him / and that se has under him a part in Kent alone
London has under him Estsex Myddelsex and half Herdforthshyre. Chychestre has
under him Southsex and the isle of wight. wynchestre has under him Hampshyre
and Southery. Salesbury has under him Barkshyre wyldshyre D^rsete. Exetre has
under him Deuenshyre and Cornewayle. bathe has under him Somerseteshyre alone
/ wyrcestre has under him Gloucestreshyre wyrcestreshyre and half warwykshyre
Herdforde has under him Herfordshyre Chestre is bishop of Couentree and of
Lychefelde and has under him Cherstreshyre Staffordshyre Derbyshyre half
warwykshyre and some of Shropshyre and some of Lancastreshyre fro the River of
Mersee unto the River Rypylle. Lyncoln has under him ye prouynces that been
between Temse and humbre that been the shyres of Lyncoln of Leycestre of
Norhampton of Huntyngdon of Bedforde of Bockyngham of Oxenforde and half
Herdefordeshyre. Ely has under him Cambrygeshyre outake Merlonde. Norwyche
has under him Merlonde Norfolk and Suffolk. Also tharchebysshop of
Caunterbury has four suffreygans in wales that been Landaf Saint Dauyes
Bangor and saint assaph. The Archebysshop of york has now but two bishops
under him that been Durham and Caerleyll. R. And so ben but two prymates in
England what of hem shall do^ to the other and in what manner point he shall be
obedyent and under him. It is fully contained within about the year of our
lord Ihesu christ a thousand.lxxii. tofore the first king wylliam and the
bishops of England be commandment of the pope. the cause was handled and
treated between the foresaid prymates and ordained and demed that ye prymate of
york shall be subgette to the prymate of Canterbury in things yt longen to
the worship of god and to the believe of holy church that in what place ever it
be in England that the prymate of Cau^therbury wylhote and constreyne togader
a counseyll of clergy the prymate of york is holden with his suffrygans for to
be there and for to be obedyent to the ordinance yt there shall be lawfully
ordained when the prymate of york shall come to Caunterbury and with other
bishops he shall sacre him that is chosen / and so with other bishops he
shall sacre his own prymate / if the prymate of york be deed / his successor
shall come unto ye bishop of Caunterbury and he shall take his ordinance of
him and take his oath with prosessyon and lawful obedyence. After about the
year of our lord.xi.C.lxxxxv. in the time of king Richard ben resons set for
the party for either prymate and what one prymate did to that other in time of
Thurstinus of Thomas and of other bishops of york from the conqueste unto
king Henryes time the third. Also there it is said how each of them starte
from other. This place is but a forspekynge and not a full treates thereof
Therefore it were noyfulle to charge this place with all thylke reasons.

Of how many manner people have dwelled therein. ca. xiiii.
BRytous dwelled first in this ylonde the xviii. year of Hely the prophet /
the.xi. year of Solinus postumus king of Latyns.xliii. after the taking of
Troy / tofore the buildynge of Rome.CCC.xxxii. year. Beda. li.i. They come
hyder and took her course from armonyk that now is that other brytayn they
held long time the south countres of ye ylond It befell afterward in
Vespasianus time duke of Rome. That the Pyctes shypped out of Scycya into
Occean / and were driven about with the wind and entered in to the North
costs of Irlonde and found there Scotts and prayed to have a place to dwell
Inn and might none get. For Irlonde as Scotts said might not sustain both
people Scotts sent Pyctes to the north side of England and behyght them
help ayenste the Brytons that were their enemies if they would arise / and
took them wives of their daughters / upon such condycyon if doubt fylle /
whoo should have right to be king they should rathar chese him of the mother
side than of the fader side of the women kyn rathar than of the men kind
Gaufre. In Vaspasyan the Emperous time when Marius Aruiragus sone was king of
Brytons One Rodryk king of Pyctes came out of Scycya and ganne to destroyed
Scotlonde / Marius the king slew this Rodryk and gave the north party of
Scotlonde that heet Cathenesia to the me^ that were came with Rodryk and were
overcome by him / for to dwell Inn. But these men had no wives ne none might
have of the nacyon of brytons there for they sailled into Irlonde and took to
their wives Irysshemens daughters by that couenaunte that the mother blood
should be put tofore in succession of heritage. Gir. ca. xvii. Netheles Sirinus
super Vyrgilium says that Pyctes agatyrses that had some dwelling plyce
about the waters of Scycya and they ben called Pyctes of Peyntynge and
smiting of wounds / therefore they are called Pyctes as painted men. These men
and these goths ben all one people. For when Ma^imus the tyrant was went out
of Brytayne into France f^r to occupye thempyre. Then Gratianus and
Valentianus that were brethern and folowes of thempyre brought these goths out
of ^cya with great gifts with flaterynge and ^re behestes into the north
country of Bryta^ne. For they were stalworth and strong m^ of arms and so
these thieves and bryborus were made men of land and of country and dwelled in
the north countrees. And held there cytees and towns. Gaufre. Carancius the
tyrant slew Bassyanus ^ and gafe the Py^^e^ a dwelling place in. Albania
that is Scotlond / there they dwelled long time afterward and meddled with
Brytons. R. Then sithe that Pyctes occupied first the (...) side of
Scotlond. It seems that the dwge place that this Carancius gaat them is the
southe side of Scotlonde that stretchethe from thawrte over wall of Romans
work to the Scottesshe see. and conteyneth Galleway and Lodouia that is
Lodewaye. Th^rfore Beda.li.iii. ca. ii. speaks in this manner. Ninian the
holy man converted the southe Pyttes. Afterward the Saxons come and made that
Country long to Brenicia the North party of Northumberlonde unto the time
that Kynadius Alpinus sone king of Scotlo^de put out of the Pyctes and made
that country that lies between Twede and the Scottesshe see long to his
kingdom. Beda.li^ ca. i. Afterward long time the Scotts were led by duke
Renda and came out of Irlonde that is propre country Scotts and with love or
with strenthe made him a place fast by the Pyctes in the North side of that
arm of the sea / that breketh in to the land in the weste side that departed
in old time between Brytons and Pyctes. Of this Duke Renda the Scotts had
the name and were caled Darlendinas as it were Rendaes part / for in her
speech a part is called dall. Girp^. The pyctes might have no wives of
Brytons bute they took hem wives of Irysshe Scotts and promised hem fair for
to dwell with them And granted him a land by the sea side / there the sea is
now That land is called now. Galleway Marianus Irysshe Scottesshe lord
datte Argall that is Scotten clyfe for Scotts londed there for to do tharme
to the Brytons or for that place is next to Irlonde for to come a land in
Brytayne. Beda. And so the Scotts after Brytons and Pryctes made the third
people dwelling in Brytayne. R. Then after that come Saxons at prayenge of
the Brytons to help them against the Scotts and Pyctes. And the Brytons were
soon put out in to ways. And Suxons occupied the Land little and little. And
efte more to the Scottysshe see. And so Saxoas made the fourth manner of men
in the ylonde of Brytayne. Beda li.v. ca. ix. For Saxons and Angels came out
of Germania / yet some Brytons that dwelled nyghe callen hem shortly Germans.
R. Netheles abowte the year of our lord.viii. hundred Egbartus king of
westsaxon commanded and badde all men call the men of the land Englysshmen.
Alfre. Then after that the Canes pursued the land. Abowte two hundred year /
that is for to say fro the for said Egbarteus time unto saint Edwardes time /
and made the fyfte manner of people in the land / Bute they faylde after
ward. At last come Normans unto duke wyllyam and subdued Englysshemen / and
yet keep they the land and they made the ^y^the people in the ylonde. But in
the first king Henryes time come many Flemynges and received a dwellynege
place for a time be side Maylros in the weste side of Enlonde / and made the
seventh people in the ylonde. Netheles by commandment of the same king they
were put thens and driven to Hauer fordes side in the west side of wales. R.
And so now in Brytayne Danes and Pyctes fayllen all out / and five nacyons
dwellen there in that been Scotts in Albania / that is Scotlond. Brytayne in
Chambrya that is wales. but that Flemynges dwell in that is west wales. And
normans and Englysshmen ben meddled in all the ylond / for is now doubt in
stories how and in what manner they were put a way and dystroyed out of
Brytayne. Now it is to declare how the Pyctes were dystroyed and sailed. Girp^.
ca. vii. Brytayn was sometime occupied with Saxons / and peace was made and
stablysshed with the Pyctes / then the Scotts that came with the Pyctes saw
that the Pyctes were nobler of deeds and better me^ of arms though they were
less in nombre than the scotts Then^e the Scotts having thereof envy turned
to their natural treason yt they have often used for in treason they pass other
me^ and ben traitors as it were by kind. For they prayed all the Pyctes and
specially the great of them to a feast. and waited her time when the Pyctes
were merry and had well drunk they drew up nails that held up holowe be^ches
under the pyctes and the pyctes unware suddenly fill in over the hammes into a
wonderful pytfull. Then the Scotts fell on the Pyctes and slew the^ and left
none alive. And so of two manner people ye better warryours were holy destroyed.
but the other yt ben the Scotes which ben traitors all unlike to the pyctes
took prouffyte by that falls treason / for they took all that land and hold
it yet unto this time and it. Scotlonde after her own name / In king Edgars
time Kynadin Alpinus sone was duke and leder of the Scotts and warred in Pycte
land / and destryyed the Pyctes. He warred syx sythes in Saxon and took all
the land that is between Twede and the Scottysshe see with wrong and with
strength.

Of the langages of manners and vsuge of the people of that land. ca. xv^
AS it is known how many manner of people ben in this ylonde there been also
so many langages and tongues. Netheles walsshe and scotts that been not meddled
with other nacyons keep yet their langage and speech but yet the Scotts that
were sometime co^federate and dwelled with Pyctes draw somewhat after their
speech / But the Flemynges that dwell in the west side of wales have left her
strange speech and speken like to Saxons / also Englysshemen though they had
fro the beginning three manner of speches. Southern Northern and myddell
speech in the myddell of the land as they come of three manner of people.
Germania. Netheles by commixyon and mydlynge first with Danes and afterward
with Normans in many things the country langage is appared / for some use
strange wlaffynge chyterynge harrynge gartynge and grysbytynge. This apparynge
of the langage comes of two things / one because that children that gone to
scole learn to speak first English / and than ben compelled to constre his
lesso^s in Frensshe and that have been used syn the Normans come into England.
Also gentylmens children be learned and taught from their youth to speak
Frensshe / and up londesshmen will counterfete and lyken himself to ge^tylmen
and are besy to speak / frensshe for to be more set by / wherefore it is said
by a common proverb. Jack would be a gentylme^ if he could speak frensshe.
Treuisa. This was much used to fore great death. but sith it is somdele
changed / for sir Johan Cornwayle a master of gramer changed ye techynge of
gramer scole and construccyon of / frensshe into English. And other scole
masters use ye same way now in the year of our lord. a.M.CCC.lxxxv. the.ix.
year of king Richard the second / and leave all / frensshe in scoles and use
all co^struccyon in English wherein they have advantage one way that is yt
they learn ye sooner their gramer / and in a another dysauauntage. for now they
learn no Frensshe nor can none. which is hurt for them yt shall pass thee
see. And also gentylmen have much left to teache their chyldred to speak /
frensshe. R. It seems a great wonder ye Englysshmen have so great dyuersyte in
their own langage in sown and in speaking of it which is all in one ylonde.
And the langage of Normandye is comen out of an other land and has one manner
sown among all the^ that speak it in England / for a man of Kente southern
western and northern men speken / frenshe all like in sown and speech but they
can not speak their English so. Treuysa. Netheles there ben as many diverse
manner of / frenshe in the reame of / france / as diverse English in the
reame of England. R. Also of the foresaid tongue which is departed in three is
great wonder / for men of the eest with men of the west accord better in
sownynge of the speech / than men of the north with men of the southe Therefore
it is ye men of mercii that been of myddell England as it were partynes with
the ends / understand better the side langages northern and southern than
northern and southern understand either other. Wilhel. de pon.li.iii. All the
langahes of the northu^bres and special at york is so sharp shyttynge
frottynge and vnshap / yt we southern men may uneath vnverstonde that langage^
I suppose ye cause be yt they be night to the alyens that speak straungely. And
also by cause the kings of England abide and dwell more in the southe
counteree than in the north country. The cause why they abide moore the south
country than in the north country / is by cause that there is better corn
land more people moo noble cytees and mo profitable havens in the southe
country than in the north country.

De gentis huius moribus. Gir. in (...)*
FOr the manners and doing of walsshemen and of scotts ben to fore somewhat
declared. Now I purpose to tell and declare the condycyons of the meddled
people of England. But the Flemynges that been in the west side of wales ben
now all turned as they were Englysshmen by cause they company with
Englysshmen. And they be mighty and strong to fight / and ben the most
enemies that walsshemen have / and use marchaundyse and clothing and ben full
ready to put themself in auentures and to peril in the sea and land because
of great winning and be^ ready sometime to the plowe and sometime to deeds of
arms when time and place areth. It seems of these men a great wonder that in
a boon of a wethers right sholder when the flesse is soden away and not roasted
they know what have be done / is done / and shall be done as it were by
spyryte of prophecye and a wonderful craft. They tell what is done in far
cou^tres towenes of peace or of war / the state of the royame sleynge of men
and spousebreche such things they declare certain of tokenes and signs that
is in such a sholder bone. R. But the Englysshemen that dwell in England ben
meddled in the ylonde and ben far fro the places that they spronge of first
tornenne to the contrary deeds lyghtelye without entysynge of any other men
by her own assent. And vnesy also impatient of peace / enemies of besynes / and
full of sloth. Wilhel. de pon.li.iii. says That when they have destroyed
their enemies all to the ground / then^e they fyghten with theymself and
sleeth each other / as void and an empty stomak werketh in it self. R.
Netheles men of the southe ben esyer and moree mylde than men of the North. For
they ben more unstable and more cruel and more vnesy. The myddell men ben
parteners with both. Also they use them to glotony more than other men and ben
more costlewe in mete and clothing Men suppose that that they took that vice
of king Herceknot yt was a Dane. For he here set forth twyes double mess
at Dinner and at souper alsoo. These men ben spedefulle on horse and a foot.
Able and ready to all manner dedys of arms / and be wont to have vyctorye and
maystrye in every fight where no treason is walking / and been curyous and
can well tell dedys and wonders that they have seen. Also they gone in diverse
lands uneath ben any men rich in her own land or more gracyous in far
and in strange land / they can better win and get new than keep thyr own
heritage / Therefore it is yt they be sprade so wide and wene that every land
be own. The men be able to all manner sleyght and wit / but to fore the deed
blonderynge and hasty. And more wise after the deed than tofore. an leven of
lightly what they have begone. Solinus li.vi. Therefore Eugenius the pope said
that Englysshmen were able to do what ever they would / and to be sete and put
tofore all other ne were that light wytletteth. And as Hanyball said that ye
Romans might not be over comee but in there own country so: Englysshme^ may
not be over come in strange lands but in there own country they be lyghty
overcome R. These men despysen her own and praise other men's. and uneath be
pleased nor apayd with their own estate what befalleeh and becomes other men
/ they will gladly take to them self. Therefore it is that a yeman arayeth him
as a squyre: a squyre as a knight a knight as a duke / a duke as a king / yet
some go abote and will be like to all manner state and ben in no state. For
they take every degree that be of no degree for in derynge out ward they be
myntrals and herowdes. In talknynge great spekers In etynge and drinking
glotons / In gaderyng of catell hucksters and tauerners. In array tormentours.
In wnynynge argry. In travail tantaly. In taking head dedaly. In beds
Sardanapaly / In chyrches mawmetes. In courts tho^dre only in preuylege of
clergy and in prebendes they knowle^he themself clerks. Treuysa As touching
the terms of latin as argi / tantali / dedali / serdanapali / ye must
understand them as ye poctes feyned of them. Argus was an hard and kept
bestes he had an ho^dred even. and Argus was also a ship / a ship man and a
chapman / and so argus might se before and behind and on every side. Therefore
he yt is wise and ware and can se that he be not deceived may be called Argus.
And so the Cronycle says in plurell nombre yt Englysshmen ben argy. that is to
say they se about where as winning is That other word tantaly / the poet
feyneth that Tantalus slew his own sone wherefore he is dampened to perpetual
penance / and he stands always in water up to the neither lyppe and has
always ripe apples and noble fruit hanging down to the ouerlyppe. But the
fruit ne the water may not come within his moute. He is so hold and
stands between mete and drink and may neither eete ne drink / and is ever
an hongred and a thyrste that woo is him alive by this manner likeness of
Tantalus they that do right naught there is much is to do in euere side ben
called tantaly It seems that it is to say in trauaylle they be tantaly / for
they do right naught thereto. The third word is deda^e / take heed that
Dedalus was a subtle and a slye man. And therefore by lykenes they that been
subtle and slye they becalled dedaly. And the fourth word is sardanapaly / ye
shall understand that Sardanapalus was king of Assyryens and was fulle
unchaste / and used him for to lie soft. And by a manner of lykenys of him they
yt live unchastly ben called sardanapaly. R. But among all Englysshmen meddled
togyders is so great a chaungynge and dyuersyte of clothing and of a raye and
so many manners and dyuerseshappes that well nyghe is there any man known by
his clothing and his array of whate some ever degree that he be There of
prephecyed an holy Anchor in king Egelfredes time in this manner. Henry li.vi.
Englysshmen for as much as they use them to drynkel^wn^es / to treason and to
rechelesnes of gods house / first by Danes and then by Normans / and at the
third time by the Scotts yt they hold the most wretches and lest worth of
all other they shall be overcome. Then the world shall be so unstable and so
diverse and varyable that the unstableness of thoughts shall be bytokeneth by
many manner dyuersytees of clothing.

Here follows the dyscrecyon of the land of wales. ca. xvi.
Now this book takes on hand.
Wales after England ^
So take I my tales
And wend into wales
To that noble blood.
Of Pryamus blood
Knowleche for to win ^
Of great Iupyters kynne.
For to have in mind
Dardanus kind.
In these four tytles I fond
To tell the state of that land. ^
Cause of the man I shall tell
And then praise the land and well
Then I shall write with my pen.
All the manners of the men
Then I shall fond ^
To tell meruaylles of the land
Of the name and wherefore is named wales. ca. xvii.
WAles now is called wallia.
And sometime it heet Cambria
For Camber Brutes sone
Was prince and there did wone
Then wallia was to mean.
For Gwalaes the queen
King Ebrancus child
Was wedded theder mylde
And of that lord Gwalon
With draws of the sonn^
And put to.l.i. a. ^
And thou shalt find wallia.
And though this land
Be much less than England
As good glebe is one as other
In the daughter in the mother
Of the co^modytes of the land of wales. Capitulo. xviii.
THough that land be luy^.
It is full of corn and of fruit
And has great plente ywys
Of flesh and eke of fysshe
Of beestes tame and wild
Of horse sheep^ oxen mylde ^
Good land for all seeds ^
For corn gras and herbs that spredes
There ben woods and medes
Herbs and flowers there spredes.
There ben Ryuers and wells
Valeyes and also hills
Valeyes bring forth flood.
And hills metals good ^
Cooll grows under land
And gras above at hand
There lyme is copyous
And slates for house ^
Honey and milk white
There is deynte and not lyte
Of braket meet and ale.
Is great plente in that vale
And all that ends to the live
That land brings forth ryue ^
But of great riches to be draw
And close many in short saw
It is a corner small ^
As though god first of all
Made that land so feel
To be selere of all hele. ^
Wales is deled by
A water that heet Twy
North wales from the south
Twy deleth in places full couch ^
The south heet Demicia
And the other Venedocia
The first shoteth and arowes deres
That other deleth all with spear ^
In wales how it be
Were sometime courts three
At Carmerthyn was that one.
And that other was in Moan ^
The third was in Powysy
In Pegwern that now is Shrowesbury
There were bishops seven
And now ben four even
Under Saxons all at home
Sometime under princes of that land
Of the manners and rytes of the walsshmen. ca. xix.
THe manner living of that land.
Is well diverse from England
In mete and drink and clothing
And many other doing
They be clothed wonder well
In a shyrte and in a mantell
A cryspe brethe well sayn^ ^
Does in wind and in rain
In this clothing they by bold ^
Though the weder be right cold
without shetes always.
Evermore in this array
They go fight plye and lepe
Stand sytte lie and sleep
without surto^ gown cote and kyrtyll
without ^open tabarde clok or bell ^
without lace and chaplet that her lappes
without hode hatte or cappes
Thus arayd gone the segges
And always with base legs
They keep none other going
Though they mete with the king ^
with arowes and short speres
They fight with them that them deres
They fight better if they neden
When they go than when they ^yden
Instead of castle and coure
They take wood and mareys for socour
when they seen it is to do.
In fighting they would be a go ^
Gyldas says they ben varyable
In peace and not stable.
if men a^e why it be
It is no wonder for to se
Though men put out of land
To put out other would fond ^
But all for naught at this stand
For all many woods ben at gronde
And put the sea among
^en castles builded strong
The men may dure long vnete
And love well conume mete ^
They can ete and ben mury
without great cury
They ete bread cold and hot
Of ^arly and of ote
Broad cakes round and thynne ^
As well seems so great kynne
Selde they ete bread of whete
And selde they done one ete
They have gruell to p^tage
And lekes kind to com panage ^
Also butter milk and chese
y shapeend land and corner wise
Such messes they ete snell
And that makes hem drink well
Me^e ^d ale that has might
Thereon they spend day and night ^
Ever the redder is the wine. ^
They hold it the more fine
When they drink at ale
They till many lewd tale
For when drink is in handlynge
They ben full of Jangling
At meet and after eke. ^
Her solace is salt and leke
The husbonde in his wise
Tells that a great price
To give a gaudron with growele
To hem that sytten on his mele
He deleth his meet at meele ^
And gives every man his dele
And all the over pluse
He keeps to his own use.
Therefore they have woo
And myshappes also
They eten hot samon alway^
All though physyk say nay ^
Her houses ben low with all
And made of yerdes small
Not as in cytees nyghe
But f^rre a sonder and not to hygh^
When all his eten at home.
Then to their neighbors will they run
And ete what they may find and se
And then torn home again ^
The life is ydele that they ledes
In brennynge slepynge and such deeds
Wallshmen use with her might
To wesshe their ghestes fete a night
if he wesshe her fete all and sum.
Then they know that they be welcome
They live so esely in a route
That field they bear purs about. ^
At her breche out and home
They honge their money and comb.
It is wonder they beso hende
And hate crak at nether end
And without any core ^
Make their wardrope at the door.
They have in great mangery
Harp tabour and pype for mynstralsy
They bear corpse with sorywes great
And blow land hoenes of gheet^
They praise fast Troyau blood. ^
For there of come all her broad.
Nygh kyn they will be
Though they pass a hundred degree
Above other men they will him dyght. ^
And worship priest with her might
As angels of heaven right
They worship servants of god almyght.
Often gyled was this broad
And yerned battle all for wood
For Merlyns prophecye
And often for sortelegye
Best in manners of Brytons
For company of Saxons
Ben turned to better right
That is known as clear as light
They tyllen gardyns field and downs
And draw him to good towns
They ride armed as woll god
And go yhosed and yshoode
And sytten fair at her mele
And sleep in beds fair and in feel.
So they seem now in mind
More Englysshmen than walsshe kind.
if men axe why they now do so
More than they wont to do
They lyuen in more peace
Because of their riches.
For their catell should slake ^
if they used often warke
Dread of loss of her good
Make them now still of mode ^
All in one it is brought.
Have no thing and dread naught
The poet says a saw of preef
The foot man syngeth to fore the thief
And is bolder on the way.
Than the horse man rich and gaye
Of the meruayls and wondres of wales.
THere is a pole at Brechnok
Therein of fysshe is many a floke.
Often he changes his hew on cop
And bears above a gardyn crop
Often time how it be ^
Shape of house there shall thouse
When the pole is frore it is wonder
Of the noise that is there under
if the prince of the land hot
Birds sing well merry not ^
As merely as they can.
And syngyn for none other man
Besides Caerleon
Two mile fro the town
Is a roche well bright of leem
Right against the son beem. ^
Goldclyf that roche hight
For it shyneth as god full bright ^
Such a flour in stoon is naught.
Without fruit if it were sought
if men could by craft undo
The veins of thetth and come thereto ^
Many benyfece of kind
Ben now hyd fro man's mind
And ben unknow yet ^
For defaute of man's wit
Great tresour is hyd in ground
And after this it shall be found
By great study and besynes ^
Of them that comen after us
That old men had by great need
We have by besy deed Treuisa.
In books ye may read
That kind fails not at need
When no man had craft in mind. ^
Then of craft halpe god and kind
When no techer was in land
Men of craft by gods hand
They that had craft so then.
Taught forth craft to other men
Some craft that yet come not in place
Some man shall have by gods grace
R. An ylonde is with noise and strife
In west wales at Kerdyf
Fast by Sauerne stronde.
Barry hight that ylonde ^
In that hither side in a chene
Shall thou here wonder dene
And diverse noys also ^
if thou put thyn ere to
Noys of leaves and of wind
Noys of metals thou shall find
Frotynge of iron and westones thou shall her^
Hetynge of ouens then with fire
All this may well be.
By wawes of the sea ^
That breketh in their
With such noys and fare.
At Pendrok in a stead
Feudes do often quede ^
And throws foul thing inn^
And despyseth also sin.
Neither craft ne bedes may
Do thens that sorrow away ^
When it greueth so.
To the men it bodeth woo
At crucynar in west wales.
Is a wonder buryals ^
Every man that comes it to se
Seems it even as much as he
Hoole wepen there a night ^
Shall be broken er day light
At nemyn in north wales
A little ylonde there is ^
That is called bar^ysay
Monks dwell there always ^
Men live se long in that hurst
That the oldest deyeth fryste
Men say that Merlyn there buried is.
That hight also syluestris ^
There were Merlyns tweyne
And prophesied beyne
One heet Ambrose an Merlyn ^
And was y gotten by gobelyn
In demicia at carmerthyn
Under king Vortygryn ^
He told his prophecye
Even in sonwdonye.
At heed of the water of coneway
In the side of mout eryry ^
Dynas embreys in walsshe.
Ambrose hill in English
King Vortygere sat on
The watersyde and was full of wone.
Then Ambrose Merlyn prophesied.
Tofore him right tho Tresa.
what wit would wene
That a fend might get a child
Some men would mean
That he may no such work welde
That fend that goth a night
wymmen full often to gyle
Incubus is named by right
And gyleth men other while
Succubus is that wight
God grant us none such vile
who that comes in her gyle
wonder hap shall he smyle
with onder deed
Both men and wymmen sede
Fendes woll keep
with craft and bring an hepe.
So fendes wild ^
May make wymmen bear child
yet never in mind
was child of fendes kind
For without eye
There might no such child deye.
Clergy makes mind
Death sleeth no fendes kind
But death slew Merlyn ^
Merlyn was ergo no gobelyn
And other Merlyn of Albyn land
That now is named Scotlonde
And he had names two
Syluestris and Calidonius also ^
Of that wood Calidonie
For there he told his prophecy
And heet Siluestris as well
For when he was in batell ^
And saw above a grysly kind
And fill anon out of his mind
And made no more abood
But ran anon unto the wood
Treuysa. Siluester is wood
Other wild of mode Other else
That at wood he dwelles
R. Siluestris Merlyn.
Told prophecye well and fyn
And prophesied well sure
Under king Arthur
Openly and not so close ^
As Merlyn Ambrose
There ben hills in snowdonye
That been wonderly hye
with high as great a way
As a man may go a day
And heet eryry in walsshe
Snowy hills in English.
In the se hills there is
Leese Enough for all bestes of wales
These hills on top beres ^
Two great fysshe wears
Contained in that one ponde.
Meueth with the wind an ylonde.
As though it did swymme.
And neyheth to the brymme. ^
So that herdes have great wonder.
And wene that the world meueth under
In that other is perch and fysshe
Every one eyed is
So fares all well
In Albania the mylwell ^
In Rutlonde by Tetyn well
There is a little well
That flows not al walye
As the sea twyes a day
But sometime it is dry
And sometime full by the eye ^
There is in North wallia
In Mon that heet Anglesia
A sto^e according well nyghe ^
As it were a man's thyghe
How far ever that stone
Ben born of any mon.
On night it goth home his way
That he found by assaye ^
Hughe thereto of Shrowesbury
Hn time of the first Harry
For he would the sothe find
That stone to an other he began bind. ^
with great cheynes of iron
And threw all Iferen
ybounde at one hepe
In to a water deep
yet amorowe that stone ^
was seen erly in Mon.
Achorle held himself full slyghe.
And bound this stone to his thyghe.
His thysthe was roten ordaye
And the stone went a way.
if men done lechery.
Nyghe that stone by
Swote comes of that stone. ^
But child comes there none.
There is a roche right wonderly.
The roche of herynge by country
Though there cry any man born
And blow also with an horn
Noise there though thou abide ^
Thou shall here none in this side
There is an other ylonde
Fast by mon at hand
Hermytes there ben ryue
if any of them done strive
All the myse that may be get
Come and ete all their mete ^
Then cesseth never that woo
Till the wryfe cesse also
As men in this land
Ben angry as in Irlonde
So saints of this contreye ^
Ben also wretchefull always
Also in this land
In Irlonde and in Scotlond.
Ben beiles and staves
That in worship men haues
And ben worshyped so then ^
Of clerks and of lewd men.
That dredes also
To sweten on any of tho ^
Staff either belle
As it swre the gospelle
At Basyng work is a well
That Sacer heet as men tell.
It sprengeth so sore as men may see
What is cast in it throws aye
Thereof sprengeth a great stronde
It were Enough for all that land ^
Seek at that place
Have both hele and grace
In the welmes ofter than ones
Ben found reed spercled stones.
In token of the blood reed
That the maid wenefrede
Shad at that pytte ^
When her throat was kytte
He that did that deed
Has sorrow on his sede
His children at all stoundes
Berken as whelps and hounds
For to they pray that maid grace.
Right at that well glace
Either in Shrowesbury street.
There that maid rested sweet
Of the descrypcyon of Scotlonde sometime named Albania. ca. xxi.
IT is a common saw that the country which is now named Scotlonde is an out
stretchynge of the north side of Brytayn and is departed in the south side
from Brytayne with arms of the sea / and in the other side yt is be clypped
with the sea. This land hete some time Albania and had that name of
Albanactus that was king Brutes sone Albanactus dwelled first therein / or of
the prouynce Albania that is country of Scycia and nygh to amazona therefore
Scoctea ben called as ye were scyttes for they come out of Scicia. After ward
that land heet Pyctauya for ye Pyctes reigned there in a thousand.CCC.lx^ year.
And at last heet. Hibernia as Irlonde hight Gir. in top. For many skylles /
one is for affinite and alye that was between them and Irysshmen for they took
their wives of Irlonde and that is openly seen in her believe / in clothing /
in langage and in speech / in weyyn and in maneres. An other skyll is for
Irysshemen dwelied there sometime. Beda.li.i. Out of Irlonde that is the propre
country of Scotts come Irysshmen with her duke that was called Rendar. And
with love and with strenth made hem chyef sees and Cytees besides the Pyctes in
the North side. Gir. Now the land is shortly called Scotlonde of Scotts
that come out of Irlonde and reigned there in CCC.xv. year unto reed wyllyams
time that was Malcolyn brother. R. Manyeuydences we have of this Scotlonde that
it is often called and byghte Hibernia as Irlonde does. Therefore Beda.li.ii. ca.
xi. says that Laurence Archebysshoppe of Dunbar was Archebysshop of Scotts
that dwelled in an ylonde that heet Hibernia and is next to Brytayne.
Beda.li.iii. ca. xxvii. Says Pestilence of moreyn bare down Hibernia.
Also.li.iii. ca. ii. says that the Scotts that dwelled in the south side of
Hibernia. Also: li.iiii. ca. iii. he says that Cladde was a yonglynge and
learned the rule of monks in Hibernia. Also.li.iiii. ca. xxii. Egfridus king
of Northeumberlonde destroyed Hibernia: Also.li.iiii. ca. xv. the most dele of
Scotts in Hibernia and in the same chapter be called Hibernia proprely named
/ ye weste ylonde is an hundred mile from eueryche / Brytayne and departed with
the sea between and called Hibernia that country that now is called Scotlond
/ there he tells that Adamua abbot of this ylonde sailed to Hibernia for to
tethe Irysshmen the lawful Esterdaye And at last come again in to Scotlonde.
ysy. ethi. li.xiiii^ Man of this Scotlonde ben named Scotts in their own
langage and Pyctes also. For sometime her body was peynted in this manner / they
would some time with a sharp egged tole prycke end kerue there own bodies and
make thereon diverse fygures and shappes and peynt hem with ynke or with other
peynture or color / and because they were so peyntede they were called picti
that is to say peynted. Erodotus Scotts ben light of heart and wind enough
/ but by medlynge of Englysshmen they ben much amended / they ben cruel upon
their enmyes and hates bondage most of any thing and hold for a foul
sloth if a man deye in his bed and great worship if he deye in the field.
They ben lytyl of mete and mow fast long / and eten selde when the son is
up / and eten flysshe fysshe milk and fruit more than bread and though they be
fair of chappe they ben defoulde and made unseemly enough with their own cloth
thing They praise fast ye vsages of their own for faders and dyspysen other
me^nes doing her land is fraytful enough in pasture gardyns and feldes. Gir.
de. p^. ca: xviii. The princes of Scotts as the king of Spain be^ not wont
to be enoynted ne crowed. In this Scotlond is sole^pne and great mind of saint
Andrewe thapostle: For saint Andrewe we had the north parties of ye world
Scites and Pyctes to his lot for to preche and convert the people to crystes
believe. And at last he was martred in Achaia in grecia in a cite yt was named
Patras and his bones were kept.CC.lxii. year unto year unto Co^sta^tynus
the^perours time. And then they were translated in to Constantynople and
kept there.C.x. year unto Theodosyus the^perours time and then Vngus king
of Pyctes in Scotlond destroyed a great part in Brytayne and was besette with
a great host of Brytons in a field called Mark. End he herd saint Andrew
speak to him in this manner. Vngus vngus here thou me Crystes appostle. I
promise the help and socour when thou haste ouercomen thyn enmyes by my help
/ thou shall give the third deele of thyn heritage in alms to god almighty
/ in the worship of saint Andrewe / and the sign of the cross were tofore his
host and the third day he had the vyctory and so turned home again and
deled his heritage as he was baden. And for he was uncertain what Cytee he
should deal for saint Andrewe he fasted three day / he and his men prayed
Saint Andrewe that he would show him whate place he should chese. And one of
the wardeyns that kept the body of saint Andrewe in Constantynople was warned
in his slepte that he should goo into a place whyder an angel would led him
and so he come in to Scotlonde with.vii. ^elowes to the top of an hylle
named Ragmonde. The same our light of heaven beshone and beclypped the king of
Pyctes that was coming with his hooste to a place called Carceuan. There anon
were held many seek men. There met with the king Regulus the monk of
Constantynople with the relyques of Saint Andrewe. There is founded a church
in worship of Saint Andrewe that is heed of all chyrches in the land of
Pyctes. Too this church comen pylgrymmes out of all londes^ There was
Regulus first abbote and gadred monks. And so all the (...) lord that the
King had assygne^ him he departed it in diverse places among abbayes.

Of the descrypcyon of Irlonde. Capitulo. xxii.
HAbernia that is Irlonde. and was of old time In corperate in to ye lordshyp
of Brytayne so says Gir. in sua pop^. where he decryueth it at fulle. yet it
is worthy and semely to praise that land with large praysynge for to come to
citt^ and fulle knowledge of that land these tytles yt follow open the way.
Therefore I shall tell of the place and stead of ye land how great and what
man^^^ land it is / whereof that land has ple^te and whereof it has defaute
/ also of whate me^ have dwelled therein first. Of manners of me^ of that land.
Of the wonders of that lord / and of worthynes of halowes and saints of that
land.

Of the boundynge of Irlonde Capitulo xxiii.
IRlonde is the last of all the weste ylo^dos and high Hybernia of one
Hyberus of Spain that was Hermonius brother / for these two brethern gate and
wanne that land by conquest. Or it is called Hybernia of that River Hyderus
that is the weste end of Spayn / and that land hyghte Scotlonde also / for
Scotts dwelled there sometime er they came into that other Scotlonde that
longed to Brytayne / therefore it is written in the Martyloge Such a day in
Scotlond saint Bryde was borne / and that was in Irlonde. This land has in
the southeest side Spain three days sayllynge thens aside half / and has in
the eest side the more Brytayn thens a days sayllynge / in the west side the
endless Occean and in the North side. yselonde three days sayllynge thens.
Solynus. but the sea that is between and Irlonde is all the year full of great
wawes and vnesy that men may selde ^ayle sekerly between that see is a.C. mile
broad.

Of the greenes and qualyte of that land. ca. xxiii.
IRlonde is an ylonde grettest after Brytayne / and stretched north ward from
Brendas hills unto the land Columbyna and conteyneth.viii. days Journey
every journey.xi. mile and from Deuelyn to Patryks hills and to the sea in
that side in broad.iiii. de^ thanne in the ends / all other wise thanne
Brytayne / is as Irlonde is shorter north ward than Brytayne / so is it longer
south ward the land is not plain but full of mountayns of hills of woods
of maryes and of moors the land is soft rayny wind and low by the sea side
and within hylly and sondye. Solinus. There is great plente of noble pasture
and of leese / therefore the beestes must be often driven out of their pasture
lest they eete over much for they should shend him self if theye might ete
at their will. Gir. Men of that land have communely their health. And
strangers have often a perylous flue by cause of the moisture of the mete. The
flesh of kyen is there wholesome / and swynes flesh vnholsome^ Men of that
land have no fever but oonly the fever ague and that right selde. Therefore
the holsomnes of that land and the clennes out of venyme is wroth all the
boste and richesse of trees herbs of spycery of rich clothes and of precious
stone of the Eest lands. The cause of the health and holsomnes of that land
is attemperate heete and cold that is therein. In quibus rebus sufficit. In
this land ben moo kyen thanne oxen / more pasture thanne corn / more gras
thanne seed / there is plente of Samon / of lamprays / of eeles and of see
fysshe. Of Egles / of carnes / of pecockes / of curlewes of sparouhaukes of
goshoukes / and of gentle fawcons. Of wulues and right shrewed myse there ben
attercoppes / blood souke^s eeftes that done none harm / there ben fayres
little of body and full hardy and strong / there ben barnacles fowls like to
wild ghees which grown wonderly upon trees / as it were nature wroughte
against kind. Men of relygyon ette the barnacles upon fastyngdayes by cause
they ben not engendered with flesh. wherein as men thinks they err for
reason is against that. For if a man had eten of Adams leg he had eten
flesh / and yet Adam was not engendered of fader nor mother / but that flesh
come wonderly of the tree. In this land is plente of honey and of milk of vine
and of veynerdes. Solinus and ysyder. written that Irlonde has no bees
Netheles it were better written that Irlonde had bees and no vyneyerdes. Beda
says that there is great hunting to roobuckes / and it is known that there
ben none. It is no wonder of Beda for he saw never that land but some man
told him such tales. Also there grows that stone Saxagonus. And is called
Iris also as it were the rayn bow if that stone be hold against the son^^
