anon it shall shape a raynbowe / there is also a stone that is called Gagates
and white margery perles.

Of the defautes of the londe^ Capitulo xxv.
WHere corns ben there full small vnne the yclenced with man's hand /
reserved men / all bestes ben smaller there thanne in other lands. There lackth
well nyghe all manner fysshe fresshe water that is not gendred in the sea
there lacken unkind faucons grefacons / per tryche fesauate / nyghtyngales /
and pyes / There lacken also Roo and bucke / and Ilesypyles wontes and other
venomous beestes. Therefore some men feynen and that favorably that Saint
Patryk cleansed that land of worms and of venomous beestes but it is more
probable and more skylfull that this land was from the beginning always
without suceh worms / for venomous beestes and wermes deyen there anon if
men bring them thither out of other lands. And also venym and poison
brought thither out of other lands lesen their malice as soon as it passes
the myddell of the sea. Also poudre and earth of that land cast and sown in
other lands driven away worms so ferfor that if a turfe of that land be put
aboutt a worm it sleeth him or makes him thryll that earth for tescape a way
In that land cocks crow bute little to fore day / so that the first
crowynge of cocks in that land and the third in other lands ben like far
totore the day.

Of them that first enhabyted Irlonde. ca. xxvi.
GIradus says that Casera Noes nece dradde the floode and fled with three
men and fyfty wymmen in to that ylonde and dwelled there in first the last year
tofore Noes floode. But after ward Bartholanus Seres sone that came of Iaphet
Noes sone came the there with his three sons by hap or craft.CCC. year after
Noers floode and dwelled there and encreaced to the nombre of.ix.M. men and
after ward for stenche of kareyns of gyauntes that they had kylde they
deyeden also save one Ruanus that lived a.M.v.C. year. unto saint Patryks time
/ and informed the holy man of the foresaid man and of all the doings and
deeds. Then the third time come thither Nymeth out of Scicia with his.iiii
sons and dwelled there.CC.xvi. year. and at last of his of spring by diverse
myshappes of wars and of morenyge they were clean destroyed and the land
left void.CC. year after they fourth time five dukes that were brethern
Gandius Genandus Sagandus Ruthe regus Slauius of the said Nymethes successors
come out of Greece and occupied that land and deled it in five parties / and
every party co^teyneth.xxii. ca^dredes. a Candrede is a country that
conteyneth a.C. towns and they set a stone in the myddel of ye lord as it
were in the navel and begynnyge of five king domes. At the last Saluius was
made king of all the land.

The fyfth time when this nacyon was xxx. year. together they wexe feeble.
Four noble men that were Millesius the kings sons come out of Spain with
many other in a navy of.xl. ships and two of ye worthyest of these iiii
brethern that heet Hyberus and Hermon deled the land between the^ tweyne / but
after ward covenant was broken between them both and Hiberus was slain Then
Hermon was king of all that land. And from his time to the first Patryks
time were kings of that nacyon.C.xxxi. And so fro the coming of Hybernensis ^
unto ye first Patryk were.M.viii.C. year. They had that name Hibernensys and
Hibernia of the for said Hiberus / or else of Hyberus a River of Spain. They
were called alsoo gatels and Scotts of one Gaytelus yt was Phenis neuewe.

This Gatelus could speak many langages / after the langages that were made
at Nemproths tower / And wedded one Scotra Pharoes daughter. Of these dukes
come the Hibernensis Men say that this Gatelus made the Irysshe langage and
called it Gaytelaf as it were a langage gagred of all langages and tongues. At
the last Belinus king of Brytayne had a sone and hight Gurguncius come out of
Donnemarke at ylondes Orcades He found men that were called Balclensis / and
were come theder out of spain / these me^ prayed and besught to have a place
to dwell in And the king sent them to Irlonde that was tho void and waste.
And ordained and sent with them duke and capytayns of his own and so it
seems that Irlonde should long to Brytayne by right of old time. From the
first saint Patryk unto Fedliundius the kings time.CCCC. year reigned.xxxiii.
kings eueryche after other in Irlonde^ In this Fedliundius time Turgesius duke
and capytayne of Norwayes brought theder men of Norwaye and occupied that land
and made in many places deep dyches and castles sengle double and tryble and
many wards strongly walled and many thereof stand yet all hole but Irysshmen
reche not of Castles / for they take woddes for castles and marayes and moors
for castle dyches but at ye last Turgesius deyed by gylefulles of women / and
Englysshmen said that Gurmundus wanne Irlonde and made thylke dyches / and made
no mencyon of Turgesius / and Irysshmen speak of Turgesius and know not of
Gurmu^das. Therefore it is write what gurmundus had won Brytayne and dwelled
therein / and sent Turgesius with great strenth in to Irlonde for to win that
land / and because Turgesius was Capytayne and leder of that vyage and Iurney
and seen among the^ therefore Irysshemen speak much of him as a noble man that
was seen in that land and known at the last when Gurmundus was slain in
France Turgesius loved the kings daughter of Irlonde and her fader behyghte
Turgesius that her world send her him to the low largeryn with.xv^ maidens
and Turgesius promised to mete there with.xv. of the nobleste men that he had /
and held couenaunte and brought no gyle but there came.xv. young berdeles me^
clothed like women with short swerdes under their clothes / and fill oon
Turgesius and slew him right there / and so he was traytoursly slain after he
had reigned.xxx. year Not long after.iii. brethren Almelanus Siracus and
Iuorus came into Irlonde with there men out of Norwaye as it had been for love of
peace and of marchaundyse and dwelled by these sides by assent of Irysshe men
that were always idle as Poules knights / and the Norwayes builded three cytees
Deueyn waterfore and Lymeryche and increased and after wexed rebel against men
of that land and brought first sparthes in to Irelonde So fro Turgesius
time unto roderykes time king of Connacia that was king of all the land
were.xvii. kings in Irlonde and so the kynnes that reigned in Irelonde from
the Hermons time unto the last time Roderyks were in all.C.lxxxi. kings that
were not crowned neither enoynted ne by law of heritage butte by night
maystrye and strenthe of arms The second Henry king of England made this
Roderyk subget ye year of king Henryes aege xl. and of his regne.xviii. the
year of our lord.xi. hundred ^lxxii:

Of the condycyons and manners of Irlonde. ca. xxvii.
SGlinus says that men of this land ben strange of nacyon houseles and great
fyghters / and acount right and wrong all one thing / and ben syngle of
clothing / scarce of mete / cruel of heart / angry or speech and drynketh
first blod of deed men that been slain and then wesshen their vysages therwyth
and holden them paid with flesh and fruit instead of mete and with milk instead of dr^nke and vsen much plain and ydlenes and hunting and trauaylle
butte little. In their child hode they ben hard nourysshed and ^erde fed and
they be unseemly of manners and of clothing and have brechee and hosen all ne
of wolle and strayte hodes that stre^cheth a cubyte over thesholders behind
and foldynges instead of mantels and of clokes. Also they use no sadels boots
ne spores wha^ they ride. but they drive their horses with a chambred yerede in
ye over end. Instead of byttes with trenches of brydels of reest / they use
brydels that let not their horse to ete there mete / they fight unarmed naked in
body / netheles with two darts and speres / And with broad spar^den they
fight with one hand.

These men forsaken tyllynge of Land and kepen pasture for beestes.
They use long berdes and locks hanging down behind there hedes ^ they use
no craft of flax / of wolle / of metal / ne of marchaundyse but give hem to
ydelnes and slouthe / and reken reest for liking and for fredome for riches /
And though Scotlonde the daughter of Irlonde use harp tymbre and to boure.
Netheles Irysshe men beconnynge in two manner Instruments musyke / in harp
and tymbre that is armed with were and strenges of bras In which Instruments
though^ (...) play hastily and swyftly they make ryhgt (...) ^onye and melodys
with thycke tewnes ^erbles and notes and begin from be mo^^ and playen
secretly under dyme sown in the great strenges and torn again unto the same /
so that the grettest party of craft hydeth the craft as it welde seem as
though the craft so should be ashamed if it were take These men ben of evil
maneres in there living they pay no tythynges the wedde lawfally / they spare
not their alyes / But brother wedde the broththers wife / they besye to betraye
her neighbors and other they bear sperthes in their hondes instead of staves
and fight ayenste them that trust most to them / these men ben variable
and unsteadfast threchours and gylefull whoo that deals with them needs more
to be ware of gyle thanne of craft of peace than of brennynge brondes / of honey
than of kynghthode / they have such maneres that they ben not strong in war
and in bataylle ne true in peace they become gossyps to them that they will
falsely betraye in the gossybrede and holy kynred Eueryche drynketh others
blood when it is shed / they love somd^l^ her nouryce and her playfers
which that souke the same milk that they souked while they were children. And
they pursewe there brethern their cosyns and their other kyne / and despysen
their kyne whiles they live / and avenge their death when they ben slain.
So long has the usage of evil custom endured among them that it has
gotenne the maystrye over them and torneth treason in to kind so ferforthe
that they ben traitors by nature. And alyens and men of strange lands that
dwell among them following their manners that vaunteh there is none but he is
be smetted with their treason aslo. Among them many men pyssen syttyge and
wymmen standing.

There ben many men in that land foul shapen in lymmes and in body / For in
their lymmes they lack the benefyce of kind So that no where ben better
shapen thanne they that been there well shapen and none worse shape^ than they
that been evil shapen. And skylfully nature hurt / and defouled by wyckednes
of living bring the such gromes and euylle ^penne of hem that with
vnlawfulle delyn^ ^yth foul manner and evil living so wyckedly defouled
kind and nature. In this land and wales old wives and wymme^ were wo^re and
been yet as me^ say often to escape the^s^^^ in lykees of hates for to milk
there neyghb^rs ^ine and stole her milk and often gr^y hou^des ren^ after the^
and pursewen the^ and weuen that they be hares Also some by craft of
Nygrama^cye (...) ^^tte swyne for to be reed of color and self the^ in
markettes and fayres But as soon as these swyne pass any water they torn
into their own kind whether it be straw hey gras of ^ues. But these swyne
may not be kept by no craft for te^dure in lykenes of swynes over three days
Among these wonders and other take heed that in the vttermest end of the
world falls new meruaylles and wonders. As though kind played with large
love secretly and far in thendes than openly and nygh in the myddeell.
therefore in this ylo^de be^ many gresely wonders and meruaylles.

Of the meruaylles and wonders of Irlonde. ca. xxviii.
MAny men tellen that in the north side of Irlonde is the land of life. In
that ylonde no man may deye but when they ben old and vexed with great
sykenes / they ben borne out in to the next land and deye there. There is an
other ylonde in Irlonde that no womman there in may bear a child / but yet she
may conceive. Also there is an ylonde in which no deed body may roten. In
vltonia that is Vlstre is an ylonde in a lake wo^derly departed in twene In
that one part is great dysturbaunce and dyscomforth of friends and in that
other party great lykyng and comforth of holy angels There is also saint
Patryks purgatory that was showed at his prayer to conferme his prechynge and
his lore when he preched to mysbyleued men of sorrow and pain that evil me^
sho^ suffer for there evil works. And of Joy and of bliss ye good men shall
receive for there holy deeds he tells that who that suffers the pains of
purgatory / if it be enjoined him for penance he shall never suffer the pains
of hell / but he deye finally withon repentance of sin / as the ensample. is
set more full at this chapter end. Treuisa. But truly noman may be saved
but if he be very repentance what someuer penance he do / and every man that
is very repentaunt as his lives end shall be sekerly saved / though^ he never
here of saint Patryks purgatory. There is an ylond in cona^te Sale / that is
in ye see of Conaccia hallowed by saint Brandon yt has no myse there deed
bodies ben not buried but be^ kept out of the earth and roten not. In Mamonia is
a well who yt wassheth him with that water of ye well he shall wax / hoar on
his heed There is an other well in Vltonia who someuer is wasshe^ therein he
shall never wexe hoar after ward / There is a well in Mounstre or Mamonia \
if any man touch that well anon shall fall great rain in all the prouy^ce
/ and that rain shall never cesse / till a priest that is a clean maiden
sing a mass in a chapel that is fast by and bless the water / and with
milk of a cow yt is of one her besprynge the well. and so reconcyle the
well in this staunge manner. At Glyndal can about the oratory of Saint Keywyn
wyches beryth apples as it were apple trees and ben moore wholesome than sauery.
That holy saint brought forth these apples by prayers for to hele his shylde
that was seek. There is a lake in Vlstre and much fysshe therein / which
is.xxx. mile in length and. in bread. The River Ban renneth out of that lake
into the north Occean and me^ say that this lake began^e in this manner.
There were men in that country that were of evil living coeuntes cu^brutis.
And there was a well in that land in great reverence of old time / And all
way covered / if it were left uncovered the well would rise and drowned all
the land. And so it happed that a wooman went to that well for to fetch
water and hyed her fast to her child yt wept in the cradell / and left the
well uncovered / then the well sprange so fast that is drowned the woman
and her child and made all the country a lake and a fysshe ponde. for to
preue that this is so there it is great argument / that when the weder is
clear / fysshers of that water see in the round under the water round toures
and high shapen as steples and chyrches of that land. In the north side of
Irlonde in the country of Ossyyryens every.vii. year at the prayer of an holy Abbot / tweyne that been wedded a man and a woman must needs be exyled and
forshapen in to lyknes of wolves and abide out.vii. year. And at end of.vii.
year. if they live they come home again / And take again their own shappe /
And than shall other tweyne goo forth in their stead and so forshapen for
other.vii. year. There is a lake in this land if a poole of tree pyghte and
stycked therein that part of the shafte or poole. That is in the earth shall
torn in to iron / And that par^e that abides in the water shall torn into
stone / And the part that abides above shall be tree in his own kind. Also
there is a lake that tornethe hasell in to asshe and asshe in to hasell if it
be done therein. Also in Irlonde ben three Samon lepes there as samons lepe
ayenste a Roche of long speres lenthe. Also in Leginia is a pound there ben
seen colmans birds. The berdes been called certelles and come homely to man's
hand but if men do him wrong or harm. They gone a way and come notte again
/ and the water there shall be bitter and stynke / and he that did the wrong
shall not a stert without wretch and myschyef but if he do amends. R. As
touching Patryks purgatory. ye shall understand Saint Patyrk that was
abbote and not bishop while he preached in Irlonde labored and studied for to
torn thylke wicked men that lived as beestes out other evil life for dread of
pains of hell / and for to conferme hem to good life and they said they
would not torn but some of them might know some what of the great pains and
also of the bless that he spoke of. Then saint Patryk prayed to god almighty
therefore / over lord Ihesu Christ appyered to saint Patryk and took him a
staff and ladde hy^ in to a wild place and showed him there a round pytte
that was derke within and said / that if a man were very repentance and
stable in believe and went into this pytte and walkede therein a day and a
night he should see the lorowes and the pains of evil men / and the Joy and
bliss of good men. Then Christ vanysshed out of patryks sight ^ and saint
Patryk arered and builded there a church and put therein chanons reguler and
^se the pytte about with a wall / and (...) in the church yerde at the eest
end (...) church and fast shette with a strong (...). For no man should
nycely goo in without (...) of the bishop or the poyour of the place. any
men went in and come out again in Patryks time and told of pains and Joy
th^^ they had seen / and the meruaylles that they saw been there yet written
/ and by cause there of many men turned and were converted to right believe. And
also many men went in ^ come never again. In king stephens time ^ynge of
England a kynght yt hight Owayne (...) saint Patryks purgatory and come again
and dwelled ever aft during his life i^ needs of thabbaye of Lude^sis yt is of
thordre Chystews and told many wo^dres yt he had see^ in Patryks
purgatory. That place is called Patryks purgatory / and ye church is named
Reglis No man is enjoined for to goo into ye purgatory. But cou^seylled yt he
should not come therein butte take upon him other penance And if a man have
auowed and bestale and will needs goo therein He shall first go to ye bishop
and then he shall be se^te with letters to the pryoure of the place and they
both shall cou^ceylle him to leave and if he will needs go thereto he shall be
in prayers and in fasting xv. days and after xv. days he shall be how seld
and led to ye door of the purgatory with processyon and letany and yet he
shall be cou^seylled to leave it / and if he be stedefaste and will enter / the
door shall be opened and he blessed and goo in a gods name and hold forth
his way / and the door shall be shytte tylle ye next day / and wha^ the time
is the pryoure shall come and opene ye door. and if the man be come^ he
ledethe him in to ye church with processyo^ and there he shall be fyftene
days in prayers and fasting.

Of the meruaylles of saints of Irlonde. ca. xxix.
HEre Gyraldus makes mind yt as me^ of this nacyon be^ more angrye / than
other me^ and more hasty for to take wretch whiles they be^ alive / so saints
and halowes of this land ben more wretchefull than saints of other lands
Clerks of this lord be^ chaste and saye^ many prays and done great
abstyne^ce a day / and drynketh all night so is afou^ted for a miracle / ye
lechery regneth not there as wine regneth / and ben chosen out of abbayes into
the clergy / and done as monks should / whate they yt be^ evil of the^ be^
worste of al other. So good me^ among them though they be^ but few been
good at ye best / prelates of that country be^ full slow in correccyo^ of
trespass / and besy in contemplacyn and notte in prechynge of gods word
Therefore it is yt all the Saints of ye land been co^fessours and no martyrs
among the^ / and no wonder / for all ye prelates of this land clerks and
prelates should do as to the^ unknown. Therefore wha^ it was put aye^ste ye
bishop of Cassyl how it might be yt so many saints be^ in Irlonde and
never a martyr among them all sythen that ye me^ ben so shrewed and so angry
/ and the prelates so rycheles and sl^we in correccyons of trespass. The bishop
answered frowardely enough and said our men be^ shrewed and angry enough to
themself but to gods servants they leye never hand but do he^ great
reverence and worship But Englyssh me^ come into this land that ca^ make
martyrs and were wont to use ye craft. R. The bishop said so because ye king
Henry ye second was to new come^ into Irlonde frensshly after ye martyrdom
of saint Thomas of canterbury Gir. In this lord in wales and in Scotlond. be^
belles and staves with crooked hedes and other such things for relyques in
great reverence and worship / So ye me^ of this lord dreden more for to
swear upon one of thylke belles and gold staves tha^ upon ye gospel. the
chyfe of all such relyques is holde^ Ihu^s staff yt is at Deuelyn. with yt
which staff they say yt the first saint Patryke drofe ye worms out of
Irlo^de Augus. de. ci^ dei. ca. vii. if me^ axe how it may be that diverse
manner of beestes and of diverse kind that be kyndly gote^ bitwene mayl and
female come and be^ in ylo^des after Noes flode Me^ suppose^ that such bestes
swa^me into ylo^des about and first to the next and so for forth into
other. Or else me^ sayllynge into ylondes brought with he^ such beestes for
love of hu^tynge / or angels that god almyghtes commandment brought such
bestes into ylo^des about or ye earth brought the^ for ye first and fulfilled
tho gods co^mau^deme^te \ ye co^maun: ded ye earth to bring forth gras and
quick bestes

Here ends ye descrypcyo^ of Brytayne / the which contained England wales
and Scotlonde And also because Irlo^de is vnd ye rule of England and of old
time it has so co^tynued Therefore I have set ye descrypcyo^ of the same aft
ye said Brytayne. which I have taken out of Poly cronycon. and also enprynted
by one sometime sco^e master of saint / Albons upon whose soul god have mercy
Amen.

Enprynted at London in powlys church yard at the west door of powly^ beside
my lord of londons palace by me Iulyan Notary In the year of our lord
god.M.CCCCC.xv.
